reviews.review: Impressive. Very impressive especially if one considers the history. Well worth a visit and then going forth to visit the Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace.

Nice place. I visited this mausoleum and its solemn atmosphere is so special. Everyone automatically keeps silent walking around the place where they display the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh President.
From October to December, you may not be able to come inside due to the maintenance. Walking around and seeing the flag hoisting are cool too.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum for honoring the national hero: President Ho. Entrance: FreeHours: 8AM-11AM, exc Mon&FriThe building looks well maintained, neat, clean. Preferably early visiting and bring an umbrella or hat , because of long queue and hot weather. Very huge area around the museum and. wheelchair is not available. There is a souvenir shop in the area but the price relative more expensiveVisiting the Mausoleum is free of charge but a lot of strictly regulations. No short skirts or tank tops are allowed and there is high level of security check upon arrival. Day packs can be put in a safe deposit before you enter. Taking photos, talking are strictly prohibited inside the mausoleums.
Huge. Had an interesting day exploring this place and found it to be fascinating. Our guide was excellent and explained it to great detail making it much more interesting and personal.

Espectacular !. First I would like to tell you to go early casue the atracción close around 1 or 2 pm, they are very organized and even if you see a long line they pass very quick, cameras has to be left in the entrance in the beginning as not photos are allow inside of the mausoleum, when Ho chi Min is , you can pick them up right after and make photos of the beautiful surroundings, the presidential house , the summer house , the beautiful gardens is all really well preserve and beautiful, if it s summer you really want to be there before 11 am as is very hot and even if they are quiosk to buy water inside and souvenirs they are far apart. Is a Must! Defenelly in Hanoi, and the museum is really interesting give it a try is very modern, and explain where he has been in the world , I found My country and I was amazed he has been there , he travels a lot and his people loves him. I put here some photos of the museum, a great experience for children as well as is ultra modern and very very visual. Enjoy your visit, is worth every penny you pay , the entrance of the museum as the normal atracciones are 40 Vietnamese dongs the entrance of the mausoleum is around 70.
Impressive . Impressive building, permanently guarded - looks more interesting at night when illuminated.Pity not to be able to go inside though.
An important site. A must monument to visit. Yet be aware that during the months of Oct to Dec, you can not access the place but only to see it from the outside
A must seeq. Get here early and watch the flag raising. Such an amazing historical place and well worth a look. Must beat the crowds through

Walk around. The Mausoleum was shut for repairs and maintenance when we visited. I believe this lasts until December, so plan accordingly. However, one gets a good enough view of the structure from the street itself.
Impressive. The solemnity of this monument is obvious, with soldiers mounting guards, and a general hush about this area. The significance of this Mausoleum is easy to see.
well worth a visit. we couldnt actually go into the mausoleum,as only dignitaries are allowed to go in,but we learned about the history and the man himself,which was very interesting

Reverence and cleanliness at this Mausoleum is high. Worth a visit when in Hanoi. Not sure of entrance fee as we did a tour of many places and this Mausoleum was one. The gardens that surround are beautiful and relaxing. When inside the Mausoleum, the reverence and cleanliness is high and we found we were kept on the move, no time to stop and reflect, we had to keep walking so the time spent inside Mausoleum is very short.

Closed for maintenance. We could not get near the building although it seemed quite impressive. As well as it being closed we could not get too close as the Phillipines president was visiting the nearby palace and security was in force.
Popular location. This was created against Ho Chi Minh's wishes but is an area for people to remember him. The houses next door were more interesting.

A great Leaders Mausoleum. A good useful insight into the life and works of Vietnam great leader Ho Chi Minh. Not really a great place to be if you are not a History enthusiast. However I would like to add that this museum is not a glorifying account of Uncle HO as he is popularly know in Vietnam nor has it got to do anything specifically about communism.
Impressive. Really worth visiting. Memorial to a great Vietnamese patriot and the sense of reverence is strong. Important part of Vietnamese history.
Impressive . Impressive to visit, not open every day so make sure to check opening times. There can also be a waiting time to get in.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Interesting to see, but we did not get to enter the mausoleum because the body was in Russia for its annual "touch up"
Closed during October 2016. Exhibit closed. But the surrounding complex and museum are open, well worth a look. 100,000 per adult

Closed . Was closed 13th October but still worth having a look at the outside. If you're planning to have a look at the palace, stilt house and museum make sure you enter to the right of the mausoleum... We made the mistake of going left to the museum first and then had to walk all the way back around the front to go to the stilt house
Excellent. Excellent. Highly recommended. However Ho Chi Minh was in Russia for refurbishment. Botanical Garden was fantastic and we got to see the Presidential Palace and his old living quarters.
Good for picture. This huge building is good to take picture and put it on your facebook and saying "I am in Vietnam" that's all

Very honorable place for a very honorable person.. This was a very somber experience. The Vietnamese people show their respect for this man in very large numbers. I waited in line for 2 hours to view his body.

Nice walk, outdoors, no mausoleum until dec.. It was a nice outdoor walk around Ho Chi Minhs old property, see his old cars, etc..problem is it is nowhere stated that you cannot view the mausoleum from Sept thru December 2016 for 'renovation.'

Truly Amazing. The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum was amazing. The walk into the building and around the presidents body in sheer silence was an amazing experience and something I would do again. I would definitely recommend people to go and see it.

worth the wait to get in. It is a very formal place. One has to wait quite a while outside to get in. Once inside you are asked to be silent while passing through the viewing room. Never been to a mausoleum before, so this was a new experience. Well worth it, if only to see how much his country loved and respected him in making this magnificent mausoleum.
History. Great place to go to learn about the History of Vietnam.Great location & easy to read (English) information.

A must see . Impressive size and design. You really have to see this, even if you just walk past. Its most likely a long walk for most people, so get a taxi for an affordable price. You could always just walk the one way back and stop at a nice restaurant or bar

Part of History. When in Vietnam, Uncle Ho is a prominent feature. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a grand building that houses his remains. Unfortunately for me , the timing of my trip coincided with the annual maintenance of his remains which is circa Sept - Oct every year. So if you have in mind to view his remains, do check the schedule. I was told that the front of the mausoleum is the parade area for National day celebration. Well it would have been grand. Keeping it in my next to do list when I return to Hanoi .

Magnificent. The whole structure looks so much better in person than in photos. One of the finest looking building i ever seen.There is a huge huge huge parade square directly in front of it. And next to the parade square is a huge psych of grass. Many newly weds and ladies wearing Vietnamese traditional attire were having photoshoots in the parade square and grass patch. Directly opposite this hcm monument, across the parade square and grass patch is another very superb looking building but i have no idea what's that.

restoration season. during this time of the year the mosseloum is closed as they are doing restoration work. you can only go around the mosseloum and take pic. it is pretty hot and humid in the afternoon around the mossleum.

The highlight of it all. This is one of the most important tours if your in Hanoi. Although I visited at a time when Uncle Ho was having his own hibernation, and all we could see is the outside of the mausoleum, his house and just the sight of the Presidential Palace, it's still worth it.

Historical Buidling. Very nice view for photoshooting. But better to go at sunset hour, as very hot. Weekends was closed and only can walk around at outside the building. To enter the museum, have to wear proper as per respect for their culture.
Another Nationalist lies in state. I guess everyone needs to go but really not my cup of tea. Lines area long and tightly controlled by the Gov. The atmosphere is repressive

Historical place. Quite sad they are fixing these days I only can visit outside. It ứa hot. But still fine. Just consider as one of my exercise after hard working day in front of desktop at workingplace

just outside the masoluem . we were just able to look and take pictures from the outside since that day when we have a tour, it was a saturday and all the locals were there to pay a visit to HCM which they consider their "uncle". so there was a long long line if you wanna get inside and they were only open half day on saturdays.

Walking. tour. The mausoleum is accesses by walking it is one way walk through the life and times of Ho Chi Minh, through the grounds around lakes and wander the gardens. If it is hot it can be taxing so allow plenty of time, it is worth the visit.
Trip. Nice to experience the massive building. There are not any information signs, so be prepared if you want to learn something.

Tourism . It seems it's a must see when in Hanoi. Long que and you have to be very patient. Best time to visit is towards the end of the visiting hours. Ho Chi Minh is very well preserved and well respected.

Ticked the list. Spending the afternoon touring around the Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace and Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum located in the center of Ba Dinh Square. 下車參觀巴亭廣場，它位於市中心，還劍湖西北，廣場長320米，寬近100米，可容納120,000人，是河內人民集會和節日作用中的場所。我們又參觀總督府又名主席府。建於1906年的黃色法式建築，原是殖民時期印度支那的總督府，為胡志明主席處理國政之處。

Solemn. From the outside it looks like a very solemn place, heavily guarded. I know it represents a lot for the Vietnamese people and I would say it is worth a visit. Nothing breath taking about it. Unfortunatelly I haven't had the chance to go inside as the place is only open in the morning. Nonetheless, you should give it a try as it is one of the most important things to see in Hanoi.
Hanoi Centerpiece. I am pleased to see that Vietnam is one country now and the people are just getting on with life. This place signifies the unity that prevails now.
Not an afternoon visit . The mausoleum is only open from 7-10am which makes a visit in the afternoon a little morning as you only get to see the exterior of the heavily guarded mausoleum.

Unable to go into the mausoleum. The main attraction of the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is being able to enter the mausoleum and see the preserved body of the founder of Vietnam Ho Chi Minh. However, during the period we were there, they were doing some restoration to the body. As such, being unable see the body was a great disappointment to all of us. We however manage to witness the changing of the guards.So importantly before visiting the mausoleum, do check whether it is open or not. Or you will be left disappointed.

Skip it if you can.. This tour is part of the mandatory sites that the Vietnamese tour guide take you. But it is to show who is Ho Ci Main and who he live, it was as always a hot day and we walk a lot in the sun hear some stores about Ho Ci Main and it was waist of time. Skip this tour if you can.

interesting. Really interesting visit. A little strange to see someone lying there preserved but interesting non the less. Be careful to visit during a time when the body is actually there and not gone to Russia for restorations.

Beautiful Escape. Unfortunately the actual mausoleum was closed when I went but I got to see the changing of the guards which was very simple but cool to check out. I toured the grounds in about an hour. The trees, birds and pond created and wonderful environment, and the cool temperature was a relief from the city heat. It was neat to see where Ho Chi Minh lived and hosted his guests. Important to Vietnamese history and worth an hour of your visit to Hanoi.

When in Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh, or his embalmed body, was in residence in the monumental structure where it is housed. We were part of a group and were given priority entrance. Long lines of uniformed smiling grammar school children were lined up beside us and could anticipate a very long wait. A cottage in which Ho resided is also on the grounds.
Visitors . I loved it. I hope everyone loves it as much as I did. Lots to do nd plenty to see all in all was a good

Great Experience. Uncle Ho was a true socialist. It is a pity he did not survive post Vietnam American war. His Mausoleum is certainly a place to visit. Do not worry if there are large crowds in a line .It moves quickly. His body can be observed there.
Saw the change of guards. Did not get a chance to pay respect to Mr. Ho's as his body was in Russia for maintenance. We did visit the compound, seeing the house and garden. Quite crowded.

Astounding. The whole site is fascinating - from Uncle Hos house to the mausoleum itself. Many Vietnamese ladies, in full national dress, make pilgrimages here, and it is delightful to see them all. The site itself is a peaceful retreat from the busy streets of Hanoi, and is quiet and spacious.

INSPIRATION OF A NATION. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a rallying point for a people and an inspiration for patriotism for a nation.
I discovered a people united and ready to forge a ahead together because of the figure considered as the founder of modern day Vietnam.

You can't visit Hanoi without visiting Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Be prepared to queue, but after you have been past the embalmed body of Uncle Ho you get to visit the grounds and see where he did a lot of his work, worth the queues

Worth a visit as it is quite an impressive monument to Uncle Ho. We took a taxi ride to the monument and walked into the grounds. There were a number of tourists around all taking photos individually and in groups. There were soldiers dressed in smart white uniforms standing at attention very much like the Buckingham palace lot do. There is a changing of the guard every half hour so that can be interesting to watch. There is a red line about 25 metres from the stairs to the musaleam. Do not cross the red line!!! Some girls went over the line just to mess with the soldiers and they politely but firmly motioned them backWe could not go in as it was closed for some reason. Not sure I would have gone in as its not my thing to view embalmed bodies but many people might want to and do.It's a nice outdoor activity and one of those tourist tick the box locations. I was glad I went, does not cost anything, and now I can say I was there ;-) I've got the photos, wrote this review and now I'm moving on.Be careful of the taxi drivers. We got ripped off by one in a green taxi. After we had travelled 200 metres, he reset the meter to 200 000 dong. Said it was a different rate that time of the day which was BS*. Then his meter spun as if he had won the Vegas lottery except it was a drain hole for my wallet if you get what I mean. It cost me 500 000 dong ($30 NZD) for a 5km ride which should have been around 30000 dong. All Vietnamese taxi drivers can thank this guy for the fact that the other twenty taxi rides I went on in Vietnam were then all with Vinasun taxi services, who are trustworthy and consistent.
Good to see . This is an amazing building. We also seen the changing of the guard. It is closed for viewing from October to November and therefore dress code is not necessary.

Visit to the Mausoleum. A bit disappointing that we were not able to enter - the place was guarded because of all the Independence Day preparations which were beginning 2 days later. Lots of activity from local gardeners making sure everything was looking spotless and beautiful and we did get some photo's from the outside.

Must do but be prepared to line up!. Craziest day- decided to walk here and that perhaps was not the best choice because the entry is not where you expect it to be. The most organised and rule driven experience ever in Vietnam but amazing to see the reverence with which they hold Uncle Ho!

get ready for lots of controls. Getting to Mausoleum is not so easy and very much time consuming. So get ready that you will have to leave everything before getting there and lines are long even from early morning. the visit itself is super short as you must follow the crowd.

Closed during different periods on the year . For me it was great to see a communist monument like this! In the middle of Hanoi, I highly recommend a short visit, do keep n mind it is closed at some point every year !
great . not a lot to say explorer yourself no more words to say just do it this 😅100 words are silly easy go any where
Interesting. we could not go inside the mausoleum but we still loved it. The complex is big and good just to walk around, but it is nice if you have a local guide to tell you some things.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. This is a very impressive Tomb of the famous Ho Chi Minh. Unfortunately we couldnt enter,as it was closed. We witnessed the changing of the guard,which was very impressive !! Apparently,you can see Uncle Ho's body in his coffin when inside.He is a very well respected Figure Head in Vietnam,as he did a huge amount of good for his People and was one of the Worlds Greatest Leaders of his time. You can feel his presence everywhere in Vietnam.

Important part of the cultural history. We managed to get there with almost no waiting time which probably helped the experience. A great introduction into the symbol that HCM represented to the people and how he continues to be honored. Very well done
amazing place. We visited Ho chi Minh palace a few months ago. It was an amazing experience visiting my hometown with my boyfriend. The place reminded me of Vietnamese history and traditions.

A taxi ride away. You don't have to sign up for the mandatory organised tours to visit this place. Very spacious and cool at night with lots of local folks. This place is family friendly and good for couples. Did not enter the mausoleum and it's still worth the visit. I believe it is more beautiful at night due to the external flood lights.
We love a good Mausoleum. As mausoleums go this one is pretty good. It was being refurbished when we were there so we could not get inside. Still worth a visit though!

Fantastic experience and a highlight of our trip. I agree with other reviews that say it is "a must see to appreciate".It was incredibly hot the day we went and you walk for quite a while underneath sheltered verandah's until you finally reach the mausoleum. It is so cool and peaceful and you automatically feel like you are in a very revered place where the utmost respect comes naturally within the quiet surroundings. Ho Chi Minh lays beautifully 'sleeping" and he looks perfect. Absolutely worth the effort. Trouble is when you leave the mausoleum you have to walk through al the palace gardens to get out. On a very hot day this was not very pleasant but if it was cooler I would have appreciated it more. The one pillar pagoda is nearby and good for some nice photo opportunities. Make sure you check the website for opening times for the Mausoleum and the strict rules re clothing and no photos.
Must see. After our visit here we had a greater understanding of tbe hustory of vietnam. Spend time just wandering snd taking in all the history

The highlight of my experience in Hanoi.. The most priceless and memorable experience ever. I visited the place on the day after the independence day, the queue was long but it was worth it. The place overalls the rich history of Vietnam and its people, the struggle and the triumphs in the journey of their lives. Ho Chi Minh is a man of honour and paying my respects to him, really humbled me.

Must see to appreciate. It is a great place to understand the history and the great man behind Vietnam's grand stories and independence. Unfortunately when we were there, the location was under renovation and we were unable to enter. Still, it was a good experience just standing outside of the mausoleum listening to the guide explain to us on the details.Definitely a must see location for you to appreciate. We will definitely visit again if we return to Hanoi as we did not manage to enter the location this time.
Interesting. Unfortunately we were unable to go in as it was closed. However the Mausoleum is definately a place to visit if you ever find yourself in Hanoi. A great part of Vietnamese history.

Interesting and essential part of Vietnam visit. Probably a mandatory part of our organised tour of Vietnam it was a very interesting experience, helping us appreciate a central part of the culture. Joining the queue relatively early in the morning it took us about 45 minutes to reach the mausoleum. Outside it is a piece of classical communist architecture; the interior is really very simple but we felt created the right, somber atmosphere very effectively, leading up to the experience of seeing such a significant figure of c20 history. Very pleased to have had this visit included in our tour.
Amazing to See. What a place of history to visit and see.It was a fairly long walk from the Old Quarter so catch a taxi or rickshaw if you can't or don't want to walk in the heat.

Just to watch some "important stone" for Vietnam History. It is a must to see place so you can understand better the local feeling fot this symbol man! It s a very simple mausoleum with a clear russian background!

Don't cross the yellow line. A large area marked bu a yellow line near the mausoleum that you aren't allowed to cross. Security everywhere. The Mausoleum is closed for 3 months September to November as they send his body to Russia to be reembalmed. The gardens and royal palace are lovely. You also see the houses that he lived in and if you have a guide you will hear the history of his life. Very crowded with tourists.
Interesting and intriguing visit. Was indeed and interesting visit and to be able to make the trip there. Appreciated the history behind this tour.

Check opening hours. Beware this place is closed on Fridays and the weekends and is only opened in the morning on other days. I didn't get to go in but it was nice walking around the complex to see some of the communist structures of Hanoi.

no 1 place to visit in Hanoi. a historical site ,for the young to learn their fore fore fathers n those who help n sacrifice themselves and brought the country to independence.It is a holy attraction n for people who pay respects n remember.The old residence of great Ho Chi Minh n the compound the garden n the ancient architecture are the site for local n foreigners to see themselves .Not forgetting the tour guides to explain n tell the histories.

Currently closed due to maintenance. Nice, but nothing special from outside. . We knew that the mausoleum itself was closed for some months due to maintenance but decided to go anyways and see it from outside. To be honest it was little spectacular. It's a nice building and the closed, very broad road in front is a nice break from the traffic, but else it's not that special. Ok to take some pictures, but if in a hurry in Hanoi, definitely not my recommendation. Rather take some time to visit the adjacent President palace. Much more worth the time.

Uncle Ho, An Interesting and Visionary Man. No trip to Hanoi is complete unless you visit the three sites. Start with the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum then walk to your right to the Palace and Ho Chi Minh Houses, it is a one way walk so see everything then move on because it is difficult to go back again. Exit and walk onto the museum. Spend a little time reading about his life and travels.
Take a cycle-rickshaw. You can't go in, so you would only go to take photos, but it's an easy cycle-richshaw ride from the old quarter. Highly recommend taking this there as its fun!
Very Interesting. we really enjoyed the experience but found the security quite strange and heavy, it is set in huge grounds right in the centre

Significant Location for History Buffs. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a significant location for those interested in Vietnamese history. Personally, even if you're not into the history, it's still worth a visit knowing how one man can massively impact the country. The place is patrolled and there's a yellow line that won't let you in closer to the site. Two guards in white stand still outside and another blows his whistle for those crossing the yellow line or I guess standing too long near the building.

A must see. I was taken there with a Vietnamese person.Go there in the evening for the ritual. The lowering of the Vietnamese flag at 21.00 hours every day.You will see a amazing display of respect for the great leader Ho Chi Minh.A true testament to a great Man.Wort a visit.
Uncle Ho. He was died many years a go, but he still living in my mind for ever and ever ! Guy !you should come and see him !i was crying so much a bout our difficult during the war before .

It is the highlight of town but..... The fussiness of the guards around the tomb and its Hitlerian arrogance of construction make it amusing. Check out the charming Buddhist temple beside the museum (often closed).

The Man Who Changed the Country. Visiting Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum gave me a sense of appreciation for the Vietnamese people and their accomplishments. Ho Chi Minh is the father of the land so it was great to see the Mausoleum.
Hanoi city tour. Historical, clean, big garden with pond & fishes, many flowers & fruits plants, well preserved place for next generation & generation.

Good to see in passing. It's a must see item in Vietnam due to the history of Ho Chi Minh. He founded the country and is on all of the Vietnamese currency. You can't however go anywhere near the site. It's not accessible for tourists or civilians. So visit it on the way to something else.
Well worth a visit. A fascinating place to visit - see Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body and learn something about the pride the Vietnamese have in their achievements

Impressive. This is a very impressing and imposing structure. The changing of the guard is held on the hour. Try and time your visit.The disappointment is as our guide said "Ho Chi Minh is on vacation". Apparently his body is sent "somewhere to be refurbished every year. I don't know if there is a schedule when he is not available for viewing.

Paing Homage to Uncle Ho.. Whatever your political persuasion, one would think that every visitor to Hanoi would like to catch a glimpse of the man who shaped Vietnam's destiny. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is evidence of the esteem that the people of Vietnam hold this Great person in, as he lies in-state, superbly preserved. As a monument, it is simple, beautiful and immaculately maintained.

The resting place of 1st Vietnamese President Ho Chi Minh. A tourist spot for sight seeing. It was most unfortunate that we were not allowed in during our visit as the body of Ho Chi Minh was sent to Russia for restoration. We saw the changed of guards. It was a pleasant Mausoleum

Uncle Ho looks in pretty good shape. The embalmers have done a good job, although armed guards are on hand to make sure you don't loiter or take photographs. You're in and out of the actual tomb in about 15 seconds, hardly long enough to take advantage of the hugely welcome air-conditioning (after queuing for up to 20 minutes in the ferocious heat). Then you're expelled out in to the glare of the sun, wondering where the nearest bar is.
If you are willing to wait in the heat. We were there in the middle of June. It was so hot and so many people waiting in line to go inside. So we opted out for walking around outside.
Came at the wrong time.... . Came at the time when it is closed for maintenance. Managed to catch the mini guard changing ceremony. Still good to take a good look of the place.

Fascinating insight into the history of Vietnam's Uncle Ho. Ho Ch Minh's story is shared with great reverence and the lasting impact he has had on Vietnam and its people is one we all found interesting. Must see for anyone visiting Hanoi

Closed for 3 months. When we went on 7 sept, it was closed. The guard explained that it will be closed for 3 months. So do check if it is open before you visit. However, Ho Chi Minh museum and residence is still open for visit.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum . It is free for visiting, you have to walk a long way to see something interesting. It it also a holly place so be careful your clothes and your behaviour. It will be so crowded so should go in the early morning

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. . We were not permitted to enter the Mausoleum as it was being renovated.
Large crowds were present there even though it was closed.
It is an impressive looking building
Worth seeing. Worth seeing on your trip to Hanoi. The location nearby is also interesting to walk around. We were not able to go inside, but it did say that it was open for special viewings.
Sort of interesting. Good to have a quick look around, really reinforced how revered uncle Ho still is. Was not really that insightful if you have the time worth a look gardens are nice.

Halong Bay and Tam Coc. You msut visit Halong Bay as it one of the main attraction of Hanoi. Please visit Halong Bay and enjoy its unique beauty and cruise around the limestone hills/islands as it is one of the best places which mather nature can offer us. Really beautiful and captivating. See Tam Coc and be mesmerised by the way the paddle the boats using their feet only to paddle and take us around Tam Coc which is 7 km to and fro.

HCM Mausoleum. It was guarded, more to be seen in order to explain the history of Ho Chi Minh and how communisim was introduced into Vietnam. The buiding itself is guarded, strict dress code of below knees and shoulders covered. One of those places you have to go see in order to tick off your list.

Closed on Mondays.... Only rating this a 3 because we couldn't go inside as it was closed on Monday when we went. (We knew it would be closed but still thought it would be good to see it.) we took a 15min rickshaw ride from the old quarter (paid 100,000dong total for the 2 of us, about$4 USD), and it took us about 45min to walk back. Make sure you bring a map instead of trying to navigate your way back from memory like we did (it sound have taken about 30min had we known where we were going.) The building itself is impressive and the grounds in front are quite nicely manicured, but that is all we know.Pretty boring and not really worth going if it will be closed.

Walk about. . See the great mausoleum of the leader. Funnily enough he wanted to be cremated. The people parliament is there and the presidential palace. You can feel the French influenced architecture sitting next to communist Stalin influenced structures.

Fascinating monument. To be clear, we didn't actually see the body, as it was in Russia being re-embalmed. That was too bad, but the entire complex is a fascinating and different look at Vietnamese history. Loved walking around and seeing all the guards, and very nice coffee shops in the area.

To those that like to learn history of the other side. Very interesing biased view on the 20th century and the evolution of this country. Those that understand that life has more than one way to look at will greatly enjoy it

Moving, interesting and unique in equal measure. If you are prepared to get up early to queue, to endure the white-coated guards blowing whistles at you for stepping out of line, and the sticky heat from so many bodies in the queue, then this is a brilliant experience. One of our highlights in Hanoi for sure. There is copious security and you have to walk right round the back of the building to find the end of the queue but to be fair it moves pretty fast, and the actual mausoleum building is heavily air conned. They instruct you to keep walking round the body at all times which means you can't really stop and look, but nonetheless the general atmosphere is amazing. Ho Chi Minh is very visible and lit up. Really reverent and stunning experience. Be respectful, cover up and don't put your hands in your pockets. I hope this tradition continues because it is very educating of Vietnamese culture even today.
It was closed . We walked around Hanoi with the view to visiting the mausoleum. However, When we found it, It was closed...it was still an interesting walk around the area though.

Surreal experience. You genuinely won't get an experience like this again. You walk in silence, in freezing cold, round an embalmed body surrounded by security. There isn't a whole lot of information on him which is a little disappointing, but I would still recommend it.

Very interesting, but closed. The mausoleum itself is really interesting, and gigantic! Beautiful place to walk around and take pictures. BUT, we couldn't enter, as the tomb was closed for the months of September and October. Very disappointing. We were unsure if this was an annual closing or just temporary for renovations. The gardens and grounds are still open, tickets were 40,000 Vietnamese dong. We weren't that interested in that attraction so we didn't feel it was worth the entrance fee. Just be sure to do as much research as you can so you don't end up in the same boat we were in.

Go early to queue. As expected the queues are long - bags had to be deposited at a bag drop which was no problem but retrieving it was not as easy. There were no directions back to the bag drop and we were told to go in all directions on completion of visit.The soldiers in stark white uniforms were entertaining when marching - otherwise filing through took a couple of minutes and that was it.
Closed for remodel. We were only allowed to see from outside in the front as it is closed for remodel. Guards are very strict about not getting too close, understandably.

Interesting 2 hours understanding a great leader. We went on a national holiday and the queue was long and snaking (about an hour). Nevertheless lining up was enjoyable doing people watching - families, shool groups, soldiers, couples, tourists... etc.

Uncle Ho looked pretty good. Visited the mausoleum as part of a city tour and we all agreed that it was a highlight. An interesting piece of Soviet architecture and probably the most vivid reminder that Vietnam is still a communist country. The gardens and his living quarters were also quite neat to see.

Grotesque and bizarre to the Western observer.... ... But your Vietnamese hosts take this place very, very seriously indeed, and you'd better follow the rules and be respectful too. Bare shoulders and mid-riffs are not allowed. Food and drink - even water-bottles inside your bag - are not allowed. Cameras are forbidden and must be surrendered at the entrance and collected after your 'viewing'. An airport-style security check is required, and there are guards everywhere. Inside the mausoleum itself is the coldest place in Viet Nam, and Uncle Ho appears peacefully at rest, albeit in a rather waxy state these-days. So get your hands out of your pockets, take your sunglasses off the top of your head, and make a pilgrimage to pay homage to the man who the Vietnamese revere so highly.

Nice for a rainy day. A bit surprised to see the dead body of Ho Chi Minh in the mausoleum we didn't consult our guidebook before. It's a crazy idea to put a body in a glass box, but it's kind of honourful as well. We went in a bit too late (11 am) and the place closes at 12, so we couldn't see everything, go early ;)
It looks impressive.. The whole area around is magnificent. Unfortunately, I came on the day when mausoleum was not open, but roaming around it really made my day. All recommendations for this place.
Uncle Ho wasn't in that day. We visited the museum but the mausoleum was closed. That was a little disappointing. Easy to get to by cab and the most empty place in all Vietnam.

Baggage issue. We visited here on the day before we were going to leave Vietnam and we got to the front about 30 minutes before they closed. I couldn't take my backpack in with me but the ladies at the bag check said we needed to hurry as they will close the doors and leave if we are not back before they close. I believe it was promptly at 11am. I was worried as they were closed the next day and we flew out that afternoon so I didn't go in and let my husband and daughter go. I was a little annoyed as they should have this bag check open 10 minutes longer than when they close so people have time to collect their things. I could tell these ladies wouldn't give any exceptions so too risky for me to attempt it. It turned out there was plenty of time but still if you can't take your belongings with you, they should be open for you to collect them!

Not always open. Closed on Mondays and the actual body may or may not be on view! The residence and gardens are quite interestingly modest for a world leader, and the big parade ground around the mausoleum interestingly grand and very soviet. Gives very limited insight on the man or the regime.
Mausoleum. Very interesting history. Well organised trip. I found that Hanoi was well worth the visit. I had heard so much about it.

Respect. I give this 5 stars for respect. however as a tourist if you want to visit this place, be noted you may need to stand a long time in a line and in the heat. They now upgraded it with a roof to stand under in the line. However expect alot of chinese tourists, etc. This is not a place to write negative review, its a place of respect, hope all tourist understand and pay respect when visiting.

Very interesting Mausoleum. You line up and must be very quiet and respectful when going through the Mausoleum. Ho Chi Minh is laid out and looks (probably) much as he did before he died. No pictures allowed inside the mausoleum.

Imposing . A complex of two main parts. One that felt like a nod to the communist past of Vietnam, imposing structures and grand wide space, followed by what can only be described as a beautiful and stunning imperial house, peaceful gardens and also a look at how Hoi Chi Minh lived his life in such simple conditions. Do not miss !!!! this one of the highlights of our total Vietnam trip
Hostoric. Guards standing with honour guarding the mausoleum and the giant inscriptions to his people are a great way to honour a person who did so much for Vietnam

Historical place. I don't like this place much.we have to stand in a long queue to get into the building. And food or drinks should be left at the counters at the front door. Big bags are also forbidden. Nothing much can be seen.

Holiday. We went early like we were advised as queues are long and it is hot.If you don't want to hand over your bags to the officials that maintain the security of this facility I suggest you leave everything as we entered we were ushered to the first window we lost our backpack which was exchanged for a tag, but we were allowed to keep our big camera we walked further then another window where we had our big camera taken and another tag given (they let you keep cellphones) but you are forbidden to take any photos inside the Mausoleum photos outside fine....After seeing Uncle Ho Chi who lays in a glass box for you to see him in person we found where we could collect our camera big relief one thing back... then onto the next stage where you basically have to purchase tickets to get out 40,000vnd each but this allows you to visit everything in complex. Finally finished then we had to find our way back to where we could claim our backpack back not so easy but a very helpful man guided us to the exit and bag claim window.This was an awesome experience and worth a visit to understand Ho Chi Minhs role in Vietnam history.
Interesting but not much to it. Seeing the mausoleum up-close is pretty cool, but there's not much more to it. I probably could have sufficed seeing a photo.

Disappointing stop-by visit. Was disappointed visiting this place. Waited for long q for more than 20 mins just to get in. Although I wasn't enjoying it but be very respectful to those local on their respect to their legacy leader.

Pick your time to visit.. This museum is not open on a Monday, and for only a couple of hours in the morning. The authorities are very sensitive about cameras. The queues for the mausoleum can be quite long but are well managed and kept moving.

Interesting . A must do in Hanoi.Although security really strict and confusing.Expect long queues for this attraction. Anything larger than pocket sized cameras will be taken off you placed in a sealed bag which you get back when you exit mausoleum. No photography. Whilst in queue told no photography but everyone was doing anyway.Also no liquids/food. Bit bad when you in blazing heat and you have no fluids.Understand that it would be disrespectful within mausoleum but not whilst queuing.Again ladies no bare shoulders.Very regimented but a must see.

Interesting. The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, as its name indicates, where Ho Chi Minh is exposed. They control who gets in, what you carry, what you dress (you can't take cameras, phones) and the visit of the body only lasts for a few minutes. But it's interesting.

Must visit while in Hanoi!. Apart from paying respect to the late founder of Vietnam, a visit to the mausoleum brings you to lush of greeneries at its spacious backyard garden. You will also find One Pillar Pagoda here, small but ancient, where locals and tourists pray. Tips:1) Wear decent clothes (no shorts or mini skirts for ladies).2) Dab lots of sunblock, the weather can be very humid especially in summer months.3) Leave your DSLR in hotel, no food or drinks allowed. The security is on high alert, all bags are subjected to security scans and any bulky belongings will be asked to be stored. You will be given a tag to get your belongings back, but it will be a hassle to walk back and collect them, especially if you're heading out somewhere else.

Incredible affection for a former President. The reverence the Vietnamese people have for their long dead President has to be seen to be believed. The queues of people lining up to pass through the mausoleum to pay their respects to "Uncle Ho" is incredible and this happens almost on a daily basis. Well worth the visit as there are a number of other displays in the grounds that preserve the lifestyle of the first President of Vietnam

Impressive building! . Go early to avoid the crowds. Very impressive building which holds the grave of Ho Chi Minh, a little eerie but no less spectacular. May suggest having part of a tour or guide to explain the presidential palace. Which cost a few Dong to get into. We thought that guides were mandatory when you paid to see the palace and tagged on but only found out at the end they were part of a bus tour when they walked off. Awkward! Worth seeing none the less!

A must see in Hanoi. This is free tour and is well organized and directed by the staff. You just go in one straight line to visit the mausoleum to see Ho Chi Minh's body. This place is next to One pillar Pagoda.
great for historians. We did not go into the mausoleum as we arrived on a Friday and the Mausoleum is closed, we enjoyed seeing the rest of the history of Ho Chi Minh (home and gardens)

Disappointing and annoying. An ok experience. Be aware that you cant take anything into the compound with you - no water, cameras etc, and you cant get it back until you fully exit the compound.
Seems like a good scam to make you buy the overpriced water that they sell inside.

Uncle Ho's resting place. Many, many Vietnamese come to pay respects to Uncle Ho. Quite high security and well guarded by guards. No cameras are allowed. Uncle Ho lies in state. I found it a little creepy but many locals seemed overwhelmed emotionally from their visit. QUITE A FEW STAIRS IF MOBILITY IS AN ISSUE.
Not Sure if it's Him . Line ups can be long and hot and you can't take water or large cameras in with.The precinct outside the mausoleum is quite beautiful.

Worth a visit. Spent a few hours looking around the mausoleum but was to busy to go inside. Was told this is a normal thing. Gardens were lovely and enyoyed our time there. After walked around the streets where many wonderful embassy buildings were and to Lenins statue.

Definitely a must do!. If you're in Hanoi you definitely need to visit the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum!
Its a free activity and well organized.
A must do!
A symbolic building. The day that I went there was very hot and the Mausoleum was closed. The space is big along the building specially if you are walking with 38ºC of temperature.
weird!. Found this a bit weird filing past Ho Chi Min's preserved body which is laid out behind glass.Very important site though for people of Vietnam.

Go on a rainy day and avoid the long lines. It was raining the day I went and I just walked in, no waiting, but the walk is long if you are not on a tour. Worth the visit to see the enclosed glass tomb which holds Ho Chi Minh. It is just like seeing Lenin's Mausoleum in Red Square in Moscow, Russia. You have to keep moving around the glass enclosure at all times. Do NOT take anything inside the Mausoleum with you. The guards keep an eye on everyone and everything. Items like cell phones, cameras, backpacks must be handed over and picked up after viewing Ho Chi Minh.

Worth a visit. While you only get to see the actual inside of the mausoleum for about 30 seconds, it is worth it. You basically spend some significant time lined up outside with all of the visitors, and sweating in the heat, but it is a creepy & worthwhile sight once inside. If you visit in the summer like we did, you have to balance sweating profusely in the heat with dressing modestly enough to go inside.

Glad We Went. Got there at 7:15 a.m and joined what looked like a scaringly long queue. But once the doors opened at about 7:30 a.m the queue moved quick. We were through and out by 8:00 a.m. Definitely worth doing
Expansive Parade Square. Definitely worth a look. The parade square is tremendous and the place offers a few instagram worthy shots. Do note of the opening hours and attire!
yawn. Really, if I did all over again, I would be the one sitting in the shade waiting for you to come back yawning. But the line went on for ever and ever and ever. Outside is impressive.

Impressive building. Not too much to see if you come at the wrong time, it was closed when we arrived, however it is an impressive building and area. We did get to watch the changing of the guard on the door. You have to be there mid morning.

Worth a look. Definitely worth a look whilst in Hanoi found not much English spoken by anyone working there. Would be worthwhile having a guide for the tour and also know that you will have to hand In camera's, phones & iPad etc. prior to going into the mausoleum these are collected once you come out the other side.

Our tour.. Went there on a Friday, it was an extremely hot day, 38 degrees, with a humidity of 86 to 110 percent. Very interesting to see from the outside, however if you want to see Ho Chi Minh. Don't go Friday or Monday, It's not op!!!

Take a guide or it will be lost on you!. Went on a rainy tropical storm day in the afternoon which meant the mausoleum itself was closed.There are lots of other things to see here, but it is badly signposted, so without knowing Vietnamese or having a guide, you'll find yourself wandering round aimlessly (like me). I was looking for the one pillar pagoda near by, but couldn't find it. I did find Ho Chi Minh's old house, the government building and a representation of what his stilt house was like, all around a lovely lake so that was nice, but not especially exciting.I suppose it's one of those places one should see when in Hanoi and I'm glad I did even if it was a bit of a let down.

Not sure it is worth a visit. Actually, it was what we expected it to be, seeing two other mausoleums like that one on previous trips (Mosco and Beijing), we have seen HCM preserved body...We didn't like the fact that the guards on the line asked our teen daughter to cover her legs and shoulders, while they did not ask the men in the line to do the same.

Resting place of Ho Chi Minh. This massive structure, resting place for Ho Chi Minh, with guards in front of the building and standing at attention inside around him, was very colorful and showing total respect for him. It is a quick walk through, but very compelling and will be long remembered.
City tour. Amazing.Ho Chi Min toomb. Body on display in airconditioned toomb. Well worth the walk to get to it.

Hard walk under that heat. This visit is what it is. Seeing the embalmed body of the hero of this great nation. What I didn't like was to walk and wait under that toasting heat with almost no coverage and no water. The visit to the house on stills and pillar pagoda was nice.

Unsure. So, we were on a private tour, where we were standing under a tree for shade, listening to our guide.Unfortunately, it was a Monday and the building was closed up so that no public could go inside. We went mid-afternoon and it was really really hot. Not a pleasant heat to go to this place. I recommend you go to this place in the morning on any day but Monday!

Get to know Uncle Ho. As a young adult during Australia's involvement in VN this was something I really wanted to understand. Worth doing the Mausoleum and the general precinct as it does help to understand what was going on.

Check where the entrance is. This is interesting, but my research was not good enough so I went through the 'outside only' entrance before realising I couldn't get into the mausoleum. This meant lots of extra walking with no shade. The mausoleum entrance is on Ngoc Ha. The line line moves pretty quickly and is mostly covered. There is no entrance fee, and there are plenty of vendors as you exit for drinks and snacks.

Very interesting. . Although it was pouring with rain we still enjoyed our visit especially Uncle Ho's very modest home which contains all the original furnishings and accoutrements. Disappointed that we did not get into the actual mausoleum for viewing the glass case. Still the Changing of the Guard ceremony and the beautiful gardens were worthwhile.
Hanoi Tour. Found this interesting with some good history knowledge and a lot of info about Ho Chi Minh. This was included on a full day tour around Hanoi

Curious experience. The Mausolum itself is nothing special but what makes mandatory to go there is the mummified body of Ho Chi Min, even if you have just few seconds to see him.The mausoleum is for free. You have to pay a ticket just to visit Ho Chi Min house and the One Pillar Pagoda.

Not going in there. I'm actually just passed through this place because it's already 6PM at that time and I feel lucky because when I came, I saw the process of guard change. It's kinda unique so I like it.. And also if you want to go to this place remember that they're close at monday and friday
Good. This is one of the few things that are make sense when visiting Hanoi. The visit is very brief but an interesting experience.
long queueeeeeeeeee. be sure to arrive earlier, such a long queue!! and in the end we gave up since it was too hot, not much shelter on the outside
great view. easy going, good for photo shooting, very spacious, no pressure though you may feel lots of communism. do have one bad thing is most people can't speak english.

Fascinating experience. Really an interesting visit to the symbolic heart and soul of Communist Viet Nam. Seeing the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh lit up by an orange light giving him a near-radioactive look was a bit of a surprise, and the pomp and cult of personality vibe was very interesting to witness, particularly the guards dressed in all white uniforms. Very austere building for the actual mausoleum. Museum attached with presidential palace and ho chi minh memorabilia was also worth the visit, despite the oppressive heat and extreme humidity.

Interesting, but different . The museum was not was I was expecting. I admit I was expecting Ho Chi Minh to be shown in only positive and idealistic light, however the displays often made no sense. The displays were supposed to be representative of his life, however I felt they were sensationalising his life and the role he has played in Vietnam. They also did not necessary match the explanation. I will admit my view on the museum is based on my political views which is representative of the country I'm from.

Different experienc. We were keen to see this - but it was a strange experience. You start queuing immediately but once you reach the end of this queue you join another and then another... The staff here are very strict but sometimes the instructions are not clear. We were in various queues for around 90 minutes before we got inside. At the point we were shouted at to walk quicker and get out! If it interests you then it is worth a visit but it is a lot of queuing for a very quick sighting!

For History lovers its a must . This is a great place to visit, especially for history lovers. Get there early in the morning (8-10am), so you can view Ho Chin Minh's body. The grounds also contains the stilt house, one pillar pagoda and the HCM museum. The museum is a great insight into Ho Chi Minh's life and the uprising of communism in Vietnam. My advise would be to get a guide to talk you through the history. Having said that the museum has put together detailed English text under each event (pictures/official documents) so it can be followed quite easily.

interesting place. I highly recommend you visit here while in Hanoi, HCM Is the greatest hero Vietnam has ever had, he is everywhere in statues, posters, pictures. Get up early and queue up for less time it is strange in some ways but I do feel its a must do in Hanoi. We got there at ten to 8 and were out by 8.30 - try to best the queue. I live close to here and you can see how bad the queue gets after 9am.

Get there early in the day!!. The place closes by 2PM, so get there early. It quite an interesting place and although we didnt get to go inside, we got to see a bit of the parade as it was ending. Its quite an elaborate setup, and it happens almost everyday.
Interesting to see. The mausoleum is intersting to see, but you have to go early. They only open from 7:30 to 10:30 in the morning in the week. And from 7:30 to 11 at the weekends.

Must in hanoi... . The place is must in hanoi. Especially Ho chi minh is great person and idol for vietnam history and people. So his life, culturr, lifestyle should be read. You can get in the place at only fixed times. There is no flexibilty. The place is also very central. Easy transportation. You must put top for hanoi visit..CheersErnur

Important cultural tourism stop. Worth the visit if you are interested in participating and learning more about Vietnam's history and culture. We arrived to the security gate around 07h45, quickly passed through security, dropped off our bags at the bag drop and walked the path leading to the Mausoleum. The guards ensure all of the visitors continue moving, there was a line of people but it moved very quickly. We happened to be in the room just when the changing of the guards occurred, at 08h00. Ensure you dress properly, shorts covering the knees, and a shirt that covers your shoulders. It is best to be there in the early morning to avoid crowds.

A must do for us. Be aware that the mausoleum has specific opening times (morning) and that security and waiting takes (a little) time. Dress according to common rules. It is a twirling line through the cool building, with guards making sure you won't stop. We thought it was very impressive to actually see Uncle Ho. He has done a lot for the people of Vietnam and we are very glad to have gone.

Interesting. We visited this attraction thinking we wouldn't really enjoy it much but we came away thinking the opposite. Seeing 'Uncle Ho' was a bit surreal while extremely well organised. The grounds, admin buildings and his house were interesting to see. I would recommend a visit. I would have liked to see some information placards around the buildings to add some knowledge/interest. Don't catch the taxis when you exit, they charge 10 times more than metered taxis.

Poor management and opening hours. The opening hours are very limited and when we visited following advice from the hotel, this important attraction was closed - when it was meant to be still open. We were very disappointed. There needs to be more reliable opening hours so that tourists can plan their visits & the opening hours should be managed closely. Fortunately we could still view the museum and the Uncle Ho historical homes and gardens which are separate to the mausoleum.

Worth visiting . This is worth doing with a knowledgeable guide who can give you the history. Interesting to see his house and gardens. Arrive in front of the mausoleum just before the hour strikes to see the changing of the guard.

Respect and reverence . Wow. Well organised military precision process. The context, environment and staff all combine to make this an Occassion. A must do. Then grab an ice coffee or beer at the cafe by the entrance / exit.

Go early to avoid queues. Nice to see but I wouldn't squeeze this trip in unless you have plenty of time - can get very busy unless you go first thing and I would not recommend standing in line for over 20 mins or so. I understand the queue can be up to 2 hours on occasion

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. A very long wait in a queue that was approximately one kilometre long. The weather was a scorcher but the queue had a covered canopy to shade the visitors. Cameras had to be handed in to special booths and collected at the end of the visit. Sunglasses were not permitted and shoulders had to be covered. Guards along the queue made sure that the queue remained in two single files and we were reprimanded for forming a row with three people because we were chatting quietly. As we neared the Mausoleum it was expected that everyone was silent. After the long wait, the passing through the mausoleum only took approximately one minute. The body was amazingly preserved. Heavily guarded along the entire route. Air-conditioned inside. Worth the wait.

An impressive mausoleum. If you are planning to visit this "attraction", be sure to arrive early as the queue only gets longer throughout the day. The mausoleum building is impressive and viewing the body was more tasteful than I had expected. You walk past the body single file and must be respectful, no hands in pockets etc. The strange thing is that our guide told us that Ho Chi Minh did not want this; he wanted to be cremated and his ashes scattered to the different parts of the country.

Amazing Monument. This is a place that should be visited for sure. Not only because of the mausoleum where Ho Chi Minh rests but also for its surroundings. Beware not to carry bags but only your camera that is also forbidden to carry when you enter the main building and thus you have to leave it before entering but you can then get it back to get photos of the other attractions like the square the parliament Ho Chi Minh's houses, cars etc.

The must, but not so must. The mausoleum itself is just a walk around the preserved body. It is worth of visiting for history lovers, if you also plan to see the palace area or the museum in the same complex. Visiting the mausoleum alone is just the lose of time.
Huge open space and amazing monument. Note that the opening times are limited.. the day we visited we missed the opening time, but still worthy of a wander around the area

Ho Chi Minh is there. Very interesting experience to see the father of modern Vietnam and his home and work area directly behind. Apparently you need to check to see if he is there as once a year he goes to Russia for upkeep. Everyone is very serious and the guards watch your every step. Expect to have to leave cameras etc as no photos are allowed. You will get to see history.

The location is great - a must see visit - but the 'Police' are overbearing and rude. I'm a British photographer, and clearly not a local. As I travel I carry a huge rucksack of equipment, and a tripod. Now any professional photographer will know that the tripod, the most dangerous photographic item in the world, is not always welcome. On arriving at the Mausoleum on a Sunday night at around 8pm, there were probably around 50-100 people wandering around. It's a huge place, so that meant that there was plenty of space, no large crowds, and as a photographer plenty of opportunities. I had previously been using the camera on a tripod prior to arriving, and so they were still mounted together. I sat on the floor to change a lens with the camera pointing towards me - and away from the Mausoleum. A police officer approached - and of course we didn't speak each others language - but in effect it was clear he was saying 'no tripod'. This I know happens in some of the major tourist attractions - so I'm ok with it. I gave him the thumbs up sign, and tried to show him I was changing a lens. He became irate and started shouting in Vietnamese - which wasn't really helpful. I then translated using my phone the phrase 'Only changing camera lens' - showed him, and he shouted even more. Obviously I was getting irate myself then, as I wasn't using the tripod to take a photo - the camera was pointing at me! I then translated another message 'I am not using tripod - only changing lens' - he shouted again, and then stood behind me while I finished changing the lens, and then separated the camera from the tripod. Whilst sitting on the floor, I was able to take some photographs with the tripod next to me, a rule I always find to be crazy, but I'll always comply. As it is a tourist area, it would be good if the Police were trained a little - not specifically in languages - but how maybe they use body language to try and communicate, as there are many languages in the world - without being shouty shouty shouty. This does nothing but heighten stress. So if you have a tripod - don't bring it here. I sat and relaxed for a while - and my 'guard' stood next to me the entire time - making sure I didn't touch the tripod. Sometimes photographer seems to equal terrorist on the scale of police activity.

The Mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh. The mausoleum is a must for all tourists. The leader of the Vietnamese peoples struggle and a great nationalist dies in 1969 and his body has been very well preserved in the mausoleum for people of all walks of life and nations to pay their homage.There is a long queue from point of entrance to the mausoleum. Cameras and mobile phones are not allowed.When you enter the mausoleum and go around his well preserved body you get a feeling that he is fast asleep..Photography is allowed once you are outside the main mausoleum.A must visit.

Felt really proud about Hon. Ho Chi Minh. This place is a remarkable place where you will feel proud about a leader of another country. The security and the silence also add more respect to the Vietnamese National Hero.

a visit people feel they should but can miss long lines in hot weather it is a killer. not really interested in seeing a well preserved body. long lines and hot weather . no photos. do not know what is the big deal. can be missed

A place for leaning about Vietnamese history. By visiting the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum and comples, you learn a lot of history of Vietnam and it's founder father Ho Chi Minh. A nice and tranquil place in central Hanoi where you will learn and enjoy the well kept buildings and mementos.
Quick visit. It was a quick visit as the lines were very long and we were not prepared to wait. However it was a sight to see and a must if you ear visiting Hanoi
Not worth it. Nice to know about it but better to imagine that to see. Not much to do and too much time to get there. 5 minutes visit.
Drizzling HCM Mausoleum. It was drizzling in the afternoon and no longer allow tourist to queue and go in to see. It was a nice mausoleum to visit.
Interesting to see. Dont miss the flag hoisting at 7 am or de hoisting at 9 pmThe ceremony is awesome to watch with so many people

Closes at 11am most days. Be prepared to queue though the line moves fairly quickly. Hide your camera and dress conservatively. The guards keep everything moving and after you can buy a ticket to walk through the gardens.

Must See Mausoleum. This is a must see, Ho Chi Minh is revered in Vietnam this site houses his body in a special cooled glass tomb and is only visible certain days of the week and only up to certain times of a day, jump on a day trip and go along, the grounds house the palace he worked at and also the homes he worked and lived right up to his death in September of 1969 it us beautifully set out and a must see to get an idea of this father of Vietnam, one must be aware that around the actual tomb they are very strict on noise, sunglasses hard etc these are signs of disrespect and must be either taken off or put away and housekeeper to quiet talking, perhaps not the best for younger children. A word to the people who wear transition prescription glasses, you best explain them to the guards as they were a bit displeased about mine. Also there is a restriction on cameras inside the mausoleum but outside is not an issue they will mind the cameras for free or you guide won't mind holding the for you as well, our guide was fantastic in that area....

Fascinating visit . Seeing the body of Ho Chi Minh, in state, is absolutely fascinating. Such an enormous monument. Very serious inside. No talking, or even walking in single file.Make sure to wear pants past your knees, and have shoulders covered. While waiting in line, phones can't be used after a certain point, and laptops, iPads and cameras must be handed in before visiting (and picked up immediately afterwards). The body itself is remarkable! Free to visit, but the lines are very long. Don't forget an umbrella or a fan - can we wet and very humid!

Amazing tour . Fantastic experience to see the resting place of this communist leader. It's a bit of a wait on Sunday's but plenty of protection offered from the elements. Wear pants to ensure no issue on getting in. Some days they are relaxed but some days they are not so make sure you play it safeUmbrella a must between April and November.

Unremarkable. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was just 'OK.' Naturally, there is confusion (in SE Asia? No way!). You can only enter the complex from one side, and exit from another. There are no signs posted, and you only find out when you walk too far and have some soldier with a gun shouting at you in Vietnamese, so make sure you walk all the way around to the proper entrance. The Mausoleum itself isn't terribly huge or impressive. The complex surrounding, displaying the houses, car collection and gardens was quite nice, but crowded. There is so much to see and do in Hanoi, so whereas I would definitely recommend this attraction, I would plan accordingly, as opening times vary, and it is a little bit far from the old quarter, which does indeed provide an interesting walk through the town markets, etc. I would not spend an entire day trying to see this.

Interesting. Worth a visit only to witness that Vietnam actually can have structure. Nothing is left to chance, you walk in line all the way through the area. There are guards watching and marching alongside the que. Remember to cover your knees and shoulders, otherwise you will have to buy a scarf for 100.000 dong to enter the area.

Essential for Hanoi. The mausoleum and its grounds are an essential visit to give some understanding of the reverence that Ho Chi Minh is still held in by the Vietnamese population.As well as the Mausoleum you get to see the state palace used for official visits, but never lived in by Ho Chi Minh, and the cottage and library that he lived in within the grounds. Security is tight and no photography is allowed within the mausoleum itself, although you an photograph outside in the grounds. I would recommend that you takes guide with you to get the full history and some explanation of his life and ideals.

Don't believe opening times. Arrived at around 1045, to find it already closed. No signs to work out when it would open. No information. Poor effort by whoever runs it. Gardens are ok to walk around though. Museum is a little informative, but also a little bizarre.

Historical Site. This reminded me of Lenin's tomb. Obviously, they were contemporaries who each brought revolution and communism to their respective countries, so I suppose I am not surprised at similarities. It is a shame to see the money and opulence spent on a dead person in the middle of an impoverished nation. A fitting monument to Communism.

This was not meant to be our day.... We first arrived in the morning only to be told that it was closed as some vip leader from a country. We then had to switch our tour program around. Tour guide decided to swap the morning program with the afternoon. We wentbback again in the afternoon and we're so disappointed to find out that it was closed to the public on Mondays and Fridays. And we were so lucky to pick a Friday to visit the musoleum. We could only hang around outside. Sad...Also, make sure you do not visit in the months of Sept and Oct as you can't get in then too. Ho Chi Minh's body will be flown to Russia then.

stunning. It is amazing ! when you go in there you just feel a strange excitement! One of the most important symbol of the battle of Vietnamese people against the French and American imperialists! Don't miss it!

So Massive!. It is closed on Mondays. We went on a Saturday morning and arrived around 9 am. Surprisingly there were no long lines. From arriving to entering the Mausoleum took about 25 minutes. At the entrance they give you bags to put your bottled water, and cameras in to. I had my cellphone in my shorts and I didn't see them frisking anybody. Just make sure not to take fotos near a guard or inside. NOTE: Wear shorts to your knees or pants and regular t-shirt, not the sleeveless ones. Otherwise you wont get in. I was impressed by the nice marble inside. Also by the 4 guards around Uncle Ho. I wonder how long they can stand without moving? Unlike Chairman Mao, with Uncle Ho you really get a close-up view of him. We were in and out withing 10 minutes. I recommend the earlier you arrive, the quicker you will finish. One good thing is that if you do go late, they have provided a covered walkway to shield you from the sun. Very impressive and thoughtful I thought.

A beautiful monument to a beloved leader. It was a small and beautiful monument to the late President Ho Chi Minh. As there were no explanations or translations, we read up quite a bit about this humble leader and the great things he had done for this country. We recommend anyone coming to this place to do some research before visiting. It will make a world of difference.

The biggest Mausoleum. Certainly the biggest that I have visited so far. Not sure if there are bigger ones in countries like Russia, China or Romania. Ho Chi Minh is revered like God here, and the Mausoleum is a testimony to that fact!
Interesting. Give us a very god view of how "management" lived during the Vietnam War. The information was very helpful. How things were used for.

High security, upmost respect. We had a tour around all the buildings in the vacinity.Bags were handed in, cameras recorders and tablets were put in special bags then handed back.We were lucky no queues but this wasn't normal.Lots of young men having completed their national services but choosing to embark on a career in the army. All soldiers wore white signifying the vaginal state of their leader. Felt very.....different walking past a military deceased ruler lying in state. Everyone remained silent, anyone making ...even a whisper was corrected. Young lads displayed, proudly many nedals
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is powerful and solemnly peace. Guards are gentleman in honoring for the late leader. Powerful Site and very Solemn. Great site and Mausoleum.
Lovely place. Very nice place to see flag hoisting ceremonies at 7 am in the morning or de hoisting ceremony at 9 pm

This one is a must. No one should leave Hanoi without a visit to see Uncle Ho. Just seeing the reverence paid gives a good insight into what makes the country tick. We arrived about 9.30 to virtually no queue... There is no charge to visit but if you want to go on to enter the gardens it costs 40,000 vnd for foreigners. Big bags need to be checked in but that is also free of charge. Be aware.. You should be dressed respectfully.. Cover up the shoulders and when the main room is entered, make sure you keep your hands out of your pockets. Be careful taking a cab away from here as we heard there are a couple of scams going on!
Good monument to know Vietnam's history. This place is well protected, so that not very much being commercialized. It would be worth visitng if you were in Hanoi.

Glad to come. Very eerie feeling walking past Uncle Ho. Something that is not for everyone but thought for me it had to be done. Everything is done very well and in an orderly fashion. Just a note for going in. Long shorts, t shirt and sandals/closed shoes are all definately fine. Did not wear thongs so not sure on those, but observing others no one had things on, just sandals or shoes.

Nice musuem. Ho Chi Minh museum is a great historical story in Vietnam that is located at central of Ha Noi capital.Do not forget to check the close time and date before visit. Specific show form soldier at the gate in front will represent at hourly.
amazing. This tour is well worth doing , it was absolutely amazing to see the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh , very long queue so is a must to go early.

interesting but very touristy. My wife and I had a guide and if we never I'm sure a local would "offer a service" for a price. The grounds are very well kept and interesting to see. a very peaceful place, If you go to the lake where the fish are, don't forget to clap, the fish come to the surface of the water.

Hot and not an ideal choice unless you are really into the history . Was not a ton to see but our guide insisted we go here for a picture. We took a taxi and combined the visit with the famous pagoda near by.

Important to the Vietnamese . Unfortunately we were there on a Monday when you can't actually see Ho Chi Minh's body (also the same happens on a Friday and afternoons, if you haven't done your research). However arriving early in the morning meant we had the whole area almost to ourselves. It was peaceful and our guide explained how much this fundamentally means to the the nation; it is somewhere they all feel they should visit once in their lifetime. Certainly worth a visit. Mausoleums for famous communists; can you catch them all!!!!
Beatiful. so beautiful and in side is clean, Ho chin Minh history class is number one in hanoi and control country go forward to business growth
Strange but unique. You have to queue in line and no pictures are allowed. The feeling is quite unique and I would recommend it for people interested in Vietnam history. Interesting

This is one of the more unusual places to visit. There's not much to see at the mausoleum itself, except for an exceptionally well-preserved Ho Chi Minh. The line is moved along quickly by armed guards. No lingering. Certainly no pictures. It's kind of creepy and, yet, as important as he was to the history of Vietnam, you kinda can't NOT go! We also bought tickets and walked around the grounds behind the mausoleum. Again, kind of interesting and a good way to make the trip to the mausoleum a bit more, but there isn't that much to see and not particularly well identified. Probably better if you are with a guide.

Great-but arrive very if you want to go inside.. If you visit,it is best to go with a guide who can explain the history.Arriving at 9.30am the queue to enter was already taking over an hour to reach the front.Therefore we walked around the outside and through the gardens-which included the 1 pillar temple.Travelling during August saw the temperature reach 38C with very high humidity-so take plenty of water.There are several street vendors selling drinks & souveniers as you wander around.

Interesting, definitely worth a visit.. Need to get there early as it closes at 11am. Dont be put off by the queue as it moves quickly. Had to leave bags behind as bottles of water are not allowed. However, after the visit had to walk on the outside perimeter to go back to get the bag as you are not allowed to take the same route that you came in. This was a bit tricky as needed to rush back to get the bag before it closed. The actual building is very impressive and you have to keep walking once you are inside but very impressive, worth the visit.

Really strange, but worth a visit. This place shows the mummified body of Ho Chi Minh and you will actually only see him for about 30 seconds while walking. But somehow it's worth a visit due the whole scenario and the way it is used to keep alive the idea of Ho Chi Minh, even though he actually wanted to burned and his ashes to be spread in the north and south of Vietnam.The line seems to be endless in the beginning but actually moves forward quite fast. Only open in the morning.

It is was it says on the tin. Very impressive site and the area around it is worth visiting although, on the way to other places of historic significance as well, lots of things to see nearby so not just a mausoleum.
Impressive . Stand out building adjoining a large ground and park. The illumination in the evening is good. Lots of people walking and jogging.

A part of National Identity. Only open from 8:30-10:30 daily (except Mon&Fri). The queue is DisneyLand long, with a mass of people. Primarily nationals in their finery to pay respects. Admission is free, buy a fan to help wave off heat (5'000d). The line progresses swiftly. It is a solemn place and no one speaks as you walk past the leader. Four guards stand watch. Afterwards people begin to laugh and talk again. Great experience to help understand the national psyche and their respect for Ho Chi Minh.

Good to see but very busy . The queue is long to get there and they are very stricken about cameras and water neither of which can go in. The remains are a little spooky to see but it's an experience to understand the reverence with which the locals hold their first leader.

Great & Brave Leader Who Held Firm Ground During The Vietnam War. Was happy to see the place where he is kept today. You can visit the body on a Thursday where is open for visitors. Behind is where Ho Chi Minh lived humbly
