MUST GO. I highly recommend this place to everyone who visit Hanoi. It is a Must go place. You would have to queue for about 20 mins before you are able to enter the Mausoleum and once you entered it, you will be wow by how grand it is.

Uncle Ho. Set off to see Uncle Ho's preserved remains inside the mausoleum (part of a day trip organised by hotel) on an extremely hot and humid Sunday. We arrived at 08.30 to a queue of thousands; apparently people arrive from all over Vietnam to pay their respects to their hero, Sunday being the most popular! Our two teenage daughters (and my hubby) were not keen on joining, what was possibly a two hour wait, so reluctantly I agreed to tour the grounds only.Our guide paid the entrance fee (not sure how much) and we set off to see the area. It was still very busy and we basically shuffled around viewing his house on stilts, (where he eventually spent his last years), three old cars he used and other buildings he had lived in. It's quite a lovely setting with beautiful mature trees and an amazing colonial building - I imagine on a quieter day, it would be a contemplative experience... Not on a Sunday!

Long queue. Yes, the queue is looooong, but don't let that put you off, it moves quite quickly as you are not allowed to stop or take photos or video. Uncle Ho lies in state permanently and is guarded extremely well. The mausoleum is open every day 8 a.m. to 11 a.m. except Fridays.

Impressive place. On visiting the Mausoleum you immediately get an understanding of the importance Ho Chi Minh has to the people in the north of Vietnam.
The Mausoleum is a must-stop destination for tourists.

Listed as must see , intriguing . We came to the mausoleum as we wanted to connect with the history of Vietnams struggles and it was a great way to get a feel for the present and past that pervades this society and in many ways holds it strongly together.There was an orderly queue to get in security checks and bag drop all free.There are signs saying no photos inside the mausoleum but you could take pics around the grounds.It was a throw back to another era with James Bond styling in many respects bullet proof vehicles and grand mansion immaculate grounds soldiers in crisp white uniform guarding the preserved remains of a icon of the Vietnamese people great theatre great respect and worth a visit.All free and quick to get in and quick to move around. Queue was not too bad and I think the place closes 11.30 am so you got to get there early, no lie in if you want to see this place of interest.We were on a tight time limit but still got to see a lot as the tour just follows a Straight forward system. Once again watch out for people helping you get a cab outside the site as they are teaming up to scam you onto a ride that takes you round and round clocking up the fate whilst not taking you where you asked.Bit cheeky so take care as all else is so honest and orderly that this type of behaviour is unexpected so you can fall for the scam.Glad we came to see this place

lots of rules and lots of queuing. Very military and coordinated system of getting tickets ,queueing and waiting. Must leave bags at a bag storage. Must cover shoulders...no phones allowed in and no photo'sCheck days and times as they are limited.

Interesting. Interesting place to visit if you can avoid standing on line for hours to get it. Tours may offer special arrangements for skipping the line. If you do not know much about Ho Chi Minh - as I did - you can learn a lot about his life here.

Complicated visit. If you want to see the park and the mausoleum From the outside, you go there all day. If - however - you want to go inside the mausoleum to see the 'grave' of Ho Chi Minh, you'd better go and be there 1) during week days and not in the weekend or holiday of the VIetnames people themselves and 2) be there at opening hour (7.30 am or so). Otherwise you stand in a line of 2 hours or more.

Surreal... but worthwhile . My main advice: GET THERE EARLY. And preferably on a weekday. The place is only open to visitors for a very short period in the morning (excluding Mondays and Fridays I think?). The first time we went to visit we got there about 15 min before it opened on a Saturday and the line was ENORMOUS. Seriously, it was so long. So we decided to leave it for the time being, instead coming back on Wednesday morning, about an hour before it opened. Even on a Wednesday, a queue built up pretty damn fast. The visit itself was... surreal. I mean, it's exactly what it says on the tin. You're only actually in the building for a very short period of time. I think we were in and out within 5 minutes. So overall - I would definitely recommend a visit, but get there early!

OK but don't expect too much.. At the weekends there are many local people who come to pay respect to Ho Chi Minh so you are moving all the time in the long human chain. The only cold place is actually the mausoleum inside where you are approximately 1 min. It is exactly what is says on the tin: You go and see Ho Chi Minh's balmed body.

INCREDIBLY DISAPPOINTING. I was so looking forward to seeing the resting place of Ho Chi Minh but the whole experience is so regimented and you feel like you are being processed and checked as an enemy. It was a very uncomfortable experience and if you really wanted to take a long look forget it you are ushered in and out at military precision pace.

Interesting cultural visit. If you are in Hanoi then the Mausoleum is worth a visit to learn and experience a bit of the history behind the countries foundation. We arrived at the Mausoleum in the morning before it opened and there was already a long queue. By the time we had queued and been through the Mausoleum, there was no queue so it seems the later you leave it, the quicker you get through.A few things to note is that the dress code is quite strictly enforced, knees and shoulders covered etc. Also, most possessions have to be stored at the entrance and cameras are an absolute no-no!

Make sure it is open!. Cannot visit Hanoi without coming here but plan and check when open to public. Also if you wish to visit uncle Ho make sure he is around as he needs annual preservation treatment. If you do get in to see him ,serious business take it serious or you will be cautioned.

Go before 11am.... If you want to see his body as its closed after that and then there is just a garden/house/museum nearby to look at... Which is pretty average. Kinda cool soviet era architecture if you're into that. Worth a butchers if you're in Hanoi.

Massive Russian revolutionary structure in beautiful garden setting. Note the crisp white uniforms and the signs that bar entry everywhere. Come before 11am or you will not gain entry. Too bad French architecture had no influence on the commemorative shrine to a national hero and father of the country. The Russian revolutionary architectural school is so ponderous and unimaginative. The evening lights help.
Ho Chi Minh. Once in Hanoi you have to check it out, but it's basically a huge building manly interesting for the national fans

LONG, hot wait!. I am happy I went to hear and see the propaganda based around this fallen leader. But be prepared for LONG lines. The line moves quickly and there is a covered sidewalk that attempts to reduce the pain of the merciless sun. We waited just about one hour or two bottles of water! You will go through security midway and they take backpacks, cameras and iPhones. I was allowed to keep my purse but not my cellphone. The military keeps the crowd moving in two lines to the mausoleum (it's airconditioned). The line moves so there is no pause to spend looking at the body. It is somewhat surreal or I was suffering from dehydration! The tour of the presidential palace grounds was a wonderful example of propaganda. I highly recommend it for only that reason.

It is what it is... . High security and a fast moving queue of people ends with a 20 second view of the great man. I guess if you are in Hanoi it would be wrong not to visit, if only to get the sense of how the local people still hold him in such high regard

Creepy Must See.. Just go, it takes an hour max and it's creepy interesting to visit a mausoleum that houses an embalmed body under an orange light reminiscent of fast food and armed security. If you happen to be one of those weirdos of the intelligentsia that digs seeing communist mummies, then you obviously need to check this off your list.

A must-see in Hanoi. The actual mausoleum was not open for tours when I went by (might only be open for a couple of hours in the mornings?), but still an excellent visit. The square itself is gigantic and interesting, with a huge Vietnam flag waving over all of it. The structure is imposing and stark, very communist flavored. There are guards stationed all over the place wearing elaborate crisp white uniforms. Be sure to stay behind the yellow lines, because the guards spring into action at the slightest encroachment towards the building.

Wicked experience-- unlike any I've ever had. If you go to Hanoi you must see the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. It is free to the public, although you'll have to walk a bit through the "park" to get there. The experience truly cannot be described. You will half expect Ho Chi Minh to sit up and start talking to you. A bit creepy, but easily one of the craziest experiences of my life.
Travellgalore. NICE experienced many tourist came and witnessed the wow view. AMAZING!Very secured area security personnel are there to overlooke and guarded the sorroundings specially the people

Iconic Monument. Iconic monument of Hanoi, but is located quite far from the city centre and other landmarks. The architecture has nice subtle Vietnamese touches on the minimalist structure with beautiful greenery surrounding the monument - but it's far for just under 30 minute visit (you can't spend more time than this, unless you go inside).

Imposing communist building... from the outside.. It takes about 20 minutes from the centre to reach the location walking. The building is situated on a large flat concrete plain with a well kept garden to the sides, restricted to visitors. There is a yellow painted line which prevents you coming too close to the building and guards in white uniforms keeping strict watch over the perimeter. The building itself is a large stone blocky building in a communist style, fairly imposing with its large stone pillars and simplicity. We were not able to enter the building on two times we past it, but i believe there are opening hours states between 9-11.There is not a lot to see, but it is an important part of Vietnamese history if you want to check off all the main sights, this will not take more than 10 minutes at most , from the outside.

Worth a visit. We visited after the morning rush.July school holidays queue was not tooo long.Please remember that NO PHOTOS or TALKING inside the viewing chamber as the guards were very strict in enforcing this rule (especially on foreigners in front of us). Allow at least an hour for quesing

Ho Chi Minh looks so real. Went on a Saturday, arrived at 8.15am, after getting tickets we queued for 35 minutes. Drove past same time on Sunday and the queue time would have been at least half an hour. Whatever day you go get there early.

Interesting Tourist Site. It seemed odd to file past and see a dead man lying in state, but we did it. Lines are long, but as you can't stop inside and can only file past, it does move quickly enough.

Worth the visit but long line in heat quote taxing. Whether you approve of Communism or not, still the visit to Ho Chi Min mummy gives you a good sense for the communist cult of personality and the work and story of their country leader.After the musoleum, the visit took us to the living quarters and, with a guide, was very instructive.The musoleum closes early at 11am and it is closed on some days, so do your research.I think it took us 45 mins of a long but moving line. It was well organized, Disney-like line, with little cutting in line.Worth the cultural experience.

you just see the outside. impressive building, in a great location but the times you are allowed inside are very infrequent. Across is the new congress building which is beautiful and you can walk to the water and a lovely temple there.

Important part of Vietnams history. Part if Vietnams history. Open for limited timing.... Usually 4 days a week up to 10 am, and closed for several months in the year when the body is sent to Russia for preservation/ maintenance. Check details before visiting. Hot and humid in summer. Caps/ hats/ umbrellas and drinking water should be carried. Good garment shopping around the area.

Just wanted to go to the museum. It doesn't seem possible to go to the mausoleum complex without actually filing past Ho Chi Minh lying in state. So in order to see the museum and stilt house we had to join the orderly queue. It moves quite quickly and the path has shade canopies but we would have preferred to just go to the museum etc. The museum was really informative however we arrived just before lunch and were rushed out as it was closing for lunch despite people still arriving and paying to enter. The complex grounds are pretty and quiet. We saw everything in an hour.

great man. A great man of Vietnam the remaining of His hardworks for his people are found here, he was a hambleman simple and stay single till the end of his life, is worth to visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum if you Happen to in Hanoi Vietnam
Great place. Seeing this area after doing city tours with novntravel, great place. beautiful and peaceful. Have chance to see Ho CHi Minh's body inside mausoleum

Vietnam national hero. Nice and okay place to visit if you want to know little bit history about Vietnam' founding father. You can see and feel the area when Uncle Ho lived and worked to unite Vietnam. House and library. Good and clean place.

Peaceful place a must place to visit. Very calm and serene atmosphere. beautiful architecture, good maintenance and clean. be here before 10am to visit mausoleum and enough time to visit the whole complex

Ho Chi Minh resting place. It was quite a long walk before we could reach the resting place of Mr.Ho Chi Minh where you could see the preserved body just like sleeping. The whole complex comprised of the govenment presidential Palace and the old houses and the working places of Mr. Ho. No camera allowed in the mousoleum and you need to dress discern for ladies avoid shorts.

oh god!. what a travesty of a museum. there was one wall with the history of ho chi minh and another room with weird art that had nothing to do with him at all. don't waste your time. wikipedia would be more informational.

Fascinating and one of the most unique attractions I have visited while on hols. Expect queues, however it is very organised and the queues move along in an orderly fashion. The Mausoleum is a fascinating tribute to Ho Chi Minh and it is worth queuing up to see the man himself. The grounds are also interesting and I am glad we went out of our way to visit. Highly recommended. If it is a hot day, bring a hand fan to help cool yourself. Be reminded that knees and shoulders must be covered and hats removed. The respect they hold for Ho Chi Minh is very high.
Not so crowded like Mao.. It's good to have seen the mausoleum because it's a Milestone for the history of Vietnam. It's not busy there.

Inaccessible . As someone who has done my research on Moscow and Pyongyang in the past, I was not in the least bit surprised when I first laid eyes on the mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh. The architecture dominates the entire flat area around the grounds of the park, with the building visible from all of the surrounding building lines.The park itself is fairly plain, merely consisting of wide communist concrete parade ways and patches of grass. On a hot day it offers absolutely no shade from the sun, which gets rather sweltering. Once one has admired the mausoleum, however, there is very little to do. Unlike in Moscow or Pyongyang, one cannot go inside the building. If a single step is taken up off the road onto the outside pavement, the chief of the security guards shouts angrily to warn you off. The grandstands too are unapproachable. I did wonder why our rickshaw driver offered to wait for us when he dropped us off, and we soon found out. The stop is worth about ten minutes, and is rather difficult to get to from the old town. As a result, I found myself disappointed.
You have to visit!. This place you have to have on your to do list. Be there when they open. It will be a lot of people there. No shorts are allowed!
Holiday in viet. I went here with groups from my mum's company, the architecture is great, really clean, and well design.

Closed on a Monday. Fantastic piece of architecture. You cannot go in side on a Monday, but can still visit the grounds and see where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked. Beautiful mansion house and house on stilts. Stunning scenery and grounds.

Queue moves really fast. Get there early and expect to take 35 mins from the back of the queue to the inside. Dont be put off by what appears to be an extremely looooong queue...Its very well organised crowd control and you file past in 2 rows and are kept moving at a pace. Be aware of the following; take water to drink in the queue if its hot but it will be taken from you part way in at the security check, ladies wear shorts or dresses to the knee and no singlet tops, no photos allowed inside. Worth the effort to go.

Odd / Powerful and worth a visit. Go early as the queues are huge - we queued for about an hour to see Ho Chi Minh for about 2 minutes.It is definitely worth a visit for the iconography / setting / local people watching and it was odd seeing a famous figures seemingly asleep next to you.A must do in Hanoi

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum Was Okay. I think the mausoleum visit would probably mean more to someone from this country and those who experienced the changes in the Vietnamese government. For me, it was just a stop that didn't mean much.

Is it him tho?. An interesting place to visit for historical purposes but you would struggle to spend more than 30 minutes here. And then theres always the question of if its really him, I doubt it but doesnt really matter anyway I guess.

The whole experience - well changing the guard is fascinating. Enjoyed the Visit to the Palace adjacent and to see the house where Ho Chi lived and his car collection, very peaceful surroundings- Mausoleum limited hours of opening-

Long queue moves fast. Must do when visiting Hanoi. We walked to the front of the mausoleum area but the entrance is on the other side and the queue started about 500 meters from the actual entrance. Probably best to take a taxi to the start of the queue and taxis in Hanoi are extremely cheap anyway.

An experience. The day we visited the ques were so long, it may have taken hours to get thru. We went with a guide who took us past the lines and straight in. We didn't go into the Mausoleum itself as a long wait on a very hot day. The grounds and gardens were just beautiful, and worth going with a guide, You learn so much more this way.
Its a guy in a tomb.. Not a bad place to walk around for the architecture, but kind of a propaganda stop in Hanoi. We walked around for an hour.

Uncle Ho. It was rainy day when we visit the Museum of Uncle Ho we just roaming around outside of the museum, we did not go inside because of the long queue outside. one of the Historical place of Vietnam People...

Surreal Experience. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is open to the general public between 08:00 and 11:00 daily. We as a family arrived in the afternoon and as can be seen from the photos it was closed and guarded. Luckily we could return the following morning prior to our departure to DaNang. I'm very pleased we did. There is a dress code to be adhered to out of respect, dress appropriately. Ladies no open shoulders, revealing cleavage, recommended to wear a dress, there is a shop selling clothing at the entrance if you arrive in your summer or "beach wear". They prefer men to wear long pants and a collared shirt, however closed shoes and belted shorts are accepted if worn with a collared shirt.Once entered you will be requested to hand in your rack sack to be collected afterwards. It is safe and secure, however remember to take out your wallet just in case as you will need it to buy juice in the heat of Hanoi. You will be ushered along a winding undercover pathway (helpful when it's raining) in pairs to the entrance and reminded to remain silent, once inside a couple of stairs lead you to view to embalmed remains of Hi Chi Minh, laying in State. A must see while in Hanoi.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. You gotta do this, it's unreal. Open from 7am - 11am not worry about lines it moves quiet quick. Totally worth it.It's closed two days of the week Monday and Friday's weekends are busy but like I said the line moves quick. Ladies if you wear shorts of singlet take a shawl,to cover you legs and shoulders otherwise you will have to buy one there as they wont let u in.

Ho Chi Minh monument. Can't get very close to it, surrounded by fencing and armed guards. Not much to see there, but a walk in the nearby neighborhood to see the government buildings and embassies was interesting.
Worth visiting. One of the most important places in Hanoi, especially for vietnamise people. It isn't too far from the Old Quater. So, I think it's worth visiting.

Should miss the chance to visit the President Mausoleum. Well, this place is a holy place for each Vietnamese. The entrance is free but you have to queue, especially in the weekends, it is crowded. It opens all days except for Monday and Friday. It can be combined for you to visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Ho Chi Minh Museum, One-Pillar Pagoda, stilt-house where President Ho Chi Minh worked, ....
Interesting museum to visit. A visit to this museum will offer reasons why Ho Chi Minh is revered amongst Vietnamese. It is also a great architectural trip to see the old French colonial palace

Got to visit.. A must see when in Hanoi. Be careful with what you wear. Shorts & vests not permitted. Knee length shorts & Tshirt ok.Have to hand camera in before entering mausoleum (must be quiet) get back after leaving. Also you see Ho Chi Minhs 3 houses. Outside of the old French residential palace. Definitely worth a visit.

nice place !. Nice promenade to do in this place, you can see many things such as the monument on this picture, a temple, and many more things.You can do nice promenade, it's free, and if you like history, you'll lean many thing !
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is good to visit if have spare time in your plan , but waiting time is long and not suitable in sparkling sunny days

Nice place but the museum was not that great. It was a Monday so unfortunate for us as the mausoleum is closed on Fridays and Mondays so couldn't go inside to see ho chi minh's corpse. But that was ok though you would need to cover your shoulders and wear something below the knee out of respect but this applies only if you are visiting the mausoleum. Every hour they do change of guards but nothing like the palace in England so dont raise your expectation as it is only 2 officers changing for 2 other officers and 1 supervising them. In the museum, you pay vnd 40,000 per person and the first section that spoke about his life was excellent. But the second floor was very confusing and made no sense to be honest- it was hard to follow what was going on in life. You can also visit his home and his cars but we didnt do that this time as was a long turn we had to take and it was just really hot. All in all, not the best place we have been to but guess it is a must for all to see..

Part of History. We went on the weekend as part of our Intrepid tour. Fortunately we went early but still a massive queue (several blocks worth). However the queue moved promptly under the guidance of the soldiers. No time to linger and not allowed to take photos. Majority of visitors were Vietnamese residents including families and Ho Chi Minh is a very reverent person in their history.If you can go during the week, the queue may not be as long.It is very hot and humid in July, so take water and a good hat, and loose but respectful clothing.In the distance we saw the changing of the guard.

Different. Wasn't sure what to expect reading reviews. The queue moved quickly which in the heat and humidity was good. A lot of pushing. Literally less than a minute to see him. They charge foreigners 40000 after you have seen him and then walk around his grounds. Again a lot of pushing.

Well wort the visit despite the queues. This is a must whilst in Hanoi! Don't be put off by the queue - it moves quickly . Hoi Chi Min is in a glass coffin surrounded by 4 soldiers standing so still for hours on end. A surreal experience but well worth it.

must do. I jogged to this place nearly every morning and every morning was different. All the locals also do their morning activities and Thai Chi there as well. Very busy - unfortunately when was there the body was back to Russia being embalmed again which they do every year at that time so it was closed.

Worth at least a look. At least we saw it. Unfortunately, the lineups outside this attraction were so immense, that we had no time to wait. We walked around and took a few pictures. Next time we will try to visit at a quieter time. On this visit, there were thousands of schoolchildren - all eager to talk to us in English!

Get there early. We visited the Ho Chi Min memorial today. It closes at 10.30am so you have to go early. Got there about 9.30am and the line was about 300m from front entrance. We were entering within 15min. Disneyland could learn something from these guys. It is worth the effort as there is a lot more to see than Mr Ho Chi Min. We busted the presidential compound and the museum. Some really interesting information on his life and the birth of modern Vietnam. Probably spent about 2.5hrs wandering around. All very well organised. From here you can walk to the lake and the Pagoda no trouble.

Must see at night. Just like Hoan Kiem Lake, this landmark is something to see at night too! Lights up beautifully! The entire place never gets too crowded, and you can sit by the corner and just relax.

You have to see this. Als je in Hanoi bent is this a must see. It will take some time. Don't go on weekends when all Vietnamese also are honoring there hero. It makes a lasting memory from Vietnam and it is impressive to feel the impact of Ho Chi Minh on Vietnam. There is a Ho Chi Minh museum (not free) next door, but for none Vietnamese this does not add much to the experience. The museum shows Ho Chi Minh's car, house, bed etc.

Just go as a form of respect . Nothing much. But thought would be good to go as respect to Ho Chi Minh and for the Vietnamese people. They respect him a lot and travelled across the country. It is very grand and solemn. Many soldiers at every turn. We are not allowed any photos inside the place.
Amazing. We did not go into the museum which I believe is very good but spent our time walking through the beautiful gardens & admiring it all, it's huge
interesting. it's a great museum,I learned a lot about Ho Chi Minh that I didn't know before. The interior is impressive as well
a mausoleum. The building is at a very big square and with very well guard. You can't come close or get in. A construction that is not really vietnamese.

Historical, but.... No photos allowed inside, which makes sense. You walk in a highly controlled procession, no phones or cameras, under the scrutiny of several armed, no nonsense guards, up several corridors, walk in a U around the well preserved and reverently presented body of Ho Chi Minh, and exit.If you are really interested in the history of Vietnam (which I am) then this is a good visit. Others might find the hour long wait in line a bit much for the overall payoff.

Mausoleum. good to see, its part of Vietnam history. Very long queue, but very quick. No pay for entrance, elecronic devices(phones, cameras,..) are forbidden.Shoulders and knees must be covered (for ladies -if you forgot it, you can buy big scarf and use it like skirt)my recomendation - buy a paper fan(10.000VDN), its very hot in this time.

What You'd Expect. Came shortly after opening time and the line wasn't long. You walk through a que and then go in to see his body. You just walk through the inside, but it's air conditioned so walk slowly! They don't allow you to take photos inside and there are lockers to store your valuables. Wasn't sure what the point of the lockers was since they don't go through your bags. Just don't wave your camera or phone around, keep them in your bag, and you won't need the locker.

great museum. we unfortunately arrived just on closing time for lunch, but the doorman allowed us to race through.it was a really impressive museum .'would have loved more time but were lucky to see what we did.impressive
Must go. Can't miss to visit here to have further understanding on this relevant part of Vietnam's history.Clear explanations in english, french and Vietnamese. 5 minutes from Old Quartier.

Tour. Very interesting. Dealt with in typical Vietnam fashion, orderly and with just the right amount of freedom. Lovely gardens and grounds, worth the 25 minute queue. Worth taking as part of a guided tour.

Very underwhelming. We visited this early to avoid queues and hot weather. Bags, cameras and water were confiscated although many Vietnamese tourists were allowed through with theirs which disappointed us. We were filed through a long line to see the corpse of President Ho Chi Minh for a mere 30 seconds. No information was provided to visitors.
Nice place. Amazing place the soldiers on duty are nice to see them. Don't forget to take photos with them. It is very hot during the summer time don't forget to wear proper clothes.

Only if you have the time..... Wonderful to see the reverence and respect for Ho Chi Minh, but it was a very strictly run process, no knees, no shoulders, no sunglasses allowed and take off your hat as it is disrespectful. I carried a sarong in my bag - luckily - and turned it into a skirt which allowed me in, You are also not allowed to take photographs.

Too crowded. If you like seeing people who have been dead 50 years then this could be your thing. "Uncle Ho" was certainly the least unpleasant of those that are "immortal."The queue kept moving but you only get to walk round the old codger for about thirty seconds after you have queued for qbout 45 minutes.When I visited the gardens first in 2013 I was just about the only person there. I guess that there were 20,000 (mostly Vietnamese) there the day we went.

A Must Visit When in Hanoi. Make sure you visit the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It's free. BEWARE of the guards. If you step out of line, look as if you're not showing enough respect, talking or worse laughing, the guards WILL bring to your senses with a stern telling off.

A most befitting tribute to the Great Leader. The environment in and around the Mausoleum is very professional. The dedication of the soldiers on duty was overwhelming and infectious.The upkeep of the mausoleum is just like any place of worship. Salute the spirit and loyalty of the Vietnamese people to their leader

Unusual experience . We went on a day tour of highlights of Hanoi. This included about two hours at the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. A long line of tourists filed past the body of their revered leader who died in 1969. We also were taken to see his house on the same estate. The whole setting is tranquil and there are some interesting aspects about going there. It gave us an appreciation of the change in circumstances in Vietnam after the end of the colonial era.

be quite. the most respectful person in Vietnam sleeping there. I was really surprised about how they respect him and surrounding him with a lot of guards. he is like a god for them. really nice to visit and see who liberate Vietnam
Boring. The place made me think on east germany in the 1970s. We didnt tried to see Ho Chi Minh because it was steaming hot and there was 1000 people standing in line.

A great place to see. But no need to go inside.. The Hô Chi Minh is a great place to see. But no need to go inside. Take pictures from outside. The imperial gards rotate/change every hour. Worth seeing.
A great insight.. Long queues, but well worth the wait. From Uncle Ho's lying in state, to the house he lived and worked in,to the cars which were donated to him, a fascinating tour.

Great communistic monument . Ho Chi Minh Monument is clearly a must see when visiting Hanoi. The visitors form a line that is approximately 2 kilometers long. The line moves fast into the monument that is guarded by soldiers. You go through the room where you can see the mummy of the former communist leader. It actually is a very interesting site. You should have a guide that can tell the story of Ho and explain the background and history of the monument. As I understood it the monument is only open before 11 am and closed a part of the year when they do some maintenance work on the mummy.

Good place to learn about Ho Chi Minh, Father of post-colonial, communist Vietnam. We went on a damp, drizzly day in December. This imposing place is built of granite and centrally located (at Ba Dinh Square). It invokes solemn feelings. There is a strict dress code. Guards make visitors neatly lined up before entering. Once inside the Mausoleum, you cannot dwell. You keep on shuttling and have about 15 seconds of glimpse of the embalmed body. The face looks like a wax figure but very well preserved. There is no picture taking inside. You can catch the changing of the guards. You may have to check (store) larger cameras. I think this portion is free. Once outside, you can take your time to tour the presidential palace (which requires an admission) and simple bed and room HCM used to sleep. We were told by the guide that HCM was never married (so he could focus on his country), and that he died (in 1969) before seeing unification. HCM is declared a Saint by the Communist Party.

Mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh. Lots of guards around and only a short taxi ride from downtown Hanoi eerie to see his body mummified and no photos but interesting just make sure you are dressed with legs covered to knee and shoulders covered as this is a must to allow you in to the area great market shops nearby to buy sarong and scarf if needed

must visit. this is a must visit place. great to walk around and enjoy the vastness of the place. the one pillar pagoda is a near miss in this complex only. also the opening and closing times you need to check and go accordingly or you might land up there on a day and time when it is shut

A must-do thing whist in Hanoi . We lined up with what seemed like every other visitor to Hanoi for 1 1/2 hours. The line wends its way around probably 2 kms away from the mausoleum but is extremely well organised, no pushing in due to the vigilance of the security. Eventually you are shuffled past Ho Chi Minhs body( literally 10 seconds) and just like that it's over! After all that waiting in line. No photos allowed inside where the security is again vigilant.

Great place to learn more about HCM's history. Great museum to learn about the history of HcM. The museum is all about the ex president of Vietnam. Great place to spend on a hot and sunny day. Gardens are beautiful with army recruits having their run.

The Great. Ooh what a great respect for a Great Leader if you miss to watch this i can say simply your trip is useless and meaning less even you pass after 1 Kilometer Queue also you will be satisfied after watch Great Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum

Interesting experience. Apparently Ho Chi Mihn actually wanted a simple cremation but upon his passing it was decided he would be embalmed and displayed.Other than regular trips to Russia to have the embalming worked upon ( I suppose they are world experts given their maintenance of Lenin) he is at this free to enter exhibit.It is more interesting to see the Vietnamese peoples reaction (glee) to seeing Ho Chi Minh than anything else, however the marble work in the building is beautiful.Come early and enjoy a quick free unique experience. Any later and the long queuing in the hot sun will taint the experience.You have to dress respectfully, within sight of the body there is no talking, no laughing and unfortunately no photographs.The armed guards do not look like they take their jobs lightly or could take a joke.

Couldn't work it out!. Not many other people seem to have had this issue but we couldn't work out how you got in. Maybe we were lacking a few brain cells that morning or maybe it was closed but either way we only saw the building from the outside . Would suggest getting some advice from your hotel before heading over there, as it was difficult to get information once there.

Worth the visit. We weren't sure what to expect visiting the tomb of the Ho Chi Min, but as we lined up with the locals dressed in there best clothes we began to understand how revered he is to the Veitnamese people.Don't let the large crowds put you off. You aren't allowed to stop when you are inside and the pace moves steadily. You might be asked to leave your camera behind before you enter. No photographs allowed to be taken inside.Once you leave the Mausoleum the path leads you the the presidential palace which is beautiful.You have to pay for this part but it isn't much and worth it to wander the stately grounds.

Interesting but don't expect much time there. I believe this is a good destination for Vietnamese or people with a connection to Ho Chi Minh.With all due respect, to a westerner it is a large building with a huge "runway" amount of land but nothing that interesting to see.I'm happy I've been and seen where it is, but I wouldn't be one to line up in the massive heat for what is said to be a couple of second look at his body.As I said.. If you are in the area go check it out but you will be there for about 10 min tops.

Interesting to see important cultural site. The mausoleum is interesting to see, and Uncle Ho's body is really there looking all life like. You just walk by it for about 5 seconds, which is honestly more than enough time. The line for it is almost always very long, especially on the weekends because all the school children go for field trips. It moves pretty fast though. After seeing him, the best part is going to his Stilt house and seeing where he lived and worked. There's some really interesting things there, and I enjoyed that part much more than the actual mausoleum. If you happen to be in the area in the evening, it's fun to watch all the vietnamese people doing their exercises in the lawn in front of the mausoleum!

Stalinist design to both the mausoleum and the plaza . We were actually there on the wrong day of the week and so could not go inside. However upon first arriving there it immediately made me think of the Red Square mausoleum in Moscow. Surrounded by open air, open plazas, and brutalist architecture, it is at least also nicely further surrounded by trees and grassed areas. One to cross off your list, especially if you get to see the body of Ho Chi Minh himself.
The Queue is way way too long. Hours of queuing required to get in & in the sticky heat we could not bear the thought so we walked around the outside which was OK.

Visit uncle Ho. This building was once voted one of the ugliest buildings in the world, I have not seen all buildings in the world, but it could be true. Diffidently a visit worth if you're in Hanoi, just remember if you want to go inside wear long pants.

Surreal experience. Worth going to and a surreal experience if you are from the west. Queues can obviously be very long, but they move quickly. It is worth getting here early. No water, no short shorts or uncovered shoulders. Small bags are fine and we did not have to check in our camera, although no photos are allowed inside or as you approach the mausoleum. You can take pictures when you exit.

Uncle Ho. We had a bit of trouble access ing the Mausoleum. It is really a local pilgrimage. Ho Chi Minh is so revered here. We did line up and see the body of Ho Chi Minh. Very eerie. We appreciated the opportunity. Well worth a visit.

Nice place to visit in Hanoi City for History lovers. This place is really good. Better to travel during evening (before 5:30 PM) . If you want to see Ho Chi Minh's body then need to visit by 10:30 AM (be ready for long line) . If you do not want to see Ho Chi Minh's body then travelling in the evening is good . This place is really good .

Peaceful place.. Though this place has a great history, so you definitely visit this. Its a peaceful place, a little far from old quarter. You can rent a bike for a day and visit this place. A lot of embassies are here. Its a good place to take walk with your partner in evening.

A Must See. It was pouring with rain the day we took our two daughters, but it was still worth the trip, especially to see the wonderfully preserved "Uncle Ho". Our young daughters found their first encounter with a dead body "really cool". Whether it is actually him or a wax model I have no idea, but the crisply dressed guards and sense of ceremony that come with a visit to the mausoleum of the father of modern Vietnam make it a terrific experience.

See Ho Chi Minh's preserved body. Long queues and it closes from 11.00am - 2.30pm on a Sunday and similar breaks on other days. It took about 30 minutes to eventually see the body of Ho Chi Minh and the huge queues give an idea as to how revered he is.Excellent grounds and surrounds as well.

Historical and interesting . We went on a lovely 38 degree day and we had the choice of visiting the mausoleum and opted to just do the grounds tour. This avoided a 90min line or so I'm extreme weather. Plenty of history around and you did walk past the mausoleum on your way. Do a tour, you need about 90 min and it can be very busy even when going the grounds. Take plenty of water. Worth visiting, in the heat, not good for young children.

Worth a visit . Definitely worth a visit if you are in Hanoi, an amazing experience which allows you to see an important figure in Vietnamese history and it's free! You leave bags etc at the entrance which is all professional and legit so nothing to worry about

So respect. We had chance to visit Uncle Ho - The great person leading Vietnamese to take independent from France and America. We respected to him and all Vietnamese. We took some souvenir to remind us about this very nice resting place of Uncle Ho

you will see the Founder of this country. The body of HCM is laid inside, guarded by 4 guard.to get inTo this building, some said that you cannot use short pants.Its very formal building, and lots of aoldier, but compare to the taiwanese soldier that i saw, i prefer the taiwanese which is famous for the ceremony of changing shift.you may not take pics once you are inside the building. You will circle the place which HCM laid, with a very limited lighting.overall, even the queu line sometimes a bit long, but it worth to see inside

Please be serious. Thankfully there was a really short queue to see Uncle Ho as I understand at peak times you can wait hours. You shuffle along in a queue to get to the entrance and the guards in white uniforms are quite intimidating. As you mount the steps in side the building you turn a corner and there he is, in a glass case. You cannot speak or gesticulate, just walk solemnly past as the guards are all around. Once outside you can reall appreciate quite how ugly the building really is

Go super early, cover your shoulders, and follow their instructions!. You have to go to this super early b/c many tour groups arrive and you have to wait in line to enter the Masuoleum. You need to purchase tickets (cheap) and leave your bags after clearing security. They allow only groups of people who're not part of tours to enter the property (there's a separate line-up for tour groups) and then walk in rows of 2. NO cell phones/cameras allowed so keep them inside your pocket otherwise you have to leave them at a checkpoint. After walking along with instructions, you enter the Mausoleum in files of 2 inside at a slow pace and the guards there will instruct you to walk along to keep the line going. There he is, lying in the center with 6 guards in position watching you and guarding the body in a glass cage. Lots of locals visit so definitely go early. Also, there is a dress code; you have to cover your shoulders out of respect in your attire; no tank-tops or tube tops. You don't want to disappoint yourself for not wearing appropriate attire. Also, that whole area has very strict entrance and exit; it's hard to get around the property easily. Also, tour groups and your own enter at two separate locations so be sure the taxi drops you off at the right one.

Wow. This was truly an experience. Be sure to keep all belongings in your bag (ie sunglasses) and cover your shoulders. Be quiet and respectful when entering the building. Although children were present, I wouldn't necessarily recommend.

HCM. Worth doing only because you don't get too many chances to visit a mausoleum like this. The line goes for miles but does move quickly. No pictures allowed and you have about 10 seconds to make your mind up if it is the preserved remains of HCM or a waxwork model

Historical. It's a mausoleum, it has Ho Chi Minh's body. That's it. Just like the one in Beijing. I saw quite a lot of local people visiting and paid their respect to Ho Chi Minh and that was honourable. It got quite a strict entry rule : no shorts, no tank tops visible shoulder, no camera, no water. And even stricter one inside the mausoleum : no loud talks, no walking outside the carpet, no stopping. But that's what made it a solemn visit. A bit disappointed that the staffs at the front gate couldn't see that we don't understand Vietnamese, but still blurted out orders in Vietnamese. On our day of visit, it was drizzling and the staff either told us to keep moving (because we stopped to wait for the rest of the group) or any other, because it was drizzling. But we were lucky and there were not much queue that day, we didn't stop until we reach the mausoleum. And even luckier, the entrance to the mausoleum is in form of stairs and one of our group members was in wheelchair. Since the mausoleum is guarded by guards, they were kind enough to carry the wheelchair (like some VIP guest) up. Afterwards, it was a tour to visit the gardens and residence of Ho Chi Minh, it was quite normal. Make sure to take a picture of the mausoleum structure once you're outside.
Not to be missed. We went to see him and I was what the hell, he had been dead for nearly 50 year and looked very good, but we must remember this was not what he wanted,

Interesting to see but not a must unless you're really interested in the history. The day was very hot and I definitely underestimated the local crowds. The queue was very long but it moved quite quickly. It helped that I found some fellow tourists to chat to. Seeing Ho Chi Min was really interesting and much better than I had expected. Remember to cover shoulders and knees out of respect or u won't be allowed to enter.
My Journey My Views . It Was A Wonderful Experience For Me To Pay My Homage To The Statesman And Great Leader Of Vietnam Ho Chi Min There With The Most Patriotic Feeling And Proud.

Sombre. You will only get to see the corpse of Ho Chi Minh very briefly but it is worth it (considering it is free).Practical advice:1. Check the opening times. It is only open at certain times. You have to queue but there are soldiers to shepherd you along2. The entrance of the mausoleum is in the southwest corner (at the corner where Le Hong Phong meets Ngoc Ha) but the queue stretches northward along Ngoc Ha. 3. Don't bring bottles of drink, since you can't carry them in. If you have a large bag, they will ask you to store it at the lockers. Small handbags are OK to carry in. You are not allowed to use phones or cameras in or before the Mausoleum but you can take photos after you exit the mausoleum.4. The mausoleum is air conditioned, which is a respite from the Hanoi heat. The corpse is dimly lit and is guarded by four soldiers. If you get the timing right, you will see a changing of the guard.

Place to go. Please note that tee shirt coverjng shoulder and long short/trousers are required, otherwise you wont get in...It is far too hot to wear this tyoe of clothes but it is worth it.The mausoleum is very quick to see / visit although there was a pretty long queue. (You are not allow bags or camera or food/water inside)The intersted bit for me was the building around the mausoleum with the house if ho chi minh for example.Verry busy place, would recommend to go early

Worth a visit to view the corpse of one of the most revered men in Vietnam. A landmark which is worth a trip to view the well preserved corpse of one of the most revered men in Vietnam. Dress appropriately, without exposed shoulders or legs.

If you are in Vietnam, you have to visit this.. Part of the local culture, part popular devotion, part propaganda, definitely history and understanding of Viet's fantastic people.The solemnity, the lines, many locals visiting it. He, Ho Chi Minh the father of this country there lying in a window coffin. Apart from Lenin in the red square I don't remember another case of historic leader to be seen this way.If you are around and don't go, is a sin.

The Line to Get In Was for At Least 3 Hours. We went to visit here on a Sunday and we just couldn't get inside, the line was non ending, just to reach end of the line took us over 20 minutes and it was still further. It is open just for a few hours, hence we wouldn't manage to reach inside and it was peak summer and didn't have patience to wait in the heat. Requested one of the police to guide us to the museum and it had a detailed exhibition about Ho Chi Minh, hence got a good view of his life and struggles (though not all was mentioned in English). It was crowded and most of them were really noisy, there should be silence so that the visitors can absorb the atmosphere but the cacophony spoilt the complete visit. They need to get a little strict and make the visitors realise it is not a picnic spot as was being treated.

Remember to check the opening hours. . We went to the mausoleum around 13 pm just to realise that the mausoleum closed for visitors at 11 am (opening hours 8-11 am). The mausoleum was not that exciting seen form the outside..

A Must. you must visit here, very busy at weekends, so avoid if you can , but if you have no choice get there at least 1 hour before opening, open 8.30am- closes 11.30am, we got their at 7am on a Sunday got in at 8.40 am, you only get a walk past view but definitely worth it.

See the body of Ho Chi Minh. A must-see in Hanoi. It's only open during certain months for about two hours a day - check in advance for availability. The display is free for all. When we arrived, we had to throw out all liquids and walk through a long maze to get to the mausoleum. My camera was confiscated and held at the security checkpoint until after I had exited the display. Going in, you walk single file with hands to your side, silent, to show respect. It was a beautiful experience. The interior of the mausoleum is very clean and well kept. The body itself looked almost waxlike.

Fantastic . I love history and the history of Vietnam. So going here was amazing for me. Although there is so much propaganda throughout the museum. The people were nice and the information given was amazing
Uncle Ho is looking good. Ho Chi Minh is laid to rest here. His body looks remarkably good. They are doing a great job with this mausoleum. The surrounding area is worth seeing as well.

Mausoleum and surrounding attractions . The mausoleum was a moving experience. Very well organised and marshalled. The palace, gardens and lake, all great photo opportunities. Very happy to have experienced.
Ho ch iminMausoleum. A must to see the preserved body of a great man for his country is a must it is somber but the respect shown to this man for what he did for his country is immense.

Interesting piece of history. We could not go inside the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum the day we visited as it was being spruced up for the upcoming Peoples Congress the next day. It is quite imposing from the outside, and there were many soldiers about in full dress uniforms guarding it. I wondered what Ho would have thought of his grave-site being a tourist attraction.

It's ok to visit if you are around.. I don't feel like here is a must. It's good to visit if you are just around. Overall, you will see their sodiers in action if you are lucky to visit in the right time.

Worth a visit if you have time . We stayed in Hanoi for 3 nights and then a subsequent 2 nights while visiting elsewhere. My chance we were visiting mainly over the weekend and as it was school holidays in Vietnam, the mausoleum was packed. We managed to squeeze in a morning trip on Tuesday (it's closed Mondays like most attractions) and while it was interesting, I could easily have given it a miss. Do it if you have time. First thing on a weekday morning. We arrived at 745 for the opening at 8 and left the mausoleum at 830 and that was before all the military personnel had paid their respects.
Great visit. This is probably the # 1 attraction in Hanoi that gives you a lot of the countrys history. Plan on spending a few hours including great park and museum.

Must see. The Mausoleum pays tribute to Uncle Ho, who, I suppose can be called the father of the nation. Its very well managed and even though there was a very long queue, we were very quickly able to reach the sanctum santorum. The mausoleum is free to visit by Uncle Ho's house/office needs a ticket to visit

Worth seeing it. It was nice to be able to see Ho Chi Minh's body irrespective of whether you agree with public display of a dead statesman's body is a good thing or not. There were long queues but our guide was smart and he took us there just 20 minutes before it closed.The Mausoleum is open only for short period of time so check out the opening times before going there.

Very Interesting. My boyfriend and I visited the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and we both agreed it was not what we expected. I wish I had have read reviews before we went to we were aware wee had to check our bags in at the entrance and were not told how to collect them. When we asked how, we were given several different answers which ended in us both being rather frustrated and unsettling as our bags contained our passport. Turns out we had to walk all the way back around 2 blocks to get back to the entrance to collect our stuff, which no one told us when we checked out bags in. Luckily for us there were 2 guys from Northern Europe who were in the same boat as us and we eventually all found our way back to collect our bags.Seeing Ho Chi Minh's preserved body was interesting, he looks a little like a rubber chicken. He is very heavily guarded by security guards that are paced out every 5 metres or so. There are very strict rules you must cover your shoulders and knees before entering into the Mausoleum and must walk in 2 lines side by side, no arms folded across your chest and no holding hands. Would recommend seeing it as it was very interesting but once you've seen it you probably don't need to go back again.
Worth A Visit. Well worth a visit - but get there early to avoid queuing for too long. Queues are orderly and there are plenty of staff on hand to keep everyone moving.

Interesting experience . We visited the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum and found the experience to be very interesting and a testament to how much the Vietnamese love and respect Uncle Ho.Admission is free; however there is always a queue to enter and view his embalmed body.It is important that you dress conservatively, with clothing covering shoulders and knees. Photos are not allowed inside the mausoleum or of the body, and bags with food, water etc. are stored free of charge.Once inside the complex you can also visit the Ho Chi Minh museum for 40k dong. It was extremely crowded and hot inside and so I did not really enjoy it.You can also pay another 40k dong to enter Ho Chi Minh's house and see where he lived and his collection of cars (we didn't do this part).

Taste of Hanoi. I'm a Japanese living in India.I love and respect India.Then, when I visited Hanoi, I felt a bit sad because... Hanoi is very ... clean ...While Hanoi can do it, why many of Indian cities are messy, dirty, and confused.I'm working on improving Indian social infrastructure. I hope it works.

Strange and surreal. You are not allowed to take anything with you so you either put your things in a locker or your tour guide holds them. No cameras is important.I felt very much like I was a beef cow walking along the ramp waiting to be stunned and killed. We were ordered to walk in pairs and very slowly, in a trancelike state, in a maze formation to get to the mausoleum. Along the pathway there are men in army uniform holding their guns. It was horrifying! After the 20 minute or so walk to get to the building you are told "no talking, no stopping" as you get about 1 minute to walk past the wax Ho Chi Minh. Then you are outside and you can talk and take photographs and buy soft drink and all the usual. It was just plain strange.The rest of the complex has other government and official buildings as well as the little wooden hut that Ho Chi Minh lived in.

Visit if you want to know about Vietnamese Culture . Nice place to know about Vietnamese culture n Ho Chi Minh and his sacrifice for freedom of Vietnam. A visit to museum will enhance knowledge of young children about history of Vietnam.

Long walk for quick look. Not sure of cost as it was part of a package. If you are a woman you cannot visit the mausoleum with bare shoulders so you will have to buy a shawl or use something to cover up or they WILL NOT let you continue. No food, large cameras or large bags in the mausoleum area they make you check it in at the entrance. I really don't know why because there are soldiers with bayonet guns all over the place. They probably wouldn't hesitate to point it at you if you did something wrong. The walk to the mausoleum seems to take forever. The good thing is the pathway is all undercover. We were told sometimes on the weekend it can take up to 2 hours to quickly walk past and see Ho Chi Minh embalmed body. No photos in there. All that lining up and it's a circular walk and your out of there. After this you can see the grounds of Ho Chi Minh palace, his cars, and other smaller houses he chose to live in through out his life. You really need an informative guide to tell you the history. The signs around the complex are in English as well. Near the exit are souvenir and food shops.
Busy . We went on a Saturday. Crowds and line up were massive. Moved fast. Lots of other stuff to see close bym

What Ho Chi Minh certainly did not want. Once dead you have no say anymore. To be put into this mausoleum, being flown to Russia every so often to 'renew' the body with chemicals is something that Ho Chi Minh certainly did not want.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. it is complex. the museum is beautiful. The one pillar pagoda is small but unique and sounds interesting. It is presidential palace where current president works

Beware with the schedule of opening. Too bad we cannot get inside since we were wrongly pick the day of visit. I forgot what days they are open but if you wanted to give a visit, make sure you check from the hotel or website,not simply walking in like us.

amazing place. went here on Saturday at 7.15am (45 minutes before it opens) and there was at least 3 thousand people in the line before us. The queue went quick and within 1 hour and 15 minutes we were inside the mausoleum, seeing the body of Ho Chi Minh. The place is busy but very quiet.
good to see. this is the place nice to see but a bit to busy on sunday because of Viet Nam people go for traveling

Within expectation . The hotel told us the place closes by 11am so we gotta be early. Read online re the dress code to "cover knees n shoulders" so we were "appropriately covered". (However, looks like this is not strictly enforced as we see many tourist in shorts/ tank tops etc). When we arrived, we saw a long queue and was guided to join the queue. We had no idea if we need to buy a ticket (we didn't). The queue was orderly + quiet and before we knew it, we saw HCM. Was impressed by how organized everything was. There were guards everywhere - which Prob helped ensure orderliness. No pictures allowed. After we came out of the building, it was "free & easy" to roam around the place & take as many pic as one like.
Historic site. Check it out if you have the time and watch the change of guards. Grab some pictures as the ground is expansive.
Nice place. It is so nice place for visiting. It is quite busy at the weekend because local pepeople.Ho Chi Minh is great person who we really respect

HERO OF VIETNAM. The depth of respect shown by the Vietnamese people for the Late Ho Chi Minh is quite moving. The queues were long and there was quite a wait but it was worth the walk to the mausoleum. Well presented in an impressive air conditioned building the visitor has a clear close-up view of the man who led and won the fight for Vietnam against the considerable foreign forces.

Seeing hi Chu minh. You have to go and see him when in Han-Oi it's a very special place but remember if you do you have to cover your shoulders and not to have knees showing as a sign of respect...you go in and see him but not allowed photos or to speak inside and it's very quick as you can't stop and look but continuously walk around him..this is a must do thing

Really interestinf. If you are a westerner, I would highly recommend this experience. Totally unlike anything I've ever seen and something that the local Vietnamese people frequent. But be careful of very long lines on the weekend - best to go in the morning during the week if possible.

Do not miss it. Almost people coming to Hanoi will visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum to be introduced about Ho Chi Minh and History of this country. However, I must say that you can consider to coming here everyday on 6Am to expericen the Saluting ceremony at Ba Dinh square or Flag lowering ceremony take place at 9:00 PM. You will have chance to see how's Vietnamese people respect and doing during that time. I am sure that you will have really meaningful moment and memory.
Impressive and very big! . Very impressive building. It is massive and it is interesting to see. So much culture and history. The whole city you see the famous how Chi min. Worth a visit.

Strange to visit. Like visiting a prison, visiting a mausoleum is a strange affair. But, the obvious reverence of the people for the memory of Uncle Ho (Ho Chi Minh) was fascinating the observe. People were willing to wait for hours in the humid, rainy morning just for the chance to quickly walk past and pay their respects. Unfortunately, you could not stand and contemplate (something I find more interesting to do in cemeteries).

An outdoor activity that reflects history and culture. The old, Soviet-style mausoleum and military parade grounds are a bit of a relic of history, and the central location give this the feel and importance of the US Capital Mall. It's an essential site. The changing of the guard isn't worth planning your visit to see, but it's nice serendipity if it occurs while you're there.

So dignifidely managed... Touched by the respect & the honour shown to the celebrated leader. Everyone are instinctively influenced to conduct themselves in a way befitting of the dignity of the place. Thanks Vietnam. We salute you

Patriotism in Action. As a Tourist I don't think I will ever get inside. It is a fantastic site to see the thousands of Vietnamese lining up under kilometres of mobile extendable awnings to visit Uncle Ho. The whole district is nice to wander around in

Really cool!. Ho Chi Minh would be rolling over if he knew how large of a spectacle this is given he requested a cremation! But it's definitely worth seeing, just make sure you check it out during the week as earlier in the day. The line up can be up to 2 hours long! We waited only 20mins but we were also there by about 9am. Make sure to cover your shoulders and knees. The line up might look long but it moves fairly quickly. People will be pushy in line but just be patient, it's worth the 5min walk around Ho Chi Minh's dead body!

Interesting experience. We saw huge queues for this when we arrived and almost gave it a miss. But decided to go ahead. The queue moved fast and was mostly in shade. Security is high, and protocols such as no sunglasses and strict two line queueing were interesting. After viewing the body you have the opportunity to walk around some lovely outdoor areas then into the museum. We were only partway through that at 12:30 on a Sunday when we were advised it was closing time. (We began queuing at 10:30 to give you some idea of how long to allow.)

Definitely BIG. Quite a monolith, it was raining when we visited which suited the sombre atmosphere. The size of the monument equates to the feeling they have for Ho Chi Minh in the north of Vietnam. We didn't go in as it was closed but I would have liked to see inside. Maybe next time.

Important Historical site. I would recommend visiting the Mausoleum, Ho Chi Minh is very important to the Vietnamese people. If you want to go inside the Mausoleum to see Ho Chi Minh make sure to check when it is open, it is only open a few days a week (and I think only in the morning).

Must do. You must do this if you visit Hanoi!The visit runs along smoothly and there is no waiting around. After the mausoleum you can visit the grounds for a fee. Well worth it. We didn't visit the museum as there were a lot of school children. The museum was another part and another fee.

Interesting. You have to hand over your camera but can pick it up after you have been through the Mausoleum.It is a long walk from the gate to the Mausoleum where he lies, but it basically a quick walk past and out of the building. The palace and grounds where amazing, and it is Vietnams history.
Understand Vietnam. . Take the time to visit this site. You will understand the soul of the Vietnamese people. It is steeped in ceremony and honour

Good place. I came and would like to know more Ho Chi Minh . It was a great chace for us to find this place
You should go this place when you come to Hanoi

Quite interesting. Everything that you need to know about Ho Chi Minh is on the second floor.
The third floor holds the exhibits. Which repeats what is said on the second.

Open only in morning to view body . Huge queues so went elsewhere first. Came back when it was closed for viewing the body. Place empty. Great.
Viewed from outside. Building nothing special. One pillar pagoda behind. Also nothing special.
Beautiful walk through History. We really enjoyed the HCM Mausoleum. Loads of information in English as well. The Stilt house is an incredible piece of architecture even all these years later,

Busy!. I went to the mausoleum today and don't think it was worth the trip. (Disclaimer: I went mid-morning, on a Saturday, during the Vietnamese school holidays - not a good idea!)I arrived at about 9.30 to find thousands of people in a huge, snaking queue out in the sun. I joined the line, not wanting to miss out, but I really regret it.The kilometres-long line (no exaggeration) moved decently quickly, but it was still about an hour until I got to enter the mausoleum. Bring a hat and sunscreen.You need to deposit any bags and cameras before entering the mausoleum - the signage is very clear and you don't really lose any progress in the line. It is free of charge.Seeing Ho Chi Minh was pretty cool, although you're whisked along very quickly, so you spend less than a minute in the mausoleum itself. You enter the room in two lines, and the left line gets a better view, so aim to be in that one.After exiting the mausoleum, you end up in a park area (forgive my ignorance; I don't know what it's called or what its purpose is). A long pathway leads you through the park, souvenir shops, cafes, etc. After about a kilometre you may reunite with your bag +/- camera!Overall, it was an ok experience. I definitely recommend going early in the morning (apparently it opens at 8am), on a weekday, when it's not the school holidays.P.S. Don't believe Wikipedia when it says to wear long pants/trousers! Barely anyone wore long pants. I did wear them and sweated so much! Just dress sensibly with shorts/skirt at knee level and shoulders covered.

Not much to see but worth a visit!. It is a mausoleum so don't expect much! The mausoleum itself is small but the surrounding area is spacious. The most surprise thing to me is how people is so silent and in order when they are here. Totally different with outside. Interesting!
Travel. Beautiful gardens and buildings full of history. Ho Chi Minh's private dwelling, vehicles and an understanding of his humble life

How can you not pay homage........ Worth a visit for several reasons - understand a little bit of history and start to ask questions about leadership and respect. Uncle Ho is taken annually to Moscow for a spruce up, so that he stays in good shape for the crowds. Go early and enjoy the grounds at the same time. Even if you do not go in to the mausoleum, take a stroll around the square early evening and enjoy the local spectacle of the changing of the guards and hanoi families enjoying their evening constitutional.

Mausoleum and Garden. The Mausoleum was beautiful and the grounds were very spacious. Definitely worth the walk or time to see the resting place of Ho Chi Minh. The guards are strict, but be respectful and it is easy to enjoy the sight. Great area as the garden and pagoda are close by.

Must visit when in Hanoi. Best to visit this place early in the morning before the crowd set is. We didn't experience the long wait at all (maybe we just got lucky). When inside the mausoleum, it is a quick visit to see the father of Vietnam. You will be going through multiple checkpoints/gates but it is all worth it.

A must visit in Hanoi. You've got to go to this place when in Hanoi! Not only to pay respects to the father of this country but to see the difference in Vietnamese behaviour when visiting their idol compared to being on the street - silence, order, it's amazing! Make sure to check the opening times and days with your hostel/hotel before going, as I'm pretty sure last entry is 1030am and I can't remember what days it opens.

Cultural interest. We visited the Mausoleum and surrounding area. The structure is brutalist in design and is a very clear reminder that this is a communist structure. The queuing system is well organised and takes you in one side and out the other. Seeing Ho Chi Minh embalmed is quite surreal as you troop past him. He is still highly revered by the people of Vietnam and as a consequence tourists should be very respectful both in dress and behaviour when visiting this site.After visiting the mausoleum it is really interesting to visit his residence and see the contrast between how he lived and how he has been preserved in death.

Sacred place, should visit once. Although have to queue up a long line, and enter the mausoleum slowly, but each time I visit it, I also feel that's a sacred place, where Uncle Ho lying there. Vietnamese have a great love to this great man, like their father, grand father.

Long wait but worth it. The wait was 2 hours but we felt it was worth it to go through the masoluem. We were the very few western people in the line but great history attending. Out of respect definitely need to wear a skirt or pants that cover your knees.

Nice experience. Before entering on Ho chi Minh Mausoleum be sure to fall in line in the main gate. They have a tight security check if you carry a bag with you pass on the security scanner otherwise a second security will call you're attention. You have the option to view on the outside of the mauseleum or you want to go through the longest line to get inside. It was been a nice experience for me that i included it on my itinerary.

Incredible . Visiting the resting place of Ho Chi Minh was an honour.....an incredible man who brought the people of Vietnam together. Not suitable to take very young children/babies into the Mausoleum itself where Ho Chi Minh's body is but the rest of the facility is open for everyone.

So very different from anything in the west. this was a great experience to actually see the man who lead Vietnam to freedom. you hear so much about leaders in school but here you can actually see one laid in state. something that never happens in the west. Just make sure you pay your respects take your hat off and keep quiet etc. it's a must visit in hanoi.

Interesting, but not that Impressive. The mausoleum has a very long line almost any time of the year. It is a little Eerie in terms of the extraordinary reverence they show for Ho Chi Minh. Preserving a body for that long leads to lots of speculation about whether it's real or not. The grounds around the mausoleum hold more interest in terms of open space with well-manicured Gardens , pounds, and hosting used by Ho. Worth the visit but overrated.

Historic Ho. This is a must visit during your stay in Hanoi. But be prepared for a long queue. We went on a Saturday morning getting to the site by just after 8am. We queued for an hour in the heat although I thought it was going to be longer going by the length of the queue. But this visit is extremely efficiently organised by the military. We moved along quickly only stopping for a security check and handing in my iPad. Then it is a quick walk around Uncle Ho, but not too quick. Very sobering experience as all around you are local people paying homage to the great leader. Afterwards you can visit Ho's Presidential Palace for a small fee.

What you see is what you get. We got there thinking that we could go in. Wrong. You stand outside in the blistering heat, behind a line on the road infront of the guards on the steps to stare at a closed door. Looking at this picture is sufficient.

A brilliant person. It's a place to commemorate the Father of Vietnam: Ho Chi Minh.
Note to wear formal clothes and keep silent your children.

When in Hanoi . When your in Hanoi don't missed this place or else your trip isn't complete, my girlfriend booked for a city tour from the hotel where we stayed and visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was included. The place is one of the best tourists attraction in Hanoi, but sad to say we're not able to get inside the mausoleum because there's a lot of people queuing just to get in. It seems that the line was endless that there's no room for you to insert yourself. However, it's worth the visit!.
It's a mausoleum, so not too exciting. Part of the history but don't expect too much. It's a mausoleum after all. Must visit I guess, but didn't think it was great.

Historical place to visit in Hanoi. I recommend that you should bring some iced water if possible. (fill up a bottle of water and freeze it) the weather during July, August and the beginning of September is very very hot and humid. By the time that you get to the mausoleum and wait for the line the ice will thaw. If you're not used to the hot sun you should also bring hats or umbrella (it won't be a strange thing since Vietnamese use all means to avoid the sun). I think it's closed on Mondays so you should check out their info so that you time won't be wasted. I did not enter the mausoleum but I went to the museum and the old house where the President lived. It was a very nice experience and I got to see so much of the history and also the President's ordinary life. We had an English speaking guide with us. I'm not sure if we have to book in advance or not, but I think there are always guides who are ready to help you.

It's Ok!. We were very much interested in Vietnam's history and culture and it's included in or city tour. And we were not dissappointed. It's, however, too crowded with a long queue and too hot this time in Hanoi!

Just did the muesu. Well we went with the intention to see all of it but when we found a 2 hour queue to see Ho Chi Minh we just decided to do the free museum. Goodness knows what time they start queuing from but there were thousands there.One point to stress is "don't" get a taxi from out side the perimeter of the mausoleum.The drivers assure you the taxi is metered, which it is, but he's probably set it to the most expensive rate. We paid and extra £10 for a 10min ride we found out later. Our fault but a lesson learnt.But the mausoleum and grounds are defiantly worth a visit.

Good for those who loves history. A well respected great man by all vietnamese. Being told that all vietnamese have to visit his mausoleum at least once in a lifetime. Thats where you can get to know about Ho Chi Minh's life when he is serving his country....

Abandoned ship. We arrived at the mausoleum at 745am and already the queue was right around the park. We walked 2km and didn't see the end of the queue, and that was the queue before you even get into the grounds. In 36 degree heat we bailed, it was too hot to stand in a queue for 2 hours (friends of ours were ahead of us and got through in 70 minutes). If you are going, get there really really early, take plenty of water, the ladies are there to sell you a fan.
Watch the parade. I went after a tour at 9 pm to see the parade with the locals it is very busy but is easy to get a view.

Massive and austere.. Lots of the story of Ho Chi Minh is reminiscent of Kamil Attaturk, in this case his museum in Ankara.The massive flying saucer building over the Green must be the assembly which he can keep a beady eye on!Unaware one could go inside but as we were there on a Monday we would not have been able to anyway. Much more interesting was his house at the back which is a separate "attraction"

Dress Right. Arrives at the Mausoleum to discover we needed to have similar clothes to visiting a Wat in Thailand, was not told by hotel staff, taxi driver and did not see online.Make sure you wear clothes that cover your shoulders and knees (men and women).Long queue so very glad a nice tourist couple let us know before we lined up for an hour only to be turned away.Worth visiting the grounds and Museum (more art gallery dedicated to Ho Chi Minh and his amazing life than historical), 40k pp.

Revered Uncle Ho. Though there was a slight downpour of rain at the time we visited the place, long queue of people are not moving out of the line. It was understandable because Uncle Ho is well respected. No matter how long and slow moving is the line, people are not complaining instead they waited patiently to have their time inside the mausoleum. The visit at the place was worth the time.

Glimpsed of Uncle Ho!. Queue was very long, we waited for 1 hr in hot sun just to catch a less than 15 seconds glimpsed of Uncle Ho. Security is very strict, no big bags, cameras, electronic gadgets, etc.

A trip to understand the great man of Vietnam. High security at the entrance.
