Not allowed to wear shades, sleeve less shirts and for the ladies, no shorts/Bermudas allowed.Walk a very long way from entrance to deep inside the building to view and pay respect to the body of Ho Chi Min. Additional charges are incurred when you choose to enter the museum at VND 40000 per adult.A good way to understand Vietnam's rise over the last 30 odd years.
Just stayed outside. Closed on Mondays and Fridays. Were there on a Friday, so we just stayed outside. Was able to see the changing of the guard which was very interesting.

Hanoi Half-Day Tour. Hanoi Half-Day TourMr. Tiến was our tour guide, who provided an extremely detailed tour of the Old Quarter, the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, the Temple of Literature, and other notable sites within Hanoi. We were thankful for his willingness to pace his tour to my limited walking while sharing with us his vast knowledge of Viet Nam history and points of importance at each of our destinations. We highly recommend the Half Day Cultural Tour, hosted by this gracious guide.

Unusual but worthwhile visit . It really is a fascinating experience to see 'Uncle Ho', especially to see how many people come from all over Vietnam every single day to visit the mausoleum. We found the inevitable queues not bad at all.Before going we found accurate information about the mausoleum - opening times, queues, cameras - hard to come by so hopefully this might help some people.We arrived around 10 am on a weekday to see what already looked like a large queue. However, after quickly passing through the security check, the queue moved pretty quickly and we enjoyed the whole experience in about 30 minutes. Cameras (SLRs etc.) must be placed in a special bag at security check and then handed in just before the queue enters the mausoleum - you get them back immediately as you exit the mausoleum; camera phones were not collected in (but you are not allowed to take photos inside). Shorts seemed OK, but shoulders must be covered and hats and sunglasses removed as enter the mausoleum.The opening times remain a mystery to me (the queue seemed to close at 1030 am?), but getting there early in the morning (pre 10 am) worked for us! Enjoy!!

Probably not worth the time queuing.. Don't get me wrong it was interesting seeing poor old Ho Chi Ming on display but the 21/2 hours queuing was probably not worth the 2mins you get to walk past the body. If you hesitate for just a moment the guards push you along. We did this as part of our Intrepid tour of Vietnam but with hindsight if all the tour members agreed we probably could of spent that time better.

GET IN EARLY!. Didn't actually see the Mosoleum (gave 5 stars to be fair). Just wanted to warn other travellers... Opens at 0800. We arrived then, thinking of a small line (was a Saturday)... Oh my Gosh. The line(s) went for hundreds of meters, we tried walking to the end and gave up. Plan early. So sad we missed it. Bigger line than the Louvre in Paris.

Interesting Place. Visited the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and Museum in May. Found the couple of hours we spent there to be very interesting. Although the lines to pass through the Mausoleum can be quite long.

Just did the outside. We attended on a Sunday and during school summer break. This meant there were extremely long lines to visit the mausoleum itself. Our guide advised us to get there really early if you wish to go inside to view the body. Also it closes @ 11 am so if you are in a long line at that time. Bad luck. I would recommend using a guide. As well as giving local knowledge, we were able to queue jump at the entrances because we were a "tour" even though there was only two of us
Interesting but long heavily controlled queues. An interesting place to visit although it is highly sanitised and controlled with long queues. Armed police and guards are slightly unnerving.

Speechless. So a few days before, I'd had an off road motorbike stack resulting in a bung knee. I arrived on crutches and was promptly offered a wheelchair. Then provided a chaperoned, shaded push past literally thousands of people waiting in line (beware the line). When we got to the Mausoleum (a considerable distance from security check in) I was greeting by 4 military gents who picked me up, wheelchair and all, and carried me up into the 3-4 storey Mausoleum, up and around Ho Chi Minh's resting body (which in itself was amazing to see) down the stairs and out the door. I don't know any where in the world where this level of assistance would be provided to a person with mobility issues. Blew me away.

Be prepared for a wait. We arrive on Sunday morning and the line wrapped all the way around the lake in the park. Had to be a several hour wait so we went to the front of the Mausoleum. Unfortunately we didn't have half a day to wait in line.

Mausoleum visit. Make sure you have something to cover your bare shoulders and knees (for females) even just a scarf is ok. It is free entry for the mausoleum which only takes a couple of minutes to go through but sometimes there is quite a line up to go through, and it is only open for a couple of hours a day. You need a ticket to go through the gardens etc. Not overly exciting but if you have an hour or so to kill, worth looking at.

Very long wait time, several hours. The grounds are beautiful. I'm not sure I can recommend the mausoleum unless you go early. Otherwise you will wait for hours. Inside the rules are very strict ie: no talking, were to put your hands and dress. All rules are to show respect.

If you have a lot of time, you may visit this place. The long queue, and random as well, make the wait more annoying. I should wait for 1.5 hours to finally be able to enter the mausoleum just for 3 minutes stay to see Ho Chi Minh's grave.Well, if you have all time in the world, you may consider visit this place. Otherwise, just spend your time visiting other places.

So strange it is definitely worth a visit. I like strange things so this was definitely up my alley. I went around 9am and only waited about 15 minutes in line, though I was lucky. After going through security you walk a long way on a designed closed in path that takes you to the entrance of the mausoleum. Then you go in and walk through it and see Ho Chi Minh's preserved body. You can see it through the glass sarcophagus. The place is heavily guarded. I didn't get the impression that pictures were allowed in there, so I didn't try.

Go early. We arrived at 9:30 and were told it would take about 3 hours to get through. The line was a long way down the street from the official entrance. Still, we were through the mausoleum by 11 a.m. It was hot, but the line moved at a good pace. Be ready to check any large bags. Small purses and phones seemed to be fine, but pictures are not allowed inside. It's also a good idea to review the dress policy.

impressive.... it's an impressive place governs by stricts rules exclusively written in Vietnamese .There is a whole ceremonial set up and you'll have to follow the rules.
They agree photos and camera

Worth the wait . I visited during school holidays and the queue was enormous! I waited two to three hours. However, I enjoyed the experience in the queue and was fascinated how present day Vietnamese are still in awe of Ho Chi Minh.

Ho's Final Resting Place. This was just about the first place we visited in Hanoi. It was a very hot day and we walked all the way from the hotel. Finding the entrance is a little tricky but some security guards pointed us the right way when I attempted to enter the wrong way. You are not permitted to take photos so they take cameras from you and store them for return later. You have to line up but maybe we were lucky as it didn't seem to take too long. You must be respectful so taking off hats is a given. The viewing is quite short as the need to keep the line moving is paramount for the officers on duty. Ho's body doesn't look too bad. He certainly looks a lot better than Mao in Beijing.

Impressive Communist style building. Resting place of Ho Chi Minh who unified the separate parts of Vietnam after the war. Scores of visitors present to view the mummified body inside.. in an amazing show of public affection. Whole area elks to communist times of past.

Educate Yourself before Visiting. I know many people won't agree with me on this one but I'm just being real... As an American, I liken this national shrine to that of visiting the monuments of Washington, DC. If I were a foreign visitor to our nation's capital, I know I'd appreciate it a little more if I knew more of the background on the person, place and history. In visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, I knew little of this revered national hero and his impact on Vietnam. After visiting the site including the homes and museum, I had a better understanding of his role in Vietnam's long history. This is a 'must see' for many of this country's citizens. School children arrive by the busloads, older folks, tour groups, et al, visit between 7:00 am and 10:30 am (yes, very limited hours) to see the mausoleum and surrounding grounds. The wait can be as long as an hour or so with a long winding line in the morning heat. Other reviews can give the detail of walking into the mausoleum and the protocol (be quiet, no hats or sunglasses - AND NO PHOTOGRAPHY!). Be respectful of their customs, rules and laws. Remember this is a communist country. Would I visit again? Probably not. Is it a must see? Yes, if you read the background and get an understanding of what you will see and experience. Simply put, this helps you put things into perspective.

Be prepared to queue!!!. We arrived at 10.10am and didn't get to see the guy until 10.55, 30 seconds later we were out of the door. We were informed later we did well, you could queue for 2 hours! It is a bit macabre to see a dead man in a glass box, think of it as a dummy and you'll be fine. If you do go, watch out for the queue jumpers who try and push their way to the front while you meander through the queuing system. Is it worth the wait? I don't really think so, do something better with your time.

Long Queue. Went to the Mausoleum but took me ages to find the entrance. By then it was break time but the queue looked massive! Couldn't be bothered waiting for it to open again but the outside is great for pictures. Whilst you're there you can visit the museum, pagoda and the presidential palace.
Do not smile inside. Definite must see, the banners outside and the plaza were great, inside very serious, no photos, guards everywhere

Ho Chi Min in State. This was a very spiritual experience. You do not have many opportunities to see an influential world leader in state. They moved the viewers through the beautiful setting and the queue was hardly noticeable due to the beautiful grounds. You would have taken the walk in any case. The mood was very quiet and respectful, even in the path to the mausoleum. Once you entered the building it was like you were entering a tomb or temple in the middle east. The setting and case Ho Chi Min was placed in was well positioned for viewing and the dress he was entombed in was very exotic. This was a very special way to move forward with a very difficult and recent conflict in our history in Asia. I felt my respect for their leader was a tribute to the wonderful way I was treated in Vietnam.

Interesting time. I visited the mausoleum this morning. I wasn't really sure what to expect, but it delivered on some surprising aspects. First off, there are about 2000 people around. You have to go early, they stop letting people in around 10:30 am I believe. It was very strange getting in. There were many tourists and there were many people who were just paying respects (some were crying). It's worth checking out, but not for reasons one might think.
You have to Do this whilst in Hanoi . It would seem strange not to visit whilst in Hanoi and the visit is what you would expect but interesting nevertheless

Ho CHi Minh Mausoleum. This is a nice place to visit ad learn about the history of the Vietnamese. We spent more than an hour around the area and also went to the one pillar pagoda from here. It was pleasant even the weather was a bit hot

Structure is Impressive. HCM's Mausoleum is beautiful from the outside. We didn't get to actually see his body because 1) the kids were too terrified and 2) the viewing hours are quite strict. Sounds like the viewing is actually very quick (maybe too fast to appreciate) but to see the reaction of local Vietnamese folk would've been interesting. Walking around the HCM Complex is enjoyable in and of itself but do be sure to check viewing times if you are a die-hard HCM fan.

What to say of this..... Place of worship for the locals, somewhat bizarre for tourist visitors. A place that still shows communist dictatorship, must march two by two for the remains of Ho in a glass coffin, wait long cue, be insite for 2 minutes. Enormous squares a la Beijing. Chech if he is home as several weeks they maintain the corps

Blink and you'll miss him. Be prepared for long queues as you get ushered around the site following line after line of compliant Vietnamese. When you eventually get to the entrance of the mausoleum itself, you are told, in no uncertain terms to take off your sunglasses before you enter. You are then ushered around in file and you cannot stop to have a proper look as the guards are straight on your back to keep moving. The whole viewing time of the mummified Ho Chi Minh is less than a minute then you are ushered out the other side to join the multitude in the grounds.For me it was a tick in the box exercise to say I've done it. The grounds are immaculately kept and when viewed from the road, the view of the mausoleum is quite impressive.

More appealing to locals and anyone with a real interest in Ho Chi Min. We were taken on a tour around the outside of the mausoleum. Be prepared to queue for hours and hours. It is treated somewhat like a pilgrimage by Vietnamese people to undertake the visit. I can appreciate and respect the relevance of Ho Chi Min in uniting the country and gaining full independence, but with time a premium, we were happy to visit his residence in the grounds.

Worth the wait if you know about HCM. The line can be quite intimidating, but if you understand the significance of Ho Chi Minh and respect him then it is worth the wait in line. Look yo restrictions before you go in though! No shorts/tank tops allowed.

If you like..... Long linesSweat Umbrella'sPeople pushing & pawing People cutting in lineThis is an activity for you. We got dropped off near the entrance line or what we thought was the entrance line by our Uber a little after 9am. After walking for 10 minutes we found the end of the line. No joke. People we not friendly and ended up pushing or touching me every time the line moved especially if there was sun. We were told we had to have our shoulders covered, pants for men and a skirt below the knees for women. That was not the case there were a lot of tank tops and shorts and you still were allowed. If you bring a camera you must check it. Total wait time 2:06 before reaching the mausoleum. You are ushered up a flight of stairs where you keep walking, there is no time to stop. Total time in the Mausoleum 3 minutes. Plus side a little over 3200 steps for those with a fit bit.

If you're in Hanoi for more than one day; then go in . I thought the queues for the Vatican were long, but this was something I've never seen before; queues for miles from multiple entry points. As we were only in Hanoi for the day, we didn't want to spend hours queuing so passed on it. Ticked the box to say 'seen it' but didn't go in. Instead walked round to the back and enjoyed the Botanical Gardens which were really nice; even in 37 degree heat! They are worth a walk through.

Just to see the 1st person of Vietnam.. You spend time, but it's to see the person who liberate this country, Vietnam, from the most strong state in the world : USA.Ho Chi Minh is the "father" of Vietnam.You must visit, with respect in the history of this country and his people.

Be sure to check hours. We didn't get to see the actual body of Ho Chi Minh because we didn't check the hours and realize that view and entering the Mausoleum was restricted to morning hours. We did get to see the Changing of the Guard. And visit the grounds. I loved the feel and design of the whole park. It was especially profound for me since I am a Vietnam Vet, boots on ground during the Tet Offensive in 1968

Impressive - Line Moves Too Fast. This is an impressive building from the outside and the inside. Quite the monument to Ho Chi Minh. Be sure you're entering at the correct starting point for the queue. My only complaint is that you're ushered through the actual mausoleum too quickly to really take in what you're seeing. Other than that - great place; a must see.
A Must visit in Hanoi. Thousands of school kids line up to see this icon of Vietnamese history. The grounds are interesting and beautiful with many interesting plants and buildings
Interesting. Opens only in morning, Ho Chi Minhs body is in there! One of the 3 frozen body's in the world. It was really interesting, something different to see.
Nice place to walk. This area was a great place to get out for a walk. There's plenty of beautiful old French architecture around the area.

You must visit. We visited HochiMinh mausoleum on monday. It was closed. But we impressive for the Vietnamese people around here for friendly and polite. A little disappinting, but would recommend for visit if you have in Hanoi !

Been there....done that.. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was built on the spot where Ho Chi Minh (not his real name but one of his many aliases), declared Vietnamese independence. The Vietnamese people love Ho Chi Minh ....... but not enough to honor his wishes that he be cremated and his ashes scattered over the countryside of Vietnam. Viewing Ho Chi Minh is a rigidly controlled experience. Guards line people up two by two and people are not allowed to stop walking when viewing Ho Chi Minh. One man walked in clasping his hands in front of him and he was immediately told to put his hands by his side. People musn't touch each other while walking through the mausoleum. No talking of course, not even whispering. Nothing can be carried into the mausoleum. The line of people walk into the mausoleum, along one wall and then across the front of the Mausoleum. Turning their head to the left they can then see the emblamed Ho. There is a light that illuminates Ho. Behind Ho, the wall looks to be dark brown marble. On one half of the wall is a big yellow star and on the other half of the wall is a hammer and sickle, all done in marble. It looks very dignified. Be careful of opening hours - sometimes they are restricted. Also be aware that Vietnam sends Ho Chi Minh to Russia somewhere around September - November each year for re-embalming. So he isn't there during those months. It is worth visiting the mausoleum just to experience the rigid conditions of entry as the viewing of Ho is extremely short. Most interesting is how the Vietnamese people love Ho and to see their reaction and reverence was more interesting then Ho himself.Don't forget the museum , it free to wonder through and also you can see the one pillar pagoda and presidential palace here too.

Very Impressive. This was so interesting. I suppose it's not for everyone, but I thought it was. The way they have him in a glass coffin looking like hes asleep is unbelievable, the technology alone is amazing. Don't plan on taking pictures tho, and no talking either. You get a better sense of the magnitude of the love and respect the people of Viet Nam had for their leader by visiting this site. Well worth the time.

Interesting outing. Worth the hour long queue. A strange thing to do, but 99% of visitors were Vietnamese so it was interesting. To visit the surrounding gardens and where Uncle Ho lived and worked from was very interesting too.
History. The area around the Mausoleum is just beautiful and shows how important they value their history. The around is surrounded by a park and is closed to traffic.

Dried old waxworks . All a bit mawkish for me but it was nice to see the Presidential Palace and gardens and the house where Ho Chi Min lived. It's a good thing to do but you won't do it a second time.....

Umm... It's a fake!! . We went to see the great leaders mausoleum with our Hanoi Kids ambassadors. I really wanted to see him in the flesh. Partly morbid curiosity and partly out of respect for the great man. Firstly most of the visitors are Vietnamese not tourists and it gives insight into the respect and veneration they hold for him. The granite tomb is impressive but sadly no pictures allowed. Once inside you file past his body in silent single file; it's eery and weird! He looks in AMAZINGLY good shape. I visited Lenin's mausoleum in Red Square once and Lenin was wrinkly and did look every bit a mummified corpse. When home I got to looking the subject up. There are theories abound that what we're looking at isn't the real McCoy and that the real Uncle Ho is in a secret location somewhere else. In my humble opinion he looks like a wax work. Judge for yourself....The grounds are pretty and you can wander around looking at his small residence from the outside. Some great old cars to see. All in all it was an enjoyable experience and I can recommend but perhaps not strongly. Can be done in a hour.

Fascinating . Our son, 7 at the time, was very keen to visit: a macabre fascination I expect. It was an interesting insight into the culture. I'm not sure he would have wanted to be so deified. Made me very reflective! We also saw the changing of the guard on another day when the area was deserted. All in all a fascinating experience.

Surreal experience . The masoleum is only open for viewing in the mornings so do go early if you plan to visit. It is closed on Mondays and Fridays. While the queue is long, it moves pretty fast. Do take note of the dress code - no sleeveless and skirts/dresses/ pants should cover the knees.Admission is free. No cameras are allowed in the masoleum.After visiting the masoleum, you can visit the garage of ho chi minh's used cars, ho chi minh's stilt house as well as the presidential palace and the ho chi minh museum, which are near by.
Hi Ho. If you like walking slowly in long lines past a mummified Ho then this is for you. There are no photos and I saw no post cards of the mummy Ho. But the grounds after are great.

Good if you're into seeing Ho Chi Minh. When I went there was a huge line, it moves relatively fast though. They don't allow photography or talking within the building, and once you're in you'll get to see his body. He has sort of an orange glow to him, not sure if it's because of the lighting or whatever they put to preserve his body.

Very Interesting. The mausoleum is a very interesting piece of Vietnamese culture. With that being said, remember to act very respectfully while visiting. There are guards all over the place, and they do not tolerate shenanigans. Only take pictures when they say it is okay, don't shout (raised voices or excessive laughter will get you kicked out) and make sure to dress appropriately. Men- long shorts or pants, no sleeveless shirts. Women- Long skirts or pants, no shoulders or cleavage. Do NOT take your camera out when you are inside the mausoleum!!! Ho Chi Minh's preserved body is inside, and pictures are prohibited. On Sundays, the mausoleum is free, but this means it is very crowded. People from all over Vietnam will be visiting on Sundays, so that means you may run into some people who have never encountered Western people before (white people). When we went, it began to get a bit uncomfortable, as we were being grabbed to take pictures, my hair was being grabbed (as it is blonde), and we were crowed around for photos with or without permission. It is best to just smile and nod and be respectful even though your personal space may be invaded a bit.

Worth the early get up. A man that goes down as one of the most important in history, it is worth getting up and going through about a 2 hour line for a glimpse of his well maintained corpse. No charge but you cant bring a camera and theyll make you check yours in but its safe.

Why do Vietnamese call Ho Chi Minh by Uncle. Vietnamese respect Ho Chi Minh and love him by all there heart. So we call Ho Chi minh Uncle to remind he is our family. You should start your visiting early and stand in line because everyday many Vietnamsese come to Hanoi to visit their Uncle ^^
Uncle ho. Maybe you have to queue up for few mins but worth. Please note cameras and bags are not allowed inside the building. Also mausoleum is closed on Monday and Friday
He looks alive!. The mausoleum is beautiful and it is fun to watch the changing of the guard. However, go on a day when it is open so you can view Ho Chi Minh. He does look alive...incredible!

too long the line. We had to wait in line for 5 blocks outside and then 3 more blocks inside just to pass by the body.
Impressive but you can not stop or talk inside the mausoleum.
Afterwards, we visited the places he used to work or sleep and his cars.
It was very nice but took too long.
Make sure knees and shoulders are covered. An interesting visit to the mausoleum followed by the Presidential Palace and the Ho Chi Minh museum

Catching up with history. Somehow, my timing was not correct and I did not see anyone going it. From checking the internet, I found out that there may be periods when people can go in. This is only in the morning. However, there was also periods of time in the morning when the place was totally devoid of tourists ... still wondering why. So follow the correct group and go in.

The experience starts at the queue!. There are 3 parts to this experience; the Mausoleum, the gardens and the museum. You can enter the gardens and museum separately and avoid the queues or it's a natural progression to do all three at the same time.First, the queue. There is no avoiding this unless you get there hours before the opening time, so come prepared to line up. Tip: The queue is divided into two lines - pick the one next to the wall as this is the side nearest the body in the mausoleum. It also gives you the opportunity to perch on something when the queue is stalled. When we were there, the gates opened at 8.30. We arrived at 7.50 and the queue was already hundreds of people long. It's very ordered and moves quite swiftly once the gates open. We queued for just over an hour. You'll swelter in the heat, so dress for the weather (and modestly if you're intending to enter the mausoleum - see the dress rules). There are lots of local sellers going along the queue offering you the chance to purchase fans, trinkets and bottled water. Don't worry about buying souvenirs,. there's some good shops inside the complex selling reasonably priced and interesting items. Definitely buy a fan - I'm now the proud owner of a Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum style that was very efficient as I slowly melted in the humidity. The locals are very friendly and curious; we had our photos taken with various people we met in the queue and were the object of much interest from the children. I'm sure they will now grow up convinced that at least some westerners are wet and slippery like eels due to my complete inability to handle the heat. Once you're through the gates, you pass through security and must hand over any camera equipment, including phones and ipads. The item will be placed in an official bag and you'll receive a numbered tag that you hand in when you leave the mausoleum area. You won't need to do this if you're only visiting the gardens.The queue keeps moving - you must not stop or pause as you move through the mausoleum. The body of Ho Chi Minh is displayed in a sunken section in the middle of the mausoleum (blessedly air conditioned) so it's easy to see, especially if you're the height or taller of the average westerner. Exiting the mausoleum you can collect your camera gear and proceed around the gardens to the museum. Everything is clearly marked -there's no charge for the mausoleum but there is a charge for part of the gardens though some people appeared to walk straight through. We couldn't figure this out. The gardens of the Presidential Palace are lovely, with Koi ponds and a variety of plants and trees from all over Vietnam. The Museum is of interest as is the Treehouse which is surprisingly chic. By the end of your visit grab some freshly squeezed sugarcane juice and sit under a fan to cool down, then buy some souvenirs in one of the many shops. Despite the queues and the heat (did I mention the heat?), we felt this was a terrific experience. Probably not recommended if you have small children unless they're weirdly patient. Arrive early, check the dress code and opening times, obey the security and make a bunch of new friends!
Grand and intereftig. This was very grand and interesting to hear how they admired this man, would highly recommend it for anyone visiting Hanoi

Very informative...with the "obligatory" guide!. As per my last review about the Presidential Palace, again this attraction is only enjoyed and fully appreciated with a local guide. Luckily we had the best and as with the Palace we learned a great deal about Ho Chi Minh and the history of Vietnam. We were there on Graduation day so therefore we didn't get to see the body of Ho Chi Minh due to ridiculously long queues but that wasn't an issue for us.

Well organised and respectful. After learning so much about Ho Chi Minh during our stay it was fascinating to actually go to the Mausoleum. A little macabe but respectable. Don't be put off by the queues of people, it is highly organised and streamlined.

Peaceful. It's such a big complex, having 3 parts: maosoleum, museum and garden.The whole place is clean and well-organised. Staff is nice. You need to give your camera to the staff (otherwise you cannot enter to the maosoleum) and 10 mins later your camera is at the exit, waiting for you in a locked red bag.
Peaceful night visit. The grounds are quite well kept and an appropriately somber mood prevails. Best seen at night (unless you want to view the body).

Amazing. A very spiritual place for many Vietnamese. Please accept the guards and go with the flow..... you will know what i mean when u get there! See if u can time it for the changing of the guards too!

Respect for the dead, but now back to the living. While I ditched the opportunity to see Lenin lie in state in Moscow, I decided to have a peek at "Uncle Ho" as he was/is known to the Vietnamese. His name also brings back memories of the 1960/70s: the demonstrations, the horror of war, the victory of the Vietnamese people. This visit is rather underwhelming. It is an efficiently run affair, no waiting, it all runs smoothly (at least it did this Saturday 21 May 2016, two day after the commemoration, one day before elections in Viet Nam and two days before the historic visit by Obama. Once in the mausoleum, people are hushed to pay due respect, and one files in a never stopping line along the body of this great leader of modern Viet Nam. It is a bit of a Madame Arthur's experience, he looks rather waxed in the dim light, and his hands seem very small. So while in physical terms it is not a very exciting stay, it has a lot of value in that it gives food for thought. The nearby park with his house etc makes up a nice complement to this more macabre attraction. No pictures allowed!

Historical. The Mausoleum is only a small part of the complex. You stand in line for about ten minutes while Vietnamese military guards quickly usher people through to see Uncle Ho's embalmed corpse. Weird but cool. Then you get to see where he lived and some other stuff. Make sure to go to the museum as well.

Not my thing. Long lines and... in the end it's still just a Mausoleum. I'm sure it's very significant to the Vietnamese but I personally found it a "meh" attraction. I liked the architecture and it was cool to see the honor guard but... meh.
Interesting. Did not expect to visit the mausoleum during our trip but glad we did.Queued for a while along with 100's of school children but it was fine

Architecturally interesting. Ho chi minhs final resting place. You can't take bags or cameras inside here and opening hours are limited (mornings only) and offer attract large queues. Make sure you venture here in the evening for a photo as the mausoleum looks fantastic when lit up. Also please note that most of hanoi historical attractions are closed on a Monday.

Impressive!. It's closed on Mondays and Friday's and only open in the morning for a couple of hours on other days which meant that we weren't able to actually go inside. However, it's worth taking the time to go and see this place anyway because the building is so impressive! They also do a flag raising ceremony every morning and a lowering at 9pm at night which is worth going to as its done by armed guards in a precession with a band playing etc. With the history of this place as well its definitely worth going to!
A good experience. You will find many locals spending their evenings here. A busy place but very interesting. Good views and near to other attractions.
Different adventure. the visit is really interesting. However the queue was quite long and you should try to visit in the fall. The summer is too hot to try.

It took me less than an hour. I was afraid, after reading reviews, that I'd spend all morning there but in less than an hou I was done, and it was Ho Chi Minh's birthday. Interesting thing to see. Very cold inside, obvious reasons I guess.

Seen to put a dot. for me it was like in my chieldhood-when all puples in school shold visit LENIN*S mousoleum...nothing interesting for me(its only my opinion)-also long time u will spend in waiting line.Not reccomend.

A must thing to do in Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is beautiful monument, where Uncle Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body rests. The waiting time can seem be long at the beginning but as soon as you get though from the security check everything moves quickly. I recommend not going in the weekend. The visit inside only lasts about 5-10 minutes but it's definitely worth it. Seeing Ho Chi Minh's body was an amazing experience.

Worth visiting. My friend and me visited the mausoleum on a Wednesday. Although there was a line, it went very fast. From the entrance to the mausoleum we had to walk around 10 minutes, without stopping. Worth visiting!

Queueing to get in and no loitering once inside. The mausoleum is strictly guarded and attracts as many locals as tourists. There is usually a queue io get in and you're not meant to hang about while you're inside. It is definitely worth seeing and experiencing at least once.

Very interesting. The mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh is an interesting experience, after going through airport style security its a long walk through the grounds to a large marble buildings guarded by men in white military uniforms, we were ushered in and in complete silence we walked around the body of the former Communist leader of Vietnam who now lies in state, it is quite a surreal experience but one worth seeing to understand why this man is so revered.
A must visit. What an experience ... just go ...we thought it would take ages but everyone moves quickly and it is so worth it ... the grounds are worth a look as well ..

Surrounding grounds hold most interest. We visited with a private guide who advised us not to line up for the visit to Ho Chi Minh if the line was long. Luckily our wait was only about 10 mins before we were marched through with a group. Interesting but glad we did not need to wait any longer.

Fascinating Insight . You must visit this site where the body of Ho Chi Minh lies embalmed. It offers an insight into the history of Vietnam and it's turbulent past. It also shows the great reverence that the country still holds its past leader in
It was close when we visit. Not too much to see since the museum was close when we visited. but I like the people around. I like the weather in Hanoi.

Part of intrepid tour. A bit of a must do if travelling through Vietnam . Very very long queues were a bit daunting when we first arrived but staff ensure everything keeps moving along. We were in line for almost 1 hour but it was almost all under cover from the hot sun and we chatted amongst ourselves and with others - lots of school children. Impressive to see the reverence held for Ho Chi Min who shaped the country.

Beautiful compound. Respectfully a beautiful compound where Uncle Ho Chi Minh is resting in peace. Please avoid to visit Mausoleum on the weekend because the line will be 1-2 hours long and the time spent inside the Mausoleum is only 5-10 minutes maximum. Please plan accordingly.

Neat museum. We debated about whether or not we would go, but the cheap admission and A/C drew us in. I'm glad we did; it was well worth a short visit. The photos and old posters etc were interesting, as were the HCM relics. The art pieces were interesting, but not the highlight for me. Very cool overall. Also, in my opinion, comments about about the "one-sided" nature of the museum are missing the point.

Unbelievably busy. We went there at the weekend and the queue was horrendous (probably three hours) so we just went around the outside (had to queue for that too). The mausoleum looks austere and no photographs are allowed - you may need to check your camera in before entering.
Interesting place to go. Amazing life story of President Ho Chi Minh. It is very interesting especiallt to all the tourist who has no idea during the the vietnam war.

Long queue even on quiet day but worth going. I didn't want to go. Long queues on a hot day. However queues under covered walkways, kept up momentum and got through in under an hour. Whether you agree with the politics or not this was a great servant leader, humble and inspiring.Good to see where he lived and worked. No visit to Vietnam complete without this visit.

Good to see. Ho Chi Minh tomb was known by the vast majority of Vietnamese individuals and guests. We went there and spent the entire morning around the region. Decent and calm spot. Extremely occupied at the weekend
Not much to see. An impressive Mausoleum if you are into concrete and columns. Not much to see really. On the day we visited we went allowed inside, so a little underwhelmed.
Interesting. Interesting place to go. For some but not others. Avoid saturday as many licals go to pay tribute. Apart from lengthy que of upto 2 hours. I felt i was intruding. Go on a week day
uninteresting. you see a big building. is this how you want to use your time in hanoi?? i think not.. chose something else

A waiting game. It was a good experience and we were really looking forward to coming here, however we waited in line for over 1 hour and we were given approx 2 mins to view Ho Chin Minh before being signaled by security to keep walking.

Endure the long queue only if you like mausoleum visits. We went on a Sunday, but that was a huge mistake. Student groups from kindergarten to high school throng the mausoleum on weekends, and we only found out later that the huge weekend crowd likely came from other provinces outside Hanoi. Water, paper fans and humour/patience are good-to-haves. We started queuing at 740am and only completed the whole experience at 11am. The crowd on our day was 95% local and you simply need to have an excess of humour/patience, as there were lots of queue cutting and jostling, and no one seems too bothered with private space (the guy behind was constantly stepping on my shoes and breathing down my neck). Logistics were not well handled, I had the security personnel shouting and pushing us physically in two files, which obviously no one seemed to observe or care, and of which a proper queue management system with barriers would have 90% solved.Anything larger than a small sling bag must be stored at the luggage storage counter, which obviously adds on to the already considerable hassle, so I definitely recommend going light.Funny thing was, after queuing for nearly 2.5h to get to the entrance of the mausoleum, I saw a tour group of elderly caucasian tourists walking straight in after presenting a wreath of flowers, hence bypassing the crowd and heat. Normally I wouldn't have mind such "priority queues" for "privileged" people (after all in many place you can pay a due to join the express foreigner queue), but I put myself in the shoes of the locals and wonder how they might feel about foreigners' privileges at visiting their own leader. This did not feel quite right, we were not exactly at Disneyland with express lanes. Moreover, the caucasian tourists were happily snapping away with their cameras right in front of the mausoleum. And I thought cameras were strictly forbidden???All in all a very average experience logistically, but I am impressed by how the locals came in forces to pay their respects to their leader. Not quite the same sombre and peaceful experience I had at Lenin's mausoleum in Moscow some years ago, so I would say come join the crowd only if you like mausoleum visits, and be prepared for the long queue.

Impressive grounds. We weren't there when it was open which was fine with us. It was just impressive to see the immensity of the grounds the city has dedicated to the mausoleum. We got to see the guards change which was cool. There's enough other main sites near the mausoleum that it can easily be fit into an itinerary. Just a note, if you're going to take a cab from here to you next destination, make sure it's one of the cheaper ones. The cabs in Hanoi charge vastly different rates and I got the sense that the more expensive ones hang out at this location (we learned the hard way). Would be worth walking a block or two to find a more affordable fare.
Impressive monument. visited here in March, we waited in line for 45 minutes. Once in the grounds the line moves quickly. Interested place to visit.

Not worth the wait . We got there super early and still waited over and hour. The locals have no concept of ques and push in. You glimpse Honda Chi for about 40 seconds as you walk past. If you are in line 2 you have a line of people in front of you blocking your view.

Beware of long queue and short opening hours. The visiting hours are quite short everyday and so there are long queue for both Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum and The Presidential Palace cum Ho Chi Minh's House everyday. They do not open on Monday and Friday. There are student groups and tour groups queueing for the two different attraction everyday. For free & easy traveller, it can be very confusing and the soldiers do not speak English and so help is limited. Some suggestion: 1) Go early before opening time 2) The 2 attractions are at the Ba Dinh square and there are two different queues for the two attraction. it is very crowded and so take note of people jumping queue 3) Bring small bags because they will do security scan 4) No bermudas and slippers allowed. Wear decent 5) forget about going on sat and sun. the queue is too long 6) If you want to visit both attraction, queue for Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum first because the queue is longer. 7) Tell the taxi driver to stop at the area for the queue because Ba Dinh square is quite big and you may have to walk a long way to the queueing area if he stop at other side of the square. 8) Tell the hotel to write the attraction in vietnamese so that you can show it to the soldiers to check which queue for which attraction.

Nice visit . We have been at this place on a sunny day. It's a bit hot but we still enjoyed. There're a lot of people coming here since it is a must-see in Hanoi to visit uncle Ho , you can visit one pillar pagoda and big square too. We had to wait for an hour to get inside. After that we saw a green garden with a big pond - what a green area after long time waiting on hot weather. Love this place

Didn't go inside but well worth seeing the outside . Quite an impressive monument for a man who really didn't want it! Visit at dusk for some good photos. I bit too far from the old town but easy to get a taxi there, not so easy to get one back but we managed after about 10 minutes
Worth it. You wait in a long que for hours but its worth where you get to see the man who built the country.it feels as if he is sleeping. Dress properly and act respectfuly at all times.
Worth a visit.. This is worth a visit.However be prepared for a long que to get in.Remember not to bring any phones or cameras inside. The guards will yell you to leave it in storage.
Nice green area. Great place to go around. Vietnamese people are pround of this great man. He helped the whole country to win other stronger countries during the war,....

If you have time. Resting place of Vietnam's past leader, guards changing ceremony and history on the country. If these interest you then by all means, else choose other attractions. Not worth the long wait though.

More of a pilgrimage than a tour.. This was by far the busiest location we visited on our whole trip to Vietnam. Uncle Ho, as he is known to most of the population, is revered and probably with good reason.We joined the long line of mostly local people waiting to file past Uncle Ho lying in state. But be warned, no inappropriate dress, no hands in pockets and definitely no talking. Cameras are confiscated before entry and returned to you on leaving. If you are there as part of an organised tour, your guide will explain all this to you and he will take your cameras and day sacks/hand bags for safe keeping. The subsequent walk around the parkland is well worth the time you will spend here. Again the guide will explain it all to you, including Uncle Ho's house on stilts.

Nice walk around the complex. We went on sunday morning and it was very crodwded. We were considering skip and go back in the afternoon but the security man said the Mausoleum only open in the morning. So we did it and it worth the waiting. It takes about 2 hours to visit the whole area.

Don't go on a Hot Day!. An interesting and immaculately kept place, let down for me (as a western tourist) by the strictly enforced military discipline.We went as part of a Chinese coach tour, and upon arriving we were told to leave any bags or water bottles on the coach. Having been escorted into the grounds by our tour guide for a brief walk around outside the mausoleum, we then had to leave the site, and join a long queue to go through airport style security to re-enter the site when it opened properly at 8:00am. Eventually arriving at the security check I was told that the small camera in my pocket wouldn't be allowed in, and had to be given to our tour guide - which is bizarre, as mobiles which all contain cameras nowadays were allowed.Having got through security you are strictly shepherded into two lines as you walk through covered walkways to the mausoleum.Bearing in mind that the temperature was by now in the mid-30s (centigrade), and we hadn't been allowed any water for well over an hour, I wasn't happy. I'm sure this kind of enforced mass dehydration of tourists wouldn't be acceptable in the west.Upon approaching the mausoleum any hats must be removed. Inside was thankfully heavily air conditioned, and pleasantly cool.You are watched closely by Vietnamese soldiers in white dress uniforms, and any talking or signs of levity are quickly suppressed.Ho himself is inside a glass case in a pit surrounded by four more soldiers, all in a strange orange glow.The two lines move quickly around three sides of the room, down the stairs and back into the hot sunshine.After a tour around Ho's garage, office and house on stilts, we were at last allowed out into the gift shop area, which thankfully sold large quantities of cold bottled water.In interesting, but not particularly pleasant experience.

Surreal but poignant. While you may queue for 1-2 hours and you don't get to spend a very long time viewing Ho Chi Minh's body it was well worth it for me. It's an experience unlike anything I've done before and if you're interested in the history of this brilliant country it's a must. The solemnity of the Vietnamese you wait patiently with, and the clear reverence that they have for Uncle Ho when in his presence, shows how powerful the cult of personality still is in this country.

Best air con in Vietnam . A wonderful short walk round a small room that is so cool we considered going again immediately. Also a respectful place to see the man himself. A strange tourist attraction but worth seeing.
A place of honor. We just had our pictures taken in the huge park/area before the Mausoleum.It is amazing to witness how the soldiers honor Ho Chi Minh.

Nice around.... I do not have too much to say about it because it was closed when i arrived to the mausoleum. Be advised that It close at 11 am so, if you are late, you can pay a ticket to enter to the museum or just go around it and see the beautiful gardens for free.

A Must Experience. Although the time given to view Ho Chi Minh's resting body is very short (about one minute), the entire experience is well worth noting. The military order, from walking through the queue, being observed by many well dressed soldiers, the changing the guard and the time allocated to view Ho Chi Minh was precise and very impressive.I chose to look at each soldier, as I walked by, smile at him and wish him a good morning, brought smiles to each and every one of them.I enjoyed myself and got to see the remains of the very powerful and beloved founder of Vietnam.
Just if you have nothing to do !. You have to be very patient to wait 1-3 hours in the queue to see past Vietnam leader for few seconds.

Effort to get into, but like no Mausoleum I've seen before. Worth seeing how the Vietnamese honor Mr Ho.A bit of walking around drop your bag off, then another place to drop the camera off, walking more around structured walkways,Note that it closes at lunch, don't rock up around lunch as you will be waiting a while. Mind you, you probably don't want to be in the midday Vietnamese sun anyway.

Mausoleum. is only open at certain times and you have to line up for a long time ,and when you get in you are hurried through quickly and the security is very high! but is well worth seeing and understanding what this great man meant to Vietnam! but every night you can watch the ceremony for the flag folding at 9pm it is amazing

Prepare yourself to stay in queue for 2 hours. We went there first time on Sunday - Bad idea! The line was 2 km long! All the vietnamese people are there on weekends so if you plan to go there on weekend you need to wake up 7 am and go there at least to avoid to standing in line for a long time. Opening hours are 8 am- 11 am but they might stop taking visitors in after 10.15 am. And it's closed on Mondays and Fridays. We went again on Thursday. The line was still long but it moved quite quickly so we got in to the mausoleumi. Interesting place to visit.

Only see because of the history.. The Mausoleum is nice to look upon once and to see the officer's in white blowing their whistles at tourists who cross the yellow line but there's nothing special about it. If you're a bit meh about history just bypass it. If you do go there's no real need to spend any longer than 2-3 minutes to get a photo and move on
Amazing. Amazing place sad in some places, but well worth the trip, was amazed at the ladies cutting the grass on hands and knees with normal scissors

A fitting block of concrete for His final resting place.. A hot Sunday morning bought us to the area of Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The queues on the weekend are very long but seemed to move at a good pace. We deceided not to view Ho Chi Minh and instead strolled through the gardens and surrounding areas including the Former President's house on stilts where he lived from 1958 - 1969.The house overlooks a medium size lake filled with goldfish. He never lived in the Grand Presidents home.Also in the area is the small but iconic One Pillar Pagoda. The area is very safe and serviced well with police, soldiers and other men in uniform. You can spend up to two hours here enjoying the atmosphere. Just a short walk away lies one of the oldest sights in Hanoi, The Temple of Literature, called Van Mieu in Vietnamese. The "temple" was founded in 1070 by Emperor Ly Thanh Tong, and is dedicated to the Chinese philosopher Confucius. Six years later, Vietnam's first university was founded here to teach the children of royalty and aristocracy.The long narrow temple complex consists of a sequence of five courtyards divided by walls.The first two courts are basically gardens with mature trees providing shady surroundings while the high temple walls help to subdue the constant noise of the streets surrounding the temple on three sides.The third courtyard is mostly taken up by a large pond, called the "well of heavenly clarity.Beyond the well of heavenly clarity is the courtyard of the sage sanctuaryThis paved courtyard is lined with buildings on three sides. Directly facing you as you enter the courtyard from the previous one is the Great House of Ceremonies, which houses a large red lacquered statue of Confucius. The buildings that flank the Great House. The last courtyard is the Thai Hoc, holding some of the largest structures. Flanking the large two story main hall are a drum and bell tower.

Wanted to see slightly dissapointing. A must see if in Hanoi if your interested in history and how revered Ho Chi Minn is. Waited in a long queue which wound its way around the grounds for about an hour and not allowed to take photo's outside. Marched up the stairs with your hands by your sides and pushed through by guards when in the chamber in about thirty seconds flat.
Mausoleum. Sorry don't like mausoleums. Hanoi has much more better places than this one to visit. Only for historic lovers

Be prepared for long lineup!. Our taxi dropped us off at the field across the mausoleum. We see a huge line up and proceeded to walk around the mausoleum forever to look for when the line ended. Note that you can't bring water into the mausoleum (you have to throw it out before going through security). They also don't allow your camera so you have to check it in with security (they put it in a bag and give you a little tag to collect it again later). Once inside you're able to see his resting body. It was a good experience. I would recommend it to anybody visiting Hanoi with an interest in Vietnamese history!

Awe inspiring!!. Recently visited Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. Quite an experience. Amazing to still be able to see him in the flesh and observe just how much the Vietnamese continue to adore him and all he stood for. A must see when in Ho Chi Minh city.

An important piece of Vietnamese history. We were told that we were very fortunate with the shortness of the queue. Our visit was made by the presence of an old Vietnamese lady, obviously emotionally closely connected with the late leader. The guards managed to be both stiff and formal and caring and supportive of her. The area around gives an excellent view of the life of Chairman Ho.

Glas we went. We were luck enough to be there on a day that it was open and his body was there. It was quite a long wait with local people keen to push in front of us. The long line snakes its way around and eventually up the steps and past the body. Once you are in the Mausoleum you are kept moving. This might not be an ideal attraction for an older person as there is no where to sit down while you wait in line.

Well worth the visit. Who would have thought that when going on holidays we would be lining up to see the body of Ho Chi Minh. There were thousands of people lined up to see him. It was so well organised. The lines were very fast moving and took hardly no time at all to get in. You do need to keep in mind that children(as well as the adults) need to be quite while walking though the mausoleum to show respect. The gardens that you walk though are very well maintained and the place is so full of history. We are not big into history but found this place very interesting. In the grounds are the houses Ho Chi Minh lived in as well as the cars he drove. It is a once in a life time opportunity to see so make sure you put it on your list of things to do while in Vietnam

Immortal. Arrived very early on Sunday at about 8am to visit the mossoleum of HCM but only to find qeus snaking around the road about 1.5km long & many more buses with visitors so we decided to view it from the outside , was so impressed with the discipline of the police and visitors alike , the pathway in front of the mossoleum is beautified with amazing burst of colors of flowers

Unique. Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is located in the Ho Chi Minh complex consistent of the Mausoleum, the garden, Presidential Palace, his 2 houses and 3 fancy cars and a fish pond...all together in one part of the botanical garden built by the French. There you will have chance to listen to interesting history and stories about this legendary man, as well as history of Vietnam through their French colonial war and the civil war.

Surreal experience. We went on a city tour on a friday, so we were not able to visit this that day. Instead we went back the next day, and man there was a very long line - but it was worth it, even though it was only a glimpse. :)I would recommend that you go there before 8am, especially on saturdays (there's a lot of school field trips during this day). And they close the line at around 10:30am.Also, don't use any shorts or sandals. They dont provide rentals so you might have to buy just for that glimpse of uncle ho. :)
Worth a visit.. Being interested in history, it was very interesting to walk through the mausoleum. It was well organised. Dress codes apply, so check before you go it see if you meet the code.

A good history of the man.. If you want to learn about Ho Chi Minh and his beliefs then this is the place. We used an older travel guide book and either Ho Chi Minh's body is no longer on display or wasn't when we visited.

Very interesting!!. Ho Chi Ming's mauseleum is a concrete monument to the former Viet leader. Watch the changing of the guard if you time it right. Huge building and a nice op, adjacent gardens, home and lake are picturesque along with museum. Do not take a tour...do it on your own pace.

A morning visit here with our guide.. As we visited early in the morning we didn't have to queue for long and the entire visit was quite interesting. Our guide advised against visiting on a Sunday because of high numbers of visitors.

Worth seeing . Well I think it was worth the wait we have been here a week and always missed the opening times (the girls were busy shopping ) we did have trouble getting the right information . Some say you can only go inside the mausoleum in the morning . As it only open Tues we'd Thursday but we went Saturday Morning at 8 am and the line was long but it just took 30 min before got inside .women can take their small handbag with them, You can't take backpack s in so you have to leave then at the front gate and get a ticket your bag is not locked up so don't leave any valuables in. To collect yr bag you have to walk all the way around the mausoleum at least 600 meters back from the exit to get it so best not to take one . We took out camera with us all the way but just put it in our pocket when we got closer to it. You are supposed to hand it in but it wasn't a drama to have it in our pockets . But all in all I think it worth the trip if you in hanoi . It made us more interested in looking on the net for more information about vietnamese history

Ho ChiMinh Mausoleum - morning visit. The mausoleum is impressive, and is the view of people coming to give respect. It is extremely well organized, and attention paid to every detail. We were able to get inside, to view Ho ChinMinh grave ... Memorable place. Starting at 8am the visit took less than half an hour.

A touching experience. This is a must-see for visitors to Hanoi as this is the place where Ho Chi Minh's preserved body lies. Naturally it is a high-security zone, but I was humbled by the local people's reaction upon seeing Ho Chi Minh, who was a humble hero.
Interesting. Interesting to watch the changing of the guard (if you time it right). Unique place, but remember it's only open early in the mornings

History point. Although the waiting line... is a interesting point to visit the embalmed body of the biggest leader of Vietnam.Near the mossoleu it is posible visit his house and enjoy tho beautiful gardens... A point that the people's shouldn't loose!

Ho chi minhs mausoleum. This place is very eye opening very strict no cameras phones hands in pocket Sunnis etc but hard to believe they still have ho chi minhs body after 40 odd years we were told though weekends it gets packed so be aware

Very long queue on a very hot day. I find it difficult to believe that Ho Chi Minh's last wishes were ignored. Instead of cremation, as he requested, to mummify his body and place it on view. The best parts were seeing long lines of 3,4 and 5 year olds walking past in long lines to see the body (can't say I approve, it would have given me nightmares at that age) and the peace and cool in the mausoleum
good. its amizing plaza !! big wide place and surround of many big hestoric buliding but in my time of visit !! its was close unknown resone they didnt answer why its close or when will open

With respect. Having spent nearly 3 weeks exploring this fabulous country from south to north it seemed quite fitting that one of our final destinations was Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. Given that "uncle Ho", as our guide referred to him, our pilgrimage was much easier than of most Vietnamese people. We were fortunate to visit on a Thursday morning following a 4 day public holiday. No queuing and quite a thought provoking experience. A definite must do add to the jigsaw of completing the Vietnamese experience.

Long line up to walk past a dead person. I didn't enjoy the long line up out in the sun, for a few moments of quiet to walk past a dead person. No talking, no asking questions, no information displayed. Didn't really excite me all that much.

Check opening times!. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a sight to see. The love that the Vietnamese people have for Ho Chi Minh is inspiring. I can't recall ever seeing a place adore a leader as much as here.Unfortunately, the Mausoleum was closed when we arrived at 11am. We had been told it shut at 11:30am. By the end of the day, we were told it shut as early as 10:30am. So be safe and go extra early if you want to go inside.Also, the museum next door has odd opening times too, so again, check that before going out here.
Scary and boring building. I wouldn't recommend this building-very pompous and harsh building with huge grounds and nothing around.

Shrine to a Dead Communist. I enjoyed walking around the mausoleum and was able to observe a changing of the guard ceremony but I didn't really have any desire to pay my respects to Uncle Ho. If you do want to see his embalmed body, make sure you know the observation times as they are limited during the day.
Famous place. Ho Chi Minh mausoleum was known by most of Vietnamese people and visitors. We went there and spent the whole morning around the area. Nice and quiet place. Very busy at the weekend

Awesome. You have to see with your own eyes the Vietnamese peoples dedication to their past leader Ho Chi Minh.Ho's embalmed body is on display in the granite mausoleum modelled after Lenin's tomb in Moscow. Streams People queue each day, sometimes for hours, to pass his body in silence.

A place to visit in Hanoi . You can see the Embalmed body of Mr Ho Chi Minh ... He is the father / God figure for Vietnamese . Maintained Spic and span in cleanliness . Total discipline and no talking also . No bags / photos etc allowed . Dress code is very strict .
A place of respect. I went through the morning air is very good with indigenous people to stand in front of the place. Open Psalms Homage Ho Chi Minh

Ho Ho Chi Minh. Be prepared for a long wait at the entrance , then a long walk with crowds, but to be part this important part of history is worth the effortUshered quickly through the mauseleum you only get a quick glimpse of Ho Chi Minh which is surrounded by security guardsNo cameras are petmitted, not even mobile phones so be prepared for some high securityThe square itself is very well maintained and this is a must visit .

Very fast paced beautiful gardens. . It was a nice place to go. You are rushed through the viewing of ho chi minh but it was still worth the visit. You then take time through the garden. It was very busy though. I think today may still be a public holiday.

It is a mausoleum but.. The place is mobbed by Vietnamese who revere the country's leader. The grounds are beautiful, the lines are long, and the hushed respectful crowd passing the embalmed remains of Ho Chi Minh are clearly national touchstones.
HCM mausoleum . Really liked the place. Very unique. The area is best at sunset, stop by a small table on the side to have a coffee or a beer while the buzzing scene is cooling down before sun goes.
longest line altime!. This was the third time to visit Ho. But after lining up for two and a half hours could not continue, was a DNF

Waste of time!. Visiting Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was included automatically in our itinerary. We queued for 2 hours to get inside and then were whisked round past his body in 30 seconds. We weren't keen on going, but didn't want to offend our guide by not going - someone else told us at breakfast that it wasn't worth going. It's 2 hours of our lives that we won't get back!
impressive. You will see how much the Vietnamese pay respect to him. Visiting his presidential palace reflects how he spent his life. It is very interesting to learn.
Impressive. The mausoleum is an impressive structure with plenty of space around it to take it all in. It can be seen from miles away too as it is so spectacularly lit.

Great outside but underwhelming inside. The gardens on the outside are a great place for a walk.To get inside you will need to queue for up to 2 hours and is plain not worth it to see what appeared to me to be an imitation of HCM.The guards are unnecessarily officious and abrupt.I think it may be of more interest to natives of Vietnam but to all the non-Vietnamese I spoke to we all seemed to have the same reaction - "Meh" If you are interested in the story of Ho Chi Minh you are better off going to the HCM Museum nearby.

And now for something different . It's not every day you get to stand in line to see a preserved dead dude.People complain about the long line but it only took us 30-45 mins to see HCM.The line moved quickly and it was most definitely something different. Once out of the mausoleum we walked through the rest of the garden and saw some HCM related displays like his office setup, his cars and the house on stilts.Try and avoid the tour groups. The pathways are not the widest and it can get very crowded very quickly.Specially when the Chinese tour groups decide to do their thing and elbow you out of the way and stand in front of you with self importance sticks whilst your trying to take a picture.

Strange but interesting. This is a very important site in Vietnam, and the appropriate respect (dress wise) is expected. Ho Chi Minh, or "Uncle Ho" is revered throughout the country, but it still feels rather strange to view the body of someone who died in 1969. He looks in remarkably good condition, and from what we were told the body is "maintained" every October. Very interesting, and it is set in lovely grounds. Well worth a visit, and you can do this as part of the city tour. We booked through our hotel (The Essence Palace)

Interesting for sure. The drill is you get in a long single file line and solemnly parade through the tomb and view Uncle Ho in mummified form. It's a worthwhile visit if you know anything about Ho Chi Minh. Don't let the long line deter you as it moves along pretty fast no problem.

Beautiful gardens. The mausoleum is only open until 11.30 (they shut down the entry at about 10.30 depending on demand) and it is closed on Mondays and Friday's! No shorts or singlets are allowed and you have to check you backpacks & cameras and you collect them at the exit. You're filed past Ho Chi Minh himself fairly quickly and see him for less than a minute. Once you're in the gardens you can wander and enjoy them at your own pace after collecting your camera. It's is a peaceful place even with the scores of school children. I missed on my first visit to Hanoi and I'm glad I got to go this time around.

Interesting!. If you want to see an embalmed body go here! you might wait in line a bit especially if there are school tours there.. you walk through no talking keep hands to your side.. they watch everyone very carefully! but worth it. and NO pictures! they don't like you to take pictures outside either... so you know.. just don't get caught..

Good history. We arrived in the morning and heard the story about Ho Chi Minh from our tour leader, and realize about how Vietnamese respect to him. Unfortunately, the mausoleum is closed, so we don't have opportunity to enter and see Ho Chi Minh's body. However,enjoying the place and taking picture with my family is a good memory for us.

As expected with high security control . If you want to see the body if the local's hero, then you should visit this place. There is nothing else to see here.Dress appropriately (covered shoulders and knees) and don't bring food or you'll be forced to discard it.There a 20 minutes line of tourists and school children to see the body for 30 seconds... You can't wear sunglasses or have your hands in your pockets....
nice architectural building. Saw the change of guards taking place , simple and yet elegant with military grandeur and respect. The place is huge but we enjoyed the guide informative service

A must experience . I thoroughly my visit here. I think it's a must see for any visitor to Hanoi. I went very early and was one of the first 20 people in. Beating the crowds is important if you want to maximize your time to see other things in the city on the same day. Dress appropriately. Act respectfully. Enjoy the experience.

Had to see this.... Having heard so much about Ho Chi Minh we at least wanted to see the mausoleum.... Really interesting, we didn't want to go inside but wanted to see the grounds and surrounding area. Worth a visit.

Leave yourself plenty of time!. A trip to Ho Chi Minhs' mausoleum is not to be missed. Make sure you plan on at least four hours if you wish to enter the mausoleum as the line is almost endless, but well worth the discovery. If your time is of a premium don't despair as you can still view the outside of the mausoleum as well as presidential palace and the two other houses occupied by Ho Chi Minh. In the same location dont forget to visit the single post pagoda, a historical icon not to be missed.Enjoy!

Check the opening times before you go. The day we got there was a Friday and the mausoleum was closed. We didn't expect that. We were still able to see things from the outside but it was raining so we didn't stay for long. A word of warning - don't step over the yellow line or a soldier with a whistle will become quite irate.
a temple to glorify a leader who was as modest as can be. It seams a long row, but it moves very quickly. The reverent silence and the guards all along make the queing itself the experience
Well worth the visit. Quite outstanding in the presentation of the Ho Vhi Minh. closed Monday and Friday's . Do not take mobile, cameras and strict dress code
A place to remember a hero. The hero is Ho Chi Minh, the liberator of Vietnam from the French colonization. Good for him as his efforts were not in vain.

Worth the visit. Definitely worth taking the time to visit the Mausoleum. They have a good system set up so its efficient. Walking through and seeing Ho Chi Minh you definitely feel the passion and emotion of Vietnamese people. It's worth looking around where he lived also. It's a lovely setting and well preserved. We were lucky enough to have an English student guide us through free which was great. Make sure your knees and shoulders are covered or you will be refused entry. You can't take water in. Backpacks and cameras get stored in lockers and you get given a number to get them back on your way out. It's closed from 11.30 until 1 or 1.30 so they close the entrance at around 10.30 for morning slot. Worth the visit.
Interesting tour. We had an organised half day tour of Hanoi which included a visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The tour was interesting, and our guide was very knowledgable

Go early to see Uncle Ho. We arrived mid morning on Sunday to be greeted by hundreds of thousands of people queuing in the sun to see Ho. Sunday is school party day, and you'll find it a lot quieter (apparently) mid week. You can walk around to the side of the Mausoleum and have free entry to the outside of the venue (which is what we did) and not have to queue. Not as exciting as seeing the old man in state, but if you are not a die hard Ho Chi Minh fan entirely acceptable!
worth a visit. You just walk passed the Mausoleum as its near the Museum and the Palace o fit them all in.It was closed so not able to go inside

No signs and no guides!nothing!!. disappointment...we just didn't know where was the entrance, there was no signs in English or any other guides and no one spoke english at alll,we asked the guards but they didn't understand a word we were saying and every time they got us wrong directions,and every other tourists were confused just like us!We ask everyone in our long way to entrance if the mausoleum is still open?they were just repeating yes yes..finally after one hour of walking we find the entrance but it was closed!!they say that the mausoleum is open only in weekends!!!but opening hours written in guidebooks and sites is 7 to 11 am everyday!Anyway we just leave there without visiting the mausoleum and we never tried it again cuz we were very angry....
Very Respectable. It was great to feel the passion of Vietnamese people respecting their leader. People from all over the world visit the Mausoleum everyday. The area feels very peaceful.

Great thing to see. This was one of the highlights for me in Hanoi. Was really good to experience. However you need to be warey of the times you go. We went on a sunday (saturdays and sundays are extremely busy) and lined up for almost 4 hours. We were lucky to see the changing of the guard as we were going through when this happened. It was awesome. Make sure you are not wearing shorts/singlets. You will be turned away (after linong up for a while).most locals wear really nice clothes when visiting.

Insightful Place to visit... This place has a "spacious" field, so we can come with our friends or any group of people. I went there with my office group, and we have a great time to catch some photos and some great history about this country. If anyone wants to come inside the mausoleum, you must check the time. There is scheduled to come to inside the mausoleum.

A must see tourist attraction in Hanoi. Our tour guide took us to the Mausoleum in the mid afternoon as he said this was the quietest time and he was so right, very few locals and tourist. it was a very interesting visit to see the resting place of the father of Vietnamese Communism. A must see attraction when visiting Hanoi
Grand!! . Grand square created in front of it. One can't enter the mausoleum. There is a huge square made in front where one can click a photo.

once in a lifetime experience. Queue was quite long outside the mouseleum as well as inside the area. We arrived there at 9am and it took us about 1 hour to queue before we get to see the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. There were guards everywhere and they ensure visitors do not make noise and do not take any photos inside the mouseleum. It was definitely once a lifetime experience for me to get to see the nice condition of the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. He looks as if he's asleep.
Amazing Structure.. Reminds me so much of Tiannamen Square in Beijing. Huge area which has a real aura about it. Recommended.

Go early, don't be dissuaded by the long queue- it moves quickly. Last entry is at 10:15am, mausoleum closes at 11am.We had one failed attempt at visiting this attraction. We had seen where the mausoleum was on the map and decided it was a 30 minute walk (therefore we would arrive just before 10am). However, we did not realize that that the entrance was on the other side of the compound. By the time we walked around the compound and found the queue at 10:20am we had missed the last entry by 10:15am :(Our second attempt was on a Saturday. We arrived in time (around 9:15am) and were greeted by a massive queue. We were determined not to come back a third time so we joined the queue. It moved fast, especially as you are not able to linger in the mausoleum. Some local grandmas were intrigued by us and kept touching us e.g. on the arm, patting our tummies and backs! Quite an odd experience.We had a great tour guide who showed us around the Presidential Palace. She spoke with great emotion about "Uncle Ho" :)

Major attraction. This is a much bigger attraction that I had expected. Aside from the mausoleum, there's a museum you can go in ($4 US) and a more historical park with some temples. Very attractive.There's active police guarding the space, so pat attention to signs alerting where you can/can't access. We caught the changing of the guard, which I personally always enjoy. No matter how different the cultures, that ceremony is often very similar.

Long line, worthwhile experience. Had to stand in line for about 1/2 hour. The line moved fairly fast. The you get to see the guy on the Vietnamize money. Well preserved communist. I wouldn't put it at the top of my list but it was worth the time to see it.
An essential place to visit!. Part of the tourist trail but well worth visiting! Try to go when it is quiet because an awful lot of tourists visit - week days are best.

A fantastic insight. We were very lucky to have our excellent guide Springy, he was able to provide us with the full history of this man Ho Chi Min and everything he stood for. Politics aside, being a foreigner with no real understanding of this country, i still felt very moved. It did give us a little more of an insight into the history of this very beautiful but complex land. The architecture of the presidential palace is glorious and is absolutely polar opposite to the private homes of Ho Chi Min which is comparison were absolutely frugal. The grounds are beautiful and the guards changing every hour was quite a spectacle. We didnt actually get to go inside as it was a Friday, i would like to next time we are in Hanoi.

Great to See. HoChiMinhs mausoleum is a must see in Hanoi.It is close to his residence and old frenck provincial buildings .It is obvious he is a hero of the people as the lines of people,students is very long if you get there late.Go early if possible

Top Ten Sight. Quiet, well policed pedestrianised area. Do not cross the yellow line in front of the mausoleum. Sits in what we might call parliament square. Good photo area, do not use tripod it is not allowed. With the mausoleum on your right you can turn right down to the one legged temple. Toilets available there.
