Ho CHi Minh - Uncle Ho. I the place with green grass. Ho Chi Minh has been known by the local here and also the whole world. only thing is you need to go there before 10:00 AM. It is closed in the afternoon and it is super busy during the weekend

Closed on Monday and Friday. I came on Friday and found the mausoleum closed for viewing. I strolled all my way from my hostel at the Old Quarters to visit the Citadel, the West Lake, the Military Museum and the Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace Historical site and it was a waste that I missed the viewing of one of the greatest and most respectable revolutionary leaders of South East Asia. So, if you are keen to view his body, don't come on Monday and Friday when the mausoleum is closed for viewing. Nevertheless, I still had the opportunity to take a photograph at the front of the mausoleum with the background of the white uniformed officers standing solemnly and smartly on guard at the place. I also went to the rear of the mausoleum to visit the small little Botanical Garden and the Ho Chi Minh museum. It is fun wandering around looking at the slow march of the guards and watching the visitors taking photo at Ba Dinh Square. I had visited Mao's Mausoleum in Beijing few years back and it was a tiring long queue. No luggage or camera is permitted in the viewing hall. I believe the same procedure applies here.Ho Chi Minh is a great revolutionary hero who led his people valiantly against French Colonialism and US imperialism. The French were in Vietnam to exploit the resources and in defense of Democracy, the US dumped millions of deadly bombs into Vietnam and transformed the battlefields into killing mines. No nation had ever undergone such tumultuous times for independence and suffered such catastrophic damages and intense misery that Vietnam had gone through. Yet, Vietnam survived and emerged a victorious and united country. The credit goes to this man - Ho Chi Minh. While I am not a supporter of communism, I respect this man and his contribution cannot be denied in the history of mankind. in the relentless struggle against colonialism by the Western powers, he made all Asians proud. My salute to him! Uncle Ho, may your spirit now rest in peace.
A must see in Hanoi. There were hundreds in line but we moved first as we had a private tour. Very well managed and fascinating to see! Loved the grounds as well!

Don't go on a Sunday morning. We walked a half hour to get there only to find bus load upon bus loads of people. There are thousands of people in different lineups all over the place. We, along with lots of other people said forget it! We didn't see Ho Chi Minh but apparently we could have visited the grounds.

Mausoleum is a must-visit. Ho Chi Minh's complex includes a museum and his house, which was all very nice, but the mausoleum where HCM's embalmed body is kept steals the show. It looks very lifelike. Among "sights" of Hanoi, I would put this in the top 5.

Too crowded. We arrived near the mausoleum at about 9am but decided not to wait in the extremely long queue (over 4 kms long) so we walked around the grounds and saw the pagoda, Ho Chi Minh's House. That was interesting

Insight into Vietnamese respect, history and tradition. One Saturday a couple of weeks ago we waited exactly one hour in the queue after ensuring that we followed the dress code of covering up shoulders and knees (for ladies). Was an amazing experience to see the reverence that the Vietnamese have for Uncle Ho. Not sure that I'd visit for a second time but very glad that I made the effort. I agree with other reviews: a must for any visitor to Hanoi! Make the time to see him and be patient in the queue!!!

HCM Mausoleum. The Vietnamese people loved this leader Ho Chi Minh so this is a very serious tour, therefore no photos/talking/wearing of hats or sunglasses once inside. Also make sure you wear clothes that cover your shoulders & knees. The tour operator never told us this beforehand so a couple of us had to buy scarves outside entrance gates from a street vendor to enable entry.It was a hot day queuing for 45+ minutes in the heat, especially when the patrolled tour only took 5 minutes where you walk in & around Ho Chi Minh's glass encased body then straight out again. Interesting to see but it was part of our organised city tour so not something I would normally have done or would do again.

"Over rated". The mausoleum is a sight to behold, this is true however it casts a subtle air of creepiness and politics. It was a stinking hot day, constant feeling of being watched and a bit of a let down if I were to be honest. I couldn't quite fathom the costings behind it all while the people struggle to survive but that could possibly be my Australian democratic ways surfacing. The changing of the guards was the highlight for me but I should mention that I watched this from afar & atop my bicycle which may be the reason I enjoyed it. An ok visit but one I wouldn't highly recommend.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Beautiful to see at night by motorbike. I did not go inside and see a body but the structure and square were inviting enough.
GO early as line ups horrendous. This is very interesting however, go early or you will be standing in a 3-4hours line up (in the heat)

Didnt actually make it inside..... Line was enormous and unfortunately went on a Sunday when it closed early at 11am. Lots of school type groups that visibly had priority over tourists.
Only managed a photo of the outside.

Uncle Ho. I think the visit was worthwhile but It is a very strange concept to us to queue for 1 hour to see a preserved body. The building is grand and rather communist but that's what they were aiming for. Visiting the mausoleum is free but it does then lead on to the presidential palace, one pillar pagoda and Ho Chi Minh museum which are not free. It is a good thing to see and do if you have time in Hanoi.
Nothing special. I know that for Vietnameses this is a very important place, however I didn't like it very much. A long queue for staying less than two minutes in the mausoleum...

Interesting. The mausoleum itself is an impressive building with soldiers guarding the entrance in white uniforms. You have to wait in a long cue but while waiting we enjoyed watching Vietnamese school children walking past in their colourful uniforms. Visit the adjoining gardens and Ho Chi Minh house. You need to pay for this part but it is worth it. We enjoyed the beautiful Lake. A nice young student joined us and offered to be our guide for free.

So Impressive. Do not be deterred by the size of the queues as the visit is all worth the time spent and the ever present soldiers keep everyone moving. The building itself is huge and imposing, a clear indication of the reverence in which Ho Chi Minh is held and is in stark contrast to the small serene figure held within its walls. Do make sure you also see where Ho Chi Minh resided and worked. Not the grand highly decorated palaces one comes to expect, rather small, humble abode which suited his needs and wishes. Well worth a lengthy visit.

Hanoi Free Walking Tour. We were fortunate to have booked our tour and had Loan as our guide. She took us first to this complex which really consists of several sites: HCM museum, HCM mausoleum, Stilt House, One pillar pagoda and lotus fountain. Very worthwhile visiting. We were there on a Saturday so long line to see Ho Chi Minh's body. We decided not to wait in the line. Museum was very well done.

Day tour. This was avert busy day to visit I have never seen lines soo long, all to walk past a coffin, I could never imagine any one in Australia lining up to see a dead Poli. Same again do a private tour.

A quick walk past HCM's body lying in state. We joined the very long queue which moved quickly. You are hustled along, no photos allowed and this was our first real reminder that we were in a communist country. The young soldiers complete with rifles and bayonets, marched along goose-stepping outside the building while others manhandled us into position. To be physically pushed along, I found very confronting. Having said that if you are interested in seeing the body of the revered leader who died in 1969, it is interesting.

Meaningful to the Vietnamese. We visited the square where the Mausoleum is located but did not go inside. It was interesting to learn about Ho Chi Minh but unless someone is really interested I'd pass on the Mausoleum.

He is now in a fortress when he lived and fought in a bunker. Like all Mausoleum, we are constantly reminded by the guards to be respectful, solemn, and walk through quietly and chided when someone steps out of line, whether locals or tourists.The queue is always very long around the block, but once you are in, you are encouraged to keep moving on, photography is not permitted inside.The whole experience is enriched by seeing so many Vietnamese school children, well dressed, well behaved, and well mannered, all holding hands to form a disciplined queue and guided by their teachers to pay their respects.Looking around the city of Hanoi, most of the French quarters and "colonial" buildings are now educational departments or schools. Ho Chi Minh might be gone but his legacy has given hope and a strong future for all young Vietnamese.
Imposing building. An impressive and imposing building set in a large park which frames it perfectly. One of those must-see icons when travelling.

Historical. The line is long, BUT don't let this discourage you. It moves fast and efficiently. We went on a weekend and the seemingly never ending line took less than one hour. Once inside you are ushered very quickly around the room where the actual remains are. It is eerie but historical and well worth a visit. There are no camera allowed inside the actual mausoleum, but there is a secure place to store them. Shorts must be longer than your knees. This is an important and respected site so please be respective with dress. 40k dong as of April 2016.

Entrance is closed on Monday. We saw the mausoleum from the exterior only as it was closed the day we visited. Apparently you have to queue for what can be a long wait to enter the mausoleum to see the body of Ho Chi Minh. The building itself is not that attractive - a large concrete block building which is Russian in style. We visted because it is listed as a must see sight in Hano but we preferred the visit to the adjacent Ho Chi Minh Presidential complex with a number of interesting buildings and nice gardens.

Ghost house without soul. I had passed a long queue to visit a cold and dark cemented building with a mummified body from a 2-3 meter distance,but this visit is good because of some surrounding good places.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Absolutely worth a look!The Mausoleum is really interesting and is huge!Really great piece of Vietnamese history.

A definite must see in Hanoi. Many reviews already exist and clearly the Mausoleum is a must see due to the importance of Ho Chi Minh. Having read a number of reviews, we were concerned about the waiting times described and a bit hesitant at first. However, having checked with some locals, they all assured us the waiting time would not be anywhere near to what we had read, so we gave it a go...and I'm glad we did.In the end, it took about 40 mins from the entrance (security check) to inside the mausoleum. An experience not to be missed...
Cultural Experience. This was certainly worth a visit particularly with a local guide who gave us the whole story of Ho Chi Minh.
Such a peaceful place!!!!. Great view to walk by! Spend a whole morning at here, friendly local people, nice atmosphere. One of must visit in Hanoi!!!

Also worth a look. Myself & my Mate lined up for about one hour to get into the Mausoleum as it was a holiday in Vietnam & there was many locals coming to respect their great leader Would I queue up for one hour if I knew what I was going to experience, absolutely if was worth every minute of that hot humid hour “don’t miss it if you visit Hanoi “NB It’s not open of Fridays or Mondays plus it’s only open in the mornings so check the opening time before you go

Interesting experience but pure propaganda. The Vietnamese people apparently venerate Ho Chi Minh (which was not his real name) as the father of their country, although the thing is really forced adulation of a dead revolutionary politician just like Chairman Mao etc.His mausoleum is a separate building next to gardens and a simple house where he supposedly lived, and the whole stately area really forms the civic centre of Hanoi. Vietnamese people are expected to visit here at least once in their life.The mausoleum is a stand alone building containing just his embalmed body in a showcase, looking like something in Madame Tussauds. Getting to see it (which takes literally 20 seconds before you are out again) is a mammoth exercise. It is only open a few hours a day, closed 2 days a week, and for 2 months a year he is shipped off to Moscow for maintenance. The crowds are monstrous, with no indication of which long queue to join. It will normally take at least an hour in the queue, even if you get there well before the 8am opening time.Most tour groups will not take the time to queue, so probably few westerners actually get to do the actual walk past the body. Interesting thing to do mainly as an insight into Vietnamese political affairs.

Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. This was a site you should visit while in Hanoi. The lines look unbelievably long, but they do more fairly quickly. From outside the gate it took us less than an hour. The "visit" takes about two minutes. Upon entering the Mausoleum, you are rushed along (no stopping for photos), but you do have a clear view of Ho's body lying, uncovered, in state. I believe they close the Mausoleum once a year to replace the embalming fluid with "fresh material".
Must see. This is something no one can see anywhere . A once in a life time experience even though it lasts only a few minutes Go for it and yes there may be a queue ...
Impressive. Respect to Uncle Minh. You get a real feeling of the importance and esteem held for the man. Nice design to the architecture as well. Guards are a bit grumpy though.

The manicured lawns. Unfortunately we visited the Mausoleum on a Monday. As a consequence we could not go inside. That said the structure is imposing and clearly shows the respect and love the Vietnamese people have for their former leader and mentor.The guards are dressed in white and when they march off it is very impressive.

Strange, Sombre, Quirky, Sobering. Uncle Ho is Viet Nam's national hero. Here he is preserved for proterity so that generations can pay their respects. However, it also doubles as one of the most fascinating 'tourist attractions' I've ever seen and I'm so glad the people of Viet Nam allow westerners to share this experience.As other have said you queue for around 30 minutes at different points. you're bags, cameras etc are taken from you. It is afterall not a tourist attraction. And after a while you shuffle past the embalmed body of one the 20th centuries foremost protagonists. The whole experience is surreal, but wonderful!

A long line.. This site is of cultural significance and reverence for all Vietnamese so if you are interested in this view (and perhaps challenging a view or two of your own) this is a good place to start.

Visiting Uncle Ho. Vietnam's historic leader, Ho Chi Minh, is on display in an impressive mausoleum in Hanoi. My guide took me to the site on a weekend, a very busy day for visiting as it turned out. He bought the ticket and asked me to hand in my mobile phone to an office and get a receipt for it. Then, he asked me to join a very long Q. Most of the people in the Q were Vietnamese, followed by foreign nationals. The atmosphere was that of quiet respect. Nationalist songs were broadcast through speakers mounted in the line leading to the main building. After 30 minutes of slow movement, we reached the entrance of the building, guarded by Vietnamese soldiers in full uniforms. Up the stairs, I had a quick glimpse of the leader's face but I had to hurry as the line was moving fast to allow others to take our place. It was a historic moment to see the country's modern leader, Uncle Ho, as he is fondly called by locals. This is a must visit while in Hanoi but remember that shorts and phones are not allowed.

Definitely different . If you're in Hanoi it is definitely worth a visit as its something you just don't see very often... After if you're interested in the history or just the buildings and gardens you can wander around. Took us around 1.5 hours in April but make sure you check the times as its only opened in the morning!!

Strange but impressive. I was just strolling around the city when I was ushered into a queue and after going through metal detector and having my cigarette lighter confiscated I was again ushered by guards in a line to the mausoleum. Cameras and phones were taken from us and returned after we exited. I really didn't know where I was going or what I was about to see and it had a very strange atmosphere. Seeing Ho Chi Minh was actually really impressive and he has been incredibly preserved. It was a strange experience but I'm glad I accidentally experienced it.

A nice place to learn about a nice person.. We heard about this man a lot before getting to Vietnam. The queue was quite long but we managed to see his body in the Mausoleum. The stories after that about his life and career was really interesting. It was a nice area full of history. I guess it would be not easy queuing in the sun in mid of summer here.

To Actually have stood where Ho Chi Minh once stood was an amazing experience. Go and see this as well as the Ho Chi Minh museum, and you will not be disappointed. you can also visit his house and garage where his cars are still kept inside lovely gardens where soldiers still practice their drills

Different Cultural Experience. We visited the mausoleum on a Saturday and you have to go early to avoid the heat and queues. We arrived at 9.15am and there was a 1km queue and it was 40 deg Celsius and 100% humidity which was very draining. The locals admire Ho Chi Minh as their "father" so the whole experience was quite sombre. After queing for 70 minutes we filtered through the mausoleum centre in two neat lines to view the perfectly preserved body of their beloved leader in a glass casket. This was a bit strange but interesting none the least. After filtering outside you then pay a small charge to enter the palace grounds and have a free guide service through the grounds and parks around this auspcious site. Worth a visit as you get to understand a little more about the Vietnamese culture and their respect for their long term leader.
Worth the wait. It's great to experience the awe and respect that locals have. The actual viewing is solemn interesting and respectful.

A Must Visit Attraction. Late Ho Chi Minh was a great Vietnamese leader who inspired his people to fight first the French colonial rule and then the U.S. occupation. The entire complex is spick and span. Though the tourists' number is usually large, the staff maintain order and discipline to ensure the viewing is done without hassle. Inside the mausoleum late Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body is kept in a chamber controlled at certain temperature so that the body preservation is not affected. The body looks life like. Close to the mausoleum one can see the old presidential palace, that was once used by the French Governor General, and Ho Chi Minh's two homes, both very modest for a head of state.

Beautiful. We set out early and were horrified at the queues!! The queue went around 3 sides of the complex. We waited at least 2 hours to get in. It's a bit like being herded around between the lines but was worth it when we finally go into the Mausoleum. Uncle Ho just look like he was sleeping

Good to see. We didnt go inside the mausoleum to see the body of Ho Chi Minh - it is only open until 11.30am I think. We were aware of this but had read that the queues can be very long. We walked here from our hotel and it was nice to see the different streets around the mausoleum which was wide, tree lined and fancy! Very different to downtown Hanoi. I was glad we went to see it.

Impressive building. It's a shame this is only open early morning and then you have long queues. However it is still an impressive building to see. The historical significance is important with the sincere reverence that the vietnamese have for Ho Chi Minh.
It is worth to see. There are not just the mausoleum,but a beautiful garden,and the hauses what used to used Ho Shi Minh apó.The row went well.So we can go through the mausoleum about half an hour.

Worth the visit. Even though lines are long, the visit is well organized and moves along. Inside you will see Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body. You should visit the place where he lived (inside the same complex) and the museum. Need about 3 hours for a proper visit.

amazing. we were came here to meet the real HoChiMinh, who was gone.
one of my friends was burnt in to tears when we came inside! should come

A visit to the mausoleum of a revered leader (in North Vietnam, at least). This is a sacrosanct place for many people in Vietnam, especially in the North. There are lines of up to 3 hours wait to see the preserved body of Ho Chi Min. According to his way of life, he must have been a remarkable person. The is a great pageantry in the whole thing. But in the South I was told his resting exposed body is a fake. Anyway, worth visiting.

Interesting if you have time. I wanted to go to this monument to try and better understand the almost god-like status of Ho Chi Minh in Vietnam. You essentially stand in a constantly moving line for about 1.5 hours and are subjected to lots of strange and disorganized bag searches and check in counters. When you arrive at the mausoleum you are able to walk around Ho Chi Minh in his resting place then are rushed out the door. Overall you get to see him for about 20 seconds. It's very interesting, but also missable. Also make sure you check the time it will be open because this is very limited. Many taxi drivers will offer to take you there from the old quarter at times when it is certainly not open.
ho chi minh mausoleum. very interesting. grounds kept immaculate. well worth the visit, especially to learn about the "American War"

Rules of conduct strictly enforced. Long lines to visit but they move quickly. In the building there is no talking, modest dress is required, no hands in pockets. Guards are quick to respond to any transgressions. An interesting display that seems peculiar to the four Communist countries, China, Cuba, North Korea and Vietnam.

If you have time visit! . This place is only open a few hours each day and is very popular! We queued for 2hours in the very very hot sun! The queue did move quite quickly. No short skirts or shorts allowed. No bags allowed inside and no pictures. Once you enter inside you walk around the square fairly quickly seeing the fascinating preserved Ho Chi Minh! Visit if you have time.

Seriously long queues due to short opening times. Seriously long queues due to short opening times.We queued for over 2 1/2 hours! It was shot and hard work. However, once you see HC then it was an experience.

An Absolute Must. While admittedly have not pried, I think it is true that Ho Chi Min was a supremely courageous leader of the Vietnamese people -- to whom this mausoleum solemnly pays tribute. I've visited both times I've been on Hanoi. Particularly impressive are the perfection of the appearance of his body; the respectful demeanor of the visitors; the lovely flowers and grounds surrounding the mausoleum; and the cute guards, all smartly dressed in starched white uniforms and outfitted with bayonet-attached rifles.Admission to the mausoleum is free. Upon exiting, visitors may pay 40,000 VND per person for a guided tour of Ho's private residence, cars, bomb-shelter, and grounds. Our guide was a lovely young lady, speaking nearly-perfect English, and knowledgeable of what she spoke. If I'm ever in Hanoi again I'll certainly come to this place again.

Beautiful park and interesting masoleum. We were with a tour group. We went through the masoleum where Ho Chi Minh laid, and then visited the park around it. Interesting to learn the history of this man from the Vietnamese perspective. Very busy place and pretty grounds.

Walked from our hotel..... We walked from our hotel here....we couldn't walk straight in and kept getting guided all around the square....lots of areas you can not walk...so by the time we got there the doors were closed. Make sure you check the opening hours.Lovely gardens
Not a must visit place. Dont visit on sunday or public holiday, the queue is very long...takes abt 3_4 hrs. Not worth the time wasted.

Worth it . Definitely worth it if you have the time. Was very impressive with well maintained grounds. The line looks long but actually moves very fast. Just make sure you check your bags before going in as it got very confusing for us.
Not much too see. Walked here from our hotel. Was nice took a few photos. Nothing much happening around here. A few soldier's marching an mostly tourist s. Was good to kill a few hours

Only 3 in the World. Ho Chi Minh, Mao, and Lenin are the only leaders who are preserved with a special embalming process. It's interesting for that reason. You can not take any photos or carry any backpacks so plan ahead. There are long lines and it's best to get there early. My husband had his hands clasped behind his back as we were walking past and the guards made him put them at his side. Very serious and regimented. The guards keep the line moving at a slow but steady pace so even if the line is long, you get through with not much problem. We were told that his body is removed once a year and sent to Moscow for a month where they "refurbish" it. So it might not be open depending on when you travel.

Mysterious and Awesome. January 31, 2016 - As we came closer to the end of our tour of Vietnam, we visited Hanoi for a few days. Today, we visited Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum with our guide. We visited in the morning and it was an overcast day, sometimes a little rain. From the entrance to the area, it is quite a walk to the entrance to the Mausoleum. But once at the entrance, we did not have to wait long before we were inside of the building where we had to climb a few stairs before we got the area where we walked around the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh. It was a fascinating experience.No pictures are allowed inside of the Mausoleum and you must take off your hat as a sign of respect.As you leave the Mausoleum, have the chance to walk by a garage which has some of Ho Chi MInh's old cars on display. The, as you continue walking, you have an opportunity to walk by the structure where Ho Chi Minh worked and lived in his later years, the building where he lived just before he died and the building where he died (when he had maximum medical assistance).The entire area is well maintained and there is a beautiful lake.

Glad to have visited. The line seemed long extending outside of the square but surprisingly it moved very quickly. About 45 minutes from when we got on line until we were inside the mausoleum. Well maintained. Lots of guards dressed in white throughout area which made for some great photos. No cameras or bags allowed inside the actual mausoleum. Our Tour Guide had a big bag and he kept all of our cameras, etc. outside for us.

A must if in Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh is Vietnam's national hero. A visit to his mausoleum is a must if in Hanoi. Very austere Soviet style architecture, but very nice to see. The surrounding area is very nice as well. Definitely with a visit.

A must. This is a must for a visit in Hanoi. There can be long lines. To find the entrance for the visit, walk towards the Ho Chi Ming Museum - there is a long low building and covered waiting-line area. You are not allowed to take photos inside.

You've got to be seriously interrested in Soviet architecture or HCM!. I guess I am biassed as I don't do mausaleums of dead embalmed people, so we certainly did not waste time queueing up to go inside. The building itself could in no way be described as attractive it's sort-of monolithic in a soviet kind of way. The security people also make an inordinent fuss about you walking in front of it (even on the far side of the square|) whilst it is open and then abandon all this pretence once it is closed - I mean, do they think we are gling to spirit away the corpse or something!?!However, your guide will insist that you go and see it - just don't waste much time doing so!

Austere. Huge construction, did not go inside as it was closed. Found the colours on the marble to be a little bleak, maybe because it was raining at the time. Big complex and lots of visitors. Definitely worth visiting.

Worth a Visit. We were lucky to be on a tour so got to know the full history of behind it. It's very very busy. Loads of kids on field trips. You get to see his house on stilts and cars he owned a look in to his house.We never went in to the mausoleum as our guide said it can be up to 4hr que and you might not get to see him but we didn't have the time. Must see if you are there. Nice little shops before you exit

A must do.. This I guess is the must do in Hanoi. It closes at 11.30am. So an early start in a must.Their are lots of other things to do and see in this area, so you could spend a couple of hours in this general area. No bags or cameras allowed.

A great memorial to a revolutionary leader. A somber place. well kept and maintained. Great to pay respects to Vietnam's Father of the Nation. Huge area to walk around. The body is preserved indoors and can be viewed till 11am on most days. Smart military guards man the doors and keep the unwanted away.

An area with many things to visit. Of course the mausoleum is a key visit but bring time as you may queue for many hours. In the surrounding parc you can visit the one pillar pagoda and if you leave towards the north you can see the West lake and visit the chua tran Quoc (20 min walk). You pass by the presidential palace. Worth the little detour!

Interesting see. Follow the masses of people into the grounds. Ensure you dress appropriately (cover knees and shoulders for both men and women and better to wear closed shoes). You then queue for a while and snake along until you get the the mausoleum itself. Inside is an embalmed Uncle Ho, which you see for about a minute as you shuffle along before you are outside again. From there you can pay either for the museum, or the house of Ho Chi Minh, both are interesting. 30 000 pp for either I think. The guards dressed in white are very smart to see and it is just fascinating to see how respectful the people are towards the man they highly revere.

Woah Mr. Ho. I borrowed this review - purely because it gave me a huge giggle as we experienced exactly the same :I rated this site highly purely because since it is free, it is worth experiencing the bazaar event for yourself. Before you go, make sure you have read even just a small paragraph about Ho Chi Minh. Hell I will tell you the little I know. Uncle Ho wanted to be cremated and have his ashes spread across Vietnam (kind of as a giant gesture of Vietnamese unity). After he died, they decided instead to embalm him and place him in possibly the coldest ugliest building you will ever come across. It is rumored the (wannabe Lincoln mimic) building is representative of a lotus flower. We had fun trying to imagine how! Why I recommend the trip is because once you have been marched into the mausoleum, silently walked around the body and marched right back out you will feel genuinely disturbed. More than ever you will appreciate your free will and rights! Go do it! << like he said ... go do it

A must see.. This should be one of the required stops on your visit to Hanoi. Not only will you have the opportunity to see Uncle Ho as the Vietnamese refer to him out of respect, but you will also realize the importance Ho Chi MInh played in the history of Vietnam.
didnt know we would see this. A very special place for Vietnamese people - very traditional and special they loved this man very much

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Interesting adventure. We were lucky as it was a rainy day when we went so the queue to get in was small but apparently it can be hours before you get into the actual mausoleum on a busy day. You have to go thru security before entering, then have to strictly follow a very long path and roadways, following instructions from armed guards, before you arrive at the place. Once we finally arrived at the mausoleum, it was all over and done with in a flash, as you have to keep walking, past Ho Chi Minh's body, and out the door. It was certainly worth visiting but get there early and expect it to take up at least 4 hours of your day.
An important part of the nation's histroy. It's a must-see because of Ho Chi Minh's historical importance to Vietnam and it's not expensive. In fact, I don't remember paying anything to walk by it.

Pay your respects to the Dear Leader. Its the Wandering Yank here. For Americans of a certain age, Ho Chi Minh is probably the only North Vietnamese (or Vietnamese period) one could name. Here's your opportunity to see him in person. To be honest, he looks a little waxy.Mrs. Yank and I visited on a Sunday. Avoid taking a bag or backpack, as you'll have to check it in at the entrance to the park complex mid-way on the queue. It closes at 1030 this time of year, so we had to be back to the baggage check by then, consequently we were a bit rushed. You'll also have to check in cameras at a second point near the mausoleum, so give up any idea of a selfie with you know who.The queue was very long, but it moved along fairly quickly.Be sure to dress modestly - no shorts or bare shoulders - or you'll be turned away, or so we were told by other foreigners.

Eerie!. Dont let the massive queue put you off - it moves quickly and as westerners we were (embarrassingly) paraded half way down the long queue of vietnamese to cut in. Waited only about 15 mins to see the preserved body. Was shouted at by the scary guards for talking and using cameras whilst in line! The rest of the HCM complex is more interesting.

Weird but interesting experience . This is definitely one of those "do it for the experience" things. Remember to get there early as it closes at 11:30am. Note you are not allowed cameras or backpacks inside, you can drop these off with the staff in storage, but to save you a bit of hassle just use your phone for pics and leave everything else behind. You will be met with long lines and quite comically strict guards. Fortunately, the line moves relatively quickly and before long you will find yourself being shuffled past HCM himself, the encounter will be brief so drink it in while you can. After seeing Uncle Ho you are ushered outside where you can check out the house he used to live in, I would say it is worth the entry fee and quite interesting.

moving. Dont be scared off by the line to enter as it goes through quite fast and very well supervised. Very moving and do take a guide with you to know all the history about Ho Chi Minh. I normally just like to wonder by myself but found having a private guide the history is really good to know

Good if it's your first mausoleum . Having visited the Lenin memorial before it wasn't anything new but if you haven't seen this before totally worth it. Sad that's it's not what he actually wanted but what can you do. The surrounding grounds are nice but it's a mash of people.
vietnam 2016. A VERY long queue and get there early as if you are not in the complex by 100 you are not allowed in, I was amazed in how many people were queueing to get in. The museum was very good.

Busy on Saturday. . Visited today on a Saturday. There were tons of kids and soldiers in green uniforms. Saw the museum but was required to go through security check to even get close enough to the mausoleum and it was too long a wait. I think there are better venues to see during the weekend. I'd wait for a weekday to see this one. Not many places for us old folks to sit and rest....lots of walking. Great place for kids. Massive history lesson if you can spend some time and read through stuff.

Very interesting!. I had to queue for over an hour to view Ho Chi Minh's body. It was interesting to see how many people queue to see him and it is quite surreal. The viewing takes a matter of minutes and is quite formal but worth taking the time to do. There is plenty to do on the grounds including visiting the museum, the one pillar pagoda and shopping for souvenirs! Closed Mondays.
Worth a look for the Importance. We did not go in, queues can be horrendous, but the building is impressive. Probably impressive on ceremonial days.

A good photographic and history opportunity. The mausoleum is included in the city tour and is held in reverence by locals in addition to Lenin. It is ideal to go on a tour to these sightseeing highlights as often an English explanation is not provided. This can be viewed and photos completedIn around 15 minutes. Combine this also with a self guided trip around the city using a sight seeing guide to glean the history.

Fascinating to go in and see it. It's a nice area to walk around and see the tribute made for Ho Chi Minh in Hanoi. It's well worth the 10-15 mins queue to go in the mausoleum (I think it is open only in the mornings and for longer hours in the evening - check timings online before going). The gardens and parks around are quite nice too

Worth visiting!. Ancestor worship is such an integral part of the Vietnamese culture and this is it done on a grand scale! For non-Vietnamese visitors it is a really interesting experience to see the respect Ho Chi Minh is given. The buildings and gardens are immaculate and heavily guarded, and the tour is quite regimented. I didn't really want to see his preserved body (being a bit squeamish) but I did and am glad I went and saw this emblem of modern history.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is one of the 3 Communist Leaders’ Mausoleums in the world. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is one of the 3 Communist Leaders’ Mausoleum in the world. They are contemporaries in the fight for Marxism. Like Mao Ze Dong in China, Stalin in Russia. Ho Chi Minh is a well respected leader in their war against the French for independence. The Mausoleum is usually very crowded. You may be disappointed in the long line up. It is best to get a tour guide who will help you to see the place more relax and find short cut for you.

Nice Tribute. A nice tribute to a man revered highly in Vietnam. Right near the new government buildings. Felt better than Stalkn's tomb in Red Square. Don't go on Mondays because closed on that day. Can get crowded fast

Be prepare to wait hours of lines. Great leader, should see, but there was a huge line so we did not get inside the mausoleum where Ho Chi Minh is burried. We just visited from the outside.. Even so we waited about half hour. Make sure to not visit in hot or rainy days..very long lines and you have to follow the path..

Must see on trip to Hanoi. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is an impressive structure in the center of a large plaza with guards stationed all around. Although you can go inside to see Ho Chi Minh's preserved body, our tour guide discouraged us from doing so citing long lines and the inability to take in your belongs (it's only open from 8-11 a.m. on certain days of the week as well).

monument to a Leader. Very interesting place to visit. You must be patient as you may find lines of 2 hours to enter the Mausoleum. As most of the communist leaders Mr. Ho Chi Minh was embalmed.Close by you can also visit the one leg Pagoda.

Very interesting, especially for history lovers. Go either early in the morning or right before they close to avoid the lines. Ho Chi Minh is revered by the Vietnamese and all visitors to the Mausoleum need to wear pants and shirts with at least short sleeves. The inside is dark, cold, and quiet and you get to see his preserved body. Go and see the cars and his home afterwards as well. It was interesting to see how much the Vietnamese still respect and honor him, and to learn a bit about his life.

part of recent history. to my understanding a visit to Vietnam should also include a trip into the recent past of this exciting country. Therefore a visit a visit to Uncle Ho's Mausoleum is a perfect choice to get an idea of the fascination that he has still for the Vietnamese people. No photos allowed inside and you will of course need to be respectful. A no hat and sunglasses policy is required.

Interesting visit. If you enjoy history or have some interest in history of Vietnam, then you will learn a thing or two. Display of Ho Chi Minh,s place when he lived, the house, his car collection and the larger areas are good, otherwise it's a place where the leader of Vietnam used to live!.

A passing visit with a tour group. . The visit was from outside only. The tour guide was excellent with her knowledge of the history of this site. We were allowed photos from a distance - guards were protective of this distance.

Interesting and worth a visit. This man is a legend in the Vietnamese people eyes, and rightly so. It's worth a visit for sure. The preserved body of Hoi Che Minh is a highlight. No photos allowed inside and you will of course need to be respectful. A no hat and sunglasses policy is required.

Odd. Wasn't really interested in visiting but was part of tour. After queuing up for what seemed like hours, but wasn't, finally got in. Jobs worthiness gone mad. Got yelled at and ordered around and wasn't allowed to take my camera in. Queued for ages again and several people were ordered and yelled at. Finally got into the mausoleum and had to be silent which is fair enough. Fast march around the body of Uncle Ho. He looked really odd, more like a wax work. It is sad that his final wishes were not followed because he did not want to be entombed like this. I suppose it is because he is so respected that the people want to see him.

Worth the effort. A really surreal experience. It's not particularly clear how to access the site, but once inside the level of security seems a bit excessive, with certain items such as cameras confiscated for the duration of the 'tour', but phones (with cameras) permitted. After following the well-defined route through the site under the watchful eyes of smartly-presented guards, the mausoleum is entered and silence rigorously enforced as you are hustled around the dimly-lit viewing gallery above the 'body'. No stopping, photographing, visible legs or acts regarded as disrespectful. It's a well stage-managed experience.

100% A must see!. This sight is definitely a must on your list of things to do. We recommend arriving as early as possible, and you should expect to queue when you arrive. Something to note... We went on a weekday, and were informed that if we came on the weekend, we were looking at a 2hour long queue.*If you wear shorts and have bare shoulders then expect to be told to cover-up. If you don't go appropriately dressed there are local shops that sell shawls for approx. 100,000vnd.
great for pictures!. It is a great place to walk and take pictures and that is more than enough for what I wanted. There is a tour but I was not interrested in that.
Mrs. Long wait, crowded wouldnt say it is a place to go. Lots of people, very strict and couldnt even reay see the body when we went by.

Marched 2 by 2. After being in Moscow and seeing Lenin tomb I thought the Russians were strict with the rules of visiting but the Vietnamese were even more.Got in trouble for crossing my arms as we marched through 2 by 2 like a army.Outside this the attraction was fantastic and get eat to see Ho Chi Minh.Worth a visit

Enlightening. A very imposing, clean and regimented precinct. Whilst the Mausoleum was closed during our visit the museum was very informative and gives an insight into history and politics in Vietnam from the 1960's onwards.A must for any visitor.John and Chris
a visit to Uncle Ho is a must do in Hanoi. The queues can look frighteningly long but they don't take as long as you think - arrive early 8-8:30 to get the shortest queue time

Avoid at weekends, go early. We just went this morning (Tues 7:30am) and were done before 8am. It looked like it was getting busier when we left and I assume the waiting time on weekends is much longer. It is a short but eery experience and the atmosphere is quite moving.

Not a priority. It's certainly interesting, especially to see the amount on Vietnamese who come here to pay homage, but it's not great given the long lines. It's not as "ugly" as it's alleged to be, in fact it's pretty grand. Still, there are a few better uses of time in Hanoi.

Worth the wait. We waited for a bit over an hour in the queue before actually seeing Ho Chi Minh's body. The queue moved reasonably quickly considering how many people were there. The actual viewing of the body was over and done with in less than a minute but quite amazing to see regardless. There are four soldiers standing to attention around his corpse and the room is silent (even with the masses of school children visiting). It is also quite cool. You're outside before you know it and can then visit the grounds of the palace. Definitely a worthwhile experience and not something you're going to see everyday.

Interesting observations here!. We queued for six blocks but it only took less than an hour and I that time we enjoyed observing everyone . The respect and patience shown by little children to their parents was amazing, and of the Vietnamese as they paid homage to Ho Chi Minh(who is apparently retouched in Russia each year). The grounds were enjoyable.

Impressive. This free tour is, I have to say it, almost only a long waiting line to see, at the end, Ho Chi Minh body. But the ceremony, the sovietic building and the atmosphere make this place very impressive.Great but you better go there early as there is a lot of people and it is open on morning only.Free entrance

Imposing. The queues to visit this are enormous, usually starting very early in the morning so we contented ourselves with visiting the outside rather than join the queue to go in. Everything was well ordered and clean in the surrounding area and the entrance area was well guarded by army personnel. A very imposing monument.

...Cannot say in a word.... ...That used to be my dream when I still a small girl......Could visit to Hanoi, could see Uncle Ho, that is really my big dream..and that day came...I could see him, a strange feeling..and I counldn't say it in a word......We, my other three friends and me, start at 8 am from Old Quarter drove to Ba Dinh Square, the feeling was peaceful, a slowly life, not quickly like in Sai Gon where we are living,...and Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum was here, in front of our eyes...^^...we waited for about 1 hour before could go inside to see his body...how to say my feeling that time...he lied there, just like sleeping...his face is still like smiling...his hand is long and beautiful...i tried to walk really slowly than other in order to see him more and clearly...and even now when i am writing this status...my tear is streaming out......I will be back and believe my feeling not change...

Interesting experience - even the long queues!. I wasn't sure whether to visit the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum when we were in Hanoi as we were travelling with two teenagers and I had been told the queue can be up to 2km long and a 90 min wait. However we were on a city tour and this was on the list and I'm very glad we went. I would highly recommend doing this with a guide as ours knew where to get the driver to drop us off, where to get into the queue and then for the hour that we had to queue he told us about Ho Chi Minh and Hanoi and all sorts of interesting info. He also got us talking to a school group in front of us so they could practice their English and then he translated what they were saying. The wait time in the queue went by very fast and was an experience in itself. Viewing Ho Chi Minh was interesting and it meant so much more as we had been told a lot about him beforehand. The queue is marched through and past the body very fast - that's how they get so many people through in the 3 hours it's open - and there is no photography allowed. Highly recommended with a guide!

Changing of the guard. This is a quick stop best made T the top of the hour when you can see the changing of the guard. Ho Chi Minh is revered a nd this is worth the visit. The changing of the guard is worth seeing as well.

A strange experience . First you queue in pairs, then singly, then through security. You must leave cameras behind or they confiscate them. (you collect it at end of visit). I did not realise we were visiting the embalmed body of HCM, beard and all. Quite a shock!. Soldiers in white guard him and you must be very respectful. Some lighter relief comes later when you visit the lovely house and gardens but be prepared for crowds.
Not sure what to say. An experience I won't forget in a hurry. Guided through by very young solders in white uniforms. You don't get chance to stop.

Better understanding of Vietnam history. We visited the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. It is just opposite the Vietnam parliament. Very interesting to learn about Vietnam history from our guide and we came away with a newfound respect for the humble but great man who gained independence for Vietnam.
Must visit place. Very organize,and you can see Ho Chi Minh body inside the mausoleum. Excellent place to visit inHanoi
Too busy. Impressive scale and size and interesting to learn the history but who really wants to see an embalmed body - clearly lots of locals
Worth visiting. It worth visiting how they respect the leader who made them over US in war and unfortunately he was not alive in the time of victory. The time you should spend depends on the queue.

Long queues, pay hom. Would avoid when it is raining and when it is hot.
Children found it incredibly boring. I was not far off that myself.
Very long queues and you have to follow the path. Zzzzzz

Huge lines, not much to see. The lines were insane and the traffic surrounding the mausoleum was even more crazy than usual. You get about 30 seconds inside and cannot take a pic for speak, so the queue isn't really worth it

Do it but don't worry if you run out of time. You know what you are in for based on the other reviews... A long line (90 min for us, arriving at 9:45 am on a Saturday) and a quick look. This is a huge attraction for Vietnamese locals, and we had fun attempting to chat with the young students who wanted to take photos and practice their English. You need to line up to get into the grounds to look at the other Ho Chi Minh related museums so if you have time you may as well see what the fuss is about if you have the time. If you only have a day there are better things to do like a street food tour.
Unique and historic. For us this unique experience was worth the 45 minute line. The ceremony and respect of this mausoleum was very impressive.
One more dead hero. Go see it. It is worth standing in line and watch the school children and the veterans marching to pay respect to the dead leader.
Must see. If manage to get over here, u must see it, it's really great to see how the people and government respect their leader which left finger print in the countery history.

Not worth your time. Such a horrible place to visit. The guards were rude and makes you feel like you're in prison. They shout at people when they're walking across the field and to those sitting on the curbs, but they were too lazy to shout at those who was sitting at the curbs 20 meters away.

Interesting. Sadly closed when we went so could visit inside but spectacular mausoleum to view from the outside . However they close the square between 11-13.00 to the public and at various points you can't take photos . But an impressive square to view

Crowded ++. The line up for the tomb was at least 2kms long, so decided we weren't that interested - huge line, humid, NO THANKS. Big attraction for locals. We instead walked around the grounds which was free and with the guide narrating the history

Long queue but moved quickly. When our tour stopped here & we saw the lines that seemed to span many city blocks I was slightly panicked with an (un-interested!) 8 yr old and 13 yr old in tow! Our guide got our group into line and checked on us throughout the wait. He said it would only be 40 min to an hour, we all had serious doubts about that! However, once the line started moving it was a continuous flow and indeed was only around 50 minutes. Apparently we were towards the end of the open hours for the day (closes at 11am?). Be conservative in dress, shorts/skirts below the knee, covered shoulders and the guards will make you take off hats before entering. I had a sleeveless shirt on but gave our guide a few dollars and he purchased a scarf for me, no issues. It was a solemn and quick pass around the body lying in state. If you want to go I would recommend going as early as possible in the am to cut the wait time but if you have to do the wait, it really wasn't that bad.

A history lesson in itself. After queuing for well over an hour, along with about a million others, we finally reached the mausoleum. An interesting experience that has encouraged me to do more research on my return home. Security is tight but understandable. A lot of history involved and I don't envy the guards who maintain such a severe presence for such long hours.
part of history. it is closed in the afternoonsthe guadrs / soldiers are not amused if one tries to get too close to the parts closed for public , not even to take a picture
Very busy. Went on a Sunday, so a lot of visitors.We decided life was too short to queue for 2+ hours so didn't see him.Grounds are interesting.

queue hours to spend 30 seconds viewing a very suspect wax works like image.. Go if you must, but it's a real disappointment and you'll be processed by very communistic guards and attendants - only time I realised this definitely still is a communist country despite the wealth seen on the streets.

Interesting. The visit to the Mausoleum was free but required a lot of security to get to. We got through quickly (Wed 10am) but I have heard of others waiting hours on the weekends. There was no standing, we were rushed through pretty quick, but worth it, would recommend to others.

A must do. Weekends can be very busy - and ensure that you have lined up at the correct location. We went mid week and early - somehow we were escorted to the front of a line. The line moves at 7.30am but the mausoleum opens at 8am. We were right behind the guards and first in. Then the path takes you out and into the Presidential Palace, Ho's homes and car garage and Ho Chi Minh Museum. The Mausoleum itself is a sombre affair and represents the respect the people have for their leader. We arrived at 7.20am and were through about 8.15am - you get 30 seconds in the actual chamber - if you stop you get moved on.
A Bit Scary, A Bit Reality.. Long lines, but to see the "sleeping" Ho Chi Minh up close and personal is very memorable. Be very quiet, respect the rules, no photos! - guards are extremely serious!

out for repair. we walked by the grounds. they are very pretty sadly Uncle Ho was out for repair so we didn't have to see him. I actually think it was a rainy day. No great lose for me it was a canned tour

Interesting place. The Ho Chi Minh-mausoleum complex is a rather interesting place. To a foreigner it was interesting to see the Vietnamese people's reaction when entering the mausoleum itself. He still means a great deal to many of them. The rest of the complex is a collection of buildings and garages and gardens. A good place to spend a morning or an afternoon.
Worth going to see but not to queue. An impressive monument but unless you really want to don't spend the time queuing to go inside. A walk around his house is interesting.

I want that hour of my life back. Ho Chi Minh is a national hero for the Vietnamese and they will line up for hours to spend even just a few moments with him. So unless you're Vietnamese or have a strong sense of national pride, it's just not worth it. The wait was an hour and included fending off constant line cutting and the person behind me crawling up my backside...all to be shoved (the guards literally grab you and push you along) along for two minutes time in the mausoleum itself. Full respect for Ho Chi Minh and his loyal Vietnamese, but for most of the rest of us, just take photos of the building from the outside and move along.

Not much to see. We only had to queue about 10 minutes before going in, when you basically see the embalmed body of "Uncle Ho" for a few minutes before leaving again. It probably has a lot more significance for locals and maybe other Asians. But personally i didn't find it all that interesting. I understand that sometimes to queues are significantly longer. If the was the case I would give it a miss.

A strange experience for a foreigner. We visited this attraction during a Free City Tour with a local student. It was a strange experience as a foreigner who was unaccustomed to such a thing. Very quiet and somber, lots of rules and intimidating soldiers (on purpose of course). I can't say it was "enjoyable", but it was definitely interesting.

It's the People. The lines were long, but efficient. It was interaction with the children that was the highlight of our time there. The hundreds of school children on school day trips were a delight. Very friendly and asking our names, trying to use their English. But all well behaved. The Mausoleum complex was impressive with Ho Chi Minh's house on display. Simple and spare.

A glance of Uncle Ho. This is something you must plan to go, not just happen to pass by and decide to drop in. You have to stand in line to buy a ticket (our tour took care of this so I had no details).Then stand in line again to walk through a security check. Cameras nor ipad is not allowed and if the security detects it you will have to leave it with the security. The day we went, there was a Chinese lady who kept taking pictures with her mobile phone. A security guard walked passed her many times as a warning gesture but she kept doing until he had to give an order for her to stop and turned off her phone. You will not have more than a few minutes with Uncle Ho. So if you had no idea of what this great man had done for his beloved country, you might think it is a waste of time. Considering the number of people who queue up patiently to get in, I would recommend you familiarise yourselves with the history of new Vietnam before visiting this place. It will make this visit much more intersting and worthwhile.

Impressive Tomb. Uncle Ho did much for North Vietnam and his body is entombed here. Viewing is mornings only and we missed this. It was suggested to us that the body is a waxwork but we cannot comment on this. The area is traffic free which is quite unique in Hanoi and woe betide anyone who crosses the yellow line to get nearer to the mausaleum. the guards get quite irate!

No entry on Monday and Friday to see his embalmed body. The actual Mausoleum is just as you see in the pictures, but large crowds mass in front for pictures especially the Vietnamese. Good to say you have seen it but even as our guide said, it is a smaller version of the Moscow one. The tour around the back and Ho-Chi Minh's private home and gardens are nice.We went on a Friday for upkeep of his embalmed body, but to be honest I think this would be for loyal citizens and not a great Tourist sight, especially as I believe the queues are enormous.,

Unique Vietnamese Experience. This is worth a visit if you're in the area. It's a very solemn experience but important to the history of Vietnam. It's also very unique! It's kind of like the less-beautiful Taj Mahal of Vietnam. The line is usually quite long, but it moves quickly. Afterward you can see the grounds of where Ho Chi Minh's palace was as well as where he lived (there is a small fee). You can't bring in big bags or cameras, but they provide places for you to check those in for free. There is also a museum connected but it was closed when we were there.

Giant Edifice to One Man. Unfortunately, being a foreigner, we were unable to experience this attraction in its entirety. We skirted the mausoleum-proper rather than being able to feel the potential emotion of its contents.

Different sort of attraction. We went into the mausoleum out of interest because we were passing on a walk. I am so glad that we did, of course it was very solemn but I had never seen this sort of thing before. The grounds are lovely and the pagoda was beautiful and worth a visit. The monk was reciting from a book and striking his gong, it was so peaceful that I could have stayed there all day immersed in my own thoughts.

Homage to a hero of Vietnam. This is a very well organised mausoleum. We went with a group so was able to jump the queues. But no pushing or shoving and lots of army to keep you under control and your cameras in your pockets. Strictly taboo to take snaps. You quickly walk past Ho Chi Minh's glass coffin. But check your timings if you want to see his preserved remains. The authorities take him down regularly for maintenance. Food and drink stalls and souvenirs at the end.

Interesting. The mausoleum was really interesting. There are several guards stationed everywhere - be prepared to be stopped, questioned and told what to do. The guards are particularly strict as you enter the Ho Chi Minh palace - not even hands in pockets allowed. Ho Chi Minh lies preserved in the palace. It's an odd experience if you've never seen something like that before. Entry fee around 40,000 dong. You must store your bags and large cameras with government staff as you enter.

Enjoyed the experience. At first was not sure if it was worth the long que being Sunday it gets very busy but they are very organized & get you through . I've never seen an embalmed body before Ho Chi Min's body has been preserved quite well

very long wait but so popular with the locals. We had to do this as it is very much talked about! we waited for a long time as it is a very popular attraction with locals and foreigners. Ho Chi Minh was a very much beloved figure for the Vietnamese. I would recommend visiting the mausoleum but also the places he lived - worth a day trip and as there are gardens around ideal for kids to run around for a bit!

An eye opener.. My teenage years were dominated by the Vietnam war and to come face to face with Uncle Ho was quite extraordinary. The reaction of Vietnamese people to a man who defeated the French and the Americans and established a united Vietnam was very moving. Long queues......avoid weekends....but well worth it to complete the picture.

I LOVE VIETNAM. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is an important historical attraction of Hanoi, known for honoring the national hero: President Ho Chi MinhThe mausoleum is open only in the mornings and that to for 5 days in a week. Closed on Mondays and Fridays. There is always a big queue for visiting the place. Lots of school children are brought to visit this. So it takes a little time and patience to get inside.If you’re lucky, you’ll catch the changing of the guard outside Ho’s mausoleum – the pomp and ceremony displayed here rivals the British equivalent at Buckingham Palace
Don't go on Monday . Great site we unfortunately went on a Monday when it is closed. But good to be able to see the site of where Ho Chi Minh was buried

If you have the time. Interesting way to preserve a national hero! Wait times can be long, especially on the weekend but the line does move at a steady pace. Ladies....no bear shoulders allowed. Also no cameras. No backpacks.Worth going with a guide to have more information .

imponent - reminds of communist style. nice construction. clearly reminds of communism :) it is definitely worth the walk and it faces a really nice and big green area where you can relax and lay down

Surreal. Had no idea what to expect but it is a tasteful tribute to a man so clearly adored by a nation. It's not harrowing or morbid.Go early as only open 8-11am and the queues are really long. There are also 2 queues we found - one for the actual mausoleum and one for grounds - make sure to find out which one your in as there are no signs and the marshals unhelpful.

Interesting visit. Pleased we did the tour to help understand what this man did for the Vietnamese people and how well they respect him. A must see whilst visiting Hanoi, don't be put off by the queues.

Must go to Uncle Ho. The body lying in state was closed but this may have saved us from very long queues and our guide suggested that the body was not actually Ho anyway. A very impressive site with beautiful gardens and Ho's simple house on stilts which he actually used and demonstrating the simple life he craved. Don't miss the 'one pillar pagoda' which is supposed to stimulate fertility. Early visiting times help miss the crowds.
Long lines. Very long line on the day we went, we decided to skip the Tomb and just went and looked at his house and garden etc. even this was a long wait!
interesting place. we stayed and watched the changing on the guard, quite interesting. Sadly only visited the Mausoleum from the outside as it was closed.

This is so different. My friend and I wanted to spend the morning doing something different than wander around the old quarter. And we were in for a treat. From the moment you set food on the ground - you are ordert around by guards in white uniform. We had to store a camera and a couple of small water bottles before we were allowed to stand in the single line approaching Ho Chi Minh. The tour around HCM dont take long - because you are ushed to keep the pace and keep quiert. It was soooooo different from anything i have ever tried. And we still laugh of the hole experience Try it!

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It's interesting to visit the mausoleum, but the lines can be very long, especially on weekends. However, the Ho Chi Minh Museum has lots of displays about Ho's life and the history of Vietnam's fight for independence and the American War.

Unbelievably long waiting time. The mausuleum is in the city center and it had the longest queue I had ever seen, even early in the morning. Furthermore proper attire is necessary to enter the building.

Long queue. It will take you about 30 mins to an hour to get imside the mausoleum. Despite the long queue, i think it is pretty cool to see Ho Chi Minh - as if he is just sleeping.
Pretty cool to see how strict they are with taking pictures. They would not let you bring any camera inside the mausoleum.

The Mausoleum and Museum are fascinating. This is the main square in Hanoi but is now restricted to foot traffic. It is impressive, however, ther stories behind it all are even more fascinating. If you get a good guide, you will get a good idea of the man, his mission and the difficulties encountered. Even our former communist guide had his apprehensions about the Communist movement and its ability to lead and less than demoncratic country. Some things were left unsaid and he was wise to remain silent.

Where's the front gate?. We were ready to brave the long lines to visit Uncle Ho, but as we were walking and not on a tour, the absence of signage pointing the way to the front of the gate (and subsequent long lines) finally discouraged us. We made some great pictures on the far side of the museum and it is impressive the amounts of people who arrive and the time they spend in order to view his body. The far side of the mausoleum, is interesting as one can view the presidential palace and other government offices.

Vietnam trip . This is a very good activitie for yourself and others. Nice way the Vietnamese honor Ho Chi Minh, his death, his life and humble life style. A walk through of his home and gardens.Plan a half day for this ( arrive early )
Worth a visit. You are not allowed to take pictures inside the mausoleum and so your bags are scanned and your cameras are removed for you to hand in. Queues can be long so get there early.

Only if you are truly interested. We visited the mausoleum one morning after joining a 2 hour queue. Had we known it would have taken this long we wouldn't have bothered.We did get to see Uncle Ho's preserved corpse for about 30 seconds. If this is something you particularly want to do by all means join the queue. If not I am sure you could spend your time more fruitfully in this interesting city.

Worth a Visit. This will seriously take a couple of days to walk the entire thing. Lots to look at, I would have preferred a guided tour to hear some of the history and maybe learn some cool little secrets overall very nice visit. Lots of walking
Horrible. Lines were 2-3 hours long to visit this small mausoleum with nothing noteworthy to mention, Just a waste of time, and the rest of Hanoi is also not worth the trip.

Interesting experience. We came there, and the line was like 1 km long. but everything went very fast. They take your camera and give it back et the exit. You can't stop inside, the soldiers make you to keep going. But it's interesting to see it.

Not sure if it was was worthwhile . It seems this is a must see for everyone coming to Hanoi. Long walk in order to see Ho Chi Minh. But you are rushed through and don't have really time to look. And cannot really see. Maybe wrong time of day to visit

Interesting . Be prepared to queue for many hours to only see Ho Chi Minh for a few seconds. Nevertheless it is very interesting to see how locals still honor him. 95% or more of the visitors are Vietnamese.
Great monument to a leader. A lot of walking on irregular ground. Didn't note anything of extraordinary interest. Learned a little more about Ho Chi Minh.

Don't let the line up concern you. The line to enter was the longest I had ever seen let alone stood in. I was with a guide and we waited 1hr 15mins to enter but the line moved and time went quickly. It was interesting just to be amongst the Vietnamese people and see them pay their respects. You are kept moving once inside, so the whole visit last probably 1 min if you're lucky, go and do it.
See the guards changing procedure. We visited the plaza and saw the guards changing procedure, that reminds the similar procedure new Lenin’s mausoleum in Moscow, on a smaller scale though.

Hello Uncle Ho. Free viewing. Expect long lines, which are mostly covered. No cameras or electronics, they actually have a table set up to collect these and return them at the exit. We kept ours out of sight and ignored this. No messing around here. No hats, talking, or dallying. Two abreast and keep walking. Those are loaded rifles with bayonets, thank you very much.

Not what I expected. Perhaps should have read the tour guide more carefully, I didn'tint expect to see a dead person lying there who had expressly asked to be cremated, poor old chap, long, long queues, sad place.

Father of the Nation. Designed by Soviet Architects, the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum has the inevitable resemblance of Lenin's ditto in Moscow. As eerie as it might seem to pass by the body of a man, who died in 1969, it is a compelling experience, that visitors should not miss. Uncle Ho was the father of many motto's, and his most famous one is the first thing you meet inside: "Nothing is more important than freedom and independence." Let this sink in, while you continue upstairs to pay your respects to the father of the Vietnamese revolution. Do not miss the optional guided tour in the beautiful park, originally belonging to the French colonial governor's palace, where (according to the official legend) Ho Chi Minh spent his last years in a simple stilted house. Even though you might not agree with the views of Uncle Ho and his successors, it is still one of those experiences, where you will sense the wings of history. Do take note that Uncle Ho is absent a couple of months every autumn due to renovation of his remains. You can easily tell if he is in place or not - the honour guard outside is there 24 hours, only if Uncle Ho is inside.

Not in the style of Ho Chi Minh. I really appreciate the history and importance of Ho Chi Minh, the father of a nation. But what I have read is that he was a humble and simple man who wanted his ashes to be spread in the south, central and north of Vietnam. He was famously known for refusing air conditioning in his state home stating he was happy to use a hand fan. The air conditioning he said should be given to a kindergarten as the children needed it more. So standing in line for over an hour to see him for 15 seconds wasn't worth it nor was his wish. What was interesting was seeing how many people came to stand in line, he is much loved. So move over Disneyland this line wins hands down.
A long queue for a short view. We queued for about 90 minutes to see Ho Chi Minh for about 30 seconds. A must do if you are so inclined, but be prepared for a long wait and a bunch of inconvenience
Trippy. Very surreal. Like Mao's Tomb in Beijing. You walk past Ho Chi Minh embalmed in a glass coffin. Very important to get an understanding of modern Vietnamese history though.

Reverent . This was very interesting. We were herded like cattle in very long lines that moved quickly. It's easily guarded and you must do exactly as you are told by heavily armed guards. The queue was a couple of blocks long but moved swiftly as you are herded through. Ho chi min is celebrated here. There is not a lot of information. So do your research before you go.

A Commemoration of a True Hero of his People. Visited the the mausoleum for the second time. This time Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body had been taken for preserving, as it is each year. We could visit the grounds but the mausoleum was closed. An interesting exhibit of colonial era cars, beautiful grounds, Ho's modest home next to the government palace(?).
Go here by night. During day time this place looks rather dull, however, it is nicely lit up in the evening. Not much to see but can be nice to pass by for an evening walk.

Get ready for a long wait. If you think the lines at Disneyland are long think again. Although you can book tickets online most people just show up and are ushered around the block to the end of the line which on our visit was mainly made up of school groups.We arrived at 9.30am and the wait was 90 minutes and it appeared that only a few people were allowed in after that as it closes at 11.30am.Much of the interest is in watching the world go by whilst waiting and once in the mausoleum you are ushered past old Uncle Ho pretty smartly and then out again. Bags must be left at the gate at the entrance but you are given a token and the system works smoothly.

Don't smile while inside the mausoleum!. We were lucky as the queue was relatively small. It is a very grand structure and the guards inside were keen to keep everyone moving. Outside the grounds were immaculate and women and men in the conical hats were weeding and sweeping up. A truly spectacular monument to Ho Chi Minh.
RIP. Paid our respects to Ho Chi Mihn. The que was very long and was about a 1.5 hour wait in line but worth it. So much history to discover. Make sure you get there early

Nearly as good as Lenin in Moscow!. While we joined a very long queue as we did NOT Pre book the visit the line moved very quickly in getting inside the Mausoleum itself, and kept going at a steady pace till you were out the other side.We did manage to see 'The Changing of the Guard' on the outer doors which was very good while the precision was not quite as spectacular as the Guards looking after Lenin in Moscow.While the inside of the Ho Ch Minh Mausoleum was quite well lit and you climbed up the stairs to get there.The Lenin Mausoleum in Moscow was totally dark which made it more 'spooky' and you went down black marble stairs to get there!

Long queue but worth seeing. . Said to be the ghandi of Vietnam. Long queues with rude Chinese unable to patiently wait their turn! Very controlled and high security. Was it worth the wait ??? Yes. Bit weird entering the mausoleum very cold and solemn then there he lay, very respectful and peaceful. Interesting and made better by our very knowledgeable guide.

They love their Uncle Ho :). We went on a Monday and it's closed,so we only took pictures outside the entrance. Go early if you do plan to go in--our tour guide said the lines get really long for this one.

Large memorial.... I visited in the afternoon and the interior was not open. The grounds are very well manicured and the guards quickly approach if you cross the yellow lines. Perhaps this is a part of Hanoi that reminded me I was in a communist country... Worth a visit. If you are in question of where you can go, I found making eye contact with a guard and motioning to where I wanted to go produced a head nod or the "shake off".

Impressive. Spare the time to have a look. We went on a Monday afternoon at around 3pm and it was not crowded at all. You will get some good shots of the guards too. Walk along a little further and visit the gardens and temples - all lovely.
Must See. Don't be put of by the long queue it moves very quickly. No shorts for men and women's shoulders should be covered.

Interesting.... It is a Mausoleum for Ho Chi Minh. That was built after his death. He is located inside but as a visitor you are not allowed in. To me, it was just another sight to see and then move on.

Interesting. A monument worth seeing. . Enjoyed the visit. We went alone without a tour guide. Worth seeing for sure. Best to go before 10.30am if you want to go inside as apparently it closes to the public after that time and you can only look at it from outside. I'm not sure if I understood that correctly though when I read up online. I didn't go inside as we were too late. Check it out either way and visit the museum nearby after.

Must see but get there early. We arrived on a Saturday at 9.30am very busy so went back on the Monday around 8.30am. Whilst the queue appears long it moves very quick. It is all a rush seeing his body but a must do.

Half day visit. Shown around by our stand in guide ( not sure what happened to original), and he dud say that he was not 100% sure what we needed to know. When we got there the queue was enormous but he said 20/30mins and took 1hr 50 mins to get in ( with certain people thinking they were entitled to push in). The place its self was really beautiful and I wish I had read more of the culture of Vietnam before visiting but felt I learned a lot

Suppose need to see if in Hanoi. First leave large bags and big cameras at home (hoteL 0 or they are taken from you at entrance and have to return there easter visit to collect them. Mobiles and mini digital cameras are allowed in but not into the Mausoleum where 'Uncle Ho' body is displayed. The queue for this starts at entrance and disney like every time you reach what you think is going to be the end yoiu join another line. That said the queue moves quickly. Guards understandably want respect shown so noise and mucking around is stopped + the actual walk by the body is in strict two at a time and you probably get less than 20 seconds in the area where the body lies.
