More interesting to see how the locals and guards behave than the actual walk by….. But next door are the Museum and One Pillar Pagoda so can visit those at same time...

Dignified memorial. The area and park around the Mausoleum and One Pillar Pagoda can be crowded at times - but the visit is worthwhile as a demonstration of the reverence in which 'Uncle Ho' is held by many. However, as a Westerner it might be salutary to explore more about the myths and controversy to properly appreciate and place the man himself in context of Vietnam history.

Boring . We went here on a days your around all the old war memorials. Not as good as it is made out to be. You can't go in and see anything, guarded 24/7 but it looks quite pretty from 50ft away (closest you can get). Will take you about 15mins to walk around.

It is all about respect. On the days that the Mausoleum is open hundreds and hundreds of visitors line up to pay respect to Ho Chi Minh, often referred to as 'Uncle Ho'. As a visitor from abroad one can stand in the line, or try the entrance for registered visitors and kindly ask permission to follow one of these groups. Bags are not allowed. there is a line indicating that from there pictures are not allowed. Soldiers in white uniforms organize everything. While 'normal people' line up, other groups (sometimes in uniform) line up on the square. Finally people enter, in two lines, the mausoleum itself. After taking some stairs one reaches the inner part where again soldiers in white uniforms guard the body of Ho Chi Minh and arrange some speed. His body is surrounded by glass. At the exit people head for the Ho Vhi Minh Complex. One has to pay entrance. In this complex various houses where Ho Chi Minh worked and lived without luxury can be visited. Leaving this complex one can see how far the line reaches. Those standing there, among them many children, will certainly have one or more hours to wait before paying their respect. It makes one think about our respect for political figures.

Worth A Visit. After 2 previous attempts, once in November 2014 and once in October 2015 only to face monthly closures, we finally got a chance to visit this mausoleum this March. The visiting days are Tuesday to Thursday, Saturday and Sunday with visiting hours up to only 11:00 a.m. There are strict guidelines to adhere by in order to gain entrance: visitors are paired 2x2 in single file, cameras are absolutely forbidden but can be checked in before entering building and cell phones must be turned off. Once inside the mausoleum, visitors must be absolutely quiet while viewing Ho Chi Minh's preserved body. Once outside, you could also view the changing of the guard if you're lucky.

Amazing that the embalming has lasted this long. This is a very limited time experience. Long single file lines and when you get inside don't dare put your hands in your pockets! They are open for only a few hours as the lower the casket beneath the ground to help preserve the body. It might be a wax figure for all we know, but with their strict rules, maybe it is really the man.

Well worth a visit.. Allow a minimum of 45 minutes to see this place or even longer if the q's are big. We went on a slow day - it is very interesting, but you only get 2 minutes to view Ho Chi Ming. We made our arrangements with Hanoi Transfer Service on our private one day tour.

A must see. You kind of have to go there if your in Hanoi. Mind the opening hours are quite limited and that there might be a huge queue to get in (it moves quite fast though). Don't miss the Ho Chi Minh museum and one pillar pagoda just nearby.

Worthwhile visiting but don't take anything other than a very small bag with you. We took a taxi to the mausoleum. The entrance is quite confusing and we have to walk around the block to get to a very long queue, but it did move quickly, The whole process is quite solemn. Prior to entering the mausoleum you have to leave your camera and any phone. Don't take a large bag or water as you have to leave that at the entrance area to the actual mausoleum , and then when you have finished you visit, walk back to the start to get your bag. It is still worth a visit

Grand and symbolic. Since coming to Vietnam I have wanted to do this and after standing in line for about 40 minutes I have to say it was worth it. Regardless of what you think of Uncle Ho, the regime, etc. it was very interesting to see this grand mausoleum and witness thousands of locals, children and foreigners alike come to view it. No cameras allowed inside, a quiet walk through was very interesting. Very Art Deco, the building and the mausoleum inside very stark but appropriately decorated, oozing with pride of the Vietnamese ruling party. I thought it was worth seeing it; the kids said it was "cool". Entrance is free but note opening hours (closes at 11am for lunch).

Takes time to visit but worth it!!. The mausoleum is open only in the mornings and that to for 5 days in a week. Closed on Mondays and Fridays. There is always a big queue for visiting the place. Lots of school children are brought to visit this. So it takes a little time and patience to get inside.But having a dead person from so long intact is amazing. You don't get to see such stuff everyday. Definitely worth the experience. Vietnamese consider this place holy. So go properly dressed especially for women. Else there is a chance you might not be allowed inside.

Really, really, long line. . . and then, your're done!. Sorry to pop anyone's balloon about this tourist spot being a "must see" in Hanoi. I waited in a long, 2-hour line in March after getting up early to make the "8 am showing" (this attraction closes for several hours in the middle of the day??) and got the opportunity to view Ho Chi Min in repose. Not that great for me, but it is great if you are a Vietnamese citizen. Dozens of tour buses already there at 0830, and as I said, a huge line for about 900 metres in all with lots of rules enforced by the uniformed military staff. I could have driven to Halong Bay in the 3 plus hours I used for this experience. Again, very important and magnificent to Nationalists, but not so for casual tourists! Go to the B-52 museum, or the John McCain parachute site instead.

Amazing building set in a huge open square.. We didn't actually go into to view Uncle Ho (his body is preserved inside and available for viewing, but NO PHOTOS), but the square is massive and the mausoleum itself is massive. Not too far of a walk from the Old Quarter, either.
Nice building. Nice building and if you had already read about it before visiting, you will realise it isn't open all day! Unfortunately, we couldn't access it as it closed at 12md

A Saigonese's first time visit to the museum. I was born and have been living in Ho Chi Minh city for my whole life, and this was the first time I've ever visited Uncle Ho's mausoleum. The feeling was hard to express. However we came to Hanoi on Friday so the mausoleum was closed, only saw it from the outside. But not sure if it's a good idea for everyone to get inside the place where it should be the most peaceful place for Uncle Ho.

Long wait. We had an 1hr and approx 1km wait in line to enter. Not convinced that it was Ho Chi Minh. I feel he may have had a visit from Madam Tussards. I must to see just to say 'been there, done that'
Really. I agree it means a lot to locals and if a particular political leaning. But really a big stretch for the average tourist god it is not a sight as such
Lovely place. Just stopped during a day trip out, great place, very interesting, well worth a visit if you have some spare time on your hands

if you have time, go..... This is only open a few mornings a week,and the lines are very long, but they move fast. The guards are VERY strict about no backpacks or large purses (especially if you are not Vietnamese), and no cameras, but it is still interesting. For a leader that was so into the simple life, it is interesting to see what the country/government has built for him.

Too many people to even get inside. We arrived at 9.30 am and after queueing for ages with many many school children we decided to give it a miss and go to the Temple of Literature instead. Good move.
impressive location. impressive location. we had to queue about 2.5 hours - so be patient! but there are a lot of things to see - including the home of ho chi minh and his cars.

The place to honor the Vietnam Leader.. This is a place where we can see the body of the Vietnam Leader, Mr. Ho Chi Minh who died in 1969. The place was nice but we had to stand in line outdoor to enter the mausoleum, it took about half an hour to get there .

To do on a nice day, if you have spare time. It's not really exciting, but I feel like it has some value if you want to experience it. I went during the Tet holiday, so lots of visitors. Was a nice sunny day which made waiting in line for about an hour not so bad. The line kept moving quite quickly.

Remember this a respectful occasion. You are not allowed to take pictures inside the mausoleum and so your bags are scanned and your cameras are removed for you to hand in. Queues can be long so get there early. Your asked to be respectful in your stance and attitude. It is a strange concept - against Ho Chi Minh's wishes but it does have a funereal diginity despite the crowds it draws
Good to see. Well worth a visit to get an insight into the person Vietnamese people worship. Good history lesson on how Vietnam became the country it is today because of his influence.

Not impressed.. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a large memorial in Hanoi, Vietnam. It is located in the center of Ba Dinh Square. It was ranked as the "sixth most ugly" building in the world by CNN International in 2012 and I can see why. The line was long and going through the building to view the body was strange. However, it seems to be a tourist attraction one must visit.

Hi chi who?. Not sure if it's the real body, probably not. It's basically like a slightly better version of Madame Tussaud's. Is it worth the effort to go there, meh, probably not but it saves having to think about going somewhere else.

Interesting . You need to line up for a very long time to see Ho Chi Minh, so allow the whole morning and a bit of patience. Plenty of people watching and interaction with the hundreds of small school children visiting. I'm glad I went.

Its clean. This place is good for children to come. The weather is so good. There is a big place for children to play. And a fish lake where has so many big goldfishes. Its very interesting to visit the Uncle Ho's house

A bit surreal. Wandering around in a slow moving queue to have a few seconds to stare at an embalmed body is a bit strange. The grounds are very nice though, even though we didn't go into the palace itself (not sure that you can).

Get there early. The line moves steadily. We started 6 blocks away and it took us one hour. Must store very securely all possessions. Good system. Dress conservatively, be silent as you go by his body. It is not there two months a year as he is taken to Russia for Maintenon, so check. Free admission. Huge grounds. Some areas you do have to pay, but not expensive.

Interesting watching changing of the guard. We walked the length of what looks like a runway, watched the changing of the guard and the locals doing their daily exercises. We didn't actually get to go inside the Mausoleum as it's only open on certain days.

Must visit. Highly recommend this place although it's only open from 8am to 11am and usually with a long queue. Reach there around 7am and start to join the queue together with tour group .No entrance fees required and I think it's a must to show a respect to the respectful Hero of this country.

Point of interest. I was just walking around and went to see the mausoleum. It's an interesting building from the outside, you can visit the Ho Chi Minh Museam too. I heard that you can see the body, but you need to go in the morning (I am not sure if every day).
Something to be Seen!. Very silent place, very well organized, no camera allowed. Check the openinig days. You have to go at the back of the Mausoleum to visit the gardens and house where HCM leaved.
A Mausoleum is a Mausoleum. We were in a group tour, & internal access was not available when we visited, so we were told the history & gazed in awe (!!!) at the exterior.
mausoleum was amaZing history worth learning.. Tourist shopping her cheapest in Hanoi, history was amazing, recommended as a must see. Trishaw to city very reasonable. Saved our feet.

Made a big mistake!. We went and being the end of Tet, the lines were huge, and felt it wasn't worth the effort so we spent our time outside. Judging from the the size and care they took to make this edifice.

And "Uncle Ho's" Request Was For A Small Burial Space!!. It is written that he did not want his people to do exactly what they did. History states that after his death Ho Chi Minh requested a small burial space. He wanted to save the land for the Vietnamese people and many generations to follow.Well......that didn't happen. This place is huge! There are even uniformed guards in dress whites that patrol the area. We were there at the right time for the changing of the "guards". It is also said the the young men must be of a certain height and attractive enough to enjoy the privilege and honor to represent their leader.With no crowds on our visit we walked the beautifully manicured gardens and posed for several photos. This is a place of great pride for the Vietnamese and I highly recommend the visit.

Amazing and not to be missed!. I wasn't sure what to expect from this monument however it ended up being an amazing experience! I would recommend this to anyone. On entry security is very tight so I would say don't take a large bag as it takes longer. I took my camera, which is a large Canon and they take them off you. It's safe and secure, you just have to check it in a special camera bag (supplied). The masoleum from the outside is a large square pillared structure which is quite plain. Apparently can withstand an earthquake measuring 7 on the richter scale with no issues. It is heavily guarded by Vietnamese military in white dress suits. Remember to stay silent once you go inside. You are directed through a chamber when Ho Chi Minh lies in a glass coffin. I wasn't expecting that. He is flanked by four guards and there are other guards surrounding the path tourists follow. I find it difficult to express what I felt in words but it was an honour to see him. It looks like he is lying there sleeping and he could wake up any moment. The atmosphere is charged with emotion and it is truly a magicial experience. I honestly could've sat there and watched him for hours. (They don't let you btw.) What charisma Ho Chi Minh had in life has followed him into death, holding the room and the watchers spellbound as they silently file past his coffin, decades after he died.
Ho Chi Minh's House was especially interesting. We particularly enjoyed walking around the area and traditional house where Ho Chi Minh chose to live. Beautiful and informative.

Worth the visit. Our only chance to go was on a Sunday. We knew there would be long lines on the weekend, so we tried to get there early. It was about 45 minutes after open when we found the end of the line. It moved pretty quickly, but it took us about an guys to get to the mausoleum. (We wished we had gotten there a half hour earlier.) It was definitely worth it. The experience, though short, was surreal. A real sense of wonder in that room. We also enjoyed HCM's house and cars on display, as well as the One Pillar Pagoda. We skipped the museum.You have to leave your bags after security, but are told to keep your phones and wallets. We had no problems.

Eye Opening. We joined an extremely long queue of predominantly Vietnamese people wanting to visit Ho Chi Minh's preserved body on a weekend morning. It was humbling to see so many, young and old pay their respects to a political leader with the reverence usually reserved for a religious one. On learning the role he played in the country's history it became less surprising. The queue moved quickly through the well maintained grounds and through the mausoleum (you have to keep moving, no time to linger). An interesting experience.

very controlled. get there before 11am as closes.....great photo shots to be had.....very structured....palace and ground very nice.....if arriving at 11 you will be last tour group....wait at end of tour for the gaurds to leave....they will then form in to ranks and march away past you....very impressive....
worth a visit. quite a sombre experience interesting seeing ho ch minh laying in state very important man to the locals

Honouring a simple great man. True to tradition, the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is a huge marble edifice constructed from materials gathered from all over Vietnam between 1973 and 1975. Modest dress and respectful behaviour are expected. Photography is prohibited inside the monument. A queue of several hundred metres to the mausoleum entrance and inside is common to walk past the glass sarcophagus containing the body of Ho Chi Minh at a slow but steady pace. If lucky, you can see the changing of the guard outside the mausoleum. Contrary to the nature of Ho Chi Minh, the pomp and ceremony displayed here vies with the British equivalent at Buckingham Palace.

No expense spared.. Apparently you can go inside. The day we went, there was so many check points and security checks, we felt it wasn't worth the effort. we just walked past it, clearly it is well visited by the local people.
When in Hanoi. While I understand the appeal and the importance to Vietnamese history, it is hard for me to justify lining up for almost two hours to walk around Ho Chi Minh for 30 seconds.

If you visit Hanoi this ought to be top of your must see tourist list. Skip the travel agent tour guides and package deals, catch a taxi follow the rest of the people walking to the entrance way and pass through the airport style security....it's all free, you haven't spent a penny yet (except the taxi fare, about $4 from the old quarter). You might find a fairly long queue to enter the mausoleum but it's fast moving and there are plenty of military personnel to make sure it's kept moving and kept quiet, no cameras, no talking, remember where you are, you get about three minutes to walk round three sides inside the chamber and view Ho Chi Minh lying at rest, the same Soviet personnel responsible for preservation of Lenin were responsible for the set up.If you joined a tour group your friendly tour guide will most likely tell you the queues are too long or groups are excluded, don't listen to any of that if you've come this far get in line. The museum is a bit of a let down but as you're here you may as well take a walk through and see the exhibits, something else they learned from the USSR, foreigners pay and locals meters for free (just like the Kremlin exhibits in Moscow).

Interesting and a must see while in hanoi. Don't miss the mausoleum when in Hanoi. It is very interesting and a must see. The museum can be skipped however not the mausoleum. Please not that the make you check your backpack but it's only for a few minutes while you go inside and everything was perfectly fine.

Easily the Most Amazing Highlight of Hanoi. Perhaps I didn't have any expectations, but WOW, just Wow. We were told we would never get in because the lines are typically very long. This was not our experience - we waited only about 10 minutes. This is well worth the visit.
A must see in Hanoi.. This was part of a day tour and was one of the highlights. A must see when visiting the city and a very meaningful part of Vietnams rich history. Very respectfully run.

Interesting . Maybe not something everyone would enjoy but I found it pretty interesting. It's only open for a few hours in the morning but we didn't find the lines bad at all. Definitely to be taken very seriously (appropriate clothing, no smiles, and no crosses arms). However Ho Chi Minh being s national hero I found it important and insightful to go check it out.

It is a been there done that check off spot. We arrived early and the line was short. We could tell by the set up that the line gets long. Note security is very tight and proper dress is required. The guards are polite but quite strict. The view of Ho Chi Mimh is fine.

Fascinating from start to finish.. Give yourself a full morning of afternoon and preferably with a guide to make the most of this fascinating tour. Seeing Ho Chi Minh in his glass casket is quite surreal. The other sights are equally fascinating. Don't miss if you are in hanoi

Worth your time. This was a cultural experience that exceeded our expectations. Primarily Vietnamese lined up by the hundreds to pay their respects. It was free. It was a surprisingly moving experience. it made me wonder who in our country could illicit that much loyalty and respect that even after decades, so many people would line up to see them. Highly recommend.

A communist experience. Quite an education to experience the devotion of the Vietnamese to Uncle Ho. One has to walk in line, without cameras, hands out of pockets, hats off, around the precinct which surrounds the Mausoleum in which the body is viewed. Definitely worth a visit for the experience.

Go early and not at the weeekend. This is one to see if you have not been to see Moi or Stalin. Be dressed quite well and respectful and if you can find out a little about this amazing man before you go.
Wow. This place is a must see. Didn't believe we were actually going to see his body but yes we did. Re embalmed every year he really does look like he's taking a nap
Very interesting. Very interesting place to visit and part of Vietnam culture/history. I would definitely recommend it and is worth visiting.

An opportunity to view a great man. We arrived at 09.15. The queue was already past the entrance and up the road, but after a while it eventually started to move and, after 1 hour queuing we entered the mausoleum and saw Ho Chi Minh lying in state. It was a very interesting experience staged with great dignity in superbly well maintained grounds.

Great record of history. It was great to see an important part of Vietnamese history.The grounds, housing, cars and gardens are lovely.Viewing the mausoleum itself is interesting. It's hard to comprehend Ho Chi Minh's body is lying there.It's like a Madame Tussaud creation.It's a great way to spend a morning in HanoiJust make sure you get there before 9.30am to avoid the lines of tourists.

An item on the bucket-list? May be. For the people of Vietnam a Must-see, for communists too for everyone else: If you are in Hanoi, you should take the time. Even If the queue is really impressive, you need only an hour and a half to get a look on the body of Ho Chi Minh.

Enjoyable experience. !. We weren't expecting much here but it turned out to be very enjoyable .when we arrived at the end of the line to get in thought we gonna be waiting for hours. But the line moved very quickly and was really well organised .a bit of a walk to the actual mausoleum. No cameras allowed. The guards ensured that everyone was silent. No hands in pockets. No hanging around. Everyone moved quickly in complete silence. Was quite reverent. Glad we went.

Worthwhile!. If you can get your mind around the fact that there is a western-mind voyeuristic or even morbid sense to this 'attraction' I'd recommend it as a very worthwhile experience.Get to the entrance by 7:30am for opening time if possible. Queues can be long, and even longer on special occasions. That said there is a very efficient system in place - run by ceremonial-dressed military guards. The experience of queueing is great for people watching. There is almost a festive feel happening although this is quickly stamped out by the guards as you enter the mausoleum. You enter the room to gaze on Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body at a slow walking pace - you are not to stop. There are a number of guards surrounding the glass casket with others watching the procession if tourists ensuring that no one speaks or tries to take a photo (cameras are handed in prior to entering although everyone keeps the phones (with built-in cameras!)You remain in the room for less that 2 minutes. You can check out the nearby palace, stilt house, museum and pagoda if you have time. All up set aside half a day to include the mausoleum and these additional attractions.

Knowing a piece of history. A visit to the mausoleum gave me first hand info and knowledge about the great man himself as his remains lay in state. I am amazed by his humility and simple life but in awe with his achievements and despite his stature he remained a very down to earth man. A visit to this mausoleum is a must for history lovers.
embalmed body of ex president. come here early to view the ex president embalmed body. nice place for photos and there is attractions nearby as well

Take it or leave it. The Mausoleum is about half an hour by taxi from downtown Ho Chi Minh city. Whilst he was an important part of Vietnam's history, and the Mausoleum sand surrounds are very elaborate, the actual seeing of his preserved body, might not be worth the effort. The whole thing is very well organised, but only if you are really interested.

Different tourist experience. It's not everyday you get to visit a mausoleum, so here is your opportunity. Line up with the crowds and be herded along the slowly progressing line into the Soviet era building and around the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh.

Peace and quiet. We visited the HCMC mausoleum on a Monday. Un be known to us, it closes on a Sunday and Monday. So we didnt get to go inside. It didnt stop us from enjoying a moped free and car free zone though or the enormity of the Mausoleum.
The queue was half hour long. Didn't get in as the queue was too long ...however wAtched the early morning raising of the flag you need plenty of time for this if you want to see the coffin.....

An important feature of Hanoi. The mausoleum is a hugely important part of Vietnamese life. It isn't going to be the cheeriest part of any day however if you are in Hanoi you really should pay it a visit. It is obviously a very sombre place with a huge presence of soldiers and guards in the area. Obviously you will be expected to show the respect the Vietnamese require whilst visiting. You are required to hand in all cameras and mobiles and will pass through an airport style security check. Once inside the mausoleum you climb up a number of stairs before entering the main hall where the body is housed in a glass case. You are required to walk around the hall without stopping and to be honest you are in there for no more than 30 seconds. The mausoleum is closed for a couple of months in September and October whilst the body is given it's annual spruce up. Make the effort to visit if you're in Hanoi, it really is part of Vietnam's history
Very impressive. When You get some information about a Man , having save his country, You feel respect. Ho Chi Minh I respect You. REst in peace. This place is one pillar pagoda

Impressive!!. Set within a large square, (similar in size to Red Square, Moscow) this huge Mausoleum is an impressive site and it sets the scene for visiting Uncle Ho's gardens and former home etc., located close by. Be advised however: Better to get there 'early' as the enormous number of tourists builds as the morning progresses!!Note: If you want to enter the Mausoleum, don't visit on a Sunday or Monday as it's closed on these days!

Stark Tribute to Uncle Ho. Tourists and Vietnamese come here to see the perfectly preserved body of Communist leader Ho Chi Minh. Order is maintained by a cadre of soldiers. The design of the mausoleum is very simple in keeping with the character of Ho. It is closed several months each year allowing for maintenance of the body.

Uncle Ho looked great . Our group of 15 visited the mausoleum and residence grounds. Although crowded, we saw everything including his perfectly-preserved body, his actual residence, and the One-Pilar Pagoda.

Part of the Vietnamese Culture. If you're in Hanoi, you really must make a trip to the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. When we went it was a Sunday, right after the Vietnamese Tet (New Year's) so many of them were still on holiday mode and many of them visiting the mausoleum but even with that, the line seemed long but went by quickly. You must dress appropriately so women nothing above the knees and you must have your shoulders covered. Men no hats and no hands in the pockets and of course no cameras allowed. It takes merely 30 seconds to actually pass his body but in the North especially he is revered as one of their greatest leaders so it's just interesting to go see where he lies.

Worth a trip!. I visited on a Sunday, so could not go inside. It reminded me of Red Square a bit; the place is designed for a BIG military parade. You can tell this is an important place for the country so please go visit. And as a plus, if you tell the Vietnamese you meet you went there, they seem to appreciate it. Very much.

Very interesting place to visit.. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a large memorial in Hanoi, Vietnam. It is located in the center of Ba Dinh Square, which is the place where Vietminh leader Ho Chi Minh, Chairman of the Communist Party of Vietnam from 1951 until his death in 1969.

A respectfully worth while morning. . My family and I had a great experience seeing the Hanoi locals, especially children, gear up to pay their respects to their Uncle Ho. Thank you to the government for letting us foreigners learn about your history and witness what it means to its people.
Great for Ho Chi Minh lovers. You can see the actual house of Ho Chi Minh and you can see his body if you go there early in the morning. It's nice view at night as well

It is what it is.... The whole process to get in took less than 15 min, so the 15 seconds in the hall where Ho is laying were not a big invest in waiting time. We could take smaller cameras and cell phones. It is comparable to Mao and Lenin. In general, you should not expect too much...other than seeing a dead body.

Very strictly controlled.. Uncle Ho is worth a look, died almost 50 years ago and they have him at rest for all friends and foes to view. Bit of a new experience as never saw a modern times embalmed body before.The facility and surrounds are very well looked after and we'll set out. Well maintained expansive grounds cover the whole complex which comprises museums as well as this mausoleum.However it is all over the top as the white uniformed military control the visiting public with a military approach to an extent that it is unnecessary but not overbearing so as to impact but not spoil the purpose of your visit here.Very much worth a visit.Easily accessible by taxi to and from the site with cost from Top end of Old Quarter around vnd50,000 but return was twice as much - both with metered taxi (no surprise).Care, check times on website as closes early in day.

Visit to the tomb of one of Vietnam's most influential figures in history.... Visited the Mausoleum with friends on a morning tour (as it is only open until 11:00am, also to miss the crowds) with a guide. Seeing the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh was unique and shows the respect Vietnamese people still have for what he achieved. As such make sure you dress appropriately and sorry to say no cameras are allowed. Also the armed guards (dressed completely in white) stand out, but be respectful and mindful when taking pictures of them. The mausoleum does get busy (especially in the later morning) and is closed Mondays and Fridays. Interesting to architecture and history enthusiasts. Although I depending on the weather I would recommend: Sun Screen, Water, Camera, Hat or Umbrella.

Over Sensationalized. Worth a visit once. Badly organized with their directions regarding leaving your personal belongings. Long lines and inaccessible to disabled. Absolutely no English description anywhere.

Historical privilege. The mausoleum is a very sombre place, but has an immensely powerful "aura", which you should definitely experience. For anyone of my generation, who lived through the Vietnam war, visiting this place will evoke strong memories, and powerful emotions. Don't miss it.

Historical Visit. We visited as part of our Travelmarvel tour and understand this is a very significant part of the Vietnamese culture but I could have done without viewing the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. It is set in huge parkland and we enjoyed walking around the area though. It was very crowded so be prepared to queue and wait in line and follow orders from the armed guards.

Bizarre, but worth doing. It feels a bit weird to be trooping past the embalmed body of somebody who died 40+ years ago, but the mausoleum and accompanying museums (you get access to 2 museums with the same ticket) are pretty interesting.
Only open until 11.00am so go early. Great place to walk around but closed on Mondays and Friday's and only open early in the morning. It's a good place to start a morning walking tour
Impressive. We were only able to view the outside as it was not open to the public at the time we passed by - but very impressive building

somber but must see. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a somber vist but if you really want to understand the VN people you should go see uncle HO, he is like George Washington to America. It's not a time for messing around the VN take it very serious and they appreciate you show respect. It doesn't take long and is a must do if you are in Hanoi. No cameras, shorts, mini skirts or disrespectful clothing.
Normal tourist attraction.. This is a landmark of Vietnam. This place is normal, I went there just to take a selfie. Anyway, there is an interesting museum near it.

Strange. 'Uncle Ho' is a National Hero and the queue of people testify to that, I did find it a little strange to see his body lying there. If you do go then check the times as it's not open for long and not at all Monday and Friday
Mausoleum and Surrounding . We visited the mausoleum not knowing what to expect. It was fascinating, entry to the mausoleum is free, the fee comes if you visit the museum . It was all wonderful
unpleasant experience. hand over cameras and water at entrance then walked two by two through the mausoleum. No talking or touching one another. Hushed by guards even if whispering.

An impressive memorial. The colossal structure, perfectly manicured gardens, and rows of Red flags demonstrate the impact that this man had on the people of Vietnam.Only after I visited the Mausoleum did I find out that one can go inside and see Ho Chi Minh's preserved body! If this interests you, check ahead of time, because entrance into the tomb is restricted to only a few hours per day. Do your research (unlike I did)!The Ho Chi Minh Museum and the One-Pillar pagoda are only a short walk away from the tomb

A monument for their leader. HCM is a revered leader in Vietnam and credited with freeing the country from the French. This is where his mortal remains are preserved and kept for public viewing. Its not really a must do for a visitor but there are'nt that many things to do in Hanoi and you finish most of these monuments in one shot. The crowds are regulated and there are some basic rules to ensure that you are respectful to the Leader when you approach the monument.

Mum's with babies in carrier shooed off by officials.. We never made it.into the mausoleum but trying to get into it has left a sour feeling for us. After waking up early and quick breakfast, a taxi ride and queuing for depositing our rucksacks we were told we couldn't enter as we had a baby. One has to be three or older to enter the mausoleum. No one.could explain why. They only said it was a rule! My son was in a carrier and asleep! So we all decided not to go. We also noticed that the place is full of unfriendly officials who love to shoo people off and direct them to a random locations

Ho Chi Minh's Mauloleum is the imposing Soviet style block in which President Ho Chi Minh’s embalmed corpse lies.. Ho Chi Minh's Mauloleum is the imposing Soviet style block in whichPresident Ho Chi Minh’s embalmed corpse lies. Located at the centre ofhistoric Ba Dinh Square, thousands of locals and international visitorsline up to pay their respects each day.The structure's choice of location on Ba Dinh Square was a natural one—it was here where Ho declared the founding of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam in 1945. Visits to the mausoleum are expected to be quiet and respectful—skirts and shorts are forbidden, as is photography. Checking and claiming bags at the entrance can be slow, so pack lightly if possible. Lines can wind up to 2 km long, so be prepared to wait. Hours are limited to 8 am–11 am and it is closed to the public on Mondays and Fridays; it's also closed September through November when Ho's remains receive maintenance work.

Bizarre . This is very much for the Vietnsmese and though very interesting, it all felt a bit surreal. It's very well organised and has to be for the sheer volume of visitors. It was only open in the mornings when we visited, so bear that in mind when planning Hanoi activities.

“Final resting place of Uncle Ho “. If you get the chance, go to Ba Dinh Square and check out the final resting place of Uncle Ho. The reverence of Ho Chi Minh, particularly in the north of Vietnam, is distinctly on show here. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum sits atop a concrete base so it towers over the square. Ba Dinh Square itself is enormous and is for foot traffic only. The Mausoleum is well protected with special guards from the Army looking after Ho Chi Mnh in perpetuity. In fact, if you stray onto the well-manicured lawns adjacent to take a photo, you will be ushered away. Unfortunately I cannot offer you an opinion of the interior as our tour group showed poor planning and arrived after the 3PM closing time.Bu if you do only have time for a quick look, it is a great venue for a photo stop.
Visit to Vietnam. The arrangements were excellent n long queues to go in. The visit is included as a must in all tours and should have been an option.
Long line moves fast. This usually has a long line to see the body. Do not let this discourage you. The line move very fast. We were pleased.

The worst experience in Vietnam. This is a nasty place to visit. There is little to see and it is mostly closed - it closes for three hours in the middle of the day, ffs. This was an unpleasant experience and a waste of half a day. We are trying not to let it spoil our impression of Vietnam, however. Here is a list of issues, in no particular order: - The entrance is unfathomable difficult to find.  - It is closed for half the day and no one seemed to know the opening times.  - The guards are unfriendly.  - The mausoleum is ugly.  - There are no signposts and the site is huge so you end up walking in circles a lot - The museum is worse than useless: just a load of communist propaganda trying to justify the regime.  - The one pillar pagoda is deeply unimpressive.  - The botanical garden entrance is not at all close and is hard to find, despite being next door. And it is the worst botanical garden I've been to. There is an unnecessary dress code (long trousers). A waste of time - half a day of my life that I won't get back.
Stunning grounds. This wasn't on our list but glad we visited. Lines are very long but move quickly (and orderly). Most guests were Vietnamese and lots of school children on field trips.

On A Massive Scale. The mausoleum is set in a huge open area. The crowds waiting to enter the mausoleum were huge. No shade. I chose not to go in to view Uncle Ho's body. He never wanted this to happen, instead he willed his body be cremated and returned to the land he loved. So I just walked around the locale, and people watched. A personal protest.

Something to do. We took a trip out to the Mausoleum. Very busy and a long queue, however it moved really quickly. Some people forget that need to be respectful in this place. It was interesting to see how much respect this man has even in death.Not the highlight of my trip to Vietnam. I went to visit this place in October 2015 and Ho Chi Minh was in Russia.Be weary of taxi's after you leave. They may have a meter but if they are not the government taxi the meter rises very quickly. We got out and walked the rest of the way back to the Old Quarter.

A special moment. Experiencing the view of "Uncle Ho's" embalmed body is a little surreal. You are welcomed with a ceremony that makes you feel important. The only major negative is that you are not allowed to take pictures inside.
Interesting . The mausoleum isn't open every day so we didn't go inside but it's still interesting to see and hear about the leader that still inspires many Vietnamese people
Impressive . There is a good crowd waiting in line for the visit but it moves swiftly. It's impressive to see how much the Vietnamese respect their father of the nation.

Awesome experience. Vietnamese nationalism is showcased here. Locals pay tribute by visiting the perfectly preserved corpse of their hero Uncle Ho. According to our guide this is a regular activity of Vietnamese.The security at the mausoleum is very tight. Numerous checkpoints and security men ensure that no untoward event will happen here. The only way to take a photo of Uncle ho is by spy camera- eyeglass or necklace. Even this might be too risky if you get caught.

Visit Uncle Ho in Ho Chi Minh. Not many tourist attraction place you get to see the preserved body of well know politicians or benefactor of Vietnam.The Mausoleum is close on Mon and no camera are allowed inside.We were there on Thur morning and the queue is ok, moving and not that long.The place is not suitable for people on wheel chair or strollers as there are steps/staircase and quite dim area.

An interesting perspective. This site offers several items to view, including an embalmed Ho Chi Minh lying in state. It is interesting to see how revered this man is in the country and also to see what he looked like--with his beard he looks like an ancient mandarin. We stood in line for perhaps 15-20 minutes and then were routed through a large building to where his body is located. No pictures are allowed and there are multiple military members present to ensure rules are followed. We also saw his home, which was very modest for such a revered individual. While this is not a must see, it is interesting if you have time.

Not exactly an Architectural Gem!. We could not go inside as it was closed but I believe entry is strictly controlled and the visit is very quick. However, I was surprised that this hugh structure was not more esthetically pleasing to the eye for such an historical and revered leader. He had achieved so much for the country I could help thinking he was a bit “short changed” with this building. That said, I suspect it serves its purpose for ceremonial purposes.

Guarded Mausoleum. You walk all in and out of the buildings where he lived. 3 or his cars are there behind glass. You go into the underground mausoleum and see his preserved body all white. With guards guarding him. Then on passed koi filled ponds to where he lived in a beautiful wooden house on stilts. Statues and pictures still adorn the city.
Walk in the Park. Its a nice walk to the Mausoleum lots of stuff going on walk around and kinda just people watch with a cup of coffee.

Free and interesting. Very interesting to see Ho Chi Minh in his mausoleum very lobg wait in line ..bote no big cameras allowed they need to be left with authority so no point takibg them very high security also..an experience

Interesting Visit!. Visited in Feb 2016 (the mausoleum is free to public). People visiting this place on their own, please note that the place is only open in the morning, till 11 or so, please check timings and plan your trip. The place is generally crowded and long lines are expected. However the lines move on quickly and you shall be done within 30 minuted. It might take some more time to visit the palace, the one pillar pagoda and the museum all of which are in the same compound. Also note that you need to be appropriately dressed to visit him, avoid skirts, shorts otherwise you will be asked to cover the same. At the start of the line you shall be asked to deposits your bags (free of cost) and later on as you move in the line you will also be asked to deposit your cameras (free of cost) however i guess you may pay and carry the same. Taking photograph of the body is strictly prohibited, you make take pictures outside. The guards do not allow any sort of talking or giggling and also make sure to switch off your phone ringer and hands have to be kept out of your pockets when inside the mausoleum. It was really interesting to see him lying in a dimly lit room, the body is well preserved. The museum is closed between October to January as the body goes to Russia for preservation and restoration. Further if you wan to visit the palace and the stilt house you need to pay around 40,000 VND per person and another 40,000 VND for the Museum. The palace can be seen only from the outside, and yes do not forget to check out the cars in the garage next to the palace. The one pillar pagoda (free to visit) is also there however nothing extra ordinary and might be seen from distance.It is definitely a must go when in Hanoi.

More interesting than expected. Was not enthusiastic about this part of our day tour, however found the grounds and gardens lovely and the respect by the Vietnamese people for their leader impressive.

History of vn. This place tells the history of vietnam, most are written in Vietnamese, English writings are very small n difficult to read. I am not sure if tour guide is available for hiring, a walk withour guide is not recommended as you will have no understanding of most things, unless you have the patience and time to read everything.
Weird but historically interresting. A little bit weird to come see a dead body but really interresting historically and politically. Good to better understand my country story.

Visited on a closed day, therefore difficult to judge. We visited this site along with the garden which is located behind the mausoleum and the one pillar pagoda. Unfortunately it was closed during our visit so all we we're left with was the sight from the outside. Nothing too special, so be sure to check whether it is opened or not.

Mausoleum of the revered Ho Chi Minh. The embalmed body of the founding father of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam revered by many is kept here. It is open for public viewing only on certain days. You can walk around the impressive building and grounds on other days. Plese make sure to switch off your phone ringer and hands kept out of your pockets when inside the mausoleum. May not be of interest to all travellers.

Amazing presentation . The lines are long and millions of people come here to see Ho Chi Minh. Many honor guards to keep you in the proper lines. Grounds are well maintained and worth viewing the residential area.
a walk by was good enough for me. A grand structure. A dead guy in a glass box inside I'm told. The area, like Tienanmen Square, is filled with tourists. Similar format.

Worth the trip. The Mausoleum is a building separate to the museum, and is definitely worth going to see. It is closed to visitors on Monday and Friday, and is only usually open early in the morning until lunch time ish - so try and check before you go. The line will be long but we found it moved very fast so dont be put off, they also ask you to hand over cameras and electrical items to be given back when you are finished. (We turned our phones off and kept in pockets and wasnt an issue)
Check your Calendar. If you are going to this very popular site with the intention to see the remains of Ho Chi Minh it is good to remember that the mausoleum is closed on Monday and Friday

Check The Website. Closed on Fridays & one other day of the week so check the website before visiting. Also be conscious of signs & yellow lines as they don't necessarily face out & you may find yourself stood somewhere you shouldn't be & an angry soldier dressed in white on your case. Also STAY OFF THE GRASS!

Fascinating experience. Beware the hours are limited, and it isn't open every day. The mausoleum is situated by a large parade ground and lovely landscaped gardens. There are very strict rules that must be obeyed and soldiers in attendance will enforce them. No cameras, smart phones or video recorders are allowed inside and there is a strict dress code. Another was the number of armed guards policing the strict rules regarding silence (particularly no laughing)The Botanical gardens are full of a variety of plants and trees and again with a guide you my get to understand all the different species and significances, whilst also learning about his life and revolutionary activities. The Palace looks as if it is brand new and is still used today. This used to be the residence of the Governor of Indochina and after 1954 it was named the Presidential Palace and became the place where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked until he passed away in1969.

Huge memorial complex to Ho Chi Minh. Went to the site here and took photos outside, but did not go into the actual Mausoleum; talked to others in our group and they said it was ok, but didn't really miss out, as the best pics were the exterior shots. Interesting to see and take some photos, but wouldn't spend more that an hour or two for walking around the grounds.
Worth a visit. You can see the Ho lying in state in this highly decorated mausoleum. He may be revered in Vietnam, but I personally despise his legacy for what happened in the 1960's.

Tips for writing a great review. The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is reminiscent of the Lenin mausoleum in Moscow's red square for those that have been there. Immortilizing Vietnam's great leader is located vis avis the parliament and next to the gardens hosting his former residence. Large banners right and left convey messages for any anniversaries celebrated. Can walk in a large pedestrian area in front of it. Not always accessible.

Closed Fridays. Have visited here before , if you want to see Ho Chi Minh himself , check when open- shut fridays. Also go there first thing to try and beat the queues. If you can avoid taking bags all the better, saves you queuing to put then in security storage before you entre. Square outside impressive, gardens set out to represent paddy fields. As you file past the father of the nation , strict no talking. Which was obviously a struggle for the wife , who got repremanded by a guard!!!!!!

Meh. Nothing really to see here at all. We passed it on a walk we were doing around the city, and it is just a big building with loads of space around it and a few soldiers keeping you away. Not particularly interesting, unless if you're Vietnamese I suppose.

An important historical perspective. Although there is not much to see I found this site compelling. As with much of Vietnam there is high respect for this man and his efforts to obtain unification. His mausoleum is a must for history buffs.
Very interesting. One of the places to visit in Hanoi. We watched the changing of the guard and took loads of photos. The guide told us so much information it was very good.

An awe inspiring piece of real estate. When we visited the mausoleum, 'Uncle Ho', (as he is affectionately referred to) was not in residence but was off in Moscow having a makeover. We were told that he is regularly sent there for a touch up. Anyway, we got to see the outside and grounds from afar, as we were not even allowed up the steps that lead to the building. It is an impressive structure, despite being voted the sixth most ugliest building in the world in 2012. Due to it being closed we spent our time in the Ho Chi Minh Museum next door. Both buildings are included in the one entrance fee. A quick tip - the guards look great in their white dress uniforms, but they didn't dress up for fun; they are serious about their job.
Interesting . But definitely exactly what you would expect. A little maudlin and regimented and the guards were strict but very polite.

Not recommended. Our half day city tour took us here. I didn't realize we were going there, but went along with it. There are lots of soldiers about keeping people in line and quiet. You are not supposed to speak when you go inside the mausoleum. I did not find this interesting at all, but the local people take it very seriously. I think you could give this a miss.

Acknowledging HCM. We're not into viewing modern mummies, so skipped the monolithic shrine, but watched the single-file crowds move in, some (vet groups or dignitaries) celebrated by formal-marching, white-uniformed guards leading the group. Ho Chi Minh avoided the pomp of the former French Gov Gen's palace for more modest, sparsely furnished digs on the estate - well worth seeing to get a sense of his austere preferences. Other interesting aspects of these imposing grounds: bunkers, special hospital for his later days, a palm tree he planted in a huge deciduous tree as a symbol to represent surviving the bombings (palm tree lives, Viet Nam lives).
Interesting history. It was interesting place to visit , but because it was Friday we could only visit the garden .But it was s historical place and vietnamies feel very passionate about it.
Respect. A well done tribute to uncle Ho. We were impressed by the honour & respect that the locals showed to Ho Chi Minh. However preserved bodies in glass cases are not my thing.
A waste of time. When we visited you could not get near without the soldiers ushering you away and there's nothing to see really it's just a huge building, go elsewhere

Must see. Not sure what I was expecting here but what I did not expect was the actual preserved dead body of the president. It was an amazing sight to see. Heavily guarded and sober but again amazing.

Inevitable. The building is like a giant safe protected by many policemen in the surroundings. You can only visit it after waiting a loooong queue. As a building, the massive walls and sober style stand out from the colonial style buildings that can be seen "nearby" (not so near of course). As for the person, I am not interested.
What a patriotic country!. Having seen the former president and the national leader , Hochimin's body, it was really awe-inspiring to me. Really patriotic country .Still remembering that day.

Careful with the fake taxis waiting outside!!!!. The taxi in the picture (that later we discovered was a FAKE taxi) had a meter running ten times faster than it should. He was waiting just outside the mausoleum to catch tourists. He tried to charge us 600.000 for a ride worth 70.000. We realized something was wrong and bargained 200.000 (still a lot more than we should have paid). It's called taxi meter and it's a small car. Be careful!!!

very religious behaviour. The local people here, changes completely their behaviour. they show an extremely religious respect to Ho Chi Minh. everything is cancelled (hate, tradition, culture) a part from the respect for Him. is interesting to see how they become completely different, for those moments in front of Ho Chi Minh.

Not the best use of time in Hanoi. Rather go for a street food tour or get out of Hanoi and go to the hills, so many different day tour options, one documentary abt uncle Ho will give you more info than the Mausoleum

A very unique experience. We arrived there at around 9AM only to find ourselves at the end of a very long line of tourists and locals alike! We went inside ushered by guards (or police idk) to maintain our lines. It was unique! I understand it since it was HCM's resting place, and every visitor should pay respect. Just be sure to wear proper clothes! A must-visit!

Interesting. It was our first time we traveled to a Communist Country. The people are delightful. Touring the Mausoleum was sort of regimented with rules to follow. You can't bring your belongings with you and you're not allowed to take pictures inside so don't bring anything other than yourself. Stay with your group and don't forget to take off your hat for respect!

Surreal experience . A visit to Hanoi is not complete without a visit to see uncle Ho. A very surreal experience- no laughing, smiling, cameras, in 2's and no stopping in the mausoleum...Give it a try!

A must do !. The Emporah may be dead but they still love him dearly. To see just how much they still love him simply start talking once inside. You WILL regret it.Once you enter the heavily guarded Mausoleum you are struck by two things . The excellent preservation of Minh & the size of the fearsome looking guards.They are whilst not eing big by western standards , are taller & broader than any citizens I've encountered. Once outside of the mausoleum you can get your camera back & wander round the grounds of the palace. The whole experience will take about an hour but do get there early. It opens at 830 Am

Weird, well organized and for free. Visiting uncle Ho's remains is one of the things everyone is doing when in Hanoi. The Mausoleum is very well organized and even there was a huge crowd, it only took us around 20min to get in. At the entrance your bag will get scanned and you will receive a small red bag for your camera. You will keep the red bag until your group (around 30 ppl) are through the next checkpoint. After the checkpoint, you hand your camera bag to an employee and you get a number tag. Once you are finished, you get your camera back at the exit. (No need to go back to where you dropped it) Upon the entrance, there are more guards, checking that everyone behaves. No hats or baseball caps - just show respect. After a couple of stairs you walk around the glass coffin with HCMs well preserved body in it. No photos are allowed and you cannot linger there. Whole thing is over in less than a minute. After the Mausoleum you can stroll through the gardens or visit the museum (entrance fee applies) or head back to the Mausoleum to get a great front view.
Mausoleum. Really serious staff they wear White rubber wellington boots. Cute but its all very cloak and dagger

Closed. Well its marked as open 24hrs but when we showed up in the afternoon it was closed . Disappointing as we would really have liked to see inside. Maybe do your research and turn up earlier? I don't know.

Bizar place. Prepare to cue up with many tourists and manymany vietnamese. Access to the mausoleum is free. You have to turn in bags, and strangely only large camera's, small one you can keep. Bizar place with many guardian soldiers, marines and policeman. The building is ugly! You have to walk in line, 2 by 2, speaking is not allowed, hands free out of pockets, and keep pace while walking. No photo's other than after the visit of the mausoleum from the enormous square. Bags need to be recovered at the entrance, your large camera however is transported to the exit (in a red bag) and you recover with a label you receive when handing in. The whole place radiates communism in its worst suppressing format! Check out if there is access for tourists when you are there! Changes frequently.
Unreal. We visited during Tet and were the only ones in the mausoleum. The next week there was a line around the block to get in.
Really cool. Not to be missed in Hanoi. Lines move very quickly. If you take a tour the guide will explain what a hero he was to the people.

Interesting shrine to a much revered leader . Be prepared for a long but fast moving queue for this one. The mausoleum holding the embalmed body of Ho Chi Min is only open for viewing before noon. The precinct is well worth the visit as it includes homes that Ho lived in plus palace and museum. About 70 dong from city centre by cab.

Only if you have extra time in Hanoi. Before his death, the great Vietnamese leader, Ho Chi Minh declared that he wished to be cremated and have his ashes spread without ceremony. The Vietnamese government thought otherwise, building a huge, and quite ugly mausoleum in the heart of the city to house his remains. It stands, quite by itself, on one side or a long street, several hundred meters long. The street is occupied only by soldiers and tourists who have endured waiting on extremely long lines to have a look of Ho Chi Minh.Chalk this one up to necrophilia.

Surreal. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Would recommend it. After all he is an integral part of the current Vietnam govt.If you've seen Lenins Tomb in Moscow it is much the same procession. Guards directing you, pausing you before proceeding to next leg, once inside while viewing him you are slowly but swiftly walking around his presence.We went early upon opening time and was quickly in. No lines. Smooth and easy.They will have you dispose of bottled liquids, so plan on going in knowing you will not be able to drink until you exit the grounds. Don't bring a big purse or backpack unless you don't mind checking it in and picking it up in another location. They transport all bags on vehicle to another bldg. I personally had a small pouch with contents of phone, cards, money hung around neck and I was fine.Big cameras will be asked to check in.You can take pictures of grounds and huge flag after you leave the building. So I had my Android phone.Upon entering his presence, you will be asked to remove your ball cap, or hat. You can't enter in shorts or tank tops. Basically be smart, dress covered and be respectful.It's as if you would do the same in another country or entering a temple/wat.I enjoyed that the country have respect and it is done orderly.The grounds surrounding the Mausoleum is clean, vast space.Upon leaving the grounds you have an opportunity to see his residence prior to exit for another fee. We didn't do that segment.I felt elated to have seen this because again, this country loves their leader or at least a % of the citizens - depending who you ask.

Go see Ho Chi Minh in Hanoi. This was highly recommended and I was not disappointed. Mind you it has limited hours and days. Double check this info but I believe it closes at 11 every day and was closed on Thursdays and Mondays. They also close once a year to ship the body to Russia for... maintenance? If you are staying in the old quarter it is easy to walk to but the entrance is on the far side. You also have to check large bags and large cameras. They give the cameras back as you leave the mausoleum so you can take pictures outside. I enjoyed it and liked it better than Lenin's tomb.

Interesting. We went there early in the morning, no queue. A lot of people later in the day, I guess. The area around the mausoleum is big, and was beautiful decorated with lots of flowers, especially in yellow an red. Uncle Ho (he did not have any children, and was the uncle of everybody) has been laying om "lit de parade" for several years. No photos of course, single line, no talking, just walk by with out stopping. Interesting. It is also possible to go and see his house, recommendable.

Keep it to yourself. Whatever your feelings, just keep them to yourself at this exhibit. The mausoleum and surrounding gardens are attractive and pleasant to view. But, what can you say about a dead body on display. Well, you had better not say anything, as there will be a nearby honor guard sternly telling you to be respectful. I was, but a teenage girl nearby was taken out of the procession for being disrespectful.

Worth a visit. Go very early if you want to see the body of Ho Chi Minh. The queues are very lengthy most of the time. Be prepared for the very official guards to organise you in a very military fashion. You will be very aware of being in a communist country. You will see the house where he spent his final years and if you have a guide, you will be amazed at how they speak with such love and devotion for their former leader

They take this site very serious. Very cool to visit.. Just getting into this site was a bit of work. You need to get to the proper admission point which can be strange because the mausoleum is in the center of this huge green lawn. Don't even think about cutting across the grass. Not for one second. If you do you will soon hear the stern shouts and whistles. Stay on the paved sidewalk. Once inside you will be watched like a hawk. Guards every 10 feet. The guards will study you and don't even try to photograph the body. You need to leave your camera and packs in a secure locker at the entrance point. So come light. It will be easier. As you walk down to the main casket site it will be quiet. No talking or again the shout from the guards. Move slowly but don't stop. It's hard not to stare at his body sitting so peaceful and looking great. It's a strange scene and should not be missed. He is the man.

Paying your respects to Uncle Ho. For those of us of a certain age seeing Ho Chi Minh at last (if not in person) was a necessity. You are hustled through by the guards, but there he is for your short visit. The mausoleum is impressive (even if the visit is short) and the grounds are impressive, beautiful old buildings, some from the French period of government and others more recent, e.g. the stilt house in which he lived in the mid-50s. Lots of guards and many "tourists" who seem more intent on listening to our conversations. Might be wise to be careful about political stuff. But certainly, you cannot visit Hanoi without making this trip

Good experience. Despite the long wait, I am glad that we saw this site.It is quite a serious setup, people must move continuously single file inside, no speaking and obviously no pictures. Inside as well as the outside which is large and very spacious has you visualizing large ceremonies by the military that we see on TV in this and other countries.
Only open in the morning!. We missed a visit inside. Check opening times before you go, not much else there!Not particularly impressive from outside.

Might take awhile, needs to be your "cup of tea".. It is interesting to see how revered Ho Chi Minh is; whether it is worth waiting an hour or so on a line to see his mummified body is a different question altogether.We went on Vietnam's New Year's day and there was virtually no line, although the visit still took an hour or so for five minutes of viewing the body.
Worth a visit go early in the day. We went to the Mausoleum but found it was closed and was only open for a few hours a day, so we went back. Although there was a long queue, our wait wasn't bad.

Be prepared for anti-American sentiment!. My sense is you'll enjoy if you are Vietnamese rather than American. The "party line" is espoused. American POWs are described as being well-treated. Confused me!

Must see- a highlight of Hanoi. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a highlight of Vietnam. Best to go early in the morning before the big tours arrive. The experience helps to understand the reverance that the Vietnamese have for Ho Chi Minh and the importance of his leadership to the history of the country.
A striking building. We did not visit inside the Mausoleum, but did appreciate viewing the building and the magnificent square from the outside. Close to the Presidential Palace, so worth viewing.

Must visit when in Hanoi. If you're interest in history of Vietnam and President Ho Chi Minh, this really is a must! It's a great complex with a mausoleum, a Ho Chi Minh museum which is very well-organized and informative. It takes around 1 hour to visit all the complex and very worth every minute.

Very Worthwhile Visit. It is fascinating to see how revered Ho Chi Minh was for the Vietnamese people- viewed as the father of the country doing marvelous things for his people.The mausoleum has a well preserved "Uncle Ho" lying in state, a little bit unusual, nevertheless interesting- reminiscent of the Mao mausoleum in Beijing. There is a lot of pomp and ceremony with white uniformed guards everywhere.The area is large and well cared for with many interesting sites within in besides the mausoleum itself. The yellow building, the Presidential Palace, Ho Chi Minh never lived there is worth a look. Seeing the homes where Ho lived are also interesting as is the display of his three cars.

Worth taking a Look!. A huge square with the Mausoleum! Worth 15 minutes time to take a look and a few pictures. Combine with the visit to Residential Palace which I find to be a lot more interesting.
Meh. To be honest, I found it a bit boring. Hi chi Minh had just been out for a recent rewaxing but it doesn't mean much to me personally. The line moved quickly to see him though.

A sombre but fascinating experience. Try to visit in the off season, otherwise this site will be clogged with thousands of tourists. We went there in February and only had to wait a few minuntes for entry. The tomb with Ho CHi Minh's embalmed body is worth seeing, although the guards make sure you don't linger. The gardens are delightful, and the buildings interesting in detail.
Historic. Very well maintained, clean and organized. Many local people visited as well. A place very worth visiting

A fascinating glimpse into cold war communist ideology.. A fascinating experience. I am sure that once the mausoleum was a place of great reverence to the party faithful but it seems now to be stage managed for the tourist market with the soldiers dressed in bleached white uniforms looking a bit like extras in an opera.Although a little macabre the site is well worth a visit to give a sense of just how brain-washed the Vietnamese were.
if you like history you will love this place. if you like history you will love this place .Open everyday monday to friday.This is a biggest place.

A must place to visit in Hanoi. It is an experience to visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Uncle Ho, as he was known among the commoners in Hanoi, is embalmed in the Mausoleum, nicely dressed. The compound is clean and huge. The only downside is there are too many armed guards which is scary and it dampens your enthusiasm. Don't get upset when you have to leave your camera at the entrance. You can take photos of the compound, that is allowed. I have attached some photos.

History of Vietnam. You could join the long queue to visit this place, where you could meet one of greatest Man of Vietnam history, Ho Chi Minh.It could take a morning with visiting, but very peaceful area. It is usually come with visit of Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, HCM pillar house, HCM fish lake (you could feed fishes here), One pillar pagoda, and President palace behind the area.It will close in Monday and Friday.

Historical site to visit. I appreciated the historical aspect of this site. The grounds were beautiful and I enjoyed seeing how Ho Chi Minh lived. I was very put off by all the vendors at the mausoleum. I had to dress modestly to come here but there were dozens of vendors and store fronts at this grave site. . . quite ironic

A unique experience. A visit to the mausoleum was included in our pre-booked Vietnam tour. We joined a long queue of Vietnamese people all there to pay their respects to Uncle Ho. We entered the mausoleum, daring not to say a word and walked around the coffin observing Ho Chi Minh himself, laid there for all to see as though he was in a peaceful sleep, and then we exited the building at the other side. It was an eye opener and given the chance to go inside again I wouldn't take it. As the only Westerners inside the mausoleum I felt out of place and almost as though I was intruding others' who were there to pay their respects but on the other hand it was good to experience an intimate side of Vietnamese culture.

Worth the Time. This is a must see, but only if you are accompanied by a local guide. We used an organisation called Hanoi Kids, They are University students who want to practice their English and will guide you for free.They meet you at your Hotel and bring you back. You supply the transportation, The Mausoleum is an extensive complex. It takes about 90 monies to take everything in., We were fortunate to see the changing of the guard.This is a score part of the History of Viet Nam and well worth visiting. You'll find lot's of local families visiting this site.

Good for history buffs, but mostly propaganda and very regimented. This is not like visiting a Memorial in the U.S. or any western nation. You have to walk in 2 side by side lines and there are guards every 30 feet. The grounds are well-maintained and beautiful with flowers, but Ho is still treated as if he is a saint - and it is a little creepy seeing his body lying there maintained like a mummy!

Great way to start my first morning in Hanoi. Locals enters for free. Foreigners have to pay. Bags are checked before entering the main compound. You get to see the actual body of the late Ho Chi Minh in the Mausoleum which gae me an instant shock but do check when it's closed. Caps needed to be removed before entering the mausoleum. SO I'm not so sure about the Muslim ladies. Anyways, a collection of HCM's cars are also exhibited. The presidential palace was out of bounds I guess so only managed to take a pic of it from the outside.
History and Culture. Our excursions provided great insights into the history, ethnology and culture of Vietnam. Other sites provided addition important information.

Must visit in Hanoi. Well kept and operated resting place for Ho Chi Minh of great historical importance. OK for children to attend. An expression of admiration by the Vietnamese for their great leader. Mausoleum is in top shape and is set up to handle many visitors.
huge space for one person. This mausoleum has great meaning to the Vietnamese people but I can't help but wonder if it is really necessary to set aside so much space for one man.
Ho Chi Minh wasn't in.... When I went in October HCM was not in... He was in Russia for preservation/restoration. Other than that it was just a big building.

A piece of pure theatre!. It was the festival of Tet so Hanoi was packed and many of the Vietnamese children in the long queue which moved quite quickly,were dressed smartly in colourful national costume and if you ask to take their photo this is seen as a great compliment. Four smartly dressed guards in white guard the inner chamber and other members of this guard of honour marshall the crowd through ensuring a respectful silence and no phones or photos. Cameras are collected and catalogued and returned as you emerge. You can also visit Ho chi minhs house and the house on stilts my the lake, fascinating! Check opening times before you go!
NOT INTERESTING. If it was about another person it could be ok, but I can´t find anything interesting about this person no matter his importance in history.

Changing of the guard. Didn't really see much, don't think it is like horse guards parade. Nice big line to stand behind. DONT cross this line. Never got into the mausoleum. Not sure if you even can go in. It's a must see, but there is not much to see.

ho Chi Mihn on Lit de Parade. Ho Chi Mihn ment so much for Vietnam and for the people of Vietnam, and it is very meaningful to pay a visit to his mausoleum and get the story of Ho Chi Mihn. It was a place to remember.

VisitHo Ci min museum. this was an amazing experience. Very humbling and I felt very privileged to see "Uncle Ho". Be prepared for a wait in very long lines and it is a long walk from the entrance to the building.

Erie insight into communist idolatry. If you like queues and loosing you sense of identity whilst looking at heavily guarded dead people this is gonna be right up your dark alley way. The only real negative was that I queued with my partner and our baby for 45 mins before getting in to the grounds at which point a nameless and obviously utterly blameless man dressed in a non description suit (no fancy military uniform with eppilettes and shiny stars) told us at the gates that children under 3 where not allowed in, thus cutting my son and partners morning short. My partner gallantly let me continue which consisted of marching for a further 45 mins in queues, along guarded roads and walkways until I entered a shining monolith of a building at which point the guards became even more intense. I seemed to get told of for having my hands in my pockets, holding a phone or arms crossed (if only they gave you induction into how to comport your limbs in said monolith. Eventual shadowy guard lined passageways gave way to opened up central tomb, a sunken area separated the masses from the glass sarcophagus encapsulating the dead man God and all his white wispy follicles. Surrounded (obviously) by guards in the fanciest of uniforms, bayonets fixed. A gawking reverence X seemed to fall over all those that shuffled passed, though I am certain Ho Chi Minh winked at me.

Avoid on Monday or Friday. This is a large building in the Soviet style. The preserved body of Ho Chi Minh is displayed within. Unfortunately, there is no entrance on Monday or Friday and we went on a Monday. We have arranged a second tour so that we can go inside to see the remains of this important historical figure.
NICE AND FREE. No charge to see this site. Easy walk as it is all level and it was interesting. You can only go inside one day a week so we were not their on the correct day. Still worthwhile to see
Worth a visit. It was interesting to see. Be prepared for a long line. I don't know whether I buy into the whole thing as it is quite over the top but nonetheless a good attraction to go and see

Nothing much too do.... You can walk by it, take a few pictures. but other than that, nothing else, maybe is because of the timing. Our kids enjoyed the botanic garden more at the northwest side of this building.

Pretentious Mausoleum. Against his last will the body of Ho Chi Min was not cremated but enbalm after the model Lenin. The mausoleum is a pretentious building without any architectual significance. Its stands on an enormous bare space. The only attraction is the guard of honor.
Interesting . It was a learning experience. Something worth doing. The changing of the guard is fun to watch. The architecture and landscape was equally beautiful.

Wasn't Open When I Went. Unfortunately due to the time I had in Hanoi, I could only visit this on a Monday when it's closed, so I can only really review the building. As you can see from the pictures it's not especially attractive, but it's worth going past on your way to other things as it's such an important part of Hanoi.

Uncle Ho mausoleum. Where can you go to see the body of such an historical figure. He is quite literally the father of communist Vietnam. Don't take your camera, strictly no photos. Also many sights to be seen in this area. Seriously it's an experience and the que is no where as bad as the que to chairman Mao in bejing. Who should be in and out with in less than 30 mins.

Beautiful place but too packed. This is a beautiful place, grounds well taken care of. Unfortunately the lines are too long and i was unable to wait out. I hope to get in and see Uncle Ho's remains one day.

A must see in Hanoi. The Mausoleum is one of the must see places in Hanoi. There is no admission fee, but you should go early in the morning as it closes at 11. There are strict rules for entering the monument and a lot of security. Cameras and phones are not allowed inside- and no one dares to take a photo. There are many soldiers guarding the dead body of Ho Chi Minh. You spend inside around a minute but it is a nice experience.
