You can take beautiful pictures from the outside as there is very large area free of people.

Better than expected. We came away from this place quite amazed. I was a little unsure at first about going to see an embalmed body but I am glad I went. It is a very well organised place. You are ushered around very efficiently and you only get about 30 seconds in the actual room however it is quite remarkable and well worth the visit. I would highly recommend this if visit Hanoi. We walked from the old quarter and took about 30 minutes but was a really nice walk if you have a map with you.

Very Different Experience. This is a very different activity. It is very strictly run, hundreds of tourist are ushered around various walkways. It was logistically fascinating and the respect for "uncle Ho' amazing. I don't think the level of security was necessary but it did add to the drama.

Ho Chi Minh body. Very quick view of Ho Chi Minh body
Need to drop the bags at the entry - baby with stroller cannot go in
There is a nice cafe to wait outside

Very interesting. Despite the queue this is certainly worth a visit. Local people and tourists alike make a line to walk past the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. The line moves quite ceremoniously and takes a little while. It's a bit of a walk to get here, no vehicles are allowed nearby, but it's quite easy to negotiate. Then you can continue to see the lovely gardens and the houses where Ho Chi Minh lived.

Stately. If you visit Hanoi you should visit this venue. The exspanse of the site contrasts the hustle and bustle of the rest of the city. The stately presentation and reverence to Ho Chi Minh is a bit chilling. The full dress, at attention guards put you into the proper mode to absorb this event. The other stops on the grounds give you a glimps into the 3 dimensional world Ho Chi Minh lived. There is some walking involved so wear your good walking shoes and enjoy the stroll.

It was like a parade going to a funeral . We went here in a group tour of about 56 people. While we were queuing outside, our guide told us NO HANDS IN YOUR POCKETS. No food, no water, no cameras, Phones must be switched off and no hats! You have to leave all these in the counter or give it to your guide and he will hold it all for you. Once inside the mausoleum NO TALKING. Go and try it so you can see what I'm saying .

Interesting experience. Coming to the museum and see the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh was a very humbling experience. It was interesting to observe the local people paying respect to their former leader, who liberated the country from the French colonial rule. It appears that Uncle Ho still hold a special place in the Vietnamese heart. There was also the expected propaganda showcase at the museum. No doubt there are some ideological differences between Vietnam and the rest of the world, but coming to see museum is a good reference to understand the local perspective and I highly recommend it.

Outstanding building. This place is heavily guarded and you must keep your distance. Roads are blocked at either side so you do need to walk a bit to get here. But make sure you explore the surrounding area too.Ho Chi Minh is held in very high regard and this burrial site shows how much. Its a very impressive building.

Pomp on display. A large edifice with equally large parade ground to honor Ho Chi Minh, in Hanoi. Every communist country must have something equivalent. We did not go inside, only viewed it from the outside.

An Experience. It was very interesting to see the reverence they hold Ho Chi Minh in when we can wonder around tombs of famous kings and queens in England in various cathedrals etc and on one takes any notice he is guarded by four soldiers at all times and you cant speak it was very interesting

Great chance to visit the Great Vietnames man. I had a great chance to visit Uncle Ho of the Vietnamese people. It was so crowded there because i went there on Sunday. The Mausoleum was full of people

Impressive in more ways than one. For a start be prepared to be sheparded by immaculately uniformed soldiers who usher you along, no lingering! We were lucky to visit when it was relatively few visitors and quiet. To see Uncle Ho is actually very moving. A pause for respect was allowed, just. The gardens are also well worth taking the time to walk round but make sure you check the opening times. One of THE sights of Hanoi and certainly must not be missed..
Military Honours!. This one is worth a visit just to see how overboard we can go for no apparent reason. Excessive guards at every corner and it seems to be a requirement to remain somber. Amusing!

interesting viewing. We really weren't sure of what we were lining up to see. No cameras, large bags, food or drink. There are drop off points to leave things to collect at the end. Don't worry small handbags and wallets go with you. Lead around in regimental lines we didn't realize we would be viewing actual Ho Chi Minh himself he passed away in 1969 and was kept whilst this mausoleum was built he is respectfully laid to rest so all the people could come to see him. Though his requests was cremation. Recommend visiting the mausoleum and proceeding further to see were he lived in a humble building for a man with huge leadership for his people.

Eery unique stretch of land. Walk along a deserted highway size stretch of concrete bordered with communist propaganda and weathered loud speakers. The mausoleum was designed with the intention to echo the lotus flower. If you sit on the road the guards make you stand within a few seconds. It really was an eerie experience and we couldn't help but wonder what ceremonies had been held there in the past and the significance of the life of Ho Chi Minh

Incredible to see Ho Chi Minh's on the country!. This very respectful monument of Ho Chi Minh's preserved body is an incredible sight to see. Although, depending on when you go, there will be quite a wait at the entrance, the experience is worth it. The sighting of the body is quick, as you need to continue walking around the cube.Be sure to get the most out of the experience and read up on Ho Chi Mihn and his influence on the country before visiting the Mausoleum.

Ho hee ho - Ho chi Minh. A taste of communist Vietnam with the pomp and ceremony of the Vietnamese army in their military attire.Lots of communist flags and to my surprise Ho Chi Minh preserved in the glass case - don't know why I wasn't expecting that.Worth going to see where he resided and studied and met with his fellow polit bureau members.make sure you where modest clothes - no shorts or singlets/vests as they wont let you in.

Like Lenin's Tomb. If you're going to visit Hanoi, you probably have to see Ho's mausoleum. Even if reluctantly. The guy wanted to be cremated, but there he is preserved for posterity with Russian technology, the way Lenin was. No pictures allowed inside. You file in and are quickly hustled around the bier and back out the door. You get less than 30 seconds to gaze at his body, so hopefully you didn't have to wait in line, although that can happen unless you are lucky enough to going during Tet when most of Hanoi leaves town.

Has to be seen. Our itinerary said that we would be viewing the outside only, so we were rather surprised to be ushered into a queue to file through and past Uncle Ho's body. The whole process of the visit is extremely bureacratic and regimented. Having passed my small back pack through a scanner and allowed through with it, I was then told it could not be taken in, so had to leave it with our guide. Any large cameras also have to be handed in. You are then ushered through by armed guards. An experience, but not a particularly enjoyable one.

If this is your thing...... The experience is very regimented.....as it has to be.I went because my group was going, having given it a miss on a previous visit. If this is your thing, I am sure you will be impressed with your fleeting look at this historic figure.
Don't cross this place off your list of things to do. I didn't know what to expect coming here, so no expectations, I learnt more here in 2 hours then I learnt taking history in school over 5 years!

Something for free!. We felt this was something we ought to do on our first visit to Hanoi. We were rather confused by some of the regulations - leave all bags and cell phones at a booth at the entrance, but they will put your camera in a little bag for you to carry around until you reach the mausoleum, where you have to deposit it at another booth for collection afterwards. It would have been simpler to just leave the camera at the first booth! Also, there are areas of footpath which you are not allowed to walk on. The actual mausoleum is a somber affair, where you silently file past the glass sarcophagus where Ho Chi Minh lies, and then back out to daylight. Uncle Ho is clearly revered by the Vietnamese people, and his imposing mausoleum is testament to that.

Very interesting!. If you are interested in history, politics and comunism... you can not skip Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum!. We went there accompanied by 2 members of Hanoi Kids .. and they were more than frendly! They explained us the most important highlights of Ho Chi Minh's life... They were very well informed on historical details, so we understood the importance of this place. Just go! and remember that to get inside the Mausoleum some rules apply (check that before)

A regimental march. Warning do not take large cameras water or large bags unless you are with a tour. You will be asked to leave them at the entrance. A must for those who will not be creeped out by an embarmed Ho Chi Minh
A must in Hanoi. For me a must in Hanoi and it is for free as well.A lot of security around and an interesting way of walking through and around the mausoleum.

A quick walk.... Worth seeing, but no cameras allowed inside. You get a quick peek of Ho Chi Minh's remains... looking much like a wax replica. A must do, despite the wait. It closed around noon most days, so go early.

Checked that off my bucket list. Not to be too indelicate but viewing the remains of dead communists is on my bucket list. Already visited Mao in Bejing so on this my second visit to Hanoi I made the time to visit Ho Chi Minh. The security and bag drop requirements were very confusing. I you want to avoid the hassle do not bring any kind of backpack or bag. You will be allowed to take a phone and camera into the grounds any kind of bag has to be left at the gate.Not photos of the remains are allowed and appropriate quiet is expected as you approach the mausoleum. There can be a line but we were fortunate that our wait was minimal.
Not the Top of My List. The most interesting part of this stop was watching and listening to others. The No. Vietnamese hold HoChiMinh in high regards. I did learn a lot about him.
Nice landscaping. You have to walk in the garden, nice lakes and flowers. If you need to see ho chi minh's body you should go in the morning hours.

embalmed ho chi minh!! . you can see embalmed ho chi minh! we didn't expect that. the guards wear super cute white suits ;) be careful, you need two separate tickets to see his home and to see the museum.

Truly a remarkable moment. From the old quarter its a 40min walk...on your way ypu can stop my the Lenin monument n military museum also the citadel which is quite beautiful n interesting. It is quite remarkable to stand where thousands did as they listen to the declaration of independence. The museum is permanently closed. But you can go visit Ho Chi Minh residence which is near by.
Free but restricted hours. It was not open when I went, but I was able to watch the changing of the guard ceremony. The grounds are well kept with nice flowers.

A Strange But Ultimately Rewarding Experience. We visited this Hanoi "attraction" on a cold blustery day, followed the prescribed route and were part of a long line of mainly Vietnamese visiting Uncle Ho resting in his glass coffin in the dimly lit Mausoleum. Not something I would normally choose to spend even part of my morning doing. The building is not a pretty one and the experience haunting but unforgettable. Once out of the dimly lit Mausoleum the compound in which Ho Chi Minh spent his final days is of great interest. It is a calming place with beautiful French inspired building where he lived and worked. You need to understand that Ho was a man of culture, had travelled the world and only wanted to make his country great. Wether or not you agree with his philosophy he ultimately succeeded in doing this though he died before it became the place it is now.The history of Vietnam is tied up with this clever little man, though his countrymen failed to do as he asked and have him cremated ad his ashes buried in three caskets in the North, Middle and South of Vietnam. I think he would be less than happy with what they did to him for though he wanted his followers to visit the sites of his caskets he also asked that when they did so they planted a tree in his honour. A much greener way of remembering him rather than what we see today in his Mausoleum. Worth a visit if only to get an understanding of the man.
Just like Moscow. This is just like visiting the Lenin Mausoleum in Moscow. Very solemn and lots of military guards and show. We were lucky that we got there early and had no lines.

Nice to see around. If you are in Hanoi for a day to spared go and see it the people very proud of this place becouse one of there hero rest here. The street very quiet and a lot of local tourist around not that big thing but it a part of Vietnamese proud places walk around take a picture mangled with a local.
Must see mausoleum in Hanoi. Big area in central Hanoi. Interesting story of the creation of modern Hanoi. Definetely a thing to do in Hanoi.

History. So much information to take in. Very interesting place. Probably need two to three hours to do it justice. I found it amazing how this man encouraged his people to keep up the fight against the American aggressors. They were inventive in everything they did, the women of the country played an equal part in that fight. It not just a mausoleum to Uncle Ho but a tribute to an amazing story. A true one.

Very well organised.. We went to see the mausoleum with some trepidation, it was freezing pouring with rain and we were not sure we wanted to see Uncle Ho's remains.We needn't have worried it was very well organized so then time we spent queueing was minimal and the presentation of the body is very well done.
Very cool. A real piece of history from a very different culture and ideology, I enjoyed the surreal experience of seeing a historical figures body.

If you could only visit one site in Hanoi- choose this.. We came here during winter and walked straight in- our tour guide said at peak times you could line up for over a kilometre (he could be exaggerating though). When you view Ho Chi Minh you are walked through quite quickly which is the only downside. I literally held my breath, I was amazed. Don't bother about the Ho Chi Minh museum though- full of propaganda.

Pretty much essential visit when in Hanoi. This place very firmly marks the influence of communist Russia on Vietnamese history. The route through the site is carefully policed with strict rules on security, dress and photography. Ho Chi Minh lies in a concrete and stone edifice designed to represent a lotus flower, but very much reflecting solid Soviet seventies architecture. The immaculate guards are dressed in white and are seemingly a tourist attraction in themselves. The visitors are a mix of Vietnamese families and school groups as well as global tourists. The whole complex reflects the ongoing importance of Ho Chi Minh to the country.

View From A Distance Only. Become visiting, I read that this was considered a fairly ugly structure, so I thought I must see for myself. It's not as elegant as the French colonial architecture or the temples and pagodas that spot the city, but it's not that ugly. Behind or near it is a temple, park, and botanical garden. Men in uniform are marching around or standing guard. While a quick visit might be interesting, there's really isn't much to do. You can only look at if from far and head on. You cannot get close and the other sides are off limits.
A must see. Ho Chi Minh died 50 yrs ago and his body lies in a highly secure Mausoleum. You have to by a ticket and queue, but it is worth it
Quick Trip through Mausoleum. It was a quick continuous walk up to and through the Mausoleum. Guards did not allow anyone to stop along the way even outside. Don't put your hands in your pockets.

Respectful Resting Place. As inspirational and dedicated leader of the united republic, Ho deserves the respect afforded him by this memorial. But I can't help wondering if Ho the intellectual and a man of simple tastes would have constructed such a place??? Worth a visit and good photo op especially if you time to coincide with the changing of the guard.
Don't miss this. No need to go to Moscow to see Lenin,when you can see this head of state lying in state very surreal. Just be respectful , quiet, and remove your hat.

Bizarre but worth seeing. By far the strangest attraction we went to in Vietnam, but worth visiting. Note that it's only open until about 11am so get there early. Also make sure you wear long clothing and try not to bring too many bags/cameras as you won't be allowed to take them in.
Ho Chi Minh Tribute Journey. If you really want to understand the role this very famous man played in the history of Vietnam and see where he lived most of his life,this is the place to go.

Very impressive . The visit to the mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh was very special. We had to look nice for it and indeed the rules were pretty strict; no photos, no loud talking, no laughing. The building is very prestigious from the outside and the inside is very beautiful and peaceful. Absolutely worth visiting.
My Vietnamese sources say he's a wax dummy. But fake or not, it's still worth a visit. It's interesting to look around & also visit the house next door where Uncle Ho lived & worked.
Awesome. Definitely worth coming to. Such a vital part of Vietnamese culture, this Mausoleum is a special place for the people of Vietnam.

Mausoleum closed. Despite not being able to see the embalmed body, a visit here with an informed guide is a must. Ho founded Vietnam and his influence has spread deep into the nations soul. However I wonder what he might have thought of today's corruption riddled government.

Ha Noi Landmark. Within walking distance of West Lake area. I did not go inside the crypt because I didn't want check in my expensive Nikon. Behind the crypt is a large area of Ho's living compound and an extensive museum. This is one of those must dos when visiting this city.

Walked past this place. Very well guarded and interesting place to see.
I suppose more a place of pilgrimage for Vietnamese people.

Not to be missed but somewhat surreal. Need to do this to experience how the nation thinks but perhaps not from everyone. You get to file past the body quite quickly having passed a line of many guarding young soldiers. Do see the mausoleum even if you decide not to stand in line.

Contemporary concrete . Impressive in a communist country way. It's big, sterile and blocky. The weather was bad so crowds were less. If you have seen it in a picture you have seen it. Of greater interest is the home of Ho Chi Minh found on the same grounds.
The love of Uncle Ho.... It was sunday when we are there. We were not able to see inside beacuse of Vietnamese crowd. It's open from 09:00 to 12:00 and it's forbiden to wear shorts.

The Architecturally Bold Mausoleum. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum Complex is close to old quarter of Hanoi, and right place to start the VIETNAM tour.Comrade Ho Chi Minh(Uncle HO), wanted a simple cremation, but his favorite people did otherwise, building a granite Mausoleum, with a glass sarcophagus, where frail body of the LEGEND is kept, with head slightly tilted up, under a soft Natrium Vapor Lamp, casting a soft yellow glow on the face, and covered body.The body is taken to MOSCOW, on every September, for chemical treatment, and returns on end October. You can see from the photo attached, the bold erect Mausoleum, with perfect aspect ratio, holding the mortal remains of BRAVEST son of Vietnam, who defeated French, and USA, and through a civil war, got VIETNAM unified.Uncle HO--Live for eternity! After a red salute, I moved to his GREEN stilted house, built as he wished, for simple living, and there he stayed, and carried out his work to the very last day.In the front of the house , is the road , where he used to do Morning Walk--and most of the trees are planted by him, on either side of the road. I tried to capture the tree lined road, with light, and shadow ,on late morning sun.

Impressive!. If you are in Hanoi this is a must see. Note that you can only enter the mausoleum during morning hours and that the body of HCM is transported to Russia every October-November for "maintenance" work!The mausoleum is very impressive from the outside and is surrounded by great walking areas and opportunity to visit the President's palace (count 40 minutes for the visit) and see other important buildings as well, including the Parliament.A must see for any tourist in Hanoi. Go with a tour guide to get all the stories and history about Ho Chin Minh. I am more than happy to recommend you the guide we found. He did a great job showing us around for a very reasonable fee (about 20 USD for a half-day) and he spoke good English.

A very important visit . Going to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was a serious undertaking. Cameras, hats and gum chewing ate not permitted. Guards abound. His body is displayed in a glass case and is so well preserved that it looks like he is merely sleeping. Make sure you visit this important site when in Hanoi.

Worth a Visit. It was a pleasant surprise. There was a major party function on in Vietnam the time we visited. Security was tighter than normal. Our peregrine guide Nga Tam provided great info on the history. Definitely worth a visit. In January it was very cold 11 deg.Tip : sunscreen, sunhat, water, camera, warm clothes if January
Very interesting place. You should check this place out just because of the history of Ho Chi Minh and how they portray him here. Fascinating.
Worth a visit . The tour through the mausoleum is quick and with guards everywhere that makes the tour very authentic and it is just breathtaking when you enter the mausoleum.

clean & well ordered to the point of bleak....not worth half a day. Not very educational nor insightful. They purposively limit the hours that it is open to maintain a longer queue line / crowds...as if to make it more special / important.

Ok. Very interesting. The inside museum design is something to definitely check out. Plenty to read and look at! Opens in the minting and then again at 2pm. Should only take you about an hour to get though the museum.

Pay your respects. Fascinating insight into Vietnamese military authority and the irreverence of foreign tourists.. Preserving the sanctity of an historical leader and father of a nation from the self-serving need for a picture to post on Facebook. If the queue is long be aware your audience in the presence of the great Uncle Ho will last less than one minute. Also pay attention to the limited opening hours.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Good point to visit in Hanoi. There are many people visit daily. This is the firs time we came there.

ONLY OPEN IN THE MORNING. well, i can't say much but by the time we were reached there around 11.30 it's already been closed, too bad, this musium is famous.we've seen few young man in uniform (might be police) were patrol around that building with their hmm... what can i say 'classic uniform?" I am indonesian, but i think we have better uniform *peace!

Not the best experience's here. Not a place to visit with children at all. When I tried to visit this place I had my three year old daughter on my back in a child Carrier as she was tired. I asked at the front gate if it was OK to have her on my back while on the tour I was approached by a guard to say that you can not visit the masalium with your child on your back. I said I spoke with the staff at the entrance and they said it was ok to do so. As I went to keep up with the tour the same guard approached me from behind and tried to take my daughter out of the carrier she was in and in the process scratched her eye. By this time my daughter was historical and frightened. After I exchanged a few words that I will not repeat here I headed for the exit where I was escorted from the grounds. Not a very pleasant experience for us at all, considering we found the Vietnamese to be very friendly elsewhere.

Day tour with Buffalo Tours. Took my family for a day tour around the city and visited the Ho Chu Minh Mausoleum! Very educational and interesting to hear about the history. Sun from Buffalo is a great guide, very interesting and knowledgeable well spoken English and they go above expectations. Really enjoyed this place.

Interesting.... I arrived early to find a long lineup. The line moved faster than I thought as there were two lines to enter the mausoleum. It was cool inside from the heat outside. I would say you spend more time in the lineup than being inside.They are strict about not permitting cameras inside. There were guards ensuring that you take your camera to a booth where you will pickup your camera later. In addition, women cannot wear miniskirts or shorts inside. Once inside, the guards ensure the two lines are constantly moving. They are open from 9 am until 12 pm.

My Dream Hero. As a student in Kolkata in 60 to 70 Ho Chi Minh was a very popular name in Bengal and I read about his activities and he is my Hero still today. So when I could see his embalmed body so fresh and lively I just paid a respected Red Salute to the Hero!!

Must do in Hanoi. This attraction is a 'must do' for all the locals and hence there are always long queues, however the queues are very well managed and orderly and always keep moving.One trick, as you enter the actual Mausoleum the single queue breaks into two queues, select the left hand queue as this will give you a slightly better look while inside.

Worth a visit, remember there are limited opening hours for the mausoleum.. Try to do research on the times when Uncle Ho is a busy man.. expect long lines and an extremely limited opportunity to visit. There are scooter taxis in the area regularly if you're interested in taking a scooter tour after visiting the mausoleum. As a general side note, Dec-Feb is a beautiful time to visit Hanoi.

Impressive Complex. We went to to the Mausoleum in September 2015, but unfortunately it was closed though the guards were still on duty and it still made a great photo. You could still get to see the one pillar pagoda around the side of the Mausoleum complex. The complex is very impressive with a big square outside the mausoleum.

If you have the time and don't mind an ultraquick view. Uncle Ho is obviously an iconic and venerated person in Viet Nam and well regarded throughout the world. That said, the actual visit to the mausoleum could easily be skipped. While my wait was about 10-15 minutes (it was cold and raining outside), the guards were very efficient and did not allow pausing when in the mausoleum itself so the entire visit there was maybe 90 seconds. The surrounding grounds were actually more interesting and you don't have to stand in line for those.Someone next to me said it very succinctly, go see the grounds with his home on it, see Ho lying at state online

Average. I didn't particularly want to go here but on a drizzly Hanoi morning we decided to walk here.The security is extremely strict for a tourist destination and I only went along with it because I wanted to see the war museum.Basically after walking in groups in file with no camera you are led into Ho chi mins chamber where a dummy of the man lies in a casket surrounded by stern faced soldiers who must have the worst job in the world.Once we get outside the grounds,house cars etc are all nice to see,you then come to war museum which you also have to pay into (about £1.50 ) and you can spend some time there as well but all in all an awful lot of walking.

Good musuem but nothing special. Be aware that the museum and everything inside closes down from 11:30-1:30/2pm, so plan your time wisely as it's a big area.The old one pillar pagoda is just around the corner. The old citadel is also close by and its closure time is same.It's about the Ho Chi Minh era, the vietnam-US war, so lots of documents and notes about that time, which is translated to english, but I don't know if it's intersting for everyone.If you only have a limited time in Hanoi, I would suggets visitng the Kiem lake and temple of literature/ fine art museum if you like paintings.

Respectful Visit. The mausoleum of Ho Chi Mihn is an interesting place to visit but always check opening times. When visiting it is important to be dressed respectively- knees and shoulders must be covered so no short shorts or singlet tops and no hands in pockets. There is also security to pass through - no water bottles and you need to sign in cameras as no photography is allowed. It is quite a walk from the entrance and you must walk on the lines. Guards are positioned to ensure the rules are enforced. On entering the building there is a sense of reverence. The light is dim and then you see the glass case protecting the body of this important leader to Vietnam. You process slowly around until you are exiting. Once outside you can pick up cameras and take photos. The mausoleum is located in a large area of gardens which is worth exploring. This was a terrific place to visit and should not be missed when visiting Hanoi. Entrance is free which is an added bonus.

Not much to see unless you see HCM. We visited HCM's tomb with a tour group, but only saw the outside of the tomb and did not get to view HCM's preserved body, which friends told us was a "must-see." Our tour guide said the lines to view his body were often two to three hours long so it was not feasible for visits by a tour group. Not sure if that's true or not, but the Mausoleum and tomb are NOT worth a visit without seeing HCM. We never actually saw any lines while at the Memorial, but were told people entered the tomb from the back side (we were on the front side).
A must see. We dont visit inside the mausolee but just appreciated the monument from the street and the statue about ho chi minh.

Somber, but very interesting tour. The mausoleum and adjacent houses were well worth the time spent. A combination of religious shrine and national monument - and a very important part of the national history.

A must see in Hanoi. Our guide did an excellent orientation for this visit. I found it very moving. Having grown up during the Vietnam war, I had not viewed Ho Chi Minh as a hero. The perspective here is very different. He is clearly worshiped here and I felt a sense of power walking past the body. Interesting.

Was part of the tour. Cool to see and luckily there was no line because it was cold.
You cannot bring a camera inside but can take pics outside after you came out and get your camera back.
It was interesting to the guards.

Imposing. A bit of a weird experience but worth it. Only open 8-11 some days but the line moves fast and you can visit the rest of the complex before it closes for lunch if you arrive by about 8.30. I got a bit lost in the complex trying to find the mausoleum - follow the signs for exit and join the queue at the very edge of the complex. Don't bring drinks with you - they're confiscated at security - and do bring a smaller bag for your essentials as you have to check lather items. No photo taking on the approach or in the mausoleum but you can take photos once you're out the other side. The presence of soldiers everywhere is a bit surreal, as is the giant imposing room encompassing such a small body. The rest of the complex is worth a visit once you're there.

Sombre but fascinating. NB: It is only open until 11am every day! And you will have to queue and it is a bit regimented and you only get a minute or so to see Uncle Ho, and you will have to leave your bag at the luggage check and rush back half a kilometre to get it before the luggage check closes for the day at 11.45am, and there is a confusing policy about cameras (you can use them outside only, so if you don't check them in with your luggage you will have to check them in separately later before you enter the mausoleum) and there's a lot of walking involved and although it is free to see Uncle Ho, you will be shepherded into the (lovely) palace grounds afterwards and have to pay for entry...BUT its all worth it, because (a) its a unique - and uniquely Vietnamese - experience and (b) Ho Chi Minh was an amazing national and international historical figure and is so important to the Vietnamese that not to make the effort is a bit disrespectful. If you are in doubt about that, go to the museum afterwards, which tells you all about Ho Chi Minh and the struggles and development of modern Vietnam, its a great exhibition and well worth an hour or so spent over 3 levels of a very grand building for a modest entry fee.
Hot day to stand in line. Many people come to visit when they travel here, place is huge and when you go inside no camera and many guards standing around ensureing you remain quite and respectful.

Vietnam history embalmed. The degree to which the Vietnamese revere Ho Chi Minh and the mausoleum only served to reinforce his importance to their history and identity. He helped support the nation and develop it to what it is today. Well worth the visit while in Hanoi.
Interesting insight. We skipped the mausoleum per se and headed for the museum and his house. Best to get there early in the morning as it was rather crowded.

Nothing special. Not worth a detour. Only if you want to recover from the hectic traffic in Hanoi. The entrance is at the south of the building. Here you find the regular souvenir stalls. We loved the park to the west of the entrance, which we found more attractive than the facade of the mausoleum
Must see. Did a private city tour with a local guide. Found the history very interesting but didn't know we would see Ho Chi Minh laying there. Really didn't like that part of it but worth a visit.

Follow instructions of the guards. We were in Hanoi for a few quite rainy days so we decided to add this to our itinerary. We enjoyed looking around the grounds with the nice buildings and gardens as we quite enjoy history. However the mausoleum was quite strange, we were with lots of school trips and everyone seemed a little on edge. When walking around inside you had to keep walking along the exact paths and not stop or take photos, the guards pushed the kids along to ensure they kept to the path and didn't stop. Quite surreal but not expensive and pretty memorable!
Founder of modern Vietnam. I consider it a must to pay a visit to this bizarre place during a stay in Hanoi. If you are up to an attempt of understanding todays Vietnam, Uncle Ho are a key figure...
An Interesting Experience. A regimented experience from the mausoleum of Vietnam's founding father, Ho Chi Minh. It's eerie and amazing at the same time.

Mr Ho Chih Minh. You can view the body of the founding father of Vietnam, Ho Chih Minh and pay your respect to him at the Mausolem. The queue into the Mausolem is long, but orderly and fast. Remember not to wear shorts or revealing dress when entering the Mausolem. Camera and video recorders are also not allowed into the Mausolem. You can deposit them at the deposit counter located near the entrance free of charge. You can collect them back after the tour. Entrance to the Mausolem is free.
it was an interesting experience. it was an interesting experience, not only the mausoleum, but the rest of the grounds including HCM house and his stilt house car collection. nice half day trip

Bit bummed. We rocked up only to discover that it wasn't opened. The mausoleum is only opened in the morning and some days doesn't open at all. The gounds are lovely and you can get good photos. From all of my "Google-ing" it appears that you can't take photos inside anyway. I didn't feel the need to go back when it was opened just to see a body behind glass. From my understanding "Uncle Ho" didn't want to be put on display.

A definite stopping place. As part of our tour, we stopped at the mausoleum. Our guide was fantastic and was able to provide the history needed for the group to appreciate the stop. Unfortunately we were not able to go inside but we were still able to understand the importance of the site.

Do as you are told.Follow The guards instructions. Interesting.......... Do as you are told. Follow the guards instructions. Walk where the designated path takes you. When in the tomb, keep walk by, no hands in pockets or pictures. Incredibly interesting. Not on my original list to do but very interesting.
Dont let the long line dissuade you. This attraction is a must see, if for no other reason than to see the level of respect the Vietnamese have of Ho Chi Minh. Line moves quickly.

A place of congregation and paying respect ....... We did not go inside the mausoleum. Ho Chi Minh never wanted to be embalmed - his wishes, to be cremated and for his ashes to be scattered in various parts of Vietnam, were ignored. The then USSR contributed to the embalming process - funds have now been withdrawn (it costs app 1M$ in maintenance to keep him preserved).For many tourists it's on their list of things to do - regardless of their political couleur. Entrance is free, the queues are long, security is tight - bu you also notice that the queue moves at speed which makes the waiting time acceptable. For Vietnamese this is a special place - while we were there a group of recent military graduates walked up to the mausoleum in formation, the National Anthem was sung, speeches were held. The nausoleum overlooks the Great Square with formal gardens in the back.Even if you have no desire to go inside, don't miss a visit - if only for the people watching.

Looks like a waxwork. Apparently Ho Chi Minh wanted to be cremated but the Govt went against his wishes and put him on show for the populace to gawp at! Very strict on photography and may be a long queue.

Weird but you should go. Look this is something you should really go and do as it is so important to the cultural significance of the country but it is strange. The sceptic in me says that the body you see is a wax of Uncle Ho but what ever it is amazing to see how important the site is to the locals and the guards who are just so .......serious. Do go and it is ok to wear long shorts guys.

Fascinating. The entire experience is fascinating--nto just seeing the preserved body of the Vietnamese leader. Watching the solemn manner in which all the guards and attendees revere this is interesting.

Beautiful historic grounds and buildings . Friday's the mausoleum is closed. I didn't get to go inside, but the grounds are spectacular with a lot of history. I suggest a guide to get a good historical background of the man and the era.

A piece of history. The Mausoleum was closed the day we were there (Monday), but Ho Chi Minh is basically wax anyway. We did see the changing of the guard and I found the understated house Minh lived in one of the reasons he was adored by the people.

Soviet style marble edifice. A must see for any visit to Hanoi. This mausoleum set in the grounds of the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum Complex is free of traffic and also home to the botanic gardens, one pillar pagoda, Presidential Palace and Ho Chi Minh's stilt house. The mausoleum itself looks like a rather bleak marble cube guarded by military personnel in glowing white uniforms. The changing of the guard is all Soviet style pomp, but a fantastic photo opportunity not to be missed. Pay "Uncle Ho" a respectful visit, remember he is respected by the Vietnamese as their liberator from years of colonialism. No photography is allowed inside the mausoleum as you file past his frail waxy white embalmed body housed in a glass case.

Mausoleum. This place is very moving.Make sure after viewing Ho Chi Minh that you go left.I went the wrong direction and missed out on seeing Ho Chi Minhs house.I couldn't get back in and the place is like a cattle herding yard.Worth the visit.
Impressive monument. Impressive monument for Ho Chi Minh with long queues of foreign and vietnamese visitors; memory of Vietnam's history: anticolonialism and communism.
Bigger than Russia. I think they wanted a mausoleum that is bigger than the one in Red square in Moscow. The hole place just feel like a little Red Square

An interesting way to run a mausoleum!. You can't go to Hanoi and not see the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh lying in state with white color guards standing at attention! To add to the experience, the process is a bit unique. You queue up to go through security check and you need to check back packs, some purses, etc at baggage check. ( they made me throw out food and then check my bag, which made no sense. You then are somewhat escorted quite a distance to the mausoleum, passing a stop where you are suppose to check your camera, iPad, electronic equipment. You March up the stairs of the mausoleum and pass by 3 sides of Ho Chi Mihn, all at steady pace, as the color guards March you along. Somehow s you exit, they now have your cameras on the other side for you to use as you go look at the house and the garage with cars that Ho Chi Minh used. If you checked your purse and so have no money, they will let you in to this part without a ticket. The whole process was so efficient that the large number of people was not a proble. We went on a Sunday and were advised to get there around 10:30 am and it seemed to work out well. They close at 11:30 am

Nice place. Nice place to visit. Outside is green and specious. At the look of it, the place is a reminder of history of vietnam. Even if you don't visit inside, it is lovely to walk around the greeny garden and take few pics. It is worth it.

Very confusing layout. It took us a long time to find the entrance as there is only one way in for this big site...I think we just started on the wrong side so we had to do a lot of walking. When we finally found our way in, there was a very confusing process of going through security screeners, then checking in a backpack at one point but being able to take our cameras up until another point where those had to be checked in...then we were more or less ushered into a line for another site (I think it was the presidential palace and museum) which has a cost to enter unlike the Mausoleum. We found our way out of that line and then had to ask a lot of people for help on where to go to retrieve our cameras and the backpack....all of whom told us we had to exit then walk all the way around again to the entrance. I completely understand and respect the need for not allowing cameras and so on its just that the process was a bit weird and not as well organised as I anticipated. Perhaps if we had chosen to pay money to enter the other site it may have been easier for us to find our way back to our belongings. You will need a lot of patience and I'd only recommend doing it if you are really sure.
Cool!. Just a very interesting thing to see. It's very regal, but you can't go closer than maybe ten meters from any part of it (including surrounding flower patches and whatnot).
I like this place. I come to visit and i love it . I can know more about Ho Chi Minh . This place was very busy everyday . Will come back again .
Must See. This mausoleum entails a huge area which is impressively laid out and built. A must see for sure given the historic importance of Ho Chi Min.

Surreal, not to be missed!. Go early in the day. They stop viewings at about 11:30. The grounds of the presidential palace are open till the afternoon, but mausoleum close. I would point out to take a good look at the whole body notice the fingernails and bread! You move through very quickly and it is dimly lite. No big cameras, but point and shoot and phone camera okay!
Dignified and lot of security around. very smart looking defence personnel in uniforms guard the place but didn't allow pictures to be taken!
OK. Went as part of a tour. Wouldn't recommend unless it takes your fancy to see a body. Lined up for ages and guards all around. Better to learn more by reading a history book.

Make sure you arrive early. Very Very long lineups but interesting to see someone who has been dead for so long. No pictures are allowed inside. Also it closes off and on during the day so make sure you check what time it is open before you arrive. I had a bit of trouble getting there using the map I had so be sure to know where you are going before you head out.

A typical communist square. I visited this morning. It is a big square and a typical communist nation's square. There is Ho Chi Minh's old residential house which was previously a French Governor house. If you visited there, it is better to learn some history about Ho and then it will be more interesting. If you visit Vietnam, you need to have a visit there.

More than a visit to a Vietnamese National Hero. You should adhere to the regulations once being in the area. You need to buy ticket if being a foreigner. Leave your luggage before heading to the Mausoleum and leave your camera and electronic device before entering. You can get your device back and have some nice photos of the construction and the surroundings. You only have a few minutes walking around. Peaceful inside. The area is very spacious, clean and fresh. Police are nice. Notice: It is closed on Monday and Friday and only open daytime.After that, I recommend that you visit the whole Ho Chi Minh Complex, especially the Relic of Ho Chi Minh President. With this type of visit, you had better have a guide who can help you to have deeper understanding. It worth to know about Vietnam's history and politics.

Must Visit to Tick Box of Visit Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh is a Big Name in Vietnam.
The life that he lived is a Big History for Vietnam.
A visit to Hanoi will not be complete without paying attribute to Ho Chi Minh.

Not what I expected. Firstly this will take patience, a long walk and a requirement to follow strick rules (no talking, hands in pockets, no cameras and more). Basically you enter a cold room to view Ho Chi Minh for about 20 seconds. Then you walk out.

Helped me understand the country better. I know others have said it is boring, just a body in a room, but for me it really helped me to understand quite how much this man is revered here.We decided to get there early as we had heard about the lines and knew it would close in the middle of the day. We approached it from the direction of our hotel and could see the line to get in and walked towards it only to be waved off by a guard and had to walk all the way around the entire complex to find the actual entrance. I though we would never find it.You go through security with bag scanners and metal detectors and then have to check your bag instead of taking it with you. They said we had to pick up the bag by 10:30 and it was about 8:45 at the time. After that you start walking through a series of covered walkways. As you approach the mausoleum there are a number of guards in white uniforms, some holding rifles with bayonets. They instruct people to remove hats and as you enter the building, to be silent. There are signs everywhere saying no phones or cameras.We walked up some stairs after entering and then came into the chamber holding Ho Chi Minh's body. He is inside a glass case and the walkway is raised so that you walk around three sides of it. The room is darkened and the case is lit up. There are four guards standing at the corners of the case. He looks quite good. I understand from my reading that he is removed for a couple of months every year to be restored again.There is something quite amazing about feeling the reverence that the people have for this man. In other photos and documents we have seen him frequently called Uncle Ho.I don't think I fully "got" this experience until I had travelled the rest of the country and heard more about the war and Ho Chi Minh and heard from some of the Vietnamese people about how they feel. I was glad that I went as it provided context for the rest of our visit in Vietnam.Some have said not to take children. Our kids were 11 and 13. I just explained to them before we went in what they would see and they were totally fine.

A Monument to a National Hero. Little you can say about a building which you may only look at. Go during the day and then at night for the 9 pm lowering of the flag for a ceremony featuring spotless military uniforms and marching.

Well get in while you can. with very short opening hours, be sure to get in if this is what your after, was pretty boring however, it would of been better with a guide as they include more knowledge and depth into the experience

Not worth a stop in January . This museum is really not worth a stop. The information is very basic, you better read Wikipedia and get more information. And due to construction work, the highlights of the museum are closed (like the body), but price is the same so you better skip this unless you are bored. Price: 40.000 p/p
Terrible. A died skeleton in cold room, it is not good for children, good for communist who love or want to know something about Ho Chi Minh

Don't Bring your Bag. This is probably a "must see" in Hanoi and I do think we should go. I've been to Lenin's and Mao's mausoleums and they are all kind of "must see" for former or existing (depending on how you see it) socialist countries. So, I went and I didn't mind the queue. Do need to find the entrance as tourist guide books do not give your very precise information. But normally there is a crowd going there and just folow and you'll be there. Bags are not allowed and you need to keep it at the "left luggage". So far so good. No charge for everything. And that's vey nice.When you finish your "tour" (again, depends on how you see it), you will be led to a gate to enter Ho Chi Minh's museum and former residence. I finished tour near 11:30am and according to guidebook, this was about time to close for lunch break. So, I decided to skip the museum visit.Then, I found myself heading towards unknown direction. Theoretically, it shouldn't be a problem. I follow the boundary of the mausoleum and then must be able to get back to the "left luggage" counter. So, I walked. Then, I noticed that there's a park right next to the mausoleum. Because the museum and residence were inside the park, there was no short-cut to get back to where I started. It wsn't really a long walk (15 minutes, I think). But mind you, the "left luggage" service would be closed at 12 noon. So, all in a sudden, I found that I must run and need to be sure that I stayed on the right track. Otherwise, my bag would be left there and be kept there over the weekend (meaning I could not go back and pick up as I'll leave on the next day).No big deal. But if you don't need to bring a bag, don't bring it along.The other way to look at this is that mausoleum is free but you are expected to contribute by paying your entry fee to the museum. Not a big sum

Something interesting to see!. Good thing to see if your in Hanoi, I couldn't go and see all of the things to offer in that area (had to check out/it was raining) but otherwise it was very good. Very official and not something you see every day!

Poignant. I have a great respect for this man. Not that I share anything with the commmunist ideology but because this man fought for his people. His country. You can testify the immense faith & respect from the vietnames people that comes to see his Mausoleum. If you go there (and you should do), take the time to go inside and pay tribute to the man. It is moving to feel the atmposphere there. Be careful, it is closed on Monday & Friday.

Amazed, but I personally do not understand why they had to mummify his body. We went there the day before Vietnam's 50th independence day. Luckily enough we did not stand in the queue for long. Rehearsal was going on in the parade ground next to us. At one point we entered the mausoleum, a very cold and very silent room with dim lights and extra ordinary security where Mr. Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body was resting. Four sentry was guarding his body standing at the four corners of his bed. I thought how does it feel to stand like a statue and protect a body, and do this regularly for a living? Mr. Ho Chi Minh, who dedicated his life for his nation, doesn't he deserve some peace?

Long line to see the former leader of Vietnam. It was part of a city tour to visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The line was long to get in but moved quickly. Ho Chi Minh looks very well preserved after 40+ years. You are not allowed to take picture inside or in front of the Mausoleum.

Not worth it. This place is very crowded and the exciting part (entering his tomb) lasts for only a minute. My time was mostly spent waiting in line. There is also very little interesting history on Ho Chi Minh available here or at least that I could find. It is a lot of propaganda type information, which didn't surprise me, but I was hoping for more information on Ho Chi Minh's beginnings and such.

A must see with a guide. We really enjoyed this visit. We went with a guide which certainly made it more worthwhile. It is bigger than you think. There are other buildings to see such as his residences.

memorable experience but very regimented!. Well worth a visit though the tight shepherding of the tourists was rather disconcerting. You only spend a minute shuffling around the glass tomb, surrounded by grim looking soldiers but something you won't forget about for a long time.

Didn't get the point of it!. The time we visited, the body of Ho Chi Minh was sent for upkeep, therefore we could only visit the museum and house. The museum is rather poorly curated with no information about the pieces one is viewing. It is quite haphazard with pieces ranging from historical to modern abstract, but with no explanations or chronology! Unless you are sure that the body is present and available for viewing, this one can be skipped! The house of Ho Chi Minh that shows his simple living is the better of the sights in the same complex. The museum was disappointing, to say the least!

Only for history fans and fans of Mr Ho. The queue for the visit and access to see Mr Ho's tomb is very very long and starts since the morning ~8am. It is advisable to prepare for at least an hour of queuing before you get to see Mr Ho's embalmed body, which lasted only 1minute. The guards on duty will be whisking you to walk quickly - no phototaking allowed and all visitors must be dressed decently (long pants, no sleeveless, no flipflops). The depositing point for your valuables and cameras is different from the retrieval point, which is ferried by a staff. I myself did not bring a camera to avoid the trouble of waiting at the retrieval point. The visit was too short for a one-hour wait, which you had to face irritating visitors trying to cut your queue. Only recommended for die-hard fans of history and Mr HCM His Excellency.

Stunning building and history. Loved my visit, however it is closed on Fridays so you can only see the outside. It is amazing for photos in the day and night a must see attraction in Hanoi. Plus you can see the change of guard every hour.

Amazing & wonderful. If you come to Hanoi, the first place where you should to visit is here. You will amazing with this place also you can sit and look it for an hour and not bore it. It not difficult for walking to here from centre of Hanoi. Go there and feel it.

Interesting . We went with our tour guides from our Hanoi Street food tour which made this your more interesting as they told us about a lot of history. Was amazing how quickly they got through the queues of people and how many school children were there,Very formal and regimented but exactly what you would expect visiting a mausoleum. Set in lovely grounds.

Seing Ho. Not sure you have to do this when in Hanoi, but it is something that most VNese coming to Hanoi do. Long queing sometimes, and you have to stand in line and behave or you get reprimanded by the guards/police. Sometime Ho is not there, getting a facial treatment in Russia, and this is much less interesting!

Recommended for Checkmark Freaks. Ho Chi Minh is very important to the people of Vietnam, especially the people of North Vietnam. And so, to these people a visit to the Mausuleum, is something that comes from the heart,and could be a deeply moving experience. But to a foreigner like myself this is merely another checkmark to be made of the sites recommended by guidebooksThe place isn't particularly attractive.

See Uncle Ho. Only go on a day when you can go in and see the great man. This time the mausoleum was not open to the public so just do a cyclo drive by and take some photos. His physical upkeep is maintained in Russia as he was a friend to the politicians there. So every now and then he goes back there for a refurb. His guards are all dressed in white uniforms. The reason for this is that the guards are direct discendants from royalty or something like that.
Worth Visiting. Where the final burial of Ho Chi Minh, this mausoleum is worth a visit to view and read a bit about his history

Ok but did not miss anything if you did not go. Walking through the mausoleum you will get hushed through and told to keep walking. We were following the line when a guard grabbed my wife by the shoulder and pushed her around the corner. We had not stopped and were following the line up. Note that he was doing this to many people. It is interesting how well preserved he is kept.If you skip this site it is not a loss, but is another place to visit.

Visited in the rain so we may not have had the best experience.. Unfortunately we visited in the middle of a downpour. We never made it into the mausoleum. The grounds were well kept. Very crowded. Certainly worth visiting
Crowds and queues.. Lining up and streamline to get a few seconds view of wax works Ho Chi Minh was not the best place to visit in Hanoi.
The garden is nice. We didn't have much time. So we rushed through it within 1 hr. Come early. The line is long if you come late.

Make this the first place you visit. This is the 'must see' place in Hanoi. A piece of almost Soviet era history, be prepared to go through an about a thirty minute process from arrival as you go through security and are relieved of any bags and/or rucksacks at the entrance and, just before the mausoleum, of any cameras. Sombre looking guards line the route in and outside the mausoleum as you shuffle past the sarcophagus to add to the solemnity of the place. You can get your camera back after leaving the mausoleum to take photos of the exterior and the park. There is a very good cafe in the park close to the entrance / exit.

Lesson in History. Very clean Mausoleum. Visitors are taken around in small groups. Maintain silence as you enter the building & see the body of Ho Chi Minh. also includes a walk around the presidential gardens & can see the vintage cars that were used by Ho Chi Minh

Experience. Strange experience when we are guided swiftly along
Ho Chi Minh's body. The entourage is even weirder: leaving my bachpach in one place where I'll have to pick it up and leaving my camera and tablet in another place where they are being forwarded to the exit of the mausoleum.

Worth a visit. Very large complex. Free. Uncle Ho himself on display and looks so real he could be a Madame Tussauds creation. Also get to see the Presidential Houses, which are interesting, the grounds which are beautiful, and the museum which is interesting. Need a taxi to get there from old quarter, or a xich lo (tuk tuk) which cost us 120 dong (about 5 USD).

Journey through the Mausoleum. This was also apart of the tour, I think it was very nice setup and how it was just a quick look then you had to keep moving so the line was fast. It is also a great picture to keep as a memory.

No Visit to Hanoi is complete without visiting "Uncle Ho". We were lucky to have a short line. Guards are very stern, similar to Arlington's Tomb of the Unknowns. Shuffle past silently and respectfully, without chatting, wearing hat or sunglasses, or hands in pockets. Our guides held our cameras, otherwise we would have had to surrender them before entering. Though access to the area in front of the mausoleum is restricted (we witnessed guards shoeing several people away), taking a decent picture of it is still possible.There is more to see than Ho Chi Minh's body, such as the small house where he lived (shunning the nearby presidential mansion) and his cars. We also enjoyed the tranquil pond full of beautiful koi.

very unusual. well, this was mazing... we were patrolled through the entire complex by guards with guns... and finally we entered the masollem where lying in state was the body of Ho Chi Minh... it was an unforgettable experience... I recommend it...

Worth the Lines, Beautiful Place of Respect and Honor. This is not a place for silly photo ops or goofing around. Although the lines are long, things are very fast and well organized. I was very grateful for an opportunity to pay respects to a great leader. A few things to know: check for opening days, hours and whether or not the body is available for viewing. There is a dress code : no shorts, minis, tank tops. Dress respectfully. Also, no photos are allowed in the masoleum and you will be asked to leave any bags, cameras or electronic equipment at a security counter. You may keep your cell phone with you but must turn it off. This place is very beautiful with lots of photos possible outside the masoleum. The Ho Chi Minh Museum and Residence are on the same grounds.
One of the main attractions. Impressive but not a whole bunch to do when you get there. Pack water on a hot day because it gets HOT!

Unusually awe inspiring. This is a must when visiting Hanoi, I've never seen anything like it. Uncle Ho was loved and idolised by so many and it really shows when travelling throughout Vietnam. Regardless of political beliefs and backgrounds I can't help but respect the man for his accomplishments during his lifetime. The mausoleum building itself is no work of art however it does have a strong and powerful presence. There was a large line up to get in but I found it moved quite fast, I would get there early in the morning for quickest entry, also there is no admission fee.

Totally amazing. This was amazing and it was quite an experience. Worth the visit. You cannot take cameras into masoleum but there are places to leave them. There are military everywhere guarding and watching and the queue was very long waiting to walk through the exhibit. Everyone worships him. It was simply amazing to see him preserved. Once out you can retrieve your camera and take photos outside. This is a must see exhibit

Interesting experience . We visited Ho Chi as part of an Hanoi day tour. It was an interesting experience and perhaps the most enjoyable aspect was interacting with the many school children who made a long and snaking queue which slowly and steady moved around the complex before entering the main building. It is a very similar experience to Moa Tse-Tung Mausoleum in Beijing. The surrounding gardens and preserved building and more interesting to the western tourist.

What an experience!. Even if you know nothing about Ho Chi Minh (which would be a shame), you have to go to this mausoleum. Even if it is not really his body, which was hinted by our guide, again the experience is worth it. You buy a ticket and go through a series of checks, wait in line--single file--and enter the Mausoleum. As you walk past the body, you are admonished if you speak, if you show physical affection or anything but show great respect for he man/God. There are four guards surrounding the body standing rock still (except their eyes taking it all in). I wonder how often they change these guards and how many faint? This is a great way to experience Communism.

Interesting. There appears to be much more patriotism and pride in independence in the north than in the south. The activities around the mausoleum are monitored and taken quite seriously as there is great reverence for uncle Ho Chi Minh. I was appalled to see a family allow their young son to relieve himself just outside the doors of the mausoleum which I thought showed great disrespect ( he could have waited a minute longer to get to a washroom).
One of these dead leaders is much like another. I was chagrined to read that Ho Chi Minh goes to Russia for a refurb in Russia every year - having seen Lenin etc -- this is a cottage industry?

It's place of robbers and theif. I visited to Ho Chi Minh mausoleum on 27th December 2015 at around 10am to pay tribute to the revolutionary leader of Vietnam.I am really shocked and sad to see that ,when I kept my baggage at the security counter in the deposit baggage area, the officer on duty opened my bag and has stole my RayBan sunglasses.I went to the place with lot of respect to Sir Ho Chi Minh and was really felt good when I see the way the complete ceremony was organised,but when I returned back,I found my glasses missing from the bag.I have only bad memories of Ho Chi Minh mausoleum where the pious body of Sir Ho Chi Minh is kept.People in Vietnam not good.
Long lines. You wait a long time to see a wax statue of Ho. It was ok but not great. There are not that many things to see here so it is on the must do list.

Interesting place. Hope your bus gonna go to the right place, cos the entrance is far away from the mausoleum. Photos insde are prohibited, you can watch Ho Chi Minh only while you walking around his glass coffin. After that you can go to his museum. So I did.
Nice experience at HCM Mausoleum. The wait was long. Despite on the queue in the rain, we are sheltered. The queuing was ok. Quite solemn. The body of Ho Chi Min was well kept.

Meh. Huge monument with equally huge lines, I ended up just walking past it and checking it out from afar, didn't mean enough to me to line up for ages to see more. Nearby is the palace and other government building which were also interesting. Further on, behind the mausoleum, is the botanical garden with you need to pay a small entry fee to see. For me this was a better use of time and much less touristy.
Only saw from the outside. We only stopped by to look at the outside of the mausoleum, impressive building with guards around. Inside is only open certain days/times.

So big, you can't miss it!. A great feature along the way through the touristy strip of the botanic gardens, the Presidential Palace and the One pillar pagoda. You can get an idea of the place from the outside with the lovely gardens, lins of beautiful bonsai trees, the guards in their white uniforms with colourful trim. Plenty of food and drink outlets in the area as well as some shady spots to sit and relax.Worth a look.

Unusual but interesting visit. This is not the usual thing to do, however when In Hanoi I would recommend you visit. This is a free attraction and there is not the normal vendors trying to sell you things. Smack between both the palace and main museum its centrally located. Rather unusual, visiting a monument where entombed in a glass display case is the founder of a country. It sounds like a communist thing to do.Overall quite interesting and an important part of Vietnamese history. Well worth visiting.Get there early to avoid long lines, we arrived in morning about 9.30 and had s speedy entry.

'Uncle Ho' is a sight to behold!. He's so revered in Viet Nam that it's hard to imagine visiting Ha Noi without taking the opportunity to respectfully shuffle by this deceased leader while he lies in state in his crystal sarcophogus, and while your every move is scrutinized by dozens of his 'minders'.
Nice building. Nice building but on the day i went there its was prohibed by the soldier to get closer even to take pictures
Very informative and educational. It was very informative and educational. We had booked a local tour and the English Speaking tour guide brought us there plus we visited a couple of other places.

Amazing visit, well organised. Thought provoking!. Very enjoyable lead up to enter acne, lovely gardens. Solomon, respectful and emotional visit seeing Ho Chi Minh so lifelike. House and gardens worth the extra tour. Very cheap. Recommend to visit while in Hanoi.

Interesting to see but nothing more.. We had a walk on the big parade place in front of the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, we met only a few tourist and watched the guards standing in front of the Mausoleum, nothing much to say. Ho Chi Minh himself did not chose this, he wanted to be cremated and his ashes spread out on the hills of the North.
waiting times. if you desperately want to see uncle Ho, you should go. otherwise you can skip the waiting time and just visit the presidential house and the house on stilt

Worth seeing . worth seeing as very interesting. We walked from old quarter and takes about 30 minutes - be careful there is only one entrance place in the back quarter you might have to walk extra than expected. Can take a cab for about 70 000vnd apparently. Very interesting and line moves very quickly. At the end you have the option of looking at the presidential palace too - it costs 40 000vnd but is optional but they don't give you any information so be careful if you don't want to do it as they just herd you towards the ticket line
Great respect. Good tourist spot, for a good walk and chill time, nice view and all. And sure you have to buy ticket to come in.

Not much to see. You have to visit it whilst there but there is not a great deal to see. Just go along and take a quick photo. If you want to actually see the Mausoleum go mid-week during the day, as it is really busy at the weekend and at night. Worth going to see it when all of the locals are there though.

What a contrast!. leave the old quarter where motor bikes and cars fight for space to go to the Mausoluem. The parade ground in front of it is wide open space - and quiet. Cant get up to the temple as it is guarded. However, the museum is nearby. Note the museum is closed on Monday and Friday Afternoons so I cant tell you what it is like (we went on a Monday),
What a dreary building!. I went on a Friday so I was spared seeing the mummified body of Ho Chi Minh! The grounds were quite attractive with the one pillar pagoda
Quality museum. A well designed attraction and very informative exhibits. Certainly worth the visit. X-ray machine and security check to enter was unusual.

A moving historical experience. To call this an attraction is to devalue the fact that you will see the embalmed body of the founder of modern Vietnam and that "Uncle Ho" is much revered by his fellow countrymen. The majority of visitors are Vietnamese. The visit is exceptionally well organised. Please be respectful when visiting and dress appropriately. Would you go to a funeral dressed as if you had just come from the beach?You must leave large bags and electronic equipment at an office on the way in. But the service, as well as the visit itself, is free of charge. It is only open on certain days and only until 11 am, often with long queues. So don't go too late and check if open first. First admission is 7.30am. Visit Ho Chi Minh's stilted house afterwards (for which there is a modest fee).

Surreal but interesting.. Apparently the embalming of communist leaders is a thing, a thing I did not know about but decided to investigate. The grounds and mausoleum are vast it was a unique experience. You can join the debate about whether it genuinely is Ho Chi Min on display. The museum was really bizarre but also interesting as it gave me the perspective I needed on the time line with the French and the civil war etc. An overall interesting thing to do to understand Uncle Ho and by all accounts he was loved world wide. Advice- get there early to beat the crowds we were there at 800am it also closes at 1100am.
An embalmed man of history. A name we knew and many had feared but so revered by the Vietnamese I was glad to see inside this sobering mausoleum in utter silence.

An interesting day for the family. It was very interesting for the whole family, but you definitely need a guide to get the most out of it. The main monument was very impressive and the grounds dedicated to him were amazing. It really highlights how important he was to Vietnamese culture.
Mausoleum visit.. Good cultural experience. Enjoyed meeting the school children and war veterans who were also lining up.

Long Queue on 2 Jan 2016. Its worth it to see the body of Bac Ho, although we queued for an hour. Its better to join tour group as there are many lines to queue, the tour guide will lead you in and out of the premises, very convenient. He knows which lane is the fastest. If you Q yourself, you may end up queuing the wrong lane and spent few more hours there. Don bring big bag, DSLR camera as you will be asked to deposit in the counter, very troublesome.

Imposing. Join the throngs of Vietnamese children and adults queuing to pay their respects to the revered Ho Chi Minh. After some time we entered the Mausoleum and in silence are ushered around the preserved body of HCM. His body is sent to Russia every year for about 4 months for topping up the preservation process. Once out of there you can wander around the gardens and see the small house he spent his last years in. We had hired a guide for the day but it was a bit of a waste of time coming here with him as he does not come in with you and you basically wasting your money as he hangs around and you spend 2-3 hours queuing and visiting. Go very early.

Visit the One Pillar Pagoda nearby. While it may interesting to visit Ho Chi Minh mausoleum it seems to be the remnant of a personality cult , not even seen in Mao's China anymore.
The most charming part of the complex is the One Pillar Pagoda and a ficus tree nearby.

Could have skipped it. This is fine, if corpses and party propaganda are your thing. I love museums and history, but the austerity and ceremony of this site, plus the expectation of reverence, were all a strain for me.

Surreal Experience. Went along with a group of tourist and a local guide. It was a long serpentine queue for the Mausoleum with local people and children along with many tourists. The Process very well organized with so many guards watching and minding people to be in queue & follow guidelines. The place is too big, thus advisable to go with tourist guide. The visit can be completed in 30 minutes in case of no rush. Inside the mausoleaum, quite a surreal experience with a massive body of Ho Chi Minh in a Glass Case and the dim lights!
Not to be missed. There is history here so a good guide will do justice our did.Avoid Monday as Ho Chi Minhs tomb is off bounds as are many museums.

Worth a visit (with a guide). I agree with other reviewers that the mausoleum should be visited with a guide. Our guide recommended us to be there early, which made sense when we saw the long lines. The wait was worth it, especially as this was our first stop on our half day tour. I will have a lasting impression of the solemn and respectful manner in which the Vietnamese visited the mausoleum. Without a guide it may have been difficult to get a proper understanding of the place.

Great for a quick peek at Ho Chi Minh and then out the door. I've seen many preserved Communist leaders and this ranks in the top 3. The interior was a little cold (understandably), so bring a light jacket.

Ok. So u pass around this complex to see the mausoleum..museum and reach other sightseeing places as we did ..on bike behind strangers as is the system in Vietnam for public transport ..for that bit..it was fun.However ..it is just something one walks and sees..nothing to visit really..nor enter ..pass by,click photos since we are tourists and it is a done thing .That's it ..nothing dynamic about it .

an embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh,,, how can you miss this??. Its very touristy (obviously) but I knwo why, its a really eerie experience seeing the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh, they are very serious here we got shooshed quite a few times, its well worth seeing his continuously embalmed body

Surprising and humbling. It is an extremely busy place with endless queues of adoring locals waiting to enter this sacred site to view the embalmed body of the great Ho Chi Minh. Maybe not everybody's cup of tea but a most interesting experience.

Worth visiting. This whole visit can be completed in 30 mins as long as the lines aren't too long. The entire process is very well organized if a bit tedious with guards telling you to follow very specific guidelines, eg. queue up in pairs. Quite an experience to see HCM in person.

Don't go without tour guide. First of all, this place is so big that I think without a tour group it would be hard to figure out what to do and where to go. They don't give you a map of the grounds and they are gigantic. The line was so long to see the stilt house that we never saw it. I would have guessed it would have been an hour or more in line. The mausoleum and the body itself was interesting. I don't believe the body was the real Uncle Ho, but possibly a replica with the body safely underneath the temple base.

Ho Chi Minh Tomb. My son and I went to the mausoleum - it has funny opening times so check before you go. It was very interesting, rather surreal - soldiers everywhere, very strict about keeping you in line. Within a massive concrete structure Ho Chi Minh lies in state in a glass case!

Worth a visit. This exhibit is free and is a good way to kill a few hours in Hanoi. The tour of the mausoleum is very tightly controlled. You are asked to walk in pairs and are herded from the entrance of the complex to the mausoleum itself by military personnel (who,understandably,take their job very seriously). It all gets a bit James Bond when you enter on a red carpet,up a marble staircase past tens of unsmiling guards in ceremonial dress. We skipped the rest of the tour (the museum and HCM's house) as we were tight on time).

Historical figure enshrined. It was fairly quiet so we didn't have to wait long to get in the grounds and the whole experience is fairly biased and glorifying monument to Ho Chi Minh. Very interesting to see a human body kept looking normal. The museum is rubbish and the palace wasn't open to the public. I would probably not bother with anything besides the mausoleum.

Bac Ho Respect. This is a serious national monument in Ha Noi. Bac ( Uncle) Ho's final resting place. For Vietnamese people, this is like a right of pilgrimage, imo. The guards are very strict and expect visitors to be respectful and serious. No laughing or frivolity allowed. No beverages or cameras was my sense. Very similar in concept to Lenin's tomb in Red Square and Napoleon's tomb in the Hotel des Invalides in Paris. There are usually lines so try to pick a non peak time of day. We spent about 40 minutes in line for a 10 minute viewing. Went in March, 2013.
we failed to get in. Somehow we failed to find the right queue to join and so failed to get into the actual mausoleum. It was still interesting though.
