Interesting site, but hardly mindblowing. Of course it is a great place to visit to witness the respect and admiration the Vietnamese hold for 'Uncle Ho', it is not a beautiful nor awe-inspiring piece of architecture.Of typical Soviet-esque construction, set in the middle of a large plaza, across from the Vietnamese parliament it is an obvious landmark in Hanoi.The most interesting part of the experience would be watching the changing of the guard.

Essential to experience this. Somewhat strange to file reverentially past an embalmed body, but Ho Chi Minh is so important I the story of Modern Vietnam that you must make this visit. The surrounding park and various exhibits also worth seeing. The whole thing represents a different side of Vietnam to the hustle and bustle of the rest of Hanoi.

Make time for this . We came here without a guide (first mistake), then entered through a side entrance and not the main entrance (2nd mistake)Tomb itself is impressive and sombre as befits the man it honours, the walk around the grounds interesting. Our regret was not having time to spend in the Ho Chi Minh museum, having gone in through a different entrance we were restricted in how long security would hang on to our backpacks (No backpacks allowed in the area) Well worth your time to visit but do it right, get a guide or at least use the main entrance where I assume you can store your bag for longer.

A view only from a distance. We went here knowing we would not go in due to line ups of school kids. We walked along the promenade taking pics only to be told we could not return the same way so had to detour blocks out of out way.I think the armed guards got a chuckle out of it!

Worth a visit. We were in a long line, but it moved fast and was worth the wait to go through the mausoleum. We enjoyed seeing the places where Uncle Ho lived. The area is very beautiful and a nice break from the busy city.
Educational . In Hanoi, then you must visit the Museleum to learn about the father of Vietnam - Ho Chi Minh - it's free, but also busy and take a guide so he/she can explain the history to you.

A must see. I loved going to the Mausoleum and was an experience that I will never forget. Make sure you get there early to beat the groups. It is only open Mon-Fri 8am-11am so plan your day accordingly. Also make sure you are wearing appropriate clothing. Girls wear a long skirt or pants and avid spaghetti straps and boys if you are wearing shorts make sure they are covering your knees. My boyfriend had t buy a scarf to wear around his waste otherwise we could not enter. This did however make for a very funny experience.

The man himself, who represents a proud and strong people. Any trip to Hanoi should include a little reading up on Ho Chi Minh and a visit to his Mausoleum. A giant figure in Vietnam, his impact on the country will be felt for years. Please be respectful and dress accordingly.
Amazingly efficient. Probably the best run public attraction I've seen anywhere. The line moves quickly, signs are clear and there's free bag check and claim.

Hmmm...a body! . This is a good attraction if you've got time. Queues and security! To be honest, my partner didn't think it was worth it. But afterwards you get to continue through to the presidential grounds. We did this as part of the alt tours.

Little context without a guide. This stop was an important part of visiting Hanoi; however, without a guide, it is a waste.The viewing is quite interesting; however you are ushered through very quickly (20 seconds) and you are left wondering what the 45 minutes in line was about.
Not much to see. . Not much to see but concrete and security. What looks like a park on the map is private for government.

Fascinating . Make sure you go early in the day to avoid huge queues. There will still be a big queue and major security. Was a fascinating experience. Go in and have a look at the man himself. You can choose to just walk around the out side to the presidential palace etc instead of going in. But glad we went in.
No access but interesting none the less. Whilst you can't access the Mausoleum it's worth taking a stroll to see and in doing so you pass several Diplomatic Residences and Government Buildings.

Mainly for the Vietnamese.. Big, yes, impressive, yes, attractive, no, it's a mausoleum. Knowing how much Uncle Ho is revered you can understand them wanting to keep him around but this is not a tourist attraction for foreigners.

A Fitting Resting Place for a Uncle Ho. Another must see if you are in Hanoi. Like him or not, Ho Chi Minh was a fighter, a servitor and a leader that one every battle, defeating the French first and then America. Once can only respect his resilience. The Mausoleum is well organized and one can see the mummified Uncle Ho in addition to the Colonial Mansion that was once used by the French occupiers of Indochina.

Great place. Ho chi minh mausoleum is a must to visit if you are in Hanoi. Though you have to go through strict security it is worth your time and effort. We took a cab from old quarter for about 65k dong. After going through the security whereby food, drink and camera are prohibited; we walk under a sheltered walkway for about 5 mins. Outside of the Mausoleum are group of guards. As we tread quietly with a sense of awe into the place; we saw the final resting place of the President. His body are guarded. Those who stand around the body exudes a sense of pride and reverence. We are glad we are here for a visit.

Great way to find out about the history of 'Uncle Ho'. It is a bit creepy to see someone like this but if you have a guide the story is very worthwhile. Our guide told us of his humility and the reason he is here.

What an inspiring building this is. Took lots of pictures from outside the building. We couldn't go inside because there were some VIP's visiting at the time we were there and they were inside the Mausoleum on a private visit. Nonetheless we had an enjoyable afternoon in the gardens surrounding the Mausoleum and also visited the house that Ho Chi Minh actually lived in - it's a very simple home and fascinating to see how he actually lived.
Fascinating . Great place to try and get a sense of Vietnam and it's history. The music is inspiring and gives you an insight into the culture
Meh. Long queues, ridiculous security checks and a confused display of bad art and history in the museum. The mausoleum wasn't opened to the public and everything closed by noon. Not impressed.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Unfortunately during the period that we visited the mausoleum, the body was not lying in state and was sent elsewhere for preservation purposes. Our guide did not disclose where the body was and stated that the government likes to keep it hush hush. None the less, the outside of the mausoleum was quite impressive comparable to Chairman Mao's mausoleum in Beijing. The structure is reminiscence of Soviet architecture. The expansive plaza in front of the mausoleum was relatively empty. We were present during changing of the guards which was interesting to watch. It was quite pleasant to walk around the whole structure itself. It is a worthwhile visit if you include a visit to the adjacent museum and grounds also.
Grandiose . We were too late to enter the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum but the exterior was very impressive and the people around the place lovely!

Ok.. so that's a dead man. Long waiting lines, and scrupulous security measures will finally lead you past Ho Chi Minh's final resting place. For all to see.... For about 1 minute since the line is past him is ever moving. Worth a visit because of it's historic significance but otherwise not that spectacular. Kind of what you expect from a dead man in a glass box.
If not interested in the history give it a skip. Queues long but moves quickly. If you not into history give this one a skip. if you are visiting then try to go early morning.

Hey Uncle Ho!. This really is something different to do on your trip which you will be telling people about when you get home! The guards there are on an absolute power trip and it really does feel like a poster ad for communism. Be sure to do as your told- stand still, no pictures, arms by your side not folded, walk here- now stop etc. A surreal experience and one really not to be missed if you're in Hanoi. We got up nice and early to beat the ques which worked for us but I can imagine it getting very busy at certain times of year.

Impressive structure. This time in Hanoi I did not enter the mausoleum, merely took the photos in front of it. First time visitors probably should enter as it's different from the Western style of dealing with past leaders!

the final resting place for Uncle Ho. we started our day with a visit to the Mausoleum and we were not disappointed by it. the calmness and serenity in the mausoleum has a very peaceful effect. The whole place is guarded and people are usually allowed inside in batches in order to control the movement which is commendable. once inside, photography is prohibited. the whole complex is huge including the palace, stilt house, museum and should not be missed.
Weird experience. You walk into a room where you see ho chi minhs dead body it's a weird experience but hey I'm down for that. After you leave his tomb you go into beautiful gardens
Nothing Spectacular. Walked by here and saw the building and thats pretty much it. Took a couple of photos and left. Nothing to complain about, nothing spectacular either.

Don't bring your bags to this one.. The taxi driver dropped us at the museum instead of the mausoleum. They are just across the road from one another, however, you need to join a long queue to deposit your bags, and another queue to deposit your cameras. You can keep your mobile phones with you. Once inside the mausoleum, talking and photos are not allowed. Be sure to dress appropriately too. We were in and out of the mausoleum in 5 mins. The confusion starts when you want to retrieve your bags and cam, as they are in different locations, far from each other. The guards doesn't seem to speak much English nor know the protocol.I felt the museum was more meaningful for tourists.

It is about understanding modern Vietnam. Why did you come to Vietnam anyway?. This is not about coming to see the body of Ho Chi Minh. It is about understanding the people of Vietnam, their values, their government. It is about how they remember Uncle Ho that says something about how they see themselves. When you come to the complex, it is a window into the heart of this country...and ok, I always wanted to see one of those preserved communist leaders. It was surreal.Remember: Be respectful (doesn't mean you have to agree with him or anything), don't talk inside the mausoleum, dress modestly, come early, you will get your stuff back. Most of the line is covered, so you won't die. You may have to wait, but we walked right in just before the morning closing. Hang around the square later to see changing of guard (Warning: it can be very hot out there). And go to the Ho Chi Minh Museum... you've never seen anything like it.
Awesome!. Pity we can't take any photos inside but yes, it's understood. His body is so well preserved, it's a marvel in itself. Must see to believe.

See yet another Communist leader corpse. The Mausoleum is not THAT spectacular but worth a visit if you are in Hanoi and are fascinated by communist ideals and landmarks.Seeing the body of Ho Chi Minh is really an experience (but not so recommended for families or kids).Not much to do and a lot smaller than expected (compared to other similar buildings).

Very informative. I went with my parents who were both elderly and my 3 kids. 2 were teenagers and one was 5 yo. The guards are very nice to allow us to rest at the staircase as my dad got a little winded from a lot of walking. My general experience of the Vietnamese is that they are very nice. But the lady at the baggage counter at the entrance was very rude...the only rude vietnamese we encountered. An impt tip is to make sure the ID of cab driver is prominently displayed near the meter. No ID means rigged meter.
Mausoleum. It was cool to see Ho Chi Minh body. It was quick and easy, you couldn't talk, but got the most out of it. It wasn't too bad.
tomb visit. this is the first thing to do in Vietnam - pay your respects to the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh . easy access

Historic and Disciplined. This place was so historical and important because Ho Chi Minh's body lied here. All people need to observe discipline when entering this place. Beside also are other attraction. Excellent tour.

Hi Di Ho not . We went to the mausoleum at a time when you couldn't get in to see the body lying in state. I was quite keen for this sight so I was disappointed and recommend checking if you have similar ghoulish interests. It was interesting to see a large communist square but not a highlight.

Heavy dose of love for Uncle Ho. This was a great highlight of our visit to Hanoi, but if you are a Yankee, expect a heavy dose of guilt the be laid n you by tour guides. Well worth the time. Go as early as possible and expect to walk a long way before getting inside.
Lovely Settings and Surroundings. A very nice monument with lovely grounds around which are well manicured and Landscaped. Worth visiting.

A must for a true experience of vietnam. Remember to get up early to beat the long queue, and remember no cameras although many people kept their phones. The guards at the foot of the mausoleum will stop you using the phones as you get to the entrance. Once inside it is surreal as you are quickly ushered through past the mummified body. Once out of the mausoleum you exit out to the entrance of the palace for which you can buy tickets and queue up separately to the locals. Or you can make a sharp exit by turning right towards the square and then left out on the road

First time I've seen anything like this. This was the first time that I've seen one of these embalmed communist leaders on display. We all have heard of Lenin in Red Square, this is the same idea. The line is very long, and there is no talking once you are inside the mausoleum. It took 45 min to get in. Check the dress code before you go, knees and shoulders have to be covered, and no cameras allowed. They are very strict. The guards are not friendly. You have about 1-2 minutes to circle around the embalmed body, once you get inside the inner sanctum. It's something you should do, if you go to Hanoi, for an interest in history and for the surrealism.
Must see. As mentioned before, we had a long afternoon walk, over the main attractions in central Hanoi. worth a visit when in Hanoi.

Huge square. The mausoleum was closed ( open only a few hours in the morning) but we were lucky to see the changing of the guards. It does not take long but it is interesting to watch the white dressed guards marching in rhythm.The square is huge, it seems to be used for parades. Would be nice to see one.There's a yellow line in front of the mausoleum that you should not cross. It is not obvious to visitors.

Surreal Experience. Seeing Uncle Ho's mausoleum and miniature city-shrine was one of the strangest and most alien experiences I think I will ever have. A relic of older, more totalitarian times, the small group you are assigned to is constantly shadowed by armed guards in a vast and empty city-space once (and still) used for grand, nationalistic celebrations. Don't hesitate to visit, even if just to have a glimpse of the figurehead-worship Vietnamese political culture.
Cool experience. Learned a fair bit more about the history of Vietnam. Ho Chi Minhs body was well preserved. Worth a wander through the Presidential grounds next door too.

A lot of hype. I suppose all good former major communist leaders need to be preserved and placed on display so the people can show their adoration to pseudo deities to the state (Mao, Lenin, Chavez, Stalin, Kim Il Sung).The line can be long. We went late and it only took 45 min to get in. Be aware, they close early (around 11 I believe). Check the dress code before you go, knees and shoulder covered. They are very strict. The guards are not exactly friendly. They will literally shove you in a "you can't do anything about it" manner. You have about 30 seconds to walk around an embalmed body. It changed my life (JK). It checks a box. That's about all I can say. If you are interested or "fascinated" about the history, I suggest you read some impartial books.
Spectacular. Sadly it was closed on the day we visited, but even the outside is stunning and impressive as a complex and building.

Just an ordinary spot. Nothing really great about this spot. It has history to it in the form of Ho Chi Minh. But not a great looking monument or well established landscape to spend some time there. Just 30-45 mts of snapshots would be good enough.

It will make an impression on you.. My husband and I travel a great deal and we do a lot of research before planning an itinerary.  We only do private tours because we find them to be are more efficient personal.  Since this was our very first trip to Southeast Asia, we opted to have our tour guide pick us up from the airport.  If you are looking for a reliable English speaking guide, you can contact Alex Nguyen at vietnamhottourguide@gmail.com.Once through security, we found Alex very easily. He was right outside security with our names in bold print on his I pad. The airport is a good 45 minute drive from the center of town and since rush hour begins at 6:30 and doesn't end until 9:00, getting to our hotel was pretty intense with all the cars and thousands of motorbikes on the road.  Once we arrived, check in was pretty smooth.  We were given our room at 9:00 AM and were able to freshen up and change before going on our tour. The first stop was an ATM so we could get some Vietnamese currency.Our first site was a visit to the Ho Chi MInh mausoleum.  You are not allowed to take any photos inside so unfortunately, we had to leave our cameras with Alex while he waited for us to see the actual tomb.  Ho Chi Minh is embalmed, laying in this huge building that resembles Lenin's tomb in Moscow.  He is in a coffin-like case and his hands and face appear to be glowing as if they are lit from within.   Four guards stood at attention at all  times within the tomb without moving a muscle. Right in front of the mausoleum is this HUGE boulevard that is closed to all cars.  And, surrounding the building are these really beautiful gardens.  In addition to the gardens, we could see the presidential palace that was built by the French a couple of hundred years ago.  Ho Chi Minh never lived in it because he felt it would be "unseemly" given the abject poverty of the vast majority of the Vietnamese so he lived in a much smaller residence with three fairly basic rooms albeit they did have his four cars on display - one of them being a Rolls-Royce!Later on, Ho Chi Minh moved to another home based on the Thai model of building homes on stilts.  This particular home was quite beautiful, made almost entirely of teakwood.  Adjacent to the home was his bomb shelter which was used quite often during the "American" war as it is called here.  As the communist leader got older, he was no longer able to comfortably climb the steps to the stilt house so he moved to another residence 200 yards from the stilt home - also a small home with three rooms and an adjoining apartment with all his medical equipment to keep him going!

One of those "must do" things. If you come to Hanoi you must visit the Mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh - Ho Chi Minh is considered by many Vietnamese to be the founder of modern day Vietnam. Best time to come is in the Winter when crowds are at their lowest as otherwise waiting time can be over two hours. No photos or electric equipment are allowed in the building so be aware of this before you intend to lug expensive equipment around with you (if you do decide to do so, then be aware that it will be taken off you and returned later after the tour). The exhibit claims to be the preserved remains of Ho Chi Minh (I'll let you be the judge) - there is a deep sense of respect and reverence throughout. You must be silent when you enter and keep your hands out of your pockets. Photos are forbidden.Worth the wait? Probably not. A must see when in Hanoi? Absolutely. What pushed this from a 2 to a 3 was the rest of the attraction where you can see where Ho Chi Min lived - giving you a sense of the simplicity of the man, how he never wanted to forget he was a man of the people. You see the bunker he lived near during the many wars and the old Presidential home. I will definitely be picking up a good book when I get home to find out more about him.

Nothing spectacular but worth the visit. It's free and an important piece of Vietnamese history so you would be remiss to skip it.That being said, with the exception of the 30 seconds shuffling through the mausoleum itself, the majority of your time is spent walking in twos through out the compound. Not overly exciting.

Eye opening experience! . LocationLocated out of the old quarter where we stayed. Need to take a taxi that cost about 50000-70000 Vietnam dong (usd$2-3) The ride takes about 10-20 minutes depending on traffic. Environment The whole area of the mausoleum is quite huge with the palace and garden that President Ho Chi Minh used to live many years back. It is guarded by many armies and guard in the whole area. And how does it really look like I'll keep it a surprise to you to explore! Definitely a must visit! Price FOCFYIThe mausoleum opens from 8.00-10.30am everyday except Friday close. It is also CLOSE every year in the month of September for maintenance.

Half day trip to HCM mausoleum. A meaningful trip. Well organized queue system to ensure order of the visitors to the mausoleum. But do take note it is a one way route and you are not allowed to back track to revisit if you miss any point of interest throughout the visit. Overall, a good trip to make.
Woah. Must go in hanoi. Honestly hanoi itself is a pretty boring city in terms of attractions. But ho chi minh mausoleum is somewhere u have to go.

Landmark - should go and take pictures. Personally feel that this is a landmark you should visit tho it may not be that interesting. We joined the queue at the entrance to enter the place but it turned out that the queue will led us to whr mr ho chi minh is at. This place includes the president house and the ho chi minh museum (which u have to pay tickets separately)
Not much to see. Not much to see here as you are unable to get up close to the mausoleum itself. However the area is very well kept.I can't see anyone spending more than 20 minutes in this area

Orderly. There was not much to our visit. Our tour guide gave us some history about Ho Chi Minh, we lined up and went in to see the embalmed President. It was much like viewing the body of a dead relative at a funeral. I suppose if you had an affinity for the president then the Mausoleum would be more interesting. The grounds were nice. I would caution anyone who is still grieving a loss about visiting the Mausoleum. It is very solemn experience.

Be rare opportunity to see an influential leader. The North Vietnamese people idolise "Uncle Ho" so a visit to see the embalmed body is a must if you want to get a feel for the history of Vietnam. Queues can be very long on some days. Take the chance to visit Ho's house on stilts, a real place of ranquility and history.

Dress properly. A very sacred place. Almost touching for the respect that all the Vietnamese visitors of all ages pay to it. The visit is quite time consuming (no less than 2 hours): a lot of cuing (we spent more than an hour in a line). The dark, large room, where uncle Ho's remains are kept has to be visited quickly. You can't stop and you are invited by soldiers in white uniform to continue walking around it. Inside the Mausoleum are (which is very big), there are other spots to visit. Interesting the history of Ho Chi Minh: you need at least another extra hour if you want to read all in the Museum. Getting out of the Mausoleum area, you will bump into the One Pillar Pagoda so you can combine the two visits. There are lots of limitation to visit the Mausoleum: check the opening hours, check that the remains are not under restoration (periodically they are and a team of Soviet doctors come to Hanoi to do the work), make sure your legs and shoulders are covered, you have to leave your camera and you will pick it up when you exit. I strongly recommend this visit if you want to better understand Ho Chi Minh personality and role in the Vietnam history. Cuing is not a big issue as you will socialize with many lovely locals.

Must see, when you are in Hanoi. The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is obviously a must see when you are in Hanoi. We expected long waiting lines but the crowd control was superb. Take about 2.5 hours for your visit including the HCM museum and the presidential palace.

Very Organised. It was a huge monument for a country in Asia. It was a regemenred place you had to queue in perfect lines it was all very quiet and very serious. Interesting to see how much they thought of Ho Chi Minh lots of pomp and ceremony.
Respect. Great experience with an old communist Touch. Nice to visit an important part of the history of the country.

HCM Mausoleum is worth a visit. It is quite organized to go see Ho Chi Minh body. Lot's of guards. No cameras allowed while in line. The line moved very quickly. It felt really surreal to see those paying respect to HCM. Worth going in if you have time.

A bit disappointed . It was a grand monument and park and would love to see the great leader that the country respects.
However, visiting this place during weekends was a nightmare and a scary long queue!!!
The recommendation is go during weekdays morning.
It was ok, but I wasn't "wow'd".

Solem place. Very different and reverent atmosphere. Not really beautiful but moving and interesting experience. Should do it as its quick and a very unique place and experience. Lines move very quickly
Living History. We loved visiting the Mausoleum. Real history that evoked thoughts of the past and how Vietnam's history has been so influenced by one man. Would highly recommend.

Big place with lots of history. Many interesting corners with history of Ho Chih Minh as the head of state of Vietnam.
Many photo opportunities.

Quick visit, close to other attractions. Mausoleum opens from 8 am to 11 am, and the last entry is at 10.15 am. Try to go early to beat the crowd, and dress conservatively (no shorts, short skirts or spaghetti strips). You have to deposit your water bottles/mineral water at the entrance, and can only pick them up at the end of your visit. Photography is not allowed. No entrance fee is required. Queue moved relatively quickly, and the guards were rather efficient. It took us about 20 minutes to walk from the entrance of the site to the entrance of the mausoleum, which was rather fast given the long distance. Was in and out of the mausoleum in 10 minutes. The guards would usher you and you won't be allowed to stop, you have to keep moving. Interesting experience viewing Ho Chi Minh's body - would say it's one of the must-dos in Hanoi, as it's a crucial part of local life. I also got to see the changing of guards, which was a plus point.

Imposing. We were only able to drive passed this as we were coming to the end of our short stay in Hanoi and so many places to see! I am glad we at least managed to see it and am sure it would have been good to walk up to a see a bit closer.
nice. really important place for the locals!! do not wear shorts if you wanna go into the mausoleum!! the building by itself isn't too nice, but you need to see!
Quick visit, worth the trip. Unique site with HCM's body completely preserved. You'll be in and out in 20 minutes. This is a critical part of modern Vietnamese history and worth the visit.

Mausoleum inspiring . Must arrive by 1015am latest. Queue is long but moves quickly. Free entry. Great for non museum lovers as fast paced. Very imposing and worth the visit. Museum next door was not great for us.
Ho chi minh visit. Need to confirm the timing before going,since it is opened on timing basis and I heared Ho chi Minh .

A Must Visit. My youngest daughter has been studying the Vietnam Wa's and wanted to visit the mausoleum for some time, so on this trip we managed to take it in. A number of reviews stated they had to wait a long time to get in, we didn't. There was a long queue, but this was moving fast. People from a far were there to pay their respects to the Vietnam leader. Very organized and glad to managed to get in. Get there early, as the mausoleum is only open for a short period of time and only in the mornings.
Just a monument.. Wide road, no vehicles, no honking. We didn't enter the mausoleum, just took photos from the outside.

large does not make right. A huge structure that dominated the surrounding area. The mausoleum was closed to the public. The gardens around were well manicured and constantly tended. There was a line well before the mausoleum that the ever watchful guards would not let anyone cross.

A Tribute to the Father of the Vietnamese Nation. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a National monument and tribute to the Father of the Vietnamese Nation. For most people from Vietnam this is a place of "Pilgrimage"and for many people from around the world this is a place to pay homage to a great Leader & Statesman.

Worth Visiting. The queue was long and took us almost 1 hour to reach the Mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh. But it's something you will never regret visiting. Strict admission check are done so no food stuff or water during the visit. After the visit you can view the display and artifact near to the Yellow House or Presidential Palace. At the end of the journey there are a lot of stalls selling souvenirs, drinks and local fruits

Did not pay to go inside the facility. We did not pay to enter the facility, but had a chance to walk around this area. Rather touristy, and quite interesting to see the white-suited soldiers(?) and green-suited soldiers patrolling around this area. Patriotic music can be heard as you stroll through the garden too. I enjoyed this area!
Must stop destination in Hanoi. The mausoleum and who it houses have great cultural significance ( No spoilers) It is a must see if Hanoi is part of the itinerary.
Entrance to the Mausoleum. If you are not prepared to queue up, you can forget about it. By 6.30. a.m. people are already queuing like a bees line. The closing is at 11.30 a.m.We decided not to enter

Impressive. The monument is impressive when you stand next to it.The change of the guards is also nice to see.You can see this in less than half an hour.If you really want to enter in the mausoleum, check first if you can. It is not always open for public.
What a Landmark!. My first impression of the Masoleum is great. I visited on 2 pm. The Masoleum is already closed. But the attraction is to see the soldiers march in front of the building.
Humbling. Good manners are in order for this visit as we saw many people being reminded to take their hands off their pockets as we were presenting to see the remains of Ho Chi Minh.

Reverence. To understand the north, one needs to see this mausoleum. Be sure to go early (9am) to avoid long lines and check for days it is open because they are erratic. The lines wind around for quite a distance after you enter the site. There are guards everywhere. And silence is strictly enforced once you reach his tomb. Our guides told us his body goes to Russia for a "vacation" every year to be re-embalmed. Don't know if that is true but it is an interesting story. As one proceeds around Ho Chi Minh, you can't help but notice the deep reverence for this man. Many Vietnamese are weeping. He lived a humble life and chose to live in a worker's house rather than the mansion on the property. His furniture is spartan and simple.

So very interesting.. . Such an interesting place to visit. The pageantry around the mausoleum, especially as you enter inside it is definitely something we didn't see anywhere else in Vietnam. A Vietnamese lady in front of us burst into tears as she entered the room and saw ho chi minhs body on display... Learning about this country's history, her reaction wasn't surprising. The presidential palace and ho chi minhs former residence is in the same complex so it's worth the visit.Get there early as it is only open in the AM and don't wear shorts.

Very Interesting. About a half hour walk from the old quarter of Hanoi. Was strictly organized by government staff in which no pictures were allowed. The Mausoleum was beautiful and a nice tribute to Ho Chi Minh. After visiting the mausoleum you have the opportunity to see the Royal Palace and Ho Chi Minh's house and cars. The grounds here are beautiful and well maintained.

Not a lot to see or do. I have never been a huge museum lover so the HCM mausoleum was unlikely to do much for me but we were told it was one of the highlights of Hanoi. The district surrounding the site has some impressive French era buildings and embassies. Unfortunately the HCM mausoleum itself is not something you can go inside to see. Just walk around the parade ground out front. The adjacent museum has some interesting displays that showcase the people's struggle for independence but didn't hold my attention for long.
amazing. This is really part of the visit to Ho Chi Minh's home. Closed on the day we visited but you can see it from the outside

Can't miss a visit to see Ho Chi Minh!. Highly recommend a visit. The line moves very fast so don't let the crowds deter you. It's an impressive space and you do get to see Ho Chi Minh fairly close up albeit behind armed guards. Make sure to walk around the gardens in the park. Skip the museum on Ho Chi Minh, poorlylaid out and not worth your time or money

We were not allowed in. It was a weird experience visiting the Mausoleum because we weren't allowed to go in or step over certain lines. Felt like we could be shot at any moment by the guards around the building holding rifles. Eek. They do hoist an ENORMOUS vietnamese flag thee which is quite cool to see. Rather pop in the Ho Chi Minh museum next to it, much cooler!

A must when you visit Hanoi. When you visit Hanoi, this is a must. Only the experience of the many many people who show their respect to this man ... when we arrived there was a very long row op people waiting, and despite all the safetprecautions you do not have to wait for a very long time.It is a bit strange when you enter the mausoleum to greet Ho Chi Minh. It seems this was not his wish to be like this but so it is. NO photos or camera's are allowed and you have to give them before and collect them after the visit. A strange touristic attraction but anyway a must ...

Woth visting but!!. It is definitely not to miss.. The great leader of Vietnam is buried but there are a couple of problems:
1- There is a break time between 12 pm to 3 pm.
2- The Tomb is closed in the afternoon.
3- The museum is nice but not great as other Hanoi museums.. I had higher expectations for it

Silence is necessary. The Vietnamese people revere Ho and his burial site. He is buried here but on display. He is well guarded and silence is required. There is a changing of the guard every 30 minutes.

Needs longer opening hours!. Did not get to go in (heard it's only open for 3 hours a day in the morning), but the night display is nice. A typical place tourists need to visit, but just to grab a photo and be on your way.

We went inside!. I was last here in 2013 and you could not go inside, but just see the changing of the guards out front. However I just went in Nov 2015 and there is a whole new security set-up around the area that directs all the traffic through a screening process to get into the area to see the mausoleum and the one pillar pagoda. I was very confused about what was happening but we went along with the line to see what was happening. You had to turn over your computers and cameras. I was also told that I had to cover my knees. We were marched 2 by 2 to the mausoleum and went inside to see Ho Chi lying in state! The atmosphere was very stately and we were really surprised to be a part of it. It's unclear to me if that is always an option or if we got there on a special day?

In memory of a great leader. It seems that the late revered leader of Vietnam was not much into pomp and pageantry but after his death his followers were not content to let him slip into oblivion. Thus this massive memorial park with his embalmed body lying in permanent state with an honour guard in his large mausoleum,the official Presidential palace,his last simple wooden house,his office and even his garage with his cars! There is a well looked after garden and a pretty lake. There is also a large parade ground for national level celebrations. Good for history buffs though the queue for the tomb can get very long.

Surreal place to visit. Interesting hearing all about Ho Chi Minh and seeing his supposed body lying in state all these years after he died. Very strict conditions about entering the mausoleum and you can see they obviously adored him.

Interesting Guards. Didn't go in here, but saw it from the outside. Interesting to see the changing of the guard - with them doing "Silly Walks" It is right by Ho Chi Minh Complex where his house was.

Closed to the public, but interesting!. Rather austere, but impressive. A bit like Red Square, in Moscow. Worth visiting, as were the grounds and gardens and houses etc where Ho Chi Minh lived/ worked at times. We avoided the crowds, by visiting in the afternoon, but couldn't go inside.
Tourist spot. The building locate at the big area and the one pillar temple also just nearby .is can be access to this area by a google map.
Worth the long queues. Be prepared to queue but its worth the wait and the queue moves quite quickly. Get there early and beat the bus groups.

My visit to the HCM Mausoleum. The HCM Mausoleum is located in Ba Dinh Square in the city centre of Ha Noi. The mausoleum is the highlight of the Ha Noi city tour because this is where visitors can see the preserved remains of the late Vietnamese President HCM. Big bags and cameras are to be left near the entrance for security reasons and security is also tight inside the mausoleum, which is understandable. There are many nice views right outside the mausoleum such as government buildings and visitors can take pictures after getting back their cameras from the check-in counter. This particular tour is very informative but younger children may not be able to appreciate it yet.

With all my respect for Uncle Ho. A place you must visit when you are in Ha Noi. I have been there in 2010 in my 1st trip to The Capital, I have had unforgettable experience when I had a chance to visit our great leader. Everyone will be queued up and slowly walking around the area where the crystal coffin was placed. The walk way and the crystal separated areas, we cannot get nearer to touch the coffin, you can only look from near distance (4-5m), the room was dark and you must keep the voice at minimum level. It is like he is sleeping in peace after all the hard work he has done to bring back the independence to his country, Vietnam.

Impressive from the outside. We visited the Ho Chi Minh museum here but walked up to the mausoleum. It is impressive in size, but on the day we visited it was closed. Great to walk down the plaza where you knew tanks had once been. Eerie to think about it.
Emotional. It was very inspiring and emotional to see the body of Ho Chi Min.There was a long que but it moved along fairly quick.

Made the mistake of going on a Monday. Be careful which day you visit as the Mausoleum is not open everyday. Due to a compact time frame our visit on the Monday coincided with the closure. However we were there around noon and got to see the changing of the guard which although small is rather ceremonial in nature. Be aware that there are yellow lines which you are suppose to remain behind and that if you hear the head of the ceremonial detail blow his whistle then someone has crossed the line. We were informed by our local friend that when the Mausoleum is open the queues extend several hundred metres. As with other sights of this nature a respectful attitude and standard of dress is required.

OMG how to rate this ?!?*!?. Ho Chi Minh is a God-like figure in Vietnam. He is deified on all levels and is constantly being "promoted" through-out the country (from bill boards to every single museum or state owned anything...which is nearly everything). So, to go visit him "in person" was a big deal...and they make sure you pay your proper respects. First-security and camera checking2nd - Long, procession like walk, in 2's (side by side) with straight face (talking or noise will bring a "shush" from very stern guards). Much pomp.3rd - The body. Apparently the Vietnamese went to Russia to learn how to preserve the body and occasionally the exhibit is closed for "maintenance"4th- It actually is quite somber and interesting. This humble,modern architect of present day unified Vietnam who wanted to be quietly cremated remains on display for all the world, nearly 50 years after his death.5th - Following the coffin visit you tour the grounds which are lovely and see the "presidential palace" he didn't stay in, a replica of the humble house he did stay in, and the presidential car exhibit which my French compatriots loved.6- If you're in Hanoi you simply have to go here!

Closed. The building is impressive and out is a bit strange that it exists because Ho Chi Minh wanted to be cremated.Our is closed more hours then it is open, so infirm yourselves. We didn't do we could only see the outside.

Worth It!. I must say that I believe it would be wasteful to come to Hanoi and not visit this place. It doesn't take that long to visit Ho's rating place, even if the crowd looks large (it moves quickly). After that, it's up to you how much time you want to spend seeing the remainder of the grounds. It's also worth mentioning that one should at least scan Wikipedia or the like to grasp what makes this Man's life so meaningful, as seeing the Mausoleum without this understanding may take away from the experience. If you can, try to time your visit during the changing of the guards.

Eerie but interesting too. to view this mausoleum you should leave your camera with the tour guide because the government officials will confiscate it. It was rather solemn experience and the guards were a bit fanatical with visitors marching two by two. They guard Ho Chi Minhs tomb with guns and bayonets. There was no nonsense when visiting this site. Ho Chi Minh laid in a glass coffin looking like wax but you can see how much he is revered. After you leave the mausoleum you can take pictures and see where he lived. He was a simple man with love for his country. Must see.
It is avery long walk. The best part is the leader,s simple house made of wood and the collection of his cars. the monument itsef has nothing special except being big, grey and made of concrete

Interesting. I visited this place in the morning. The lineup was quite long but it moved at a steady pace. You have to check in your camera. No photos are permitted inside. As you shuffle you way past Ho Chi Minh, there are 2 guards who stand nearby ensuring the line moves smoothly & probably making sure no one takes a photo. It takes you longer to line up than viewing Ho Chi Minh. There's something freaky seeing an embalmed body.
Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. It was a strictly security manner to visit the above. Camera was left at station before queuing for your turn to Psy respect,

Respectfully Ho Chi Minh. We, Vietnamese people, must visit this place at least once in our limetime. Especially with the people from other provinces of Vietnam, the place is always in their Must-Go place when they visit Hanoi.If you can arrange your time, let's do it.
Ugly tomb. Just a waste of time queuing in the long line, not much things impressive enough here. A big waste of money also

A very popular spot for the Vietnamese. Ok if you want to see the preserved remains of Ho Chi Minh. But I was impressed by the simplicity in which he lived. Lovely garden and mature trees and ominous pmasoleum. Tons of school kids and locals and queues forever.

A must see in Hanoi. This visit helps a westerner to understand the importance of Ho Chi Minh to the Vietnamese people. Building modelled on Lincoln memorial in Washington but with the embalmed body of the leader inside in place of a statue.
Big. The mausoleum is a very large edifice to the leader of the war. We never went in but the grounds and square are worth a look see.

He was there. Was really surprised to actually see the body. Heavily guarded and serious sight but very interesting. He is/was so important to this country, interesting history. This complex has the palace and his stilt house where he spent a lot to time. Go early, it gets crowded. Worth visiting.

Interesting experience . Strange but interesting experience. Most of the visitors are Vietnamese and it is a bizarrely popular thing to make this pilgrimage to see an embalmed body. Glad to have been but not sure what to say about it

Worth a visit. I never miss a chance to see the embalmed body of a historical leader . After the solemn walk though the mausoleum (the guards push you along to keep you moving, and no talking allowed), you can visit a couple of the homes in which he lived.

worth a visit. Interesting to see for the scope it offers and the reverence the Vietnamese feel for this man. We didn't go in the mausoleum but the grounds around it are lovely including the simple house he lived in.

See the flag ceremony!. Everyday in the morning and evening there is a flag ceremony at Ba Dinh Square here. It's amazing to see the dedication and respect of the soldiers as they raise and lower the flag each day.

A spectacular Legend. We went to this Mausoleum during the change of guards. The way the guards do their parade and change guards is a must watch. The park is grandeur and it reinforces the contribution Ho Chi Minh had had in Vietnam. Highly recommended place to visit.

Come early to get inside. I probably would give this a better rating if we had been able to get inside. The visiting hours are early plus there are long lines so our tour group only got to see it from several hundred feet away.

A Must See in Hanoi. If a traveler enjoys learn job about a people's and a nation's history this site is worth the time. A guided tour, if possible, is most helpful. There's also a changing of the guard every hour and although small in scale is not to be missed.

Eye Opener. Not a bad place to see in Vietnam, but be warned that if you dare step over the white lines on the floor surrounding the Mausoleum, be prepared to be confronted by armed guards that "Will" shoot you! Also do not try to take photos of the guards dressed in white that guard the Mausoleum. The body of Ho Chi Minh is transported to Germany every year to be embalmed to preserve him. We went 23rd April - 3rd May. The 30th April was the 40 year liberation of Saigon (Now called Ho Chi Minh) so that may be why his body was not there, but check before you go!
Historic. Grand, historic, really gives a sense of the scope of Uncle Ho's significance to the country. A very proud and confident memorial, definitely must be seen if you visit Hanoi.
Nothing special. Not very interesting, not much to see. Go there if you are really interested in history, otherwise you don't miss much.

An unique experience . The mausoleum and the corpse of Ho Chi Min are both well preserved and an interesting view. Remember to go early in the morning as the last entrance is at 10:30 in the morning! One of the things that is most striking is the ambience of the whole tour... This goes beyond the normal silence and demeanour that one should respect in front of a famous figure to border repression. You must stand for about 600-700 meters in a straight line, silent, slowly moving towards the mausoleum in a huge plaza, and even hands in the pockets are not allowed. Every 50-100 meters there's an armed guard to make sure that the rules are followed. It is an interesting visit and one you should take if not for the experience alone. In the same area you can go and see the one pillar Pagoda, Ho Chi Min Museum and the presidential Palace.
flag. go early to see the changing of the guard at 6 am its amazing flag raising get a tuk tuk to it you will not be disappointed the 100 soldiers all in white and huge flag

Meet President Ho Chi Minh. It is absolutely amazing to see how well preserved his body is and how much the local people revere him. Till the break up of USSR, understand his body used to be taken to Moscow for restoration every year. Now, the Russians get here and do the same and the Mausoleum is closed for a few months during that period. His body is preserved the way it is because the Vietnamese wanted him amongst them forever, though he wanted to be cremated.

Time it well to witness the changing of the guard. This imposing structure is closed off to traffic with just pedestrians permitted to walk through the forecourt area.I managed to time my visit well to see the changing of the guard. It was all done very silently probably so as not to disturb Ho Chi Minh.The Mausoleum was closed on the day I visited, however if you are visiting, respectful clothing is required and leave the cameras and phones in your pocket (and on silent).

Respectful Place. Visited yesterday and found it a humbly experience. I felt a sense of honour and dignity - only opened 2-3 hours in the morning, I think from 9am best to get there at 10am. Wear long pants and covered shoulders. No singlets or shorts.Need to walk in twos and be quiet. Only a short time in the actual mausoleum walking past Ho Chi Ming on 3 sides. Cameras and large bags to be checked on and picked up a end.

Still no actual Uncle ho. No chance of seeing the actual embalmed body of the late uncle Ho BUT the museum of his life gives you an opportunity of seeing the liberation struggle from a much longer Vietnamese perspective

Interesting insight into Viet Nam culture. Ho Chi Minh was a modest man who reportedly requested cremation, and did not want a showy mausoleum. However, the people continually flow into the mausoleum to pay their respects, demonstrating their continued devotion to HCM. The exterior is decidedly stately and imposing, and the mood inside is quiet and respectful. HCM lies in a glass case. Military guards keep visitors moving and prevent crowds and bottlenecks.For those with mobility issues, note that there are stairs (and no elevator alternative that I could see).
Great for a photo, not much else to do. Good place to visit on a sunny/cloudy day. One of the few places in Hanoi with open spaces and a large garden.
Spacious . Very grand feeling when you are at the mausoleum.Feel like you are at the China's People Square! Be prepared to walk long distance. Bring umbrella, wear cap for shades

Where body of Ho Chi Minh is kept. Built to remember the contributions of "uncle Ho", as locals call him, the Mausoleum houses the body of Ho Chi Minh, preserved for people to pay respect. There is security check before entry, which prohibits water bottles and large bags. Use of cameras and phones are not allowed in the area also.
highlight in visiting Hanoi. Well Worth visiting despite being a difficult place to get into. Studying of the history behind it would be very helpful since all of the information are in Vietnamese.

Not What Uncle Ho Wanted. It is interesting that Ho Chi Minh wanted to be cremated and his ashes scattered in the north, south and center of Vietnam. So a huge mausoleum is not what he would have wanted. Having said that the respect and reverence the Vietnamese have for Uncle Ho [as they call him] is not duplicated anywhere that I know. It is somber walking past his remains and when you consider he died in 1969, they have been well preserved.
Huge building not very accessible. Under the hard sun of Vietnam, this huge building of great significance. Be careful when walking around, since not possible to step in the close surrounding.

Sombre, interesting and impressive. Well organised, line appears long but moves really quickly. Can only take purses and phones through, but bag hold area and camera hold area is safe and well organised.
Must go to house, cars etc before leaving to collect bags or else have to queue through mausoleum again!

Go with a guide. We visited the grounds and the Mausoleum with a private tour guide, which I found extremely helpful in understanding context and what we were looking at. Although there were placards placed around the area, we found having a guide with us to provide additional background made it an educational and enjoyable experience. The lines to view Ho Chi Minh were long, but moved along without a lot of waiting (you keep walking slowly the entire time). The homes, pagodas, and gardens are all worth seeing, but you dont need more than an hour or two here, tops.

Interesting experience . Included in Hanoi day tour - no cameras allowed on person when visiting the mausoleum. Very strict with many guards to ensure you walk two by two as you make your way through the gardens and walkways to to mausoleum. No talking allowed when you enter the mausoleum as everyone makes respectful silence as you view the very real dead body - died 1969!!!

Fake?. I'm sorry but I don't believe its really him inside! Interesting to see how the locals revere him so much but I found the security staff in the entire complex rude and obnoxious. Also had to wait in line for quite some time and had to basically leave everything on my person in a locker.

Long wait but really cool. We had to wait for over an hour in the heat so bring sunscreen, hat and umbrella if it's a sunny day. Also you need to be covered up so no shoulders showing and cover the knees too. The walk around Ho Chi Minh was surreal. It was really amazing. Must see for sure.
attractive. it is a Memorial monument for Ho chi minh in a great square in Hanoi city near state area and Foreign Embassies

Must visit, dress modestly & go after 10am. There is Uncle Ho i.e. Ho Chi Minh everywhere in Hanoi, in temples, in many of it's Museums, in art and paintings, in people's homes and hearts. So for me, personally, it was great to see the nation's hero laid there. Yes, we have to dress modestly, wearing shorts is a no-no. U have to deposit ur cameras, not phones. Phones are allowed but obviously clicking pictures isn't allowed. Dont go early morning rather go after 10am, u wont find long queue at this time.
Peaceful & Quite Beautiful. surprisingly both very beautiful and peaceful.interesting history to research or learn about.not very crowded, excellent upkeep.

Unique experience. We visited as part of a city tour. The entrance procedure was easy and hassle free. Fortunately we both wore trousers and long sleeves although pants below the knee were allowed. Lots of staff checking that clothing was appropriate but 1 visitor was turned back part way due to his above knee shorts. Que looked long but was free flowing and quick. Less than 15 mins walking to actual resting place of Uncle Ho. A unique experience esp. given the significance the Vietnamese place on Uncle. My handbag and small camera were allowed through security and photos permitted after exiting Uncles' building. Enjoyed tour of his home and other areas of the complex.

No cue if you arrive after 10 am. We arrived quit late at the Mausoleum. But this was not that bad. Because we didn't have to wait to enter the mausoleum. There was no cue. The lady at the ticket office said this was because most of the people arrive early in the morning. So I would recommend to enjoy your breakfast a little longer and go afterwards. It is an experience to see Ho Chi Minh. So if you are in Hanoi. You have to visit the Mausoleum.

A revered leader still. The mausoleum is only open to the public in the mornings, and when we got there at 9, the queues stretched as far as eye could see. This is the first attraction in Hanoi we have visited where locals outnumbered tourists. Judging by the numbers of school parties, this visit is part of the curriculum! The closer we approached the mausoleum, the more officious became the behaviour of the guards. One of us had our hands in our pockets, to be told by a guard (who looked all of 18 years) to 'put your hands down'! Interesting sights while waiting in the queue included white-uniformed guards goose stepping, a school band striking up followed by the rest of the school party emulating the guards in goose stepping. Until then, we hadn't felt the communist regime in Hanoi. After an hour of queuing, we were treated to a 5-second glimpse of the great leader as the queue snaked round his well-preserved body. You decide if it's worth it.

Visit with A Great Degree of Reverance. I have visited the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum now more than 5 times as I escort friends visiting from the USA. I escort them so they understand the particular requirements that are meant to show respect to a man for which the Vietnamese and the world have great reverence. No shorts or sleeveless shirts, jeans, or inappropriate dress....when you go....please be respectful.
Something very different from your usual Hanoi. Something you will not get to see too often. The line is long but goes really fast. Plenty great photo opportunities outside.

Not a wax figure!. We were unable to view the Mausoleum last year as Uncle Ho was in Russia. Couldn't miss it this year tho when we knew he was in Hanoi. Well organised except for the collection of bag at the end. Cameras and bags need to be left at check points, no issues with safety. The line up was long but moved quickly, surrounded by armed guards who keep a close eye on everyone (so no sudden moves). A solemn occasion, respect of the Viet leader is required. I felt quite moved by the ability to see Uncle Ho in the flesh.

Long queue for a short glimpse.... ... but still worth seeing. Be there early in the morning, and don't give up just because of the long queue. People are rather pushed through, everything is well organised. We were there at the time of opening (8am in winter), briefly after his return from Russia, with already well over 1000 people in front of us and school classes and VIPs being somehow prioritised - still we were face-to-face with Ho Chi Min within less than an hour.Backpacks and larger cameras (SLRs) need to be stored, smaller cams and mobile phones can be taken along, but must not be used.

Well preserved. Must visit. . Queue from behind the complex to enter the security area where large bags and valuables are left. Then short walk to front of mausoleum, escorted past guards in white uniform and into the dark mausoleum. Uncle Ho is very well preserved, watch the Vietnamese pay their respects to him as you shuffle through very quickly. The rest of the complex is interesting for insight into his life. Only open from 8-11am (arrive well before 11) and closed on Mondays.

Mausoleum guided tour. Interesting visit. Starts with security(no cameras, turn off mobiles). Then without guide put u a dirt of school crocodile (two abreast) to walk to the mausoleum. Inside is quiet and cold. HCM lies embalmed and in about 90 seconds you walk around 3 sides and out again. Then back with our guide we toured the huge site - with HCM's modest house, his bomb shelter, the single pole pagoda etc. I guess 2 hours in all and worth it bra uses our guide was knowledgeable.

Amazing. The respect that the Vietnamese people show to this man was and is still amazing. Not allowed to take photo's inside the mausoleum but free outside. The surroundings are very nice and packed with tourists. Wel worth a trip.

Interesting to see. To see the guards and the sight itself this is worth some time. We walked a long way under a covered walkway so this could get crowded I guess. It was not crowded the day we were there so it was just a lot of walking. Seeing the guards marching in their white uniforms was the most interesting part for me.
impresive. interesting building with interesting story, however, it was closed on that day, so we couldn't visit inside

Strangely affecting. We went on a Saturday morning and although the queue looked long it moved along quite steadily. The practicalities of security checks and the taking away and returning of cameras is all very well managed. Local people made up the majority of the visitors and there is no doubting the reverence which the Vietnamese people have for their former leader - some were visibly moved as our bit of the queue shuffled in and out of the chamber where Ho Chi Minh's body lay. Afterwards you can go and take photos of the building from the wide boulevard and then most people seem to carry on the the Presidential Palace grounds to see Ho Chi Minh's house and walk round a small lake. This was pleasant enough but there were too many people to enjoy it properly.

Interesting from an historical standpoint. It was interesting watching the guards marching. The gardens and plantings are nice. Ho Chi Minh's photo is on everything in Vietnam so to see his mausoleum added more understanding into the citizens feeling for this emperer. The grounds are sectioned off and the ground concreted for a large distance, probably for formal gatherings. Again our guide had little to tell us about this so it's difficult for me to share more.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The visit was very well organised. We were told from the beginning that cameras should not be carried in there and mobile phones should be on silent. The body is really well kept and definitely worth a visit.

See the symbol of the county. Like a Disneyland for the communist poster boy on most pictures and all the currency, this is a supremely fascinating experience. The hours are not typical, so make sure you check those ahead of time. I did not experience much of a wait, but you do get ushered in through a decorated queue with music playing. Guards then lead your small group up to the mausoleum. You go up a few sets of stairs and turn the corner and there he is. The guy on all your dong. He's guarded heavily by guards in white, neatly pressed uniforms. They don't tolerate much in ole Ho's presence---not even crossing your arms. As for Ho, he glows as if he just came out of a radioactive spray tan booth. The Vietnam and communinst flags proudly hang behind him. This is a supremely odd experience and one that I absolutely loved. When you are done, you are free to roam Ho Chi Land and see several other related attractions. This should be a must do in Hanoi.
See Ho Chi Min's preserved body. See Ho Chi Min's preserved body.. It shows the country's respect for him. Free entrance and lot of walking. Many attractions in vicinity.

A must do but get there early. We were advised to get there early and made it at 9 to find huge queues . It was quite a wait and you filed past Ho pretty fast but I suppose you can't go to Hanoi without doing it. We did notice the queue was shorter around 10.30 but then they close at 11 so you won't have long.So get there early to avoid big queues.The price goes up on 1sT December from 25000 to 40000 for us foriegners for the Presidential palace. You can't go in the palace but there are some other things to see like the house on stilts.Free to see Ho

Well organized.. The Mausoleum and grounds were great to see. But in the cultural context, it was most amazing to see the locals visiting and paying their respects to Ho Chi Minh. Some were crying at the sight of him. He is definitly revered and loved more in the north than in the south. Very fitting his Mausoleum is in Hanoi. Definitely a place to visit while in the city.
Closed Mondays. MISSED OUT.....Closed Mondays. Outside is immaculate and surrounded by guards around the clock. Sorry we missed this opportunity. Next time we will visit on another day.

History by the ton. Hanoi is a charming city with lots of history. Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum is not one of the charming highlights. It is cold and sterile, Soviet architecture at its best (or worse). Too much other good stuff to see to spend too much time here, including Ho's home which is interesting.

See it in person. Some things you hear about but never see. This is one of those places that I have finally seen. It's definitely worth the visit if you are in Hanoi. Don't get confused and think it's in Ho Chi Minh (Saigon)
This is a must see.. You can only view the body before 10.00 a.m. and there will be big queues. The area around is also very impressive. Beautifully trimmed trees and bushes and a huge plaza

Eerie but fascinating. A conveyor of tourists whisks you past the body of Ho Chi Minh however the reverence for this man is touching and retains a quiet air of dignity. A fascinating insight inside the psyche of the party. Do cover arms and legs to ensure entry.

You will see Ho Chi Minh!. The queue for this was enormous and we waited for about 30 mins while the guards were doing something. It was hot and water was not allowed. All you see is a body laid out! Would never have come had I realised what it was.

Is it really him. The father of Communist Vietnam. Many local pay their respect to him daily as well as a tourist site. The mausoleum is fashioned after Lenin’s in Moscow, using the same method of preservation. The body of Ho Chi Minh looked really good, one may even wonder if it is just a plastic model. A must visit.

Interesting for a short visit. From the minute you enter the gates you are ushered in a double line (and don't even think of getting out of that double line!) along a winding path and through the mausoleum to view the body of Ho Chi Minh. There is no talking, no photography...just keep moving in double file. Other than that, there's not much to see but viewing the body is worth the trip. And don't be discouraged by a long line. It moves fairly quickly.

Very cool. This was a very memorable visit. The line seems really long when you get there, but it moves quickly. We went early and we were still in line from the street, but it took less than an hour to get in to see him.

Solemn reminder that local heroes are loved.. Be sure to devote several hours to see all there is to see here. Do not walk on the sidewalk and remember that Uncle Ho is much beloved.While Communism is evident in the flags, the smiles on the people and the lack of tension in the guards made this a far more enjoyable experience than Beijing. Do not misunderstand; these guards were serious and took their duty seriously. But. It was no more than you would see at major political locations elsewhere in the world, and far less anxiety-ridden than our last trip to Beijing.Perhaps my favorite part was enjoying the many groups of school children visiting Ho Chi Minh's residence area with their teachers. As a teacher, it is reassuring to see that we all look the same when we take children on field trips. More importantly, there is a unifying effect of smiles, waves, and "Hello!" repeated again, again, and again. The world could use a team of 5-year-old ambassadors.The museum is top-notch, and while it was difficult at times--given the history between the USA and Vietnam--the artistic nature of many of the areas was quite enjoyable.
Remember, this is in Hanoi. This place located in Hanoi, not in Ho chi minh, this is the memorial place to vietnam founding fathers, nice place, clean and easy to acces, 2 km from hanoi old town
Do visit. Incredible what this man achieved in his lifetime its a visit worth queuing.....try getting the last tickets as your not rushed through as much!
Impressive specially at night time. Myst see in Hamoi especially in the night time with all the lights on .. nice park around and very safe as full of police and nice people chatting walking ......

A must in Vietnam . If you've read anything about Vietnamese history, then you know Ho Chi Minh was, and still is, the father of all the Vietnamese people. That's why you should visit the Mausoleum and see his embalmed body, but make sure to take the time to also see the Ho Chi Minh museum to see how much he did for this country.The whole complex takes about 1,5-2 hours to see, including a look at the museum. Go before lunch to avoid the crowds. Every year for some time the body is sent to Russia, so look it up before you go. You can visit the Complex anyway, but to see Ho Chi Minh really takes it to another level.

Great place. A lot of history to be learnt, a must-see while in Hanoi. We loved the beautiful garden as well. The number of guards resembles the royal guard in London! :)Be aware that the place opens only from 7.30-10.30am.

Good to see. Good to see to understand the history of the country. Interesting how they copied the Soviet cult of personality from the Soviet Union. How they work you up with singing and videos on your way there
A Hero. I heard about him by someone local in here, read a little bit about his history. A big hero , absolutely Vietnamese so pround of him!

Value history. Fresh air, a place not to be missed while in Hanoi. It contains a lot of historical value, where the Declaration of Independence read by country Vietnam, which is also the resting place of President Ho Chi Minh great here with the morning flag-raising ceremony and lowering of the flag at the evening

A bizzare, but a must-do attraction. Follow the rules, don't stick out. A very bizarre experience, but is a must do when in Hanoi. A tip - don't stick out, follow the rules. We made a mistake of getting out of the queue near the entrance as we were meeting a tour guide on the opposite side. To our surprise we were not allowed back in, in fact, we were not allowed to cross the road back again unless we went through the security procedures again - very rigid and tight security, but it did add to the whole experience!Also, no hats or glasses, no talking while in the Mausoleum and always keep walking, stopping is not allowed. Also, it takes time for eyes to adapt to the dark exterior, so wear sunglasses up to the entry point.

A must visit place. Unfortunately this place is open only between 7.30-10.30AM, but outer visit is anytime. Arrived late so unable to go in. Nice and big buildings, many guards with lines to control the way of walking. Big garden with nice flowers and a huge flag.

Surreal: worth a visit. A most singular and surreal experience: queued for a while to be let into the complex of yellow buildings and open space, which is blocked off from the mad traffic and so unnaturally quiet for Hanoi. Our line of locals and tourists then walked almost in single file march, on the road rather than the pavement, up to the mausoleum, the red carpeted entrance up to the concrete block holding it flanked by white uniformed guards, who grimly suggest you remove your sunglasses and whatnot. Once inside and into the sudden darkened blast of Aircon, still in single file or two abreast and in complete silence, we proceeded round short right angles of concrete stairs, a guard on every corner, until reaching the kernel of the building and shuffling round the u-shaped mezzanine where Ho lay in his sarcophagus highlighted under dimmed lights, flanked by four guards again - three very serious and one looking like he was about to corpse (no pun intended). Ho's tidy beard was in order and I suppose he was as immaculate as any preserved head of state might be. Apparently he's sent off to Russia for two months each year to have an oil change of his Soviet strength formaldehyde. It was a bit of a relief to exit and return to normal. We loitered outside to get our camera back (you hand them in, bagged up) as the guards trickled out of the building after the tourists. They formed up with their bayoneted rifles and marched off. I swear each one was wearing bright white hunter wellies. You then continue around the complex - in our case, shortly before it closed for lunchtime, the regimented feeling not abated by the slow pursuit of a uniformed type tapping his watch as we peered into the austere rooms Ho inhabited by his fountained fish pond, stilt house and small collection of old cars.

Should be there once time in Hanoi. Should visit this place when you arrive in Hanoi to see the honor, love of people to Ho Chi Minh - Uncle Ho, called by Vietnamese people. The mausoleum with other places in Ho Chi Minh complex ( stilt house, Ho Chi Minh museum, one Pillar Pagoda) are worth to visit. Have a learn about Ho Chi Minh, he devoted his life for Vietnam. So proud. Should participate a ceremony in the morning (raising flag) at 6.00 am or in the evening (lowering flag) at 9.00 pm.

Take of your specs & hat! . It was quite interesting. At the entrance you have to leave your bag, backpack, day packs etc. Take out your valuables like cameras & money then you queue up. They will give you a small hand bag with a camera logo outside. You can put your other valuables in here. They give you a ticket # for the bag. Further in, there is another counter where you have to leave this bag because cameras & cellphones are not allowed.Once you're queued up in two lines the leader will take you while other guards direct you which way to go. Before entering remove your sunglass because you will get told off to remove it. If you make a notice inside you will get told off. As you walk in the tomb there is no pausing or stopping so you look as you go. Once you've finished this go through the presidential palace then finish picking up your valuables & bags. As this point you can access the front part of the tomb from walking outside the street. Turn left on this particular street, you won't miss it because it's a wide street & is barricaded from vehicles... walk the length of this street.If you finished early then you can see other groups go through it & you can now take photos from the other side of this street. You'll encounter guards matching of as well.
Pleasantly surprised. Had no idea what we were walking into, but it was really cool. Basically a formal viewing of Ho Chi Minh's dead body...

Lesson in history. Go early as the queues can be quite long. They open daily except on Mondays from 8 am & closes at 11:30 am. There's a strict dress code, No wearing of shorts & sleeveless shirts or blouse & no slippers. Just bring a small bag or you will be asked to leave them at the storage counter, no backpacks. No pictures allowed, so keep your cameras & celphones in your bags or you will be asked to leave them at the storage counter. There is the presidential palace area/grounds, pond, mango path, trellis, house of Ho Chi Minh, stilt house & one pillar pagoda. Take time to go over their brochures as you might miss some of the important places. The Ho Chi Minh museum is also within the area & closes at 12 noon. Overall a good tour & lesson in history.
Somber experience. Although there were long queues, we were ushered in with efficiency. It was a somber experience, much similar to visiting Lenin.

Not open in October & November. We visited the mausoleum, but as it was 3rd November, it wasn't due to open til the 5th, so we could only walk by the outside. Its very impressive & reminded me of Tianamen square in China.

A visit to Ho Che minh mausoleom. This is my first time i entered inside the grave ! The soldiers or policemen were very impressive standing near the grave! Our guide told us that the body of HCM just returned from russia!! I was shocked to see HCM lying there!!
Bac Ho Mausoleum. We just see it from the outside. The place was packed with people. Hot and long line waiting. Very interesting sight.

Visit Uncle Ho Chi Minh. Security is very tight. You cannot bring camera inside of the mausoleum. You have to remove spectacle prior to entering the mausoleum. Inside the mausoleum, you can see Uncle Ho's preserved body inside a glass coffin. Well, I honestly don't know if it is the real Mr Ho Chi Minh but this is what they claimed. Such a unique experience to see a well preserved body with your own eyes.

Ho Chi Minh - didnt look real!. Be prepared to walk for at least 3 kilometres principally in the sun from start to finish of this attraction. Ho Chin Minh's guards marshall all of the visitors and have strict rules which are enforced at the sight. No bare arms, knees to be covered for both men and women, there was a significant delay waiting for people to stream past Ho CHi MInh in his air conditioned room. The guards must be changed on a regular basis and they perform a 'changing of the guards' every 2 hours (May be less often). The day we went it was very hot, some of the walkways at the start of the exhibit are covered but once you leave this area it is out in the hot sun. Worth the visit, the grounds around the exhibit are well maintained. Go to hear the history about the man and his country

Always check the opening days. I missed out because I failed to check when it was open, I still really enjoyed walking around the grounds though."Opening hours: Everyday except for Monday and Friday, from 8:00-11:30 and from 14:00-16:30"

Great place to see. Living in Hanoi for some time I always enjoyed my drive home past Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Its very well kept and clean and the guards are very interesting. Unfortunately never went inside, but heard good things about it
Cool to see, not much to do. We made a point of visiting the mausoleum, though the only thing to do really is to take pictures and walk around. I recommend visiting the museum that's very close by.
..... Um it was interesting to see the guards and the muselueum. The line was quick. I had to wear long shorts as im a female. No sunglasses or hads in pockets. Very tourisy.

A must if you visit Hanoi. We visited on November 11, 2015. Entry fee was waived. It's a very impressive place. Very large and cold building where Ho Chi Min lays very well preserved. You walk though in double lines, no stopping, no talking and get an up close view of him resting. It's surreal, don't miss it

A huge place. It was an awfully hot morning or perhaps I should say our first real day in Hanoi hence the heat hitting us. Ho Chi Mimh body was away in Russia so we didn't have to queue for that but visited the surrounding gardens and buildings and that was interesting.

Communist Relic. Very often closed to the public.
Big, ugly crate, but still impressive somehow.
Ho Chi Minh did NOT want to be preserved like this.
Go have a look if you are in the neighborhood - great example of person-worship gone over the top.
Lang Bac Ho. He's Vietnam's president and hero. he's very famous on the world , very respect him. Let's me known more about Vietnam history.

Paying tribute. I was a little confused with the line up system within this site, I arrived at 10:45 and joined a queue of people and just followed them in. We had our bags and cameras held restricted and I thought that was a little weird, it was until we arrive in front of the mausoleum I realized that we were entering into the mausoleum and seeing Mr Ho Chi Minh's body. We were asked to line up and keep in silence. This is similar to the visit to the Kim Il Sung mausoleum but with less strict. Keep in mind that this place only opens until 11am.
Interesting. Have to go there if you have time to see how the Vietnamese respect uncle Ho. Was very serious but fun being with the locals.
