A hghlight in Hanoi. We were delighted to find that Uncle Ho had just returned from being "refreshed" in Moscow. We were sure that we were going to miss him as he is usually not in Hanoi for two weeks in the Autumn. He had just arrived 5 days earlier. We were very impressed with the organization of the Express visit and happy not to have to wait in along queue in all the heat and humidity. It was a quick visit and we all followed the rules for a respectful visit. This national icon appeared very life-like even though we knew that his countenance was made of wax.
Fascinating. Best time to visit ids at 6am when they play the national anthem and do the changing of the guard and people pay homage to their liberator and leader Ho Chi Minh

enormous complex built against his will. the complex is huge, full of police that will tell you to walk in line. you should be full covered by dresses, keep your arms on body side, show full respect, leave your belongings several times to secutiry people that will return you in other places not well specified. in the complex you will find ho chi minh body, his office, his house, a museum about him and many pagodas. everithing looks very solemn, but a little bit out of the sense of a comunist revolution`s sense....maybe i misundestood.....i would suggest to visit this place only if you like to see dead bodies or if you are for some reason very very attached to Ho Chi Minh.

Very beautiful and dignified. Fresh air, simple and dignified, we heard a lot about the great President of the nation Vietnam, but did not expect him back so simple, it also contains the history of the nation Vietnam

Looked like a Madamme Tussauds stunt double. I have seen Lenin in Moscow, couldn't be bothered to queue in Beijing to see the main man, but glad we came to see this old boy, who looks really well, if you know what I mean.The area around is impressive and you do, quite rightly need to be respectful in terms of dress and behaviour.if you haven't seen anything like this before, then certainly would recommend.

Just another photo opportunity.... This is one of those places that take about 20mins to get to via taxi if you're staying in near the old town. A few places to visit near it too- all can be done in half a day. To be honest, this is one of those attractions that requires 5mins to take photos and then just move on. But, it is an important structure of history- so you should probably visit.

Check first if it's open to the public or not. The mausoleum was closed to the public when we visited due to renovations. We only saw it from afar behind the ropes. Better to check first whether or not the mausoleum is open to the public before visiting. Also there is a specific time for visiting the mausoleum, even if viewing it from the outside. When it was nearly 12 noon, the guards did not anymore allow us go near the mausoleum. Anyhow, there are other sights within the vicinity to visit like the One Pillar Pagoda or the museum. The Presidential Palace (not open to the public but can seen from behind the gates) is also a short walk away.
The place to visit. Oncle Ho reminds you the strength of the vietnamese people to get freedom and to build the new Vietnam...
Hanoi. Unfortunately the day we visited - Wednesday, it was not open but have to say it was very impressive.
Mausoleum a solum place. Definitely worth finding some time to see the father of modern Vietnam. Everyone is very respectful and worth the wait in the line

Memories after a wait in the sun. Memories of a visit to Lenin's Mausoleum in Moscow nearly 50 years ago came flooding back as we filed past Ho Chi Minh's mummified body. The same sense of unreality was there, too. But, as with Russia, the queues testify to an abiding interest and respect from the nation. It was strange, then, to be told that Ho had not wanted this expecting cremation instead. We were also treated to the sight of wreath laying the Viet army way.Opening hours are limited and we had to wait in line, first in a covered walkway where we were regaled with patriot singing, and then in the beating sun. So take a hat. It was interesting though to see crowds of youngsters given priority to see the former leader.
Long wait. You spend at least an hour waiting then only have very little time seeing things inside the mausoleum. I will not come there again.
Visit early, dress accordingly. Make sure to visit before 11am, as it closes after then. Wear trousers (men) and don't show shoulders (women). No photos allowed.

A quirky attraction/experience!. Visiting the embalmed body of "Uncle Ho" must be on the top ten "weird things to do in Asia" list. We had read that in November the mausoleum would be closed as the body is taken to Russia for "maintenance" so we were surprised to find it open (on 10 Nov). The line of people moves quickly as everyone files in to the building, up the stairs and past the body. It was quite creepy, but interesting to see all the same. After the mausoleum, you can visit the museum, Uncle Ho's used cars and stilt house.
Ho chỉ Minh Mausoleum. Visited the Ho Chỉ Minh Mausoleum and well keep area . Must visit when you are in Hanoi.quite crowded.

Seen this on TV during the war period.. Designed to impress I have seen on TV tanks and troops marching past Ho Chi Min during his reign here.Big wide spaces and parks. A bit over the top but clearly it worked as this place would impress used as it was during the war with rallying support for the high and almighty.

Closed in October. My husband and I visited the outside of the mausoleum as it is closed from September to the end of the year. We had an excellent guide who told us the history of Ho Chi Minh which made it very interesting.
Interesting. I liked it but only need to see it once. Inside there is Ho Chi Minh's mummified body. Very regulated as well.
Striking. A very big building with numerous ceremonial guards marching up and down looking very serious. Did not get inside (as don't think you can) only on special occasions!
Must visit while in Hanoi. Is a destination not to be missed, Memorial President Ho Chi Minh is a dignified, beautiful and preserved many historic value

The historical monument. This is my first destination on the city tour. My tour guide Mr D explained well and concise about the history of Vietnam and this monument. It might not be interesting but has its valuable historical value.

Worthwhile Vist. My guide was very resourceful and she was able to get me head of the line status. The first sensation is freezing blast of cold air from the over active air conditioning unit. a short stroll inside the mausoleum leads to the central chamber. The chairman's preserved body is exhibited under fast food heat lamps. The orange glow makes one feel as if the Chairman could sit up at any time. An interesting note: The Chairman's corpse is fitted out in a summer wardrobe and a winter wardrobe! Just like a hindu temple where the divinity is dressed in an ever changing wardrobe.

Amazing Experience for tourists and locals. no cameras, no shorts, no touching, no talking - - - if you can abide by these rules for the short period of time you're inside the building, you'll be fine. Going to see Uncle Ho is an experience that every tourist should have. Watching the reverence of the Vietnamese people in line around you shows how much respect they have for Ho Chi Minh. For me, the mausoleum was an emotional place. And the area surrounding shouldn't be missed either. It shows you what a humble man Uncle Ho was and gives you a glimpse into his simple life --- for a dollar. Ho Chi Minh is gone during winter months for restoration - so do a bit of research before you go. The website isn't really helpful with that. Just check Tripadvisor and see if there are angry posts from people saying he's gone!

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Even though the body of Ho Chi Minh was in Russia being refurbished, the visit here was impressive. Absolutely beautiful building and setting, guarded 24 hours a day by handsome young men in uniform. Recommend.

Sadly closed on the day of our visit. Avoid Friday and Monday and go before 09:00 am as it closes at 10:00. The pagoda and house was also closed due to a visit being made by the Chinese President but is normally open for the whole day (visit after the Mausoleum).

Great to visit. Unfortunately this was closed due to refurbishment but we could view externally, beware you are not supposed to take photos of the guards and you are not allowed to walk on the pavements! Guards shout at you! Stay on the correct side of the barrier!

A historic landmark!. We have just returned from our visit to Vietnam and were very disappointed on our day tour of Hanoi to be told, the Mausoleum is closed for yearly maintenance. So anyone travelling to Vietnam end of September - end of November be aware you can only view the building form the outside.It is a very simple but impressive piece of architecture, even though you are told, Ho Chi Minh did not want to be interred there.A historic landmark for the Vietnamese people.
Nice. Unable to enter as the mausoleum was closed for maintenance. Walked around the area outside which was fascinating in itself.

A piece of history. Although we visited at a time when 'Uncle Ho' cannot be viewed, we were still blown away by this mausoleum. The street in front is closed to traffic and the building faces the new Parliament buildings across the road from the mausoleum. The Presidential Place next door is certainly a must see as well. The number of tourists both foreign and domestic was amazing.Don't miss it!

A Must on any Hanoi Tour. Unfortunately we could bot get inside, as it was closed to to yearly maintenance. According to our guide, they close it every year early September until some time in November. This year they say it can go until the end of the month. However unless you want to see a coffin with the Body of Ho Chi Minh, there is not much more to see. It is more to pay respect to a great man, who was a gifted and yet very humble leader. If it had gone according to his own wishes, the Mausoleum never had been built. - the well kept garden, his living Quarter, all in all, definitely worth a visit. Anyway in the eyes of every Vietnamese, a MUST! The general situation could be improved if reliable Information about the daily openings, yearly closing etc. were available!

Impressive...but. A visit to the Mausoleum was part of our city tour. As impressive as the building was unfortunately at the time of our visit the Mausoleum was closed for its annual restoration.However we were still able to witness the changing of the guard at the entrance which was good fun. Note check visit times if you want to see inside.

See Uncle Ho in his glass coffin. We were on tour with tickets arranged by guide, on spec may experience long lines at weekends. It was not a creepy sight to see him, impressive with guard of honor, Vietnamese rever him.
Must see . Must see in Hanoi. Such a good experience. You should also visit the presidential residences while your there.

Worth a visit. visiting the Mausoleum gave me the visceral experience of how much the vaulted leader is respected by the people of Viet Nam. It was worth learning about this beloved leader because of the influence he had in supporting his people. Much respect

A fitting tribute if a little ostentatious! . He was actually a simple man who never wanted this level of tribute. That said it is a fitting way to remember a great leader who managed to defeat the might of the US military and unify his country. The area is nice to walk around with some gardens to the rear that make for an enjoyable few hours.

Must see. The mausoleum had only just reopened its doors for the season and being the first Sunday, it was packed. We were lucky to be on a guided tour and passed most of the queues! Although not what I would call a tourist attraction, it is worth a visit because of the history that Ho Chi Minh left behind him. It's a sombre affair, as you would expect, but worth the effort.
Go early to avoid crowds. We didn't go to the mausoleum but took photos outside . I expect this gets very busy in the summer so go early
Best visited at night. By day, this is a pretty dull experience - a giant concrete edifice. But lit up at night, it has an almost mystical quality.
Mr. Great place to visit worth the take your life in your hands with the traffic. A must see place. A lot of no entry signs about but you must expect that with a communist country

Have to Visit. When we were there, HCM’s body had been removed for refurbishing so the Mausoleum was closed. From the outside, the structure is impressive (must have been designed by the Soviets) if not particularly attractive. If you go to Hanoi, you have to visit this site.

Tep, that's a mausoleum alright. Frankly, unless you are on a tour where they are required to run you through, I'd skip going inside. It is an impressive enough building, but doing the tourist-shuffle through the long corridors just to look at a dead leader of a country that is not yours, well, not how I would choose to spend my time. But I can confirm, he is pretty dead.Might be too creepy for younger children.On the other hand, it is well worth walking by and looking at the monument from the outside (no line!) and then walking on around back to see the much more interesting sights, some Ho related, some not. Ho's modest house, his used cars, the one-pillar pagoda, etc. And a pretty little park with ample shade, not to be sneered at in Vietnam!
A mausoleum. If you saw the picture that's pretty much it. A building to celebrate the memory of uncle Ho. If you are not Vietnamese there is no real point.

mind blowing. very sober experiance, lucky to have a local and his children in the que before we entered the Mausoleum who gave us a running commentary. the main museum could do with more english translation.

Grand. When you do the walking tour of the old city area you have to go a few hundred years north to see this site. You can't help but get that wow feeling when you come upon this large plaza area. Police presence is very much felt but doesn't take away from the experience. No shorts or tank tops allowed inside.
Meh. Closed for cleaning. Outside view only.. Large stone building. Cursory guards out front. A little creepy. Not much to see but it seemed to be a mandatory part of our tour.

Interesting Hanoi highlight. Interesting place to visit although it was closed for restoration when we went so only saw it from the outside but given th almost god like status the Vietnamese people give this man it is interesting to go here and to where he lived just round the corner.

Will make you appreciate Vietnamese history. I knew Ho Chi Minh even before I visited Vietnam but I just came to understand how loved he is by the Vietnamese people when I went to the Ho Chi Minh complex. It's a really large and beautiful place, and inside the grand, imposing building you will get to see Ho Chi Minh. This is truly a must-visit when you go to Hanoi. Don't miss it.

Quite an impressive building. Unfortunately the mausoleum was closed to visitors during our visit, so could only be viewed from outside.....Good to be so close to such a historically important place for most Vietnamese.

Magnificent grounds. I think that this is a must visit site when in Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh had such an impact on Vietnamese history. Even though his body was not on display in order to redo the embalming, it is still a site that must be visited. It is not as impressive as Tiananmen Square, but close. The mausoleum is impressive in it's massive size. The grounds are beautiful. Take the time to accept the crowds and see his houses.

Pay homage. Anyone coming to Hanoi should pay homage to the modern father of this proud and independent society. The grandeur of the mausoleum and grounds stand in stark contrast to the simplicity of Uncle Ho's preferred living space. But hey, he's worth celebrating if you don't mind the long lines and the preserved body of their favorite son (and uncle). There's a lot to take in, although not all is open to non-Vietnamese.

Nothing much to see/do. The place was going through yearly maintenance for 2 months so we couldn't enter the mausoleum. Large empty space around structure which is generally considered to be one of the top 10 ugly structures in the world. I agree. :) Just an uninspiring grey building really. The adjacent presidential palace, uncle Ho's "modest" home etc salvaged the trip's usefulness.

Don't let the long lines of people put you off. The lines are huge, but within 30 mins you are into the Mausoleum. Once you are into the Mausoleum it takes about 30 seconds to walk around Ho Chi Minh and then you are back out again!

visit through the week. I was there on the Thursday and you can walk right in and see Ho Chi Minh laying in state and all the guards around but it is closed Friday to Monday at least it was when I was there

Flag lowering ceremony. I visited with a local friend who took me there at around 8.45pm when the guards come out to lower the flag at 9pm on the dot every evening. There were not many tourists but lots of locals were gathered here, and when it gets close to the time, they are all ushered behind a white line with a few guards standing to ensure that people stay behind the line. Just before 9pm guards march out to ceremonious music to take the flag down. It is all taken very seriously and it is a very grand gesture to occur every night. I believe a similar ceremony takes place every morning to raise the flag too.If you are staying nearby in Hanoi city, it is definitely worth going one evening or maybe in the morning to see how much respect is paid by the locals for this daily event.

Awe Inspiring. Visually this place is stunning - from the buildings in the entire compound right through to the art pieces and sculptures inside the museum. Inside is a mixture of dual language (Vietnamese and English) and Vietnamese only signs and voiceovers, so a guide shouldn't be necessary. If you want to see everything, though, set aside some serious time. We had one hour and ended up just 'skimming' through levels two and three of the museum as we were running out of time.The military guard the site so be sure not to let curiosity get the best of you and stray into any areas that are roped off in the compound (many were closed for cleaning or maintenance whilst we were there). By the way, whilst there is a warning that handbags/ backpacks must be left in lockers before heading into the museum but after going through the metal detectors we were allowed to carry our belongings with us, which we were more comfortable with.

Jaded Review: Where's Ho Chi Minh. We arrived at the Mausoleum early in the morning, not quite sure what to expect. He's embalmed (and has been for awhile), but I don't do well at funerals, so it should've been interesting. Except he wasn't there....As many reviewers note, Ho Chi Minh vacations in Russia for a few months annually, getting some cosmetic work done. We conveniently visited Hanoi while he was MIA. Luckily the Mausoleum is close to several other sights we were planning to see. So we took our customary photographs, laughed that he was absent, and quickly moved on.

Beautiful grounds. I enjoyed walking around these grounds. Unfortunately we got there too late to go inside, so make sure you check the times before you go.I really got a feeling for how loved this man was.

Must do experience.. It is extraordinary to see the young Vietnamese paying their respect to Ho. It is recommended to visit his house as well and see the rather modest living conditions inside the big palace gardens

Take note of their schedules!. This mausoleum opens early with lunch breaks. We came around a few minutes to eleven and we weren't allowed inside. My local guide informed me that all the Vietnamese donated at least a day to help in constructing the museum! They did this to show their love and loyalty to Uncle Ho. Its about a 5-10 minute walk from the Museum, the One Pillar Pagoda and the Presidential Palace. Its best you bring umbrellas or hats because the heat of the sun can be quite harsh.

If you like it overdone. This Mausoleum is a havily guarded plave. The admiration for warlord Ho Chi Min is somewhat frightening. If you like people's admiration for a warlord, please go! It is certainly an expirience you will remember.

No go for uncle Ho. On our recent visit we could not go to see Ho. His resting place was closed. We heard he was undergoing preservation maintance. Also heard the rumour that he gets flown to Moscow to visit the Lenin curators. Not really sure. Mausoleum is a grand structure similar to some German and Russian architectural relics from the past. I am sure if its open, its worth to visit to get a glimps. Definite serious historical value for all history buffs.

Clean and spacious. The square in front of the Mausoleum is spacious but with no attraction. If you are on your way to other sight seeing places around, it's no harm to pay it a short visit. I do not recommend a special trip to it.

Super long queue!!. We went there at about 9AM and the queue was very long until the main entrance gate. There're also side gate which is allowed only tour which have appointment. We don't have time to visit the place. We only manage to take the photos from outside. Be sure that you go early to avoid the long q.

How and Where to Pickle a Great Leader. As a sight for tourism it is nothing great. We choose to visit at the period in time when old Ho Chi Minh was having his annual 'lube and oil change' or more correctly; changing and topping up the Formaldehyde (he specifically wanted to be cremated!). It's still worth a visit and if on a scheduled tour insist on being there on the hour to witness the dramatic and precise changing of the guard, with the soldiers resplendent in the white uniforms. A must see....

Good for a passing visit when you're in the area.. There's really not much to see here - it's just a huge building dedicated to a man that didn't really want all the fuss of it. It's good for a visit while you're taking in surrounding activities like the Ho Chi Minh Museum and Temple of Literature.I didn't make it inside given that there was no obvious entrance (or it might have just been closed?). But I'm not sure silently walking past Ho Chi Minh's body is my idea of fun anyway.

Hanoi's must see historic site. There are two other such similar Mausoleum sites, Lenin in Red Square Moscow and Mao in Tiananmen Square Beijing. Ho Chi Minh's resting place is worth a visit. A leader that wanted Vietnam to be ruled by Vietnamese, unfortunately it took two Indo-China wars to achieve his aim. He died before he saw his dream come true. One must observe total silence, no cameras or bags allowed, so be prepared to leave such items behind in your transport when you view Ho.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It's place beautiful to pray for one of the hero in the world and I highly recommend you should pay a visit there if you go to Hanoi, Vietnam
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It was a very humbling experience to see this mausoleum and one where showing respect to Ho Chi Minh is a must.
Power spot. Be prepared Americans, this is a site for Ho Chi Mien. Lots of love for the founder. Very crowded. Lots of propaganda here. Nothing Anti American but a bit tense.

Closed . Spectular building but closed. Very austere. Would still recommend seeing the outside. But watch the perimeter line you are not able to cross. It's very easy to get to on foot from the old town. No need for transport. Only about a 20 min walk.

grand. HCM is like a god here despite he has passed on. the government has to spend lots of resources (security guards, gardeners, cleaners......) to maintain big areas, museums, palaces, memorial halls that named after him.

Closed when we went there. Check before going.. We were disappointed that we could only see it from the outside right now. It was closed to visitors. Not sure of reason, I think there was some work going on. Took some photos outside it, including of the guards. They didn't look too happy and seemed to be on edge when we did that. The area close by has many tourist attractions such as the one pillar pagoda and the Ho Chi Minh Museum.

Long Lines and Very Crowded. This is a very nice structure, from the outside.The lines to get inside and actually see Ho Chi MInh are very long, and only a limited number of people, at one time, can access the room/chamber where the body is kept.
Not very interesting. You don't see a lot and you probably enjoy the park more afterwards. If you don't have too much time in Hanoi, don't waste it here.

Great day out. The day we went the mausoleum was closed so it's a pity that we didn't get to go in. The place is full of tourist which is expected. The one pillar pagoda is very close to the area. There's a temple there but you can't go in if not appropriate clothes like long pants. There's a fee to go into the museum but worth a visit. You'll spend a good 2 hours there.
great building. did not go inside as it was closed but the building and grounds in the middle of Hanoi is a must to see

Huge. On the day we visited Uncle Ho had been taken to Russia for re-embalming. The Mausoleum is on a grand scale in a wide and open space. I believe you must walk as vehicle access to "the door" is not permitted.

Must see. This Mausoleum that Ho Chi Minh is buried in is a must see attraction in Hanoi. This attraction closed in September and October for restoration. Be sure to check and make sure it's open for visitors.

A real insight into Vietnamese pride. We were lucky enough to be taken around this area by Tung from Vivutravel. His historical knowledge is EXCELLENT and he gave us a real understanding of the complexities of Vietnam's history. This you cannot get from a history book. Thank you Tung!

Looks spooky at night!. Only a few minutes walk from One Pillar Pagoda. I came here at night and was amazed by the spacious plaza around this place. The building also emerges spooky red light from the inner part, which also make it looks like there's something scary inside!

Closed!. The mausoleum is closed until sometime in November, a bit disappointing but the building is still quite interesting. Still worth walking through there and the palace even if you can't go inside.

Chairman Mao on vacation?. This is what our guide told us as the mausoleum was closed. I guess they have some regular maintenance to do. It was interesting to see where he lived and worked. His bomb shelter seemed totally inadequate but then again perhaps he was not really worried!

Worth a visit to the museum even if no viewing. We were there on a day that the Mausoleum was not open (its open for limited days and hours and rightly so considering they're trying to preserve a body). Just the same, the nearby museum is well worth a visit and probably even more interesting. I went in not really knowing much about Ho Chi Minh or who he was and came out learning that he was a very intelligent man who cared a great deal about the common folk and their well being. I gained tremendous knowledge and respect for the man and found the museum interesting with many good displays, photographs and historical items.

Important Memorial. As an important part of Vietnam's history, this memorial to their leader/hero, Ho Chi Minh, is a must-see. Inspired by Lenin's Mausoleum in Russia (except for the Vietnamese element of a sloped roof), the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is located in Ba Dinh Square, one of the nicer areas of Hanoi surrounded by a number of embassies and consulates. The gardens in front separated by wide pathways boast of hundreds of different species of plants native to Vietnam. The Mausoleum was closed when we visited because the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh was flown to Russia for restoration and preservation work. It was a treat watching the changing of the guards at the Mausoleum entrance.

Top5 historical attractions in Hanoi. We just took a walk around mausoleum because at the moment they said its closed from public for 2 months. I think this is the one the places and areas which is worth of visiting. Huge part of the history of Vietnam.
Ho Chi Minh. Well kept and definitely worth a visit if you are in Hanoi. It is not everyones cup of tea to visit a mausoleum but it is an important part of history.

Average. It was closed when we visited. The mausoleum is closed for about 3 months (September to November) every year as the enbalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is flown to Russia for maintenance purposes. Spent about 15 minutes at the location taking pictures outside the mausoleum.

Tourist Spots of Vietnam. This is a very well preserved mausoleum, with plenty of open land in front for the tourists. It should be visited by tourists, since it does give an idea of the history of North Vietnam, and is one of the very well preserved monuments.

Just OK.. The mausoleum is huge and in a nice park area. However it can only be viewed from behind barriers so visitors don't really get to see much other than the huge building and some guards in white uniforms.

Very Nice. It is one of the tourist spots and one of the places we visited during the Hanoi City Tour that we joined. Usually it is about an hour to 2 hours queue to go inside the Mausoleum to visit Ho Chi Minh. I went there in October and During September to November every year the mausoleum is closed. So we were just standing outside the Mausoleum and taking photos. We got to visit the museum around the Mausoleum and walked around the compound.
Worth a visit. It's an impressive building with beautifully manicured gardens. I found it a really nice break from the horn beeping and motorbikes. Well worth the walk around.

More than we know. On or near the grounds of The Ho Chi Minh Residence and grounds, visiting the Mausoleum gave me the visceral experience of how much the vaulted leader is respected by the people of Viet Nam. It was worth learning about this beloved leader because of the influence he had in supporting his people. Much respect is shown in this brief and worthwhile visit.
Very impressive. This is an amazing building. The outside garden is immaculate, with workers keeping it beautiful. Quite a stunning place.

Must Go. If it's your first time visit Hanoi, you have to go here. It is one of the tourist spots and one of the places we visited during the Hanoi City Tour that we joined. Usually it is about an hour to 2 hours queue to go inside the Mausoleum to visit Ho Chi Minh. During September to November every year the mausoleum is closed so you cannot enter, which was the time I went (October). So we were just standing outside the Mausoleum and taking photos. We got to visit the museum around the Mausoleum and walked around the compound.
too comunist. too communist or my style I am from socialist country so remembers me homeit looks like china mainland mausoleos

Impressive monument to their Great Leader. I was impressed by the admiration they have for their past Leader and was interested to find out more about him and his thoughts. There was some strange elements to it which seemed a little abstract but I was happy to go through that to see the great Statue they have as the centrepiece of the Museum

Monumental significance like many others. We stood at a distance as the guide recited 20 minutes of Vietnam history, the life of Ho Chi Minh was described in detail so too the fact that we could not enter.
Ok... A must when going to Hanoi but definetly not the best thing of the city. Can have an impression about the comunist era of the time, closed from october until the end of winter.

Good place to visit. I did not read much about Ho Chi Minh and the history of Vietnam but when I visited the Mausoleum I understood about his life, his sacrifice and why Vietnamese worship him so much. Come to this area you can also visit the HCM Museum, the President Palace, One pillar pagoda, HCM's house. We had a good time.
Must visit!. The place gives you the chills. The building is so imposing. The mausoleum should be open more hours, not just from 8 to 10 am, most tourists still sleep at that time!!!

Admire a great celebrity. The first time was to visit the tomb of the president, we understand more about the people, about the values that President Ho Chi Minh has left, so simple and approachable, a national saint Vietnam, we learned a lot from him
Nothing special. The mausoleum was closed so unfortunately we could not see inside of it. Instead, since it was near, we went to one pillar pagoda and a temple near it were people were praying.

Fascinating. We walked here from another attraction just to check if it was open. We had two young kids with us (5 and 8). We all thoroughly enjoyed it. Much more than expected. I had read that I should take note of the reactions of the Vietnamese visitors when viewing Ho Chi Minh, and truly it was fascinating. Even my kids appreciated the solemnity of the situation. Really helped to gain a better understanding of the culture.

Very nice place to see. Had a wonderful afternoon walking around the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and grounds. What an amazing place. Unfortunately the mausoleum was closed for maintenance but it was still lovely walking around and seeing the grounds and history of Ho Chi Minh. We will definitely come back again.

Interesting. It is one of those visits where you line up for an hour or so to see the embalmed body of the great leader of a communist country. It was on a smaller scale to the one we experienced in Bejing but we wanted to do it for the experience. It is interesting watching the natives line up and watching them checking if they are being noticed by the benevolent powers that be! But all in all a must for any history buff.
run down national gem. A run down park, impressive as expectable for a National Gem. Unnerving "guides", everything overpriced. No real comfortable place to rest around. Closed Tuesdays and Fridays.
Check opening times. At no fault of anyone except ourselves it might a good idea to check the opening times,days and scheduled maintenance . As our two trips to Hanoi the Mausoleum has been closed.

Wonderful lesson in Vietnam history. Had a wonderful morning walking around the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and grounds. What an amazing place. Unfortunately the mausoleum was closed for maintenance but it was still lovely walking around and seeing the grounds and history of Ho Chi Minh. Well worth the time and effort

A must when in HaNoi. A great couple of hours. Jus to see the numbers of people paying their respects to the county's former leader and "father of the nation" is amazing.Beautiful grounds and whilst ther eis a slow move towards the Mausoleum that is part of the experience.Very close to city Centre.

Historical Place but not much to see.. The architecture is a classic for the Communism architecture - big and straight. The parade place in front is also huge. Be aware that Ho Chi Minh is not always there. These days the mausoleum is closed due to Ho Chi Minh is in Russia.

Living History. As a lover of History I found Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum to be a fantastic place to visit.Not for the actually structure itself but for what it has become synonymous with and what it means to the Vietnamese people.
Must see. This was our very first sight that we visited on our first day in Hanoi. It's a must see but be prepared for long lines.

Visit Bac Ho. Its one of those places that is important to the locals and is worth seeing as a foreigner. It is quick and quiet. You wait in a long line, much of it surrounded by honor guard waiting to enter the mausoleum where you can see Ho Cho Minh's body. You can't talk, can't take pictures, or even have your hands in your pockets. But it is a culturally, and historically significant experience.

Facinating HCM Mausoleum. U need to carry an umbrella as it was pretty hot and when it rains you dont have much cover. Its a wonderful place and a must visit. You can need minimum 2 hours to see and enjoy the place.

Beautiful view,but bad service. We walked to visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum because the hotel suggested us do it.We came there by 9 a.m.There was already a long queue.Many people did not stay in two lines though they were told by the tour guide.It was so noisy and some people threw the rubbish on the ground.Some staff were not friendly when they pointed at us when we still brought our small bags with us.They did not speak any English.We had to leave our cameras behind,so we could not have any pics.Overall,that was so crowded and we could not enjoy the time visiting the place

best shot for great day in hanoi. even i lived in hanoi two years, whenever i pass here i am happy. great and huge place and i can meet new friends here. many foreigners come here and take photos. at night, more great but can't go inside for security reasons.

More than a Mausoleum - a part of history. Unable to go inside the Mausoleum but a very impressive building and huge square reminds you of the significance of Ho Chi Minh. The gardens and houses behind the Mausoleum are certainly impressive and help tell a story about Vietnam's history. Our Private Guide from Tonkin Travel certainly provided the information in English to help us understand better.
Mausoleum. Quite an experience. You can't get up close to this building,very large open space.Not a lot to see,but you can imagine what it would be like during a parade there.
not worth going. This place is not worth going and waste of time. We can't go in as it is close for renovation. Skip this place.

A must for all those interested in the legend of Ho Chi Minh. Another site that is superb if you are interested in the life and death of Ho Chi Minh. Unfortunately his body was in Russia for regular maintenance (done every 3 years) so we could not see it, but we still enjoyed seeing how the legend of this great leader still continues in Vietnam.

revered by the vietnamese, not the same effect on tourists. When we went there, there were so many old people both men and women wearing their military uniforms, plus all the locals that diligently fall in line to go in the mausoleum. Our guides from hanoikids explained that he is revered by the vietnamese.But for tourists, its effect is not as dramatic. On a very hot day, regardless of the shaded walkway the place provides, the time spent (up to an hour in line) just to be inside for a few minutes is not necessarily a must for tourists. For locals, it is worth to visit. For tourists, it is worth just passing through and just looking from the outside rather than waiting in line to get inside.

Visiting as a strange person!. It was a nice place to keep Uncle Ho for Vietnam and for the customers to visit him. Feel he is sleeping on his bed but I think it was a picture of him and really where is him we can't know.

Respectful. I really enjoyed it but may not be for everyone. Very respectful which is great. Big bonus was the gardens/park next door which also very relaxing/peaceful.
Plan the time you attend as queues can be long.
Top Class- a must see. Top class but reasonable long wait & rushed through be cause of the crowd...either go early or very late.
Interesting but hum drum. Firstly no one can tell you when a good time to go is. Their either closed for the day or closed for lunch.

Pick your day to visit carefully. We picked the wrong day, a weekend and a public holiday - the queue to enter stretched for kilometres. Having walked to the end, gobsmacked at the patience of the people, mostly Vietnamese, waiting to enter, we decided the change tack and just explore the gardens. This enabled us to head to different entrance and no queue. The gardens are lovely, you can still view the original French colonial building and also Ho's smaller more modest accommodations. So we totally missed the Mausoleum itself but still had a great experience.

HoChiMins Body. It was awesome to see him in the flesh but it's now closed for 2 months according to my guide. Others told us that they believe the body is being touched up. No pictures here or even stopping for that matter.
Huge and majestic. This big yard for military shows all over the years. Some parade army soldiers was practicing with old seniors.
Wish I could have seen this . My rating is irrelevant to this place. I just want people to he aware that it is closed on Sundays. I did not know this so I missed my opportunity to visit.

Impressive and good to see, but closed. The whole areas is worth a visit with the vast square where they can do parades and the Mausoleum. Unfortunately it is closed for a month or two each year and September is one of those periods, so we could not go inside.An impressive building and area with other items of interest in the area which make it worth visiting.
If The Queue Is Long Move On. You are in and out in a flash, a poor soul in our group was told to get her hands out of her pockets, by some over bearing official
A bit dissapointed . The actual mausoleum was closed with no warning upon entering the area. If it was open then the visit would have been drastically better.

A window into history. This should probably be one's first stop in vietnam to get a better understanding od the people's struggles against the French and Americans...
This will give a better understanding into how they think in present day times.

Have to see since it's a must for the Vietnamese . Must go to this very important monument celebrating who the Vietnamese consider to be the father of Vietnam. Can file by the body, see his humble house on stilts, the presidential palace, and walk through the beautiful gardens. Guards are rude. You will have to check cameras and large bags. Women must cover their legs and shoulders.

Not home at the moment. Unfortunately HCM is away for refurbishment at the moment so the Mausoleum is closed leaving just the square.It was interesting to learn that Uncle Ho, in his will, requested cremation but they went ahead and built this anyway - so much for the last will and testament.Maybe we will come back another day.Very nearby is his house which is worth a visit.

Outdated . The mausoleum was closed for renovation, so we visit only the museum. Most of exibit are outdated, and it feels its more important for locals than turist.Go if you need to keatn about Ho Chi Minh through pictures, symbols and artifacts.

Impressive Building. We knew that the Mausoleum would be closed before we went but decided it would still be worth walking past. Its an very impressive building and if you have the chance combine with the Presidential Palace and other surrounding attractions. Had the chance to snap a pic of the friendly guard in his uniform white wellies as it had just finished chucking it down with rain.

Good place to stroll. This is Vietnam's counterpart of Chiang kai Shek in Taiwan or the Tiananmen Square in Beijing although in a much smaller scale. Read about Ho Chi Minh in google before going here so you can appreciate why the reverence for him. It gets hot during the early afternoon so best to go early in the morning or late in the afternoon. Don't sit down when taking pictures here. For some reason, the guards don't like it.

If you wait to go inside it is worth while to see. Went inside and must say that this is worth doing. The wait was long and yes the military is rude by our standards but they have this huge respect for Uncle Ho. Yes NO cameras. phones etc. Also do NOT wait in the line with your hands in your pockets...........

A strange slice of history. It was a very strange experience to see the body of a person who had died over 60 years ago. That aside, this attraction is very efficient and tourists move with speed and efficiency through the mausoleum. It's pretty chilly inside, so take something with you to keep you warm and remember to remove your hat when you enter.

Changing of the guard is at 10:00 am. "Uncle Ho" is away being preserved, whatever that involves, so the mausoleum is closed. Changing of the guard was interesting. All males have mandatory service and if one has impeccable backgrounds they may be chosen to guard the mausoleum.

Definitely worth going to see on your way to the presidential palace. It's an awesome photo opportunity to see this piece of vietnamese history. Filled with loads of tourists, so be warned. It will be hot, and you will have to queue, so bring water and food. But it will be worth it.

Closed for Cleaning. When we went the place was closed, we were told that the place closes every year at this time. The building is impressive, situated in a huge square, there was some dignitary’s due to visit so we were “shooed“down passed the building. Would have went in given the chance

Intersting. As part of our TravelMarvel tour, we visitied the day before the celebration of Vietnams 70 year Independence and we part of the many thousands who filed past Ho Chi Minh. No cameras, no talking, no smiling, arms by your side, no hats...all very respectful while being observed by grim looking military as we observed Uncle Ho as he is affectionately referred by loyal Vietnamese. It was interesting hearing "the other side" of the story and learning about Ho Chi Minhs history aNd his quest for freedom for Vietnam. The grounds around the mausoleum are beautiful and if you are interested in history and cultures this is worth the queues and hear.

Unkle Ho is in Russia between Sep-Dec. Second time visit to Hanoi to see Unkle Ho with my friend. How unlucky we are.We did some research online before the trip about where Hochimin's body is. Obviously we didn't do proper research.3 days after Vietnam Independence day(2/Sep) Hochimin leaving to Russia for make up as per our tour guide. HUE travel agent assured us we could see Hochimin body yesterday before booking day tour. Obviously he didn't watch the news. So check with Hanoi people whether he is here or not unless you wanna see only giant building.

Nothing interesting . I didn't find this place that interesting. Actually it's just a huge square with a plenty of space and mausoleum there. I liked more the embassies around mausoleum. Buildings are very nice

Very well kept exhibit and great insight to Ho Chi Minhs life. I was surprised too see such a well preserved body of Ho Chi Minh, great job by the Vietnamese and shows thier immense respect for him. I had taken tours with Odyssey tours and the guide explained me the importance of Ho Chi MInh in shaping Vietnam, great man. In the same complex adjoining the Mausoleum are the presidential building and exhibits from his life. I felt happy to have visited this place to pay respect to such a great personality. It is very much worth the visit and one SHOULD NOT MISS this.

A good start to understand Vietnam's history. I have read some of the other reviews and clearly some didn't do their homework -- yes, the mausoleum closes for some months for renovations -- understandable, but don't forget the 70 year anniversary was in September 2015 as well. As far as an ugly building - clearly these people are not in the building industry -- to consider it was built in the 60's i think it is a testament of Vietnam's growth -- well done. This was the first place our guide took us and yes, you can't take a backpack or anything in fact inside -- most of all just obey the instructions from the guards and all will be good. I would recommend if you are going to visit, do some reading of history and ask about opening times. What appears to me, that everyone tries to go early as you walk a far bit under a covered walkway and you wait, and wait; but the afternoon seemed not so busy. You can't take cameras and remove your hat as a mark of respect.

Really something to experience. This is really something to experience. Yes Ho is in there. Very rigid protocols but the people want to maintain a dignified and respectful environment. The surrounding grounds also provide some very interesting aspects of Ho and his impact on VietNam.
A special experience. A really different experience to see a body so wonderfully preserved and really a great way to pay respect to one of the great man in history.

Chilling. I don't know much about Ho Chi Minh other than he truly loved and helped his country. When I walked through the area where they have a making of his body I got the chills and now I am set I have to find out who this man is because rarely do I get chills about anything in life!!! Highly recommended.

Would have been better if we got to go in. Ok, so it's rated as the 6th ugliest building in the world.. we had to see it, and we can now understand the statement.
We caught the changing of the guard, but apart from that, we were a little miffed that we could not go inside.. that would have been awesome.. I think

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, a good choice to visit!. We're there on 16 Sept, and it's closed so we cannot go inside. But there are no clear info given by the officials, they said that it will be open in 2 months? But we still can visit and take the photo outside the building, the surrounding has a park, which is very nice to take a photo.
big place. a very solumn place,there were many people there and all were very quiet,a lot of respect shown.it was closed when we were therebut enjoyed the walk around.

Humbling Experience for me. If you have never been to a Mausoleum before, then this is a very good experience to see how the Vietnamese revere their founding father. It is a very solemn affair and can feel sometimes quite tense due to the massive military presence. Yet, it is also a humbling experience to see how this person is so venerated by many! Good experience and a must-go! [pls follow all instructions when you are there. Do not do anything that can cause you to be on the wrong side of the law!]
Nice but not a must see. Well kept and clean but not a must see. The grounds are beautiful. You cannot take backpacks and the like in with you.
Surreal. Free entry, 3-4 other sights located here. A very surreal experience going in & seeing Uncle Ho. I would highly recommend because it's not something you can do anywhere else.

Remembering History. This is a place whee tourists get to know Vietnam's history and in particular Ho Chi Minh as a great hero to the nation. Learn from seeing and went back to the formation of the present country called Vietnam. Read his philosophies and thinkings and the many events that he took part to gain independence foe Vietnam.

Symbol of a regime. The huge queue does not demotes the Vietnamese people to make a visit to te Mausoleum of the "father" of the nation. With a "socialist" architecture, this Mausoleum leaves no one indifferent.
Nice too see area. Recommend you to visit this places , we been here to see beautifully and learn a lot of history of they national father

Very Rigid and a but dull. This is an attraction that you might like for the history, i found it very uncomfortable andmy friend and i were grabbed and ahoved many times by the guards there because we weren't in two perfect straight lines. It wasn't my cup of tea.
Closed!. We came all the way here but everything was cordoned off and we were told that it will be closed for the next 2 months. Not sure if they scooter / taxi driver was telling the truth.
Our Vietnam Holiday July 2015. This was amazing, we didn't get to go inside due to the huge lines,, but the gardens and living quarters of Ho Chi Min were truly amazing!

Gotta do it!. From the structure to the wide boulevard out front, you know this guy was important! Considered the father of modern day Vietnam, he is given all the respect, pomp and circumstance afforded that of any founder of a country. We unfortunately could not actually view Uncle Ho himself since the mausoleum unexpectedly closed after the Sept 2 celebrations until December. Although a disappointment, you can still experience the grounds and the nearby museum and Presidential compound. I can't help but compare him to George Washington; could you imagine if we had embalmed our great leader and then put his carcass on display...

Odd experience!. You have to do it I suppose but this is a very odd experience. Be prepared to be hustled (physically, you will be pushed into position if you don't maintain a 2 by 2 formation) past 'Uncle Ho' by the guards, you are inside the main part of the mausoleum for a matter of seconds, but I'm not sure you would want to linger anyway. You can't help feeling a little ashamed at looking at Ho Chi Minh, he last wish was for a simple burial but instead he has been preserved for all to see. We came early and didn't need to queue but from the look of the covered walkway to the mausoleum I imagine the queues can get very long.The surrounding gardens are very pretty, it's worth a visit.

Behalf of the guards. A long queue , for a 1 minute see of Hohi Minc . It is quite an experience and respect for this great man. However , the gards are impolite and rude. But that is the way the army is in vietnam with every body.
Must see the Mausoleum. This is the place where Ho Chi Min body is lying. Adjacent to single pillar pagoda Hochimin house. war museum

Worth a Look. While in Hanoi we did a guided day tour which included the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Our Guide told us they close the Mausoleum for about 2 months every year, to do restoration work on the body. Unfortunately when we visited it happened to be during that two month period.But is was interesting to see the Guards guarding the Mausoleum and the number of people around the area.

Walking tour . This was a walking tour on a hot day. It was very impressive. However, we didn't go in because the waiting time was 2 hours and there were no water station. They have a fast track service but you have to book 3 month in advance. Therefore it was disappointing that were unable to pay our respect.
historic place.. we arrived here on independence day so lots of celebrations going on.... changing of the guard was great to see.

A must see. This is really a very unique experience and a special event even for the locals who are focused to visit once in their lifetime. Ho Chi Minh is everywhere in Vietnam. The named city, on currency and on the wall of everyones home. Statue busts are in every public building so to visit Uncle Ho in person so to speak is a very very special experience. No cameras, even phone cameras and the queue was very long and there is no lingering to take a closer look. Allow a min of two hours.
A nice walk around the area.... It's nice to visit and see a famous landmark in Hanoi, but we couldnt go inside when we go there and so just walked around the area. Nothing more to it really -

Disappointed!. Was closed on the day our tour guide took us there. We were not allowed in any of the buildings or in the bunker. Would not visit again! Felt sorry for the big peacocks, housed in a cage way too small! Not impressed!

Amazing Visit to Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. Wow, the atmosphere is amazing, The guards at the door in their speccy uniforms, the Pagoda and shrine, Gardens spectacular, A must see when in Hanoi.
Don't forget your camera as there is plenty to see,and expect to spend a couple of hours wandering around so wear comfortable shoes, and loose clothing as it is hot and humid.
Must do when in Hanoi. A fascinating experience, a one off and a must do when in Hanoi. The complex is set up very well for visitors and there is a lot to see as well as Ho himself. Recommended.

A nice walk. We were not really interested in the tomb. But the walk around the old houses and lake was nice. Be aware there are two ticket booths, one at the entrance and another to the grounds. Its worth it if you can relate strongly to the history of Vietnam.
Interesting. Well worth the look. This was also on our guided walking tour. Try to do this early to avoid standing in line in the heat of the day.
Very Nice. We visited the outside area only since there were lines for blocks to get inside. Worth visiting when in Hanoi.

Worth a visit!. This place is worth a visit - very interesting, historical. If you plan on going into the mausoleum be sure to wear conservative clothing (covering your shoulders and knees), or you will have to buy over priced scarves/pants at the entrance. It also has limited open hours so be sure to check that out before making the trip.

A quintessential communist experience. When in Hanoi this is really one of those things you have to say you've done. The tomb itself is in the midst of a huge park with most of the very lengthy line up covered over so that you don't have to be out in the direct withering sun for too long. The line ups are immense but to give them credit the line moves very quickly. The building itself is suitably austere and soviet in design. No joviality is tolerated and even small perceived slights like have sun glasses pushed up to the top of your head will earn you harsh words. As for Ho Chi Minh himself - you will only cast eyes on him for less than a minute. A rather macabre snip shot of history.....

It's closed. We have been twice over the last two days trying to get into the mausoleum. First time we were told its closed in the afternoon, only opened in the morning. So we went back this morning & were told by two different people that it's now closed September to the end of November.

Quick, easy...must do!. The other reviewers are correct: this place is only open in the morning. Buying a ticket and getting into the mausoleum is quick and easy. It may not be the most exciting thing in the world, but it is a Hanoi must do. It's a good way to start the day before exploring the city in the grueling hot sun.

Interesting and Organized. Enough interesting and very organized, but too fast everything happened. However nobody asked me about any money. I have read that stuff asks for money to let you out and it didn't happen to me. Uncle Ho is pretty.

Worth your time!. Like many Vietnamese museums, it has limit opening times. We arrived quite late and thought we wouldn't make it on time, luckily we were still able to get it in. There was a long queue, but you weren't standing waiting a long time since you aren't allowed to stop in the Mausoleum to look at Ho Chi Minh, so the process is quick, definitely interesting to go and see!

Interesting to see. Please be aware that there is only mummy of Ho Chi Minh in the mausoleum and you are not allowed to stand or take photos inside. You are forced to walk around the mummy by the guards and it takes only 30 sec. If you are not interested to see this, you can easily skip this trip. Also keep in mind that, it is very crowded at the weekend with many locals.
Limited open times. Only got to see from outside and then not too close as when it is closed it is really closed. From memory was only open in the morning which didn't work out for us.

Ugly looking building. It was so hot, no shade and it look like big runway and there was not much to see except an ugly looking building with some soldier parading around it. No informations about the building anywhere.

Ho Chi Minh's final resting place.. The mausoleum is only open in the mornings until 10.30, we arrived quite late at about 10.00 and didn't think we would get in, however this seemed to work well for us as the queue was very small and we were amongst the last dozen to be allowed entrance. Its quiet surreal inside the tomb as I have never seen an embalmed body before. You need to dress conservatively and the guards will put you in your place if you do not appear to be respectful. Well worth a visit.

Spooky and long queues. Very long queues and specific opening hours - visitors planning a day trip need to be organised how to get there/ timing, otherwise easily missed. Worth a visit, quite spooky, you get only a few minutes glimpse of the inside as no stopping allowed. Its the city feature, but can be skipped if somebody not into visiting strange graves.

Not what I was expecting at all but it still is worth to visit. First off all: we must pass thought the security and they'll keep your bags and only give it back in the endThen you almost have to march to get to the mausoleum, and you're inside there there are military guards pushing you to move faster.When I tried to leave I had a great surprise... The entrance is free! Foreigners only pay to leave... If you don't pay you don't leave... That's stupid because there was no information before! But it is only 25k, nothing to much...
Must see. Something you have to see in Hanoi. This is a place to vIsit. Today's Vietnam is the result of this man.
Worth a look. Worth a look, but there was a line up around the block, being such a hot and humid day and then only seeing the mausoleum for around 30 secs was a bit disappointing.
Ho Chi Minh. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a wonderful structure. The people of Hanoi still love Ho Chi Minh and will talk about him continuously. In their mind he is the only one they love.

Impressive lump of concrete. Hard to see what the architects had in mind here, looks nothing like a Lotus flower. Much more interesting was the self guided tour around Ho Chi Minh's private apartments.

Bad option in Hot day.. Not want to come because I visited Hanoi many times. However, as the forcing of my wife, I came here. Unlucky, it is on Sunday, so so busy with very long line in the crazy hot weather. Nothing special and attractive, will not comeback anymore.

Strange but interesting experience.. Visited on a Saturday morning. The queue was horrendous when we first arrived, many of groups of school children so our tour guide decided to take us to the Temple of Literature first and come back later in the morning when the queues had died down.When we returned later in the morning the queue was a lot better and took around 15 mins to reach the entrance of Mausoleum. Camera's and water were placed into lockers whilst you visit the mausoleum, no pictures or water allowed inside the building.Upon entering the middle section of the building you enter a cool air conditioned room where the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh lays inside a glass case - very strange to look at. When filing pass the body you must be appropriately dressed shoulders covered, no short shirts or shorts quiet, no smiling, no folding your arms or hands in pockets or you'll be told off by the soldiers that guard his body. The viewing of his body takes all of 5 secs to walk around the glass case and then back out to the grounds. I found visiting his modest house on stilts and car collection much more interesting than viewing an embalmed body. Ho Chi Minh lived a modest life which I found surprising. The grounds with a gorgeous pond in the middle are immaculate and enjoyable to walk around. Close by is the One Pillar Pagoda which sits in the middle of a small pond. Throughout the grounds you will see soldiers in their immaculate white uniforms marching around the place. Changing of the guards which was interesting and amusing to watch.It's a busy place with many visitors but an interesting place to visit. You really do a get a feel of how loved and well respected Ho Chi Minh was by the Vietnamese people.

To much security!. I went in their 70th independency anniversary and I had to move with the crowd in the line and nobody could stand inside more than a few seconds. In total not much to see. Also, in the museum next to the mausoleum majority of the label were in Vietnamese.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. If you want to learn some historical information about Ho Chi Minh, this is an interesting site. You can view his entombed body in a glass casket, in a highly guarded room. This is a site which many Vietnamese go to, in addition to tourists, so plan on spending time in line. The good thing is that they have the waiting areas covered, so in the rain you can stay semi-dry, but I would bring an umbrella, too. View the grounds, his house and garden areas. This place was built for him, although Ho Chi Minh lived modestly (compared to?). Again, having a tour guide to inform you about the buildings and grounds is helpful. I had a private guide set up before I went.

Not much to see except the Ho Chih Min statue.. No English translations for exhibits. Consisting of 3 floors, the 1st floor is basically security check, 2nd floor are some Vietnamese independence exhibits with no English wordings, won't take you more than 10 min. the 3rd floor is the status of Mr Ho Chih Min and some other cultural exhibits like weaving machine, guns used in war etc.. I felt the place was basically a location to house from the summer, more than for educational purposes.
More interesting to see the crowds than the site. Felt very much part of the culture going here but the actual exhibits are pretty limited and aimed at his local fans rather than tourists.

Worth the wait. Once we saw how long the queue was to visit "Uncle Ho"(even though we arrived well before the opening time), we almost decided to skip the visit. But we persisted and it was certainly well worth the effort. The Vietnamese in the line were solemn and respectful as you would expect judging by the reverence they still have for Ho despite it being almost 50 years since his death. Viewing the humble accommodation that he stayed in even at the height of his power gives a strong insight into the character of the man. Beautifully maintained gardens surround the complex, so there is always something to look at despite the crowds.

Worth a visit. Though it's a little weird to be staring at a man who has been dead for 45 years, it helps you understand the impact this man had on the Vietnamese people. We didn't have to wait long to get in but there is a bit of queuing and walking in the hot sun so you need to be able to bear this. Apparently the wait can be very long during the weekend.

Surprisingly good. Surprisingly good, though watch out because it closes early and we nearly missed it. Apart from the mausoleum itself we loved the house on stilts and Ho chi Minh's used car collection.

Hanoi. Its a good place to visit.It tells you the story of how the people fight to gain its independence.You will be able to see the first President of Vietnam, Mr Ho Chi Minh,how he lived,studied and help the people of Vietnam to gain independence.

A must. You have to visit this Mausoleum to ready get a sense of the dichotomy of Vietnamese communism. It is a great monument to the great man himself. Respect and decorum is expected from all visitors. Moving away from sweeping boulevard and the significant military presence you are swept back to the hub of Vietnamese day to day life of the commercial trading quarters where capitalism is alive and kicking.

HISTORY OF THE VIETNAM WAR. My husband loves history so they was a definitely have to go to one. I learnt a lot from the Vietnamese side about the war now I can say I heard both sides as I was only aware of the American version from Washington DC. Huge lesson learnt NO ONE wins a war no one - not to be missed

A Mausoleum to a Vietnamese Man of the People. Pleased we went to the Mausoleum as it is sort of a must see and our guide had such reverence for Ho Chi Minh as a person so it was interesting to hear the story about him and his upbringing and education. Very hot day so we did not spend a lot of time here but of course it is a oncer and it is an imposing structure in his honour ( which apparently he did not want!) so pleased we made the effort.

A great tribute for Ho Chi Minh. I wasn't sure whether to go and visit Uncle Ho but Glad I did! It's a wonderful tribute to a much loved leader and liberator of the Vietnamese people so one has to respect how they feel about him! The place itself is beautifully set out yet quite simple especially the grounds which are set very well one gets a real sense that this was his home its very peaceful and yet I found the Mausoleum building itself quite austere and formal.Just remember its closed on Fridays and if possible get there by 8am as the queues get very long quickly and in the hot Sun can be exhausting! Well worth a visit if your interested in Vietnamese history!!!

No provision for people with disabilities. My wife and I visited the HCM mausoleum during our recent visit to Hanoi. We researched our visit, wore the correct clothing and arrived early. The que was short as we had hoped. Being a senior aged 69, with a walking difficulty, I did not expect to have to walk 2.5 Km. My limit is normally 500 meters. Having passed through the mausoleum I looked for the nearest exit to get a taxi back to our hotel. There was no way out other than to follow the designated path. Every attempt to find a shortcut was met with a soldier pointing along the main path despite other exits being clearly visible. I finished the visit in agony. All of my previous experiences in Vietnam, (this is our third visit), have been wonderful. This experience was anything but.

Know the history. Worth visiting to know the history. Long queues on Sundays and holidays so avaid those days. We went through a travel company and hence the entry was easy and well guided. Lovely gardens and quiet location in the middle of chaotic Hanoi.

Best Place to educate my children on our histry and the hero. No only me, but the whole of my family admire the whole life or Our Uncle Ho contributed to the country, He is the founder of our country, I loved all things from my Uncle.

Ineresting. This is a must see in Hanoi. The queues are usually long so arrive early. (it's only open in mornings) Everyone walks past slowly and silently, the guards are a bit scarey and won't let you stop at all. Quite a strange experience but definitely a must for visitors to Hanoi.

Undeliable history!. Well you might think it is boring, please be advice to have good speaking local guide and read before you pay a visit to this place. I believe it is really interesting if you really understand how important this man for the country of Vietnam

Long queue. The queue was very long to see Ho Chi Minh as it was Sunday. The mausoleum is closed on Monday. You can choose whether to see inside the mausoleum or just taking photographs from outside. I recommend to come here with a guide, as they know how to get the fast lane or you can discuss with your guide the best way for you to enjoy your trip here. The queue can reach an hour from outside to reach inside (about 800metres) where you actually spend not more than 5 minutes inside. You cannot bring camera or water bottle inside. But all I can say is that, you never go to Vietnam if you do not see sir Ho Chi Minh. For me, it's worth the long queue.
Striking Building . Large mausoleum for Ho Chi Minh embalmed body. Go early as many nationals visit to pay their recpects.Dress appropriately Interesting to see, Palace is next door.

History. I always visit this tomb of Uncle Ho every time I visit Hanoi. Say what you like he worked tirelessly for his people who in turn love him till this day. I have been embraced by older Vietnamese here weeping with emotion. Take the time to quietly walk round and see the place where Uncle Ho worked and lived. Really a must see, take the right attitude

Avoid in weekends. Whilst it always interesting to see former leaders embalmed (Lenin in Moscow) the line was very long on a very hot Hanoi day.People from the provinces make a pilgrimage and Saturday was probably not the best time to go. The presidential palace is quite a striking looking building

Amazing after sunset!. One of the most visited attractions in Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is the place where embalmed body of their national hero is kept in glass box for visitors. Better to go early in the morning to avoid rush. Follow visiting rules while inside

Interesting - but make sure you visit early - it seems to shut from 12. We tried to get in 3 times and were thwarted. We got there at 3 pm one day, having found that all the places you want to go in are closed at lunch time (but this varies - some open again at 1, others at 2 etc. ) the mausoleum was closed all afternoon as well, but I couldn't find anyone who could tell me if this was normal. The guards like you to be respectfully dressed and I was asked to cover my shoulders (first time - not sure if this is normal)The soldiers look very photogenic in their pristine white uniform.Plan to do Ho Chi Minh museum (entrance is on the same side as the mausoleum) in the same day, and the pagoda on west lake.Unrelated - but don't take travellers cheques to Vietnam. Can't find anywhere to take them. Any bank notes you bring must be in pristine condition as well!!

Fascinating Unique Visitors attraction. You have to go early as it closes by about 1030 but also it's cooler although a long queue it moved quickly and was interesting to see.The house and museum were worth the extra to see although many of the display in the museum were not translated into English.

Pay your respects and visit 'Uncle Ho's'! Worth Visiting!!. This is the final resting place of Ho Chi Minh, the most iconic and popular leader of Vietnam, known to his people as ‘Uncle Ho’. His body is preserved here in a glass case at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum in central Hanoi (although he had requested to be cremated). His body lies in state similar to Lenin, Stalin and Mao, other great communist leaders before him.Security is tight and visitors should dress with respect (no shorts, sleeveless shirts and miniskirts) and everyone has to deposit their bags and cameras before getting in. Visitors are not allowed to stop and hold the constant queue up as the place is constantly busy.Highly recommend to go early in the morning, as the queue is long, and it gets quite hot standing in line. You will not only see streams of school kids lining up (learning their own history and great leader) but Vietnamese travel from far to see and pay their respect to Ho Chi Minh so dont be suprised the amount of people there are when you arrive. The queue does move fast. You will be ushered in by guards in 2 straight lines into the Mausoluem which is very cool and air conditioned. You will be only allowed to see him from the moving line and talking is prohibited. Though it only takes a few seconds to walk into and around to see this embalmed corpse, you feel immediately silent and transfixed when viewing the body. It is an eering and scary feeling but nonetheless well worth the visit. Every year the embalmed corpse is sent to Russia for maintenance so the mausoleum closes for a couple of months from October. Check with your hotel before planning your trip.HCM's Mausoleum is connected to HCM's Presidential Palace and historical site. After you exist the Mausoleum, you walk through a small garden and pay to enter to visit the Palace.Opening Hours: Tuesday to Thursday and weekends from 8am – 11am. Closed on Monday and FridayLocation: At Ba Dinh Square in Hanoi city centreDress Code: No shorts, mini shirts, hats or sleeveless shirts. No cameras or bags allowed (free cloak room storage).Cost: 10,000 VND

well organised and guarded. this place is vast and open area very well guarded and a must to see in Hanoi also visit
Temple of Literature,
This Mausoleum is in Ba Dinh Square

A must visit. Go early in the morning.
It's a fascinating thing to see.
Read the rules for visitors before you go.
Respectful. The lines are long on most days with locals paying their respect, and tourists wanting to get a glimpse of this national hero.

We hated it. Not worthy going!
There are so many lines! And they are very restricted with everything (cameras cellphones water). Very annoying! People.that work there are so rude!!!!
Not a beautiful place!

Tribute to Ho Chi Minh. It is a nice place, well maintained with dignity and discipline. Though it was ranked as the "sixth most ugly" building in the world by CNN International in 2012, the whole campus is a real best attraction of Hanoi. It has a protocol of dress code, discipline and code of conduct during the visit. The embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is preserved in the cooled, central hall of the mausoleum, which is protected by a military honour guard. The body lies in a glass case with dim lights. It is a nice place to visit on working days, as it is overcrowded on weekends.

Very big and with solemnity . We visit the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum and it's as all thee guides says. Very monumental an not so agree with communism filosophy, but that's my point of view, of course. Nevertheless we really enjoy it.

Been there, done that. It's low season, so thankfully we only waited 30 minutes in line. Visiting Uncle Ho is one of those requisite tourist "to do's" but can't say you should go out of your way or wait hours to pay your respects. Several kiosks are available to leave your backpacks, cameras and iPads, though cell phones don't seem to be banned. Don't even think about sneaking a photo, though, as guards are everywhere inside. His three homes are also onsite, but visitors are only allowed at the perimeter. Lovely fishpond and a small pagoda for the purpose of praying for a boy child. Did not wish to pay the separate entrance fee for the museum.

A must see in Vietnam.. No one can come to Vietnam without having an interest in this man given he is everything to the nation. It is a strange and very military style process when you are in the mausoleum part of the grounds. Dress code needs to be appropriate, whispered voices throughout and no photographs inside which are all understandable. You do get pushed through quickly but the queues can be very very long so not great in the heat and humidity of Hanoi.Once you've been in the mausoleum you can walk around the grounds to see the houses and museum. The conditions are relaxed and photos can be taken.My advice is go as early as possible to avoid the heat and queues.

Hanoi City tour. It's really touching. Ho chi min was a great leader. Still Vietnam people love him dearly.World need leaders like him. His body has been preserved and it's in a good condition. This is the best one I saw in Hanoi City tour.

Impressive...if not just a bit imposing.. The Mausoleum is impressive. Dominating "Ba Dinh Square" my oldest son said it is the most impressive communist building he has ever seen. Ho Chi Minh I believe chose to be cremated on his death, but there wasn't going to be any of that. Like Lenin's Tomb in Moscow the building is a worthy tribute to the father of modern Vietnam.You need to arrive early as the Mausoleum is open only in the morning.

Such a beautiful place!. A visit to Ho Chi Minh mausoleum was my dream since I was still a little child. And yes, i did it. This is such a beautiful place to visit. After visiting the main mausoleum of Uncle Ho, you should have a walk around to see the beautiful parks around, fish lake, ethinic minorties' houses. All is green which make me love this place so much. Will definately go back if i get chance.

Not easy to find your way around. There is very little signage here and we couldn't find the stilt house and asked for directions but we're directed to points that said 'no entry'. Very confusing. We kept being told where not to go but not where to go. The mausoleum is impressive but we weren't allowed anywhere near it.

Interesting. You line up for quite a long time depending on tourist season it could be longer . To see a man preserved, its quite absurd really. But there is also something quite fascinating too. A very respectful thing you would choose to do.

Must Se. We visited here while in Hanoi waited in a really long line that moved really quickly approx 30 minutes waiting all under shade... It is a very controlled environment re your dress and also how quickly they move you past the body they push you along by grabbing your arm if you are going to slow!
