But I think it is a must see as there are not many embalmed bodies to visit we also seemed to exit via the place etc which was 25000 dong not too much to see there but was pretty cheap.

A little scary but an experience. Luckily, the line was not too long so we were able to get into the mausoleum pretty fast. As always preserved corps are kind of strange and scary but the importance of Ho Chi Minh for his people is huge. The whole complex including a beautiful park and his private rooms make the visit woth it.

Must-visit attraction in Hanoi. The final resting place of Uncle Ho is a must-see when visiting Hanoi. It is an extremely popular pilgrimage for Vietnamese as well, so arrive early to be not the last person of the queue. :) Built between 1973 and 1975, the massive square structure is modelled closely on Lenin's mausoleum in Moscow. Opposite the Mausoleum is Ba Dinh Square, where Ho chi Minh President read out the Vietnamese Declaration of Independence on 2 September 1945. Bags, cameras had to be checked in. Once inside the mausoleum, you will be kept shuffling past Ho Chi Minh's body while being watched by many guards. No talking or smiling allowed. Placed inside a glass sarcophagus, he looked very serene and certainly very well preserved. His face & hands were lit-up with spotlights. Coming here and you will see the huge love and respect that Vietnamese people give to their greatest leader. Accordingly, you will understand how much they love their country and current peace.

Strange experience. We felt that it was important to make a visit here to understand a bit more of the Vietnamese culture. We arrived at about 10:20am and were pleased that we didn't have to do much queuing, even though it was a Saturday. Watching pop songs about 'Uncle Ho' was a bit bizarre before then being ushered through to see the man himself. We enjoyed wandering round the gardens and seeing the One Pillar Pagoda which is just nearby. A strange experience but we'll worth a visit!

Boring and unsanitary. We were advised to visit here by other people we met on holiday. What a waste of time we learned it would be. The only remotely interesting item was the HCM statue. There were no other interesting artefacts. Not a lot of English translations either and the toilets were the dirtiest I've seen in Vietnam. Don't bother.

Nice surroundings. A short cab trip from Hanoi old quarter. Cab ride approximated 42,000VND. Impressive surroundings. But the viewing of the body itself is fairly quick. Sleeves shirts are not allowed, and preferably knees should be covered, although we managed to enter wearing Bermuda shorts. After that, following the crowd, you'll reach ho chin minh's residence which requires and entrance fee to go in. (I couldn't see anyone exiting without going through the residence). Overall, it's a reasonable thing to do if you had some spare time at Hanoi.

Grounds were interesting. We were unlucky with timing. The external presence of the mausoleum were impressive as were the various attractions on the grounds around it, but we were not able to approach due to preparations for the Vietnam independence day celebrations.

Interesting and Super Crowded. Visiting Uncle Ho's Mausoleum was at the top of our list for visiting Vietnam. We got in line about 8:30 am, after checking our backpack and camera at two separate locations. We were then funneled into a very well organized group in two lines to wait for out turn to visit the mausoleum. The entire queue is covered with hardened roofing or fabric covering so you're not in direct sunlight. We waited about 30 minutes. Upon entering the mausoleum, the AC is a welcome blast. There are guards everywhere an you file up the stairs, into the chamber and around the crystal casket, then down the stairs on the other side and out you go. It was really fascinating to be there with mostly Vietnamese people paying their respects. The mausoleum itself is free, but after leaving there the only possible exit is through the grounds of the estate, for which there is a fee. It took us another 25 minutes to figure out how and where to get our backpack and camera back, and wade through the hordes of people exploring the grounds. All in all, a very interesting experience. Definitely worth a visit.

sprawling compound. It is accompanied by a sprawling lawn where people can relax and exercise. We reached there late evening, still we could find people around. This is the typical culture of Hanoi with a vibrant evening life. people doing light exercise in the area

Very interesting!. If you are in Hanoi, you should go there. Bear in mind that you should have a short know-how in communism and Ho Chi Minh, otherwise it's only a few stones. The enrollment of the place it's clearly a movie image from communism style.

Interesting experience. A little bit hesistant to visit the mausoleum, but it turned out to be a very interesting experience. After reading the mixed reviews we came prepared. We were a little bit surprised by the allowance of shorts, as we came in long trousers.Standing in line, waiting at a couple of stops before finally entering the mauselum. Guarded by officials, telling you to be silent and to keep your hands out of your pockets, no sunglasses, no bags and no pictures (all seem logical, but some people didn't seem to understand the regulations and were acting disrepectful). Finally walking in line and seeing the body of Ho Chi Minh. Afterwards yoy can get access to the park and museum (you have to pay to enter these). The mausoleum is a must see, because of its historical importance.

HCM Mausoleum. We visited on a weekday however unfortunately the mausoleum was closed due to works conducted so we explored the compounds of the mausoleum. As the mausoleum is situated in close proximity to other museums, we visited the Ho Chi Minh's house as well. Plan well in advance if you plan to enter the mausoleum and abide by the rules which include attire.

Well worth the visit. Uncle Ho probably spins in his mausoleum at the hero worship that he spoke out against!. Certainly worth the visit. A fascinating monument to a man who abhorred hero worship. Uncle Ho appears to be made of wax and we were hurried through the visit to the mausoleum, however as with any fragment of history, it is so poignant to be able to see it in the flesh, even if that flesh is embalmed!
Ho chi minh. Always wear full length clothing. Take water....even under canopy as you queue.Very humid and hot.Someone passed out in the line

Surreal Experience -not to be missed !!. This is one of the more remarkable experiences I have had since I've been living in Vietnam. It truly is quite moving. There is little doubt from the faces of locals and indeed tourists, that 'Uncle Ho' as he is affectionately known, was / is universally adored as the father of the nation by the people. His Mausoleum is clearly testament to that notwithstanding that he himself, was a very humble man. To see him lying in state is amazing, and an experience not to be missed. Be early to avoid queues, and once inside, be very quiet and respectful at all times

A must if you wish to understand Vietnam, it's history and people. Anybody who moans about this is missing the point. To the Vietnamese,"Uncle Ho" is a hero. The point if visiting the mausoleum, is not just to see Ho Chi Mihn's body, but to witness the esteem by which the Vietnamese still hold Ho in. It's an experience, from the imposing guards to actually filing past Ho Chi Minh's preserved remains. The Palace, it's gardens and the area surrounding mausoleum are all very impressive. The museum is also brilliant and fills in the history of Vietnam's turbulent history. Just check out the rules and regulations before you go and enjoy the experience. Yes, the queue can be long so get there early.Overall a great experience and a definite must see whilst in Hanoi, something you will never experience again!

Fascinating if bizarre!. We had a tour guide take us to Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. The experience of talking to him and the process of seeing Ho Chi Minh was far more interesting than actually seeing the little man dozing in his glass box. The military precision alongside our tour guide being besotted with Uncle Ho was really eye opening. We also stood on the parade ground watching huge videos of people singing pop songs about Uncle Ho before visiting Ho's "modest home" (which is situated in a wonderful plantation not at all like the rest of Hanoi obviously). Felt this was an important visit to understand Vietnam's state of mind and history, but take it all with a mine of salt.

Amazing experience coming from NZ. Interesting how many of his follower's still flock through. Can have long cues.. I do not condone what this man did. The Vietnamese people still seem to worship him. Not sure if this is his actual body or pretty good was model.. In saying all of that, it is so amazing to experience the regimented way in which you get to view him with soldiers with guns everywhere. No Camera, no Mini computer pads, dress below knee, no bare shoulders and no wearing of sunglasses. The Vietnamese conform and are excepting of the militancy of this whole charade. You must experience it.

Get there early. You really need to get here very early (or use a cab company that will bribe there way in so you don't need to wait in the queue, really!!!) so you can get in before it closes as the queues can be very very long with wait times of over an hour possible. The process of getting from the street into the grounds and through the mausoleum itself is very strictly controlled and super efficient. Enter at the corner of Hung Vuong and Le Hong Phong Sts. The mausoleum is the last resting place of Ho Chi Minh and a symbol of gratitude and respect from Viet Namese people for president Ho Chi Minh. Rules regarding dress and behavior are strictly enforced by staff and guards. Legs must be covered (no shorts or miniskirts). Visitors must be silent, and walk in two lines. It's a solemn place, and must be entered in silence. Hands must not be in pockets, nor arms crossed. Smoking, drinking, eating, photography and filming are also not permitted anywhere inside the mausoleum. 8-11am Tue-Thu, Sat & Sun Dec-Sep, last entry 10.15am. Behind the mausoleum are the Presidential Palace, a carp pond, the stilt house where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked during the last decade of his life. It is based on homes of the Montagnard ethnic group of the far north. The mausoleum and museum are examples of soviet era architecture. Ho Chi Minh (light bearer) once said “To reap a return in ten years, plant a tree; but to reap a return in 100 years, cultivate a people. A wise man who is respected by Vietnamese and foreigners alike. Uncle Ho is consider one the most influential people of last century by Time magazine. Opposite the mausoleum a new national assembly building is being constructed. Check out the neighboring gardens before visiting the 1,000-somethng-year-old Pagoda. While the pagoda itself is small, the complex is definitely worthwhile.

Intriguing insight into Vietnam. I enjoyed a visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum not so much for visiting the mausoleum itself but for the whole experience of joining in with Vietnamese people paying their respects to Uncle Ho. Compared to some, an 80-minute queue wasn't too bad. As others have commented on the whole process of getting from the street outside on to the grounds and through the mausoleum itself is very strictly controlled but it is efficient. I was intrigued and a little disappointed that you cannot stop when you view Ho's body but are forced to shuffle past two abreast.

Must do in Hanoi. You've got to visit this. The gardens and surroundings we're immaculate, and crowed control run with military precision. The respect they show for their leader HCM was moving.Free admission was a pleasant surprise and time in queue was not that long as it is very organised. Pleased we went.

Interesting, but not great. An interesting place to visit, and probably worthwhile if you have a bit of spare time in Hanoi. The guards are very strict and you tend to get "pushed" around most of the complex. The information boards are fairly poor, but the palace is reasonably pretty.

" Pay my respects & must do in Hanoi". One of the most important buildings in Hanoi is the mausoleum where the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is displayed. He was the prime minister and president of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (North Vietnam) and played a key role in the early part of the Vietnam War. Visitors are allowed to go into the mausoleum in the morning between 9 and 12 but – be warned – there is often a long wait. There are also strict rules in place, including a dress code. You’ll also have to leave your camera at the security office before you’re allowed to go in. It’s an eerie but quick experience once it’s your turn to enter. You have to continue walking the whole way through as you go around the body and can’t stop for a proper look. Guards will hurry you along if it looks like you’re about to pause.

Not the best to see, but worth killing time. If you want to enter Mausoleum, you need to go there early in the morning. It opens from 8:30 am to 11:00am. I went there in the late afternoon, and just walk around it. The environment is good and there is a museum on Ho Chi Minh nearby. The ticket price is 25,000 if I am not wrong.

Impressive!!. We had a good 1.5 h there walking around the mausoleum and visiting buildings as well as listening to our guide's interesting stories. A shame it was raining otherwise it would have been a very very pleasant walk around the complex.

A must in Hanoi, strange but interesting to see HCM. The big attraction in Hanoi - don't leave without attending, nowhere will you learn more about HCM than here - extravagant park and grounds surrounding the building lend the location to the political centre of any other capital city. Start at the mausoleum and work from there.

Hmmmmmmm!. Really wish I hadn't bothered. Walked 50 mins from hotel, got there and queues were enormous. Found out it closes at 11am and it was already 10.30am. Got in queue to be yelled at by a Japanese tourist who accused us wrongfully of jumping the queue (being British we are used to queues and would never dream of jumping in!!!)Waited in line for a while only to be pulled out of the queue with other female tourists to be told we couldn't go in because we were wearing shorts. What a complete waste of half a day in ha Noi. Having visited lots of Wats etc in Thailand they at least understand tourists may not be suitably dressed and supply robes. I think these guys had way more Vietnamese tourists than they can handle so don't care if the tourists get in or not!Sorry if this is a bit of a rant but I wasn't impressed at all!

Worth the wait. Long queue, raining, mixed reviews on Tripadvisor....but we went. Well worth the exposure to the reverence in which Uncle Ho is regarded. Queue moved very quickly and guards take their role very seriously - felt that was fair enough given what he did for Vietnam's history. View was clear on three sides and it was just as interesting seeing how the Vietnamese regard their experience - young and old. Complex process of confiscation of cameras and other possessions, but got everything back eventually from two widely separated sites. Overall, very pleased we went.

Waste of time. When we were dropped off at the mausoleum, we were surprised to see that there was a long queue. We waited for a long time before we were ushered in, and we were expected to place our bags at a station near the entrance. The staff at this station were rude and brusque towards me -- while I understand that it was a hot Saturday and she had to combat the crowd, there was no need to glare at me after giving me the luggage tag, or act like repeating oneself is a chore when I asked her to. This trip was simply an incessant wait to see one of the most overrated attractions. After queueing for an incredibly long time, at times under the hot sun, we entered the mausoleum to see the body of Ho Chi Minh. It was a complete waste of time and we wanted unnecessarily long just to see his body, and I was incredibly uncomfortable with this extravagant display. I understand why the Vietnamese people venerate Ho Chi Minh, but such an ostentatious display of his preserved body served to undermine his wishes and values, and this makes everything feel exploitative. Getting my bag after this encounter was a hassle because I had to walk all the way back to the entrance to get my bag in the heat, and two security guards gave me contradictory directions so I didn't know if I should continue on the demarcated path or retrace my steps back to the entrance. At the end, there was also a pathway for locals and foreigners, and I wondered why this was so, and that everyone's movement had to be so restructed. I also got yelled at a few times, and the language barrier served to exacerbate the situation. In fact, I was in such a bad mood that I did not want to see the other attractions in the area, like Ho Chi Minh's Presidential house. It was infuriating to get questioned everywhere I went -- I understood why, but this bordered on paranoia and greatly hampered me as I made my way to get my bag. The upside was that some guards were helpful and pointed the way, but most of the time, I felt like I was being questioned for no reason. I also thought I got lost in this large compound, and worried that I wouldn't get my bag back. I was also falsely led to another baggage station that didn't have my bag, and it was frustrating to finally obtain it. The long queues, walking time and getting fried under the hot sun was not worth it just to see the President's dead body. Do not bother with this attraction at all, visit the museums, cafes, or whatever else tickles your fancy.

What you expect!. Going to the Mausoleum was exactly what I expected - there are long queues but they move really fast. You are in the room for about a minute with guards moving you round quickly. It's worth going to see if you're interested, but certainly nothing will blow you away about it.It is still fascinating to experience, especially as lots of the people we saw appeared to be going more for spiritual reasons than as tourists.

Cover up!. Make sure you are covered up! The solider would not allow me in without more cover (my shorts went down close to my knees but he wanted my knees fully covered), I was also wearing a poncho where it was covered from head to calf. Sometimes you will see Ho Chi Minh's body and other times you will see a fake. You never know which one you will see when you go.

Unique experience. The outside of the building is giant and pretty ugly to be honest. Going inside to see the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh is a very unique experience. Be warned the line can be up to 2 hours and you'll spend about 20 seconds in the room where the body is. We went early and walked right in with no line. Make sure you don't wear short shorts and have our shoulders covered.

greatful to Uncle Ho. I have visited the Ho Chi Min square eveytime I travel in Hanoi . I feel so proud of him as the Great Human who always devote every minute of his to Vietnam and to the people..... I do love him and respect his gratitude to get his country free from the conquerer.....

Unique experience. Drab colored appearance.. It was a unique experience to visit the national leader of Vietnam Ho Chi Minh. I never knew you could visit this interesting mausoleum. You are able to visit before 11am. It's free to visit, you just need your passport. You should go early to avoid the long lines, but the lines go by pretty quick so it wasn't too bad. Once you enter, you are not allowed to take photographs or video which was a shame, but I guess it prevents from damaging the well-preserved leader enshrined here. The mausoleum itself is rather simple and built in a drab concert and cold-war style Soviet architecture. It's definitely a must if you visit Hanoi, but it's not as impressive due to its gray and drab colors.

Surreal experience. We arrived a little after opening at 8am. While there were a lot of people the line moved quite quickly. It is a bit of a surreal experience being taken into the mausoleam. There are guards dressed in white every few meters ushering everyone through. The room itself is dimly lit, very cold and seems to take on a different energy to the rest of the place. Overall a good experience and you can explore the presidential grounds and stilt house afterwards. We did buy a ticket to "explore the house" but later learned it wasn't required so don't buy the ticket!

It's alright, but the corpse is fake. We went there on a Wednesday morning. I looked on internet for dress code, and I was led to believe T-shirts and shorts were not allowed. So i wore a shirt with full sleeves and a jean. When we got there, the place was swarming with tourists and the men were in shorts + t-shirts. So if you're a dude like myself, you are entitled to wear casual tourist clothes, no problem.There wasn't much queue fortunately, and the entrance was free (read 10k on internet). You enter inside the glauque building and proceed to visited the corpse of uncle Ho. We clearly saw that it was fake, it wasn't "mouldy" or slighty dead, and looked like wax. So imho i would say it's fake.But still a fun attraction. Keep in mind vietnamese people come to see him because he was the one who liberated and unified the country. Not because he led the communist party to enslave the country and profit of it's people for future generations. I wonder what Mr. Ho would say if he could see what his pupil's have done to this country...

Massive. Was closed when I went but I was amazed at how gargantuan it was. It's a massive monument that shows the immense power of the Vietnamese government. Great experience (walking under the sun can get exhausting, though).

Interesting - a must see. Make sure you get to the mausoleum early, there are long lines and some stuff needs to be checked and can delay getting in, it's also quite hard to find the entrance felt like I was walking around the outside of it for ages! Don't take a lot of stuff and keep it in pockets to avoid bag searches and dropping things off at lockers etc.Be very respectful there are armed guards everywhere that will not take any trouble, as you walk through the mausoleum you cannot stop or take pictures hands are kept by your sides and no talking. You are constantly waking. You see ho chi mins preserved body for about 30 seconds tops don't expect gawping.You then move onto the grounds there is a small entrance fee with a map and you see his house old cars etc. depending how interested you are this can take you a while.

Strict Rules to see a Waxy Corpse. Very long line but moves fast. Very strict about bags, and everything larger than a small purse will need to be checked. Small cross-shoulder man bag ok. If your camera is larger than a tiny point and shoot, it too needs to be checked at separate window, then they deliver it to you after mausoleum. When you get there it's just him in a glass case. Then they usher you to museum. There was no way you could take pictures even if you wanted to, so not sure why a camera with a changeable lens is forbidden. If you don't want to go to the museum, you must walk all the way to the front to exit and all the way around the complex back to the entrance to collect your bag. the whole area is organized poorly, but I guess it's worth a visit. It is nicely lit up in red at night and it's also a place where locals practice their backwards walking.

A must for your visit to Hanoi. Amazing and slightly eerie to see Ho Chi Minh. The way the visit is organized is also impressive and adds to the experience. Organized by the army, with military precision and efficiency - fast moving queues, camera logistics (no photos inside but ok outside), no talking inside, two by two files and gentle encouragement to keep moving in front of HCM by the soldiers. A unique experience. Well worth the visit. Queues move quickly.

To be avoided!. The strangest museum I have ever visited! Nothing really made sense to me with lots of abstract art which appeared to have a very loose link to Ho Chi Minh, all very surreal! The layout appeared to be very haphazard with no real flow. There was also very few English translations so overall a disappointing experience and one place to be avoided if you don't have much time in Hanoi. The sign posting outside is very poor which meant we were unable to find Uncle Ho's Stilt House

Something you just have to do. Amazing place, we stood in line for 2.5 hours in sweltering heat, so line up and have a quick glimpse of Uncle Ho himself.... Crazy just you just have to do it... I think it's a waxed version of Uncle Ho myself.

A must see. This is a must see in Hanoi. We got there between 0830-0900 on a Thursday the que moved very very quickly and efficiently. Yes you do go through security and i lost my water but hay its was cheap. Very interesting to see Mr Ho Chi Minh and the way the Vietnamese organization of it was fantastic we should learn a thing or two.

Be respectful. . Probably the most important place in Hanio, be very respectful when you go here. Also make sure you leave earlier as it is only opens in the morning and afternoon for a few hours and you need to where proper clothing no singlets.

CONTRARY TO HIS WISHES!!. Ho chi minh wanted a simple cremation after his death, yet the government felt that displaying him to the masses was appropriate. It is only open for a few hours a day, and not opened on Mondays. The building itself is impressive, and you will see queues of people lined up to witness this gentle mans' frail body.

Go early the lines are impressive. We arrived by 9 and as we had employed a guide, he took the camera as we joined the line, 10 min walk and into the mausoleum - the covered queues could hold a couple of hours of queue easily - making Disney queues look like beginner stuff. Probably shouldn't have worn my American Eagle graphic t-shirt but no one noticed so no harm done. Rest of the site is a mix of propaganda, HCM's old cars and house, wasted on the non local - followed by some gift shops with no sense of propriety.

Important!! Bring appropriate clothes!. Please remember to cover your shoulders and wear a long skirt or trousers. I had such a stress near the mauseleum. I didnt know I had to go all covered inside, so went there with a top and shorts. The guard pointed at my bare shoulders and said 'No-no', so we had to go shopping for a T-shirt or something to cover my shoulders. Not many options near the mausoleum, but finally I bought a nice T-shirt at the shop on the corner across the mausoleum entrance (5$). When I went back to queue, the guard pointed at my shorts and said 'No-no' again. £$%^&*( Then we had to go shopping for trousers, but again, the cheapest option was 6$ and I didnt really need trousers,so finally we decided to take a taxi back to our hotel and get the clothes. It was cheaper, indeed. When we finally were in the loooong queue, it was already around 11 o'clock. Luckily the queue moved quickly. We went inside the complex and had to leave everything at the entrance: bags, camara, even water bottle. The queue moved forward very quickly and in around 10 min we were inside. I was funny, as so much rush to get to the mauseleum and you spend inside around 10-15 seconds. The queue just keeps moving, you are not allowed to stop inside, you enter, go around the glass box with Ho Chi Minh body without stopping and then just go outside. So much morning rush for 10 seconds of experience. Anyway, it was interesting. Just make sure to wear the appropriate clothes:))

Impressive to see. Visiting hours have to be checked. It's open in the morning. Although the rows looked a bit scarry long .. we were inside before we knew. Ho Chi Minh was really there and I even think he blinked en eye at us.

Dont miss out to visit the Mausoleum. THIS IS A MUST. Its FREE and open to everybody. However, they are only open for a few hours in the morning, so ask the hotel about the opening hours. Remember to bring cloths that covers to the knees and no less then a t-shirt.This is the closes you will get to a true communist feeling, so dont miss out to see the body of Ho Chi Minh.

Weird but definitely important to experience. It's hard to appreciate the degree of veneration for HCM in Vietnam until you visit the HCM Mausoleum complex--you'll find locals coming in their Sunday best and often waiting in line for hours just for a 30-second moment with what may or may not be Ho Chi Min's embalmed remains. I'd strongly suggest coming early in the morning on a weekday, especially if you're coming in the summer--doing so beats both the weekend lines and the afternoon heat. It's an absolute must to wear conservative clothing--for men, this means full pants, and for women, this means covered shoulders / skirts or pants covering the knees. A few people not keeping to the dress code were asked to leave while in line. Don't expect to stay in the actual tomb for very long--the line moves very efficiently.
Interesting but very rushed.. Iong lines, rushed through. Felt I was not given any time to see before being shoved along. Paid a lot - wanted to get my money worth.
Check out if you have time. If you are in Hanoi and have time to spare check out this place. The facade and change of guard is interesting.

Something to look at.... The architecture is interesting, and makes a good photo opportunity. But the opening hours are mostly in the morning, which means prime cooler hours before mid-day might be spent standing in line. And the soldiers blow whistles at people if they get too close. Not really sure it's worth the effort, but it is iconic Hanoi.

You Need to be Keen. After standing in the World Guinness Book of Records queue in the stinking heat without a water bottle, which was confiscated, and told to cover up when people in front of me had board shorts and tanks tops, you wanna be keen to see the dead dude.

Tourist. Amazing and a must see. His house and gardens maintained as they were at his death, everything still in its place. A peaceful place of great beauty. His crypt itself very moving with many people daily paying him respect.

A popular place. I had heard much about this place revered by the Vietnamese and, although I had decided I was not up for actually looking at Ho Chi Minh's remains (OK, I'm squeamish), I still wanted to see the building and surroundings.From the outside the mausoleum is an imposing memorial of granite/marble and is placed in the centre of Ba Dinh Square which itself is very wide. The building is protected by guards in white uniforms, and a large yellow line indicates the limit to how close you can get to them. I was quite lucky to time my visit with the 'changing of the guard'. It's an impressive display of synchronised slow marching. I was out-numbered of course - most of the visitors were Vietnamese coming to pay their respects to their past President. If you decide to go inside the mausoleum, be careful with what you wear (e.g. no short skirts or tank tops) and expect a security check. You mustn't talk, point, or take photos. Be respectful!

Standing in line with Vietnamese families. Visiting Ho Chi Minhs mausoleum was a special experience. It's a time consuming one too. Took me an hour to reach the end of the line. Waiting, I had some semi conversations with Vietnamese, that were also in line, trying to speak English and making pictures. Inside the mausoleum guards urge you forward, in rows of two. Left side is the inner lane, which passes Ho Chi Minh closest. More interesting to see how Vietnamese react and talk to them about it, than ot is to see for yourself.

Interesting and different, and a little scary.... Free entry, but we got there around opening time so the line up was huge, but gratefully very orderly and quick moving. Try not to take a bag or camera as you will have to check them in before you join the line to visit the mausoleum. There were a lot of military officials directing the line which were a little intimidating but to be expected. Ensure you cover your knees and shoulders and don't take photos. When you enter the mausoleum you have to keep walking in line, but you get just enough time to see the body which is quite a sight and something else to see. Not something you see everyday so worth the trip and standing in line!

Worth a visit.. It's a must do went in Hanoi, the queues are usually long but with free entry it moves quickly.Respect for the man is massive in Vietnam, great to watch the change of guard, go and visit and experience the feelings of the local people.

Bizarre yet fascinating. The visit of the mausoleum was for sure an impressive one. Make sure to wear appropriate attire and don't speak while passing by the corpse of Ho Chi Minh. It's a bizarre yet fascinating experience plus it's one of the rare places with a proper cold air conditioning :-)

Historic and Magnificent. Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum - which contains his actual body (preserved) - is a splendid tribute to a great leader. The building itself is fantastic, and adorned with garlands. The changing of the guard is quite cool to see also, if you can stand the Hanoi heat for long enough. Located on the grounds of the old palace, the museum and the very impressive One Pillar Pagoda. A must see place in Hanoi.

Must see!. We had heard this wasn't worth the line up.We would totally disagree, the lines moved quickly and efficiently and it was a moving experience to view the body of Ho Chi Minh surrounded by a military guard of honour.The respect shown by the guards to elderly people was very admirable, taking them by the arm and assisting them with the stairs.The gardens are lovely around the place and the sleeping house of stilts.I would totally recommend this as an important place to visit.

Ho looked good.. On the same trip with my uncle several years ago we stopped in to see Uncle Ho. This was a little creepy. He lies in state, in a dimly lite room with 2 armed guards. I must admit, for someone that has been dead so long he looked great. It was a drizzly day and the lines to see him stretched all the way down the sidewalk to the entry. Even then it took about 30 minutes for us to finally get into the building. I am not sure I would do it again, but if you dont mind the wait it is interesting to see.

Interesting to watch. The mausoleum is an interesting place. The change of guard happens at regular intervals(30 minutes) and is nice to watch. If you are in town check this place out but check for timings.

Free, so why not?. The lines were quite long when we arrived at 9.30am but they moved quickly and efficiently. You must leave any large bags or backpacks at the entrance butyou can collect afterwards. You will be shuffled through the resting place of Ho Chi Minh and you will get to view the body for less than 5 minutes. We noticed the closing time for Thursday eas 10.30am sharp!Not overly interesting itself, in my opinion, but he is an important man to Vietnam and it's history so it's something relevant to your travels through this country and I'd say the experience itself is interesting. IT'S FREE BUT at the end of the Mausoleum you get shuffled into the area with HCM's residence and park - this costs 25,000 vmd and we were told we HAD to go through this area in order to get our backpack back, suffice to say this annoyed us a bit!!

This you can't miss if you are in Hanoi. There is usually a wait and even that is fun - many school outings and groups are fun to watch while waiting The Mausoleum is striking and the even though Ho did not want a Mausoleum himself, the Vietnamese people insisted on it to remember him. They even got advice from Russia as to how to preserve the body in perpetuity. The area id festive and pleasant with much more parks, houses etc to see. You are whisked through the Mausoleum - no selfies with Ho.

Oh my word - you must visit this. We were encouraged by our tour guide to visit Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum & to be honest weren't fussed particularly as it was so hot. However we were so glad we went. It is all so well organised. You queue under awnings so are shaded at all times and the people are moved through at a dignified pace to ensure that there isn't s huge waiting time. We didn't appreciate that we would actually see Ho Chi Minh's body lying in state. The body is treated every year & considering he passed away 46 years ago, is in amazing condition. Soldiers in white move you through the mausoleum. No photos are allowed to be taken & knees & shoulders must be covered. Definitely visit.

Be prepared. Mauseleum is open only few hours in a day so you have to visit it in early morning, queues are also quite long. But overall this area is worth to visit anyway. park and surroundings are beautiful, many places to relax and eat. Big square is also very unique in this very thicky city so you will get nice pictures from mauseleum outside also. Perfect place to take a day-walk

Shock horror!. We visited Ho Chi Minh mausoleum as part of a tour. We didn't really think about exactly what we would see. The regimentation of the tour was a surprise - ILine up, remove sunglasses, don't speak, file past in single file. Then the shock! A waxy faced body looking just like Colonel Saunders of Kentucky Fried Chicken fame is laid out resplendently in full ceremony. Then we were quickly filed out without chance to really register we had seen the body of Ho Chi Minh who died in September 1969 and is preserved for all to see.

Impressive. Went there expected a bit less. But place is a big square with only one building and that is the mausoleum. The entrance is only till 4 or 5 pm. Its walking distance from lake if you dont mind 15 to 20 min walk.
A must. This is quite an experience and well worth doing. Don't let the long lines put you off, nor the macabre nature of the experience.

Worth doing even though a little macabre. It is an experience that at best gives you a feel for the respect the people still have for HCM. However, it does border on the macabre and I'm sure the mausoleum would receive far less visitors if there was only a tomb, statue or gravestone on view.

Prepare for long lines. A great place to visit on a sight-seeing tour of Hanoi, but prepare for long (I'm talking unconscionably long, Disney World-style long) lines. But even just walking around the perimeter, you get the sense of how much this man is esteemed still in contemporary Vietnam. The attached museum (where Ho's house, garden, and effects are on display) is also worth the 50 cents to visit and walk through as well.

nice try. Actually you will see a copy in wax since the real one is reserved for someone else. It is a must in Hanoi with some precondition. Everyone thought them will see the real one not knowing that they got to see the double in wax.

One of Landmarks in Hanoi. Nice place, it is well taken care of. Very calm and peaceful in the middle of Hanoi. The building the is cool but I would not come here. You are marched towards a room with a bunch of people. Also, there is no explanation, just follow the queue.

Interesting spot. Well it was interesting to go to this place and view Ho Chi Minh, crazy huge building for him to be his final resting place, considering he wanted a simple cremation. So I guess what's firstly important is to check the times that the mausoleum is open because there seems to be some conflicting messages around this and on the day we visited it was only open in the morning. So when you exit the mausoleum you end up at the entrance to the palace/museum/buildings which we had not planned to do but the alternative was to walk back around in the hot sun so we chose to pay and walk through the gardens, it was quite interesting to see the displays and it was certainly nice in the shade. Wandering around, seeing Ho Chi Minh has prompted me to read a bit more about him and his beliefs so I think that is always good when such a visit motivates this to happen. He's looking surprisingly good considering how long ago he died (perhaps a bit more wax like?).
Quite an experience. It was quite an experience being able to catch a glimpse of the great Ho Chi Minh other than seeing pictures of him
Not worth a visit. You are marched around a room with a bunch of people, no personal space, with no explanation to see Ho Chi Minhs coffin. Not worth seeing.

The father of a land. This is a most IF you come to Hanoi...IT means a LOT to the vietnames peopleIF you want to see the father of the land(it's special) then you must have long trousers on to show your respekt. Every evening at 09:00pm the gaurds take down the flag.Around the musoleum they think it's good"air" so LOT of people exercis there in the morning and evenings.

Average. Nice place, it is well taken care off. Very calm and peaceful in the middle of Hanoi. The building the is cool but I would not come here over and over again. Apparently this is a must see attraction but I would not go out of my way to see it.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum experience.. You can feel the historical value of the place, how the Vietnamese people value their culture.Unfortunately the guards cannot speak english that is why they cannot give instructions clearly. Hopefully in the future they know how to practice courtesy with people. Going inside, there should be a guide on what to expect inside the place. Overall the place is nice.

Worst timing ever. My father and I were really looking forward to visiting this while in Hanoi however we never planned ahead and it turns out the Ho Chi Mihn is sent to Russia each year to maintain his preservation and this site is closed during that time. We could only look at it from about 100m away and simply watch the changing of the guards. It was a HUGE let down but completely our own fault. Is on the list for our next trip in a few months :)

Very interesting, worth a visit. We were warned that no short shorts or sleeveless shirts were allowed and they were very strict about it, so we wore full length clothing in the brutal heat only to turn up and see that no one cared at all and we could've worn shorts. We arrived at about 9.30am and it took us about 20 minutes to get inside. Once you're close it gets very serious, I had to remove my shades and they didn't like you talking too much. You walk around the body slowly. It's pretty weird and creepy but worth it, I'm glad we went. The whole thing didn't take more than half an hour. I imagine in the peak season it will be a lot worse though...

Honoring a great man. The mausoleum looks like a concrete cubicle with columns. Inside the mausoleum lies the body of the great leader, Ho Chi Minh in a glass sarcophagus. There is forever a long queue of visitors who wish to have a glimpse of the great leader who liberated the People of Vietnam from colonialism. Photography is not permitted and you must take off your hats/ caps, no wearing of shorts or tank tops.

Worth the time. Very interesting and worthwhile. And, it's free! We didn't get there until 930 despite some of these recommendations but the line moved orderly and swiftly. Maybe because it was a Wednesday?

Must see attraction in Hanoi. Everything is so serious when you come to this building. everybody must stand in very long line just to go inside the building and no picture is allowed. The camera must be kept in the deposit area. Overall, don't miss this place if you visit Hanoi.

Priorities!!!. Was taken here by my guide. Didn't realise till too late! It's a place where someone's body is laid to rest after death!All this money spent, to show extravagance to an extreme! Me, I would have put up a head stone,or even a statue, and spent the money on social inequality, infrastructure, and JOB creation.When one is hungry/starving, and jobless, who cares about Ho Chi Minh, he won't/can't put food in your stomach!!!
Nice. Spent quite a bit of time here just walking around such a great place to a man of the people. History does not give him enough credit.
Ho Chi Minh died in 1969, still looks good. Do not smile, do not talk. Just keep your eyes straight ahead and be serious! Uncle Ho is preserved and protected by soldiers with weapons.

More Than A Mausoleum. I was fortunate before my visit to this cherished site by having a Vietnamese friend teach me the reverance the Vietnamese have for Ho Chi Minh. One evening, she handed my my iPad with it queued to a one hour documentary on him. I was flummoxed that we Americans were not taught more about him beyond newscasts about the Ho Chi Minh Trail. That such a beautiful monument exists to celebrate Ho Chi Minh's life is not surprising. Everywhere i visited in Vietnam--from north to south-- the young and the old alike asked me about him with love and affection. There was never any doubt in my mind that he remains significant to the population. The mausoleum is set in a very large urban park-like setting. During day and night, people are present; many exercising in the park, many just being comtemplative and others just being pedestrians passing by. Viewing hours are limited each day and the setting is somber. No photographs permitted. Guards are present and I was present for the changing of the guards one evening which was special. For an outdoor ( and much cooler) experience, i would suggest a nighttime visit. The monument is salient and well lit which I thought enhanced the experience. A trip to Hanoi should include this venue on your itinerary. And take the oportunity to learn about this leader and his simple objective, albeit one that complicated to achieve, i.e. freedom for the Vietnamese people from the colonialist powers.
Unique experience. It's a very unusual attraction, the body is well preserved and the schedule for visitors must be checked before heading to the mausoleum.

Mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh. When you come to hanoi, you need to know the important people in Vietnam. It is nice place, but make sure that this place no short, no photos. You need to queue before come in to inside of Mausoleum. I don't forget the place will be closed at 11 - 12 am
Not for me. There was a 2k queue in 36C heat, so we gave up and visited his presidential house and gardens instead.

Unusual and worthwhile experience. I got up really early on a Sunday morning to get to the mausoleum - when I arrived around 7.30am it was already very busy as I had expected! However, the mass of people is well-managed and I did not queue too long as it moved along at a good pace. I was very grateful for the shade! An enjoyable and fascinating experience throughout. Not just to see Ho Chi Minh (strange!) but in a way primarily to experience the atmosphere. The museum is well worth a visit afterwards.

Strange. Seeing the body of Ho Chi Minh is a surreal experience. You walk slowly under (mostly) covered walkways for a long time. I had about a 30 min wait. Eventually the line enters the mausoleum, and you file around the glass display case on three sides while uniformed soldiers look on.Guidebooks state that rules are strictly imposed but this is not true. You can wear shorts (mine were above the knee) and bring in a camera, but I don't think you can use it. There is a free baggage check. On the plus side, the mausoleum building has the best airconditioning in town! Just don't get lost on your way out, and DON'T take one of the taxis that loiter at the exit. Their meters run fast.
Queue moves very quickly! . Don't be overwhelmed by the large line! It moves very quickly! We went on a wet day and couldn't believe how fast the line moved.
Must see this. It is a must do to see this in Hanoi. Please note that you need to have covered shoulders to be able to enter
Long Distance Photo Op. Apparently the mausoleum is only open on selected dates/times. Be prepared to stand behind a yellow lone on the street outside and take long distance photos.

There aren't too many places like this on Earth!. Preserved bodies of leaders can only be found in handful of places on Earth - Mostly in communist countries. This is one such place. This alone makes it a visit to cure your curiosity. You will go in a queue (see below for handy hints) and file past the surprisingly well preserved body of Uncle Ho in a dimly lit small chamber. You will not be allowed to stop or take photos, talk etc. So make the most of it. Then it is all over.Now here are some handy hints.Do not get here on weekends or days when most Vietnamese are on holidays. The queues will be unbearable and you will wait for hours. A working week day morning or mid morning is ideal. We did and it only took us less than 20mins to go through!Opening times are short and only few hours a day. Check before you go.No bags allowed. You will leave your bags at the entry point for free to be collected upon return.No cameras allowed either. Cameras will be collected short way towards the Mausoleum and will be returned on the way out.Conservative clothing essential. Short shorts, skirts, open to and sleeveless t-shirts and garments are a no no. You will be turned back.If you have time walk to the front of the Mausoleum afer it is closed to the publick to see the ceremonial change of guards.

Maybe for the history buffs. This may be an impressive Mausoleum and it may be important for the people of Vietnam but I see no reason why one shall queue for hours and hours in the hot weather to walk pass a embalmed body. The structure is interesting and a view from a distance was adequate for me.

So amazing to see the body of Ho Chi Minh, very official and rich in history.. The mausoleum is guarded strictly by national guards. No short skirts, exposed shoulders or hands in pocket. Everyone must walk in two by two and there must be no talking. An eerie presence was surrounding the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. The actual mausoleum building is an amazing piece of architecture and you can almost feel the history as you walk around his well preserved body. A must see when visiting Hanoi. Of course no photography in the mausoleum.

Beware of opening times. We were taken here by the Hanoi Kids tour guides but didn't get to go inside as it is only open until 11.00 am and we arrived later. After talking to the tour guides we realise how important this Mausoleum is to them and therefore wish we had been able to go inside and pay our respects to 'Uncle Ho' as he is referred. The adjoining house was also closed from 11 am.

A Strong sense of History. Thee building is imposing. One can walk around the outside but once inside, people quickly shuffle past to get a momentary glimpse of the glass-encased remains of Ho Chi Minh. There is an air of patriotic pride for this man.

Loved it!. I'm fascinated by communist history so I had to visit this place. There aren't that many countries that have preserved their founder's body so I thought it was worth making the effort to get up early and take a look. Its only open in the morning. My friends and I went on a Sunday morning at about 9.30. This is the day many Vietnamese have off work so the queue was massive! At least 1km long. We decided we didn't want to wait for hours in the heat so we didn't bother. I came back on my own on a Tuesday and there was hardly any queue outside. Once I went through the entrance I queued for about 45 minutes. This isn't so bad because you can see the mausoleum and the Ho Chi Minh Museum and take some photos. They are both great examples of Soviet style architecture. Photos aren't allowed when you get close to the mausoleum or when you get inside.You’re only inside the building for about 10 minutes and you get to see the preserved body for about 1 minute so make the most of it!
Very Interesting. Good to see. Nothing a photo can't show you. Just make sure you are not wearing short dresses or shorts as my daughter was yelled at by a women during the marching ceremony.

Must-visit place in HN. If you come to Hanoi without visiting this place, it means that you haven't come here yet! One of the most unique monument in the world. But remember: no short-clothes inside, no photo or video recording, and remain absolutely silent!!

Awesome experience. We didn't knew what to expect but the whole experience was quite extraordinary. Never expect to see the body of President Ho so upclose and personal, just within 10 ft away. Now we have a better understand why Vietnamese people so respect him..

Mediocre experience. We did not get to go in to the actual mausoleum because "visiting hours" end at 11.30. It was impossible to go nearer than 50 m to the mausoleum, as uniformed soldiers will usher anyone away who get too close. We went to the nearby botanical gardens, it had some nice features like koi carp ponds and different plants and trees. The garden also contains a stilt house in which Uncle Ho supposedly had lived. All in all a decent but not great target for a day of sightseeing in Hanoi.

Queueing for nothing. Honestly go there if you are passionate about Uncle Ho. Yes he was a n inspired leader, but the mausoleum is honestly not a place you would find neither beautiful, interesting, inspiring or anything else. Once you queued for at least 1 hour you will walk by a window and a gard is pressing you to get out. 1 hour for few seconds, honestly not worth it according to me...

See what a taxidermist has done to "Uncle Ho". Sort of weird to see the man himself laying in the Mausoleum. Security is over the top. No camera pics allowed. Make sure you are fully hydrated as bottles of water are forbidden.

Respects to Ho Chi Minh. We queued for this as part of an organised tour but wouldn't have visited otherwise. There were many other walking to see and pay their respects(some with young children in the baking heat! You don't really have time to stop and look as you are ushered on by soldiers. The only plus is it is quite fascinating to watch the assumed power of the military in Vietnam!

A required visit. When we went to visit there was a special event so we were not allowed to get close.It was kind of eery in the rain & fog with no one walking around the area. Still an interesting structure & a must visit if in Hanoi.Remember no photography inside ever !!

Interesting to say the least. Ho Chi Minh embalmed in a Mausoleum.... If that doesn't peak your curiosity, I don't know what would! The hours to see Ho Chi Minh are very limited so remember to check the times prior to visiting as the lines can get long! Seeing HCM embalmed is worth the trip alone however there is so much more to see while on the grounds. I would recommend a trip w a guide who has knowledge of the area and can explain what you are looking at.

A strange wonderful thing. Do you wonder what Ho Chi Minh looked like? Well you can go see him. But is it him? My wife this it's wax, but maybe he's just well preserved. It's hard to say. The whole experience is a bit odd, you stand in a line where propaganda videos play, as you shuffle your way into the ugly tomb. It's a terrible building from an artistic stand point. It looks like an ugly Greeco-Roman building, very drab with none of the normal colorful South East Asian flourishes.You keep moving the whole time as you enter the tomb, a burst of cold air hits you. You walk around the body as guards watch and push you forward. It's a bit macabre, but really a glimpse into one of the last truly Communist touches in Vietnam.

A Must. Long line but kept moving and canopy provided for shade. Be aware - have to check ALL camera equipment as photography not allowed. Sorry as would have liked to photograph the wreath ceremony with the school groups - understand need to keep line moving and photos can slow down but felt could not capture some of the culture to share with friends at home. Worth the wait as this site so important to Vietnamese and helps understand the country and history.Make sure also visit all the neighbouring sites re Ho Chi Minh to better grasp the impact he had on country.

Good and Bad. The Mausoleum Building did not inspire us as Architecturaly it is rather average but it's not about the building its about Ho Chi Minh's body which lies in state inside. The security is very tight (no cameras etc allowed) and the ques are only for the brave - as this facility closes at 11 am one needs to be early. One can see the respect and love that the Vietnamese people have for HCM. There is a garden and house behind the Mausoleum which was where HCM lived. If ques and being searched often are not for you then give this one a miss however historically very interesting.

Morbid fascination . Really went out of curiosityLines VERY long especially during holidays but moves rather quickly Tips Go early, comfy shoes, Very austere but respectful to Ho Chi MinhAfterwards visit his residences

An obvious must. It's free, which is always good. The only thing is sometimes you have to queue up for quite some time. It's a rather bizarre but very interesting place where you'll see the preserved body of our former president Ho Chi Minh. After that, a visit to the museum is also recommended if you don't know a lot about Ho Chi Minh and want to find out more why he is still so important to our country even though he's not alive anymore.
A Must See. I think you should go and see this place as they still have the dead body of the loved uncle ho.local pople go and pay there respect.

Long queue for a 1-min visit. The Mausoleum was crowded with local and foreign tourists. We made a beeline to the entrance. Cameras and phones are prohibited in that area. The security is very strict. You can't even speak loudly or go away from the queue. The guard shouted at me as he found my bag suspicious (he thought that I brought something harmful?) and then he pulled me out of the queue to check my bag. Actually the officers had already checked my bag at the entrance. After that, I finally got into a solemn room where I could see the body of the national hero. You would have about 1-min to look at it as you must continue walking.

One of the must sees in hanoi. Its just one of those must sees in Hanoi. Make sure to also visit his house and gardens that are at the rear of this. Avoid the hottest part of the day if possible as you spend your time outside for this visit.

Appalling. This was included as part of a tour and the guide implied it was a highlight and not to be missed by anyone. There was a huge queue and we were shuffled from pillar to post before being given special access. Joining the queue we slowly traipsed past the embalmed corpse of Australia's wartime enemy under the supervision of armed guards, acutely aware that HCM had specifically requested that no mausoleum be built and that his body be cremated and scattered over the various provinces. I was disgusted.The rest of the exhibits were in better taste (especially his well preserved Peugeot 404 and his chopsticks and bowl) but only raise the rating to one star. Otherwise it would have been negative!

Historically interesting... And rather bizarre!. I was very much looking forward to a trip to Ho Chi Minhs mausoleum... It was a morbid curiosity I openly admit and I was naive not to expect too much security, how wrong I was! The use of any electical devices is strictly prohibited and and we had 3 bag seraches before we entered. We were then marched in twos into the mausoleum. I imagined we would be given time to actually look at his body however we had to continue walking to allow the next group of people to come in. There were also many guards lined up around the room who kept moving us along by pushing our arms which got really annoying after the 3rd or 4th time... The whole thing was over in less than a minute and I left more confused than I'd gone in. When were asked our Vietnamese tour guide some questions such as why Ho Chi Minh had been preserved when he wished for a simple cremation he deflected the question and told us it was difficult to explain the communist way of thinking to westerners. In conclusion, I'm glad I went, it was historically interesting... But looking back, the whole experience was rather bizarre.

A must see when in Hanoi. This was our first stop on a day long tour of some of Hanoi's attractions. The last entry into the Mausoleum is at 11.00am and the rest of the place including the museum closes at 12:00pm. Hence, it pays to be here well before 10.00am of you intend to visit all the places of interest. The place itself was very well maintained and showed the importance given to a President that was very instrumental in Vietnams freedom. The Mausoleum was a fine piece of architecture and the mood inside was quiet and sombre......it did feel like you were in the midst of greatnesss.The visit to the place where President Ho Chi Minh was also very interesting.Due to lack of time, we did not get to visit the museum but the visit was still very well worth it.We also had the priviledge of being accompanied by a very smart and knowledgeable guide from Hanoi Free Tour Guides who did a brilliant job explaining the history of Vietnam and the impact President Ho Chi Minh had on the people of the country.We are also told the Mausoleum is also closed on Mondays and fridays, so plan accordingly.
Respect.. Well there is a definable pride in how the people think of Doctor Ho. Humbling really to be able to talk to them about him and experience the pride they have in this man.
Very Moving Experience. Amazing morning seeing Ho Chi Minh in state, the museum, palace and ground all in one place. A must do in Hanoi.

A Curious Experience. It's ironic that Ho Chi Minh, who engineered Vietnamese independence and eventual reunification, stated that he wanted a simple burial when he died.Instead he has been embalmed, put into a glass casket, and is on daily public display in the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, a monumental edifice in Hanoi.When I say on daily display, that is not quite true. On an earlier visit to the Mausoleum it was shut because Ho Chi Minh's embalmed corpse had been sent back to Moscow for a "touch up".It seems strange to want to go and see a dead body, but this was a giant of 20th Century who took on the might of the French and then the United States and won, although he died before eventual victory.You must be on your best behavior when you go to see him. Dress conservatively and remove your sun glasses. Wait in line, which can sometimes be quite long, and don't laugh or chatter loudly, or you will be castigated by one of the guards. In fact it is best to keep a very serious and demure look on your face at all times,At the entrance there are bouquets of flowers for sale for you to place on the Ho Chi Minh shrine. I suspect that as soon as you have left they are recycled for resale to the next visitors. But it is curious to see many Vietnamese buying the bouquets and soundly banging their heads on the concrete floor several times as they place the flowers, copious tears flowing in the meantime.Once inside you must keep moving, so you basically take a slow walk past old Uncle Ho, resplendent in his simple khaki uniform and waxed make up, and marvel at the deification of this humble man.By the way, no cameras allowed inside.

Time Out !! . After all the touristic place ... Take time out to see Uncle Ho's mausoleum. You will travel back in time while seeing him and entire area where he spent considerable amount of time.One is amazed to see long queues of locals visiting this place early in the morning. We arrived early as well to avoid the rush but honestly i feel one should go around 8:30 or 9 am as the morning rush is finished by then unless there is any specific group coming in.One needs to take some time to see such places..

closed at 11:00 AM!! ridiculous!. Not sure whether it is the HCM house (old house) or presidential palace, but the one I went is just beside the HCM mausoleum. The mausoleum is fantastic, gave me goose bumps and eerier feelings to see how they can preserved president HCM body perfectly! The President seems like resting/sleeping peacefully.What i want to comment here is during my visit to the presidential (old house) where when i just walked in and strolling over the house area, trying to read and learn about HCM history, furniture, etc. suddenly me and my family were chased away/OUT from that area just because it's their lunch time, what?? Seriously, lunch time at 11:00 a.m??And how can a tourist spot can be closed for lunch time?? What???We paid 20K VD just to enter the HCM old house, yes it's very little money but it's NOT free!! But the mausoleum is free.At the end of my trip, especially at the HCM Square I can say I learned NOTHING!It seems that this place is 'NOT READY' to 'share' their history stories to the tourist yet. I was very disappointed during my whole visit. I was waiting to come to this place months and months before, and what I expect from this place maybe little higher than what they can give, probably. But, lunch time at tourist stop? hmm..Hopefully they will improved.My advice, just come very early, meaning 08:00 AM you have to be there at the Square already.

Different, unique and inspiring somehow. For something different, the Mausoleum is a unique yet inspiring place to visit. Locals (from all over Vietnam) would come here just to pay their respects to Mr. HCM. Some who live in Hanoi even come here multiple times a week!You can tell that the locals really respect and admire Mr. HCM, and it is sheer devotion and gratitude that many come as early as 7am (the place opens at 8am and the queue forms way beforehand). I visited at a time when it was summer vacation for the schools, so there were many children on excursions as well and the queue longer than usual.It is a solemn place and you do have to watch your behaviour, as well as attire. No flip-flops nor shorts (even bermudas) are allowed, so try to come in long pants and be clad in smart casual. I just found the experience quite a breathtaking one, and out of the ordinary. Definitely worth a visit if you have time in your itinerary - set aside a full morning if you'd like to explore the compound of the Ba Dinh Square as well.

Must dos , when in Hanoi. You should vist this mausoleum to understand the ongoing respect Vietnamese have for "Uncle Ho", and the. After go on to walk around his presidential gardens and very humble house on the lake plus the hanoi "Hilton prison" There is a lot of Vietnamese culture and way of life still influenced by Uncle Hoi and visit g here will help you throughout rest of Vietnam if you are touring. Ps absolute silence required in the tomb. It,s all very serious, and bags searched ..no cameras.
A little over the top.. I found this Mausoleum a little over the top, but I think the Vietnamese and most Communist would find it a most inspiring place.

You'll need more time than you think.... HCM Complex is a morning well spent in Hanoi. The Mausoleum itself cannot be entered without going through various security checks and in some instances leaving bags in designated lockers. Photos cannot be taken inside the Mausoleum, in fact people are marched, hands by their sides, in pairs and complete silence around the quick circuit which surrounds the glass coffin of HCM himself. The experience i a bit surreal and is over before you can count to ten but still worth it. Once inside the complex you can explore the grounds including One Pillar Pagoda, HCM's Stilt House and pond. A large museum dedicated to everything HCM. Very modern and unusual. Our visit took maybe 2.5hrs

Arrive early or queue!. A must see on your Hanoi trip. Arrive early or you will have a long wait. Well worht seeing Uncle Ho but dont think of taking a hidden camera! You will get about 20 seconds as the line never stops moving.Uncle Ho goes first class to France every year for a "tune up and face lift" so check before hand to make sure he is still in residence. Also the tomb is closed 1 day per week, Mondays last time I looked. dress conservatively, no shorts, exposed shoulders, open shoes or short dresses. You have been warned.I am only missing Lenin on the list of the Big 3 (Lenin, Uncle Ho and Mao)
So close to a great man. A moving tribute to an inspirational man. Long queues but well organised. Very hot, take an umbrella, hat and water.

One of a kind visit. . The queue is long, the rules are strict especially on clothing and the line can be very hot. But this is a one of a kind thing to experience while in Vietnam. The atmosphere surrounding the mausoleum is both respectful and a bit tense with guards surrounding the entrance. Once inside you can get caught up in what is obviously very special venture for the Vietnamese. The body itself is hard to describe and honestly I would urge you to go and experience it yourself. I would also recommend the Ho Chi Minh museum while has some stunning exhibits.
Going back in time. Very interesting but rather regimented. Give a good understanding of the history and dedication of the Vietnamese people.

Not on a school excursion day. We had to line up with all the school children and stood in line for 3 hours in 36 degree heat, make sure you ask if any school groups are going on the day you want to visit otherwise it is worth the look and make sure you have a local guide who can give you a historical coverage, and make sure you hand in your camera, you will get it back no problems

History. amazing to see his body - like he was buried recently ( as they re embalm him every couple of years) went with a tour guide so did not stand in line with hundreds of people who go every day.Women stick to the outside of walkway around body as not allowed close to him (at least europeans were told).

Interesting experience. Review on behalf of my partner...I was ill so couldn't make it. The Mausoleum is only open between 07.30am and 10.30am and closed on certain days. This means an early start.It was interesting seeing the dead corpse of Ho Chi Minh. What was much more interesting however, was meeting a Vietnamese family that took me under their wing and talked with me about life in Vietnam and really gave me a taste of what life is like for the locals.Definitely worth a visit.

It’s a nice area. A wonderful complex to visit Ho Chi Minh involving who was the first president of Vietnam. Inside the mausoleum cool air conditioning system preserving the body, requires quiet visitors to pay homage. Next is to visit old floor buildings where the president lived during his life. Finally to the museum where general relativity introduced a lot about the history of Ho Chi Minh and Vietnam modern country. A place should to go in Hanoi if you have time.
Macabre. A must if you are in Hanoi. Lines not as long as anticipated. Guards controlled our picture and belongings. Uncle Ho looks seriously pasty but you can't linger to get a detailed view.

Massive! Must see!. Few words to explain what you have in front of you: you walk by the old quarter or you reach the mausoleum from any other crowded part of the city and you face this massive land with nothing but this building on it!A wonderful contrast with the rest of the city!

must visitis. Nice place to visit. But you need to be quiet and obey all rules. Because it is a vietnamese historical place. It shows Mr Ho's body and it is strictly guarded. Near mausoleum there is palace of mr Ho.

faboulus place. I have visited the place with my famiry during our visit to vung tau.Its a nice place if you want to know vietnam history.It was surprise to see some indian books written by Dr.Rajendra prasad...Nice place to visit..

an atypical experience. this is a must-see especially if you've never seen an embalmed body (and no it's not a mummy). be prepared for queues (as in you move with the line), you'll also need to be dressed appropriately, covered shoulders and no shorts (preferably pants over knees but sleeved dresses and decent skirts are acceptable for women). nevertheless this is a great place to go to, and the one pillar pagoda and ho chi minh museum are nearby so kill multiple birds with one stone!

It's a beautiful monument.. I wish I had been here on one of the few days a years they open the tomb for viewing, but regardless it's a sight worth seeing. Ho Chi Minh actually asked to be cremated upon is death but the government felt he was too important and constructed this monument for him. Can't say I agreed or not, but the site is beautiful and it holds much significance to the country of vietnam.
My favorite place. Wake up in the early morning, queue up to visit inside Hochiminh Mausoleum. This is my first thing when i go to Hanoi.

Beautiful at night!. Apparently the mausoleum is rated the 6th ugliest building in the world, but after spending significant time walking around it and seeing it lit up at night (in communist red), I would have to completely disagree! Worth a visit, if only to photograph the outside. To see Ho Chi Minh, you must arrive early in the morning and wear appropriately conservative clothing.

Different but memorable. We went with our private guide who was very knowledge about the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, which we found very interesting. The line moved very quickly for the amount of people visiting, I didn't feel that I waited very long at all.The surrounding grounds are well manicured and a lot of history's within the complex.No cameras are allows inside. Must wear respectable clothing to enter (cover up) no sunglasses or hats when you walk in to the area which is a heavily patrolled by military guards.As we went to enter we had to stop whilst as the the laying of wreaths outside by the guards took place.It was a very different feeling when walking past Ho Chi Minh. There is no stopping once in side the mausoleum and should you stop a guard will move you along.Worth a visit and to see for yourself how well respected Ho Chi Minh is to the local people.

Surprised by the amount of locals that line up everyday to visit. Very long line but found a tour guide that got us to the front of the line for a little amount of money and once you get in there you are rushed through but found it interesting experience

Worth the Wait. Don't be intimidated by the long line that snakes around the complex for several blocks. It moves along quickly -- less than 45 minutes on a Saturday morning. Put your phones and cameras away as you near the mausoleum itself, they're not allowed. Putting the war history aside, it was an experience to be among the Vietnamese families paying their respects. A must-do in Hanoi, so plan your visit around the limited hours to be there at a time when it's open. Follow up with a visit to the neighboring Ho Chi Minh complex and museum.
Dead men tell no tales. Interesting place, everyone needs to go but once is enough. Ho had just come back from the spa in Russia, getting refurbished. No bags and no cameras allowed inside.

Surreal!. We did this on our last morning in Hanoi as we had heard it was quite interesting. It's free and you get access to HCM's house and various buildings and gardens. We had to queue for a while but luckily it moved pretty quickly, the mausoleum part only lasts about 2 minutes as you are ushered through. Hilariously there were about 4 school trip groups of tiny children being guided around (literally aged 2-3) who had no idea what was going on but that was quite amusing to watch. Overall a funny and slightly weird experience!

Interesting, but not worth the wait.. The inside of the mausoleum is only open until 10.30am due to the heat. We got there early but still had to line up for several hours as this is a pilgrimage for many of the local people. At some point they took our water bottles away too, as they aren't allowed inside. Things you should also know is that photos and speaking are not allowed, and you should have your shoulders and knees covered (so not shorts and singlets!).The viewing of the body is a very brief affair, and you must continue moving, I slowed down at one stage and a guard shoved me forward.It also not well known that the body you see is actually a wax replica, the real body is only displayed for VIPs.In saying that, it was an interesting experience, and there are other historically significant things around such as the Presidential Palace and some of the other homes used by Ho Chi Minh.However if you're just after a photo op, skip the lines and just walk around the complex, much faster and perhaps more rewarding.

People watch whole you wait. There was a long wait to walk past the body of HoChi Minh, and we were advised this was usual, as hundreds of Vietnamese visit the mausoleum to pay their respects. It felt right that did too.

A must... very interesting. The whole thing is well organised. The people visiting were th worst thing about this place. They were so pushy.The sight, lake and stilt house ia very interesting and the guide books provide an interesting take on the space.Be warned to cover up. You need to have your thighs and shoulders covered. Due to the heat my recommendation is to pack a scarf and wrap it around you as you can take it off later.

A bit eerie but worth a visit. We visited early in the morning; entrance is restricted to between 8:00am and 10:30am. When we arrived the huge queue just to enter the front gate was extremely off putting, the line was about 300 metres long. We'd read that it does move quickly so we joined the line. Officials were very efficient in keeping the line moving. You go through a security checkpoint, bags are x-rayed and you go through a metal detector. All cameras and bulky bags have to be checked in. Both men and women have to have knees and shoulders covered - no shorts or singlets - they monitor dress code strictly and some visitors were given smocks to wear to cover up. Once through security it was another long queue, stretching at least 500 metres. It took us a good half an hour but it was under the cover of awnings so we had some protection from the sun.As we were about to enter the mausoleum, the protection guards stopped everyone entering and we watched a group of Vietnamese war veterans lay a wreath and march into the mausoleum. It was great to observe this tribute to the past and see the respect locals have for this monument.Once inside the mausoleum you have to keep moving and aren’t allowed to talk. Protection guards continually move you. In the centre of the mausoleum lies the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh himself, laid out behind glass. It was a bit eerie seeing his body laid out like that. We were also fortunate during our very brief visit to see the changing of the protection guards that surround his body. For all of the queuing we were only inside the mausoleum for mere minutes but it was something a bit historic and different to see.Within the complex you can also visit former residences of Ho Chi Minh, including the old Presidential Palace, and there are well planned and laid out gardens and a lake. The visit to the mausoleum itself is free; you only have to pay if you want to see outside the Presidential Palace.Glad we took the time to include a visit to this site.

A must see on your trip. Respect is the key here. You must wear respectful clothes or they give you scarves to hide legs or shoulders. Minimize bags as they can take them off you. Do not take photos whee you are not supposed to do so. Long ques so go early. Bu tours seems to have priority but the ques move pretty fast. Shade is provided on the way in, thank goodness.
