Gaurds on duty. I was taken in by the vast open area in front .The guards were on duty and look like statues. The building is full of history and the gardens were so manicured and well kept, just sit and reflect the atmosphere around you

Unique . If you are keen to see HCM preserved, go ahead. It is a unique and swift experience. At the same time a respectful experience for many locals. But be mindful on weekends it could be a long wait. Get there as early as possible. After two attempts on a Sunday of arriving at 9.30, I still wouldn't have made it in by 11am. And the heat this summer was horrendous so was not prepared to wait.I managed to get in on a week day though when it was less busy.Remember to cover your shoulders and knees ladies! There is no stopping to look at him once inside. The line moves at a steady pace. However try to stand in the inner (left) of the two lines for a better view.

It wasnt something I really wanted to see but I'm glad I did. Its a totally surreal thing to go into this mausoleum and see Ho Chi Minh guarded 24/7. It did stir up a bit of emotion to see how much the Vietnamese people love him. I'm glad we went to see this. But beware of walking across the square itself, the guards dont like that.
Didn't see it. Unfortunately at the time of my visit the mausoleum was not open, he was getting his yearly touch ups. Only good for taking pictures outside. Boring.

A memorable but strange experience. This is something that is difficult to put words on - you wait in line for an hour with thousands of Vietnamese coming to pay their respects, and as you pass by the guards you come to see Uncle Ho's perfectly preserved, made-up diseased body in the dimly lit room for just a matter of seconds - but the experience is absolutely worth it. It leaves you with a deep eerie feeling of just how much this man, or demi-god was respected

Interesting!!. I didn't really know that I was going to see the "real" Ho Chi Minh and it was a very long line, which moved quickly and the most controlled environment, so people wont push in! (very unusual culturally) -it was holiday time for schools so there were many locals there for the pilgrimage. I actually found it a pretty powerful experience as I know how much he did for the country and how the people loved him. It shuts at 11am every day so go early.
Fitting tribute to Vietnam leader. Unfortunately closed the day we visited but the nearby museum was worth the visit and a fitting tribute to Vietnams beloved Ho Chi Minh
hochi minh. we waited in line for about 2 hours in the rain and the covers over the walk way was only material so we got wet, just to shuffle past a body that looked like wax

Worth visiting for curiosity value. Well, it's not every day that you get to see Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body....This is a massive deal for the Vietnamese and gertainly not a tourist attraction. Apparently you can queue for hours at a weekend, but on a weekday morning it took us no more than 15 minutes or so. Like I said , not an everyday sight but worth doing

Proud people. Not to show any disrespect, but Standing in very long lines for a long time to see the body of Ho Chi Minh was not very exciting. It was interesting watching the women lawnmowers on the grass across from the monument. They were trimming it by hand.

Impressive. Be sure you pay attention to the visiting hours because the mausoleum isnt open every day and only on certain hours. So i was unlucky when i wanted to visit on my last day...just closed..and from what i read here i misses something special..maybe another time. I can say that the building is impressive, high security and strict rules. Theres a lovely garden next to it which you can visit. They still love their leader very much thats for sure. If i have a next chance i sure will visit.

Loves it!. I booked a visit the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum with a tour and I'm awfully glad I did because it would have been extremely difficult doing it by myself. The line moves fast even though it was a 45 minute wait. The building is air conditioned and Ho looks better preserved than when I saw Mao five years ago. An honor guard surrounding him on the second level in a glass coffin lined with ornate wood. Must go here.

Extremely Impressive. This is one of those places that make the hairs on the back of neck stand up. It is grand beyond belief, probably no other country has anything as impressive to entomb a ruler except the pyramids.It's a very structured tour but well worth it, go in the morning as I believe it is closed in the afternoons also be prepared for very long lines (they move quite fast though) and it has this air of quietness about it, if you were to get a bit too rowdy I think you would get kicked out or even locked up.

Strange experience but worth it I think. Watch out for weekend queues, very very busy at the weekend.The queue does move quickly though, so don't be too put off.You will have to hand in your bag, then later your camera, you pick the camera up again straight after and your bag when you're ready to leave the site.

Would Uncle Ho have liked this?. Took us about 30 mins to get to the Mausoleum. It was interesting to see the reactions of the Vietnamese, the formality and the organisation. Very orderly, respectful and then after the viewing it was like the cork had been taken off a bottle of fizz. Seeing the gardens, his house etc was very interesting and well worth a visit.. Its an interesting monument built for someone who perhaps would not have wanted to become an object of veneration.. Go see. It was worth the visit

Well worth a visit. This is an absolute must if you visit Vietnam.There was a long queue when we visited however, the queue moved quickly and the guards keep good discipline and it's in the queues that you get to understand just how Important Ho Chi Minh was as the founding father of Vietnam. Highly recommended!
Not my usual adventure. I found this tour interesting. It's worth a look but once was enough. Best to have a guide to explain things.

The Father of Vietnamese...Mr. Ho Chi Minh. We visit the Mausoleum before traveling to Hue. We can see the queue outside the area and expecting to wait for so long but surprisingly the queue was moving fast and quite organized. Ho Chi Minh is so loved by the people of Vietnam and they are willing to stand under the hot sun to visit his last resting place. We are not allowed to make noise inside the Mausoleum and is just a quick go through the room. Good experience to know more about the Father of Vietnam especially if you are with the tour guide who understand the history and can explain well.

Prepare for a long wait. Lined up for about an hour or more to get through but was worth the wait for the quick walk past Ho Chi Minh. Ladies, don't forget to cover your arms and legs (grab a scarf for a few dollars at the market stall near the entrance). The grounds are stunning and the history is interesting. Don't expect to be allowed to stand by the body, it's a quick glance only and he is heavily guarded. So happy we went and paid tribute to a really well respected man. Note you have to pay a few dollars to walk through the gardens - they only seem to charge Westerners but we were more than happy to pay up. A few hours well spent. I'd recommend the visit.

Limited information available . I left this attraction with quite limited information. I visited with a guide who did not provide much information, but there was also not much written information. The site is immaculately presented, as are the staff who instruct on correct etiquette, which was appreciated. Very busy and very warm in early June.

Not recommended when hungover. Far too humid in June to wait for over one hour. I would suggest a madam Tussaud version with a shorter line. Probably good idea to learn a bit about the man before rocking up to this. Air con in the mausoleum was the highlight.

Worth a visit. We went on a Sunday morning. The queue to Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum was the longest queue I have ever seen. We just visited the grounds and museum. Try going in the afternoon, it is said that the queue is then manageable.

Don't go past the yellow line. We walked all the way from the old quarter to here only to find we couldn't enter and didn't know why. The guards were unfriendly and made sure we didn't walk over a yellow line near the steps to the entrance.

Ticked off the list. We had hired a guide for a half day tour & our first stop was the mausoleum. We hadn't really intended on visiting, as seeing a dead man wasn't high on my Vietnam to do list. It was a Sunday & there were huge queues but it didn't take long & we were inside. Pushed through by the guards my friend & I both commented on how peaceful he looked & then that was it-we were out again! Wouldn't do it again but glad we experienced it.
loved it. ho chi minh is still there looking like he did in 75. very nice building and long line. our tour guide got us up front of line. i would go back no question

A Site Worth a Visit. We were two couples visiting the Mausoleum. There is no question the army staff guarding the shrine treat the shrine with great reverence and dignity, and the lines walking through are told in no uncertain circumstances to do so themselves. No cameras etc as you would expect. Not having seen Lenin's or Mao's mausoleums we could not compare. Is he the real person, only you can decide. Outside the mausoleum there are gardens etc, which as always in Hanoi are an extra charge with no photos allowed from outside the gated walls. How much should a photo of a garden or villa cost..um?

Lifes too short. With the queues we encountered, as a group we all agreed " no way ". By the time you got in there you would probably be in the same state as Ho Chi Minh himself.However to see the surrounding grounds & where he lived as well as the old French palace had the camera clicking.
Worth a visit. We would not normally visit a Mausoleum, however it happened to be the 125th birthday of Ho Chi Minh and we were pleased to have experienced along with 1000's of Vietnamese

Why. Disappointing visit to this very anticipated location. With a group tour on a very humid Hanoi Sunday this was always going to be a challenge- the queues were horrendous and the wait interminable and once in it was surreal- I am not a fan of seeing dead people so this may cloud my judgment but this is a disappointing venue.

Long lines but with the wait. The history is fascinating and understand things from the vietnamese perspective was well worth this visit. I think tourist were out outnumbered 10 to 1 so this is an important cultural place.Understanding more about Ho Chi Minh and the way he lived gave me a better appreciation of what he was trying to achieve for his people. Seeing how he lived was more significant to me than his body. Oh and pease be respectful when you visit. It was embarrassing seeing westoners ignoring the etiquette in the mausoleum.

worth a visit. we spent over an hour in the blistering heat and being prodded by Vietnamese soldiers but it was actually worth the discomfort. Clearly a very special place to the Vietnamese and as western tourist you actually become an attraction to the many local schoolchildren. We visited as part of a city tour and it was a very enjoyable trip.

Worth the wait. This place is very secured to the point that you will feel uneasy with the place specially if your a solo traveler. But i do understand the need of this place to be secured and organized. The long wait on the queue definitely worth it to pay respect to the man.

A cool place in a hot world. What an experience. Throngs of people lined up for almost an hour to file by their iconic leader for a quick viewing. Ho's body looks like a wax model, guarded by many seriously dedicated soldiers. It was also a great way to escape the heat as Hanoi was over 106 F that day! Lucky Ho, basking in the AC.

Crowded but interesting!. We visited the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum the day after Ho Chi Minh's birthday so it was quite busy, although I'm sure it probably is all the time, lots of school groups visiting and everything is very ordered. We had a guide with us who explained a lot about Ho Chi Minh and it was interesting to see how simply he lived. Well worth a visit and walk around the gardens.

Single file, lots of security to see Uncle Ho. The grounds are beautiful, and the security is tight as you take a long to visit a man who has been long gone. Interesting to see how these people still worship this former leader.
Be courteous. Nothing to do here but to see and pay respect to Ho Chi Minh. the place is air conditioned and has strict military security.

Uncle Ho, worth the wait. Amazing to be able to pay respects to the man.Timing is very important to avoid very very long queues and the closing times.Free to the Mausoleum, cost at the Palace if you want to see it at the end (non Vietnam only). I used the exit after seeing Uncle Ho so cannot score the Palace.

Worth a visit. Difficult to find where the huge queue started but a friendly guard chucked us in the line. You have to be careful what you are wearing and make sure "respectable" as they check very carefully. The queue moves along quite fast so don't be put off by its length. You only get a few minutes viewing the body but that's enough. A local tour guide on an earlier tour told us that most locals think that it can not be the real thing after all these years! Anyway, if you are visiting the Presidential Palace then it is certainly worth going to the Mausoleum. Don't forget it is open in the morning only.

Must See. IMHO this is a really interesting stop in Hanoi. We had to stand in line for awhile and we got bossed around by soldiers who were keeping everyone in line and respectful. It is very obvious you are in a Communist government controlled city...a VERY different "vibe" the down South. Nevertheless Hanoi is awesome and this is one of the must see spots

Very secured historical place. The que for entrance is quite long so you must prepare hat or umbrella and fan and drinks to expell the heat.The drinks will be asked to be thrown away in the security entrance. All bags will have to be examined and keep in the locker before you could enter the complex. In the way to the mausoleum, you must line up for two people and after enter the mausoloeum, you should be quiet and keep flowing with other people (no stop).

Worth seeing especially if the line isn't too long.. I liked seeing his house, and the gardens. Beware the hours are limited, and it isn't open every day. Opening hours8-11am Tue-Thu, Sat & Sun Dec-Sep, last entry 10.15amRead more: http://www.lonelyplanet.com/vietnam/hanoi/sights/cemeteries-memorials-tombs/ho-chi-minhs-mausoleum#ixzz3bwGJQsvU

Highly recomended!. It was an interesting visit to view the body of Ho Chi Minh. His body is in great condition and you really only get to file past. I was very humbled and honoured to be able to visit. Highly recomended!

Because you are in Hanoi go see it. More security here then you'll see anywhere else. Long lines move very quickly. You file in and up and around until you see the lifelike figure of Uncle Ho. Then you file out and that's it. No pictures, no loitering. Over and done in about 20 minutes. Optional grounds to visit outside for a small fee. That was ok, something to do, but lots of people.

Longest Queue ever!. We queued for 2.5 hours and 2.5 Kilometres. It was the bank holiday and Vietnam was celebrating 40 years of peace! It was worth the effort. You learn an awful lot about people when you queue with them. So many are kind and helpful, some are just plain selfish. It was quite an awesome sight, Ho Chi Minh himself. Venerated and embalmed, totally against his expressed wishes.

Don't go on Sundays. I'm not sure about other days, but on Sundays, this place makes lining up for iPhones or Justin Bieber signings look meagre. Thousands upon thousands of Vietnamese descend and line up to see their leader. It is almost worth going for that spectacle alone I suppose. It is bizarre. Needless to say we didn't see the mausoleum or Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body. Disappointed.

Very intersting. We found it very interesting visiting the mausoleum and its surrounding palace and gardens, even though it was very hot.It was the 40th anniversary of reunification the day we went so the mausoleum was closed but we still followed through the palace and the grounds.We were amazed by the number of Vietnamese visiting the complex, even though they could not view Uncle Ho’s body.We shuffled along the paths with all the other tourists, it was crowded.Worth a visit if you have the time in Hanoi.
Must see. If you are in Hanoi a must do. We visited the week of his birthday so lots of official parties and school children... but a surreal place to visit.

Very memorable experience, and very well organised.. We were escorted to a very organised queue, no fee and slowly made our way to the Mausoleum, and was in awe of the peaceful gentleman in the state of "sleeping" - very moving

Tribute to a great visionary. We were unable to enter the mausoleum, however the impressive building, the guard of honour and the reverence and respect paid to the champion of Viet Nam, have left us with a long lasting impression. It is a must see.

Very long wait!. We waited two hours in the line. So very hot. No water, so bring your own. Be prepared for people to cut in front of you. Also, you can exit without having to pay for the garden at the end. We were the only white people in line. So felt very authentic and not so touristy.
Ticking another box. Having been to Mao's and Savages mausoleums felt I should see "Uncle Ho's." Worthwhile but you cannot get to see him as we could Mao

interesting. The precession past the tomb of Ho Chi Minh, was long but moved smoothly.
The museum tour, we hired a guide at the ticket desk, value for money a must. Ho Chi Minh was a very busy and interesting man.

Amazing. After queuing in the stifling heat for about 30 mins, you enter the cool, air conditioned mausoleum. Armed guards at the entrance with serious, stone like persona. Marble floors and walls, you walk up a ramp into the room where Ho Chi Minh's glass sarcofacas is on view. It's incredible how they preserved his body, it looks like he's just sleeping. I didn't know this was possible. I was awe struck.

Worth the long que line. We visited the mausoleum at around 930 am on a Saturday. It was crowded, and bear in mind that this time around Vietnam is very hot, noon can get up to 39 celsius. Patiently wait, an hour and half later we get to see the late Mr. Ho Chi Minh. Many guards around. No professional camera allowed, and Idk why, no iPad allowed. Its the thrill of looking at the late National hero himself, as if he was sleeping.

Not in Residence. No access as the embalmed body had been removed for its annual maintenance and makeover. Given a brief history of the facility and how the Vietnamese Government did not comply with the simple wishes of HCM. Typical communist morbid edifice

A strangely wonderful experience. Upon our arrival our hearts sank at the enormous queue stretching out before us. Our guide assured us it moves quickly, but after an hour of standing in the searing heat while strings of esteemed personages were allowed to cut in ahead of us (I believe this was due to the impending birthday of Ho Chi Minh, we arrived on a day when many officials had come to pay their respects,I don't think this would be a usual event) we were about ready to pull the plug, and had our guide been within reach we definitely would have. However upon entering the cool calm of the mausoleum we were instantly transformed. We filed slowly into a dimly lit room where a large wooden ornate glass sided casket housed Ho Chi Minh himself. Four guards dress impeccably in their rather splendid white uniforms stand silently at each corner of the casket. I have to admit our ignorance at this point as neither myself or my husband knew much of Ho Chi Minh or an awful lot of his work, however we left the room where he lay in state totally in ore and touched by this somewhat surreal experience. From the mausoleum you proceed to explore the grounds and the house where he spent his final years. The lake and gardens are nice to walk round although not particularly vast. From there you walk down to the one pillar pagoda. We enjoyed our visit very much and felt we would have missed out if we had not persisted with the fairly hellishly hot queue.

A line miles long. We intended on visiting the mausoleum, but the line was forever long. It's only open for about 3 hours a day so everyone is visiting at the same time. We decided not to go, but still took photos of the outside.
Fast moving line that is covered. The line moved fast and is covered overhead to protect from sun and rain. On a very busy day it took 20 minutes to finally get through. Adequate viewing time.

Glad I went!. I'm glad I went - the Vietnamese people love this man and so it felt right that when visiting Hanoi you visit the man himself Ho Chi Minh! The lines got me a bit worried but they move fast - be sure to wear something that covers your shoulders and your knees or you will be disappointed as they won't let you through to see Ho Chi Minh. May not be for everyone but I was so glad I went.

Worth a look. Well its about Ho Chi Minh who was vietnams good prime minister as the locals say it. He didn't want the tax payers to waste money on him for a burial, but when he passed on the current ministers at the time wanted to preserve his body so they got the german scientists/doctors or Swedish may of missed that bit. No much sit downs if you wanted to have a seat.
Worth a visit. Interesting complex and good museum, good insight into the Vietnamese history and party propaganda. The one pillared pagoda and a stroll through the garden is a must

A serious and sober national shrine. Thee is usually a very long line and you need to wear modest clothing. You can have your camera in your pocket but cannot bring in a bag. No pictures allowed inside the mausoleum. While you wait on line you may see schoolchildren making their annual visits, and decorated veterans coming to pay their respects to the father of the country.
This is just like any other dead body show. May be thats the only just to avoid sight in hanoi, just to see dead bodyit dpends on your fafourite sights but thats not mine

Don't be put off by the que. Make sure you check the opening times as it is only open the first part of the day. We arrived on Sunday and nearly turned away because of the que that snaked back round the part. The que does move quickly but prepared to be turned away if in appropriate clothing is worn. No short shorts or skirts & shoulders to be covered. Although you are only in the room for less than a minute it is worth the experience & interesting to watch others react to seeing their great leader.
must see. excellent place to visit, very interesting place very clean and a popular place for sightseeing ,would be nice to visit again in cooler weather
Big place. A large square to show the grandeur of the place and all the dedication and admiration the Vietnamese people has for its hero.

Nice to heave. If u are interessed to see mousoleum u have to come early, especially on the weekend. The opening hours only between 9 and 11am. And a Lot of vietnamese People and visitors want to see the sleeping HCM. It's nice to see but mit more.

Cool Place. We went in the afternoon and just walked around the place. It was pretty cool to place to spend an hour or so walking around. The park was really beautiful too. I would recommend checking the times when you can go in and see Uncle Ho's body before visiting. Don't make the same mistake we did.

The Late President. Some may find this tour interesting and poignant (as I did) but others may not. It is a place of homage for Vietnamese people so is very busy and long queues may occur, When I attended many parties of Vietnamese school children were also visiting and they were very happy to try out their English. The mausoleum is situated by a large parade ground and lovely landscaped gardens. There are very strict rules that must be obeyed and soldiers in attendance will enforce them. No cameras, smart phones or video recorders are allowed inside and there is a strict dress code. I was travelling with the tour company APT whose guide advised us on how to present ourselves.prior to entering. For me, being a retired forensic expert, it was very interesting to see an embalmed President Ho Chi Minh lying in State.
very interesting. very grand. The grounds were beautiful. Our guide outlined the history of President Ho Che Minh and what he achieved for his people
A good cultural experience in Hanoi. We had a really nice afternoon at the Mausoleum. Only cost 25,000 dong (70p/$1) and definitely worth a visit. The gardens are free to walk around and very pretty.

Interesting. Visited the mausoleum on HCM's birthday, and an extremely hot day. The crowd was moved along, and we were not lined up for too long. The life story of HCM is interesting, and to see where he lived, and how he chose to live a simple life shows how much he was humbled by his position. Lots to see in the grounds and well as the mausoleum.

An experience. To enter the Mausoleum itself is free, but it is only open on some days of the week, always closing at 11am. We went on a Sunday. The lines were very long, but moved reasonably well, given that this was the weekend of Ho Chi Minh's 125th birthday celebrations and there were hundreds more Vietnamese than usual coming to pay their respects. We were in line for about 3/4 of an hour. Viewing Ho's body is a matter of about 2 minutes, the immaculately white-uniformed honour guard keeping the line smoothly moving. It is clearly of huge significance to the Viet people despite Ho himself, a man who led a simple life, not having wanted any such cult around him, stating in his will that he wished to be cremated.The park surrounding the Mausoleum has an entrance fee to visit Ho Chi Minh's houses, the Pagoda etc, but is well worth it.If you just want to look at the Mausoleum building itself, this is possible from outside the park.

An Interesting Experience. I would recommend this experience. We caught a taxi from the Old Quarter - means you get dropped off at the "entrance" rather than the actual Mausoleum. Got there at 8am and was in first 20 people. I was expecting our bags/cameras/phones to be taken off us, but we just had cross shoulder bags which got scanned and the only thing we couldn't take with us was our water bottles. It seemed that people with backpacks had to check them in to the storage room. So I would recommend travelling light, then you can keep your valuables with you (but don't dare take your camera or phone out, especially in front of the guards). While waiting in the queue it was entertaining watching all the little school kids getting ready for their visit and their teachers trying to keep them in order!

Well worth surviving the wait in the very long queue. This mausoleum had been on my 'bucket list' for many years. The building was much bigger than I had expected. It reflects the high regard the Vietnamese have for this charismatic man who did so much to modernise his country. The size of this building was only one of the features. Another was the number of armed guards policing the strict rules regarding silence (particularly no laughing). The third was the sight of Ho Chi Min's body lying in 'state'. (Apparently just returned from his annual re-enbalming in Moscow.)
Beautiful grounds..... We went to visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum a huge Mausolem it was pretty cool... beautiful grounds you can walk around with a pretty Pagoda... very well maintained... Enjoy!!!
必見. 土曜日日曜日　朝７時から１０時までの公開ですit opens on only Saturdays and Sundays, from 7-10.

Odd . This was a very odd day we joined a queue about 2.5km to go in and when we arrived we say uncle ho himself in a glass coffin very strange to say the least, a lot of armed guards and a feeling you shouldn't be there all in all glad we did it but I don't think we'll be goin back anytime soon

Essential understanding Vietnam today. The queues move quickly the guards keep good discipline and it's in the queues that you get to understand just how Important Ho Chi Minh was as the founding father and inspired leader of this fascinating country...... The mausoleum and Lenin style embalming was everything that Ho Chi Minh did not want - he wanted a simple cremation and for the world to move on...... So for a nation where most people work dawn till dusk six days a week giving up your Sunday to visit a tomb is really quite something and there is never an un busy time ...... The experience for a westerner is almost surreal it has no context in our general experience but I'd queue again just to observe over weight over bearing Americans unsuccessfully trying to exert queue discipline over tiny little Vietnamese women who may well have fought them in the war taking their grandchildren to see their much loved leader. It's a perfect demonstration of how the two cultures never did and never will understand each other

Too crowded. Not sure what is so interesting about this place for non-Vietnamese. We were there during Vietnamese holidays, and the line was EXTREMELY long, so we did not visit the inside, only the outside.

Hot queue. Had to queue for about an hour, the walkway is covered but you''re not able to take water, camera or large bags we left ours with our tour guide from Selective Asia. If there are Vietnamese school children trips then these have priority and the queue is stopped to let them through so can add to queuing time. The changing of the guard happens on the hour and this is quite theatrical to watch.The actually viewing is quite quick with everyone filing past and the guards making sure respect is given (take off your sunglasses & hat and no noise until back outside)and the queue keeps flowing.Definitely worth a visit but make sure you check opening times/days beforehand.

Make sure you check the opening days and hours. We went from Old Quarters by taxi and cost Dong40,000, which is correct. Make sure you don't take the taxi company Phuong Nam! They're cons! However, we went on a Friday and it was closed. Hence make sure it's open before you go. And the last entry is 10.15am

long line ups, get a guide. Understandably, for the local people, this is a "must see". For foreigners, the museum and historical exhibits are worth visiting, although you really need a guide to explain what you are seeing. The queue to actually enter the mausoleum was long. It took us about 40 minutes to get inside. Once there, the guards strictly hussle you around the room in two rows. Some tall men were in front of me, but when I moved across so I could see a bit, a guard grabbed my arm and shoved me back again. After that long wait, you are actually in the mausoleum for less than a minute, and may not see anything if you are stuck in the outer line.Unless you really want to see Ho's body, I wouldn't bother going into the mausoleum itself. Just visit the other places in the complex

Interesting place to visit. It was quite surreal to see Ho Chi Minh. We were very lucky to have no queue when we went (as i had read that the queues can get quite big at peak times). We were a little confused at some points about when we had to give our bags/ cameras in to various booths to comply with rules - managed to figure it out. It's worth looking around the grounds after you have been in the Mausoleum and the gardens are beautiful.
Understand Vietnam. It is not really breath-taking but it is part of Vietnam history and helps to understand the country and people. Therefore should be seen.

Worth the long line up. Maybe it's because I've never had the privilege of witnessing such a thing but although I waited over an hour in the heat, the quick shuffle through the air conditioned mausoleum was a bit somber and inspiring. I went during the 40 yr liberation too so al the museums and street party was a good lead up seeing Ho Chi Minh up close. I was very humbled and honoured to be able to visit. I also saw the changing of the guard while in line so it was a complete experience.

Must see, together with the museum, the palace, the Ho Chi Minh small house. all is linked together, we took a bus to the museleum,be before 11:00 AM, After the visit we walked to the flag tower and the letarture temple,All of them each near the other.The mausoleumThe museumThe hi chi means small house, the presidential palaceThe flag towerThe temple of literature Enjoy the area, the architecture of e buildings, beautiful....

Research the history before you go. There is great admiration for the statesman and we decided to hire a local guide to bring us there. The place only opens on Tues to Fri and the guards changing ceremony is held every hour.Overall an eye-opener for me.PS. Strange that the guide narration is different from what you read from Wikipedia. Found out yourself.

A wonderful legacy. An amazing structure both moving and fascinating. Soldiers stand watch for 4 hours at a time without moving and then you can watch the changing of the flag and changing of the guard. HCMinh only wanted a small memorial after he died and would probably turn in his grave to this structure.
Great. Great to see, shame you couldn't sit on the grass as we would have stayed longer. Lots of people around in the evening, walking and exercising. We saw the changing of the guards

Unique Experience. I visited the place on Ho Chi Minh (or Uncle Ho) 125th Birthday. It was more intriguing. You are not allowed to bring any camera in and you're supposed to wear clothing that covers you properly or you'll be denied. The distance to the glass tank that contains his body is barely 6 metres away and you can really see him. I travel alone so it gets me thinking as I walk in on how this man has influence its country and why is he so much being revered. But more importantly, what happened after his passing. He has a good heart and great intend, but was his ideology wrong? Or was it just people of the later generation has taken advantage of the circumstances and lost the original purpose.

A little weird. Be aware of the weird openingstimes and be on time because it can be very busy. The whole area around the mausoleum is huge. You can see Ho Chi Minh lying in a 'glassbox' and just walk around it. Nothing special.

DIFFERENT!!!. This was amazing! Not so much the Mausoleum but the crowds of Vietnamese that gathered to honour Ho CHi Minh. It is not morbid but a place where Vietnamese pay homage to a man who brought change ( whether you agree or not with the changes) to Vietnam.

Impressive preservation of a great leader to Vietnam. Once we navigated the grounds of the Mausoleum we worked our way through covered walkways to visit the large monument containing Ho Chi Minh's body. Although the walk through was quite swift it was extremely amazing to see his body in perfect condition. One would wonder how the decomposition process is prevented. He looked so peaceful. This is a beautiful setting, however we felt a lack of signs in English made the entrance a tad difficult to find. Highly recommended visit!

The timings are very inconvenient. The mausoleum itself is only open from 7 am to 10 am, but the grounds are pretty, and the changing of the guard is quite cute to watch. Makes for nice pictures because of the symmetry, and the size of the structure makes the guards look like little toys.

Austere and Solemn. As part of my visit to Hanoi, I, of course, visited the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum with my group. The site is immense with broad vistas in front of the Mausoleum itself, many guards, and avenues of topiary trees and well-tended gardens. And, rightly so, for Ho Chi Minh is a legendary world figure and one who is revered by his people. I visited on a Monday, so the Mausoleum itself was closed, but on a day when it's open, the lines are long. Don't miss this iconic site.

A must do!. You cannot honestly go to Hanoi and not visit this attraction. It is definitely on the..to do list. Interesting to see Ho Chi Minh in his embalmed state, but also the pomp and ceremony that goes along with it, including the changing of the guards every hour. No charge for this attraction
EXPERIENCE. I was interested in seeing Ho. The queue was extremely long buy constantly moved. I'm glad I did it - very interesting to see a stuffed dead guy.
A lot of queues. I know it's a really important historical monument for the Vietnamese people, but I'm not sure I'd rush back. There just seemed to be never ending queues everywhere

Interesting...but patience is required . We visited the mausoleum in the morning as part of a Hanoi Day Tour and although the wait was long, it was an interesting visit to view the body of Ho Chi Minh. His body is in great condition and you really only get to file past. Understandingly no photos are allowed inside and all cameras need to be handed in at security points. The amount of guardsmen is excessive but at least they are something to look at while waiting.

A humble Leader and a beautiful historical place. Despite that Mondays and Fridays there is no entrance to the Mausoleum; one can still walk in the other parts of the premises. Beautiful grounds and park.

Austere but interesting. The mausoleum is an austere looking structure. We were unable to enter - closed on Mondays! However if you plan to visit and view Ho Chi Minh's body then allow plenty of time as we were informed there were always long queues. Ho Chi Minh's wooden style house located in grounds behind the mausoleum is well worth visiting.
Beautiful. There is so much to see, take Your time and let the place inspire You. It is lovely an You have to see this.

An Amazing Part of Vietnam's History. We visited the Mausoleum on a Friday and it was closed for viewing. We had been told that the queues are normally 2 to 3 hours long to go inside so we weren't too worried. Our guide from Top Asia Travel provide an insight into the history of the Mausoleum and about Ho Chi Minh himself which was very interesting. There are other government and historical buildings in the same area so there is a lot to see.

Very cool to see when the night falls. At 21:00 the guards will take down the flag in a very ceremoniously way and it's worth coming a little bit early for that - I'd recommend at least at 20:30. If, for any reason, you cannot make it at night, then it doesn't say much during day time. As we arrived late, we didn't enter but fellow travelers said they were disappointed.

You wait sooo long. We waited about 45 minutes in the sun till we were ushered through security. Once inside the line moved quickly and we were most the time under cover. Long wait for a short minute to see his body - if it is really him.

Interesting Historically. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is worth seeing simply because of what it is, Ho Chi Minh's body preserved and lieing in a mausoleum. If you don't know who Ho Chi Minh was, or don't care, and are bothered by long lines, then there's not much point in visiting. The mausoleum is housed in the midst of immense, well maintained laws and gardens and a huge parade square, and that, to us, was interesting.

Its bloody huge!. We didn't stand in line to see his body - as you need to stand in line for over an hour and you get 45secs in front of his body before they move you on and you can't bring your bag or camera. Plus you need to cover your knees and shoulders. But from the outside - its bloody massive! We were totally in awe!

Misunderstood by Americans. This was the founder of Vietnam with General Vo Nguyen Giap; this is living history. This was the man that visited the USA after the conclusion of WWII in an attempt to head off another war here-he also visited Paris with the same purpose-but we all know how that turned out. I was in an American combat unit here when he died in 1969. His history and writings are unique.

Arrive early stay ahead of the lines. Remember no cameras they will hold cameras for you can pick up as u leave no laughing no smiling walking hands beside you with respect only thing that got me was he looks like an Asian KFC dude

Average but worth a visit. If you go to Hanoi I guess this has to be on the list to see. It is in presidential quarter. The main structure (where Ho Chi lies) is surrounded by a parade ground (square) and botanical gardens. The building is guarded by soldiers in ceremonial uniforms which adds some additional interest. We queued to get in but it moved fairly quickly and will all filed past the old chap in silence. What was more interesting was the gardens and buildings where he used to live which is not far from his the square. Note: These places are not open on Mondays.
Peaceful and Respectful. This is an absolute must if you visit Vietnam. It is important to stop and respect their love of their great leader who led them through and out of difficult times.

Creepy. I lined up without looking up what I was lining up for. I was really really shocked when I got to the mausoleum and saw what I saw. It was quite an experience. Very different than anything I've done in my life.

Uncle Ho. Ho Chi Minh is their God pretty much and you can feel the up tight system, rules and order in your bones as soon as you step in the foot path of the complex. They will ask you to inspect or leave your bag behind. Later they will ask you to leave your camera and phone behind if you haven't done it yet. Walk in line with 50 to a 100cm distance from the person in front of you, remove your hat, close your mouth and don't stair at Ho Chi Minh for too long once inside the most beautiful dark box made of Marble with the Communism and Vietnam symbols
Very good. Very interesting mausoleum. You will see how Vietnam fought for peace thanks to great man Ho Chi Minh. You can still visit Ho Chi Minh body too. Good visit

Worth the long wait!. We waited in line for an hour. Please note that you need to have shoulders and knees covered. I learnt the expensive way and had to buy scarves to cover my skin. The long wait was really worth it. I took my 8 and 9 year old and they did not find it eery. It was a great experience.

Lookin' good Uncle Ho ; ). The actual viewing is quick and over in less than 3 minutes but how can you not go visit Uncle Ho when he flies to France every single year just to make himself ready for your visit?

History. To visit the Mausoleum, you will need lots of patience as the waiting line of people can be more than one kilometer - be prepared with mineral water on a hot day or keep some snack handy as it is quite a wait to get in to this place...

Not open on Mondays and Fridays - but still worth a visit. In the presidential quarter, there lies Ho Chi Minh in this marvellous mare structure. Nice and quiet as they block the road to traffic and you've got the botanic gardens, ho chi minh museum and presidential palace in the square.
Only thing to be aware of is that the these places are not open on Mondays.

good. Very nice to visit the square in evening, especially in the flag ceremony which happen every day in about 9pm and 6am. but not really interesting to go in the mausoleum to see a fake body. No offence though, I know Ho is a great person who brought peace to Vietnam but this mausoleum against his will completely. just propaganda of communist
Very busy. Very busy with hundreds of school children but well worth the visit. We didn't go inside, just did the gardens and house etc.

Must do. Seeing Ho Chi Minh was not particularly important to me, yet lining up with the various tour and school groups brought me closer to understanding the deep reverence Vietnamese display for Ho Chi Minh. There are a lot of rules, but my wife and I dressed modestly, put our cell phones away, and didn't speak when inside the building and we were left alone. In contrast, there was a large French family in front of us that was loud and didn't follow directions that kept being scolded by the guards.

Unforgetable. Cant miss this if you are a history buff. The complex itself is decently impressive however the sight of Ho Chi Mins embalmed body was unreal. He is literally in a glowing casket with about 8 guards in the room adding to the intensity. The experience was also made enjoyable by the simplicity, it was free and took us about 20 minutes to walk through and see every thing. For travelers who lack an interest of history and politics this might not be as impressive of an experience for you.

Long queue,short visit. On the day of my visit there were lots of school children parties visiting the site and they get priority, consequently I had to queue for about two hours to get into the mausoleum. When inside you have to keep moving and you do not really have any time to look at the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh, unsurprisingly you are also banned from taking photographs of his body. If you only have to queue for a short while then the site is worth a visit but it is not worth waiting In a long queue, it is better to go back to the site later in the day and take external photos.

fascinating life of BAC HO !!. i would suggest any body to read or discover this great guy's life rather then visiting Mausoleum erected for him..Vietnamese people had the every right to give His name to streets,schools,places or cities...when i was there they didn't let us visit inside of Mausoleum..i didn't loose any thing but i discovered BAC HO personality.....

Must see. Well how can one visit Hanoi without taking the time to visit here. There are queues but they move along quite quickly and most of the time you are under cover that has been erected. If you manage to be there when they change the guards it is an added bonus.

Be surprised!. We were part of a tour group and had the opportunity to take a short cut among the very long queue during the April-30-May 3 reunification celebration weekend. While waiting in line, we spendt the time watching the soldiers' marching and their organizing the queue, design of the huge tall buiding, the beautiful garden outside and people viewing. You have to dress properly - sleeveless shirts, above knee shorts, low neck tops are not allowed. No photos and no talking allowed inside the building.We thought we will see inside a tomb building for HoChi Minh, the "Father of Nation", "Uncle HO". But no, we saw his preserved body. Although it looked waxy, we were told that it was his original body. Amazing sight, not to be missed if you are into Vietnamese history and culture.

Go early and don't bring water. We arrived about 8:30 am on a Saturday and were delighted to see no line! We waited a very short time just outside the actual mausoleum entrance because a group of seniors (veterans?) and a group of kids were given priority. The entire process took less than 30 minutes!The experience was a little strange to me, but somewhat interesting. It's hard for me to recommend it as Ho Chi Minh himself didn't want such a display.A couple of tips: Don't bring any bottled water or other drinks as they aren't allowed inside and will be thrown away. And FYI there's no admission fee.

Nice visit - the grounds are beautiful. I almost didn't go based on the others reviews about long lines but glad I did. We went about 10:00AM and lines weren't bad at all to see his body. The rest of the grounds are very beautiful and a nice walk.Make sure you don't take a lot of stuff and are dressed appropriately as the are very strict there.

Interesting. As you wind around in pairs before you see Ho Chi Minh you are amongst hundreds of visitors, locals, school children from kinder age up and tourists which is interesting in its self. All well organised and the line moves quickly for your glimpse at this amazing man.

Worth the time. Allow time to queue to get in and wear respectable clothing. I did think it was worth the time, though a friend of mine did not. Quite the cultural experience and it helps you understand the reverence and respect some Vietnamese people have for Ho Chi Minh.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Although it took some time to get to the mausoleum, the time was spent talking to the many school children that were on a school excursion. I was surprised that they were learning English at school and wanted to practise their English Skills. The grounds leading to the mausoleum are well kept. We were also thrilled to see the changing of the Guards with precision marching and changeover. I was also humbled by the way Uncle Ho is revered. Our actual time in the Mausoleum was brief, I was glad that it was part of our itinerary. After the mausoleum we walked through the botanical gardens, then onto the 2 place Ho Chi Minh lived in no way austere, but functional. I would put this tour as a must see whilst in Hanoi if only for the pleasure of walking through the gardens and by the small lake.

Tried but too long a queue. We went to visit Mausoleum on Tues 28th April! Arrived at 9 30 only to find queue streets and streets long! After trying to join the line at about 10am and to find out it was Independence Day and line moving very slowly we decided not to bother!Maybe wrong day to see this - we may have been lined up all day! Sorry not that dedicated, although would have been nice to experience! Maybe they can organize this a little better!S

A long wait but worth it. We got there at 8am on the busiest day of the year (2 May) as it was their holiday weekend. We waited in line for 1hr 35mins for a 1.78km line (I mapped and timed it on my Garmin GPS watch). I would say that it was worth it, but I like this sort of thing. I was wearing a singlet so had to buy near the front gate. Got a Ho Chi Minh shirt for only D50,000. Bargain. But don't wear a singlet.

Worth Visiting Place. We as part of a study group visited the Mausoleum in the early hours of the day as we had to proceed to the Ha Long city after this. We saw Huge lines of people waiting for their turn to enter inside the Mausoleum. We were privileged to move inside without waiting but in strict disciplined and organized manner. The embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is preserved in the cooled, central hall of the mausoleum, which is protected by a military honour guard. Lines of visitors, including visiting foreign dignitaries, pay their respects at the mausoleum every day. Rules regarding dress and behaviour are strictly enforced by staff and guards. Legs must be covered (no shorts or miniskirts). Visitors must be silent, and walk in two lines. Hands must not be in pockets, nor arms crossed. Smoking, drinking, eating, photography and video taping are also not permitted anywhere inside the mausoleum.Though the building was declared as the "sixth most ugly" building in the world by CNN International in 2012 but still it looks graceful due to the prevailing environment full of respect and dignity. A must see place in Vietnam.

Macabre but fascinating. If you like looking at embalmed bodies then thisa is for you. Clearly the Vietnamese people (in the North) still hold Ho Chi Minh in high regard. They queue in their 1000s everyday to walk past him and pay their respects. The gardens around are beautfully kept. Everything is very clean and immaculately kept here. Interestig to hear the differing views from North Vietnamese to the South Vietnamese however when you ask pertinent questions of people on your tour from Hanoi in the North to Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City) in the South, where most people still call the city Saigon, which says all you need to know about the Southern Vietnamese!

Don't be put off by the queues!. With a short window to visit the mausoleum, we queued up at 10.30am (we didn't realise it was around 2km away from the mausoleum). They were very efficient at ushering people through, and although a hot day, they provided sheltered walkways to keep the sun off, and we made it to Uncle Ho's mausoleum entrance just before 11am (it's only open from 8-11am). It was a very interesting experience (no cameras allowed of course), but what an opportunity to see him lying in state with presidential guards all around. You're then ushered out the doors, and into the presidential palace grounds where you have to pay to enter - free to visit the Mausoleum, and 25,000 dong to visit the grounds (which is the only way we found to get out!). Worth a stroll though the grounds, and a very quick visit for us, we were out at the main entrance again by 11.30am (that is the final time to collect your bags from the drop off zone). Give it two thumbs up! Woman, remember to wear long pants or skirt below the knees, and a top that covers your shoulders, and men also a t-shirt and longer shorts or pants, and recommend going earlier in the morning so you don't have to stress about getting back to the entrance by 11.30am (when they close off bag pickup) to collect your personal items! (No back packs or large camera equipment allowed inside the grounds)
Worth to go. You must come early to visit this place, because you need queue to get in, it takes about 30 minutes.

A must see in Hanoi. The day we visited it was teeming with rain so we had to wait for about an hour before we finally entered the mausoleum. My husband and I were sharing a hotel umbrella and before long we were very close and personal with a Vietnamese couple who spoke no English. A very interesting experience. We watched the changing of the guard and observed groups of local school children who were the best behaved children I have ever seen. I am not sure whether Ho was real or not, looked very much like one of Madame Tussaurd's life like figures but the Vietnamese people were very respectful and it was evident that there was much love for this father of their country. The surrounding grounds were beautiful and it is worth visiting Ho's home and the museum as well. I certainly learnt a lot about the man and his visionary ideas.

Interesting, but not why you may think. Visiting the mausoleum and the Ho Chi Minh museum is an adventure in bizarreness. Rarely does one nowadays have the chance to encounter socialist/communist propaganda in all its glory, but here one still has the chance. This isn't supposed to insult the attraction, as the presentation is utterly benign and "the love Ho Chi Minh feels for his people" are certainly less fuelled by nationalist pride than some of the stuff I have seen come out of the USA (which, it should be mentioned, basically don't get slagged off at all).If one wants to visit this particular leftover of old times, one should show up early, as queues can form quickly. Also, completely avoid the time from 29th of April until 1st of May. They're national holidays in Vietnam (30th of April is Liberation day) and there will be lines around the block. I saw the nearby botanical garden converted to a parking lot to accomodate the masses of tourists showing up in travel busses.

a long que to view Ho Chi Minh. Only had the Sunday to visit this,it was high up on my list of things to see, so 2 of us joined the Que, with locals, dozens of tour buses full, & school children , about 2klm Que to the front gate took about 1.5 hours, inside the gate about the same again in very hot conditions,, don't know if this is the norm, in hindsight would have booked before and gone with an organized tour gets you in quicker, uncle ho is looking OK. and glad l persevered ..

A poignant visit and well worth the queue. Our tour guide dropped us off at the entrance and we joined the queue to vist the mausoleum. The queue moved fairly quickly (40 minutes or so) and we entered the building which is was deeply respectful to Ho Chi Minh and was quite moving to see the Vietnamese people pay their respects. An impressive tribute to HCM despite his wishes for a much more humble tomb.

Go early to avoid the queues. This was a really interesting experience. We arrived just after 7am which is a good time to go, we witnessed the guard of honour and laying of wreaths outside the museum. There are very long lines of people waiting to file past the body of Ho Chi Minh, but crowd control is excellent. The adjoining musuem and artefacts were also extremely interesting.

Long Wait for What?. As part of a tour of Vietnam and Cambodia we waited in line two hours to see the HCM Mausoleum and then were rushed by the body in what seemed less than two minutes! So many other things I would have preferred to see!

Cannot be missed. Beyond your political orientation, you will feel the heartbeat of Vietnam. Queuing in a fast line you will be surrounded by locals, keen to pay their most sincere respect to the Father of the Nation. Good vibes, no propaganda, just a piece of history under your eyes. After the visit you can also enjoy the nice and interesting park where the Mausoleum is located

Propaganda HQ. Ho Chi Minh was obviously a great leader and a real visionary loved by the vietnamese people.What I find difficult as an Australian is that we and the USA are referred to as the "Enemy". True - but that was another era and another political ideology. None the less, Ho Chi Minh is the Father of modern Vietnam and as they say "Victors write the history".Funny thing is that I don't see a communist country here - the good old market economy and entrepreneurial skills are in evidence everywhere. You should see some of the houses of the wealthy - talk about lavish (in French colonial style).The Mausoleum however is worth a visit.

He looks like he could wake up any moment. Somehow it is intimidating to have a human body as a tourist attraction. It was very interesting to experience the Vietnamese paying their respects, and everything went very fast and effectively.
Must see. Fantastic building in a nice part of the city. You must not cross the line in front as there are lots of guards who will shout at you. Great photos.
Must see. Fantastic building in a nice part of the city. You must not cross the line in front as there are lots of guards who will shout at you. Great photos.

he looks really good!. queued for an hour to see this in the 38 degree heat. It was worth it. I've never seen anyone look so healthy that been gone for so long!Beautiful grounds and wonderful to see the school children paying their respects. Make sure, ladies, that your shoulders are covered and you wear knee length clothing to show your respect too or you won't be allowed in.

Great place to observe Vietnamese enmasse. The centre pice is Ho Chi Min's body, but for us the really interesting bit was to see tens of thousands of Vietnamese coming to pay their respects, is quite thought provoking. The body goes back to Russia for maintain ended for a couple of months every year so check before visiting.

A beautiful looking building. We could not go in as Vladimir Putin,President of Russia was visiting but saw everything surrounding the Mausoleum and the gardens were beautiful, bonsai trees were stunning. Disappointed we couldn't see it all but what we saw was worth the visit

highly recommend. This is our second visit to Hanio we didn't do it on the first one but so glad we done it this time around . Our guide was so informative with the history I learnt more here than any other city tour.. If you want to learn about the history this tour is a must . A lot of walking involved but it's done at a slow pace so everybody kept up .if you have time recommend you do this tour and a great lunch to finish of the half day tour

Interesting to see (the other visitors). Only for seeing the guards in uniforms and all the Vietnamese visitors and even little children lining up for seeing their "idol" for a few seconds it is worth it. It is for free but plan about 20-30 min to get in.
Long lines. The lines wrap around the entire complex but don't let this deter you, it moves fast. Impressive and interesting. Worth standing in line for.
Amazing history. This is amazing , so much to learn about Vietnam ..If your a history buff you will really enjoy it...

Soemthing you should do. The Mausoleum is only open till 10.15am and not open at all on Mondays & Fridays. So we decided just to walk around it rather than queue to go in. We visited the Museum instead which if you bother to read all the displays is actually quite informative. The Mausoleum and the Presidential Palace require below the knee clothing and fully covered shoulders.
Mausoleum. An experience to queue for 20 s of a glimpse of Ho Chi Minh. The queue time was long with many by-passers. However I would regret not doing so.

Place of great significance - pleased I went. After reading so much about Uncle Ho during our travels it was very moving to see the great man. First time I've seen a bloke in a mausoleum. Well done. Don't try and argue the rules with cameras and stuff. Just do as you are told and pay your respects. Wasn't crowded when we went and it took a relatively short period of time.Worth it.

A Place of Respect. We visited once, and were really glad we did.. Its a good idea to check the opening times before you visit.. Many visitors to the Mausoleum. You normally join a line outside and then directed into the entrance door, took about 15 mins. really close to other attractions so you can easily spend a 4 or 5 hours in the area

Good to see Uncle Ho!. We went to the mausoleum at around 1120am and there was not much of queue - think most people get here quite early and also the luggage room closes between 12pm and 2pm. We were in and out in less than 1 hour. Not allowed in with a camera or a rucksack - so this needs to be handed in but can be collected once you come out of the mausoleum. Everything is very well sign posted.If staying in the Old Quarter I would recommend getting a taxi only 50000VND as its quite a walk in the heat - we took taxi there and walked back.It was good to see Uncle Ho and to see the locals paying their respects to him - was an experience.Well worth visiting!

Great tight and ruled experience!!! Love it. If you think about communism, this is a good example! Very tight rules if you want to visit. Vietnamese people come from all over the country to visit their savior. Ho Chi Minh is their God pretty much and you can feel the up tight system, rules and order in your bones as soon as you step in the foot path of the complex. They will ask you to inspect or leave your bag behind. Later they will ask you to leave your camera and phone behind if you haven't done it yet. Walk in line with 50 to a 100cm distance from the person in front of you, remove your hat, close your mouth and don't stair at Ho Chi Minh for too long once inside the most beautiful dark box made of Marble with the Communism and Vietnam symbols...I absolutely loved it! Advise: not for the short fuse people as you can get pushed or told off at some stage. Just relax and enjoy it for once the experience of living in a Communist stunning country with the most amazing lovely people!

Not worth it. You have to wait in a long line for hours before getting a glimpse at Uncle Ho body for a few second. After that we can go and visit the park and the museum near by. The museum was interesting though.
Disappointed. This is my second visit to the Mausoleum and both times it was closed. Last time 8 years ago Ho Chi Minh's remains were being restored and this time it was a holiday.

enlightening. the price of admission is very reasonable, and we learned things about Nguyen Tat Thanh (Ho Chi Minh) and Vietnam's history. One suggestion. You may want to explore the main level first; before heading up stairs. We don't know what we missed, as we thought we'd start at the top and work our way down. While we saw more than we could absorb, we realized that we were at an exit and could not get back to the exhibits that were near the entrance.

Important to Vietnamese, crowd moves quick. Nice to see how they revere their countries father, but waiting in line to look at dead people under glass isn't for me, but the tour took us there.Very crowded, but the crowd moved quickly and with a high degree of respect.

Long wait but interesting to see. The line to get is is like being at Disney. You wait in one line, then wait in several more lines along the way. The grounds of the complex are nicely landscaped and there are videos along the way that are like a time capsule. When we went in, everybody had to walk single file as the soldiers made sure we were on the correct side of the aisle. I didn't know what to expect and do not mean any disrespect, but he looked like a figure from a Madame Tussaud wax museum. Well done, but waxy pale. Also on the grounds are the house where he lived and it was interesting to see how spare and simple the decor was. Also a small house on stilts where the breezes made for tolerable living. There are other buildings as well, but you cannot go into any of the buildings except for the mausoleum. The soldiers were young and marched in formation.

Busy. We didn't know what to expect or what was the protocol for visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Be sure to wear bottoms that cover your knees and have your shoulders covered (no tank tops), no hats and no sunglasses. Guards scrutinize every single person as you approach and walk through the mausoleum (no talking inside). I thought it would be creepy but it's actually not. A lot of people join the long cues just to get a 30 second glimpse of this much loved man.

A bit of history.... As an American who protested the Vietnam War during the 60's and early 70's I visited Vietnam this year to see how the country had evolved since then. One of the first places I visited was Ho chi minh ' s mausoleum in Hanoi. You must wait in line, check any thing you are carrying, and no cameras.It is a stark place and there is a enclosed area where the preserved body of "Uncle Ho" as he is referred to by the Vietnamese is encased in glass. It's eerie looking at the body of a small man who was responsible for a civil war and brought a Communist government to all of Vietnam. The masoleum is only open for a few months each year as the body is removed to keep it preserved. Check to see when it's open as well as the hours of viewing which are only 4 hours per day.Worth the visit.
FANTASTIC. What a fantastic place to visit. Beautiful gardens and a lot of history that shaped Vietnam. Ho Chi minh palace and house were fascinating. Definitely worth a visit

Cool attraction. This is a very cool attraction, but definitely weird. There are long lineups to view Ho Chi Minh, who you get to see for only a few seconds and only during the morning, before he is refrigerated. Visitors are ushered through at top speed by stern guards.

For those interested in the history!. I visited the mausoleum as part of my city tour and our group was sent down a different line that skipped the wait. The whole visit took about 30 minutes. If you don't know who Ho Chi Minh was or are not interested in the history of the country, it's not for you. For those of us who do, it was well worth the visit, not only to see the inside of the mausoleum and Uncle Ho himself, but to see the locals paying their own respects as well as the security in their pristine white uniforms making sure we all behaved ourselves. No photos are permitted inside.

Definitely worth a visit. I was very unsure about viewing Ho Chi Minh's body but it was very respectful and peaceful. Arrive as early as possible as the queue's are super long but well worth the wait. His body is very well preserved and is well presented in a glass case with soft lighting. The entire family enjoyed this the most out of all we saw despite the 1 & 1/2 hour wait.

There is nothing interesting. There is nothing interesting, you can skip this if you don't have time there is just a lot of paper read There is nothing interesting, you can skip this if you don't have time there is just a lot of paper read

Meh. It's a long time in line to see an embalmed body. I've done it on my own but when I bring groups of students to Hanoi, I don't put this on the itinerary. I feel there are better uses of our time when we are on a tight schedule. Locals will be fascinated by you and want to talk to you and ask you where you are from. The Vietnamese government has a program where they pay for their war veterans to travel to Hanoi to visit the mausoleum. Many of them come from countryside villages and see significantly less (or no) westerners where they live. When I visited with my sister a group of veterans wanted to talk with us. They were so adorable. Our friend, who is local Vietnamese, told them one of us was American and one was Canadian. When we asked her later why she did that she said, "They'll be so excited to go home to their villages and tell everyone they talked with people from two different countries." I supposed it's a unique experience to see Uncle Ho's embalmed body but, like I said, it's a long time in line for a very brief view of him.
Beautifull building. We did not enter the mausoleum, as it is only open in the morning, but we enjoyed a walk through the beautifull garden

Only 90 minutes in Line. WOW, what a zoo filled with tourists. We waited in line almost 90 minutes to view the body is less than 3 seconds. Once you got inside the Mausoleum, guards touch you on the back of the arm to keep you moving. You could skip this unless you need the quality time in line to chat with your friends. Also, you can't take a camera, cell phone, backpack; your clothes must touch the knees and cover the shoulders.

Bizarre! (But a must-do). This experience was so bizarre. We waited in a long line with lots of rules: No bags (unless they were folded...?) no photos, no talking as you are entering the mausoleum, and hands must be by your side. It was a cultural experience to see how seriously Ho Chi Min's embalmed body is taken. I would definitely suggest it.

An interesting insight into the Vietnamese people.. Get here early - the queues get huge, but they do move along very rapidly - we got there about 15 minutes after opening time, and the queue was already about a kilometre long. It did only take us 35 minutes to get to the mausoleum itself. If you are a westerner you will find yourself in a huge minority, and will be the object of a certain amount of very good-natured attention from the locals. There are locals of all ages in the queue, from babes in arms to pensioners. Dress and attitude are expected to be respectful, and the closer you get to the mausoleum itself, the more the guards are vigilant about behaviour, even of children. There are often large groups of schoolchildren from Kindy upwards who have a special ceremony to lay a wreath at the entrance to the tomb, which cause a certain amount of delay in proceedings for those ordinary members of the public in the queue. You are ushered silently and swiftly through the central chamber where Uncle Ho's remains are displayed, guarded by four immaculate white-clad guardsmen. We did see a couple of people in wheelchairs who got their own white-clad guard to carry them up and down the stairs.

Make sure you are early! Check the times!. I can't really rate this attraction as I hadn't paid enough attention to the times - I presumed it would be open all day, the fact is they closed off at 10:15am and we had arrived about 10:30. I presume this is to process the large queue that forms every day. Check times and days (as it varies) but i think it opens at 8am maybe earlier. My tip would be to drive at 7:30 to try and beat the long lines and to avoid disappointment. I might add my wife was relieved as she wasn't keen!

Interesting, but........ We went with our Hanoi Kids guides (look them up!!!!) and it was VERY busy. Long lines to get in. So make sure you check opening times and public holidays. When we finally got the the mausoleum itself, we had to form a 2 person line before walking in. It is polite here to keep talking to a minimum and not look happy, take selfies (don't do that anywhere) ect. The we went in and through, hurried by soldiers and guards every step of the way. That is my "BUT" of the review. Would have been more interesting to take in the place if you could stop up and look around. After the mausoleum, you can walk the Ho Chi Minh grounds and it's very interesting. There is a souvenir shop and food to buy as well. When we were there, they were closing for lunch, so again, check times and plan ahead. But it's not to be missed in Hanoi!
Interesting History. To see the embalmed body of Vietnam's first President, Ho Chi Minh, was very interesting and strangely moving.

Highlight for me!. The first day we went was a 2 hour wait, so we got up early next day, grabbed a cab and came back for an 8am opening and got in quickly. I really found this interesting, Ho Chi Minh seemed really loved and respected. He had a great vision for Vietnam!

Not what was expected. Learning afterwards that he wished to be cremated and his ashes scattered throughout Vietnam, the long 1 hour lines and the 10 second viewing whilst you are rushed past by security guards almost didn't seem worth it. However, it is something unique that you can say you have seen. It is recommended that you go with a tour guide as you can get more information than you would otherwise, but it is definitely navigational if you go alone as it is well laid out and organised. Best not to wear shorts and sleeveless tops and beware of pickpockets and scammers.

Quite an experience!. Huge numbers of people visit the mausoleum and grounds, and although the queue looks quite intimidating, it actually moves quickly (helped along robustly by the regularly placed guards). No time for contemplation inside, but you can wander around the old houses and cars at your own pace.

Didn't make the cut..... Arrived with possibly enough time to enter but did not appreciate the dress code.... being a westerner in a hot country, we had shorts and vests on....and I don't think I had grasped that his actual corpse was in there.... Despite being guided into the very long queue, when we came past the chap who had put us in the queue, he decided to reject us based on our dress. This was not just to enter the mausoleum, but the entire complex.Plenty of tshirt sellers on hand, but I refused to pay. Went back when mausoleum was closed and was not required to adapt clothing at all despite bringing my tshirt.Whilst it would have been an experience to see, the whole thing does seem to go against his wish to be cremated and so part of me is glad not to have joined in.

A communist experience. What can I say - you actually see a dead man! The experience is very interesting - from queuing up with Vietnamese from all over the country who came to pay tribute to their founding father, going through the impressive communist architecture and of course passing by the body of Ho Chi Minh himself.

RIP Uncle Ho. The lines were extraordinarily long, but don't let that deter you as the lines move along quite quickly. On entering the mausoleum you find yourself in a surreal environment. On filing past Ho Chi Minh's final resting place, an unexpected sadness and respect overcomes you. This is a must to do on your intinerary.
Amazing. this is outside the Old Quarter about 15 to 20 mins walk, it has a big park and nice area. the Ho Chi Minh Museum is very informative, you will definitely appreciate Viet Nam's History.
Solemnity. The whole area in and around was clean , quiet and very solemn. We stood in a queue with 1000's others and filed past this deceased freedom fighter and leader.

Memorable. Visited twice. Building is very impressive and enjoyed changing of the guard. Unfortunately, we first went on a Monday and was closed. Also, it was raining and we all got soaked. Went back to visit body of Ho Chi Min, and although the lines were quite long and we waited 2 hrs., it was a moving and memorable experience to see someone who has contributed so much to this country.However, you are rushed through and if you don't move fast enough, the guards literally grab you by the arm and push you forward. But, for history's sake, it was worth the wait.

Solemn. The building itself is imposingly huge, but lacks any architectural merit. This man is revered in Vietnam and his remains treated with reverence. Be extremely careful how you behave and what you say, as the significant military presence will not tolerate any lack of respect. It is, after all, their country and their leader, who saw both the French and the Americans out of the door in turn. Not bothered? Then don't bother going.
historical. we choose a bad day we got soaking wet there must have been all the schools there cameras are taken of you pick them up on your way out we got very wet but a good experience

Impressive. We queued for ages in the rain, but poncho's were available and covered walkways...it was actually quite a moving experience. Although you are rushed through I am glad I went...he looks amazing.
A must-visit place if you are in Hanoi. A place to commemorate someone who has contributed his whole life for the country. Meaningful and worth the trip.

Expansive Area. Its a pity that we went on a Day, its usual closed. Don't ever go on a Friday or Monday, we were told after we went there. So no choice can only take photos on the exterior only, please beware of the yellow box, don't ever step into it, you will be chased out. Also take note of the grass patch near the 1 pagodas, it will not be wise to step on the grass patch

A long wait for 20 seconds. The grounds were huge, the line was long (however I think we caught an abnormal day with loads of school groups) to march in line like school kids getting told off if your not in line correctly. To walk through the Mausoleum for 20 seconds and out the other side.Rest of the area was very confusing to navigate and the staff were not overly helpful to be honest but there is a lot of history there should that be your liking.

Beautiful. If you want to go inside you'll need to visit in the morning as it closes at 1230. We decided not to and were lucky enough to see the changing of the guards. It's a beautiful building in a very peaceful setting.

Powerful and memorable. The Ho Chi Minh Mazza Liam far exceeded our expectations. We appreciated and respected this national figure and I am happy we have the opportunity to visit. My children were especially touched by the significance of seeing his body laying in rest.

Worth the queue. When we first saw the queue, we thought oh no as it was very hot and humid, however, it soon moved and did not queue for that long. Had not managed to visit last time in Hanoi so we were glad we could do it this time. Everywhere is extremely well kept all around. Everyone very respectful and quiet.

Mausolutely Beautiful!. I didn't go inside the mausoleum but there was no need. The mausoleum architecture is absolutely beautiful. The changing of guard ceremony outside the mausoleum each hour rivals any military changing of the guard ceremony I've seen except the British.
Impressive, Vietnams version of changing the guard.. Great building with an aurora of national pride about the whole area. Well maintained and the guard ceremony is good to watch.
very interesting tour. Great tour. Lots to see. Presedential palace. Ho Chi Mins house on stilts.The mausoleum where his body lies. Our tour guide was great.
Only open 8am-11am!. Make sure you visit during the opening times in order to actually go inside the mausoleum. 8am-11am Tues-Thursday, Sat & Sun Dec-Sept. Last entry 10.15am.
