Inreresting for the history buff.. There are guards all about. Interesting and a must see if in Hanoi, but in and of itself, not very exciting. There's a lot of hooplah for very little.

Interesting visit to see a leader revered by his people. No trip to Hanoi would be complete without a visit to see "Uncle Ho" lying at rest. A slightly surreal experience as our group lined up to visit his body lying in state in an unmistakeably Russian influenced mausoleum. No smiling, hands out of pockets and certainly no pictures is a no brainer but the soldiers guarding the body make sure all visitors are suitably solemn so bear it in mind and don't try any clandestine photos. The guards are all volunteers and it's apparently a job for life according to our guide. Once you've shuffled through and seen the body you can tour the site to see some of Ho Chi Minh's other places of residence from the rather grand French colonial buildings down to the more modes wood house he lived in during some of his final years.The site is always busy with many Vietnamese coming to visit their former leader. Whilst he is preserved here for as long as time allows, it's interesting to note that his final wish was to be cremated and his ashes scattered throughout his beloved land. When you arrive you will need to be aware that backpacks need to be surrendered at a drop off point and you can pick them up at the end so make sure you take your wallet with you. Also, before entering the mausoleum you will have to hand over your camera which by now will be in a red bag handed to you on entrance. All our items were returned safe and sound so there were no problems but something to be aware of.

Looks very much like the old Soviet Union. This was a good trip. You see the changing of the guard along with the Presedential Palace, the one tier pagoda and many other wonderful things to see in this area of Hanoi

If you aren't Vietnamese, not much to offer. Admittedly, it was not open the day we took a cab there so it was really dead and cold looking. Not sure I would have felt much more if it were open. Just took another cab back to the old quarter.

Not worth the travel over to that side of the city. I'm 19 years old and me and my boyfriend visited the mausoleum without any knowledge as to who Ho Chi Minh was. We found the whole place to be very dull and uninteresting. We didn't go to the Palace however as the queues were long and the weather was poor. Our trip over to that area would probably have been worthwhile had we known a bit more about Ho Chi and visited his palace.

Get there early. I took a taxi from my hotel to get here before 8am. Just a short queue and within 10 minutes I was walking past "Uncle Ho"Fascinating to see the organisation and the regard the Vietnamese still hold their patriarch. A somber experience once inside. Once back outside, I could see that the queue had grown significantly so would urge you to get there early. The Ho Chi Minh museum is right next door so worth a visit too once you've been to see the mausoleum.
Historical significance. Hated the long wait to get in - make sure you go early to beat the crowds and respect their rules of lining up single file
Just ok. Long lines that moved quickly. Be sure to have your shoulders and knees covered. They won't let you in otherwise. Saw the changing of the guards. Photos are prohibited in the mausoleum.
Very humbling. This was an amazing, humbling experience to see Ho Chi Minh. You can feel the love for this man as you walk through the mausoleum and his grounds. This is worth the visit.

Solemn place but worth a trip. All a bit quiet and controlled but interesting to see the Hero of Vietnam lying peacefully in his sleep. Also happens to have delightful aircon to escape the heat of the city! Real evidence of the communist industry that used to dominate Vietnam, and the soldiers are highly armed and very serious!
Worth waiting in long line. The Vietnamese people love Uncle Ho, and they line up to see his preserved body. Lots of school children visit. Worth a trip.

Worth the trip. Don't know what I expected to see, but it wasn't such a perfectly preserved body. It was interesting to find out that the body is sent every three or four years to Russia to be re-preserved. His house was quite basic (which he liked and so did I) Unusual for such an important person. Enjoyed the trip very much.

This place is huge!. A wonderful place to visit. the spectical of the Changing of the gusrd is great to see. The Vietnamese hold 'Uncle Ho' is such high esteem and high regard, this is a must of you are in Hanoi
Amazing experience. An experience not to be missed, the security, the soldiers, the queues of people and finally Ho Chi Minh himself

informative. Very informative centre. Get to know HCM, the history of Vietnam unification, etc.
The location is very strategic, close to other attractions.

Grave. Been waiting at the entrance, the crowd did not start until the end of the film about the life of Ho Chi Minh City.
The mausoleum is cool, all well organized, quiet steps heard only visitors.

A truly moving experience. Also the gardens are beautiful and a vist to the small wooden house where Ho Chi Minhl lived.. The beautiful lake and gardens and the changing of the guards and wreath laying ceremony plus the opportunity to share in the experience with many Vietnamese people.
Beautiful in the light of the sunset. This structure is very beautiful when cast in the light of the setting sun. You are allowed to go to near though.

Fascinating experience, well worth the visit. Came here on a Saturday morning, really wanting to see how Vietnamese remember Ho Chi Minh. I think it is well worth it just to be an ethnographer for the morning, and to observe how history is memorialized. You should know that it isn't open every day, and that the last entrance is at 10:15. So go early and be prepared to stand in line. Also, women's shorts/skirt should come beneath the knee, so if you are not appropriately dressed you will have to buy a wrap dress.

Big On Queues.. Beware the tourists flock here. Cruise ships, buses and more all come to see this iconic figure lying in a preserved state. We did it. We thought it worth the visit. Not the best thing ive done though and it is very very busy.

The founding father, why wouldn't you see him?. Uncle Ho, as the locals affectionately call him, rests here. He played a pivotal role in the founding of Vietnam, so it's great to be able to get close and see him for yourself. It's not a thorough experience though, because you get ushered through quickly, but the intensity the locals put you through is also experience-worthy itself.
Have to See. If in Hanoi you have to see Ho Chi Minh burial site, the changing of the guard the area that it is set in. There is also the Candian Embassy in the same area.

Impressive. Need to go early to avoid the crowds as it can take over 1 hour to queue which is not good in the heat. Okay so it's a frozen body but he was held in such esteem that the place is highly revered. Early morning (6am) they have the ceremony of the flag which is interesting to see and all the locals in the park doing various exercises.

Impressive, but be prepared for a long queue, which is also an experience in itself. Web had to queue along several blocks, which was an experience in itself and as it is quite well organised is goes faster than you think. For me a must-do in Hanoi.

Not for the gawker. A very serious (i use the term loosely) attraction. Ho Chi Minh is a national hero, so to visit the mausoleum must be treated as a chance to pay respects. The multitude of uniformed soldiers ensure the mood inside is sombre. Ho Chi Minh is lying in state in a large glass room that you filter around in an orderly single file ushered by guards that ensure an appropriate pace, removal of hats and glasses, and silence. Well worth a look in my opinion, just keep your mood "respectful".

a nations homage to its leader. the mausoleum opens at 8.30 and closes at 10 am .we rushed there to reach in time.Believe me we had to stand in line for1.30 hours in order to have a view .i was really impressed with Vietnamese respect for their leader.One has to wear pants and proper clothes to visit the mausoleum.No one can talk while going the the room where his body is placed ..Avery inspiring feeling

Viewed from the outside. It was Friday when we got there so the venue is closed. We instead joined the crowd lining the street fronting the mausoleum. We took pictures and observe the change of guards, in white uniform, every 15 minutes until it tired us.
Strange.... It is of course it is a special experience to watch a dead person in a rather dark and cold huge building...
waste of money unless you are interested in the man himself. it's all about HCM so if you are interested in his legacy and what he did than its for you if not, don't bother.

weird but interesting. Long lines of school children and everyone else--worth doing just to see. Worth while and a certain grandeur plus the obvious veneration of the people make it interesting. The Museum which is close by is also very interesting and worth a trip while you are there.
Historic and solemn. It is a must for all visitors to Hanoi. Open only in the morning and for 10 months very year. It is also close to where "Uncle Ho" preferred to live, worked and died.

Very busy . Visited the mausoleum early in the day and still took 1 hour in the Que. to get inThousands of people at any one time but moved fairly quickly , too quickly past Ho Chi Minh though as you were not allowed to stopNo cameras are permitted in the mausoleum and covered shoulders and covered knees clothing rule is strictly enforced in the mausoleum so it is rather hot considering the temperatures are around 36 degrees c. The rest of the exhibits require an entry fee and as there is not much signage in English it is not very interesting as you do not know what most pictures or displays are aboutVisited once but would not do it again as it is the usual tourist type displayBut is something to do to say you have seen it

Don't bother . Not much to write in this review . There is nothing except a long queue in hot weather .....all to see a fake dead body ( good air conditioning inside ) . The queue is for 2 hours and you will be able to spend about 2 minutes inside the mausoleum .

A must in hanoi. Great tour, Mae sure you take a guide it is helpful learning about the premises and Ho Chi Minhs life. To see Ho Chi Minh get there early, The line gets big and quickly and is only opened from 8am the 11am and check which days you can view. The complex is massive with a museum on the grounds as well.

RIP Mr. Ho Chin Minh. Nice place,not to be missed....large area in the center of the town...well maintained garden and guarded....every year they bring Ho Chi Minh remains to Russia for preservation work..make sure you don't walk in the wrong time... wont be able to see him...
Unbelievable. I was so amazed by seeing his body, I thought it was wax. I didn't know that you could preserve a body. You have to go there before 11:00am if you want to see the body.

Intimidating and Interesting... Cover up or you wont get in. Knees covered (or you will be forced to buy an overpriced shawl outside) and shoulders covered. This is a very interesting tour and well worth the visit. The filing past of the body - a bit too quick for the morbidly interested (me) ... The gardens etc are very beautiful and the story is amazing..Get a good guide, it is well worth it..
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Again, another icon not to miss when visiting Vietnam. Extremely interesting, quite a walk to get to the mausoleum, and was only open in the mornings.
Long lines for what?. We skipped this because of the lines but if you have a yen to see Ho's body, then stand in line - it moves quickly.

Great piece of history. Ho Chi MInh Mausoleum is a must see in Hanoi. We initially tried to go as part of our city tour on a Sunday but the line was ridiculously long! My recommendation would be to go during a weekday as our tour guide noted that most families will go with their children on the weekends. The line was still long when we went during the week but it went pretty fast. When planning your trip, just remember that the hours are only from 8am - 11am and closed on Mondays and Fridays.
HCM Complex. The mausoleum is within the complex. It helps to have a tour guide with you to explain the history of Ho Chi Minh.

Short but amazing tour.. I was amazed at how revered Ho Chi Minh is by the Vietnamese people. The mausoleum complex is enormous and the gardens and bonsai very impressive. Don't expect a long stay. You queue up, are marched in one door and out the other, no talking, hats, sunglasses, hands in pockets or crying children - all the time you are supervised by these armed soldiers in pristine white uniforms. No photography or cameras allowed inside the mausoleum.

A Big Part of Vietnam History. You should see it for the history. A very quite place and be sure to follow the rules of single line and no talking while going through the mausoleum. Nothing is worse than disrespectful people. It is interesting to see the modest home he lived in.

Botantical grounds worth a visit. Didn't bother lining up for over an hour for a 15 second visit, so visited the grounds instead. They are well-worth the time spent wandering and enjoying, although the crowds are extensive.We arrived fairly early in the day and enjoyed watching the school children and country people waiting to visit their father. The people watching was incredible, with bare-footed hill-people mixed in with expensive suits and dresses, all surrounded by children in uniform.

Worth a trip to see why "Uncle Ho" is so revered.. Be prepared to walk past Ho Chi Minh's preserved body in a very regimented and silent manner. The mausoleum is heavily guarded and you cannot linger but it was well worth visiting to gain an understanding of why the Vietnamese love him so much.

Nothing Special. My wife and I were here in 1992 and again this March, 2015. This time we went because our daughter wanted to see the Mausoleum. The reason for the review is to let other travelers know that the Mausoleum is only open in the morning between 8:00 AM-10:00 AM. Also once a year Ho's body is shipped off to China for "refurbishing". Check before you go to make sure he is there and the Mausoleum is open. If the Mausoleum was the only sight in the area it is probably not worth it, however, there are other notable sights in the same area. To see everything (museum, pagoda, etc.) give yourself 2 to 3 hours. To have a better understanding about Ho Chi Minh's life, the book " Rolling Thunder in a Gentle Land" is good to read.

Long Wait, The Body Is Made Of Wax. The que was 1.5 hours. Then you finally get into this small room with what appears to be a human body preserved via embalming fluids but we later found out it is actually a replicate made of wax. Soo, why did I wait in the que again? You should skip the que and see the rest of the estate which is quite lovely. Lots of well-behaved children, orderly conduct, and I think people were trimming the acres of grass with scissors. Everything you can expect from a diet communism country.

Very somber. Worth the visit plus walking through the grounds and visiting the other interesting sites. Be prepared for some queuing and ensure due respect. Heavily monitored by army personnel, make sure you follow their directions.

Save your money!. Unless you enjoy looking at dead people this is a place to avoid at all costs. The lineups to get in are LONG as the Vietnamese people love venerating their dead, and it is just not worth the time it takes. Go to the Vietnamese Museum of Ethnology or the History Museum instead.

A landmark worth a visit. Nice relaxing area for a stroll and pay respect to the father of a nation. The expansive lawn and the great mausoleum are impressive and provides a nice background for photos.

Worth it. Ho Chi Minh is a historical person and its body is preserve in this place for public to view and pay their respects. It also show the house he used to work and lived. You will basically learn more about the history of Vietnam, the fight for independence and this man.

The place your head will bow with respect.. The mousolium is imposing. The road leading to it is wide and even the rear roads are wide. The other monuments are attractive too. The simple place where Ho Chi Minh lived tells a story by itself. The beautiful lake with well kept trees around and the Palacial office building are worth visiting. The souvenir shops were neat and clean.The one pillar pagoda and the temple around are other attractions. We vitnesses a ceremony by old ladies with colourful attires.

Creepy & Exciting at the same time. It wasn't what I expected - but then again I didn't inform myself how "communist-leaders" are paid homage to after death.You have to walk in a row, like ducklings following a constant stream of tourists and locals, guarded by military-men every meter. You get this frosty feeling, beeing surrounded by so many weapons (except you're from america and are used to it I guess) , and it even gets creepier at the heart of the building, where Ho Chi Minh lies, guarded by non-moving snow-white guards. You have like 15 seconds to see it, because you walk a half-circle around the corpse-display and then leave the buildung again.It's an interesting body-cult, worth the trip there. But I still don't really know what to make of this experience.

Uncle Ho, Resting in Peace. This place is a must-visit when in Hanoi, a tribute to the idol of the Vietnamese, Uncle Ho Chi Minh. His preserved body may not be in the state that he wished for upon his death (he wanted to be cremated), but it allows millions of Vietnamese and foreign visitors to have a view of a man who meant the world to the country and its population. The queues can get long so be prepared!

Ho Chi Minh on site?. The long line ups require a bit of patience to see this important, historical site. Of course the memory of Ho Chi Minh is very important to many Vietnamese, and this is a respectful way to pay homage. Originally I was a bit hesitant to visit the site, thinking I might be bombarded with propaganda, but this was not so. The structure is very imposing, befitting any head of state for any nation. Once inside, you have to shuffle along with a lot of other tourists and locals to see Ho Chi Minh in repose. I doubt that it is the actual body of Ho Chi Minh, (it does look a bit waxy). All in all, it was a good way to meet locals and a few USA vets who were also there to pay respects.
Ho Chi Wow!. Very nice!, well maintained and very big place to see. Opens in the mornings only so be there before 11am.

It's a fantastic place to visit. we had to queu up to enter the mausoleum, and the hand bag we brought was big, so we had to put it in the store room, but it's a memorable time to visit the mausoleum....

NOT THAT UGLY LOOKING. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was ranked as the sixth most Ugly building in the world.I have not seen the other 5, so its difficult to rank the Monument.Its worth a visit for a few minutes.Here Ho Chi Minh read the Declaration of Independence.

Go - you have to - its central of Vietnamese history. You get the opportunity to view the body of Ho Chi Minh and you clearly gain a great understanding of his place in the history of modern Vietnam. Its a bit "Russian" in size and architectural design but its wortth a visit.

Make sure to check opening times!. The average rating here is really my fault as I didn't think to check the exhibit hours before heading over. My friends and I arrived at around 10:30 am and it was already closed for the day. I think the hours are fairly limited so make sure to get there on time if you want to get in. The outside was also pretty impressive though.

Worth getting up early for the flag ceremony.. Its worth getting there for 6am for the flag raising ceremony. An interesting place. 6am Flag raising ceremony. His tomb stands in the historic Ba Dinh Square which was the scene of fighting against the French and the Japanese and the place where Ho Chi Minh himself read out the Declaration of Independence in 1945.In the tradition of Lenin, Stalin and Mao, Ho Chi Minh’s Mausoleum is a monumental marble edifice. Contrary to his desire for a simple cremation, the mausoleum was constructed from materials gathered from all over Vietnam between 1973 and 1975. Set deep in the bowels of the building in a glass sarcophagus is the frail, pale body of Ho Chi Minh. The mausoleum is closed for about two months each year while his embalmed body goes to Russia for maintenance.

Worth a visit just to see the pomp and ceremony. When we arrived we almost gave it away because the queue stretched around an entire block. However, reviews had said that the queue moved quickly, and it did. The entire time for queuing and shuffling past Ho Chi Minh was only 50 minutes.Seeing Ho Chi Minh (who looked like a wax work from Madame Tussauds!) is not really that interesting, but seeing everything that went with this is quite something. Hundreds of school children, all of whom were keen to smile and wave and call out "hello" to us, were visiting the "father" of their nation. As were hundreds of Vietnamese people. They were all very obviously moved by seeing their leader.The queue time isn't boring because you get to see military officers marching around in their gum boots, and are often shoved into single file, or pulled apart into pairs (depending on the whim of the officer, or so it seemed) and trying not to giggle at everyone who is taking the queuing oh so seriously!It's free to go in, so worth a visit

Unclo Ho as he is fondly called is the Father of the Country and is entombed here in a glass casket. Long lines to visit and no cameras allowed. The line moves fast and we got to the mausoleum in 20 mins and had a minute to see Uncle Ho laying in a glass casket surrounded by an honor guard. Once you get out you also see the new Parliament building just across from the imposing masoleum

Long walk to Mausoleum. This was very interesting, to put it mildly. Walking double file around the grounds which probably spanded about a kilometre of more and took roughly 45 mins to walk, very slowly, stop, start, from gate to Ho Chi Minh. Guards everywhere, no phones, cameras or water bottles allowed and all to see a mummified body of the said "Ho Chi Minh" but rumours say it isn't really him just a wax figure - one will never know!!!

Must visit, Part of history. Huge area and involves some walking. We had a guide which made it easy to go through the place as he knew exactly where to go. The queues are long but we went very early in the morning and the line moved at a good pace. Once you are in the actual mausoleum, there is no stopping, the line just keeps moving but you are able to view the area well. The guards are everywhere. Interesting part of history and felt it was a good place to visit to get an idea of the history. Would recommend going as soon as it opens as crowds are less. No bags or cameras are allowed inside. They have to be turned in have if you have them. Have to dress respectfully, covered shoulders, no shorts.No talking and hands out of pockets and a respectful attitude is very important, otherwise the guards can single you out.This may sound intimidating but it really is not bad and a good place to visit. Just somethings to be aware of. Good idea to check the timings before going.Inside the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Ho's body lies in state under a glass sarcophagus, overseen by an honor guard of four sentries standing at each corner of the bier. The embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is very well preserved. His face and hands are illuminated.The rest of the room is dimly lit. The grounds have the presidential palace building but it is not open to tourists. One can see it from outside and straying from the designated path is not a good idea. The grounds have the wooden stilt house that Ho Chi Minh used to live in as he did not live in the palace and the house is open to the public and one can walk up the place and look at the house as the rooms are open. It is not very big and has only 2 rooms with few of his belongings. The grounds have fruit trees and a pond in the center.
A must visit place in Hanoi. Serene peaceful and wonderful location. For those who wish to see the remains of Ho Chi Minh should reach very very early atleast by 5:30 AM.

Interesting place. The thing that stands out most about the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is the efficiency in which everything was done. From entry to viewing and finish was about 20 minutes, even with long queues. The guards are very efficient also. No sunglasses. No phones. No cameras and it is imperative that you dress respectfully. Men and women wear long trousers and short sleeve shirts. No bare shoulders, short dresses or shorts allowed. I did not see it, but I was told that if you are no dressed respectfully enough then you may be asked to leave the site. Best to follow their rules.

Be prepared to be manhandled by security staff. Uneasy experience which starts with the long queues and the waiting, along with the instructions about bag sizes and no phones to guarantee entry. Once in the mausoleum (over an hour later) if you actually want to have a good look at the coffin and you do not walk 'fast enough' (whatever pace that may be) for the security guards they grab and drag you round. I obviously lingered for a fraction of a second too long and was grabbed and dragged twice. The whole process from beginning to end is regulatory and disciplinary and I get the distinct impression that any slight transgression such as sneezing or coughing could get you into hot water with the officials throughout this venue. Not for anyone who has any mobility issues or behavioural challenges as these will not be tolerated. Good respectful behaviour required throughout. The complex outside and Ho Chi Minhs house are fascinating and worth a visit.

Back history.. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, also known as President known as President Ho Mausoleum, Uncle’s Mausoleum is a place to keep the corpse of President Ho Chi Minh. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, officially started on Sept 2nd, 1973 and inaugurated on August 29th, 1975 is situated at the location of the former platform in the middle of Ba Dinh Square, where he had read the Declaration of Independence to found the Democratic Republic of Vietnam and chaired the great rallies.Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum opens 5 days a week, on Tuesday morning, Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday, and Sunday. In hot season ( from April, 1st to October 31st) from 7.30 a.m to 10.30 a.m and from 8 a.m to 11 a.m in cool season. Yearly, Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum closed for periodically maintenance in two months is October and November.

Atmospheric. Loved this experience. The queues are long but that just builds up the excitement. The guards are also totally unhelpful/unfriendly (so check out where to queue and opening times etc in advance) but again this just added to the somber atmosphere which built up to the few moments you get to spend in the actual mausoleum. You need to dress respectfully (which is reasonable) and only get a few moments in the actual room., but really it is worth the effort.
a must visit. you have to visit but it is a very regimented visit bags are not allowed and expect to queue lovely setting

Go at 2pm... We were very lucky to be there at 2pm to see the great spectacle of the changing of the guards. A very impressive building with the most exquisite collection of Bonsai trees I have ever seen in one place. Before 2pm you are not allowed to enter the gardens of the Mausoleum and only up to a certain painted line at the front guarded facade. After the guards have paraded and changed you are able to wander through the area and see the amazing work of the very talented gardeners all very busy pruning and dressing the impeccably manicured trees and lawns. A must visit.

A unique historical experience. The 45 minutes of queueing up with thousands of Vietnamese visitors (and a handful of tourists) make this a truely unique experience. The Vietnamese still honour HCM as the liberator of both colonial French rule and the victor of the American war, and treasure the moment they will get to spend paying tribute to his physical remains. It is a only a short moment that visitors walk past his embalmed body, but the quiet and scerene atmosphere make this a pilgrimage no one is likely to forget.

A visit of two parts. The mausoleum is impressive and it's grounds immaculately kept, with beautiful topiary. I personally would not have gone inside to see the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh, but my partner was interested and I might have offended our guide. I would, however, have gone to see the mausoleum. It was interesting to see how many Vietnamese go to pay their respects, including large parties of school children.

Very impressive view of Ho Chi Minh. The embalmed body, with 4 guards around it, is very impressive; the atmosphere is very solemn (no talk, no whisper, no camera allowed). You stand in a queue and go around his visible corpse under a glass cover in around 1 minute. I was told by a guide that they send his body once a year in Russia for restoration, and to renew his make up.Quite worth seeing it!

Loved it. Really wasn't sure what to expect. Loved the structure, the formality of the guards, Hoi chi Minh himself looks bazaar under the preserving lights, yet super interesting. Double Check the opening times, days, hours and even months (they close for a few months a year to refurb)

One we should have missed. This was not a great experience. It was difficult to know what we were looking at or what we should be looking at. The Qs can be long and the officials in uniform who run it are thoroughly scary and unsmiling. Yes you get to see Ho Chi Minh lying in. Glass box but I could not wait to get out of the place.

gives the chills. Visiting this mausoleum feels like being in a very closed communist regime for a few minutes. You have to be well dressed (shoulders and legs covered, at least for women), cant use sunglasses and your arms should remain close to your body. No photos & lots of vietnamese army men watching every step while you go to a very cold and dark chamber where Ho Chi Minh's body is at. Gives the chills.

Viewed from outside. Uncle Ho was on vacation in Moscow getting his annual make-over so he wasn't there when we visited and thus we didn't actually go into the mausoleum. If you are planning to go for the sole purpose of visiting him, make sure to check ahead of time that he will actually be there as he's gone 2-3 months each year. Make sure you either read up ahead of time or have a guide explain to you some of the history to appreciate the irony of the mausoleum. It is definitely a structure of store that should not be missed while in Hanoi. If you are not going to go inside, you can easily just stop by for ~5-10min to snap some pictures so really no reason not to stop by as it costs nothing to take pictures and takes virtually no time.

Absolutely essential to visit. Regardless of your politics, visiting uncle ho's mauseleum is an experience that should never be missed. Don't be put off by the queues. They move fast and is a part of the whole experience. By visiting here a westerner begins to get the feeling of the nationalism of Vietnam. do it!

So crowded. We went here but it was packed. The que to get in to view Ho Chi Minh was so long we didn't have to to wait. We looked at the grounds and his house instead. Worth doing if you have the time.

It was against everything Ho Chi Minh wanted. Ho Chi Minh is a greatly loved man by many Vietnamese. He brought peace back to the people of Vietnam after the north and south divide. He asked that when he dies he gets cremated and his ashes spread in the north, middle and south of the country as a symbol of this. When he died his wishes were not met and his body is now preserved and put on display to tourists. For a few months a year his body is shipped to Moscow for fixing. It is really quite sad. Just something to think about before visiting.

Must do. The mausoleum is must do in the early in the morning. It is open only from 8:30 AM to 10:30 AM. You will have to wait in line and no camera or device are permitted to enter the site. It will give you a great feeling of the regime at the time just like in Russia.
Revered. The Vietnamese nation is so obviously both proud of their late leader and the atmosphere of respect and reverence is so tangible. Everything kept proudly as perfect as they could.

Very, very odd!. We went to this thru morbid fascination! We were not disappointed, not because we were herded thru the whole initial entrance, that had very strange music going on, tv screens playing a odd video with subtitles telling you about the air quality, yes the air quality! It all felt like Disney gone wrong, not there is much right with that statement ;)So first stop, bags please, take your cameras out, second stop, get shouted at for not being in the line in twos, had your camera in, back in line, in twos please!Then shuffle thru the main hall. To get accosted by lots of white clad men/soldiers looking at you in a very scary way!Keep moving, keep moving!It's over you back outside, very surreal, very strange and a must just for the experience alone.

The interior is quite bizzare. It's like a mix of modern art and old-skool museum. There are a few things that look like it's misplaced. So distracting.If you have a good attention span, you'd be able to enjoy the actual museum displays such as manuscripts, pictures, costumes, etc.I was there walking alone, without a tour guide. Maybe it would be better if there's somebody explaining the whole story to me. Maybe...
A must see in Hanoi. This is another must see in Hanoi. it shows the dedication of the Vietnamese people to Ho Chi Minh. You can also see the military in action here.
A Mausoleum.... Well, it is maousoleum, nothing special... if you have spare tiem, it nice to see. Nothing special and the staff are not friendly.

history. Great tour and a guide is available for all details of Ho Chi Minhs life. Unbelievable to see him in the mausoleum with guards everywhere. Get there early as line up is long and Mausoleum closes early. line goes through quite quick. Vietnamese people love him.
A privilege. This is a worthwhile sight if visiting Hanoi. HCM seems to be the symbol of nationalism in Vietnam. It was interesting seeing all the schoolchildren and locals paying respect.

Stepping Back in History. How excited I was to know that I was going to step back in the history which I studied so many years ago. (Let me declare upfront that I am a history freak). To my disappointment we were visiting on a Monday and it was closed!. (The mausoleum is closed on Mondays and it's best to enquire first about opening times).Needless to stay just standing there and taking it all in and remembering was enough for me for that moment - remembering the Great leaders like Mahatma Gandhi, Nelson Mandela and Ho Chi Minh et al and all that they stood and fought for. The building is surrounded by guards (who won't let you cross the yellow line...smiles). The square is filled with beautiful flowers and we walk through to the Presidential Home. So now I am very curious to see the inside....that will have to wait for next time.

Pleasant garden setting for historical site. Disliked the regimented queue but viewing Ho Chi Minh's body was quite awe-inspiring. The surrounding gardens with the presidential palace, his houses and the lake are lovely.
Outside View Only. In a huge parade ground/square , obviously a must for the locals with the history but apart from the grandeur of the venue, not much to see

Hi Chi Minh msusoleum. We visited the mausoleum and you need to go there early. Considerable queues build up but these are managed very well and move quite quickly. Expect an hour or more. The mausoleum is free to visit but after you exit there is a small charge of 20VND to enter the gardens , the presidential palace and Ho Chi Minh's house . It's worth it. It's a good day and well worth the visit. It's does not open on Mondays and it closes for a few hours of each day. I think 11.00 until 2.00pm. Di best work around these times. You should enjoy it. Particularly if they change the guard whilst you visit .
Certainly worth a visit. Only open in the mornings. Long queues but moves very quickly. You are required to be respectful when visiting the Mausoleum and you cannot carry large bags or cameras.

Bizarre and interesting. Its worth doing this for the pageantry alone. Being ushered in by soldiers in their snazzy white uniforms makes for a very interesting and weird atmosphere. Be early so you don't have to queue.

Amazing. This is a really elaborate and very well visited monument to Ho Chi Minh. All visitors are expected to walk 2 by 2 and be extremely reverent. Cameras and bags must be left outside and phones must be switched off. Well worth a visit though.
Never open. I've been trying to see this place twice, but without any luck - I wish there was more information and that there was more people who could guide you
Give it a miss. After queing for an hour or more the sight of Ho Chi Mihn was an anticlimax which could well be missed if our guide did not impiy that it was mandator to visit.

Very calm quiet, people are watching him with reverence. As a part of of our day long city tour we arrived at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It is the first and main attraction at Hanoi. It is an iconic symbol of Vietnam. Visiting this place early in the morning is a very good experience especially in the winter season. The whole area look so beautiful. Before entering the secured area you have to hand over the travel accessories like Jacket, camera etc to the staff of security. If you are along with the travel guide he would carry all the belongings. While entering the area the people are standing in the que very politely and patiently. Ho Chi Minh is very well respected personality in Vietnam like Mahatma Gandhi in India. His body is kept in a glass box and the body is lying as if he is sleeping. People are looking at him with so much reverence. When you are coming out you are onto a well maintained garden. A very good experience.

Fascinating. Joined the queue and was fascinated by the organisation outside as different groups went ahead of us. Seeing Ho Chi Minh was a bit weird and he looks remarkably good considering the circumstances

Good people watching. Going to see a dead body doesn't usually make the must do list for a holiday but this was an interesting experience. What I enjoyed was watching the people around me as they saw him, I don't think I really understood the importance of Ho Chi Minh to the Vietnamese people until seeing this and the museum next door. I liked watching the guards as well, they were very serious about their job and making sure we were in neat queues. No strong desire to go back

Iconic Symbol. While I don't necessarily see Ho Chi Minh as a hero but rather just another communist dictator, I still paid my respects and saw this iconic symbol of Vietnam. The reviews say to be reverent. You can't help but be reverent as there are guards there that will hush you up if you speak. Photos are not allowed and the place is quite cold, a welcome relief from the intense heat outside. The whole site is beautiful and worth a visit. I really wanted to see it to compare with Chairman Mao's Mausoleum in Tianamen Square in Beijing. Both bodies look fake as the legend amongst both are that they are indeed fake. Nevertheless, I was glad to visit and would do so again.

If you like mausoleums, you'll like this one..... As part of the tour we were on, we queued with the others, walked up the red carpeted stairs, saw Uncle Ho and the po-faced guards, walked down the other side and out into the sunlight. If you are going to worship dead dictators and make their tombs tourist destinations, this was as good as any I have seen. Good toilets, too.

Hi Chi Ming mausoleum. This is an interesting experience that means different things to different people and different cultures
Ho Chi Ming is a national hero in Vietnam and it is important to he respectful when visiting the site.
There are multiple components to the site: gardens, walkways, and finally the actual mausoleum. It is a serene yet somber place, an iconic monument.

A good experience. It was a very serious visit as we approached the entrance. There were guards who keep everything in order - no holding hands, no caps/hats, no pictures until you are outside the mausoleum. It was a short visit as the queue was quite long. A good experience for us.
High Security. Absolutely no cameras. There are so many security guards, and they make you feel like you are intruding.

About as Exciting as Watching Rock Grow. Unless compelled, not a p[lace to visit other than as a curiosity. Why do all Beloved Leaders need such monolithic tombs? And, don't cross the red line or you will be yelled at or worse. Cute changing of the guard ceremony.
Good place!. So crowded on the holidays but free week-day. Something different than before inside. But I really love visiting there on the holidays, I feel touched.

Nice place with weird rules. It's like a history lesson and some required readings. It can be awfully boring for some but very interesting for others. It's essential if you want to learn more about the man who was credited with reuniting the north and south, and fighting off the foreign powers who tried to occupy them. Plus: the grounds are very beautiful and one can take lots of photos. Negative: they have all sorts of rules that can seem arbitrary. No shorts (even for men), you can't bring DSLRs but a phone with a camera is ok, no "large" bags and backpacks (but no one can seem to define what large is), no picture taking of the grounds (we were stopped a couple of times while walking towards the Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum but it was a free for all as soon as we exited the mausoleum and to the other nearby places such as the presidential palace, and HCM's various residences within the grounds.

Owes more than a little to Madame Tussauds!. Interesting visit to Uncle Ho's embalmed body; we liked the fact that the crowds filing past were respectful, as befits the man who was so influential in the recent history of this tortured country. However the body does look suspiciously good, but perhaps the embalmers' art is better than we think!

Is he there?. Is it him or his wax double? Story is he is flown to Russia regularly for re-embalming and replaced with a wax copy!All a bit too serious. I don't think Uncle Ho wished for himself to be worshiped like this... same goes for Buddha...Oh well, humans will be human.

Interesting experience. having read other reviews we knew what to expect. However in contrast to others the Vietnamese group around showed no respect. They had their phones out taking selfies and were told off on three separate occasions. I'm glad we experienced this as it was very interesting to gain an insight into the history but it is a fairly short excursion and not one we would repeat on a return visit

Worth a visit. We were quite amazed at the sheer size of the mausoleum and the square in front of it. It felt a bit like Tiananmen Square in Beijing but smaller. You certainly know you are in a communist country here. We didn't queue to see his preserved body as it would have been at least a half an hour wait. Instead we walked around the area and saw the interesting French architecture of the chateau style house that was offered to Ho Chi Min to live in. However he did not want it as he thought it far too removed from the way his people were living. Instead he chose a humble home which you can visit, made from teak wood and looking very similar to the homes on stilts that his people lived in.

Very impressive! Well worth a visit. Just get in the line once you pass security otherwise you will be directed to exit.. We went today as we missed it last time we were in town. We were so surprised how well preserved Mr Ho Chi Minh's body is. There is so much security around so do show respect and please wear appropriate clothing. Ho Chi Minh's palace and museum are near so would be good to do it all in the same day. Do be aware that the opening times are 8:30am to 11am. It is important to embrace the history and this man was a massive part of Vietnamese history. It was a little confusing when we entered. We went through secrity, then were getting told to exit. It was very strange. If you see a line of people just get in that line to enter the building. It was confusing once inside the premises but just get in the line.

Ho Chi Minh. This is so obviously a treasure to the people of Vietnam, they loved him like a Father. It is very important to follow their requests on correct dress and behavior. Also no photos - only at the building and from a distance. You walk through and no stopping allowed. His remains are so perfect and not even covered with glass. It is only open two days a week for a few hours each day only, you will have to check it out and plan well because queues are very long, so get there early. We went on to see his places of residence and the beautiful lake. Well worth the visit. Do stop and see the one pillar temple on the way out.

Impressive for what it is. I wouldn't normally go out of my way to view a body, but Ho Chi Minh is an important and almost sacred figure to the Vietnamese so we did it. Line is very very long to get in, but don't be put off, it moves along quickly. Large cameras and backpacks have to be checked and then re-claimed after.

Regimental!. We were taken to the Mausoleum by our local guide on our walking tour,it was a bit of a surprise because he never said we were going there! The Mausoleum is a very imposive and impressive building,we were asked to photograph it from outside the grounds as you are not allowed to use cameras once inside.We were faced with a very long queue but it moved along quite quickly,kept in order by the various guards.Women with bare shoulders are asked to cover up. Once inside the Mausoleum you pass by the glass covered coffin of Ho Chi Min,it just looks like he is sleeping.After departing,you can get another ticket to take you into the part of the estate where the leader lived,you see his offices,cars,house etc.It's a lovely area with a lake and beautiful trees. There is an area for a refreshment and souvenirs.

Thought provoking as a foreigner. I visited at around 10am on Sunday and was amazed at how many people there were there. Hundreds already. The queue moved at a reasonable pace and I had the unfortunate mis pleasure of being in front of three Australian women in their 50s (my least favourite type of traveller). As other reviews stated the respect that the Vietnamese feel for Ho Chi Minh is incredible, and more interesting to me than the tomb itself, so I wish I had been in amongst more Vietnamese to see their reactions. The grounds were amazingly well kept, clean, and beautiful gardens, once again pointing to the money the government spends on itself in favour of the people.
A powerful experience. Very interesting to see Ho Chi Minh lying in state. The extent of respect shown was very impressive.

Ho Chi Minh’s burial wishes ignored. He just wanted to be cremated and his ashes scattered. This building looks like a typical ugly Russian architectural eyesore and is apparently is rated the 6th most ugly building in the world. The grounds around the Ba Dinh Square are nice to walk around in and the surrounding colonial buildings show some style, but unfortunately can’t be photographed because they are government? There are no photo signs on most of the buildings in the neighbourhood.One Pillar Pagoda is more inviting, as is the stilt house.

Visit but not just to see Ho. I have reached the trifecta of mausoleums having seen Mao, Lenin and now Ho. It's a dubious distinction I suppose. Ho is looking about as good as can be expected. But for me, the importance of our visit was observing the reverence Vietnamese visitors demonstrate for this hero of their liberation. Seeing Ho is truly moving when seen through their eyes and the seriousness with which the guards do their duty. Do visit Ho but look around you at your fellow visitors when you do. Their faces will enrich the experience for you.

One of those things you should see.. Fortunately the crowds and queues were not very long on the day we visited. Despite this we were made to move quickly through. The importance of Ho Chi Minh to Vietnam is significant and so we wished to see him.

A Must See in Hanoi.. No visit is complete without a visit here as they worship Ho Chi Min. To understand this country you need to see the line up of Vietnamese people and respect they pay here. Almost like the Vatican. You stand in a line 2x2 and their is silence as they usher you thru his tomb. A quick visit but an important one. Like Stalins tomb in Moscow.

Give Uncle Ho his respect. a long line in the morning to view Ho Chi Minh lying in state. The locals are moved to the point of tears. This is a must do experience while visiting Hanoi, paying your respects to the George Washington of Vietnam....whatever your political views.
The must. This is the most impressive place for me. You can feel the respect of Vietnamese people for Ho Chi Minh here.

You actually SEE HIM.. You get the full experience doing the march with the guards and are escorted through the mausoleum. I could not believe that was his actually body. So amazingly preserved. We also saw the changing of the guards. They walk km's with there legs up high to do this. Really crazy cool experience.

A unique place to visit.. It is interesting to see the well preserved body of Ho Chi Minh the first president of Vietnam. The people of Vietnam regard him as the father of their modern nation free from foreign intervention.

An Experience Like No Other. A mausoleum with the vivid viewing of the body of a Vietnamese and political icon in a beautifully built and maintained building and area. Probably the only chance in a lifetime to have such an experience.
Beautiful surroundings. Large, spacious boulevard, interesting to look at. Easy to find and not too busy. Would have been more interesting if we could enter building.
Uncle Ho. Natasha is still in shock that it was really him. Uncle Ho preserved as if it was 1969, even if he did want to be cremated.
Grand Setting but Not Much to Fill Your Experience. Must say the setting was grand and clean. Visited the tomb inside the Mausoleum. Not much to see other than it.

We wasted our time. We walked from our hotel to the complex. Got to the mausoleum and it was closed for some reason. Nothing to see but guards in white uniform. We took some photo of the building though.

Lovely place to walk around. It is interesting to see how revered he is and to go through the queuing. We went through the gate and then about 100 school kids came through. A lot of them love to say "hello" to the Americans; it was the highlight of the visit.

Must See, from outside. The Ba Dinh Square, is where the mausoleum is located is worth seeing, not quite as impressive as Teinamen square but close. Our guide advised us not to queue to see Ho Chi Min as the queue was very large and would take hours to have a glimpse but no photos.

Long wait, very strick rules, eerie. The wait was about an hour, in the open sun. They're very strict on rules while waiting in line and of course in the mausoleum itself (no hands in pockets, no hats, no sitting in line). Once inside, it was eerie to see a preserved body so clearly, I hadn't realized you could see it through glass, thought it would be sealed. Not sure I would take my 10 and 12 yr old kids again.

Quite literally, a must see. This is an awesome experience, as it was meant and designed to be. It was the first place our group was taken to visit. The dress code is strict -- no shorts, no sleeveless shirts or blouses, no hats. And, of course, no photography inside. You follow the endless crowd up and then around Ho's glass coffin. Inside the body is preserved, we were told, chemically. It looks very natural. With the moving line, once you're inside the building, it takes perhaps 5-8 minutes. Something you may have to do as a visitor and, on balance, worth doing for the experience.

interesting insights. The place is well organised and orderly. It is a highly recommended visit. Do not wear shorts. Take off you hats and sunglasses. Be respectful. This place gives you an idea about how well loved and respected HCM was and is. Interesting to note, is the fact that HCM did not want to be mummified or revered this way. Also Uncle Ho's house on stilts is a great place to visit.The museum, which is part of the complex, is a waste of time and lacks any insights or education into HCM and his legacy.

Definitely something to see if spending time in Hanoi. We went here on a Saturday afternoon to find that the Mausoleum was closed, we were still able to walk around the complex. Pretty much everything is gated off with large exclusion zones so it is difficult to get a good view of anything. The lake inside is nice and it was interesting to see Ho Chi Minh's house, cars and the house on stilts.We returned the following day to enter and see Ho Chi Minh. The line was huge but moved very quickly - be mindful of people who push in initially though. Once through the first security check point you have to leave your back pack at a luggage check point and are given a tag for collection. About 150m further along you are required to hand over your camera and are also given another tag. From there you queue up again and walk along until you get to the main building. There are guards everywhere, some with firearms and bayonets attached. As you approach the building you must walk in two single files. You are required to walk around to the left inside the building, up the stairs in an anti clockwise direction towards the body. You then enter a cold, quiet room where there are 4 guards standing with guns/bayonets at either corner of a clear glass coffin. You are not permitted to stop walking and will be ushered along if you do. You are probably in the room for about 1 minute all up but I definitely think it's something to be seen whilst in Hanoi.After you leave the building you return to a different point close by to collect your camera and the same place as where you drop your bag off.Entry to the Mausoleum is free and there is a 25 000 VND fee if you wish to see the rest of the complex.

Nothing but a pain in the you know where. No cameras, check those seperate to the bags you need to check, no communication, short hours, unfriendly service, simple, and nothing special. Long lines and disneyland like atmosphere with a military like communist flavor. Spend your time and money meeting and talking with lovely local people. Ho Chi Minh was a great historical figure, but this mosuleumm doesn't do him any justice what so ever.

First timers to a mausoleum. Be sure to check times as I beleive it is only open until 11am. Two in our group got herded into a lineup that was going to the mausoleum and we didnt know it. The other 4 missed out as it closed by 11am. When you go to the museum complex do this first. It is everything you would expect from our tv experiences into mausoleum protocol. Marching single file into a cool, dark building, parading around the glass encased and guarded body. So interesting.

So much love & respect here. Visiting this Mausoleum will give you a very realistic idea of just how much he was loved, honored and respected in Vietnam. Very short visit but a must do to experience Vietnamese culture.

It was ok, long lineup in sun though.. You are herded in long.libe to stand in sun for 30 mins then quickly marched.inside and past Ho Chi Minhs body. I expected more information about him (a musuem or somethin). The grounds were nice, but it isn't something id do again.

Worth while. A strange experience but worth while. It is strange for Westerners that so much respect and adoration is given to someone at the time of my childhood was considered to be "bad". Thus, like many things it brings home how things and people are judged by the media that is read at the time and pre-conceived notions.

cult of personality. like in Mother USSR the communist party of Vietnam developed the worshipping of Ho Chi Minh. His role in fighting for independence and unification of vietnam was detrimental and he was really a great leader with the vision of free Vietnam, yet the culture of personality is somewhat exaggerated. The Mausoleum is a huge gray building, you go into quite dark staicases to arrive at the glass coffin with Ho Chi Minh embalmed body. 6 fully armed soldires are standing on both sides of the coffin, frozen without any movement. ypou are not allowed to stand there for a long time, you must walk in line , complete the way around the coffin and go out, not to stop the infinite line of visitirs.It is impressive in its own way.

Check Times. This place is not always open. No pictures are allowed inside and people are kept quiet and kept moving. Go early as when it is open, it gets very croudedI would have liked a chance to slow down and really LOOK at the body. It seems more like a Madam Tussauds wax model.Glad we had the opportunity to view it as not everyone does.

Interesting experience. There is something infinitely interesting about visiting this mausoleum, something about the armed guards that seem like they are watching your every move and the absolute order you must follow. Don't get me wrong there is something slightly scary but an absolute must do to really get an insight into Vietnamese culture and really how much Ho was revered. The museum which follows is also a great look into communism in Vietnam

For History's Sake, Well Worth A Visit!. We didn't really plan on seeing Ho Chi Minh lying in State, but's that's what we ended up doing! We walked from The Old Quarter in Hanoi to the Mausoleum (about 20 mins, easy walk, except the entrance is not where you think it might be, turn left at the start of the Mausoleum/Gardens and keep walking)! It's a worthwhile experience for those of us that remember the Vietnam War; for younger people it probably won't mean much. Interesting to see the revered "Uncle Ho" (preserved and sent to Russia every year for "maintenance"). A historic icon in Vietnam, but sad to have read in various writings that he just wanted to be cremated and his ashes scattered over Vietnam. The gardens, pond, his house, and seeing the cars he drove were restful after (briefly) filing past his remains. Not for everyone. You really have to go with a feeling for the history of the era and some knowledge of the conflicts within Vietnam.
Scenic but not much to see. See above. It didn't look like you could go in but it is in a nice setting with lots of green space and areas to walk around or sit on benches.
Stark. When you are here you feel as if you are in a communist country. Which you are being a socialist country. The monument is nicely kept and big. I enjoyed it and its a must see for Hanoi.

Definitely worth a look. Make sure you find out in advance if this is open as apparently the body is only in the mausoleum for certain parts of the year. I also recommend going very early to beat the rush.Our guide took us around the grounds quite quickly to begin with. It would have been quite confusing if we were on our own as it was not obvious where to go or what the protocol was. We saw many war veterans paying their resects and then we were ushered in to the mausoleum. You have to keep moving past the body and the walk though only took a few minutes but it was quite interesting. We then saw more of the grounds and the house Ho chi min lived in which was also quite interesting. None of this attraction was mind blowing but if you have a good guide who can tell you the back ground and some good stories then it is definitely worth a look.
.... Although this mausoleum was really big but i did not feel much happy when i be there cos it was too tired and bored

Dead good. Not sure about this, I can well understand the reverence for 'Uncle Ho', and the ceremonies of wreath laying and honour guard are well done, but the restricted opening times ensure visiting is very busy with a crowded experience in the mausoleum, which seems inappropriate.I guess you should do it, but if you are the least bit squeamish I'd suggest you don't go!
The highlight of our trip to Hanoi. It is spectacular and surreal.You must see this as it shows how the Vietnamese still revere Uncle Ho.

A must see experience . Coming from the United States and growing up in the Vietnam war time we enjoyed seeing how the people hold this man in such high regard. Not often do you get to view a body that is preserved since he died in 1969. Our guide informed us that on the fall they close the museum and fly the body to Russia where they update the preservation of the body I call it getting a spa treatment of keeping him looking good,

Solemn & peaceful; interesting historical site. Interesting learning experience, historically, politically, and culturally. Remember to wear proper attire, no short skirts or shorts. The grounds are neatly kept. The guards will not hesitate to remind you where you can & cannot walk! Photos are not allowed in the mausoleum.

Interesting place to visit.. Very interesting place and area to visit with Mausoleum protected by guards marching up and down. We did not actually go inside where HCM is lying in state - not open anyway during our visit and apparently usually long queues. Can also visit HCM's residences and where he located himself to avoid American raids, etc.
A fitting tribute. Important to visit this park and mausoleum. Great insight into the man and the country. Changing of the guard and personal quarters particularly touching.

A humble mausoleum. My earlier comments on the Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace Historical Site were actually meant for the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum.In short, it is a place worth to see and pay respect to a great statesman of Vietnam. Whatever difference we may have with his ideology over politics and war, he was a man dedicated to his country and people.

An interesting couple of hours. An interesting way to spend a couple of hours. Very funny sensation to be forced in to walking two a breast even if with a total stranger. The actual Mausoleum is slightly surreal. You will have your camera taken from you at the entrance and you will pick it up from a totally different place but it's increibly well organised so don't have any concerns.

Great place, but don't step out of the lines. Fascinating, but don't cross the lines. I stepped over to take a picture and immediately 3 people started approaching. I stepped away and all was fine. Obey the rules 100%.
Mausoleum. It's worth a visit although we didn't go inside as it was closed for Tet so just walked around the grounds
Sacred experience. Don't be put off by the line it moves fast very unique and special experience obviously very sacred to the people of Vietnam

Striking cultural experience. Honestly felt surreal, the whole experience. At times I thought I was on a movie set. The whole environment seemed designed to engender respect and awe. Get there early, as the last groups come in mid morning. Cameras not allowed as you go thought to see Uncle Ho lying in state - which when you get there you see why. - it seemed disrespectful to take photographs. Security is tight. Being up close with the security was exciting, a little unnerving. In authoritative white uniforms, with gold and red trim, and snappy hats made them fabulous subjects for a long shot with my camera, when I finally got it back from the authorities. Photography of the guards is not encouraged, however. Use discretion! Go in with an open mind, obey the rules, and respect the experience. It was amazing.

Ho Chi Minh. Closed in Mondays...non-Vietnamese visitors can get in quickly. Go early to advoid the lines. It is a quick walk around the embalmed Ho Chi Minh. The outside of the building is impressive.
Sombre reflection. Well presented and lovely surrounding grounds but experience fairly controlled. One to see on your visit to Hanoi but not get excited about

Must see, but be prepared for a bit of a queue.. Long queues, but pretty efficient.Lots of men in uniform looking stern and bored and no cameras allowed - most people still used phone cameras instead.The respect they show for Ho Chi Minh is very much evident and the honour guard in the tomb is top notch.Odd opening hours so you need to make sure it will be open.

"Now, there's something you don't see everyday!". Another must see for Hanoi. Iconic Uncle Ho in all his mummified glory. A little surreal for sure. Make sure you obey all the rules! Also, very interesting and scenic surrounding grounds and complex.

Didn't go in, but the park outside was great. Came during new year, so the place wasn't open but really enjoy the park outside, and looking at the white uniform-soldier guarding the park, blooming flowers, red vietnam flag all over the place, can really make you feel all the more the patriotism spirit of the Vietnamese and their devotion for Ho Chi Minh.

No cameras or large bags.. Very tight security, they don't allow you to take large cameras, and all bags are X-rayed. And if your a person with disabilities be warned as it's not easy! In my group was an elderly man in a wheel chair. The guards had to pick his wheelchair up and down the stairs. Although he quite enjoyed this, others may not be comfortable with this. The whole experience is quite quick, takes longer to question and get up the stairs. Well managed and controlled environment.

Didn't go inside. We didn't realize how early this closes, but we enjoyed walking around it. It is a stately building with beautiful flowers setting it off and big banners too. Loved the white uniformed guards.

Being in the communists' town. Interesting feeling while the police requested you to remove all belonging (cameras, video recorder and telephones) as you shouldn't take picture.This remind you of Moscow. Some of my friend refuse to do this.

Closes early and no photographs. We went midday, and sadly last entry is at 10:30 in the morning. Also, there were numerous signs outside saying cameras and mobile phones are not allowed inside.You can also not get that close to the mausoleum from the outside as guards surround it and blow their whistles and get all cranky when you step over the small barrier.

Macabre exhibit, leader lying in state. This seems to be a trait of Communist states and like Lenin, Ho Chi Minh the much revered Communist leader is lying in a temp and air controlled glass coffin. There are honour guards dressed in white uniforms posted at every turn inside. No photos are allowed to be taken and tourists are kept moving round it as you look in. The body looks to be fresh and asleep or is it a Madam Tussauds waxwork? You decide.

Very interesting tour. This is something not to miss, the gardens in the mausoleum is very beautiful. Was a very interesting historical tour of the life of Ho Chi Minh. His body is brilliantly protected and is so life like.

Unique and very impressive. Very impressive building and the awe of this one person is evident. A definite piece of their history to experience. Get there at 8am when it opens and the journey to the entrance isn't quite so long.

Impressive Edifice. Didn't go in as queues were very long, so walked around and visited the simple house HonChi Minh lived in, alongside his rather large fishpond. Don't miss the One Pillar Pagoda nearby.
propaganda museum. museum seems to tell a very colored story. It seems that it is more about Vietnamees propaganda and the celebration of 85 years's of communism in Vietnam than anything else.
Worth the journey. A rare opportunity to see Ho Chi Minh in the flesh. Quite an experience! Entrance is free but you have to queue to get in and walk a short distance in an orderly, sedate line.
A 'must see' when visiting Hanoi. Part of a general city tour that's worth seeing. Very large free-standing large complex with frequent elaborate "changing of the guards" ceremonies.

Well.....you have to go since you are there. No even Ho Chi Min wanted something monumental as his current Mausoleum. It is good to go because we have to see the country and its attractions. The order and respect to visit the Mausoleum is amazing but to much and way to big building for a country where most of the people struggle in the rice fields for living.

We weren't prepared.... Our guide did not tell us what to expect, nor did I do my homework prior to arriving. When you are guided through....your guide can not walk with you, so you are yelled at to get in a single file line, and marched through the grounds...all of this was a bit exciting and unnerving. Once inside, you are walked past Ho Chi Mihn's body laying in state...you are then required to "bow" out of respect to their former leader. Overall it was interesting and educational. Once outside of the Mausoleum, the guide can then meet up with you again, and things relax...the grounds are beautiful and it is a must see while in Hanoi.

Great sense of reverance. It was amazing to see Ho Chi Minh. There was a great sense of ceremony and reverence at the Mausoleum and it was good to see the how the Vietnamese people and tourists alike visit. I highly recommend adding it to your itinerary when you visit.

interesting, but a little creepy. loved seeing the reverence shown to their leader. This is a beautiful monuement, but it seemed a little creepy, keeping him laying in state. Especially since they went against his wishes.
Good to see Uncle Ho.. It was the most popular place to visit in the hole city. There were tourist from all over the world.

closed. there was a cordon around so no entry to mausoleum
the surrounding area with the one leg pagoda was good
and also the museum

Beautiful grounds, Mausoleum closed on Mondays and Fridays. Felt we had to go but sadly closed on Mondays and Fridays - unfortunately our guide hadn't warned us about that. As others have said grounds are well cared for and very relaxing after the turmoil that is daily life in Hanoi but be careful not to put a foot wrong as you'll be shouted at by the guards.

Pretty cool site. I was in Vietnam for a year and I have not had the chance to go inside the Mausoleum (as it was closed). However, it is nice to walk around and look at all of the Bonsai trees and gardens they have in the surrounding area. Great for pictures.
Nice and quiet. Impressive building but we were too late to to enter the mausoleum. We walk around the place and took some photos.

Strange. It was very strange getting filed into two straight lines and shuffled through a winding route. At one stage I lost my friend and I felt like i'd never see her again. The guards are pretty intimidating and it's quite a suppressive environment. You never really know what you are allowed to do. The room where Ho Chi Minh is lying is dimly lit and eery, and ultimately very cool. I just hope it's real.

An excellent morning in Hanoi, North Vietnam. There are many things to do in Hanoi, but one must-see is The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. One word of advice, the queues can be long, so get there early. It was an easy walk from my hotel, the wonderful Pullman Hanoi, and I was there around 8.30 am to be near the head of the queue when it opened at 10 am. Many people who came late would have missed ou when it closed. Within this area is also the Presidential Palace, Ho Ch Minh's House, the Botannical Gardens and the One Pillar Pagoda. All up I spent some 5 or 6 hours touring these complexes and it was a day very well spent. On one level there is something a bit ghoulish about seeing his body like that, on another it is a very effective memorial to the father of modern Vietnam. There was very deep respect from foreigners and locals alike. Quite a moving experience.
Closed that day. Unfortunately the day we visited it was closed for maintenance so we didn't get to see inside. However we did get to wander around the gardens. Very beautiful.

bit creepy. I think it's kinda part of communism trend to balsam corpse and display for public. I'm still bit puzzled with this creepy idea.Worth a shot once - this was my first and last mausoleum visit!

must see. although the sight of a dead person (for many many years) is not the best of sights for all, this man has been instrumental to the history of Vietnam. It is a must for every hanoi visitor. Go early, as they are quite disorganised and you may feel confused with the guest processing system. Last entry is 10.30. Leave the tablet at home. you won't be allowed in with it.

You must visit!!. This was amazing. Seriously. It only lasted less than a minute (viewing the body) but it's a whole experience. You walk in single file and you must be quiet with guards everywhere watching your every move. It was so surreal to see Ho Chi Minh inside the glass case, I was so sure it was fake. It was amazing! I could have walked through again and again and again. It was absolutely fascinating! It costs nothing so no excuses! Every visitor to Hanoi must visit!
Impressive Building. We just walked around the building, but were definitely impressed by it. Not sure if you can go in or not, but it's in a gorgeous area.

Make this last on a day's itinerary. We were told no cameras at all while queuing but cameras are everywhere after coming out of the mausoleum. Same spot big difference. Enjoy the walk on the compound. Not much time is required to visit because you can only circle around Ho Chih Minh for less than 5 minutes. Instead of going early to be the first in the queue, I recommend to make this the last place on your itinerary. An hour max for adults.

Worth visiting when in Hanoi. Quite an interesting museum, showing the evolution of Ho Chi Minh's ideas and giving a social and historic background to it. Visually the set up is quite modern despite the museum was set up a few years ago. Next to it it is nice to visit the single pillar pagoda

Hmmmm. What pomp and circumstance. It was interesting to spend 2 1/2 hours in a single file line being ushered through the mausoleum, Ho Chi Minh's living quarters, and the immense (and beautiful) grounds. Heaven forbid if you wanted to leave early. You can't. You are there for he whole experience. No rule breaking here.The propaganda output is as immense as the grounds.
Not one to rate. A somber visit but it shouldn't need a rating. The guards were very strict. No talking, hands behind your back or sunglasses. Certainly no cameras allowed.
Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. Very interesting, beautiful gardens, worth a visit, go early in the morning to avoid crowds, took about 15 min from the centre of the old quarter by taxi

Beautiful and peaceful at night. We passed by Ho Chi Minh mausoleum when we did the Hanoi food motorbike tour in Hanoi. It had great atmosphere and very quiet at night time. We didnt have enough time to visit it or go inside to find down but next time we definitely come back again :). We love Hanoi so much

Against Ho Chi Minh's wish. Mausoleum of a preserved Ho Chi Minh; this is against Ho Chi Minh's wish for his body to be creamated and not celebrated. Only waited a few minutes on a cloudy Sunday morning. Guards are very serious. No bags, hats, sunglasses, iPads, photos, or hand in pockets. You have less than 1 minute to see the body. If the wait is long, I would skip this.

The great man.. This visit was a privilege indeed. Arrive early about 8am, the visit is very regimented and orderly. But you can see the love and respect that the country has for the great man. He looks like he is peacefully sleeping so wasn't creepy at all. You are not permitted to take your camera into the Mausoleum and it will be stored for you and returned immediately.

Certainly worth seeing once. The line up seems long, but it moves briskly. The guards take their task very seriously. Some tourists in front of us had their hands in their pockets when we were entering, and the guard snapped at him to remove them immediately. It's very orderly. The tour walks you up a set of stairs, into the chamber, and you walk around Uncle Ho. He is preserved beautifully. I'm glad we went.

Ok.... . We went here on rainy day, queue wasn't so big but judging by the queuing system it must get busy here in the summer. You literally only see the body for 10 seconds, no information about Ho Chi Minh on display so you will have to do your own studying before you go to understand his importance the Vietnamese people.

A must see. The queues are long but soon go down. Expect tight security with bags & cameras taken from you & guards who take their duty very seriously. Hands in pockets are frowned upon as disrespectful. The visit itself takes around a minute once you reach the building itself as no-one is allowed to stop. I must admit that I went out of morbid curiosity myself & didn't really know what to expect. To me, the body didn't look real ... I know it is ... but then I'd never seen a body which has been preserved for so long before. Guess that's why we visit???

Worth seeing if you're interested in Vietnam's history. We visited the mausoleum on a rainy day, so we did not have to wait too long to enter. The tour inside the mausoleum is very short, you have to keep on moving, no time to take a good look and taking pictures is not allowed. The building itself is huge, but not really nice. With the same ticket, you can also see a government building in french style, which is quite nice, and the wooden house were ho chi minh used to live.
Mum and daughter. Quite an experience to see Uncle Ho in the flesh. It was quite a line up to get in but well worth it. The museum is very beautiful

Long wait and a quick get in and out. We had to stand in a really long queue to get in, it took us almost 45 mins, while inside is a quick walk around the body, no photography allowed in, so in case you dont have the time or it does not interest you it would be better to skip the line for going in and just have a look from outside, you wont miss much.
This was a very nice introduction to Hanoi. Arriving in Hanoi our guide brought us to the Mausoleum. It was a very good introduction to the country and his history
History of Vietnam. An excellent place to start and learn all about Vietnam, Ho Chin Minh contribution in liberating Vietnam, not a place for me but a must go place for all history lovers

WOW!. When we were told that Ho Chi Minh was still on display (he died in 1969) we thought it was a bit over the top. Some of us decided to go anyway and it was worth the visit. Apparently he is transported to Russia for two months every year for refurbishment - not sure what term is correct for that procedure but maintenance seems harsh. It is serene and well managed. You walk through without stopping but do pass by three sides as you go through the facility. Lines went quickly - be sure to be properly dressed and follow directions completely.

Based on a true story. I am not very much into history but with a nice tour guide the whole experience at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum became a woderful experience with stories after stories.
