I've learned so much about the history of Vietnam, the mentality of Vietnamese people, the views of new generation. What a fascinating place! My recommendation is " a good tour guide is a MUST"

Interesting enough. To be honest I somehow felt both overwhelmed and underwhelmed by my visit to the mausoleum and surrounding palace etc. The mausoleum itself is impressive, though accessing it seemed to involve dropping different personal belongings at different locations and collecting a tag at each which was weird.Ho Chi Minh looks ethereal bathed in orange light, but you won't get to gaze upon him for long, guards are on hand to give your elbow a gentle nudge to keep the flow moving.Once outside I needed to stop and get my bearings, working out what I wanted to visit, but guards didn't seem to like that so I got ushered into the presidential palace complex which was another long queue of tourists all the way around the several buildings. The temple was closed for refurbishments and by the time I ambled past the souvenir sellers to the museum, I couldn't bare more tourists (plus the place looked huge). In the end I made my escape and headed for the Temple of Literature for some peace and quiet. It's worth a visit but know what you want to do before you go and be ready for the crowds!

We gave up. Too crowded.. We didn't get inside. It was a public holiday. The line to get in was miles long. It was on our tour itinerary and fortunately our guide saw that we were not that interested and just moved on. However, the view from the outside was nice. Big, impressive, Soviet-style building. There is a huge piece of vacant land, very well-manicured out front. Several football fields big. It's patrolled by many young policemen or guards in ill-fitting uniforms who look like they will give you what for if you ignore the "Don't Step on the Grass" signs and disturb a single blade.Before we gave up, standing in line, watched a video of the highlights of Ho's life. That was qquite ok and I enjoyed it, but I would have rather watched it in the hotel room.

History. This is a historical site where the building in which Ho Chi Minh himself is buried in. I didn't get to go inside because i came on a Friday. They say if you go in, you have to be respectful. No horsing around. No pictures. No smiling! so be warned!In front of the mausoleum was a huge Vietnam Flag. Other than that, it was just open space. The area is open supposedly for the people to gather and just hang out. There was an entrance at the back however, that led to Ho Chi Minh's old dwellings and his massive fish pond full of Koi fishes. The architecture was French. The walls were painted intense yellow and the trees were chalked at the base.Saw three of Ho Chi Minh's cars that were given to him as presents.It was a good visit. With the right tour guides, you can really learn something. I thought Ho Chi Minh was just the name of a capital. Had no idea the capital was named after a very important icon in Vietnam. Learn something new all the time.
Relevant . Relevant for its historical importance and for understanding Vietnamese history and Ho Chi Minh participation. Closed on Friday. ..

Interesting and impressive. We went here with our kids. The architecture is interesting. It gives a good feel of the "communist" era" with it's straight lines,"bombastic" style and grey colour. The whole set-up communicates "respect" and "solemnness".

Very good history about Uncle Ho and the city. The mausoleum was closed for restoration during my visit. But the complex gave ample information on the history of uncle Ho and the city. Definite-must for tourists!
A good place to visit. We spent our morning time with our guide in the morning there. It is good place with so many nice building were built b French.
memorable. maintain strict order to visit. but was worth it. Nicely built. LOts of honor guards to give right status and his body, just looks real.

Part of the trip. One of those thing that you have to do. Mausoleum is typical Russian Communist Architecture which is totally out of place and conflicts with Vietnamese culture, but I suppose they had to keep their ally happy. The area around the mausoleum is much more interesting. Make sure when you go it is not busy or you spend hours in queues for a four minute walk by, go early so that you keep the day free for other things. On my second visit I did not bother so my wife went in on her own (first visit) and agrees would not waste time again. Walking through the area around the mausoleum was interesting except for the propaganda. Wander off into the local shops and markets, every interesting and you see more of the true Vietnam.
You have to go. I thought the sky matched the atmosphere, it was very grey and a slight chill in the air. Important to go,

Must Visit. Even though there are many protocols in place to visit this place, it is worth it to just experience them. The walk past the body of HCM lasts seconds but there is so much more to see at this site which is quite vast.

Ho Chi Minh was traveling during our visit. Our tour group visited during December and unfortunately this was during the last two months of each year that the remains of Ho Chi Minh are sent to Russia for ‘upkeep’. We were able to spend some time walking the ‘boulevard’ and the grounds around the mausoleum. There were a lot of flags and propaganda slogans to the side of the mausoleum. There were also viewing stands in front of the attractions that were being taken down, so there must have been some sort of ceremony days before our visit. It was good to at the very least see the building even though we were not able to go inside. There are at least two guards on duty at the entrance to the mausoleum 24/7 protecting the remains and the door. Stay on the sidewalks and no running, otherwise, the personnel will make sure to stop you.

You just gotta do it. I was unsure about this attraction as mausoleums are not usually on my travel itinerary, but a friend advised me that "you just gotta do it," and he was absolutely right. It's a very unique experience, being escorted through two-by-two and seeing the embalmed Ho Chi Minh. My experience was definitely helped by a short line (it was a Tuesday morning). Also beware that they will make you check a backpack and don't exactly make it easy to get back there, so consider traveling light.
Was good but watch out for opening times. They seem to close this whenever it suits them...cerainly before the 11am they advertised. It was very interesting and informative..a well spaced out museum
Boring. OK, it's a piece of Vietnamese history but this typically monolithic communist structure doesn't do them any favours - no wonder Ho Chi Minh himself didn't want any part of it.
Long cue!. Line up for how long for just a few minutes to see him. No talking and hands on the side. But he looks great after all these years.

You MUST see Uncle Ho's Mausoleum. This is part of the required tour given by certified tour guides in Hanoi. Don't even think about taking photos inside. You will be detained by the police. This happened to someone in our group and the guide was reprimanded. This is very serious as the guide's family can be in trouble as well as the guide. We were able to go inside and view Uncle Ho's (that's what the guide called him) re-embalmed body. The tour is fast paced. No one can stop walking even for a moment. Steps are involved.

Important site to visit. Very formal visit with guards in full uniform directing tourists to Mausoleum. There is a great sense of State respect and formality. We felt that the opportunity to visit this place should not be missed. Dress code does not allow short skirts or sleeveless tops although did see men wearing below knee shorts. For women pedal pushers OK but not short shorts.

Quite a different experience. My trip here did not start off well, as you are required to walk around outside of the whole museum/mausoleum area on the outside before you can enter the grounds (if you walk from old town that is), but once you got inside walking to the different sites was very smooth despite the very large amount of people visiting. Guards make sure that the flow of people inside the mausoleum never stop moving so all you get is a quick glance of Ho Chi Minh, but I was amazed by the sight non the less. I never imagined a body could be that well preserved through the years. Quite a different experience, and well worth the visit. Entrance is free, but remember that they close the entrance around 10am.

Old school communism is not dead!. This is the place where you can pay a respectful visit to the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh (or uncle Ho, as the Vietnamese call him). And it's a very organized place. As a visitor you're being herded from the entrance into the mausoleum itself, depositing your bags and valuables along the way (you get them back at the end). The mausoleum itself is a huge concrete and granite monstrosity in old-Soviet style, with plenty of Vietnames an party flags in sight. There's wreaths with red ribbons, and lots of ceremonial soldiers in white uniforms, who make sure that everybody is behaving himself (no phones! No hats! Hands out of you pockets, and walk two by two!).All in all a very special experience. It's pretty genuine as well. 'Uncle Ho' is still immensely popular in Vietnam. We also saw lot's of school classes who were visiting the place on a field trip, it's definitely part of your education here.After the mausoleum itself you can go and visit the old presidential palace, Ho's old house, his old cars and some other interesting stuff. There's also a nice one-pillar-pagoda in there somewhere. Worth a visit (ony open in the mornings though, and lines can be long, especially in weekends, so plan ahead).

Interesting but not overwhelming. Long queues and all very sombre as if death occurred last month and not 25 years ago. The museum was of more interest and highlighted the very varied life of Ho Chi Minh. In the "what if" aspect of history, the failure of President Truman to reply to Ho Chi Minh's letters in 1946 eventually led to the deaths of 80,000 + US and allied soldiers and 5 million Vietnamese.

Good experience. I was torn whether or not I wanted to visit this, but after staying in Hanoi for a day and speaking with others who visited, we gave it a go. Overall I am glad we went, and I'd recommend it to others. After going through a little security and dropping your bags off, you're ushered through the streets in a line, and there's some walking/waiting/walking that happens for maybe 5-10minutes. Then you enter the mausoleum which is very somber, walk around the room where he lays, and then go back outside and exit the area. It's an experience worth doing because it means a lot to many Vietnamese people and so for that, I carry respect for this. While here I'd also check out his house, and walk down the road with all the embassy's as there's neat little cafe's and houses to check out!

unmissable. A must for anyone interested in History, or wanting to understand modern Vietnam. Seeing the great man lying in state is an extraordinary experience. A solemn moment, for me. Like Mao, Churchill or De Gaulle, Ho is one of the most important figures of the 20th century. His houses and other artefacts are equally interesting.

Great to see. We went to see the Ho Chi Mausoleum, but had no idea what a special occasion this is the Vietnamese people. Visitors are coralled into lines of two people, cameras taken away, as are large bags. You cannot stop inside the actual tomb, you must walk around Ho and keep going as there are hundreds of tourists following you in a very organised manner. The whole situation was rather surreal, very well protected but you can tell there is so much respect for this man and therefore you cannot help getting caught up in the excitement.

Remember to go there before 10am. So if you want t go inside to see the body of Ho Chi Minh then one has to go there early as they shut post 10am. Also they are closed on Mondays and Fridays. But one can see the building from outside which is quite impressive, and the change of guard is also fun to watch.
Highlight of the trip. This was an absolute highlight of a month of travelling in Vietnam. Moving experience that speaks volumes of the psyche of Hanoi. Not to be missed.
Beautiful architecture, but solemn.. Ho chin minh lay inside the mausoleum you make a round taking no photos and making no sounds, it's good to at least pay a visit.
A very unique experience. This was one of the most unique experiences I've had in all my travels. Everyone visiting Hanoi should go. Make sure to check the hours as they're a little limited.

Like the Pharaos and Lenin. All about body conservation in the modern times. Lenin in Moscow, the Pharaos in Egypt and Ho Chi Minh in Saigon,or better in Ho Chi Minh because this is the name of the city now. The mausoleum I'm impressive, the lines to visit it are organized by the white dressed guards and I like the visit it very much. It closes 3 months a year....guess.... Russia's come for maintenance. Come and see it yourself.

Educational. We went on a Monday - which is when they closed unfortunately. They open every day except Monday until 11am. However, we visited anyway, and it was inspiring to see and hear the whole history behind ''Uncle Ho'' as the locals call him!
Great place. Must visit to pay respect to the great leader. Fighter for freedom and independence. Well preserved body of the leader.

Ho chi Minh graceful!. You can feel the outmost respect given to this man. There was order on how far to walk in between the many guards surrounding the mausoleum and no one was talking just pointing to the direction you need to follow. A bit creapy to see when you have never seen one but you walk all around his body in a distance and walk out. You also follow a red carpet all the way out.
a must visit!!!. a must visit when in Hanoi, a bit enexpected but come and experience it yourself!!!!! When here walk around HCM's house and Presidential palace as well.
Closed. Oh, well. The Uncle Ho museum was good and nostalgic. No one knew what I meant by "creeping capitalism."

Stunning and solemn. queues to get into the actual mausoleum are long but move very quickly. As you would expect, a sombre place, but quite magnificent. Guarded on all sides by young soldiers dressed immaculately in white. Interesting to think it went against all Ho's wishes. A very memorable place

Want to be like hochimin. Great place to visit and to thing about our life, I thing this place is very special for meditation that will help us slow down things keep calm and gain better ideas for life.

Somewhat interesting. Getting to the mausoleum itself is a challenge and you're turned away at each imagined entrance to walk a further few hundred meters down the road.Queuing to get in is almost an exercise in military precision as you stand two by two, are not allowed to take photo's of the grounds and follow a specific route. Seeing Uncle Ho himself was a bit sombre, but gave an insight into the regard that the Vietnamese give him. We visited on a rather grey and damp day which may have ruined the visit somewhat.

Worth a visit, but not too exciting. Of course we did the obligatory visit to Uncle Ho. It’s amazing how much of a hero he is to the Vietnamese still today and their respect for him is inspiring. But the visit got very boring pretty quickly (maybe its not really my thing!)It’s still pretty freaky to see Ho Chi Minh lying there (he’s so tiny!)

Impressive building but too much bureaucracy. The building is indeed impressive but seeing Ho Chi Minh in this state is rather bizarre if not somewhat macabre - perhaps others would disagree. I'm, not sure why someone should be kept in this state. Also, the money would have been better spent on the people in need.The guards and bureaucracy that surrounds this whole area is over the top. Whilst visiting hours are on, you can only walk in designated areas and guards will force you to walk half a kilometre out of your way to get to your destination; however, out of visiting hours, you can walk pretty much anywhere. The security you have to go through is similar to a modern airport, again, over the top.
Must visit. We visited with our own guide who gave us a detailed account regarding Ho Chi Minh and his role in Vietnamese history. The site is well organised and was not crowded.
Interesting. We went to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum - it's very interesting, but a little bizarre. The grounds are very nice.

Only open in the morning. We got there a bit late (after 12 noon) and by then it was already closed. The outside looks impressive and do do the soldiers in their white uniforms. The surrounding gardens are picture perfect.
Impressive memorial. This mausoleum is impressive. You can't go inside, but it is worth looking at the structure and magnificence of it.

An honour to see President HCM. The security is quite strict.. Cant bring cameras inside as u need to leave it behind at the entrance and you will get it back at the exit.. Anyway it is kinda sad to see the body of President HCM as I have read the history before I came here.. You can take picture around the park just not inside the building..
Worth the time to visit.. Ho Chi Minh is the father of this country. The site gives you insight to why he is so important to the people.

you can go.... I don't know how does it looks as I couldn't enter the museum due to the weekend time but it was nice to move around the place & infrastructure. one of the remarkable infrastructure of Hanoi that you can visit if you have time & interest.
Beautiful building. Beautiful building, indoor activity helped on the wet day when we visited. Nice to see, but remember it is a mausoleum!

Lots of tourists but..... The gardens are absolutely lovely. There are always plenty of tourists at this attraction, but the grounds are so large that you really don't feel smothered. I enjoyed it very much

Get there early. Go first thing in the morning to avoid the crowds. We showed up around 8 AM and managed to walk in while the queue lines were still non existent. Takes about 20 minutes if you get there early from start to finish. Even with no crowds expect lots of walking through empty queue lines for a short glance at Uncle Ho.
Kind of Strange. Well kept up Mausoleum, but a bit creepy when you enter into it and see Ho's body there like the various Popes' in the Vatican. Worth going through to see the Vietnamese perspective.
Great for photo.. Didn't enter the mausoleum due to lack of time. Took some great photos of the exterior of the mausoleum though. Makes for an unforgettable trip to Hanoi.

Worth it...one of a kind experience.. One of a kind experience to see the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. Great place to observe the locals pay respects to him and see the love they have for him. This was one of my favorite and unique things to do in Hanoi.

A different kind of experience. My friends and I were able to visit the mausoleum on our day tour of Hanoi. As most have mentioned, make sure to get there early and make sure you're visiting when it's open to the public. When we went the queue was quite short. The amount of respect and care they take in maintaining the grounds and guarding Ho Chi Minh's body was evident during the visit, and you should make sure you do the same while visiting. The visit itself took us about 5 minutes since we went early. Not something to miss. They will take your cameras and bags for safekeeping and return them to you at the end of your visit. There was no admission to the mausoleum.

Difficult to Rate This. Get here early in the day and the lines are short, later you might have a very long wait. Inside you get to see the remains of Ho Chi Minh, but you aren't allowed to linger, they keep the line moving. No sunglasses or hats allowed out of respect. Ho Chi Minh is held in very high regard here, and everything about the site reflects that. I found this visit to be interesting, but I could see where others might not.

Respect. The keyword here is "respect", you are allowed to see the body of Ho Chi Minh, the "father" of Vietnam, no matter your opinion about the current regime and political state, you should go here and see how he's being honored by his country.

Best site to see. This was the coolest attraction I saw in Hanoi. You actually get to see Ho Chi Minh and all of the active guards around the grounds. You really get a feeling of the how people felt towards him. The grounds are kept almost perfectly and it is quiet and peaceful

Huge Mausoleum , long Q,. Go early in morning , otherwise a very long Q is expected, very strict robotic soldiers , no photograph, public money spend on huge mausoleum , big building, big lawns, good photo shot point ,but I don't know why Armed Soldiers stops you for pictures, when every where in city the picture cards are being sold. . Visit only if you have at least three hours.

we need to know. in my opinion, Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is one of the important place everyone should include in travel diary. The building is dedicated to house Ho Chi Minh’s preserved body and a place where visitors can express their admiration and gratitude towards the national hero while. Visiting the Mausoleum is free of charge but involves a set of strictly enforced regulations. No short skirts or tank tops are allowed and there is high level of security check upon arrival. Day packs can be put in a safe deposit before you enter but make sure you do not carry many valuable items with you. Taking photos, talking or finger-pointing are strictly prohibited inside the mausoleums.

Follow the crowd.... This is the national memorial to Ho Chi Minh, the founder of modern Vietnam. Coming from a country which doesn't have one particular historical leader/founder, it was interesting to see the respect being paid by the hundreds of visitors. The building itself is interesting, a heavy, serious piece of architecture well suited to a mausoleum. You queue for a while (just follow the crowd) and then eventually are allowed into the mausoleum itself, where you walk silently around the coffin. I found it interesting more from the point of view of seeing how another country respects its history, rather than from what there was actually to see.

Ho Chi Minh mausoleum Hanoi. This is a must for any traveller with an interest in how this lovely country survived the Vietnam War. A truly enormous edifice, built to hold the body of the country's wartime leader, the waiting and crowds can be off putting. But stay the course because it is worth it - a true piece of history and as important as the Lenin Mausoleum in Moscow. Surrounding the mausoleum are the grounds and house in which he lived even through the worst of the bombing campaign against Hanoi. Now a peaceful and languid park they are a stunning contrast to the glorification of Ho

A great place to visit. Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, which is one of three mausoleums in the world, is so amazing.When my family went there, we was impressed by special construction.The exterior is made of granite while the interior is gray, black and red polished stone. Especially, we could see distinct vietnamese architectural elements. So great !

Unique experience. First of all, there is no entrance fee.But what you experience in the mausoleum is really special. You have to show discipline and walk in lines, never leave the way you are supposed to walk in.Ho Chi Minh lies in the mausoleum like he is sleeping. You are supposed to walk in a steady pace and don't stop, talk, put hands in pockets - there are a lot of guards making sure you comply to all the rules.

Close Encounter with Uncle Ho. This review is quite late. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is not only one of the most visited tourists attractions in Hanoi; it is also the holiest of all places revered by the Vietnamese people. The mausoleum building is a splendid example of Soviet-style architecture. Located in Ba Dinh Square this huge block building is guarded 24/7 and visitors have to queue to get inside. There is no fee but discipline, silence and orderliness are strictly enforced here. As a sign of respect no word should be uttered while visiting the mausoleum. The embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is available for quick viewing and visitors are expected to move at a steady pace until they leave the building. I noticed some VIP visitors are coming in big groups with an official guide. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is closed during Mondays.

Wasn't exactly what I was expecting!. visited here back in 2008.He's lying there on his bed like he's asleep!Everyone files past all solem. The soldiers make sure you don't smile or put your hands in your pockets so respect is the order of the day. You have to wait for maybe 30 minutes before you get in and I don't remember it being too expensive.Wouldn't say it's unmissable but certainly a unique experience and makes a change from just looking round temples all day Cambodian style.

Yes well. I suppose you have to go. I'm anything but into mausoleums and graves, but if you go to Vietnam you have to go. Don't mess with guards, I inadvertently went along a walkway which had been closed (it was lunchtime and there were no signs, I was supposed to know) and I was jumped on really quickly and told in no uncertain terms that I wasn't going there, to which I agreed straight away. Perhaps I should have known when it was only the guard and me there.

Ho Chi Mihn' final resting place. Initially I intended just to go and view the buildings, the mausoleum and other historic relics of this proud nations struggle for autonomy, but once in the queue, it seemed that I was trapped on the surf as if riding a wave to the beach. I found myself entering the final resting place of this revolutionary leader and was rather awed by its spectacle. All around were guards immaculately dressed in white uniforms. We were ushered in and I maintained a dignified pace to ensure that the authorities were assured of my sincerity. It's like a smaller version of similar buildings holding the embalmed remains of Mao Tse Tung in Beijing and Lenin in Moscow. Admission is free but last entry is 11:30. I also liked the single leg pagoda, and the small market like street if shops selling "Good Morning Vietnam" T-Shirts and other miscellaneous goods. I'm glad that I got to see this display, but wouldn't recommend it as suitable for children.
You have to see this. Wow ... such a contrast to western culture. Its a people place and there's lots of things here. make sure that you observe the rules

Soviet style.. The soviet style Ba Dinh Square is where Ho Chi Minh read out the declaration of the nation's independence in 1945. The mausoleum is very similar to Lenin's mausoleum in Moscow and is 70 feet high and 135 feet wide.We visited in November when the body had been removed and sent to Russia for maintenance - but were able to photograph the building and watch the soldiers in bright white uniforms march around the outside.On the same site is the museum dedicated to Ho Chi Minh and his very modest house.Worthy of a visit - even when the mausoleum is closed.
a mgnificent place to watch the ceremonial changin of the guard/. It was impressive and the flower displays were beautiful. Plenty of Asian people wanting to take our photographs.

A very serious place!. This was a surprise visit for us. The security was tight. People were moved along quickly. Once inside they even didn't want you to hold your hands behind your back. There is certainly a right way and a wrong way. They will tell which is which. This is a national treasure for the Vietnamese and should be treated so.

Interesting Experience. I visited Mao in Beijing in similar circumstances in the late 1970's and that left a lasting impression as no doubt this will. The day I went the line moved quickly and in an orderly way. You are expected to be respectful - which is fair enough. If you can't be - don't go. This is definitely not for children. Apart from just curiosity this is an insight into a communist world that is an anachronism, but is also an insight into Vietnam and the genuine regard with which Ho Chi Minh is held (at least in the north)

its an experience. The queuing up was the most interesting part. Thinking about why HCM's body is on display, the security around it, the armed guards etc. It was all serious and we had to keep our arms by our sides the whole time. You dont have to put handbags and cameras into security, only larger bags and cameras you put round your neck. This was not clear and I certainly did not want to get caught doing something wrong!
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Mausoleum locates very close to Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace. Mausoleum is very similar to Moscow's one.

Worth a quick look - avoid the actual tomb. Its all a bit regimented. Queue up and be prepared to be marshalled very strictly through the mausoleum complex. The actual tomb room is strictly controlled any you ar expected to rigidly display your reverence to HCM. The museum complex was more interesting.

The parpernalia more interesting than the main attraction. Worth going for the experience more than just seeing a preserved body. Certainly an exercise in "control". Don't take a water bottle (you will have it confiscated), camera or anything really. The line is long but moves quickly.

One of the must see in Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is free for all to enter. First you have to pass a security screen, and leave any bags and cameras at desk, as not pictures are allowed( which you will get back exiting the mausoleum). Also don't both bring water in as it won't pass security and you will either have to drink it all or dump it. You have to walk single file with plenty of military guards onsite, and walking to the mausoleum feel surreal. There is an open parade ground next to the mausoleum making it look like a communist army is going to march through, saluting Ho Chi Minh. It's important that you keep quiet while entering and view Ho Chi Minh body as it is seen as disrespectful. After seeing his body, you go pass the presidential palace, and see the stilt house, similar to where Ho Chi Minh stayed before coming to power. Shorty after there is a pagoda which is still being built, overall worth a visit and your time.

viet nam Hero. we were visit here and saw him fews minute But nice poeple, after that we go to outside visit him Pont have so much fish and have so much poeple coming here meet he for perday.if you coming to here we are so sure you like this area. please dont forgot coming here if you visit vietnam
amazing. great location.motorbikes can be pain in the neck. be careful when on the streets. everything else is nice experience...

Enjoyed very much. The striking thing about the mausoleum is its simplicity, which it seems Ho Chi Minh would have approved of, after seeing his simple but elegant residence. Soldiers direct you in single file and there are no photos allowed inside. They move people through very efficiently. He does appear to be sleeping and it is a moving experience. Be aware that talking and laughing while inside would be very disrespectful. After this, you can proceed to the presidential palace, which Ho would not live in - his adjacent residence consists of three rooms and you can also see the One Pillar Pagoda nearby. Don't miss!
He looks like he's sleeping.... Ho Chi Minh is so revered that his mausoleum has lines of people walking thru just to get a glimpse of him lying in state. He does look lifelike...a little eery.

Do this in Hanoi if you do nothing else. Amazing experience and slightly wierd - soldiers will be all over you if you step out or inside the line as this is the man who saved Vietnam - people visibly moved shuffling past the tomb - apparently HCM goes off to Russia for a makeover every 3 months - does he go first class?
A moving experience. Very well presented; the wait and then the circuitous route to the Mausoleum prepare you for a sombre, but moving, experience.

Respect. This was an experience. Uncle Ho is revered and visiting his body in state is regarded as a serious event. You cannot photographs and all cameras need to be handed in to be collected later but everything is so well organised that you equipment is safe. Get there early and beware it closes at 11 am.

A very reflective experience. Just lining up to enter the Mausoleum enlightens you on how important and respected Ho Chi Minh is in north Vietnam. Suggest you check opening times and be prepared to wait in line. Absolute respect and silence is appreciated when you go through the mausoleum. Worth going. No photos allowed inside.

Wonderful experience!. Vietnamese people are respectful towards their Uncle Ho, that is clearly seen through the number of people visitting the place. The mausoleum is nothing special. What i love is uncle Ho's garden. It is so big, so simple yet luxurious and peaceful. He surely lived a life of simplicity and dedication!

Worth a visit . We were fortunate that we didn't have to wait very long before being able to enter. It was a unique experience. The security is intense! Make sure you leave enough time to go through security checks and to put your camera in storage.
A bit of walking involved. Time was spent on handling over cameras, cellphones, etc. for retrieval later. Security was very strict and silence is observed.

impressive communist style architecture. Situated on a massive Communist style parade ground. Opposite the government seat which is ugly Soviet style but interesting. The tomb was closed our visit day. The Mausoleum is stolid three tiered structure. The changing of the guard is interesting.

Interesting and a must see. We went to see this but it was closed on the first day so tip 1 is that you need to get there early as I believe it closes around 10:30 am.It was an interesting experience and well worth doing as it gives you an insight into the reverential esteem that Ho Chi Minh is held in to this day in Vietnam. The actual walk round was quite hurried as there were large numbers of tourists but well worth doing.When you leave you wander through the gardens and see the "House on Stilts" where he planned his campaigns, with "a room for working and a room for sleeping" with a boardroom area below.The Ho Chi Minh Museum is also well worth a look but is open for longer hours so go to the Mausoleum first

Surreal. This was an interesting stop. Single file, regimented, no photos very solemn experience.The Vietnamese revere this site, it is guarded and serious.we were even made to have hands at our sides and as foreigners we were directed to the outside of the line as we walked through but nationals could be closer.No photos in sensitive areas.Surprised to see the body still there encased in glass lying in state.It was a great experience.NOTE: apparently they shut it down for maintenance 3 months from Sept-December and send the body out. So do not try and visit at this time.

Revered.. The most famous place in Hanoi, this is where you can feel the respect of the Vietnamese people toward their respected leader. The building itself is also very impressive too, and there are strict moral codes for anyone who wants to pay a visit. Furthermore, you can understand more about Vietnamese history if you got a good guide showing around here.
Maudlin at the mausoleum. Free to visit.the mausoleum has restricted visiting and is often closed. No stopping is allowed when viewing Ho Chi Minh and respect must be shin at all times.

ABM-Another Bloody Mausoleum. Inside super controlled discipline, they have learned all the possible options to breaking the rules and have taken steps, would have been nice to be able to see more of the grounds. Best to come early before the crowds

Best spot in Hanoi. By visiting the mausoleum, we got a sense of the country and the man and the people, all in one place. Our line was short, and it took less than 1 hour to line up and go through. After that, the grounds are lovely, but the museum is more worthy. At the moment there is an exhibit from the Russian archives that makes it a must-see.

Interesting. I think any one that travels to Vietnam needs to visit this place to understand the respect the people have for Ho Chi Minh. There are strict protocols to visit the Mausoleum and there is a reverence about the place.
nice. i knows more about Vietnam's history here. Was a good day here with my little girl guide who give me more information.
Part of the Paloma Scooter tour. We did not go in, the though sort of creeps me out but it will appeal to some travelers. It is part of their DNA so you have show respect for it.
Part of history. The crowds are long here and you have only a few moments inside, but seeing Ho Chi Minh's body is certainly an important part of the Vietnamese history.

Massive building!. the Mausoleum is really cool on the outside. The HCM Complex is this massive thing in the middle of Hanoi. It's just mind blowing how big of a mausoleum they build. Be prepared to go through many lines and security checks, with conflicting info. You can't bring water and you can only bring in small cameras, even though you are not allowed to take pictures inside the mausoleum. Once you get through the main entrance, they file you into a single column and you follow the crowd in the mausoleum, where you see Ho Chi Minh's body and then outside. The whole process was kind of fascinating. Once you are out of the mausoleum, you can pick up your camera if they asked you to leave it and you are free to roam through the rest of the complex and take as many pictures as you like. It was a cold day, so most people were well dressed, but there may be stricter dress rules during the summer. Bring stuff to cover and take off your hat and glasses.

Kind of creepy but a must see. Since we arrived everything was very odd, the security was highly enforced, all the guards were absolutely strict and tough, you cannot wear sunglasses, hats, cross your arms, speak loud, smile.... which is kind of understandable since you will visit the high national hero of this great country.Inside you will see a death body which is not an everyday experience so is creepy and interesting at same time and more when we are talking about someone who change the worlds history.
You gotta do this one. This is just one of those things in Hanoi you "have to see". It is interesting to see "uncle Ho" still lying in state 45 years after his death.

A must for a Hanoi visitor. I think a stop here is a must for any visitor to Hanoi. It is a bit bizarre, but shows just how much respect the Vietnamese have for Ho Chi Minh. No bare shoulders or knees allowed, hats and sunglasses off. You just file straight past - no lingering and no photos allowed. But I feel sorry for the guy - he wanted to be cremated and his ashes spread in north, central and south Vietnam. Instead he is embalmed and displayed here. They go to great lengths to try and maintain the condition of his body - giving a new dose of chemicals every day when the mausoleum is closed to viewing. Visited with our tour group, continued from here onto the Presidential palace and Ho Chi Minh's stilt house, which are adjacent to the mausoleum.

A must see for people interested in mummified comunist leaders!. Quite huge, a lot bigger than Lenin's mausoleum in Moscow. Be sure to get here early as they only let you line up to see Ho Chi Minh for like 4 hours a day and they close some days as well.

Cool but creepy. It is an odd place where you are shuffled around by guards, making sure that you are in a single file line. You walk quickly through the mausoleum and into a cold room, that houses the "body" of Uncle Ho. Interesting but creepy.

Important. The mausoleum occupies a large site which is carefully maintained and carefully controlled. The regimentation insisted upon by the authorities is unusual for contemporary western tastes but it illustrates the deep reverence held by the Vietnamese for Comrade Ho. It would be hard to imagine promoting such reverence and respect with tourists wandering all over the shop acting as if in the street. I didn't have a problem with it. There was no cost, as it should be. The walk through the chamber where Ho's body is held takes only seconds but the observer gets a clear idea. No talking, no camera etc and all under the careful scrutiny of white uniformed guards giving clear direction as to what is expected. For gardeners, the huge bonsai pots surrounding the mausoleum are a treat. It was great to see so many school groups in their white hats visiting. The mausoleum complex is open from 08.00-11.00 and 14.00-16.00 and is closed on Mondays and Friday afternoons. If you're of an age from the war, this is a must.

Become immersed in Vietnam's history. Ho Chi Minh body is there that will speak to you about Vietnam's thrive for freedom. I know that history is made by whoever is in power, but the fact is that is very solemn to be there. I like the solemnity that is required when one enters the mausoleum - to talking, not hands in your pocket, nothing disrespectful. maybe God's worshippers should take a lesson and know how to behave when they are in God's worshipping place.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. This site is very guarded. No cameras, no walking with your hands behind your back, just single file walk through, view Ho Chi Minh , and walk out. Time might be better spent elsewhere

so beyond cool. Its open only between like 9 and 11 am so plan this one well. the are very particular about staying on point and no cameras. But tis awesome. He's actually there in front of you. So cool

Interesting. If you are in Hanoi, I would go. We were very clueless, but were herded in the right direction. I enjoyed the logistics of how the place is run just as much as seeing Uncle Ho (whether it's really his is debatable). We never paid -- not sure if this was free?

Lying in state. Visited on a Sunday. Turns out this is a popular day for Vietnamese to visit the site, so long queues. Went through Security, then walked in 2 lines through the huge park, to then enter the mausoleum and view Ho Chi Minh's body. Not the most riveting experience, but the formality of the whole ceremony was fascinating.We then continued walking in the park to see the Presidential Palace and 2 very modest homes of the great man. Well worth doing, despite the long queue.
Bizarre. We wouldn't have missed the attraction but it was bizarre how regimented the whole visit was and how you had to follow a set path even if you didn't want to follow the crowd.
Ho preserved. Uncle Ho looks waxy. But the overall solemnity for the Viet people is real, they do seem to revere Ho and the pomp around his mausoleum is genuine.

square block and coffin. The mausoleum is a square block (bomb-proof) and inside you can see the body of Ho-Chi-Minh in a glass coffin - thats all you see. Later you walk along the houses, Ho-Chi-Minh has been living and working.

Strictly follow the rules. No pictures, no backpacks, no hats, no masks and have to queue in a line. Oh ya, and make no noise! But can tell that the people really respect Mr Ho Chi Minh very much and see themselves as his descendents

A must see. The queue seems long but it goes fast. No skirt or short above your knees, or naked shoulders. No liquids after the entrance, not even water. You enter the room walk quickly around the body and you're out. Still it's a good experience, and for sure, no cameras allowed and not even possible to take a spy picture, there are guards everywhere.
No pictures. Arrive early in the morning around 8.00am to avoid the massive queues that form later on. Remember to dress appropriately as they will not let you inside.

Mind the Rules. The experience was very restrictive upon entry. Patrons are requested to stay in two single file lines, no hands in your pockets, no sunglasses, etc. It was explained that the real body is only on display some months of the year, meaning most of the time the body seen is a wax figure. The remaining part of the tour, including his home and the one pillar pagoda was the most enjoyable part of the visit to this complex. And whatever you do, do not try to photograph the guards.
When is it open?!. We were too late when we decided after 11 am to visit. Then we discovered it would not even be open on Mondays or Fridays! very disappointed indeed.

Worth a visit to pay respects to a great leader. This is a well-executed operation. Do not be put off by the very long queues. You are moved along quickly and efficiently by the rather brusque guards (no hands in pockets or talking) and will be filing past Uncle Ho in next to no time. A man of great significance to Vietnam, the region and the world.

Go early and not on weekends/public holidays. Go early in the morning as stated by many reviewers to avoid the long queues (even though the queues move generally fast). This is an important site for the local people as many Vietnamese's' wish is to be able to see Uncle Ho at least once in their lifetime. You will be able to see many locals paying their respect to him and do accord Ho Chi Minh the same respect - do not wear sleeveless/shorts/skirts and no laughing/giggling. Cameras will also not be allowed into the mausoleum and there is tight security at this place. The mausoleum is closed for about two months every year as Ho Chi Minh goes to Russia for restoration. But even if you cannot see Ho Chi Minh, the structure of the mausoleum itself from the outside is quite magnificent and it is inspired from Lenin's Mausoleum in Moscow. Also, we managed to catch a short changing of the guards around 10am, Hanoi time. I think it is definitely worth a visit. Just make sure not to go on weekends/public holidays or be prepared to join the long queue of people. After visiting the Mausoleum, you can go on to visit Ho Chi Minh's stilt house.

Don't go on weekends or public holidays. Plenty to do in this large complex as it includes Ho chi min mausoleum , his palace, his simple home, his cars and also included by my guide the one pillar pagoda. Just be prepared to queue if you want to see his embalmed body. Security is tight here and today the queue wait was well over two hrs. (Saturday) The weekends brings all the Vietnamese from the countryside into the city to visit so huge queues. Their is a security search of your bag and you are not allowed carry large bags or cameras so expect to put these in lockers for storage or give to your guide if on a tour. Remember you are visiting a tomb so the security police will be on look out for any misbehaviour, disrespect or attempts to take photos. When you reach his tomb you just pass by . no stopping, no hands in pockets etc , dont draw attention to yourself they are very quick to reprimand you.unless you have a lot of patience , go early in the am and on weekdays to avoid long queues. The remainder of the complex is lovely to see, the palace from outside and views of the simple life Ho Chi Min chose to live in his simple home and his stilts house. All viewed from outside through glass but here it's allowed to take photographs. If you don't have long queue for mausoleum about one and half hrs will be sufficient here . If long queues add two more hrs. Pity they didn't respect his wishes on his death, i find it's a little macabre walking past his remains but the respect Vietnamese show to him is wonderful.

People Power. This is a sight where you can see the Vietnamese people pay respect to Ho Chi Minh in an authentic way. Beautiful and tasteful surroundings full of history of the recent past for Vietnam.

Want to see a dead man?. I gave this 4 stars only because of the interest factor otherwise I wouldn't be bothered with the huge queue to see some stiff as you walk by his glass showcase (you can't stop to look).

Interesting but grim. I was definitely not expecting to walk into the mausoleum and actually see Ho Chi Minh embalmed there, sleeping. It was surreal and a bit sad to be seeing someone embalmed. Personally, I cannot imagine being dead and having tourists walk around my body watching me every day.

Historic. A massive complex and very much a tourist pulling sight going by the rows of people trying to get in, the big downside to this sight is that they are only open for a short time in the morning and Ho Chi Minh is not for viewing in December as he is supposedly sent to the Soviet Union for maintenance but the museum is a small consolation and should be considered worth visiting as well.

interesting to visit. Good museum interesting to learn about the history of Vietnam. The mausoleum itself was closed to visitors which was disappointing as we went in the one month of the year when the preserved body is "touched up"

Important part of the history of Vietnam. It reminded me a lot of the Mausoleum in Moscow, for obvious reasons. It was amazing how the guards took on their duty with such seriousness and fervour.If you take a camera or iPad they will not let you in with them. They are well organised and you hand it in at the entrance and then get it back at the end of the visit. The items are put into a bag and carried across the site by one of the staff so that it is ready for you at the end.

Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. This is closed on Monday,,other days open from 8 am to 11 am only. We went by taxi and were dropped at the front, but, we had to walk around the building, maybe one km, to the rear to gain entry. There is a security check and cameras are not permitted. They are taken and returned after you have been into the Mausoleum . The building is no wheelchair friendlyIt is very crowded but well organised and the queue is fast moving. There are some interesting gardens and you can see where Ho Chi Minh lived, there is a fee to visit this part.

Very interesting and impressive site. The queue was long when we visited but it went rather smoothly. Go as early as possible to prevent waiting to long. There were mainly Vietnamese people in line from all over the country.

Impressive view of a 45 year dead body.... Took a while to find the entrance to this place, and a couple of locals helped out. You have to leave bags at the gate, so consider this as you plan the trip. We were queuing for an hour and despite the look of the length, the queue moves fast. Some of the wait is covered to protect from the sun, but some isn't, so be prepared to cover up during your wait. Once entering the actual building, you get moved along by the guards. No one is allowed to stop, or talk. It's all explained on signs as you enter the building. You shuffle past the body - just looks like he's asleep and looks VERY good for the years since his passing.I found getting out of the grounds and back to my bag a bit confusing. You can't go back the way you came, so you have to go through the grounds to get back to the place you handed your bag in. I didn't want to see the grounds, but as a foreigner, was being asked to pay to see them. I just wanted my bag! So I snuck through the Vietnamese free gate in order to get back to the start. The grounds were pretty, and you could easily spend a couple of hours in there. Worth a visit if in Hanoi - such respect shown for the man.

Go early in the day, to avoid the queues and the sun. HCM didn't want to be immortalized like this. He wanted his ashes to be scattered across Vietnam.But when it was decided to create a Mausoleum for him, they certainly did it in style! As long as you get there early enough, so you don't have to queue too long, it shouldn't take more than 30 mins to file up into the building, past the numerous white uniformed sentries, up to the glass covered body of Ho. He looks like he's just fallen asleep, and you get a few seconds to view him before you are ushered along to exit the interior.Then you can see his office and living quarters and also the humble stilt house he had built for himself later, with the openair office underneath.An appropriately sedate monument to one of Vietnam's heroes, and the founder of the modern State, but I couldn't help wondering what he would make of the current state of Vietnam, which to all intents and purposes is now a (successful) single party capitalist State.

worth a visit out of curiosity. The Mausoleum is only open in the morning untl 11 a.m. If you arrive early you have to walk to the rear of the complex where you will join a queue of thousands bussed in every day to see their cherished leader. The queues are very long, but in fact move very quickly. I thought I would be there for hours, but was inside in about half an hour. It is free. Once through the airport style security, your camera will have to be dropped off at a left luggage along with any food etc. Water is not permitted and will be thrown away. Once though security, you snake through the Ho Chi Minh museum - where you mix with all the other tourists there, so much for security. You snake round to the front of the Mausoluem, where you enter at ground level in the center amongst much csremony from the guards dressed in white. They take this very seriously and there will be no infraction of the rules and serious demeanour. You go inside, up several staircases -there is a lift for the disabled -and are ushered into the small central vault where he lis, lit very dimly with yellow lights on his face and hands. You walk around the guarded sarcophagos and leave - 2 minutes at most.

Looks good for 2014. Despite being dead since 1969 Ho Chi Minh looks great. The mausoleum is an elegant building with a very respectful display of the great leader. There are many rules of order but you will be walked through the details of what to do and what not to do.

See earlier comments about Presidential Palace. Uncle Ho apparently had returned from Russia for repairs at the time; but, the building was not ready for visitors. The "changing of the guard" was similar to the US Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.
Check opening days. The Mausoleum is only open on certain days, and when it is you should arrive early to try and avoid a long line. If closed you can visit Ho Chi Minh's house next door.

Very reverent presentation to honor Uncle Ho. Our tour group was lucky enough to have arranged a wreath laying at the mausoleum, so we got to go straight in, two by two, at our appointed time. Although uncle Ho had left notice that he wished to be cream aged, this is a beautiful fitting tribute to a man revered by his people. Subdued lighting, intricately carved wood around his resting bed, very intelligent design to get people in, around, and out , and solemnly guarded by several young men.Remember that knees and shoulders must be covered, and no photography and no bags or backpacks are allowed.

Not much to see.. It is touted as a must see in Hanoi, but unless you are particularly interested in Ho Chi Minh, then there really isn't much to see. You can get any where near it as their are guards who whistle at tourists who cross the yellow 'do not pass' line.

Unique. It is quite interesting to see the love that Viet people of all generations show their "uncle Ho" who is kept in near mint condition in a cold chamber. As there are not that many people in the world being preserved like this, I do recommend the visit. Not sure however that uncle Ho wanted to be showcased like this...
Must See. We couldn't go in because of the time of the year, when they close. But even so, it is important to see from the outside a part of Vietnam's history.

Interersting. Worth a visit but please remember to show due respect and reverence for their former head of state and a national hero. To fail to do so is frowned up and possibly more. Coming from a country that has great monuments to former leaders and soldiers that have become controversial with historical perspective in a modern age but never the less interesting.

Beautiful at night. At night the mausoleum is beautiful, the lighting is great and there is not too many tourists around. It's great to have a tour guide to explain the history and significance of the area. We also went during the day, but due to it being a Friday we couldn't go inside. Very well maintained mausoleum.
Historical -must see. Its a marble edifice wherein deep inside the vistage of HCM is kept . Shows respect for the man honored to liberate the people from colonialism .

Not so Macabre. I was nervous about meeting Ho Chi Minh. But it was a very peaceful and respectful visit to a different man that I had learned about at school. We were lucky to visit the Mausoleum a day after it had been closed for 3 months. Entry is through a security system similar to the airport. No cameras and water/liquids are allowed on the premises. The queues are long, but fast moving. The movement through the compound is monitored by security and you enter the Mausoleum in small groups of ten. You must keep your hands out of your pockets. Afterwards, we had a guide explain the life of Uncle Ho and there was an opportunity for us to see the flag raising at 6.30 am the next day. I found it an interesting way to honor the dead.

Worth the queues. The queue moves quickly and you can't take your camera in but this is fascinating and worth the trip. We were running too late to go to the museum beside this, but found it interesting to see the guards, building, and of course Ho Chi Minh. Not eery at all. And once you're in, it's quite quick and so well run that your camera and any other checked in goods are promptly available.Remember not to take in a full water bottle - so give to your children if they are waiting for you in the cafe like we did.
Interesting. We were outside and heard about then history of Ho Chi Minh but were disappointed as we were unable to go in. When we were there he was being "touched up".
A bit of Uncle Ho. Small, but ok Ho Chi Minh Museum. Interesting photos and you get a pretty good impression of the President's life.

Wife thought creepy i thought amazing. . Large crowds but moved quickly. I found the army shoving people and making sure folks were respectful - hats off, hands out of pockets and my 15 year old daughter made to walk behind me interesting. Such respect for a founding Father. My wife and daughter on the other hand found it just creepy looking at a shell of a body surrounded by military.

Everybody loves this... Well, it seems like eall tourist in Hanoi just go here as they thought this is the only tourist attraction! It's really cool place and maybe we're not very much into museums or mausoleum!

Creepy experience. I get that the Vietnamese people revere Ho Chi Mihn but seeing his preserved body was just creepy. There are guards everywhere that make sure you are walking properly and don't talk. No talking is allowed inside and it's a little scary being hushed in Vietnamese by someone in uniform. I am all for being respectful but I couldn't wait to get out of there.

No queuing to see Uncle Ho!. Having expected long queues we pretty much just walked in and joined a line of about fifteen people. Seeing an embalmed body is a little strange but he is still revered by the Vietnamese so thought we should go. Wear respectful clothes, no sunglasses, hats and no talking inside the mausoleum.

Surreal experience visiting the mummified body of Ho Chi Minh. It's necessary to wear respectful clothing and entrance is free. We picked up an unofficial guide who fast tracked us past the hoardes of schoolchildren on school trips from "the countryside" for $10. He also took us on a side walking tour of the adjacent area and we saw the remains of the B52 bomber partially submerged in a small square lake.

Our guide told us something fascinating if it's true.. The mausoleum itself was closed which may have been a blessing as our guide told us that you can wait in line up to 90 minutes to get inside. Our guide also suggested that in fact it could be a wax effigy and not the real body of Ho Chi Minh. He told us that Ho Chi Minh left instructions that his body was to be cremated and scattered in three different parts of Vietnam (north , south and central) as a way of uniting the country.A visit to the gardens and the surrounding parklands was interesting so perhaps we were lucky on the day we visited.

Short and sweet. After walking around an entire block , we finally got to the entrance of the Mausoleum . It had been a crazy hot morning after walking in two straight lines and being quiet , we finally got in . The room was ice cold (which we definitely appreciated) and we basically got paraded past HCM and then walked out . It was pretty intense as we were watched seriously the entire time and there was a multitude of guards with harpoon guns . We got in before 8am when the gates were supposed to open but went in straight away . Definitely get there early as when we walked past later on there was a line around the block !

Ok if Embalmed Communist Leaders are Your Thing!. Not wishing to be unduly disrespectful, but I do wonder why communist leaders (Lenin, Mao, Ho Chi Minh) have to be embalmed and exhibited in vast mausoleums. When we were there, the mausoleum was in the middle of its annual two month holiday. Someone explained to us that Ho Chi Minh goes on an annual 'holiday' to Moscow to be 'renovated.'The mausoleum itself is huge, set in a truly vast open space. There are also some impressive gardens and a lake, and the stilt house that Ho Chi Minh lived in.This is obviously a place of massive importance to the Vietnamese people who still revere Ho Chi Minh, and more importantly, to the Vietnamese Communist Party.

Insight into the Vietnamese psyche. The queue is long but it is very well organised, so you get in quite quickly. The guards are very strict in ensuring everyone is quiet orderly and respectful, which comes as a bit of a shock to a westerner. Looking at Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body is quite freaky, but this is obviously deeply meaningful for the Vietnamese. Even the architecture of the building has significance for the Vietnamese, although it looks like a concrete bunker to western eyes

Rush job.. Was one of the must-see places on my Hanoi list. Woke up really early to reach this place by 8.30 am. Read in the other reviews of the strict regulations so I kept a passive, thoughtful face throughout. We were pretty much ushered along at a quick pace and this limited our viewing to 3 minutes at most. Not really worth the hassle

A long wait. We queued for about three hours to get it. I had been previously on a tour and walked straight it, if I ever went again I would book a tour, much quicker. Be careful not to take to much with you, any bags need to be checked in and collected on your way out. Despite the long time waiting we were glad we went.
Ummmmm. I found seeing a dead body a bit creepy. Very regimented, felt very intimidated by the guards. Glad I went but don't take kids!

Typical Communist Architecture. Didn't visit the inside. Just saw the outside. That was enough for us. It is rather a monstrosity of a structure, built to be huge and imposing but architecturally uninteresting. Most interesting part was the land in front of it that had been laid out to look like rice paddies.

You can feel the atmosphere here!. I found the experience of lining up & then parading past, what is literally a preserved dead body a little weird, but the atmosphere & the undeniable love from his people, who come here in their millions is an incredible thing to see.
A must see in this city. One of the few mausoleums in the world, this one is the only one I've seen so far but I went away very impressed. It's impressive inside and out.
Interesting Historical tour. Another interesting historical attraction that you must visit when in Hanoi. Beautiful old French building 👍
peaceful atmosphere. been there many times and each time i feel i am a new visitors, i suggest pay a visit at night around 8 p.m to see a marching in front of the mausoleum
Interesting place!. We enjoyed seeing the Mausoleum, though because it was December, Ho Chi Minh's body was not there. They send it to Russia each year to be "freshened".

Military parade courtyard. Impressive mordern square building but soulless and not particularly attractive.
The ride from the hotel to there was more enjoyable.

Solemn atmosphere. Security in the compound was exceedingly tight and we had to walk in a single file towards to mausoleum. I found that a bit odd but I suppose it is to ensure everything was done orderly. At the entrance we had to put our stuff through the scanner and I was made to deposit a jar of candy which I had brought along. However staff spoke extremely limited English. Fortunately a friend translated for me.The mausoleum itself was very quiet and sombre and reflects the deep sense of respect that Vietnamese have for Uncle Ho. We were not allowed to stop and view the body, and hence the whole viewing was over in about 2-3 minutes.I went quite early on a Wednesday morning (around 8:30am) and there wasn't a long queue.The entire compound was huge and several hours can be spent exploring the tranquil place.

Bac Ho. Those of us who appreciate Ho's dictum that nothing is more precious than independence and admire his time spent in Europe, China and Thailand and also those aspects of his life that Vietnamese history plays down must visit the Mausoleum: not least also because Ho specifically said he did not wish such an edifice be erected to his memory

The father of modern Vietnam. Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum is impressive. The setting is beautiful, with well maintained grounds, and the building itself is a fitting tribute to a great leader and contrasts well to the simple home he occupied in the grounds next door.There is no entrance fee to the shrine. There was a long line of visitors, who are all ushered with respect through the grounds. Do wear clothes your granny would be happy to meet you in for Sunday lunch, ie no shorts, or else you won't be allowed in. You also have to leave large bags and telephones, etc. I was impressed by the efficiency of the organisation: a covered walk way to protect you from the sun, lots of loos, guards keeping the lines moving and respectfully reminding people to take off sun glasses or stop talking.Outside, there are various places to buy gifts or purchase refreshments.For those with mobility problems, there are quite a few stairs to negotiate.When you have finished visiting the mausoleum, there is the accommodation The President lived in next door, for which there is a modest entrance fee of less than £1.

Cozy and solemn place. Its a nice day when we came here after finishing business trip, introducing by local people. I found very interesting when coming inside. The astmosphere is so solemn, people sitting in line for waiting to see Uncle Ho, just in silence. Then I came to his house (maybe just a sample for people to know), which very simple and friendly. Its a awesome experience in here
extravagant. at the corner of the mausoleum you can see the humble residence of HO CHI MINHthis contrast is disturbing. there are many beautiful old trees around.

We were given dignitary preferential treatment. It was a Sunday with very long line ups. However our group was given an honour guard treatment. Be prepared to be treated like you were in boot camp. Straight lines, no photos, cameras put away and out of sight, no sun glasses, hats, etc. The sight is impressive and was recently renovated. The entry fee also includes other parts of Ho Chi Minh's life, house, etc. Well worth seeing and cameras can be used after you have seen his body lying in state.
Worth a Look. A large impressive structure. The changing of the guard takes place regularly. You can take pictures but don't cross the yellow line.

No smiling and check opening hours. No smiling and check opening hours as there are many rules etc.You have to leave you personal stuff in an open locker area, so don't take much stuff with you.You have to dress politely and act seriously.Also, Uncle Ho gets re-pickled for 2 months each year. So check to see if they are displaying his body before you go.It's interesting to note that he wanted a simple funeral after his death and didn't want any fuss.

Reverence for "Uncle". Clearly Ho Chi Minh is revered by the North Vietnamese people with long lines leading to his body on display in the mausoleum. There are military personnel everywhere in the complex. No hats and proper attire are required.
Worth a visit. This mausoleum is one of the few mausoleums one can find in the world. Seeing the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is quite an experience in itself. Definitely worth a visit.

History. The place is big and involved a bit of walking. One may feel unwelcome because of the strict rules. You walk in line two by two and enter to see the well preserved body of the great leader. Unless you are well versed in the history of Viet Nam, you may wonder what's the big deal. I would rather prefer some display and explanation of his great work before enter to view the body. Still recommend to visit.

Should see it!. Went without really knowing what to expect. When going in you have to line up quite far away from the actual mausoleum, you get directed through this random pathway I guess. The actual mausoleum is quite cold inside (for obvious reasons). It was interesting though, some locals were quite emotional

Uncle Ho was on vacation. Mausoleum was closed when we visited, as Ho Chi Minh remains were taken to Russia for restoration. However we had a glimpse of mausoleum from outside. It is worth visiting the place.
Pay a respect to the hero of vietnam. A place to be put into priority in the morning itinerary as the opening time is really short. 8:30am to 11:30am.

A must watch in Hanoi. It divided into few parts . The most attractive part was to witness the body of Ho Chi Minh. He passed away on 2nd Sept 1969, same day as the independent day of Vietnam. His body was preserved well and until now is for people to visit and pay the last respect to the father of Vietnam. Of course to enter there , despite ticket price, there were lots of rules and regulations to follow, such as cannot wear short, cannot take photo, cannot wear sunglasses.. The tour guide will tell u all of these.The next is to visit his cars. The president car, which is a bullet proof one, was given by Soviet Union. Then he had another 2 cars, one of them was given by the people of Vietnam, it was a Peugeot. Lastly we visited the uncle Ho's previous home. The stayed in 2 different houses which were not far apart. The visitors were not allow to enter the house, everything was preserved as what they been. We only can peep from the window, it was rather simple and never a palace looking. We get a long story about him, and all the sacrifices being done to bring the country along the journey of independent. It is a place that worth visiting, that's why 5 stars be awarded.

Couldn't Get In. While I was there the mausoleum was not open because the body was in Russia, being 'restored.' However, I wasn't much interesting in viewing the body and the park-like site was beautiful. Because we stayed in the Old Quarter I had the feeling that the whole city was crowded. However, in the French Quarter (the location of the mausoleum) the homes, their grounds and the site of the mausoleum were vast and beautifully landscaped.

History lesson. When travelling to new countries it is always interesting and important to learn the local history. Hanoi with all it's museums and monuments gives the perfect opportunity to learn some Vietnamese history. The attractions are inexpensive and quite well maintained: great quality.After visiting the mausoleum you should definitely buy the ticket to the rest of the museum area. It is cheap and offers nice garden-like area to stroll around and visit the few points of interest inside. Arrive early because the mausoleum closes at 11 AM.Ho Chi Minh's body itself is better maintained than Mao's in Beijing. Overall, the room with the coffin is somewhat more beautiful and mysterious than Mao's own place. One should remain quiet and keep slowly walking through it.If you have a big camera you must leave it before entering the mausoleum. You will get it back right after exiting and it will be kept in secure place. They also confiscate your water bottles and them you will NOT get back. Makes good business for the drinks vendors there!
Very Inspiring. A staunch communist leader who is entrenched in the minds of all the Vietnamese. Very inspiring leader who is still respected by the common man.

Strange experience - but worthwhile. Strange experience - but worthwhile.No talking, ushered through in one line - no photos etcNot so sure if Uncle Ho is a replica or the real deal - but hes looking great either way!

Know the history behind simple building. The mausoleum was closed and we could not go in... Just walked around to admire the simple structure and view the changing of guards.But visits to HCM's working and living quarters, as well as the museum nearby helped us get to know why the Vietnamese revered this man. A must do when in Hanoi.

Must go in Hanoi.... Great place to visit if you are in Hanoi...dont miss it out if you are a communist freak...If you have the dram of visiting all the mausoleum's of the communist leaders, this is the right place...enjoy

Part of an organised rour. This was closed when we visited but it is just one building among so many others.....we spent a good few hours looking at everything else and loved it all due to our guide being a mine of information. Vietnam is full of history and sights!

Mr Ho Chi Minh work and living quarter. I was told that this site is the original Mr Ho Chi Minh's working and living quarter in Hanoi, as compared to replicates in HCM? Anyway, it is not far from the city and you may need to spend at least 1.5hours to have a good look around the premise.As I occassionally go to Vietnam for business trip, this place allow me to understand Vietnamese's love and respect towards Mr HCM better. Correct me if I am wrong.....Go and have a look.

The grounds, Ho Chi Minh's accommodations and the structures, worth a visit. Leaders like HCM leave a legacy that are worth studying. With a brutal enemy to contest, with crude weaponry, the will and steeled determination led the people through thick & thin to liberty, dignity and amazing love for humanity.The above may sound to be brainwashed propaganda of the Vietnamese Government, that I do not subscribe to. Buddha's wisdom combined with human resolve has helped the people to forgive and move on. The current system is not an ideal one, but where on earth is an ideal system in practice?

Guide is helpful. We were unable to visit the mausoleum - had to view it from a block away. Our tour guide gave us valuable information as to the significance of the architecture which was good to know.

Massive area. The Mausoleum, houses and grounds occupy a large area in central Hanoi.The whole area is very well maintained and the grounds house some interesting shrubs and trees. We watched the formal changing of the guard but could not enter the mausoleum this time as it was closed.( I have been inside before and was disappointed not to do this again. I remember 8 years ago security was very tight considering he is dead) we were not allowed to take any bags, cameras into where he lay in state and were also frisked before entry. No one was allowed to speak while slowly moving around the coffin(entombed in glass). He was perfecly preserved and it was a moving experience.) I think he was away to Russia getting re- embalmed at the time we were there.The house on stilts shows what a simple living he preferred.A must do on a visit to Hanoi

Wow, like Buckingham Palace. It's a long wait, and you a in a file, kept in order, hands out of pockets, hat off.... All you get is a few minutes to view the amazingly presented body, after a major organisation and herding process prior to entry, but it's enough.There are guards everywhere, hundreds of men to add to the pomp, and the sense of reverence. And importance.Every country needs at least one here, I guess HCM is vietnams King

Ho Chi Minh's house. We did not get into the mausoleum because it was closed. However the grounds were nice. For me, Ho Chi Minh's house on stilts was the highlight. Such an elegant construction! A lovely conference table on the ground floor, a modest bedroom, and a perfect piece of architecture. I hope he had at least a few nights of comfort here

Ho Chi Minh away for restoration. I loved the information that was in the Museum but sadly we were unable to view Ho Chi Minh as his remains were being restored. If that is the case when you visit Hanoi, go anyway, as it is interesting.

Large and impressive but not open at the time. Not sure if Uncle Ho was back in Russia He is supposed to go back there for 2 months every year to be attended to. The Mausoleum was closed when we were there.

Full Day tour to Hanoi, including Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. While on a 18 day tour from Hong Kong to Singapore, our choide gor yhe day stay in Halong Bay was just one : visit Hanoi,! The full day tour offered by Holland America Line was perfect and gave not only the great opportunity to enjoy this city with shadows from the past but also get to know the countryside on the drive to and from Hanoi.One of the pkl]places to be visited is the park where Ho Chi Minh lived and close by, the famous Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, which we enjoyed from the outside.

impressive. Very impressive structure Chance to visit Hochiminh's house on stilts and gardens with lake We saw young soldiers being put through their paces and rows of papaya fruit trees Well worth a visit

Take a guided tour that incorporates this attraction. Sorry don't mean to be disrespectful, but this Mausoleom seems to have been transported straight from Moscow. However if you get a guided tour, you do get a history lesson, and if this is to be believed!! then Ho Chi Minh was a great man whom has transformed this country and thus making Vietnam a power player in Indo ChinaThis made the visit worthwhile
major attraction. This is one of the major attraction in city tour. You may include in half day city tour. You will have to follow the history guide explains. Good for photo stop as well

An impressive plaza, but the mausoleum was closed. If you happen to wander by it is worthwhile having a look, but only en route to somewhere else really. The outside of the tomb is quite impressive but it was closed when we were there.

Impressive building - not open :(. The Mausoleum sits in Ba Dinh Square, where Ho Chi Minh first declared independence from the French rule in 1945. Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum is closed for entry every Monday and also from September to December each year. No entry to the Mausoleum, but you can view it from the exterior. Not overly impressed with the grandeur of a tomb, when so many in the country are so impoverished.

If you're a Vet probably a must see. I'm not going to go in to the politics of my visit but suffice to say as a veteran of the war and considering this man represented my enemy......this visit was cathartic and I suggest you do it if your situation was the same as mine. Per all of the wonderful people we met in Viet Nam, everyone here was quite pleasant and very respectful. Watching the changing of the guard was truly interesting and I'm glad I saw it.
Interesting. We arrived early in the morning, and the line moved rapidly, efficient situation. Very strange exhibition...

Wait until December 2014.
