We went to HCM Mausoleum and Museum in Nov 2014 and asked if the ticket price included entry into the Mausoleum and was told yes but when we exited the Museum we were told the Mausoleum was closed for renovations until December. Ummm.... total waste of money as we were not interested in the museum and walked straight through!

A strange mish mash. I think the locals have to recommend this BUT we were totally baffled by the experience! The exhibition about Ho and the Russians was pure propaganda and with very little information. I am still no wiser about the man, his life, politics and regard at home and abroad. The mausoleum was closed, the stilt house not accessible and much of the complex was overgrown rubble. We tried to make sense of it but then walked to the Women's Museum where at least the exhibition was informative and interesting and gave a far deeper insight into Vietnam than the Ho Chi Minh complex did.

Life and Rest of Uncle Ho Chi Minh. Quiet placeThe mausoleum is a master cube surrounded by nice Ho Chi Minh park and former Ho Chi Minh remainings... And Hanoi history with One pilar Pagoda and French Quarter

In line for 30 mins for a 30 second viewing. Not really sure why we did this except that our local VN friends were keen. I would say take a pass unless you were really really interested in a quick glimpse of a formaldehyde Uncle Ho. More interesting was the HCM residence nearby, and the museum.

Interesting you could say. Went without really knowing what to expect. When going in you have to line up quite far away from the actual mausoleum, you get directed through this random pathway I guess. The actual mausoleum is quite cold inside (for obvious reasons). It was interesting though, some locals were quite emotional

Weird situation. It seems that one isn't supposed to stay there too long!The military guards keep on rushing visitors through, maybe in fear that something "unexpected" is detected...No cameras and no cellular phones allowed...
Like Kremlin. You will stay in a long line to see a mummy for 2 seconds. Not worthed at all. Instead go to see the house he lived and worked! Take pictures of the Mausoleum and be happy!

Not much to see. The only reason to go here in the 2 months that it is closed is to say that you've been there. You can't get close to the building itself and from a distance it's just a concrete building.
Stop by on your way through Hanoi. The soldiers doing the march outside are quite entertaining to watch. Brush up on your history before you come visit here.

bizarre. Bizarre to walk into a room and see such a well preserved human body. I was in a bit of awe when entering the room! I felt for ho chi Minh though as he stood for human rights and equality and never wanted to be seen as anybody different to you and I. He refused to live in the mansion built for him and wanted a standardised funeral and yet they have built a huge memorial building in his name and a shrine to him. He also asked to be cremated so in some respects I find it sad his wishes were not met. The rest of the museum was very interesting and exciting to look around.Packed with tourists, long ques and ushered around quickly in parts.

Historical anomaly. So first you buy the tickets, then you join the queue, the queue snakes its way for a long distance, outside with some shelter from the sun but little from the rain or cold!. The queue moves at a slow pace, but eventually you get to the Mausoleum, and once inside, its up the stairs and then finally into the "chamber" where the rule is keep moving. So allow some considerable time for the queue, but remember you get barely 5 minutes when you can see the body.The experience is special however and it is interesting to watch the reaction of the Vietnamese people for whom a visit to the Mausoleum is clearly still a very special occasion.Must be done, interesting in a cultural way but probably not for small children!!!

A must see, but only once!. Amazing organisation too. Nice walk there from our hotel in old quarter. Didn't do the next bit... We had a few weeks in Vietnam and felt no need to see any more temples, or crowds!

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum - arrive early!. I was fortunate to be in Hanoi when the body of Ho Chi Minh was in the Mausoleum. Apparently, the body is taken back to Russia for three months of the year, to be re-embalmed in preparation for the following nine months in Hanoi. Tickets are only available in the morning until about 9 or 9.30am. To avoid disappointment it's best to check online to see if the Mausoleum is open, and the cut-off time for tickets. Once you have your ticket, you join the long line/queue to make your way into the building. Bags, backpacks, purses, cameras are not allowed in the Mausoleum, and you have to check them in with security. I was fortunate to join up with a friendly tour group, so I left my bag etc. with their belongings which worked out well. As we got closer to the entrance, there was an increasing sense of reverence and importance. The interior of this enormous building was very cool, with an eerie silence. Uniformed guards stood at every corner and quietly directed visitors to the auditorium where 'Uncle Ho', as his followers liked to call him, lay resting under a glass dome. It was quite incredible to actually see this iconic figure who passed away 48 years ago! On exiting the Mausoleum, the tour guide fielded our many questions about the history of Vietnam. The combination of viewing Ho Chi Minh and having a very knowledgable guide, make this a really memorable experience for me.
Interesting look at history. Interesting place, only open short hours and certain months so definitely one you need to plan for. Super cool and different though.

Uncle Ho is in hibernation. Don't bother going there for the next three months as Ho Chi Mihn is out for a touch up. So if your are going wanting to see him , you will be sadly disappointed . Apart from that there is some interesting things there but if like me you're wanting to see Uncle Ho wait for 3 months.

A big land mark. The uncle Ho's mausoleum is a very large building. We had no access to it the day we visited but could admire it from outside!Ho Chi Minh was so venerated by the people of Vietnam that this building was built so people could continue to pay their respects to him.It us not a particularly beautiful building and was voted in the top 10 most ugly by a CNN poll. However it is rather imposing and set in some lovely surroundings.

Massive structure. Visited the mausoleum but it was closed as Ho Chi Minh's body has been removed. Wished I'd checked on here first. The guards didn't allow us to the front of the building for photos so in a way wasted our time. Shame really, but is due to open again 5/12

Did not get to see Uncle Ho. Unfortunately we did not get to see Uncle Ho, who was in Russia for annual restoration. Our guide was disappointed that we could not get to see him-- truthfully I was ok with just taking photos of the building from the outside. But the complex is quite large and we did see his house, which had many of his personal items on display. He lived in a wooden house in the style of the countryside, not the large presidential palace built by the French. The One Pillar pagoda wad also under restoration, but you could walk up and take a photo. The day we went there, hundreds of school children in their blue and white uniforms were there to sightsee.

Place of rest of a great man. The time I visited the place, Ho Chi Minh's body was not there. It was that time of the year when they send it abroad for maintenance. But I saw the Palace area which is a beautiful sight.

A monstrous show piece. Perhaps I am being harsh. I was rushed through place by an attendant as it was closing time. I couldn't appreciate how this portrayed a great man, full of modern gimmicks. Perhaps Vietnamese may appreciate this.

Moving and emotional experience. If you only go to one attraction in Vietnam, then make it this one. Ho Chi's body leaves once a year for 2 months to Russia for re embalming, so try to go see him when he is there. The whole complex is fantastic, the museum there is great, an emotional and moving experience. Take at least half a day to see it all, the queue that you have to walk in to get into the mausoleum is very long, but moves quickly, and as it is not just for tourists this place but locals,and many Vietnamese that have travelled all over the country to see it, you can interact a bit with them as you wait. I wouldn't say this is a 'tourist' attraction as such, as it is not for tourists specifically. A great visit, if you have time for only one attraction in Ha Noi, even all of Vietnam, then make it this one. Don't miss it whatever you do, even just see Ho Chi if you are time poor. Fantastic!!!

A Hanoi Must See. The mausoleum is full of artifacts from Ho Chi Minh. Everything from his sandals to his typewriter is on exhibit. We were at the mausoleum in late October and were informed that every October Ho's body is returned to Moscow for maintenance and cleaning. So if seeing his remains is a priority, you may want to check and see if he is on exhibit.Definitely worth the visit.

Worth it if you are interested in History. The mausoleum is a really great excursion to go on if you are interested in learning about Ho Chi Minh and are willing to wait in line. If you plan to go, you should be prepared for long queues in hot and humid weather. You are able to bring a camera, but you must leave your belongings at the entrance when going to the mausoleum. You also go through a scanner, so bring disposable water and money so that you can buy water on the other side. Due to the importance of Ho Chi Minh, the mausoleum is highly busy and is only open at certain hours, so research times to go and book ahead! I went in the morning and had to wait 3 hours in 34 degree heat. Thankfully, shade to stand under is provided but large bags and cameras are not allowed within the actual mausoleum. You only have a small amount of time to pay your respects, and are chaperoned around by guards, but once you have visited his mausoleum you have more freedom to visit the presidential palace, Ho Chi Minh's home and he museum dedicated to him.You can only see the palace from afar, but are able to get closer to his house. It was very crowded when I went, and the children who were there seemed to be thoroughly uninterested. The museum was also very crowded, but interesting to go round. It isn't very large, so only takes about 30 - 45 minutes to see. Overall, it was a highly interesting experience, but quite tiring from all the walking and heat. I wouldn't recommend it to those who aren't interested in the history of the country or those who have children. Otherwise, it is a unique - if not eerie - sight to see.

Must See. Visited the mausoleum on our recent visit to Vietnam. The mausoleum its self is impressive the body of "uncle ho2 is well lit and although there is no stopping you have plenty of time to view the body. The site contains a number of other buildings where Ho worked and lived surrounded by extensive grounds and with interesting artefacts relating to his life.The site is very popular and on the day we visited there were large numbers of Vietnamese there to pay their respects to the Great Leader
No Ho until 5th December. Worth a picture from the outside but unfortunately the mausoleum is closed until 5th December as HCM is in Russia being looked after by the same people who look after Lenin.

Uncle Ho was not receiving visitors this month!. History suggests that Ho Chi Minh requested a cremation but the public demand was such that the authorities chose to commemorate him in traditional Soviet style a la Lenin. As it turned out the mausoleum was undergoing it's annual shutdown for maintenance during our visit and so we were only able to view the main building from afar. The building itself appeared to be designed to make a statement of grandeur and to my western eyes appear to err on the brutalist style. Fortunately, in the company of our Buffalo guide, Springy, we were able to gather a detailed understanding of the affection still harboured for 'Uncle Ho' who apparently is still regarded as an extension of the family by many Vietnamese. He's certainly a character that I intend to investigate in more detail - by all accounts very well traveled and a deep thinker who looked to combine his travel experiences to create a way of life to which he adhered. Although the mausoleum was closed, the gardens and his former residences were all open for inspection. I was particularly impressed by how simple and humble these were for someone wielding such power - whilst the accommodation was very nice there was no overt ostentation as one might expect of such a prominent person. I particularly loved the polished hardwood residence situated next to the carp pond. I found myself thinking of him more in terms of Gandhi or Mandela - one of those rare people who preach reasonable things and actually practice what they preach.There were some well preserved state vehicles on hand to reflect the past - a Peugot from French colonial times and a fine pair of Russian models that I didn't recognise.Overall, well worth the visit.

HCM was not there.. The Mausoleum was closed no public access as Ho Chi Minh not there. Walked around the the grounds which doesn't take that long but nice to see what Ho Chi Minh lived etc. If you don't know the history then get yourself a tour guide. I did like his Stilt House

Meh.. Didn't find the HCM Mausoleum particularly stirring, even less so when you learn that Ho Chi Minh specifically requested NOT to be interred in state (ala Lenin), but it happened anyway. If one is interested in HCM, better off spending some time at the nearby HCM Museum, which had lots of interesting photos and displays.

Visiting the hearts of Vietnamese. Me and my boyfriend went to Hanoi in September 2014. We booked a tour to the Ho Chi Minh complex with a local student guide - an amazing experience in itself. We visited the mausoleum and the compound right around the Vietnamese independence day - that meant a lot of activity in the mausoleum. Our guide told us people nearly do pilgrimage to the place. Afterwards we looked around in the compound, and ultimately at the museum - which was really biased, BUT it is part of the experience of Vietnam - another guide we had in Vietnam kept talking in loving terms about Uncle Ho, and it seems that he is a figure that all Vietnamese can come together around - all of our guides - some rural farmer girls others middle class hanoians, who were deeply political different could all express the same feelings toward this man, who has been placed in the mausoleum against his will. One has to bear in mind when visiting both the mausoleum and the museum that this image is the one the Vietnamese know - and how much one may disagree with the political propaganda, one cannot discharge that Uncle Ho is essential for anyone who wishes to understand the Vietnam of today.

good to walk around, but nothing special. Big area to walk around, but nothing to see as impressive. Big building, which is fine to see on the web, since you see it from far enough as it is secured by security.

Closed in the Fall every year. We would have liked to view Ho Chi Minh's remains but the Mausoleum is closed for maintenance for nearly the last 4 months of the year every year. We were able to view the Mausoleum from a distance and see the changing of the guard from a distance but you could not get up close. Check the schedule to see whether it is open or not.
Waste of time. No where to sit and admire the gardens, and the whole thing was a one way system to walk through - men blow whistles at you if you stop to look at the amazing fish in the pond.
You must get there early. Its only open in the morning and i think the last admission is about 11am, its free to go see Ho Chi Minh but there can be long ques if the school children go.
Fascinating Structure. Worth going with a Guide, who will be able to explain more of the History and Life of this incredible person.

Impressive but inaccessible. Tried to get access to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum but it always seemed to be closed and on further enquiry it appears that Uncle Ho is not in state at present.I had to content myself with far away views of the building as I travelled around Hanoi visiting other tourist attractions.

Impressive - even though Uncle Ho was "out of the office". We came here while HCM was in Russia getting a make-over and touch up.We tried to walk around but the guards were not having none of it. Still an impressive place - and I bet Lenin would be narked that his body is in a smaller building than HCM.

Impressive. Impressive building and gardens. Good explanations from our guide so an enjoyable outing to learn some Vietnamese history. Ho is being 'maintained' at present so not able to see inside the mausoleum.

Visit to Uncle Ho. Wow this is such a unique and amazing experience, a very special thing to visit. You will have to put up with alot of Vietnamese rules and regulations but this is to be expected at the resting place of their most esteemed leader. Definately worth a visit to see one of the pickled presidents!

Must visit but not enough impression.. I visit Hanoi in August and this was listed as a must-go place for tourist so i try it first. After 2 hour waiting in line to visit the Mausoleum i continue to visit the garden and the house where Uncle Ho lived. I must say it got a quite atmosphere compare to the streets surround it. Also i heard that there is a rumor about the body inside the Mausoleum was a doll, not the real one.

The Great Leader is Away. The buzz around the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is massive even when, as when I last visited in September 2014, the Great Leader was away. According to a local would-be motor-cycle guide, Ho Chi Minh was off with Lenin enjoying a vodka. This legend, urban or otherwise, was lent credibility by the complete closure of the streets and straits around the tomb itself, forcing visitors to flock into the fabulous historical museum and the adjacent One Pillar Pagoda in the immediate vicinity.At other times, an early morning vigil and a long wait will allow you access to the great man's apparent remains, and for appropriate homage to occur. Once again, there are urban legends: one guide is heard to say the remains are real; others are adamant they are 'plastic' or at any rate a facsimile. none of this matters, as you are there to pay obeisance in respectful silence, and the result is always awe-inducing.The Diplomantic and Governmental avenues around the Mausoleum are wide and aeroplanes bearing presidents and dignitaries land there, moments away from the pumpkin-coloured ministries that surround the mausoleum. In the evenings the plaza becomes a flood of locals out to exercise within a stone's throw of their great leader's gaze. Ba Dinh Square is one of Hanoi's great public spaces.The ethnography surrounding the mausoleum with its Vietnamese-styled neoclassicism is as fascinating as the site itself. Modelled on Lenin's mausoleum between 1973 and 1975, the austere stonework shines in dark greys and flashes of red. Visitors are to dress respectfully, as they should for a visit to any pagoda or other shrine or site of worship, and to avoid any clothing that stops above the knees.Photograph yourself and your family, but, remember: "Nước Cộng Hòa Xã Hội Chủ Nghĩa Việt Nam Muôn Năm".
Historic. I pass-by this spot quite often but nothing special that attract me though unless you are into history of Hanoi, this is a must visit.

Is this just for communist propaganda?. A grand site, with a whole lot of Ho Chi Minh artefacts... Nothing really makes a whole lot of sense other than in their own disparate context.i can only feel somewhat sorry for the current leadership... All this praise, money and reference surely can't be outdone. All a bit over the top.

Uncle Ho and his homes are a must see while in Hanoi. Uncle Ho is interred here and his homes show he lived a very simple life dedicated to a unified Vietnam. Walk the grounds and go to the one pillar pagoda for its historical significance.
Must Visit Place. Very Peaceful and lovely place to visit. The Body of Ho Chi Minh is preserved there. very beautifully landscaped garden. Must visit place in Hanoi VietNam

The Honor Guard Carried My Wife.... i have lived in Vietnam for over two years now and know how important Ho Chi Minh is to the Vietnamese people. When in Hanoi last year, we decided to see the Mausoleum. Yes, there was a very long line however, my wife had a stroke 14 years ago and when we travel we bring along a wheelchair. When we arrived, they saw my wife in the chair, pushed her to the front of the line and the honor guard, in their white uniforms actually carried my wife in the chair all the way up into the chamber where the body was. They pushed her through and then carried her down the stairs to the exit. Of course I was there too. What an amazing act of compassion and grace. If any one act could melt away any animosity between the Vietnamese and Americans, I experienced it. Amazing!

Not much to see til after December. This was part of our tour but you can only see it from a distance. The history is very interesting but as renovations are taking place, you can not get close til after December 2014

Mausoleum for a Great Leader. No doubt that Ho Chi Minh is a great leader. This mausoleum is the main sight in Hanoi. A monumental marble edifice that contains the embalmed body of the great leader (but rumors say its just a wax). The line going inside is sooooo long, but its worth the wait. There are regulations to follow which are strictly enforced by the 'Red Guards'. Avoid wearing short skirts and tank tops.
No point. This experience left us speechless and was actually just a bit weird. But and experience to see how they in the communistic culture burries their great leaders

so emotional!. I wasn't expecting to have chicken skin throughout the visit! The longest line ever to get in was moving quite fast and together with the solemnity of the whole organization contributed to give a special atmosphere to the experience. I was asked to leave mobile, camera and backpack at the entrance deposit (you get everything back at the exit). Once you place your first step in the mausoleum you come assaulted by an atmosphere of peace and respect. Seeing uncle's Ho little body right in front of you is such an honour, I can't imagine what Vietnamese people can feel if this has caused in me such sensations.

Bucket list item in Hanoi. Just one of those sites you must see. Impressive and somber; expect to stand in line in the heat for some time. The line moves efficiently and this is worth the wait. No glasses, no hats, covered knees and shoulders and the guards will so remind you. Go see it.

Symbollic and not for everyone.. One of the symbol of Hanoi and the Party. Pretty impressive and overwhelming (by all the military stuffs going around) but might not for everyone - only for who is interested in Vietnamese history. BTW The from what I heard before leaving Vietnam, Mausoleum will be closing down for a few months in September.

Only open at certain hours. Unfortunately I wasn't able to enter the mausoleum, as apparently the interior is only open at certain hours. I only had a few hours one day to get out to do sightseeing, so when I arrived I was only able to take pictures of the outside. Although, the outside is done very nicely.I have no doubt that it would be very interesting to see the interior, but it will have to wait for next time.
Sombre. We felt quite moved by seeing Uncle Ho, lying in state. Some people since have told us that it isn't the real body anymore...

MAUSOLEUM CLOSED 5TH SEPT-5 DECEMBER 2014!!!. After reading online that the mausoleum was open in September and only closed in October and November I was disappointed this morning (9th September) to find the Mausoleum was closed. The guards didn't speak very good English but we understood it was closed and we where not getting in. There was also a sign in Vietnamese which I didn't understand but in large print had the date 5-9-2014 ...... 5-12-2014, which turns out is the period this year the Mausoleum is closed as I guess Uncle Ho's body is off to Russia. Arrived a 7am to make sure I wasn't queuing for too long, gutted!

Uncle Ho's home. I visited this site as part of a full day tour offered by the hotel. If you do any historical touring this is the most important visit in the country. It is important that you see Vietnam through the leadership of the 50s-70s. As part of a tour we had expedited lines. The guards and people involved could not have been nicer.

There is a dress code - just a FYI as we couldnt get in. My rating invalid. We hadnt done our research and when we went to queue were told we needed to be more covered up. No problem there - just a warning to others who might fall into the same trap and be unprepared.
Gone to Russia..... It was disappointing to find out that the mausoleum was closed due to HCM body gone to Russia for 2 months to be re-embalmed...

Ho Chi Minh lies in state. This is a fascinating site to see, such a great leader of the people embalmed and forever on show to his adoring millions. However it is a puzzle when he actually wished to be cremated and his ashes scattered in his home village.
So sorry, but over-rated.. They are proud of Uncle Ho, but the lines are long, can take over an hour depending on time of year and you will just file past him.

Boring. Very military and regimented. Standing in long lines waiting to see a mummified body in very dark room. No talking and no camera for the viewing. The buildings are large and grey and the area is extremely hot. Take a bottle of water.

something to see but need planning. This place only open from 6 am till 12 noon, close on Monday and Friday. The line is very long after 8 am and I mean it when i say long. We went here 3 time and only got inside on the third time, 1st time was Monday so it was closed, 2nd time got there at 10am back of the massive line, get close to the entrance and it was pass 11 am and they stop the line as they close by 12 noon hence the rest will go through by 12 noon. ( we were in the part that wasnt going to get the cut :( .Third time we book it part of a day tour around Ha noi which include a few other places as well, we get in through the tour entrance ( no line ). but once inside it was worth it, get to see the National Hero, very strict inside though like no camera, check your bag and stuff. Definitely a place to see if you visit Ha noi. If you want to see it without going in a tour I recommend get here at 5 30am and be the first to get in, nice weather for a morning walk as well :D

Just a glance!. This atraction in Hanoi is monumental, very impressive. Once we had been to the mausoleum we then walked round the grounds and then went into the museum. Well worth a visit although seeing the preserved body on the glass box is quite eerie.

I wouldn't recommend it to those who aren't interested in the history of the country or those who have children. Otherwise, it is a unique - if not eerie - sight to see.

An interesting insight. We met up with two young men in the line who were practicing the city tour as guides. They welcomed us and used us as real tourists to practice on. I was touched and interested by the impact the embalmed body of "Uncle Ho" had on these two young men. At one time whilst explaining the final moments of Ho Chi Minh to us our guide could hardly speak, over come with emotion. Don't come here for the macabre, come here to gain an better understanding of the influence Ho Chin Minh had and still has on the people of Vietnam. Be ready for the discipline, order and structure and most importantly don't treat the experience like a side show.

Quite impressive. Probably Hanoi`s most popular sight, attracting hords of visitors at weekends and on national holidays. Ho Chi Minh died in 1969 and his body was embalmed and in public view after 1975. The visit won't last more than 3 minutes since you access the grandiose building whre he now lies, and you will be escorted by soldiers in immaculate uniforms. No doubts this is a must do in Hanoi.

Eerie!. Visited in the low season we still had to queue to get into the mausoleum (it must be a huge wait in high season ) trailing single file past the preserved body of Ho-chi-Min was a solemn but eerie experience .There are extensive gardens outside but we picked a rainy day so missed out .

GO EARLY. We got a great tip from our hotel to go early. It opens at 8am and has a massive draw card, with provision for HUGE lines, so go early.You will need to drop both your bag(at entry) and camera (a little further on) and go through a scanner. It's highly guarded with armed Soliders everywhere on high alert. Nothing to be worried about just follow the clear direction and flow of people. Make sure you drop by the palace and stilt house. Interesting! Oh yeah you will need to pick up your bag within 2hrs. But if you go early it's plenty of time.

One of the few reminders you are in a Communist Country. Much of the time you're in Vietnam, as a visitor at least, there's nothing conspicuously 'communist' to be seen, other than the occasional Soviet-style artwork posters in the streets and on roadsides. Many years ago I visited some of the old Eastern Block while the Soviets were very open and proud of their control of their neighbours (that said we're seeing glimpses of this again in Ukraine) and more recently went to Cuba, so I thought I had an idea of what a typical Communist State looked like. I didn't expect Vietnam to look like Czechoslovakia in the early 80's as even today's Czechoslovakia doesn't look anything like the old Soviet controlled Czechoslovakia (it doesn't even exist as one Country) but I was expecting it to be rather more like Cuba in some respects. Economically Vietnam puts Cuba firmly in the shade and looks like it's out-performing many of its non-communist neighbours too. While the Vietnamese are quite open about their dislike of China (more so than the US or France) they appear to be following their economic approach faithfully and very successfully. So when visiting Ho Chi Minh in his mausoleum (he was I understand preserved in Moscow and has been returned there every so often for repair work) it came as a bit of a surprise to be told to walk in twos and to keep our arms at our sides and not to even whisper by the many guards lining the route. I could see the frustration in their faces as they had to repeatedly tell the vaguely interested tourists to show more respect. I was half expecting to be instructed to walk in step with my partner. Ho Chi Minh is clearly, and for very obvious reasons, still highly revered by the Vietnamese. Apparently he wanted to be cremated when he died and have his ashes scattered throughout the land, but the Government wouldn't allow this and had him preserved instead and put on permanent display for future generations to visit and pay thanks to (and now tourists, but I doubt they thought about that at the time). I suspect this was a very wise move by the Communist elite as Ho Chi Minh will remain the leader of their Nation in perpetuity and the people continue admiring what he fought for, believed in and accepting of the form of government he imposed. Consequently, to criticise the government is to criticise Ho himself, and what self-respecting Vietnamese is likely to do that?

National hero of Vietnam. When we got there it was after11am and I think the Mausoleum were being renovated. In away I am glad because I don't think I would like to see a well preserved National hero dead body on display for the public to see. My reason is very simple, it's against my principle. As far as I am concern once you die your body should be cremated or buried, it does not matter if he was a national hero, but that’s only my opinion.
Long wait - bit surreal. We went on a Sunday so had a huge wait - bit helped by lots of locals pushing in. It was then 30 seconds to see Uncle Ho which is a little surreal.

A nice place. it was so surprising when you can come here. a place that many visitors from many countries spent their time in a long queue get inside. Make sure you only can visit only every day in the week but Monday and Friday. and only until 11 Am in the morning.
Important landmark. One feels it is rather obligatory to visit this site, not least to appreciate the symbolic and real historical importance of Ho Chi Minh as a leader.

Ho Chi Min Mausoleum, Hanoi. It is amazing how long people are willing to stay in line to have a rather short glimpse of a former leader whom some seem to honor greatly. The crowd waiting, then slowly walking towards the Mausoleum is disciplined. In true communistic order everyone stays in line and obeys the order of the guards in detail. They tell you to be quiet, to stay in line, to bring your arms from behind your back to you sides in honor of the embalmed person whom you will see shortly for a few moments. Is it the real Ho Chi Min or maybe an imitation? No one wants to answer this question. However, this body is preserved in a cooled hall. For many Vietnamese Ho Chi Min remains a hero.The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is located in the center of Ba Dinh Square, which is the place where the chairman of the Communist Party of Vietnam from 1951 until his death in 1969 lived. Here he read the Declaration of Independence, establishing the Democratic Republic of Vietnam. This mausoleum was ranked as the "sixth most ugly" building in the world by CNN International in 2012. Was it worth the waiting in line? Yes – to get a bit closer to understand communism.

A truly iconic place. You will feel like you are gently getting taken to a place with no freedom. Make sure to wear long pants and clothing covering your shoulders, or you will kindly be asked to leave. No phones, no cameras and hands where they can be seen.But keeping little details aside, this place lets you see how important Ho Chi Minh was to the Vietnamese population. The White Guard soldier's presence is also very impressive.Watch out if you have little children that walk slowly, the guards will not let them mess around. Also be careful this monument is not open every day, and will sometimes be closed long periods of time due to body-care.
Like a theather. Like to do a check in in the USA , the difference is that you don't go to take a flight, you just go to see the Ho Chi Minh death body.

Worth Visiting. Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body is place in a glass box in this complex. No photographing is allowed in side the Mausoleum. We had to be in the queue to go inside and may be because it was a Saturday, it took some time. It is closed on Saturdays and only opened until 11.30 Am other days. After visiting the Mausoleum we were en-routed to visit Ho Chi Minh House. We had to buy tickets at the entrance.

Pay your respects. This is a very popular attraction, we entered as soon as it opened so did not have to queue, however by the time we left the queues were winding round the complex.Must have your upper half covered up, walk no more than 2 abreast and don't speak, plenty of military around to remind any one who is inconsiderate enough not to remember.Uncle Ho, looks peacefull!I have to say that is odd as this mausoleum goes against everything he would have wanted, he liked a humble life.

That's place you will regret if missing. WHy???1- If Russia are proud of Lenin, India are proud of Gandhi, South Africa are proud of Nelson, Cuba are proud of Fidel Castro, why in VIETNAM don't visit the great Father of our country, the communist party founder, patriotic person, President - Ho Chi Minh/ Uncle Ho. Also, he was fluent in many languages. You may line-up and wait (but not long) and see how people love him and foreign visitors are curious about himSome tips: Don't bring devices such as cameras, phones....WE NEED TO KEEP QUITE2- After that, It is CONVENIENT for YOU to see other sightseeings around this historical relic complex consisting of:- Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, and near the exit area, some artists perform Vietnamese traditional music recognized by UNESCO, you can stop and enjoy. - Ho Chi Minh's tilt house where he used to live in his tenure near a fish pond, we call it with a close name " Uncle Ho's Fish Pond" - One Pillar Pagoda - the most unique architecture recognized by Asian Record After that, you can buy some souvenirs and book, like "NÓN LÁ" - Vietnamese palm leaf conical hat 3 -After that, you can visit some places such as:- SQUARE with 79 cycad trees, symbolizing Uncle Ho's 79 springs of life. And you can see Vietnam Assembly 's Headquarter in front of your eyes- Temple of Literature (less than 1 km) - the first university in Vietnam in 11th century - HANOI Old Quater

Experience the history. Our guide was very informed on the history of Ho Chi Minh and the legacy that he left his people.Although we were unable to see the tomb the Mausoleum is to say the least an impressive structure.The humble places where he actually lived and entertained people was a a display of this mans understanding of what was important to his people. Avery moving experience and one that should not be missed

Historical Site. If you are a historian or at least like to learn social, politic and history, this place is a must. You will see stuff that Uncle Ho had left behind and you can even meet him in his tomb! You may want a guide to explain things around. Otherwise, it will be a boring place. Not for adrenalin pumping person. Went there on national holiday so it was very crowded with international and local tourists. At least they got interesting food stalls. Beware for weak stomach though.

A deeply respectful place. Interesting to see the deep reverence given to Ho Chi Minh who lies in state here. Tears flow freely from those visiting. Very strict security here, respectful clothes only allowed, all cameras, phones etc placed in camera bags and in security for collection at the en of the mausoleum.

Very solemn and revered.... Busloads of people from all over come to see "Uncle Ho" lie in state...It was drizzling and foggy and we didn't mind it as we slowly walked in a procession to view Ho Chi Minh's remains. For the N Vietnamese this place is most revered. No cameras, no videos,no cell phones,no flashes...We were all quiet as we passed Uncle Ho lying in state....

A must see. Strange to go and see the body of a dead man, but it is a very fine experience. Tight security and strict rules, but this in respect for the dead leader. An absolute "must see". Take time to also visit the garden and the presidential house.

Mausoleum. This is the sort of place, you have to go visit. To walk by Ho Chi Minh as such. The place itself is very militaristic and you have to keep very quiet. I had my arms folded and was told to put them by my sides! Dress code of long trousers for women are expected. There were a great deal of Vietnamese people there along with the tourists, showing how important this man was to them.

Completely Amazed. I came here just yesterday morning and though it was hot like I never experienced before, it was a very pleasant visit. I'm really mesmerized how all the tourists queue to enter the mausoleum (unlike how thing goes in my home country) and how clean the areas (actually the entire city of Hanoi) is (in contrast to what I've been hearing about Hanoi being the one of the most polluted cities in Asia). This attraction is a must-visit if you're coming to Hanoi and my advise would be to wear something that covers at least your upper arms and knee caps because I conclude that the place is highly respected by the local people.
Ho Chi Minh. Strange experience and hard to define. To me, it's a must do. Tight security. No photos or video allowed. The complex around is mandatory when visiting Hanoi.

Peaceful. He has passed into history doubt he would have approved, preferring the simpler life.
HCM 1 - US 0 would be a suitable epitaph.

Top spot to be visited when in Hanoi. Just to help fellow traveler make sure you have your pants below the knee or bring a sarong to cover it and no sleeveless or else you wont be allowed to enter. For your information as well, the Mausoleum is only open at certain hours of the day and depending on season. So be sure to check before you go. I know some travelers that missed the morning session and need to wait for the afternoon session for few hours. Worth your time as well as standing in the long line. No picture inside and the security is tough.

It's a must.. We went in August.Queue was about 20 minutes.Knees covered, shoulders covered.Walk in pairs.No stopping.No cameras.Hands straight down.Respectful.Interesting to see.Out almost as soon as you are in.You must experience it.

HAVE TO VISIT. This was our first tourist destination and we really did not know what to expect. Very heavy security, you have to walk in pairs, no cameras, hats, shorts or bare shoulders for women.There are armed soldiers everywhere and when you finally arrive inside the centre of the mausoleum, there is a very good replica of the body of Ho Chi Minh, on display, inside his casket.

A must see in Hanoi. The Mausoleum is an amazing experience, the respect and love for Ho Chi Minh is most evident here, to truely understand the people of the north of Vietnam this is a must. The queue may look long but it moves really quickly, this is a very respectful place so remember that knees must be covered (men and women), no shoulders can be showing, and for women remember that a shawl does not work, you must wear a tee shirt or top that completely covers your shoulders, you cannot take photos and if you take a bag larger that a small handbag you must put it into storage, my suggestion, take nothing with you, anything you have on you will go through xray. Once in the Mausoleum you will walk at a steady pace, Ho Chi Minh lies in state with the best of the Vietnamese soldiers standing guard, the Mausoleum is air conditioned and very very quiet, once you leave you can walk back to the front and take as many photos as you like, on a good day the Vietnamese flag will be blowing strongly and it is an amazing site.

An interesting insight. We took a taxi to the Mausoleum around 8.30am on Sunday morning and when we arrived there was already a long queue of mainly locals waiting to go through the Mausoleum. The queue moved quickly so the wait was not nearly as long as we had feared at first. The arrangements are well organised with your 'luggage' being collected before you enter the Mausoleum and delivered to the end so it is waiting for you when you exit. We managed to see the changing of the guard at the Mausoleum which was special. Seeing the body lying in state was interesting but more interesting was seeing the reverence which the Vietnamese obviously have for this man who led their fight against the French and the Americans and re-united the country. Seeing where he lived and worked and hearing a little about his spartan lifestyle was also interesting.

A nightmare. This experience was terrible for the following reasons:*You had to leave all your belonging including you valuables in the massively disorganised luggage counter. You could take your camera with you only to have it taken ten minutes later by another person at another kiosk and there was absolutely nothing to photograph between these two kiosks.*The queue was unbearably long and hot with no fans to keep guests cool as there are in other attractions within Vietnam.*My boyfriend and I only wanted to see the museum (having very little interest in seeing a dead body) but had to go through the queuing rigmarole anyways. *It was packed, I don't just mean it was a busy tourist attraction, I mean it was quite literally CRAMMED full of people.*The One Pillar Pagoda was very nice but has some heavy, messy and noisy construction work going on around it, totally ruining the peaceful atmosphere you usually have at a pagoda.*There apparently was a ticket price admission for the museum but no one seemed to be paying and just walked in? Overall the disorganisation and discomfort of the whole affair meant that we didn't go inside the Mausoleum or the museum and saw the pagoda for all of two seconds.I really wouldn't bother.

Interesting visit!. The queue was huge and even though it moved, be prepared to spend more time in the queue than in the mausoleum! You walk one behind the other, look at Ho Chi Minh and keep walking. We were not allowed to wear knee length shorts, neither women or men and had to wear long pants , yet the young local girls were allowed to wear extremely brief shorts! Go figure...

Note the small hindrances. It opens from Tuesdays to thursdays, and from 630am to 1030am. Many different people gave us differing times, so we ended up going back when it was closed etc. So to be safe just head over early. There is only one entrance, so make sure the cab driver drops you at that if you are cabbing over. If the cab driver drops you and there are no barricades to enter the area, chances are that the Mausoleum is closed. You can still visit other places around though. Do not wear singlets or sleeveless. A scarf bought from a neighbouring shop should not cost more than 50k Dong. Entrance fee to the Mausoleum is free though you need to queue for around 30mins to 1 hour. It is only a good 20 seconds inside the chamber with his body but I suppose if you have learnt of enough Vietnamese history, it is interesting to see the great man himself. A sombre and surreal experience in the chamber.

Same Feelings. I visited Bac Ho at Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum years ago once when I was a kid, just a little older than my son now. I remember vividly the long line of people queuing orderly to be able to go into the mausoleum and visit Bac Ho (I wish Vietnamese people remember to practice queuing like this everywhere, not just at Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. If that happened, our country would be so much better because one good habit will lead to another. Sadly, this only happened at the mausoleum). I remember how nice and big the mausoleum was, how beautiful the guards walked, how great I felt when walking in line, how sad but proud I felt when seeing Bac Ho, how happy I was when I was given an ice cream after the visit. It was one of my best trips in my childhood and so I would love to let my children experience all of that. I tried to explain to them about Bac Ho, how great he was as a person and a leader of the country and what the mausoleum was used for (before, during, and after the visit). I hope my children would remember some of it until the next time we have chance to visit it again.

I could have missed this one. It was ok to see the Viet Nam national hero, but I would skip this stop if I returned. Aside from the mausoleum, I did enjoy the history of the man, his cars, and his home on stilts.
Not to forget. Concentrate on Ho-Chi-Minhs houseon pillars in the well kept park and the one pillar Pagode and avoid the Queue in front of the colossal but less interesting mausoleum
It is like visiting Red Square. Very similar and a great site to visit to see a tomb that is much larger than Lenin's. If you visit at the top of the hour, you can even see the guard change.
It's okay. Nothing special but it's okay when ever you go there just you can see some past time of Vietnam war with French and USA etc that's it.

Inspiring Uncle Ho. Visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a must in Hanoi. It's best to go early in the morning before the sun and heat really kick in (in summer). There is always a daunting line, but don't worry, it goes fast. Make sure not to bring a big backpack and they don't like big cameras, either. I had a small purse and a point-and-shoot that was fine. You shuffle along orderly and then when you reach the mausoleum white uniformed military guards make sure nobody loiters. Ho Chi Minh is encased in glass and has a yellow tinge to his skin. It's all quite peaceful, if not a little macabre. Afterwards foreigners have to buy a ticket to see his stilt house, the President's palace, his cars and the gardens he used to walk. Then there is the Ho Chi Minh museum which is filled with old photos and symbolic exhibits. That part was not my favorite. Everyone was screaming, kids were running wild and I found it hard to concentrate. Oh well. It is a very special place for the Vietnamese. Tons of souvenirs to buy afterwards. Uncle Ho goes to Russia every fall for 3 months to get freshened up, so check to make sure he's home before you go!

Skip it. We waited in a very long line for over 2 hours in the sweltering heat for a 2 minutes walk-through of the mausoleum. While this is a place of reverence for the Vietnamese, tourists would be better off skipping the mausoleum and just visiting the museum and Ho Chi Minh's residence which are right next door and give history and context to his life.

Eerie orange glow. We went to the mausoleum because it was free, we had time and well its a mausoleum. We had no idea we'd slowly be guided around a island with a glass box atop it-his body inside, of course. I wish there was more information on HCM and his personal life although seeing his compound and those artifacts were neat. There was a very long line, but it went quickly. There are restrictions and must cover thighs and shoulder out of respect. *To visit HCM's compound, there is a small fee for visitors.
Stunning Location. I came in Vietnam fro vacation in July 2014 from JapanBeautiful place with amazing view , they Love Ho Chi Minh and you can see itI think this is a beautiful place

My life construction. It's a good place you can go any time. I find it close to me, like my home, my life. Very well - decorated and perfect construction. But it's just open from 8am to 10.30am, a little bit short time to visit. By any way, I love it.
Very Grand Mausoleum. The mausoleum was not open for visitors, but it is very majestic Russian style building from all sides. The grounds are hand manicured.

Long queue. We went on a Sunday and I was amazed at the length of the queue. I didn't take note of the queue time but I estimate it to be over an hour. It didn't matter because we had lots of fun in the queue talking to Vietamese families using the few phrases in the back of the Lonely Planet.
Uncle Ho. If you want to know more about Vietnam...you should first go to the very first president's mausoleum. The place is really clean.

Long queues but nicely lit up at night. When we went to the Mausoleum there were really long queues so in the end we decided not to wait as we had seen the Mausoleum itself and taken photographs. We went for a walk one evening and I was surprised to see how nicely it was lit up with coloured lights so if you are just going to see it and not go inside I would recommend going in the evening. We also got to see the changing of the guards which was an added bonus.

Good with a guide on a Friday!. We went here on the morning of our 2nd day in Hanoi. We went with our guide. We weren't overly interested in seeing 'the body', and on a Friday you can't which means that the grounds and surrounds are much MUCH quieter. No long queues or bustling crowds. This was great for picture taking and strolling. I would recommend going with a guide. Ours was from our tour operator, but I heard a HanoiKids guide giving a very similar quality tour in excellent English. There is very little signposting or information, so you'd rely on a guide or detailed guide book to tell you stuff. pretty grounds, lovely buildings and an interesting bit of history.Top Tip: take some of the political ideology/country history etc with a pinch of salt and don't challenge it. The ideas and beliefs of some of the people here differ greatly from the West and they are proud people.

A nice to see in Hanoi. A visit to the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is a nice thing to do when you're in town. Not to see Ho but for the atmosphere, the guards in their spotless uniforms and the immense Sovjet-style building in wich the Vietnamese keep their 'Uncle'. Come early and dress appropiate.

Weird but interesting. This place embodies Communism. Large concrete pillars, wide-open paved areas, and very regimented, tightly monitored lines of tourists filing by to see Uncle Ho's 40 year old corpse. Its pretty creepy, but a must-see if you are in Hanoi.

Wednesday perfect day to go. Our line to enter the mausoleum was shorter today as is less busy than other days and especially the weekend. We basically walked through the extensive grounds to view the referred leader. Great to see the awe he is heald and respect shown , gives a dignity and interest to this iconic display.Beware security prevents photography inside viewing hall.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Look it was ok it's just that the Veitnamese really revere Uncle Ho , and as a foreigner it was the only place after 4 trips to Vietnam that I felt uncomfortable , and I don't feel we should have been gawking at him in the first place , the day could have been spent better else where and leave Uncle Ho to the people who love him . On the other hand it's really good to see the respect accorded to Uncle Ho by the people of Vietnam and you may see the mausoleum in a different light to me .The Mausoleum is very well maintained and really we'll guarded , do not think of stepping out of line at all at this place they do not tolerate any indiscretions at all .Also the lines are long and slow so be prepared for a fare wait to see Uncle Ho.I call him Uncle Ho as a sign of respect ,as I have not heard him called any thing else by the people of Vietnam

Weird and strict but worth it. So a few rules wear pants/ long skirt / have a sarongDon't wear shorts or have shoulders uncoveredDo come before 10 am or you will miss out on seeing the shrivelled highly decorated Vietnamese leader. No photography inside and the guards line you up file you past reasonably quickly. No talkingFor all of that it was an experience seeing how the 'royal' (white) guards operate. No where else in Vietnam is this much efficiency and rules towards a 'tourist' attraction. It really reveals how much uncle Ho chi Minh is revered by his countrymen and the deep respect they have for him as a leader. Seeing his body in person made this experience seem quite special and brought understanding of all the museums dedicated to this one leader. It's not every day you can view a mummified world leader so I emphasise the importance of waking up early and going to the mausoleum. It is also close to ho chi Minh museum one pillar pagoda, presidential palace so make a morning of all these attractions. After I would head to the temple of literature in the afternoon

Worth the experience. The exhibit is exactly what you would expect from a visit to see a preserved body. Note that while most of the advice indicates shorts (and cameras) are not allowed, many people were permitted to enter the mausoleum wearing shorts and carrying cameras. Most people were required to check their large bags and cameras with security. Guests were permitted to carry their cell phones. Once inside the mausoleum guards ensured that visitors remained quiet.

The main attraction. This tourist attraction is among the few things to really see in Hanoi. Younger Kids can get tired as the whole visit inside requires to walk to long hours. Opting for the Guide is best as you get updated on alot of Historical information which helps you understand well.Note you cannot wear shorts for the 1st part of this visit.

An absolute must in Ha Noi. The Mausoleum for Uncle Ho are maybe the most important place to visit for any Vietnamese. Ho Chi Minh's importance in Vietnamese history is undisputed, whatever views you have on his politics. Visitors to Vietnam should experience the special feeling of coming to the grave with hundreds of travelling Vietnamese; students, families, old war veterans, farmers on their first visit to the capital ever etc.The line of hundreds waiting might seem too much, but it moves quite fast. Expect around 30 minutes in the line before entering the mausoleum. Please observe the rather strict rules on photography, staying quiet etc, to show respect.After the mausoleum, do not miss the gardens (ticket must be purchased), his houses and the museum at the end of the garden.You have not been to Ha Noi without having seen Lang Bac (the grave of the older uncle).

Worthwhile experience . Contrary to what I had read, we arrived at about 9am and joined the queue. We were into the complex in a matter of minutes and then snaked our way through the waiting areas and walked straight up to the mausoleum. Thoughtfully almost the entire journey is covered by a canopy. It does feel a little like you're on a slow escalator but as Ho Chi Minh is so central to Vietnamese history, I'm very glad I went and experienced it! The building is striking.

Worth the time to visit. Sounds a bit of an odd thing to do but many locals visit the mausoleum more than once, the changing of the guard and silent reverence for the great man are worth witnessing in this modern age.Bags and cameras have to be handed in to the ticket office and reclaimed later so be prepared for this and don't be too late as the ticket office closes at a certain time.

History Preserved. For those of us living and loving in the sixties and seventies this a must. Dedicated to a legendary revolutionary this place is wonderful if a little strange. A mausoleum to Ho Chi Minh, containing his embalmed body, is grand if a little surreal. The gardens and his home nearby give an insight into the man. We were accompanied by a local guide who informed us of the man and brought back my time as a 'revolutionary' at university in the late sixties. Something I had not given too much thought to for a long, long time. Worth a visit whatever your age and history.

Interesting. The structure itself is quite impressive and the grounds are very well kept. The Military guards are very somber which permetes the entire atmosphere of the very short visit. You walk into his tomb room, then around a glass enclosed structure which houses his preserved body very quickly. No one stops and the lines are kept moving by the guards. I'd say you are in and out of the place in less than a minute. What is interesting is that the Western view of him is so much different than the way the Vietnamese people see him; as a national hero. Dress conservtively, don't joke around or laugh as you go through the Mausoleum and remember that you are viewing the body of a national hero. I'd say it was very much worth the visit if you take time to understand the role this man played in History.

Uncle Ho. Line was long but went very quick. There is no stopping to pay homage to the great Ho Chi Minh...you are actually in the chamber less than 30 seconds. Remember that dress must be conservative...my girlfriend had short shorts on and a tank top...they made us buy 2 "shawls" for her top and bottom for about $10. He is preserved very well and considering his history, it was pretty cool to see him. A worthwhile stop and it did not take long at all.

Impressive. Heavily guarded but possible to take pictures. Lots of visiting Vietnamese folks as well as tourists, most of them Asian of course. In spite of natural American bias, the little I know of Ho Chi Minh is very impressive. He is, of course, a national hero and pretty much "the father of his country".

Useless. Lining up 1 hour under a killer sun by 36°C should not an option for anyone, I discovered a polished corpse preserved with help of soviet and perhaps chinese specialists.Awful copy of the Lenine's mausoleum, which is not a masterpiece in architecture.

Line too long to enter!. We arrived at 10am in the morning and the line was about 4 blocks long with hundreds if not thousands of people lining up to enter the mausoleum. You need to arrive there very early (they open at 6am to get in at a reasonable time) There was no way we were going to enter in the opening times to see Ho Chi Minh. We decided to go to The Temple of Literature and then come back and see the outside of the mausoleum instead of going inside.

What a man. Regardless of your politics, you have to agree Ho Chi Minh was one of the most important men of the last Century. What is not widely known was Ho's desire for close relations with the US and his admiration of the founding fathers.
closes on Mon. and Fri!!!. I went there on friday and so was so unfortunate because the place was closed..

The changing of the guard, and the lowering of the flag.. I was lucky enough to be near the Mausoleum at about 8.45pm, so my Vietnamese friend suggested we go to see the changing of the guard which starts at 9pm. We arrived to find a fair number of Vietnamese families making their way across the park towards the nightly lit Mausoleum, in front of which the guards were standing by a large the flag pole where the Vietnamese flag fluttered in the warm wind. At 9 pm on the dot revolutionary music was played through the loud speakers, and the ceremony began. I was impressed by the way the large crowd of people (I did not see another foreigner) stood behind a white line painted on the ground without surging forward, with only a young soldier standing on the other side of the line seemingly in complete control of the situation. The ceremony involved lowering the flag and the soldiers marching around the square taking exaggerated steps in exact time with the music playing from the loud speakers. It was sombre, and I found it moving in that the people around me were obviously taking this act of national pride very seriously. Afterwards, my friend and I, along with many others, crossed the line and wondered across the square to the front of the Mausoleum, where I had my picture taken and where I took pictures of the children and families playing in the square. I would like to visit the Mausoleum during the day and wait in line to see Ho Chi Min's preserved body, but that will have to wait till another time. I'm glad, though, that I saw the evening ceremony, and would recommend it to others.

Don't let the queue size deter you.... ...it moves very quickly. It is worth joining the very solemn and respectful queue. It is an experience where you will take in the love and respect the nation still has for its former leader, including those generations born many years after Uncle Ho's passing. A humbling experience brought about by what appears to have been a very humble man.

an aura of tranquility. Amazing place , good arrangements for tourist, inspite of the heat it was comfortable as there is a long winding covered pathway leading to the entrance of the mausoleum. We were lucky we did not have to wait long, to get in. has an aura of tranquility , no talking laughing no photos one has to be in your best behaviour or the guards bring it to your notice. The mummified body of HCM calm and serene looking inspite of the years gone by. He is considered as the father of Vietnam just like Mahatma Gandhi is the father of India. a must see place , you cant leave Hanoi without paying your respect to the Father of the Nation.

closed!. Was so looking forward to lining up and seeing the big man himself in all his glory, but when we were there, HCM was being re-balmed and so the Mausoleum was closed. Apparently this happens annually. We were there in early October.

Unexpected. I did not realize to what extent the people of Vietnam honor Ho Chi Minh….now I know.Luckily the que was not very long when we visited as we were told that people can wait for hours.My girls really enjoyed this experience.

Not quite sure what to make of it. Firstly if you want to see the body make sure you don't go on a friday or monday as he has 2 days off. We came on a friday but decided to visit the museum anyway as we were there. It is very well maintained which shows clearly the respect and admiration held for Ho Chi Minh by the Vietnamese people. However, as a tourist visiting the museum and not knowing much about the president's history the museum does little to help your understanding. The exhibits seem very random and symbolic as if to let you make your own interpretation without any clear explanation.

Should visit... go inside before 11 am..... This place is unbilievable. it shows how much respect the Vietnamese ppl have for Ho CHi Minh. They have mummyfied his body and kept it in this place. he is in sleeping position. there are always atleast 4 soldiers surrounding it, and nobody is allowed to speak inside the room. they have maintained it so well that its worth a visit...

Interesting experience . A good experience considering the country's love for this president, but probably not worth it if you know little to nothing about his life and presidency, as there is barely any information provided. Highly controlled environment, and you probably can't walk around by yourself, you're kind of ushered in and out within 2 minutes. Not 100% sure if it is a real body either, obviously they claim that it is, but it looks very wax-like. Regardless, it was an interesting visit. Definitely check out the presidential gardens, it was a nice walk in a beautiful place that was less restricting. Please respect the Vietnam custom by dressing conservatively (as you would in most temples across Asia). No shorts/skirts above the knee, or bare shoulders. T-shirts are fine. You won't be allowed in if you are not dressed appropriately. Be prepared to have to check your bags/cameras in at a locker, as you are not allowed to bring these inside the mausoleum.Double check with your hotel staff to make sure this is open before you leave. Be aware that it is closed Mondays and Friday afternoons, but can often be closed for months at a time for "renovations". We booked this as part of a tour, so everything was sorted for us.

Cool inside.... Just remember that even though it's free, you're still queuing to see a dead body. They are very organised and get everybody through pretty quickly (although I was part of a group and we went almost to the front of the queue). Nice and cool inside which was a great relief from the heat and humidity outside. Does have a few steps leading up and down to the viewing of the body (maybe 30-40), so if you struggle with steps, consider whether you go as they will keep you moving through the mausoleum.It was ok, but there are also other ways of paying respects to and learning about Ho Chi Minh if you really want to. Interesting that he never wanted to be embalmed either, but yet that's what happened.

Exceeded expectations!. I was dubious about visiting the resting place of a dead person, and became even more dubious when lining up with literally THOUSANDS of other people on a rainy day in a queue that was without exaggeration, probably a kilometre long.But - I must give the staff that run the grounds credit where it is due, their militant attitude kept things moving like the dead themselves were chasing the line! We moved through the whole line (which snaked through the grounds and into/around the mausoleum itself) inside 10 minutes. Incredible!Actually, it is an odd feeling when you are ushered into the room where Ho Chi Minh is entombed by military officers in full dress - silence is strictly enforced and a hushed awe befalls the room as you file around his final resting place. Much more awe-inspiring than I thought possible.p.s. The staff throughout the grounds are crabby; just ignore them and have a nice time wandering the grounds and enjoying the scenery.

intersesting. It was interesting to see, you should really see this mausuleum, gives good insight to Vietnamese history. The only downside is that you are not allowed to sit down anywhere, if you try guards will tell you it is not allowed.

A lot of reverence. "Why are we going to this" was the first thought that crossed my mind especially when you saw the line up to enter. However, the crowd moved at a good pace and it was pleasing to see how many locals were there to show reverence to a powerful leader. No matter what your politics, it is worth a visit.

It's free and has A/C. This is a free attraction and involves probably the most respected Vietnamese hero there is. You NEED to go. A lot of people go see this attraction - it's nice to see many locals who also go. You cannot take food or drinks in. You can, however, check these all in at the entrance and retrieve them afterwards. Wear appropriate clothing (cover your shoulders and wear pants past your knees!)The queue is long, but moves steadily. There are plenty of white-uniformed military personnel to guide you and shush you if you get too noisy. The A/C is on full blast inside the mausoleum so it's a nice escape from the humidity outside. However, you are only in there for a total of about 5 minutes. Ho Chi Minh is well preserved. It's a bit eerie. Don't miss out on it. Oh, and you can't take pictures.

Needs to be seen. Be ready to queue, although it moves quite quickly and shouldn't take much more than half an hour, but it's got to be done if you're in Hanoi. Once in, you've got access to a number of other attractions like the stilted house, Presidential Palace etc. (although you pay) which is handy but the mausoleum is free. In itself there's nothing other than Ho Chi Minh himself but it's a fascinating piece of history, a great experience and got to be done. If you've ever been to Lenin's mausoleum in Moscow then it's (purposefully) startlingly similar. You'll see many Vietnamese people queueing to pay their respects to their dead hero and to properly experience Vietnam you've got to visit the mausoleum of the man who did so much to shape it.

Unique experience. Viewing the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh, surrounded by his statuesque, white-uniformed military guard, is worth a visit for the sheer uniqueness of the experience. Be prepared for the following: shoulders and knees must be covered to enter. Otherwise, you must purchase coverings from vendors just outside the entrance. Last entry is 10:15am. The later you wait, the longer the line. Backpacks and cameras must be checked before entering. These are 2 different checkpoints and return stations, which can be confusing and a little frustrating.

Intense. When we arrived there was a long queue of people under a sheltered walkway. The queue moved quickly so it didn't take too long until we were inside the Mausoleum. There were guards every few metres making sure that everybody in the queue was walking two by two and that nobody was talking as we approached the Mausoleum and when we were inside it. They also ensured the queue kept moving so we were in the chamber that held Ho Chi Minh's body for less than a minute but my family and I all agreed that it was worth the visit. Ho Chi Minh's body is sent to Russia for two months each year for maintenance but not sure when so it might be an idea to check beforehand because this is a definite must-see if you are visiting Hanoi.

A nation remembers its greatest leader. Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum is located in the centre of Ba Dinh Square. Vietminh communist leader Ho Chi Minh, read the Declaration of Independence at this square on September 2, 1945, establishing the Democratic Republic of Vietnam.. Coincidentally, this was also the day that Ho died in 1969 . The embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is preserved in the cooled, central hall of the mausoleum. Construction work began on September 2, 1973, and the structure was formally inaugurated on August 29, 1975. The mausoleum was inspired by Lenin's Mausoleum in Moscow but incorporates distinct Vietnamese architectural elements, such as the sloping roof. The exterior is made of gray granite, while the interior is gray, black, and red polished stone. The mausoleum's portico has the words "Chủ tịch Hồ Chí Minh" (Chairman Ho Chi Minh) inscribed across it. Photography is strictly prohibited inside and visitors are expected to maintain silence and decorum. Must visit site in Hanoi
A must see. This is a must see - well worth it.There is a real sense of respect and love - evident.Highly recommend being there for the changing of the guard.
interesting visit. Luckily we didn't have to wait to long to get in - apparently the queues can be very long - worth going early and not on a weekend. Interesting to visit - our 3 children enjoyed it

Very different. Seen this attraction quite early in the morning(0730). We had a guide who held our pers belongings. If you don't you have to place them in a locker or with reception. Long queues, however, thy move quickly. You see the body of Ho Chi Min for about 30 secs as your moved through his chamber quite quickly. If you stuck for time I would give it a miss

Good photo shoot!. The Vietnamese have tremendous respect for Ho Chi Minh and as a mark of respect I think all tourists need to visit this solemn place. One is not allowed inside so this is a quick touristy thing to do.

Get a different viewpoint. A lot of pomp and ceremony and respect for a person that is probably not well known to westerners. A guide is very helpful and the times they are open is irregular. Close at 10:30 am and not open Monday and Friday.

You have to see him. You cannot go to Hanoi and not see Uncle Ho. The queue to get in is horrendous but it moves quickly. Get there between 7.30 & 8.00am to avoid the heat. You must wear long pants and have your shoulders covered. Hats are acceptable when waiting in the line but you cannot wear your sunglasses.
Lined up for an hour in the rain. And it was surprisingly worth it. It can give you a unique perspective on the Vietnamese people. And visiting Uncle Ho is a surreal experience too.

Beautiful building from the outside. Imposing architecture. It wasn't open (or didn't appear to be) when we where there, but was great to observe a bullding representing a nations pride in its former leader.

Typical attractive site of Ha Noi. This is the place most of tourists who travel to Ha Noi want to come. You can know more about the life of Ho Chi Minh and how he has devoted for Vietnam.But just come to this place if you love history, love the Great Father of Vienamese because you must wait with a very long line before you can visit Ho Chi Minh. Besides, this site requires formal clothes. Otherwise, this tour is worthy to visit because it is very typical in Ha Noi

A weird must-see. Note that this is only open Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday mornings, so if you really want to see this, plan accordingly. Don't be put off by the long line. It's fast-moving, and the people watching is pretty good. No water or food is allowed, but no one ever checked for cell phones or cameras (despite all the signs saying that none are allowed). Once you get through the mausoleum you will get turned out into the grounds. There are loads of people moving through narrow paths, so it's more than a little difficult to go against the crowd. Check out the museum before you join the line to see the stilt house. There's no way to go back after that that I could see, and I totally missed the museum as a result!

The devotion and ceremony worth the visit. The Vietnamese people are so devoted to Ho Chi Minh and their respect is reflected in the mausoleum. You need to cover your knees there - sarong can be used (I purchased one out the front). A guide is helpful - Ho Chi Minh was very modest and refused to stay in the palace built for him when his people were so poor. Worth the visit.

Long, hot wait to see a dead body. Lots of security, waiting and rules await visitors here. You walk with thousands of other people two-by two through a labyrinth of outdoor walkways into a huge heavily guarded building that centers around a single room with a "Snow White" type of sunken room housing the alleged body of Ho Chi Mihn. Much of my thoughts wandered to 'how do the guards hold their statue posture for so long' as we were whisked through.
ho chi minh. we enjoyed this tour immensely as you would need to read a book regarding the man himself as to all the good deeds that were done for his people

A sort of pilgrimage. We had to queue from the far down the outside street, and it took almost 45 minutes until we saw uncle Ho. i hate queuing, but this felt like I was apart of history.You will be paraded around corners and stopped, then paraded again until you reach the resting place of the body. There is a lot of shade and some fans, but you are not allowed water so I recommend drinking as much as possible during the initial stages of queuing. The military officers will temporarily take your cameras, make sure you do not talk on your phone, and make sure your hands are by your sides and you walk in an orderly fashion. I think many of the locals found this a hassle but I enjoyed the discipline and the way the Vietnamese respect the process as much as Uncle Ho himself. The whole thing felt like a wholly pilgrimage for Vietnamese.Uncle Ho is quite hard to see, and you don't get long to look, but for me the beauty of was the experience itself. The parade grounds outside have a very imposing feel to them, but coming from the west I loved it, we have nothing like that where I come from. Remember to wear clothes that cover your shoulders, and for ladies, remember to wear pants, as you will be asked to leave the queue if you have shorts on.There are vendors to the left of the queue once inside that sell pants and scarves to don't panic if you forget, just pop over there and then re-join the queue.

Be prepared, arrive early, dressed properly!. If you go to Ha Noi, this is a must see! However, if you want to have a good time, be well-prepared!- Come early (I recommend be at the line at 7.30 am) because the line can be like 3-mile long. No fees are needed- Check the weather before you go (be ready for the intense heat during summer and cold during the winter while waiting)- Dressed properly (no shorts, no dresses that are shorter than knee length, no tank-tops, no caps, no sunglasses) AND act respectfully (no talking loudly, laughing, joking around)- No photography is allowed (check you cameras in up front, they will return the cameras to you by the end of the tour. However, you can take pictures once you're outside the mausoleum)- There are other attractions in the same plaza that you can visit and take pictures with (Ho Chi Minh's house, One Pillar Pagoda, and a Museum)- If you go with a big group, I suggest you schedule ahead of time in order to skip the long waiting line.*Little trick to skip the line: blend in with the tourist groups (if you can), because they already made the reservation and that can save you a tremendous amount of time if you barely have a day in Ha Noi.

Creepy but memorable. Don't be put off by the long lines here as it moves fast albeit in military fashion (two by two and don't step out of the lines or drink). Don't take anything with you such as gum or water as they will confiscate it at the door. You can supposedly get it back but there was not enough time (by 10 am you can get it). The time in the mausoleum is short but memorable. It's very cool inside and dimly lit but his body is illuminated. My youngest (8) was a little nervous at it so perhaps not good for younger ones. Outside is OK but don't get too excited at the houses and sites to see around --little boring. Go for the mausoleum mostly -- check opening times and days though as it's only before 10:30am on certain days.
