Be prepared for a surprise. This is a must see. Line up from arrival. Long constantly moving queues and as you get closer to the mausoleum things get more formal. Be quiet, no hands in pockets all while being watched by armed guards to ensure you show your respects. The wait is worth it to see Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body on display for all to see. When you leave the mausoleum and wonder the grounds and see the humble quarters he so cherished it does make you wonder if this is what he would have wanted. That said, it is a must see when visiting Hanoi.

Go there early, drink water before, and dress properly (kids included). The first time we visited Hanoi, the Mausoleum was closed for cleaning.So this time, we make sure that we would go back and visit it.We arrived early (9am), but since the Mausoleum opens at 7:30, there was already a huge line.The taxi dropped us in front of an access with a billboard "with appointment".We asked clarifications to the guard in front of the billboard, who looked at us to check if we were properly dressed (wear long shorts, the knees must be covered - also for kids!) and made us go through. OK.We got to the check-in. We were told that we couldn't bring anything in there - if you have a baby, you cannot even bring his/her bottle, let alone stroller or anything else.We checked in all we had, we just kept our wallet with us, as recommended by the staff.First surprise: other people were actually holding on their backpacks and handbags, no check-in required. OK.Second surprise: they made us join the line at a point that was quite close to the entrance. We probably had a 10 minute-queue, that's it.Third surprise: we were not the only ones. We saw other tourists coming through the same way as we did. I kind of felt guilty about passing in front of the others, but we just followed what the guards told us to do. No-one ever asked us about an appointment.In the Mausoleum, you cannot take pictures (anyway, you checked your camera), you cannot talk (normal), and you walk quite fast (normal also, otherwise the others cannot have a chance to get in). What I regretted afterwards (it's my fault, I didn't check beforehand), is that my young kids were a little shocked at seeing Ho Chi Minh. You would think he is just sleeping.

A bit weird. You must line up two by two here. You cannot take bags, water, or take photos. Waiting on line was extremely hot and uncomfortable. Walking in to the mausoleum I have never been more grateful for air conditioning. Walking around Ho Chi Minh was a bit weird, I still wonder if he was waxed? Unless you are really into seeing him, skip the mausoleum and just walk the grounds.

When in Hanoi. This is probably worth the lineup especially if you are to be in the area for the other sightseeing opportunities behind the mausoleum. However it is exactly as you would expect a mausoleum to be and you will be inside for all of about 45 seconds. The line moves faster than it appears. Note that despite all literature saying otherwise, shorts on men are perfectly accepted (although perhaps not entirely respectful). Also note that while no cameras are allowed, don't worry about checking into the lockers anything but a fullsize dSLR camera - point-and-shoot cameras and cellphones can easily be carried with you although using them is prohibited.

Hanoi - Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum - Paying our respects. I suppose being in Hanoi and not seeing the mausoleum would have left us wishing we had, but something about lining up and walking past someone who has passed away is not my idea of an attraction. So, in the interests of paying respects to a leader much loved by his country we joined the long queue to visit the mausoleum. The queue seemed very long when we first joined it and at various intervals there are requirements you have to abide by, like a bag drop off point and a location where cameras and video cameras of a certain size and type are handed in under a ticketing system. I had a smaller hand held camera and was allowed to progress with it but on the strict understanding no pictures. Which I was always going to respect. The queue actually moves very quickly so the wait is not that long. Soon we were entering the mausoleum building and being ushered along at a pace by the white uniformed guards. Ho Chi Minh's body is on display and you get a few minutes sight of it before the flow takes you out of the building and away. All done fairly respectfully, if having your body on display to the public is deemed respectful. After leaving the mausoleum you can walk round to the other side of the yard area in front to grab some pictures, near where the large flagpole is located with the huge Vietnamese flag on display. I have rated this fairly highly here as the Vietnamese worshipped, and still do, their former leader and this mausoleum allows many nationals to visit. It's all done quite tastefully and the visit ran extremely smoothly. However, maybe it's me but these sorts of places are not ideal. Still you have to visit when in Hanoi.

Fantastic site to see. A great way to spend sometime in Hanoi. It is wonderful to see the respect the people of Vietnam have for him. We went on a Saturday morning, got there about 10, and queued for approx 1 hour, but well worth it!

Interesting Exhibit. I saw this as part of the Ho Chi Minh museum visit. I am not a fan of mausoleums and it is my understanding this is not something Ho wanted. It was ironic that the honor guard and their uniforms, and their drill and ceremony appear to be straight from a French military manual. I talked to the guards during their break and found them approachable(for Honor Guards).Still, I understand their desire to honor Ho for his part in creating the modern Vietnam, but I found the museum and house more informative as to the man.
Respectful. The sense of pride and respect is on show. We visited during a quite period and enjoyed the "space". The guard change is worth watching.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and his house. The mausoleum visit, was one of the more fascinating parts of Hanoi. Some basic rules are required however, being that you get there very early certainly by 9:15 AM, and planned not to take any water et cetera in with you as you will be stored for your return. You can purchase water inside. Everything is done very tastefully, and Ho Chi Minh lying in state was very symbolic. However the most interesting part of the whole visit is to view his house and office. Ho Chi Minh, had no palatial home nor office, and ran the government along the same lines.The contrast of his simple house next to the imposing former French government general of Indochina's house is absolute. I'm sure Ho Chi Minh made sure everyone understood.Very well maintained, well organised and a credit to the government.

Interesting, I felt , the great leader is still alive , just resting. Aesthetically matained ,one could feel the love &respect of Vietnamese people in this beautiful memorial .A must see for all tourists to Hanoi
Must visit. You can only understand what Ho Chi Minh represents to. Vietnamese people after this visit. It is impressive by itself but more over when you learn how locals still relate with him.
Ho's mausoleum.. Magnificently set way back in a large park. The body is sometimes removed to Moscow(?) for its refurbishment.
Cold and stark. Beautiful granite tomb. Large grounds and fabulous new government building across the mall that was under construction. Don't miss the grounds at the 'palace' and his home.

Ok for history buffs. even though you will have to stand in a long line we only waited about half an hour to get thru the line and into the mausoleum if you are a history buff it will be worth the wait, I found it interesting but wouldn't do it again. found that a lot of the locals quite rude i.e pushing into the line and their attitude when confronted about pushing in very rude, I must admit this seemed to be quite common the further north you got in Vietnam

Ho Chi Minh - Embalment. I have previously visited the Mausoleums of Mao Tse Dung and Lenin so thought it a must-do to visit that of Ho Chi Minh, whose influence on modern day Vietnam is well documented and revered by most Vietnamese today. We went in the morning and were marshalled in a long line towards the mausoleum slowly but surely - be patient and drink enough water while waiting (there are toilet opportunities along the way). The visit has to be treated respectfully (no bare shoulders, shorts, flip flops and you have to remove your sunglasses and hats before entering the mausoleum. Arms are supposed to be at your sides and not crossed.....and keep any talking to a minimum or low tone......otherwise the soldiers will reprimand you or escort you off the premises robustly. Ho Chi Minh is embalmed in the mausoleum and the brief sighting opportunity is quite poignant and made me want to learn more about the man and his life and impact on Vietnam. Afterwards you can visit his house and the museum. This has to be a must-do when in Hanoi.

A Hanoi must do. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a definite must do for any visitor to the city. Easy to get too and you just have to remember the usual hats, covered shoulders routine. No pictures unfortunately. The museum is also really interesting and has a lot of interesting things and some art as well and is well worth a visit as well.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Long Q and ushered past Ho Chi Minh very quickly but worth going if interested in the history of Vietnam. Note no photos allowed to be taken of Ho Chi Minh.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. I had seen Ho Chi Minh when i was a young girl living in Mumbai and he visited the city. I had a lot of respect for the man so my husband and i were determined to visit thie Mausoleum.Be prepared for LONG LINES. The mausoleum is only open for a few hours each day and the lines are just unbelievably long but everyone stands very patiently. Most of the people i would say 95% are Vietnamese as they loved this man. We stood out in the crowd since we were from India and looked different. Yet i have to say the people of Vietnam are very kind. We could not speak their language and they could not understand us as we spoke English but the kindness they showed us just warmed my heart. We are in our 70;s and it started to rain and the couple behind us pulled us under their umbrellas so that we would not get wet. When the lady found that the four of us could not fit under one umbrella she tapped the gentleman in front who had an umbrella for himself (he had not noticed us getting soaking wet) and told him to take me under his umbrella which he did very willingly and all this without a word being spoken only gestures. I will never forget this experience, and i have to say we thoroughly enjoyed our trip to this beautiful country.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum visit in Vietnam. A gr8 historical place. Our guide from Indo China Odyssey was good and explained the details. We took a long walk from one end to another and came to stand in the center to watch the change of guards. Humbling and interesting experience indeed!

A Must Do. Second day in Hanoi and we have organized as an experience a Rickshaw to pick us up and take us to pay our respects to Ho Chi Minh.This was to be a good way to see some of Hanoi's streets at a leisurely pace, this worked fine but we found the pollution from the thousands of motorbikes dampened the experience.On arrival we had our bags checked and proceeded to join the que . We were lucky with our timing as they were changing the guard.Going through the Mausoleum was very humbling and an experience that I was to repeat on a City tour as well.Certainly a learning kerb going through the grounds, housing area ETC of this hero of Vietnam.This is a must do when visiting Hanoi and is on the agenda of all city tours.
A little dull for me. I went here as it's part of the things to do in Vietnam, but I found it a bit boring. If you're interested in History you will probably get more out of the visit than I did.

no short pants,please.. closed @11 and remember to not wearing any short or bring shawl or something. Really good place tosee and to know more about Ho chi Minh. We need to Q but even the line is long, it will not takes so much time to the mausoleum because they manage this place in really good way.

Worth seeing. We got fast tracked by our guide so only spent a short time queuing, you can't take any phones or cameras inside and you walk through the mausoleum at a leisurely pace. The body is in a glass case about 3 metres away surrounded by 4 guards. Afterwards you can visit the house where he lived and the nearby museum of his kife

Go early and book at tour!. We booked a tour to see this and i am very greatful that we did! The tour was able to cut the line which was very very long! Very respectful place for Vietnamese people and seeing Ho Chi Minh's body was definitely eye opening

dont go on weekends!. be prepared to queue for an hour if you are there on weekend. many locals visit this place on weekends. and all you get to see is Ho Chi Minh's body resting inside. not even sure if it is really his real body. after all the queuing, you proceed to Ho Chi Minh's residence which you have to pay to get in.

A mausoleum to commemorate the leader. The place is opened in the morning. We went there in the afternoon so it was closed. The mausoleum is at the Ba Dinh Square itself and it's just a walk away from the Ho Chi Minh Museum. There's guard at the entrance to the mausoleum. Even though it was closed, you can still take photos of the mausoleum and enjoy the breezy walk at the square in front of it :)

A must do in Ha Noi. Uncle Ho is held in very high reverance in Viet Nam and the opportunity to visit the Mausoleum was one not to be missed. Arrive early in the morning around 8.00am to avoid the massive queues that form later on. Remember to dress appropriately as they will not let you inside.
a very large tombstone.. it was closed when we visited but nevertheless a walk round the outside is well worth it when coupled with the imperial palace right next door.

Shut on Mondays. I went on a day when the mausoleum was shut which was disappointing but it's still impressive to see how big this place is from the outside and there are some guards protecting it. Would recommend going, would love to see inside! Beware of annoying men wanting to take you on tours knocking about here who won't leave you alone

Huge Mausoleum for a communist Leader. very impressive mausoleum, We visited with our tour leader part of an arranged tour. Lots of armed guards but no more than we have seen in America or some European Cities. Be sure to get to all attractions before the Korean and Chinese who manage to walk in front of your cameras!
Got to be done, I guess. Well, of course it is interesting to see how the Vietnamese worship their "glorious leader", but I'm not sure it was worth queuing in the heat.

worth seeing. This museum tells the story of hundreds of years of the Vietnamese fighting against foreign invasion. If you are in to planes, there's great display of aircraft out the back. Definately worth a visit but not as confronting as the Ho Chin Min City museum.

Worth a Visit. I went one morning after getting off a night bus.I was interested to see it and because I heard so much about Ho Chi Minh from the Vietnamese while traveling from the south.Takes maybe an hour all in all.The line looks huge but moves very quickly.
Tribute to uncle ho. A tribute if or if not deserved , a well preserved mausoleum of a revered Vietnam personage .housed in a magnificent building and well orderly to view

Really neat.. Everything about this visit was kind of what was expected but pretty interesting. Lines were very well enforced and of course Ho Chi Minh looked good. Definitely a must if you want to get a feel for communist culture.

Grand building and possibility to see change of guards. Unfortunately it was closed when we were there, I think it was a monday, therefore I can only give a review of the exterior. The building is grand and built with national pride. When we passed there they were changing guards, which was quite amusing to watch.
Go early!. We showed up about 10 minutes before 8. Didn't really have much of a line at all. Filed through the mausoleum. It was good, quick visit.
Nice view from the outside.... Not open on the day we went, closed on a Monday and Friday. Disappointing....be sure to check it out on days it is open.

Quite a sobering spectacle. We were taken here on our first full day in the country. Amazing that so many people come here and that school children see it as a treat. A long covered queuing area was fortunately not needed on the morning we visited although it was still busy. Water is among the long list of things you cannot take in. I was slightly sad that the elderly gentleman with surprisingly large ears had wanted to be scattered in two parts of Vietnam as part of an attempt to unite the country rather than be kept here in the very dramatic mausoleum. A real indication of the reverence Uncle Ho is still treated with
Closed on Mondays and Fridays. We had one days in Hanoi which was a Monday. We made our way to the mausoleum but is was closed on Mondays and Fridays

Show respect. Unclo Ho lays at rest here in a glass cabinet.the building is open most days and is attended by lots of tourists.there are long lines of people waiting to enter.lots of armed guards about the place making sure you obey the rules.no hats,no hands in pockets,,no folded arms,no smoking or eating,no loud voices,.respect,respect,respect.there is an airport style security point to pass by and no backpacks etc are permitted.photography not allowed.When inside you pass three sides of the enclosure where Ho Chi Minh is entombed.sort of open coffins affair.that's it,you leave.Make sure to see if the guest of honour is in.Uncle Ho is in Russia each year for a make over.a month or so.

A Must Visit in Hanoi. Mausoleum was the first place of our trip in Hanoi. We go there with Hanoikids volunteer. They explained us about the history of Vietnam and Ho Chi Minh. It is better for you to visit here with tour guide. Because you will got a rich information about history of Ho Chi Minh.

very interesting. At first I didn't want to go there but now I'm glad that I did. To see Ho Chi Minh was not the most exciting on this visit (and to be honest I'm not able to say if it was him or not) but it gives a good impression about the importance of Ho Chi Minh for the history of Vietnam. Don't miss the garden next to the Mausoleum where Ho Chi Minh lived and died.
A must when you visit Hanoi. It is very busy so go first thing. You see a Ho ChinMin (either a wax work or embalmed) lying in state. All impressive, as is his house.
Saw the outside. We went here, but it was closed to visitors, so could not go inside. Be sure to check the visiting hours before going!

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It is a temple that remains of the great Ho Chi Minh City have been enshrined. It is a good idea to take a taxi or Baitaku because there is a little distance from the old town of Hanoi. Processing is given body of Ho Chi Minh City, you can actually see. It was the impression that nobody knows. It would be good to visit once Hanoi stay.

Well organised and moving. We went very early to avoid crowds and were surprised by the long queue already forming, mainly school children. Apparently all children have to see Ho Chin Min at some point and come from all over Vietnam, however the queue went down very quickly as it was constantly moving. The children in the queue were very entertaining as it appeared we were a novelty being white and they were practising their English! The mausoleum itself was very somber as befitted the occasion and everyone including small children were respectful and quiet. It was very moving.

be aware it is only open in the mornings. We wanted to see the Mausoleum but came too late. So we decided we would like to walk around, but that was impossible. There were guards everywhere so you couldn't even get close to the Mausoleum.It is interesting to see how the communist regime deals with Uncle Ho, who actually wished to be cremated ( as far as I know).

go see uncle ho. a strangely moving experience of lining up and filing by the preserved body of ho chi minh. no liquids allowed. cameras etc are ok but can't be used. a very vietnamese experience. one of those sites where there are relatively few foreigners in comparison.

calm opulence. the lines to get in are kilometers long so one must go early and wear sun shading clothes.. no photography allowed.. if you follow lines and instructions can be a smooth process.. worth the wait

An experience. It was a pretty hot day when we paid Uncle Ho a visit, but we were not disappointed. The queue, although lengthy, was kept moving smoothly by the guards and staff on duty. You can't say you have been to Hanoi if you've not paid Uncle Ho a visit

Nothing like this place to get a taste of socialist architecture. Large open spaces all around the main mausoleum building evoke a sense of magnificence. Inside, seeing Ho Chi Minh's body is a one of a kind experience. The only drawback is large queues. We arrived there at 7:30am when it opens and already there was a huge queue. We had to wait an hour before we got into the mausoleum.
Revered Ho Chi Minh. Whilst the mausoleum is an impressive building,the sheer volume of people passing through meant that there was no stopping - keep moving !

Weird.... I thought this was overrated. The line for the "attraction" was ridiculous. Luckily our tour guide got us in through the VIP line, which made it much shorter. But I guess we didn't quite understand what we were going to see inside and we were a shocked. Why can't they just build a statue like everyone else.We thought it was weird, especially all of the families with children that waited so long to get a quick peek.

a must do!. Uncle Ho is loved by Vietnamese and our Vietnamese family said it was a must do before we left. The organisation to visit Uncle Ho is great and although at sometimes you may need to queue it is worth it to share the Vietnamese love for Ho Chi Minh. There is a great cafe on the outside of the complex - on the street side of the covered queuing area to get your camera and bag checked.

Ok if you have the time to kill in Hanoi. There isn't that much to do in Hanoi so we found ourselves going to the Mausoleum just to check it out. Whilst i guess the mausoleum is big for a building to house one guy, the building is significantly smaller than what I pictured and not really that impressive.

Quite an experience. The long queues to see Uncle Ho might not exactly be worthwhile, but the surrounding of the whole Mausoleum is worth a visit here.
You can't say you have been to Hanoi if you have not been here.

Fascinating experience, just be respectful.. We queued up with many others to file past Ho Chi Minh and were not disappointed.While the queue was lengthy it moved smoothly and efficiently and, provided you show respect such as having your phone turned off, remove your hat, are modestly dressed, file in and stay two abreast, be quiet and take no photos, it is a fascinating experience. The guards are quiet and subtle but keep everyone in check.We checked online before we went to ensure we knew the opening times and went in the morning. There is no fee.I needed to hand over my DSLR camera as it was not permitted in the Mausoleum - I was given a ticket and picked it up afterwards with no issue.Recommended.

Something different. We were actually pretty impressed with the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. I was worried as I knew you couldn't take cameras but the camera check in / pick up system was great and there was no fuss (or hidden charges). The Vietnamese guards to take their job very seriously and you need to dress conservatively (including no sunglasses) - I even got told off for having my arms behind my back, apparently you need to have your arms by your side. Get there early though, we arrived by about 8am and moved through the queue fairly quickly, but when we exited the queue was easily double the length of when we started.

A Must See. You need to make sure you are here by 9am. Our guide had organised it all as after 9am many school groups arrive by bus and the queues get really long and it can take over 3 hours to get in. We were lined up for about 40 mins, it is a walk under a canvas in 2 lines until you get to the Mausoleum and then you enter and are not allowed to take any photos. you just walk in and around the coffin with him in it and straight out again. It is something you just have to see though as he is still though of as the most respected man in Vietnam.

With Respect. We waited in line to visit the Mausoleum, but it was worth waiting for. if you do visit it, remember to switch off your mobile phone and do not put your hands in your pockets as a mark of respect. Worth seeing.

A great disappointment. Nothing went right for our visit to this complex. The opening times were not well advertised and we happened to arrive just before the midday close. We had not been warned that women must have a covering of their shoulders in order to go into the mausoleum. The One Pillar Pagoda was being re-worked and therefore not accessible. Visible directions and explanations within the complex (at least in English) were non-existent.

Worth a visit. It seemed unfair to be in Vietnam and not visit Uncle Ho. There is no entrance ticket and one needs to be attired properly. Security lockers are available for big bags and cameras (no photo allowed inside the mausoleum). The queues generally are very long but it is impressive to see that they are so well coordinated and move quickly enough. Close to the mausoleum is the HCM museum which is informative and well maintained. Definitely worth a visit.
a vietnamise experience. the line it's impressive to see but it goes pretty fast, it's interesting to see all the vietnamise people going there, not that many tourist.

Ho Chi Minh. Really worth making time to visit the Mausoleum to experience for yourself how the Vietnamese revere their great hero. Its a throwback to the old Cold War days and I found it and interesting and exciting experience. Go early to avoid the queues and the heat. Its walking distance from here to other local sights...

Who wants to see Ho Chi Minh?. Very educational and a must visit place in Hanoi! You can walk around and learn many things about Ho Chi Minh's childhood until the era when he led Vietnam into independence. Overall this place is OK.

Must see when in Hanoi. This was really interesting to see. Being a tourist we entered via a side entrance and missed the big line. From walking through the gates we were in the Mausoleum within 10 minutes. The gardens were very beautiful also. Would recommend seeing this attraction.

A bit weird. Best Mausoleum i've ever been to (only 1), we walked straight through and didn't need to Q. Doesn't take very long and it's a bit weird to see. You can sense the amount of respect that the people of Vietnam have for there former leader.The immediate grounds of the Mausoleum are cool but Ho Chi Minh's residence is pretty dull

Surprised how easy the queueing system was. Was a rainy day when we visited, were lucky to be there when some VIP's visited and laid one of the large wreaths. The queuing system is very well organized, done with a military precision but works!

It was a pity. I won't share any photo this time cuz, many photos already posted. It was a pity, I can't go in, cuz it was the day off (no entry) for tourist (or for everybody ?). They said ''treatment-day''. There was some custodian wiped everything outside the mausoleum, like the mark of no entry, the pipes of the garden,,, the weather was windy, cold and drizzle too.
The landmark of Hanoi. Nothing to shout about. Just see it, been there, done it and take some pictures. Take picture of the guards if possible.

Long queues. Long long queues under a canopied walkway which offered no shade in temps of mid 40's. Not allowed to take water with you whilst waiting. Once inside the building you passed the great man in single file and was out again in 30seconds and it was all over.

History of a leader. This is a must do if you are in Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh is well preserved and looks like he is resting. The security is a high as expected. We were lucky enough to see the changing of the guards at the entrance which was interesting. Unfortunately you can't take any photos. Visit Ho Chi Minh's residence whilst you are there. The gardens are lovely and it gives you a real sense of a leader who liked to live in a very simple way.

It is a Must. Everyone that goes to Vietnam should go and see the body of Ho Chi Minh. Ok he does not do much but we all should show our respect to this honorable man. Pomp and ceremony astonding. Please be prepared and wear appropiate clothes..in other words cover up a little.

Interesting place but nothing much to see. If you love history, this place is great for you! But avoid weekends if you can because a lot of locals come here during weekend. Expect a loooong ques! If you are in the area, adding the Presidential Palace and the Ho Chih Minh Museum in your itinerary will justify your visit.

strange. well worth a visit to see the man himself, if not that then to enter the beautifully air conditioned chamber where he is kept! interesting to see the set up and queue up with hundreds of others for a very brief glimpse of Ho Chi and his marvellous beard. you also get to have a look around his old house and the gardens. recommend if you have the time
Take a walk by at night, it looks ok... By night they light up the building in red and it looks quite nice. Its nothing extreme, but if you are in the area... why not
What other country respects a leader like this. It so interesting and is breathtaking at night. Make sure to check opening times as they are not your normal 9 - 5.

Impressive building. Great architecture for a huge foreboding sombre place. Easily accessible and relatively fast moving crowd.. No hats or photos in tomb. Looking a bit waxy .... Free but should lead straight into the grounds next door. Worth spending some time at the base of the massive flagpole. Reminds me a lot of Beijings Square.

If the Mausoleum is closed, visit the nearby HCM Museum. Before you walk (it's a long one) or taxi from downtown hotels to the mausoleum, be sure to inquire about operating hours. It often is closed. But a short walk away is the HCM Museum, which contains a fascinating collection of memorabilia from Ho's lifetime, including his working in the U.S. Be sure to go early before the school kids arrive in force on their presumably mandatory excursion. As others have mentioned, both sites are located in a vehicle-free area, so consider bringing a lunch (no restaurants in the immediate area). For history buffs, the park site is where Ho declared independence from France after Japan's surrender in 1945.

Interesting. I had a great time at the Mausoleum. It's very interesting to see especially as the starting point to your trip if you are travelling around Vietnam as it gives you a good idea about what he means to the country. The staff are excellent and all is very well organised. Just make sure you do your research and arrive at the right time of day and year.

Impressive Setting. What is striking about the setting of the Museum and Mausoleum is the stark contrast between it and the rest of the city…here its off limits to any vehicles, quiet, green and serene.We did not take a tour of both attractions but to me it was worth the visit to this quiet and expansive area of Hanoi which it gives one the impression its almost a sacred place.

Well organised. As an important place of pilgrimage for Vietnamese people we expected this place to be busy especially as it was approaching HCMs birthday and we weren't disappointed. It was incredibly busy but the system in place to deal with the numbers worked. It is worth the visit in conjunction with the other spots nearby.

Don't leave hanoi without visiting this mausoleum. Be there by 9am. Dress code to enter this mausoleum is casual but smart. Shorts below knee and shirt with sleeve or for ladies bring a shawl to cover yourself. This mausoleum is only open to the public in the morning so set your alarm and be ready to see him then. Be warned there are always a large crowd of people visiting everyday.
True or not. This place is the best although its hard to believe it is actually it is his body on display I tend to think maybe its a wax figure but who really knows? Well worth the visit though

Goes very fast. My husband and I lined up for about 20 minutes to get in. Once inside you're only in the room for about a minute as the guards make you move along. Ho Chi Minh didn't look reL, we were sceptical as to whether it is really him. Worth a look though.

Viewing a piece of history. We saw saw Ho Chi Minh at the Mausoleum while visiting in April. It's definitely worth a visit if this is your cup of tea. He is a revered person in this country and the setting is impressive. Try to go when it is less crowded as the lines get long during peak periods.
Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. It was interesting and a experience to do lovely gardens it takes less than a hour to walk around but go early in the morning
A must place to visit. You have to go and see this monument, a tribute to Ho Chi Minh, the day were there it was the changing of the guard, very impressive soldiers in all white uniform.

long wait to see a corpse. Unless you have a strong interest in history and its leaders, don't bother to spend an hour in a queue to see a wizzened wax-looking man with a pathetic excuse for a beard. The money spent by the government on the extravagent edifice/mausoleum is truly disgusting.when so much needs to be done in infrastructure...but that's the way the commies did it back then. Statues before peoples' needs..

Definitely worth the time and effort to go. Our whole family agreed it was well worth going. Ho almost looks like he's glowing. Has to be the best example of embalming in the world! But beyond that, seeing the solemnity of the guards -- who are clearly chosen by height, since they are the only six-footers we've seen in Vietnam -- the enthusiasm of the crowd, and realizing the enduring symbolism of Uncle Ho, it was all a great part of our visit to Hanoi.
Impressive. Ho Chi Minh is very important for Vietnam. We visited the Mausoleum and were very impressed. Go very early in the morning to avoid long queues.

SPF Travel and Tours and Hanoi, Vietnam. SPF Travel and Tours helped us with our tour in Hanoi, Vietnam. They assisted us every step of the way from day 1 of our tour until our tour ends. We've really enjoyed our stay there because of the good itinerary plan provided for us. So far, the place is awesome and I'm looking forward to visit it again the next time around. :) #happytraveler #spftravelandtours

Morning hanoi with beautiful place.. There is a great place in the heart of city with security surrounding this site . visit in the moring from 08 am to 11.30 am it's most beautiful area in Hanoi, you can choose to walk from your hotel..... along the way to walk to could see many pack around..

Must See in Hanoi. The lines look intimidatingly long, but they actually move very quickly.The actually building of the museum is very impressive, a very commanding structure.You walk past the body of Ho Chi Minh in silence, the atmosphere in the room with his body is quite powerful.Make sure you go early as it isn't open all day and it's not something you want to miss.

Jennie and Elliot visit Ho Chi Min Mausoleum. A must see when you are in Hanoi the mausoleum sits in the centre of a huge square there are guards everywhere it is very solemn occasion viewing him in his coffin, the queues to enter the mausoleum can be very long and it is advised to go with a guide that has access to the fast lane. No cameras allowed and appropriate dress is required. It shuts down for maintenance in I think in September.

Long line, embalmed body. The people watching, the grounds, the very serious guards and the changing of the guard are probably more interesting than the 1 minute you spend walking by Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body, that looks like a wax replica. They take their Ho Chi Mihn very seriously in the North and if you want to understand the people there, you want to experience this.

Grand Resting Place. There is a great deal of security surrounding this site and one must be very careful as no photos can be taken inside. We didn't see many locals but rather many busloads of tourists that seem to make the required visit.Once you clear security, you walk into a rather grand marble building in which you must keep walking - no stopping. Inside the main room is the body of Ho Chi Minh under glass and again great security. We were told he only comes up from below in his case for a few hours per day the back down and that he is taken to Russia for restoration once a year. Only his head and hands are really visible. In saying this, the gardens and a small temple behind are very nice.

Historical - Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Surprised by the number of visitors from the long queue, but was speedy in getting the crowd moving. Although didn't managed to walked in as was late, heard from the guide it closed at noon.From the historical point where our guide shared with us, respect the leader late Ho Chi Minh.Very meaningful place to visit and you will learn and understand more about Vietnam from here.Worth the visit here.

Fascinating to see Ho Chi Minh lying in state. Never having seen an embalmed body before found this interesting as he looked as if asleep.Very solemn place - no talking ,laughing - you just had to file past the body in silence.Obviously highly revered for his influence in the Vietnamese war

Nice surroundings. I got a motorbike taxi there for 30,000 dong and was lucky that it was quiet (9:30am on a Tuesday). Is quite a walk to get to the entrance of the building (I think they are used to having long queue's) but all under cover. The white guards are the same idea as the guard's outside Buckingham Palace. It was very quick to get in and you only spend about 30 seconds actually lookinig at Ho Chi Minh himself as the guards shuffle you to move on. It was quite strange, I wasn't expecting to actually see him as himself, so clearly.

Visiting Ho Chi Minh. A long queue but this was a unique experience - to visit the mausoleum of a man so revered in Vietnam. You were watched the whole time to ensure you did not show any disrespect: no hats, no sun-glasses, no hands in pockets, single file only (no side by side), no talking, no pictures or video, etc. Well worth the hour or so.

Weird but awesome. It's not every day that you actually get to see the body of an historical figure and we were feeling a bit creepy about it. But I have to say it was absolutely worth it. The reverence, the respect, the whole sense of historical meaning of this place takes the creepiness away and you get to see to point of it all. The whole visit gets you thinking about Ho Chi and wanting to learn more about him and the manner they conduct the visit is quite unique. Don't think twice, go pay your respects to the old man!

Well worth a visit if you are interested in Vietnamese History. I was surprised how short the foreigners queue was to get in. Once through airport type security- no large bags or cameras allowed in the Mausoleum - it was quite a walk to the entrance to the building. Once past the white uniformed guard, the casket containing the body of Ho Chi Minh was very respectfully and tastefully displayed.
Not great, not terrible. Seeing the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh was interesting. Not much to see but interesting nonetheless.
Definitely go!. We queued for a few minutes, it was quick and very organised, free and incredibly poignant. Just make sure you are reasonably covered up, no shoulders and knees!

one of the most holy place in Vietnam.. i think. I didn't dare to go through the huge line to enter this massive building but also just walking outside of it gives you the idea of how this leader was LOVED by his country !! People comes from all over the country just to pay homage !! Nice place to see by night walking around! Is probably one of the safest place in Hanoi and guards are everywhere!
reverent monument. the mausoleum and surrounding grounds are beautifully maintained and a reverent monument to a hero of Viet Nam.

Interesting sight, long queue but waiting time was ok. We visited this mausoleum on Saturday. Free entrance fee. The queue was very long, already started outside of the gate. A lot of local people are visiting.But then the queue always moved forward, the waiting time until we came in into the mausoleum was about 20 minutes.The mausoleum was pretty impressive. The guards made sure that the queue is moving, and we had about 1 minute to see the preserved ho chi minh body.Interesting experience.

Well worth a visit. This site is well worth a visit. The queue moved quickly, but was also a chance for us to ask questions of our guide (from Hanoikids - very helpful) and get a good understanding of the site overall. Yes, the guards do ask people to maintain a respectful attitude and behaviour, which is fair enough as Uncle Ho is the national hero.Beautiful grounds and buildings of significance.

A little eerie. One of the strangest sights to see in Hanoi. We lined up with lots of other locals and tourists for around 45 mins. The line is kept moving fairly quickly though. From walking through the main gates the line snakes around the grounds for quite some distance and a two different stops you hand over "knives" and any drinks, then large camera equipment. Once you make it to the actual mausoleum everyone files in, around and out in about 3 mins. Enough time to view a deceased embalmed Ho Chi Minh. It is all a little macabre, but after the viewing the grounds and gardens are well worth a stroll through. This place gets fairly packed out. The mausoleum has only a short opening time, so plan well in advance or miss out!

A bit anti-climactic. The line-up was around the block, but it kept moving consistently. The security didn't allow any water bottles/juice bottles, etc. We had to toss EVERYTHING before we were allowed to continue through the line. We also had to check some items with security. After a while, you go through another security scan... Seemed a bit excessive. When you get there, it is a small, sombre room with Ho Chi Minh encased in the centre. The line keeps moving through, so no lingering.

An unforgettable experience. We loved the pomp and ceremony and also the way we lined up with so many ordinary Vietnamese and their children coming to pay their respects. The founding father looms large here.
Camera is not allowed. The rules around here is very strict and one has to always maintain a respectful attitude while waiting in line and might be reprimanded by the officials guarding the place.

Glad we went. Never again.. As a History teacher, this was a fascinating and interesting experience. Long, hot queues and guards keen to demonstrate their respect for 'Uncle Ho' by telling tourists off. Our son did tell his friend that we'd queued for so long that by the time we got there... he was dead.

Respect to Ho Chi Minh. An amazing opportunity to see the leader who lives on, present day Vietnam testament to Ho Chi Minh's dedication to his country. The sight of the preserved leader is moving, and one that should not be missed during your visit to Hanoi. A very special experience.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is impressive. Ho Chi Minh is probably one of the most beloved world leaders. The Maousoleum produces a spiritual feeling of respect; it is sacred.

One of Hanoi symbols.... I did visit mausoleum on Sunday early morning while it was heavily raining. Entrance is free of charge - you can buy umbrella at storage room for incredibly good price of 50.000 VND (approximately USD 2.50) and staff helped us to overpass the queue avoiding to wait in the rain. Visiting mausoleum keep on mind that you have to behave with respect - no photos are allowed, you can't stop - just keep walking in a queue around Ho Chi Minh - and your arms have to be all the time along your body - no crossing them or so - otherwise militars will take immediately care of you. When you exit mausoleum you will follow the crowd and get to Ho Chi Minh residence and garden. As a foreigner you have to pay entrance fee - meanwhile all locals are passing freely around. I did not understand what am I obliged to do there when I was stopped by militar - and when I asked he was not polite at all - rather screem at me pointing I have to pay (and it really took me a while to understand why I have to pay). However it's worth to visit this site.

Very well organised, queue moves quickly. We went on the weekend of Reunification/Liberation Day, so the queue was incredibly long, but it moved very quickly and was very well organised. Some locals were (of course) blatantly pushing in but the guards very quickly put a stop to it. The site is well set out, the building very impressive, and it was a very interesting experience to visit. Don't wear shorts on or above the knee or you'll be forced to buy a US$5 scarf to cover them up. Cameras are taken off you and you collect upon exiting the building.

a moving experience - a must-see. I arrived at 7.55 a.m., the visit starts at 8 a.m., I was the 10th person in line, the line moves very fast and people are quiet and respectful. After one enters and walks up a few steps, one sees the glass casket of Ho Chi Minh lying in state, the line moves fast and quietly around the casket , at a certain distance, but one can view the face of Ho chi Minh well, from the left, the front, the right, and then the tour takes one down some steps and out. It all goes very fast. I loved the visit, because one can observe the people of Vietnam who come to pay Ho Chi Minh respect. Soldiers in white uniforms stand guard and help elderly people up the steps. Even if one comes later, the line moves fast. During opening hours of the mausoleum from 8 to 11 a.m. every day, one cannot go to the front and take pictures. After the mausoleum one can visit the home of Ho chi Minh and admire the French governor's palace in a beautiful park.

Embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh... very moving. Rare sight of embalmed body of Hoc Chi Minh, inside the dimly lit room his face and hands are the focus with a spotlight shining towards them. This experience was surprisingly moving, we visited on a light showery Wednesday, a covered walkway saw queues of 2 abreast move quickly thru the complex. In Uncle Ho's Will he wished to be cremated with his ashes to be scattered over North, Center and South of Vietnam. Unbelievable the amount of Vietnamese paying their respects to their once leader. Pay attention to open hours 8-11am closed Monday & Fridays, 2 months of each year it is closed due to corpse going to Russia for maintenance.

Mausoleum. The mausoleum was built by the Russians, it's plain and stark on the outside and you have to line up to get in, although the line moves quite quickly. Ho Chi Minh is lying in state under spotlights some distance from the path you use to walk around.
pretty good. Its a must visit thing, as it is a good place, to start with the history of Vietnam.Nice, quite and peaceful
amazing. very long queue but was ok to wait. Shorts (not too short though) and t-shirt are fine and cameras can be taken although no photos allowed inside the mausoleum

strangely enjoyable. Don't be put off by the long queue when you arrive - it moves very quickly. I wasn't that excited about visiting but when you do get to see "Uncle Ho" it is quite an experience. Difficult to describe really but well worth the visit when in Hanoi.

A long queue and a long wait!. We went on 16th march as part of a tour we were on. There were thousands of people waiting to see Ho Chi Minh, we queued for 1 and a half hours. Must admit when we got to see him it was quite humbling, especially to see all the schoolchildren waiting to see him. A lot of these children hadn't seen western people and were so excited to see us and have their photos taken with us. It was worth the wait!regardsBaslady
A different experience. Impressive building and military guards but not really much to see for a longish wait. The people-watching during the queuing was fascinating, however.
History Stop. Stop here for a history perspective (also at the HCM musuem within the complex). Might be better with a guide.
Just astonishing!. It was fascinating and bizarre to see Ho Chi Minh still lying in state and under guard. The building was of necessity very cold so it is important to be prepared for that.

Worth visiting! Don't miss it!. This was a unique experience and would strongly recommend you go! How often do you get to see someone who's embalmed! I checked, only 4 people have been embalmed! So it really is a unique experience. its also worth going to see the grounds afterwards. You can see Uncle's Ho's house, cars, and lake. We also went to the museum. I can honestly say I came out with no new knowledge on Uncle Ho, so it wasn't the most educational museum, but the displays were very artistic and nice. I think its worth to do a quick 30 min walk around.

Another mausoleum. Not wishing to be disrespectful, but this mausoleum was on par with the others we have visited - ie. The Lenin Mausoleum in Moscow and the Mao Mausoleum in Beijing. All are similar. The building set in a large open square, guarded by lots of soldiers, very tight security, long queues of the local population and tourists - all to see a dead person behind glass. To be frank, it was more interesting watching the people in the queue, and the backhanders being paid to the guards to let people jump the queue in the square - mostly tour operators to let their tour group through quickly so as to not disrupt the tour's schedule.

Interesting place. I have spent a whole morning on the grounds of ho chi minh site. The terrain is extremely spacious.The series was probably about 2km long, but it went quickly forward - so do not be put off! Then you can visit uncle ho's house . I definitely an experience that will be remembered.

Interesting quick visit. We went there on a Tuesday morning. We arrived early at 9 am and didn't queue. It was very quick, maybe 45 seconds to walk around. Not worth queuing for if it is busy when you arrive. Spooky setting, somber guards and a peaceful looking Ho. An interesting experience.

My morbid curiosity won!. Seeing 'uncle Ho' in his embalmed state is a big thing for the Vietnamese. To us, he was a sweet, old, dead guy behind glass. The only emotion i felt was pity, that he was being gawped at by constant streams of people, despite wanting to be cremated and his ashes scattered to the North, Central and South of his beloved Vietnam.
A must visit. I would highly recommend visiting the mausoleum but do take note of it's restricted visitation hours.
Mausoleum. Closed on Mondays and at lunchtimes very difficult to fit this in on our three days in Hanoi the Vietnamese people dont seem to grasp the concept of museums and other artefacts.
a must. I mean it is a must. the queues maybe long but it only takes 5 minutes inside to see the ghostly pale body lie in state.
Wear comfy shoes. We queued for 1 1/2 hours in the heat to take 1 1/2 minutes to file past Ho Chi Minh! After ward's we walked to see his residence awhich is next door, that was interesting.

This is about process not a result. There is no doubting Ho Chi Minh's crucial role in the formation of hte Vietnam we see today.When I read that Ho wanted to be cremated, I was a little non-plussed about what motivated the authorities to 'do a Lenin' on Uncle Ho. I don't know about you but gazing no matter how reverentially on the preserved remains of a human being does absolutely nothing for me.The last time I was here, his remains had been sent to Moscow for a periodic service so it wasn't open. Neither is it open on Fridays or between 11.30 and 1.30 pm each day.On arrival and alighting from our bus we were fed into a gigantic conga line which progressed about 500m at a steady rate from the back of the precinct around the side and along the big square in front of the mausoleum. There are occasional pauses while they do a shift change of the guards.Inside the tomb all is dimmed light and hushed tone with the white uniform guards ushering folks though, ensuring people remove hats and don't talk; one moves by the glass walled enclosure and out the other side.I couldn't help feeling that a Madam Tussaud effigy in a standing pose delivering the oratory that caused the site to be selected, would be a more compelling mark of respect.But that's only my opinion.The adjacent park and 'house on stilts' was also jam packed meaning the conga line continued.I had been before when it was quieter and it was much more enjoyable.
Mausoleum. Most interesting. Please wear decent clothing (no shorts, halter top). Allocate a full half day as there are other important sights nearby

Go appropriately dressed. One of our party was wearing shorts and not allowed to enter so the other party members went ahead. There was no dress code for the presidential palace but the catch 22 was that you could not bypass the mausoleum to get to the palace despite being told we could. Disappointing and much time wasted trying to deal with the bureaucracy.

An important Hanoi experience.. This gives you a sense of the government of Vietnam and reminds you that this is a communist country despite the openness of parts of the economic structure of Vietnam. There is a great deal of security and can have long lines but they move pretty quickly. It is sort of eerie and the gruffness of the guards reminds you of the culture that the Vietnamese live in. Be forewarned, you cannot take a camera into the mausoleum and they make you check it, so don't take one with you if you aren't with a guide who can hold it for you. They do allow phones but you cannot take pictures or even have it out of your bag. You can take pictures outside. Also women's shoulders must be covered and your shorts need to be to your knees or they will not let you in. They do sell scarves at the entrance that you can wrap around yourself. It is an important VIetnam site as the people( especially in the north) loved Ho Chi Minh. Worth a trip

When in Hanoi you have got to see Ho Chi Minh. So very pleased that we went to the mausoleum. We got there at 9.30am, yes there were hordes of people, mostly Vietnamese, and school children galore but there was absolutely no waiting except for the 10 seconds at the area where you leave your bag. We were impressed with the constant and steady movement of people, no pushing shoving or queue jumping. The system works well and everyone seems to know what to do. There is no question of the high regard and respect for Ho Chi Minh by the Vietnamese people. The only thing that troubles me is that Ho Chi Minh requested that his body be cremated but against his wishes his body is kept on display for the world to see. I find this somewhat disrespectful.
Interesting to see. Hi Chi Min is a revered figure in Vietnam so it is part of their culture and there for should be on your list of things to do

Weird but worthwhile . Even though the line goes for ages it's a moving line, I never had to stop and wait like a normal queue you just walk in a line through the gardens until you're out the front. It's taken very seriously and quite interesting to watch the people around you, the viewing itself takes 30 seconds and it's done, but it's a worthwhile 30 seconds. Remember to check the times as it closes over lunch and is closed Mondays, also dress code and rules apply so best to be aware of what you're in for ( ie covered shoulders and to the knee, no cameras, hats, sunglasses, etc). I liked the seriousness and formality of the viewing I found the whole experience fascinating.

Must see. The mausoleum has limited hours that it is open so you should plan on being there when it opens. There are other things to see within the complex too. The mausoleum was very cool. You walk through in a long line and you can't linger, but it is worth it. You will have to check backpacks before you go in. They let us take our cell phones (although no photos are permitted in the mausoleum).

Ho Chi Minh. Make sure you get there early as queues can be very long.Also be aware of opening times as the Mausoleum closes at 11am.Photographs are not allowed inside or of the permanent guards stationed outside.

Long lines and very strict. The experience was interesting but you felt as if Vietnam was still under strict communist orders... everywhere, people were being herded and cops were checking to keep queues straight! Was a bit unnerving when you had a hyperactive toddler along. Otherwise, well maintained gardens and a good glimpse into what strict socialist orders could have been like!

Check he is there before you go. Our lonely planet guide indicated that Ho Chi Minh would still be available. However, we got there early, appropriately attired (long pants etc), only to find that he had gone back to Russia for restoration. Oh and don't walk on the grass unless you want to be yelled at by guards.

You have to go but....... Four adults and four kids aged 11 and 15 half day tour of Ho Chi Minhs Mausoleum, a few Pagodas Uncle Ho's house and cars. After coming from Saigon where the people seemed really carefree Hanoi felt like the people were a bit more contained. The mausoleum was over the top in strictness. It was very regimented to the point of two lines, arms unfolded, sunglasses off and be quiet. The very long line moved quickly. We got to the tomb and not having done my tripadvisor homework didn't realise that Uncle Ho is in a glass cabinet........probably should have warned the kids! Oh well...they coped. It is amazing how the dead bloke has such an influence on the country and is evident every day. It is worth having a look to experience the dedication and respect the Vietnamese have for him. As for his cars (donated to him by the Russians) and house I could take or leave it.

Huge place. We do not go into it but outside the Mausoleum is a huge place called Bai Dinh Square. The place is very strict in security, some area was strictly protected and not allowed to go in or step inside. The changing guard is just very normal with only 2 guard walking from another side of the building and changing shift in front of the entrance door. Nothing special.

Don't go on Friday. We were there on a Friday, and the Mausoleum was closed, so we didn't see the interior. There were quite a few people around, but our guide told us that it would be mobbed on any other day. It's a huge somber edifice, not particularly appealing, but very important to the Vietnamese people. Even though the mausoleum was closed, we were able to visit Ho Chi Minh's houses and see the one stilt pagoda. The gardens behind the museum are very beautiful as well.

Worth it.. It's hard to understand why every day people would line up for 2 hours to walk thru a Mausoleum. We stood there with mostly school kids. We watched honour guards do their thing. Then less than 60 seconds inside the Mausoleum... and it's over. yet it was powerful because Bac Ho... (Uncle Ho) lead the Vietnamese out of french domination. If it means that much to them... then it has to mean something to all of us who take for granted our daily freedoms.Do the visit... the rest of the experience outside the Mausoleum helps put the picture together.

Worth the queuing for about 30 seconds of viewing.. You can see the reverence with which the Vietnamese people hold Ho Chi Minh when visiting the Mausoleum. Even though you have to join a long queue, it moves steadily and is undercover. There are soldiers guarding the mausoleum both inside and out. Our guide kept our camera for us as you can't take water or cameras with you and you need to be dressed with your knees and shoulders covered. When you get close to getting inside the guides are making sure people are quiet and respectful. Inside we were kept moving but walked around 3 sides of Ho Chi Minh on the walkway. As part of the whole Ho Chi Minh area of Hanoi he is a must see.

Go see it if you get the time . This is such a strange experience but something you should do if you get the time as Ho Chi Minh was the cause behind a pivotal change in Vietnamese history. It is free to enter although try and get there early to avoid long lines however no matter when you go, you certainly won't be alone. You and your bags must go through an X-ray machine at the start (much like at an airport) and all liquids incl. water must be disposed of. All professional cameras and equipment have to be left behind also and collected later whilst hand held cameras and cellphones can be kept on your person but cannot be used once inside the mausoleum. There are guards everywhere who will tell you off for talking and they will request that you remove sunglasses, hats etc. when going inside. Once inside, you walk around the glass case housing Ho Chi Minh but you are unable to stop, you must keep moving. The line is continuous and your turn within the mausoleum will be over within a couple of minutes.

The staff love messing westerners about.. You have to queue, you cannot take a camera, you cannot take a photo, you cannot talk, you can only get in at certain times. Sorry I went, waste of time. Just go bury the guy.

A must see. I was in Moscow years ago and visited Lenin. This of course is based on the Russian mausoleum and it is well worth a visit. Ho Chi Minh continues to be a revered figure as the father of modern Vietnam. This is a stately area and you should be dressed appropriately to gain admission. The guards move you along and the total visit is less than one hour.

Unlucky. The structure itself, along with the 1 pillar pagoda, is a nice place to see. I was unlucky because every time I tried to go inside, it was closed to the public. It was just bad luck on my part and nothing wrong with the place itself (closed on Mondays, and Wednesday was a national holiday).
great. very interesting to know that they still keep their first president or the most famous one. i did come inside and take a look at him. you should come once.

Put on your best serious looking face. This was such a strange experience and a must do when in Hanoi. Best advice is to get there soon after it opens at 8am. It is located a 2km away from the main tourist centre of Hanoi in a spacious area devoid of other attractions, just a few embassies.You cant take anything inside with you, such as bags or cameras. You really have to watch your behaviour and take it all seriously. Guards are watching you all the time. No smiling, strictly no talking as you file past his body in a glass case. Hands must be down by your side, not in pockets - no pointing. It is all so strictly controlled, you almost feel like holding your breath until you get out the other side.
Ho Chi Minh, Unesco Celebrity. Ho Chi Minh was read the Declaration of Independence, the founding of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam in 1945. Recognized by UNESCO as cultural figures.

A must. You cannot visit Hanoi without a trip to the mausoleum it was worth the trip make sure you wear lose cotton clothes because it can get very hot in the queue and you cannot carry water past a certain point.
Line moved quick. Was good to see his body! The directions were not very clear for English only speaking tourists. The line moved very quick.
Don't be put off by the crowds. Yes, you do have to queue and the restrictions are fussy but this is a special place, well worthy of a visit.

So Its okay.. Went as its a big thing to do in Hanoi. I had read about Ho Chi Minh before and his desire to be cremated so I felt a little sad about the situation as his wishes were not granted.The queue was huge and spilled out onto the streets. Some Vietnamese people just tried to cut in front of us on a few occasions and we had to be assertive in order to prevent this. You walk for ages through strict security and eventually get to the mausoleum with guard every few steps and get to walk around Ho's body. I found it a bit weird but he looks great for someone who has been dead for 45 years. He just looks asleep. You walk around, look at him and leave.Glad I went but wouldn't have gone if it wasn't free.

Very surreal!!. We visited the Mausoleum on a friday when it was shut which was really interesting walking around the grounds and seeign the guards in training on the days it is shut.We came back on the saturday to go in and the line was MASSIVE however it moved very quickly almost a constant flow.It was rather intimidating and a little scary even but absolutely amazing to see Ho Chi Minh.This is a must do would definitely recommend it.

Great Destination. We visited Hanoi 1 month ago is a great destination. During that time we visited Hochiminh mosuleum intelligence is the soul of this city, very clean, spacious, quiet, demure and amazing scenery. you can visit the next location such as one-pillar pagoda, Ho Chi Minh Museum, house of Uncle Ho. Definitely, we'll be back Hanoi in the next trip.You can visit Hochiminh Mosuleum everyday morning except 2nd and 6th. I recommend avoiding weekends because there are so many Vietnam, you will have to queue.

Interesting. Closed on Monday and Fridays. Had to queue for around an hour, some people were queuing for much longer. Very strict security around the area, no cameras. Bags had to go through scanners etc. Eerie place, Ive never seen a dead body, but he looked good!! All very regimental but very well organised.

You have to see it. You can only view this building and it is a little intimidating with all the guards protecting it. However you cannot go to Hanoi and not see it. This is part of the Ho Chi Minh complex so there are other things to see aswell.

Don't go on Monday and Friday. Sad cause I went there on Friday, so I can't go inside the mausoleum. Just take picture in front of the building. Outside building and surrounding are beautiful and well maintained.

Great. Lovely to see the mausoleum. The grounds around it was very well maintained. Trees and flowers and it overlooked the French part of the city. From their we walked to the Ba Dinh square and saw the one-piller pagoda.

impressed!!. I really impressed by the way they treat Ho Chi Minh. Vietnamese call him as "uncle Ho", even they learn philosophy of him in school. Its open 8am in the morning, try to come early so you don't need to queue, you just walk pass the body, no photo or stop allowed. Close on Monday and Friday. The body well preserved, and guarded 24 hours. The mausoleum built with help from Russian government and very similar to Lenin's.

went but totally not my thing.... Went because it was part of our tour.As we visited early morning the que was not long thank goodness because it was gruesome.The building is severe solid cold and strongly sends the "Party" message, Felt sorry for the poor man as its going against his wishes as he left instructions to be cremated and for his ashes to be scattered .Dont think he would approve! A spectical for the Vietnamese

As a Viet Nam vet feels weird to visit this site. Hugh building bigger than Lincoln Memorial. Heavy security. Very solomn. Told to take hands out of my pockets. I was actually more interested in seeing his very simple home and old cars. It was worth it.

Fascinating. Be aware you need to have your shoulders and knees covered to enter here. No cameras or hats or sunglasses allowed in the Mausoleum. There is a place you can leave them. Great place to visit and put on the list of must do's. Plenty to see in the grounds as well as the Mausoleum

Interesting!. Interesting to see how important this place is to the Vietnamese people. The Mausoleum is only open between the hours of 8-11am on Tuesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays & Sundays. You are also unable to take water into the mausoleum as they will take it away from you on entry. It is free to enter. It was a great thing to experience but other then there is not a lot to say as you are going to look at a dead body.

Worth seeing if you can skip the lines. Came as part of a tour, and was lucky enough to be there on a miserable day in December in the morning. As such there was little to no line and got in with no trouble.I'd seen the Mao Mausoleum in Beijing, and was interested in seeing how this one compared. Its a much better memorial, and feels far more respectful to Ho Chi Minh himself. Not sure I would have come if there had been a substantial line, but am glad I saw it regardless.

What can you say. I'm sure that this is an interstitial g site but I'm unsure why I made the trip. You line up for some time....it is all very officious... And then you are rushed through to see a wax looking leader who,passed away many years ago. I cannot think that this is the last thing he would have wanted having read about him. I'm also sure if tourists gave it a wide birth this great man could at last relax!!

ho chi minh mausoleum. unable to go inside, as was closed when we were there (monday AM). pay attention to hours open to time your visit right. went to ho chi minh area as part of half day city tour; nice to have a guide. if you are going to go inside, would recommend getting there early; our guide told us that the lines can be a kilometer long to get in!

Very good, interesting. This is a very interesting place to visit, not just to visit the mausoleum but to experience the culture that surrounds such a practice. remember not to wear a hat, or take it off in line - its a little unnerving being told off by an armed guard!

Worth a visit just to see how important this is to the Vietnamese. We queued for an hour to spend 30-60 seconds walking past Ho Chi Minh, but it was worth it to see how important he is to the country. We went on a weekend and there were lots if school grouped so maybe go during the week!

Interesting Piece of Vietnam History. The Mausoleum of Ho Chi Mihn is an interesting bit of local history. Like Lenin, he is preserved in a glass box, with thousands of people respectfully filing by. The place is well organized, and easy to navigate. Worth seeing if you are in the area.

A Magnificent Structure Housign the Remains of Vietnam's Hero. The structure housing the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh is huge and befitting the memory of a man who is remembered as a hero to his people.

Ho deserves better!. As part of the tour we had to 'must see 'an embalmed body!Look I found it more or less Communist propaganda to the fullest,instead of respecting his last wishes to be cremated and his ashes scattered he found himself on display!I am sure this is the last thing he would have wanted.The queue from various directions long, but seem to move along just fine, under the direction of white uniformed what looked like Ice Cream vendors!what amazes me the strong appearance of school children some of them just toddlers, not sure what to think of that.I would give this site a miss and move on directly to his former official residence, it shows that he was a man that appreciated simple things without showing off, this in contradiction to his counter part in the South.

Avoid the queues. We planned to go to this Hanoi landmark, however advice to other travellers: avoid the weekend. But it's closed Friday and Monday, so there's not a whole lot of options. We went on Sunday, when at 8:30am, we would have had to queue for close to half a day. The queue was largely Vietnamese, who travel far and wide to visit. So, we were torn between the fact is a draw card for locals, but when we're only in Town for a few days, it didn't seem justifiable to wait that long. So, we settled for the grounds and home in the afternoon after the mausoleum was closed. PS spoiler alert: our guide said it's speculated that the body is a replica of Ho Chi Minh!

A must for any political enthusiast. Arrived at 9 and queued for about 1 hr in a long procession of Vietnamese tourists. Definitely worth it. Stoic soldiers in sparkling white uniforms, with heavy backdrop of propaganda music and awe-inspiring geometric architecture.

Worth a look. Whilst I didn't go inside, the queues can be up to 2 hours long, the outside is an impressive piece of architecture and the square outside an interesting place to observe visitors and locals alike.

Long Wait. The Vietnamese endow great honor on Ho Chi Minh. It showed in the long lines waiting to enter the mausoleum. Adults, cadets and schoolchildren in buses and buses, kept coming. The parking area was jammed with all kinds of vehicles. When we arrived on a Sunday, the lines were long, it was raining and cold. The serious and unfriendly faces of the guards didn't melt the chill of the day. But the compound was vast and beautiful. The structure was awaresome. We got to also visit Ho Chi Minh Museum which was next door to the mausoleum. We liked the museum better than the mausoleum. Word of advice - do not visit on a Sunday and come early, very early. If you can't stand long lines - give the mausoleum a miss but it is easier to visit the museum and no long lines.

Nothing like a lotus flower!. The architects of the rather grim, grey 1970's mausoleum say it represents a lotus flower though it bears no resemblance that any of us could see! The queue to go inside was about mile long at 9.30 am so we visited the Temple of Literature and returned just before midday and waited for only ten minutes or so. The embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is displayed in a rather chilly, sombre 'room' where everyone files past without stopping. Go later in the day when the queue subsides as the actual experience is only two or three minutes.

Interesting.... Overcast and a misty, it was structure. Unfortunately, we arrived on a Monday, so we were unable to tour the interior. Instead, we walked through the compound and still enjoyed the experience.A must if in Hanoi.

Not for me. I honour uncle Ho greatly but the production line that is the tour is a bit hollow for me. It is like a wax works figure but the great man deserves to be honoured. Some very badly behaved viet sand Chinese sometimes that get told off by the guards. For god sake turn the bloody phones off and show some respect! Don't go in shorts either the same for pagodas and temples.

A little macabre and creepy. It was actually against Uncle Ho's wishes to be put into a mausoleum for public viewing (I believe he wanted to be cremated), so I'm not sure how he'd feel about an endless procession of people coming to see him. The mausoleum itself is respectful and is run with military precision. After seeing Ho Chi Minh himself you'll also get to walk around the old presidential palace, his modest house of stilts and see a collection of his old cars. If I had to sum it up I'd have to say its a weird mix between an army parade ground and Disney land! Not sure how Uncle Ho would feel about Pepsi being the refreshment option of choice for example. Worth seeing if you have the time but feels too contrived.NB If you're a woman, make sure you cover up your shoulders and to below your knees otherwise you'll have to buy a scarf for 70,000 dong before they'll let you in.

Weirdest thing I've ever done. Took us ages to find the entrance. Had to queue up and be marched around the site until we got to the actual mausoleum. Walked through single file past the body, took about 10 seconds. No photos and have to take hats and sunglasses off. Strange but worth doing just for the experience!

A strange few hours. This is a lot of queueing for very little time. The queue is massive bit it moved reasonably quickly, it still took me an hour to get to security, and then there are more long queues. I read people were told to leave bags behind but I was allowed to take mine in after it was searched - or briefly looked in anyway. I did have to leave my large camera with officials to be picked up at the end, but this seems to be a strange rule as you cab keep your phone so photograph with that. The body itself looks like a madame toussauds wax work really. It's an odd way to spend the morning but it is free and how often do you get to see a body that's been dead for a few decades. If you have the time go and see it, if not it's hardly a great loss. (The accompanying museum and HCM's accommodation is not free although in the same area, 25,000 for each).
Something unique. It is really amazing how well preserve the body is. Expect a long line for this visit. No pictures allowed inside.
A quick march. Single file and quick march to see uncle Ho. An interesting experience. Reminded me of Mao Tse Tung. Same Same but different.

Majestic Mausoleum. The mausoleum shows great respect and dignity to a much loved ruler. We visited on a day when many school children were present and I was impressed at how even the youngest quietly filed past and paid their respects. The Mausoleum can and is usually very busy, so go early to avoid long queues and waiting time.

Reverence of a national icon. Ho is revered in Vietnam - this will become clear to you when you visit if you don't know it already. So it is understandable why Ho was embalmed and displayed in the mausoleum after his death. But....he didn't want to end up this way after he died. You decide - appropriate veneration or ghoulish display.TIP: You can't take photos - or even cameras and large items - in the mausoleum.

A Stalinist edifice with no heart or soul, but well worth a visit for the historical significance.. It is a shame that Ho Chi Minh wasn't cremated as was his wish, and given a more appropriate Vietnamese memorial. A very regimented visit, but fascinating nevertheless.Difficult to decide how to rate this one, see for yourself......

Historical highlights. Ho Chi Minh complex is one of interesting place should be visited while in Hanoi, it located right in the center of most beautiful old French quarter. Most people are curious of how is his mummy are being preserved inside the mausoleum and learn a bout Resistance war of Vietnam which mostly related to his biography

Queue for ages in the rain. One of the things you have to do in Hanoi.The long queue, watched over by severe looking guards gave the experience a real taste of Soviet Russia. The heavy rain just emphasised the atmosphere.

Well worth it. We were not sure what to expect and it turned out to be a slightly weird experience,but well worth it.This man was hugely important to the Vietnamese people and whilst visiting their lovely country you should try and see his mausoleum Whilst there were queues it is all very efficient and everybody keeps movingWe saw the changing of the guard and eventually uncle Ho himselfNot unexpectedly this was really the only part of Vietnam where we really saw any evidence of the communist/army's control .Not in any nasty way but everyone was very respectful,rightly so I suppose, but it did all seem a little contrived

Worth a visit. There are limited opening times for the various buildings within the complex so be sure to check carefully. By the time we had visited the body and the museum the house was closed.If you have seen Lenin it will be exactly the same.
