Streams of people snaking around the grounds with lots of guards in white uniforms and security check points.The museum is well displayed and offers a lot of information about Uncle Ho.The single pillar pagoda is an interesting construction and used for worship.There are good coffee shops at the complex also providing delicious smoothies.

Worth the hour & 15 minute wait in the rain to view. Ho Chi Minh looks amazing -- like he is just asleep. Pagodas on the grounds worth a visit. Went on a Saturday and tons of school children were here.

Uncle Ho. An interesting site, but a must see in Hanoi. Against his wishes, Ho Chi Minh lies in state in a very utilitarian gray building. The line can look daunting, but things move quickly and smoothly.

Regimentation!. It was like going back in time, very regimented. Soldier told my sister in law to "take your hands out of your pockets" We were not allowed to stop, we had to view on a walk by. Good history lesson.

He did not want this. Based on what I read and confirmed by our Tour Guide, he wanted to be cremated and have his ashes spread around parts (North and South) of Vietnam. How is he going to "rest in peace" when there are thousands of people staring at his dead body almost every day?I reckon his final wish should have been respected by the officials at the time. Is there anyone who would wish to have his body done like this when the end arrives?
odd tourist attraction. odd place to visit, but was part of our tour. Many rules about what you take and how you fold your arms eg don't!! Long queues and walk to see the body.
Learned enough to want to read more about Ho .... His determination for an independent Vietnam was sorely under estimated by the French and the United States...

remains of a popular leader. This was an interesting experience. its the mausoleum of the father of Vietnam and its interesting to find out about the life of the man who built this country into the resilient force that it is. Weekends can have long queues and you will only get a few minutes inside with a moving crowd but do it if have the time. No camera's allowed inside.

Be prepared...... the entrance closes at 10h20 am. I was also told that on a Saturday the crowed would be worse and to go early. In fact, the queue was much worse at 8h30 than it was at 10 (hardly any). But even if the queue seems endless as it was the case when I went, it goes really fast so don't be discouraged.Be prepared though:1) lareg bags (that included my normal day backpack) can be pulled out and asked to be left at the cloak room at the entrance. that means that to get it back you will have to walk all the way from the exit along the outside walls from the opposite side of the entrance ... and it closes at 10h30...2) large cameras are also taken away at a different point before reaching the mausoleum - getting it back is very easy though, straight after exiting the mausoleum itself.3) be decently covered, do not show to much skin, shoulders should be covered.it is possible to take pictures near the mausoleum (except when your camera has been taken away.....) but not inside.NOTE: if you want to see the mausoleum without getting inside (personally, I did not think it was worth the hassle but...), just ask a taxi to drop you on the opposite side of the entrance, near the laws. you can get close to the mausoleum without a ticket and take as many pics as you want.

Sunday visit to Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Don't let the long queues put you off , they move very quickly and every thing is very well organised. We visited on a Sunday so there were a lot Vietnamese visitors as well as tourists. Show respect at all times , if you enter the Mausoleum with your hands in your pockets one of the soldiers will tell you to get them out! No photographs, No phones. Its a very touching experience.

Definitely a must see, but do not expect anything memorable. During our stay in Hanoi we paid a visit to the Mausoleum as our guide suggested. It is definitely a must see attraction and it is worth the long queue to get access to it just for the historical meaning of implication of the figure of Bac Ho. However, inside the mausoleum there is a well done copy of Ho Chi Minh body (we have been told so), guarded by few white uniformed soldiers.

Glad we didn't miss this!. Not being a follower of Ho Chi Minh, I was mixed about seeing this. It was interesting to see such a life-like man lying in state. Also, interesting to know that he wanted to be cremated instead of enabled.
Simple Mausoleum. A tribute to a man who seem to have had the right idea but chose the wrong guides. The Mausoleum is simple but rich at the same time. The grounds are beautiful.

Go to Mausoleum + Museum. The museum was really great to learn more things. They have some cool things on display there, not just things he wrote. I'd also pay the 25,000 dong to go see his old house, etc. Very pretty stroll.
well worth the long line. The line up is long but moves at a good pace and was well worth the wait. It was very interesting and provides a glimpse into Vietnamese history

Did you really consider not seeing it?. The mausoleum itself is a very imposing structure in the center of a square that you can easily imagine being filled with military parades. The room where HCM lays is very eerie with a red glow and many white uniformed soldiers standing guard. There's no info or time to dilly dally around but it's free and how often do you get to see a the revolutionary leader of a country up close-dead or alive!Be sure to arrive by 9:30 to avoid any issues with lines or impromptu closings due to ceremonies or visits from local schools etc.

Ths was quite an exprience. I was on a city tour with a group of people from different nationalities and this was included in the tour. We had to queue to get in and they told us on weekends it is very busy. To be honest I was really surprised to se the body of Ho CHi Min laid there as if asleep just didn't expect this. He died in 1969 without seeing his country free .I was really fascinated at how they had preserved his body for so long and out tour guide explained it. We also visited his house and other places of interest.

Crowded. We just did a walk past this, but there were lots of people doing the walk through, which may have been more interesting, though Uncle Ho would be turning in his grave as this was not what he wanted. The outside is very imposing but it was interesting to watch the young guards march up and down in their lovely white uniforms.

Very worthwhile. It was interesting and an eye opener , not for everyone. Not sure if the late President really wanted to be viewed in such a manner, so as a foreigner I felt out of place and intrusive.

Real Ho Chi Minh. This place is awesome, if you relly like history you must visit it. Here you can see the body of Ho Chi Minh embalmed. Must visited until 11.30 am in the morning, is free of charge. No shorts and skirts to go inside.
Madame Tussauds. I think it is worth to see, but just like Lenin in Moscow, it is a wax-like body. My guide has said that that since her childhood she noticed that the body has "changed" few times.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum-Hanoi. On Feb. 3 we walked Ba Dinh square which was quite deserted during this TET-holiday. Only western tourists were seen.We had the opportunity to see from very close this mausoleum and adjoining Presidential Palace, with beatifull flowerbeds and honour guards at the entrance of the mausoleum .Next day we went back with a guide and there were long lines of mostly Vietnamese tourists who came to show their respects to their venerated leader.We had to go through an electronic screening device and no camera's, phones, bags, etc. are allowed.This mausoleum is modelled after Lenin's in Moscow and is made of granite and marble from the famous "Marble Mountain" in Danang.Inside it is quite chilly and Ho's glass coffin is guarded by 4 elite guards.You have no time to pause : just a little time to look at his khaki clothes and his white face frozen in a eternal sleep.

strange. OH MY GIDDY AUNT didn't think I would ever see mr ho chi min we had to be really reverend soldiers were guarding him and were very stern .in the que they were playing music some western stuff and videos fromwhen the war was on Americans like Dylan sayin it was bad times .
can not miss. very impressive place, with two different lines, the one to go inside is very long, many people there, more than one hour to go in, the outside line is great and very fast. up to you

Befitting the Man. To understand 'Father Ho's' impact on Vietnamese history and society you need to visit the Mausoleum 'Befitting the Man'. Crossing the sprawling immaculate grounds, it seems somewhat like approaching the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, DC. There is a sense of awe and reverence.The stature of the guards quickly gives you the sense that strict discipline is in force. Returning as a Veteran of the American War in Vietnam, there was a strange feeling of connection.A notable part of Vietnamese history not to be missed.

Very well guarded. The street is blocked off to vehicle traffic. It is very well guarded. Someone in our group got tired and squatted down, a guard was immediately there and told him to stand! Interesting!

Treated far too seriously!. I know it's a mausoleum but how they love to throw their weight around and treat everyone like school children. Of course we should respect the place, but it was overdone. Reading about Ho Chi Min's life, he was a simple guy and would have hated what they have done in his "so called honour". we were glad to get away and breath some fresh air, and enjoy the rest of the city. Not an enjoyable experience!
Intersting!. A great place! We didnt have too much time though. small advice: never take your phone inside! they are really strict about taking photos

Be sure to have on comforatable shoes as there is lots of walking. Our bus left us off almost a mile from the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It was hot, humid and quite a trek. But once we arrived at the parade ground the huge monument became clearand we were able to take great pictures. The Mausoleum is impressive.

Well worth a visit. A memorable place to visit - and it didn't disappoint. The actual mausoleum was very strict - walking in pairs with our arms at our sides. Ho Chi Minh was clearly visible. What was very moving was the reverence for him from guards and visitors. The house where he lived was awe-inspiring in its simplicity and the gardens lovely.
A must see!. Very interesting place, a must see while you're in Hanoi! Just around the corner is the One Pillar Pagoda with a beautiful story about fertility.

a very moving experience. I'm not the sort of person who likes to line up and follow hundreds of people being shuffled two by two around an attraction but there was something a little spiritual and reverent about this place. The anticipation of seeing Ho Chi Minh lay in state was quite overwhelming in itself but the whole complex has an air of calm, despite the serious military faces everywhere. After seeing HCM we wandered around the gardens and I have to say, even though it was very busy it gave out peaceful vibes. An absolute must - go and see the guy

Interesting. Whilst its brief - the walk past Ho Chi Minh, its an interesting experience and to see where he lived and walk around the grounds is nice and worth the walk. Be prepared to line up, but it moves pretty quickly.

It may just change your view. We would not normally visit a mausoleum but this one for 'Uncle Ho' is a must. Apart from a glimpse of the man who changed the history of a large chunk of the world, the pageantry and extreme reverence in which Ho is held means the visit can be appreciated from a number of different angles.Be prepared however to be told how to stand (in twos just like school days), be warned about any form of levity or comments and total silence. If you wont like this, well lets just say I wouldn't want to discuss any objections with the honour guards.It is an amazing spectacle which truly adds to an understanding about Vietnams history especially when tied in with a walk around Ho's house.

A "grisly" must see. Entrance is on Ngoc Ha round the corner from Le Hong Phong. Not open Mondays or Fridays. Visiting hours are limited - admission between 8:00 - 11:00. You leave your at bags the entrance building for security reasons. No cameras are allowed either - out of respect.Dress code - arms and legs to be covered and hats off - of course.Entrance is free. You form an orderly and sombre queue - well managed by the uniformed staff. You walk around 600m from the entrance to the mausoleum building. There is a changing of the guard ceremony that takes place regularly on the steps of the mausoleum building, which adds to the occasion. You then proceed up the stairs to the room where Ho Chi Minh lies in state. The whole visit took around 40 minutes, but the walk round the room took about 30 seconds. All is done in silence - very atmospheric and fittingly respectful. I have to confess that I perhaps was there out of morbid curiosity. Uncle Ho looks very peaceful, but a little bit like he might wake up at any moment.

its only open 8:00am to 11:00am. definatley worth a visit, but its only open 8-11am and also not the entrance is in the back of it, we went to the front and realized we had to walk about 6 blocks to the back of it to enter, also dont take your camera or cell phone as your not aloud to have it in therethe lines were really long but they moved really fast, also dont put your hands in your pocketsonce your get in you can see Ho Chi Minh in his glass case surrounded by guards, they preserved that body pretty goodbut the museum near this is a total waste of time, pay 25.000 dong to read about how awesome communism is, dont waste your time there

Imponent. Sober and imponent construction. Huge building. We had the chance of watching the changing of the guards. Its greatness represent the admiration and respect of the Vietnamese people towards this hero.

Very well present tribute to Ho Chi Minh. A very appropriate tribute to the late Vietnamese leader. Very sombre atmosphere but very well presented. As you walk in to view the body of Ho Chi Minh, you can feel the deep reverence for a great leader. Certainly worth the long queue which moves very fast.

Mummy!. It's not everyday you get to see a preserved body. I was completely uninformed about what we were about to see, and thoroughly shocked to see Ho Chi Minh, preserved and on display (apparently against his wishes). Definitely worth a stop if you are in Hanoi
Just Okay. Large, imposing, massive. It's not for sure an architectural masterpiece. Nice gardens and surroudingsHowever deserves a visit

Mixed information about hours - here is our info. After seeing mixed information here and elsewhere about opening hours, especially with respect to "new hours" that include afternoons we headed to the mausoleum this afternoon, as we are not morning people. What we found is that the hours had changed after all, but only for the museum, NOT the mausoleum. If you get there in the afternoon you can't see the preserved body, despite notices of changed hours. The museum is open in the afternoons (except Mondays and Fridays), so we went there - it was OK. Not really much to see, but once we were there we figured we might as well. Entrance fee 25k dong.
Get there early before 10.30am. I did not get to go inside as we arrived at 11 am and it was closed but you could walk around the grounds and watch the soldiers parade, Wish we had been a bit earlier

Main attraction in Hanoi. During my visit to Hanoi, I can't go inside of the Mausoleum but even just see it from outside, it s really worth for me. A lot of other attractions nearby. A great experience for me.

Impressive and informative. There are new hours for the mausoleum, from 1/9/2013 the hours are 8 am to 5pm Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Friday and Monday it is open 8 am and closes at noon. There appears to be two entrances one at hung vuong and one further around ..which converge at hung vuong. Get there early and beat the rush and see the guards set up for the day. For Vietnamese people Ho was a statesman, an astute politician and strategist, and founder of their liberty from colonialism. The mausoleum is interesting, although being on display is against his wishes. He was their statesman and on the same level as an american president or george washington. The gardens and his house area are lovely. He certainly didnt live the rich and corrupt life. We found the guards courteous and respectful. Several even advised us where things were located as it is not clearly signed. It is also interesting to see someone embalmed, like Lenin and Mao. It adds to the ones knowledge and understanding of Vietnamese history. Worth seeing.
One you've got to do. You can't go to Hanoi and not see the man himself, queue moves quickly & worth seeing his house as well. Better than expected!

Worthwhile experience. Definitely worth visiting when in Hanoi, to learn about Ho Chi Minh, and his influence on shaping Vietnam. It is interesting to observe the local Vietnamese worship him as they visit the Mausoleum. It is strictly buddhist, so make sure you wear long sleeves and pants when going. A great experience

Interesting. I wasn't allowed into the Mausoleum as I had an infant with me and the solemnity was not to be disturbed. My husband went in and found it interesting. No bags or backpacks are allowed and security is very tight. People entering the mausoleum must walk in two-by-two and no pictures are allowed inside. Outside there are many people and the mood is much lighter. Pictures can be taken out front and parliament is under construction just across the street. The whole estate is quite interesting and you should allow yourself up to 2 hours to see it all depending on the crowds and lines. Ho Chi Minh's former houses are displayed and the path ends at a Buddhist Temple and the One-Pillar Pagoda.

A truly memorable and bizarre experience. Get up early and get in line. No joking, no laughing and show respect for Uncle Ho who brought Vietnam together again and freed his countrymen from its colonial yoke. Visiting the preserved corpse of the man himself brings a mixed bag of emotion of reverence and revulsion as you are moved along as if on a conveyor belt past the man himself.
Difficult to review. Seeing the body was cool! But Ho Chi Minh wanted to be cremated and have his ashes buried in North, Central and South Vietnam. His wishes should be respected.

The most important tourist destination. It is a major shortcoming for your trip, if you come to Hanoi without visiting Mausoleum. President Ho Chi Minh is considered the father of Vietnam country, the pride of their biggest. This is one of the most important tourist destination and many tourists welcome to visit most of the capital Hanoi. When you come to visit here Please note that: queuing (because have lots of people in here), keep silent, don't taking pictures and don't stop on the road. You can also visit the One Pillar Pagoda and Ho Chi Minh Museum, home of the president at this site.

Majestic Palace vs Humble Abode. We went early on a misty morning and glad we did as we did not have to wait in line. The Mausoleum was a solum yet respectful place. You can feel the love the people had for this great leader. When we entered the palace grounds we were in awe as to the most beautiful building and to know that he did not want to live in such a grand place but a more humble abode. His quarters were very modest and sparse. The lake and the grounds were beautiful. It was our last morning in Hanoi but had to see it before we departed at boom. Wish we had a bit more time to go to the museum as well but saw the main highlights.

Go and See!. A must visit while in Hanoi - "Uncle Ho" is revered - you will better understand the pride and nationalism of Vietnam by spending the hour or so to honor the father of their unification. The Vietnamese are such gracious hosts ...they truely want you to enjoy their food, culture and understand their history - Ho Chi Mihn inspired them toward great sacrifice and without his leadership who knows?

Of historic interest - nothing to see.. We went because is an important spot for vietnamese people and all tour guide will push you in. Ho Chi Minh is the father of vietnamese people, win the war, introduced communism, etc. For a tourist, I see no point in watching a building of boring communist architecture with a dead body inside.

Probably the only place in Hanoi where.... you can feel the Party rule. The rest of the city is a throbbing vibrant Asian metropolis but here you are made to line up in two's and marched through the mausoleum. Definitely a surreal experience and a place not to be missed.

Unique experience. Really interesting experience. I think it pays to go early in the day to avoid queues. Dont take too many valuables with you as they make you check them in before you enter the mausoleum. No photography and you have to be very quiet and well behaved ;)!
Ho Chi Minh. It is not a visit to Vietnam if one has not visited the Mausoleum and passed by the preserved revered leader of this country until his death in 1969.

It has to be done. This is a very strange experience. We queued for a short while outside the building (partly because the changing of the guard was taking place). The changing of the guard is wonderful to watch. The reverence and precision of the slow-marching soldiers is really good. Once inside we all filed slowly and reverently past the mummified body of Ho - not as ghoulish as one may imagine. Beautifully done.

Very impressed by the whole experience. Respectful and solemn. Liked the respectful requirements and the smart soldiers. The gardens and houses were easy to walk around and attractive. Quite moving to see a mummified person
Ho Chi Minh. there is a real sense of honour and reverence about viewing Ho Chi Minh, security is very tight and there can be long queues

Mausoleum. we were lucky to see the 'changing of the guard'. whilst not the pagent of Buckingham Palace, impressive in the way that these soldiers are considered amongst the elite to have the honour to be guarding the nation's greatest hero. The mumified body of Ho is a little strange to behold, but we were pleased to have had the opportunity.

Regimented. We did not go into the tomb as there were large lines waiting and you seemed to be very regimented. I did not really want to see a embalmed body There were no photographs could be taken inside The outside was very different where Ho Chin Min had lived and the gardens lovely. it was amazing to see the lake area which he loved. The day was very cold when we were there but it was worth seeing. The square in front of the Mausoleum is like that of Red square in Moscow and surrounded with guards . You can not go up close to the building and it feels you are being watched.

Lengthy queues. We visited the Mausoleum, which is a greatly revered place to visit as it is the final resting place of Ho Chi Minh, the father of Vietnam. This great man lies in state and his body is sent to Russia every few years to be re-embalmed. This I found rather disturbing.

Must do. Nothing spectacular, but really a 'must-do' in Hanoi. It only opens a few hours in the morning, then closes for lunch before re-opening in the afternoon. Beware of the times.Line ups to get in. Security may require you to check your bags, so better just to leave big bags at home. Modest clothing is required so avoid shorts and tank tops.Set aside time to walk around the grounds.

Surreal but worth a visit. We were not sure what to expect from this very popular tourist attraction. However, we would recommend you go, even if it is just to wonder at the power Uncle Ho still has over the Vietnamese people. Despite wanting a simple cremation, Ho Chi Minh was put on display in a glass showcase. Entrance is free and best to get there early morning. Visitors have to go though rigorous security. No cameras of course. Single file is demanded en route to the mausoleum and once inside there is no talking, no hands in pockets or arms folded. Everyone slowly walks around the large glass casket which is guarded by white uniformed guards. There are in fact guards all over the place making sure visitors abide by the rules. After visitors leave the mausoleum, they are allowed to walk around the vast area outside and take photographs.

It's a long walk for a brief glimpse. It's a bit of a pilgrimage for many Vietnamese so there can be a lot of people there. We went fairly early so beat the main queue. Be prepared to hand your camera over for most of the walk/visit (but you have to carry the camera bag minus camera! Go figure!). There was a changing of the guard which was fun (think small scale not a London experience) and the Mausoleum itself was grimly fascinating - there are lots of guards and you need to be respectful - no shorts/short skirts, hats/glasses off, don't put your hands in your pockets etc.

Worth a look, but not that interesting. The mausoleum itself is not that interesting, much like Mao's in Beijing. There is a garden and his former residence behind the mausoleum, which is more interesting, but again 1 hour is enough to see both.
Ho Chi Minh. Apparently Ho Chi Minh wanted to be quietly cremated. It must surely be time to respect his wishes. Reminds me of Moscow etc

You will obey!. Being a significant figure in history a visit to the mausoleum is a must. You can't take bags or a camera inside and the whole operation is designed to keep you in order. The queues which can build to enormous proportions are guarded by soldiers and they do not hesitate to tell you to keep quiet even when a good distance away from the building. No hats, no talking, no hands in pockets. All of these are monitored. The line is kept moving at quite a pace through the mausoleum so don't expect to linger.

the resting place of Vietnam's greatest leader. This houses the preserved body of one of the greatest leaders of Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh. Never miss visiting this place; you will feel the love and devotion of Vietnamese people to their great, late leader.

You never know where your day will take you. Visited Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum while in Hanoi.It was a wet dismal day so the queues were not too bad.Quite high security and rules to obey.Lots of guards in smart white uniforms.Once inside we were ushered along fairly quickly.Quite a bizarre experience but certainly worth a visit.

Kind of a weird experience. I would recommend going here just because the experience is a little strange and because Ho Chi Minh is so important to the Vietnamese. Give yourself a little time to go here. While the viewing of the mausoleum takes only a few minutes, the lead up to it takes about 45 minutes depending on the volume of people.

Respect. When we arrived, there were massive queues, but we were actually through within 15 minutes. Extremely well organised by the military. I was given a non-verbal warning because I had my hands behind my back.

An Interesting Walking Tour. This is indeed an impressive place. The sheer size of this place is overwhelming. Here we could saw Ho Chi Minh's well preserved body and got to know there's only 6 or 7 past leaders in the world with the bodies preserved.We experienced how he choose to live his daily life humbly. Coming to understand his life story, we could understand why he is well respected by the people. You will get to see how he lived, worked, cars that he used, the house he choose to stay, etc. Within the compound is the One Pillar Pagoda. An interesting site. Overall, an interesting walking tour.
Closed on visiting day. When going on the city tour, we were not informed that the mausoleum was closed on Fridays so we could only look from the outside.

Huge Memorial. Located near the the HCM residence the mausoleum is convenient to visit. But be sure of the time as it was only open from 8AM-11AM and closed on various days. But if you have the opportunity I recommended going to see Vietnam's tribute to the founder of the modern state.
Big block of cement!. The founder of this great nation deserves something more attractive than this stark concert block. Also, to us,viewing a body that has been dead as long as he has is creepy.

Great visual representation of the arrogance of communism.. I think that this place is amazing. It is interesting to think that this whole complex was built just to house the body of their leader. The style is very much like what you would see in the Soviet Union. I think this is another great example of the waste of the leaders of the communist party. The fact that they raised Ho Chi Minh to the status of a god is very easy to imagine when you see this place. It still has signs that say that communism is the best and that the Vietnamese communist state will continue forever.

Flag raising. We attended the daily flag raising ceremony and enjoyed it. The ceremony takes place quite early, 6.30am, but is interesting to watch. We did not then visit the mausoleum which opens a bit later.
Paying respects to Bac Ho. Was a really impressive sight, coming from Australia we do not have anything like this. Plus it is free.

A Beautiful Tribute. Both the mausoleum and the grounds provide a touching tribute to North Viet Nam's national hero. The structure is impressive in its size and architectural grandeur; and the grounds are extensive. It was not open on either of the days I tried to get in, so try to figure out when it's actually open before you make your way over, but the Ho Chi Minh museum was open both days and was worth visiting twice! A must-see in Hanoi, especially if you love history.

. For me this place is quite far from Hoan Kiem Lake. We took taxi there and the taxi costs us 30,000 VND. We didn't enter the mausoleum and just took picture there because this place is opened from 8 to 11am .
Top Tip. The queues here were quite long so we didn't bother to go inside. However, it is well worth a trip here just to admire the size and impact of the Mausoleum from the outside.

Do visit. We were very moved by our experience here. This was our first place to visit in Hanoi, out of respect. My personal feelings, as a Veteran and history buff, were mixed, but I did have a lot of respect for him. (If only we Irish had someone with his tenacity and longevity in the same historical period). I consider a visit to his mausoleum a high point in my Vietnam travels. Also, definitely visit his museum.
Open?. Notice that this place only take visitors between 09 - 12 o´clock. We did´nt get there in time to see it.

Imposing Structure. The mausoleum is a huge structure and extremely well guarded. Visitors must pass through security very much like airport security to get in. Quite a long walk from the entrance to the mausoleum. No cameras allowed inside. Worth the visit.

Imposing - on the outside. I understand there can be very long queues and therefore a long wait for about 30 seconds walking past a glass coffin looking at Ho Chi Minhs corpse - but it looks like a waxwork. Would only go in if there was no queue.

I was surprised how much I enjoyed visiting here!. My family and I visited Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and Museum as part of out day tour with HanoiKids. I was a bit dubious at first, but we all really enjoyed the visit.I think this was influenced by the "kids" we were with, and people we met on the day. Hearing a teenage girl talk about Uncle Ho with the same admiration as she did for Katie Perry was hilarious, and kind of heartwarming. Highlight for me was meeting a group of very elderly NVA veterans, who upon learning I was from Australia, all wanted to shake my hand; it was very touching.The Mausoleum is cold, sterile and kind of earie. The grounds are magnificent, and seeing Uncle Ho's small home was interesting. The highlight was the museum though, very modern, well designed, with lots of simple but interesting displays.

A must in Hanoi. No matter what you think of the tradition of embalming national figures, you should make the effort to go through the mausoleum with the (on average) 10,000/day who do so. The mausoleum itself is impressive without being bombastic and Uncle Ho looks very natural.
Interesting. I felt that since his request was not to be popularised and because he was so humble that maybe this was against his wishes

Strange place, a hero to the Vietnamese. Queued up with the hundreds not sure what to expect, very regimented, no talking, queueing in line, very cold inside, we all came out thinking what was that all about

beautiful grounds. I visited as part of a group, and going through the Mausoleum felt rushed and controlled for a brief look at the resting Uncle Ho. I enjoyed more the beautiful grounds around it- it felt like a tropical garden, and the architecture of the buildings felt different than the rest of Hanoi so I liked the experience.

A large square and not much else. Went during the Tet festival and the mausoleum was closed so wasn't able to go inside. From the exterior, it's not much to look at so be sure to check if it's open before you bother giving it a visit.

Really interesting morning excursion. There's very few places where you can see historic leaders like this. The army are very vigilant at making sure you dint walk on the grass, cross the roads at the wrong place or go in with your hands in your pockets.
good. Interesting to see Ho, who had just come back from Moscow after a touch-up. Queueing was not a problem and visit was not too long. Ho looked very like in his photo's.

Agree with Keith P. Queues were incredibly long. Make sure to wear respectful clothes that cover your knee. Extremely regimented. Felt like we were on a conveyor belt. Everyone had to conform to single file, no speaking, no water, no cameras, no phones, no big bags...The actual museum was very disappointing. No translations into english for a lot of sections so we didnt know what we were looking at. pretty structures and surroundings.

Impressive building. This was very impressive from the outside, with many smartly dressed guards/military marching outside. The only downside being that they blew a whistle if you came to close to the building, which was perhaps a bit excessive. Unfortunately, cameras aren't allowed inside the mausoleum but you can undertsand why as a mark of respect. I wouldn't go out of my way to see this again, but if you are in the area its worth a look.

get there early. It is a beautiful grounds. We got there early, and it was rainy so there was no crowd or lines. Getting into the Mausoleum is free, but it is worth the few dollars to pay to see the entire grounds

great history expectation met. suoerb location,rich in culture ,history and vietnams plight through the 60' ands into the 70's,really enthralled with this visit,price was right and well worth the journey which itself was an adventure

Seeing a dead man.... The good things: this is part of history and Ho Chi Minh was/is an amazingly influential character in the lives of most Vietnamese. The grounds surrounding the mausoleum are beautiful and the sarcophagus building is stunning in its bleakness.BUT: everything is regimented to an extent that removes any emotion, any compassion and any belief that the guys guarding Uncle Ho really care about him, just about their orders.You queue in single file, all the time being watched by white-clad guards, enter the nasty municipal chamber to file past the body of the great man which could easily be a wax copy. You are discouraged from speaking and under the threat of something terrible were you to take a photo. Then you go outside and think... why?Our guide summed up the ritualistic solemnity by asking "did he wink at you"?

Special insight into national culture. Ho Chi Minh was embalmed after his death and is still on display, over 30 years later, for those wishing to pay their respects. The environment in the mausoleum is somber and quiet. Each onlooker has just a minute or so around the glass case. Really very unique compared to home, like an eternal wake/visitation versus just one day. Just by observing we learned a lot about the reverence held for HCM even today. Worth the few dollar cab ride from the Old Town, especially when accompanied by a visit to another attraction on the grounds. After our visit, we took a leisurely walk back to the Old Town (bring your map!) stopping for lunch at a delicious Hue-inspired restaurant along the way. Logistics: Wear LONG pants (no skin, not even calves/ankles) and avoid sleeveless shirts. Arrive early, the line is long (though it moves quickly) and the last entrance when we were there was around 10:15. We had a bit of a hard time finding the entrance line to the mausoleum.... Large bags and cameras are not allowed inside and must be checked (we were nervous about leaving our new pricey DSLR, but it was safely returned post-mausoleum).

Surreal experience, but unique!. Ho Chi Minh, as a man of the people, intended to have his body cremated when he died and his ashes placed in various places on the land of Vietnam. But his successors were having none of this, and it was decided he would be embalmed and placed in this extraordinary massive mausoleum so that people could pay homage to his preserved body encased in a glass refrigerated coffin. You may have to queue, but we got in early in the morning without a wait. The soldiers act like school prefects to keep you in line, no talking, must be properly dressed, and respectful. An experience like no other! Then you can go on to see his house, and other attractions of the area, such as the One Pillar Pagoda.

Pomp and ceremony. Passed through various checkpoints to make sure there were no camera's, escorted by staff and ceremonial guards who "handed us over" to mausoleum guards with a little ceremony. It was very sombre and respectful for revered leader. Worth a visit.
impressive and dignified. I did not like standing long time in line to get in. We left and came back after an hour, stood 3 minutes in line and got in - simple idea - come late.
Respectfully done. A must do when you come to Hanoi. There is no pomp and circumstance here, the mausoleum is done very respectfully and with great pride in simplicity.
White as a Ghost!!. You just have to go. Pay your ticket, stand in line and see Ho Chi Minh. Its not everyday you get to see a body so well preserved.

Interesting experience. The best way to describe this is a bunch of people silently gawking at a dead guy while men in uniforms stand around guarding the dead guy. It's completely surreal and slightly creepy. Since I've never seen an embalmed person before, let alone a communist leader, this was definitely worth it for me (and it's probably worth it just to say you've seen Uncle Ho up close and personal!). It closes around 10:30-11am so go nice and early - my friend and I couldn't find the entrance the first time we went and missed out so we had to go another day. Also it's only open some days of the week, so always check before you go.

Can't believe I saw him!. To walk in a single line filing past the body of Ho Chi Minh was one of the highlights of our trip. The guards standing around just staring fiercely at you were a bit unnerving but the school kids singing outside were adorable. It was a memorable moment for us.

Dead Man Amazing. Admiring the Vietnamese for their patriotism and love for their local hero. Amidst the westernization of their geographical neighbors, the people of Hanoi have preserved their own culture and practices. The city of Hanoi showcases French architecture with its well-preserved buildings and quaint shops. The city also boasts 5 star hotels. We stayed at the Intercontinental Hanoi, one of the best hotels in the world.

Amazing experience. We were amazed by the long lines of Vietnamese people wanting to pay homage to their revered leader - from the awe of the young schoolchildren from country Vietnam, to older people eagerly pushing by to get as far to the front of the queue as they can to see their beloved Ho Chi Minh - incredible. Where else in the world has a leader been as much loved as him? We queued for ages to see his body, was it worth it? Yes. To share this solemn procession with so many eager, patient and dutiful Vietnamese people was an experience worth having.

Surreal experience. We arose early for a 6am cyclo ride (very exciting for our first day in Hanoi!) across a waking city to first see the flag raising ceremony and later to file past the great man.It was all rather surreal but worth the effort to better understand the people's devotion to a man who led a simple but very significant life.
not open all year. Lenin in Moscow and Ho chi minh in hanoi.This is interesting to see .Same technology used for both.There will be lines so be patient

A important part of Uncle Ho's story. This was the beginning of our meeting with Ho Chi Minh. If death and viewing a preserved body creep you out avoid. But it was amazing and yet fascinating though brief. Not easy access for wheelchairs however.This man still though time has passed is revered and loved by his country and appreciated by many.Be aware that this attraction is closed on certain days before planning your trip.
Memories. Interesting to see especially the alive natives around.But not a big deal if you miss it.Dont go if you are limited in time and have seen similar places befor

Surreal. I know that when it says it's a mausoleum I should expect the tomb for Ho Chi Minh, but I didn't expect the royal guards and a glass encasing of the actual body, it was very well preserved. Also it was quite tense inside and I felt that if you sneezed you might of been arrested. Overall it was a really nice place to visit and would recommend if you had half a day free.

A "Must See" whilst in Hanoi. You really can't visit Vietnam, go to Hanoi and then not go to the Mausoleum. And it is both interesting and a pleasant place to see.You can decide for yourself whether you think the "body" in the glass case really is President Ho, or a very good waxwork (the view favoured by our student guide by the way), but there is no doubt that he is still revered by the Vietnam people. There is a lot more to see around the mausoleum itself. It is set in very beautiful gardens which you can stroll in at will. His small house is there - made out of beautiful teak, there are lakes, pagodas. To be honest, I can't remember all the details but we did enjoy the visit, for about 2 hours.

Disappointed. We were looking forward to this, but unfortunately it was a real disappointment.The whole complex is spread over a large area but it is not easy to walk around and you often have to go back onto the street to get to the bit you want. We got lost a couple of times and at one stage were shouted at for being in the wrong place by three officials.We paid to see the Palace area, but we're not allowed to go to the palace and just saw the stilted house. Be aware everything shuts down around 11.30 until around 2, but it is not the place where you are left to look around anyway.Be aware there are very few places you can sit down and rest.

Experience the Passion of Vietnamese People. Brief and confronting, but definitely worth seeing and experiencing. After a visit here it will leave you envying the passion and respect the Vietnamese people have for this man and leave you wishing that you could feel the same passion for a leader.

Insights. Arrived early in the morning, tagged along with a bunch of locals and was mistaken for a Vietnamese. From the entrance, visitors walk to the mausoleum in two lines (straying is forbidden, apparently). They will ask you to deposit big bags and your cameras which you will pick up at the opposite end upon exciting the mausoleum. One can see clearly how much respect the Vietnamese people hold for Ho Chi Minh or "Uncle Ho". Ho Chi Minh had stated in his will that he wanted to be cremated but somehow, his followers altered this will and with help from the Soviet Union, preserved his body. The viewing of Ho's body was very brief. The guards kept the people going. Nevertheless, the short time I spent inside the chamber where Ho was kept was surreal. Definitely worth seeing.

So Unlike Anything You See in America. It's hard to comprehend that HCM died decades ago after you see the Mausoleum. He is so incredibly well-preserved that you nearly expect his heart to start beating on the spot. The whole visit is very carefully trafficked by security -- you check all cameras, proceed in a two-file line all the way, and cannot speak inside. We were shushed. So do bare that in mind.

Spooky. It was a little daunting to see Ho Chi Minh's body. I'm glad I went, but not sure if it's suitable for little kids. The lines move quickly, so even though they looked incredibly long we went through fast.

Must see. The area is very clean and well-maintained. The embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is a must-see. One thing to remember when paying your respects to Vietnam’s greatest leader, please dress appropriately. No sleeveless tops, shorts and other revealing articles of clothing. Given that we visited during winter time, I was automatically “appropriately dressed.” Oh and hats, sunglasses and other things that might cover your head and/or face must be kept in your bag. This area is considered sacred and great respect must be showed when entering.

Vietnamese way of tribute to the makers of todays vietnam.. Must see in Hanoi to understand the Vietnamese way of salute /tribute to their nation-maker...well preserved body like wax work with some influences from communism. Little disapointed to know that he was preserved despite of his willing that his body to be cremated and his ashes scarted into the North , South & centre of the country.

Insight.. I volunteered in Hanoi for 3 months and highly recommend this as a fantastic insight into Marxist/Juche glorification of political leaders. A really surreal experience, prepare yourself for some propaganda but keep your mind open.

Beautifully kept grounds. I was very impressed by the pomp and ceremony attached to the mausoleum. The grounds are immaculately kept. I did not make it into the mausoleum itself, as I am not really keen on looking at dead people, but I can certainly recommend the area for a visit.

Hero lies embalmed in state. If you are visiting Hanoi, this is an iconic site which offers insight into the history of modern Vietnam. The complex is free to visit, although it costs a little effort and obedience. The guards insist on no hats, hands by sides and respectful silence. The visit to the mausoleum itself is brief, once you have lined up and been vetted. The body of Ho Chi MInh is embalmed and lies in a glass case (courtesy of Russian expertise and a two-month check-up each year). It is a somewhat sobering visit. Once outside, there are pleasant gardens with a small lake. Uncle Ho's cars are on display and you can see a few personal effects in the simple stilt house he chose over the Presidential Palace.

must see. must see attraction, is locted next to uncle ho's residence, one pillar pagoda presidential palace etc. remember dress smart hide your camera in your pocket and be quiet, or the guards will have words with you.
weird. probably worth a look but I found it just a bit weird seeing ho chi minh entombed, plus it was the only place where it really felt very communist, single file queuse, no smiling allowed etc

Go with a guide to take it all in. Very regimented and run on military lines....obviously. Don't forget to dress appropriately and early in the morning would seem to be the best time to go. Lots to see after you have queued for a short time to see the mausoleum, including the presidential palace and HCM stilt house.
Huge Mausoleum. The grounds around the mausoleum were very clean and the gardens were well manicured. The guards were all wearing white. This is near the Ho chi minh museum and the one pillar pagoda.

Lots of rules and regulations. It's fast and strict.The visit to the mausoleum has lots of rules, you think you are back to school and they will out you in the note corner if you don't listen. Not something that I will repeat again.
Not huge amounts to see. Had to do it. One man laid in state. You shuffle past with security keeping a very beady eye on you. Set in nice grounds

A great monument for Vietnamese people.. Not really my cup of tea, but eh, he's the Man who created what Vietnam is today, and you've got to respect that. Be well dressed, no outrageous/revealing tops, the military soldiers will be watching you.

Often closed and when open - long lines. Well didn't actually see it because it was closed. I HAD done my research and knew that it is only open in the mornings and is closed on Mondays. We went on a Friday morning and this is apparently also a closed day. Our guide said just as well, when open, the queues stretch around the whole (very large) block.

What a tribute. It's an amazing mausoleum to a national figure. However, he didn't want to be embalmed. He wanted to be cremated with little fuss, and his ashes scatted in the north, centre and south of the country. It feels weird seeing him.

Very respectful tribute to Ho Chi Minh. Go in the morning as the last admission is at 10:15. It's closed on Friday and Monday. It's also free in. Conservative clothing is a must as they won't admit anyone in shorts / sleeveless tops. Most of the visitors are Vietnamese but we didn't feel out of place. "Uncle Ho" is very well preserved and like a wax-work. Apparently he wanted to be cremated, which makes it a little sad to have done pretty much the opposite, but it's done very respectfully and ensures that his legacy lives on.

Communism On Display. It was definitely interesting to see the Mausoleum, if not for the body of Ho Chi Ming, but for the display of communist influence in Vietnam. They impose a strict dress code, with no shorts singlets or open toed shoes. Everyone is pushed through a square walkway that goes around his body quickly and you are not allowed to stop, or take photos. We also witnessed the changing of the guard while we were there, which was quit entertaining as well.

He's really dead. It is an interesting building and you do see him lying in state. It is somewhat impressive. The line was pretty short when we were there but I understand there could be quite a wait.

Uncle Ho. When I was taken there by Ms Thao, my friend from wlinktravel.com team to the Ba Dinh square- the political area where President Ho Chi Minh read the Independent Declaration, I was really inspires. This is also where preserved body of Ho Chi Minh. Another place that worth to pay a visit is Presidential Palace, also the House of Parliament.This is a must-try when you go to Hanoi!

Something different. Wow this is something different for the books, the guards are very strict on walking 2by2, no photos and then one by one inside.. No photos…..It was quite an experience before you even get inside, and then you see Ho Chi Minh, I was not expecting this. There are guards inside guarding the body as well. But it is something that we have done, and a new experience for us all.

Uncle Ho. The experience was a bit surreal.... Bit creepy too.... But definitely worth a visit! Be careful of the taxi's, one guy tried to charge us 500,000 VND and parked further down the road and up against a coach so we wouldn't be able to get out the car, he threatened us that he would take us to the police if we didn't pay so we laughed in his face and told his we'd walk down the road to the dozens of police officers down the road, threw him 50,000 and squeezed out of the taxi.( we were travelling from the old quarter)

Creepy but satisfying. We had to wait in a long line to see Uncle Ho. It was pretty interesting to observe the people and feel the reverence they have for Ho. His body looks pretty artificial as you would expect, but his face is still a good likeness that reminded me of the 60's when we used to change "Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh. Viet Cong are gonna win"!
Long queue for a minute walk past. There was a very long queue but it moved very quickly. You get about a minute to walk past his embalmed body.

You've come this far, so it's a worth the effort.... Interesting, quite unusual to experience the whole walking two by two, but all in all as you've travelled this far, you need to say you've been!Guards surround the whole glass tomb, and you walk by quietly to view. It only takes about 30/40 minutes and it is such an interesting part of history, that it is worth the effort.It was quite quiet when we went and we were fortunate to have a guide to talk us through the whole story.All part of the history and culture, so we quite enjoyed that part of the experience.
Worth a visit!. A very interesting insight into what and who moves the Vietnamese. Maybe a little too overcrowded at the weekend, so be aware of the masses on the days!

Must see for cultural experience. You'll be treated like children as you are told how to stand on the side walk two by two as you wait to enter. 8 Guards surround his glass tomb you will walk around and view his chemically preserved body. No photo taking inside or on the side of the street the mausoleum is located. If you take photos from the other side of the plaza that is okay which was puzzling.
Must do. The queue is slightly off putting but the mausoleum is worth a visit and it is free. Our entire visit took 40 mins from start to finish.
Beautiful building and grounds.. We enjoyed walking around the building and the grounds. The mausoleum was closed (for maintenance) when we were there.

Much More Than Uncle Ho to Learn and Experience. Great collection of diverse memorabilia, documents, photos and artifacts about not only one of VN's greatest and most popular heroes, but the times and people surrounding his charismatic leadership

Creepy but Interesting. This is not something that I would ordinarily visit, however we were walking around and it was close. First of all it is free, which surprised me, it was interesting to see the pomp and ceremony around this. Looking at Ho Chi Minh was not at all what I expected, it was not confronting in any way and the people clearly admire what he stood for and achieved. Well worth the visit.

Only went for the photo opportunity. I have been through the Mausoleum some years ago and the whole process is so controlled I didn't need to go again. AND is it really a body or a wax statute??? But I went on this visit hoping to get some photos of the surrounds etc. You cannot get close at all, so it was a pointless exercise really. And it was a very smoggy day so while my photos, using a telephoto lens are quite good, they are not perfect. The Presidential Palace, which is next door, is a much better photo opportunity.
Absolute waste of time !. There was nothing worth seeing and an absolute waste of time.Included by most tour operators as a way of providing maintenance of the same thru ticket entry...

Get there before 10.30am!. This is a must do. It's creepy and surreal, but you get a real perspective of the absolute supreme status Uncle Ho has, even after his death.We were outside after visiting watching people being turned away after about 10.40am- which must have been very disappointing for them.

Must Visit. This attraction is also on the must do list for Hanoi. Visiting the mausoleum gives you great insight into just how loved Ho Chi Minh is by the entire country of Vietnam. A spectacular site.

Kind of creepy but a must do. I found this a bit creepy but thought the experience was worthwhile. You have to respect the monumental achievements of this man and the mausoleum embodies all of this. It's sad though that Ho Chi Minh's wishes for cremation weren't respected. I was fascinated by the experience, especially watching the guards and seeing the reverence displayed. If you are in Hanoi this is a must do, get there early - we arrived at 745am (8am opening), but we were out of the mausoleum by 830am.

A Surreal Experience. This attractions if you can call it that is a difficult one for me to review because I’m actually of two minds whether its worthwhile or not. As an Australian, it’s difficult to fathom the kind of reverence and stature a people hold for a leader to want to build something of this nature so I really didn’t know what to expect when we went there. Sure, we have statues and shrines and memorials but this, is truly something different. When we arrived and started the slow procession into the complex it seemed more and more foreign to me as looking at the outside of the complex, I was expecting almost like a museum of Ho Chi Minh’s life or something of that nature. Slowly winding through the corridors, steps and other we came out in HCM’s the chamber then around it and wow out the other side just as quick shuffled as we came. Its very regimented, very controlled and don’t even stop on the grounds outside or the security will swarm you way to hurry you along.I hear you ask “WHY am I of two minds, the above sounds like I didn’t like it”… well, the reality is I liked it for the experience, it opened my eyes to the transcending veneration and adoration the Vietnamese and the Government have for HCM and what he did for the country. Where I think it falls short is that it really isn’t anything but a Mausoleum. If you want to learn about the man that was, or what he did you have to find it elsewhere.Expect long lines as its basically single file. They confiscate cameras and phones at the entrance and you pick them up at the exit on the other side of the complex. For my two cents, it was worth the 1-2 hours but if you a lucky enough to visit when they have any of the military honours or parades in the front square the experience will probably be better again. oh and wait around for the changing of the guards if you can as this is military precision in full dress like the movies.
Mausoleum. We were disappointed that it was closed on the day of our visit, although we did see the changing of the guard. So be sure to check opening times.
Surreal experience. Get there early and expect a very long line. They will keep your camera and have it available at another location outside the mausoleum when you get out.

Interesting piece of culture. The actual part where you file silently through the room past the corpse is brief, for me the real interest was all the ceremonial ritual surrounding the mausoleum, the gorgeously-uniformed guards (stick around to watch the fancy snappy marching when they change shifts with a new team), the rules about visitors' dress and conduct, the solemnity with which the whole area is managed (actually the whole city block, around which you have to walk the long way, twice, to get to the distant entrance to join the queue and then to retrieve your bag from locker room), and watching the reverence of the local visitors towards this man of incredible vision but who presided over so much oppression and suffering. Really worthwhile to try to get some insight into the attitudes of all those local people in whose homes you will see a Ho Chi Minh portrait in a prime position on the wall. Something really different!
Impressive..... After get to know the Vietnamese history there is no way not to admire Mr. Ho Chi Minh!! Being at the mausoleum and offering flowers was a highlight in our trip!

History right there!. To me this was an incredible experience. First you have to queue up and shuffle along a guided track and go through a security check for cameras and bags. Even though it does take awhile to get to the mausoleum itself there are plenty of informative propaganda type videos playing to tell of the history of "Uncle Ho". Eventually you are shuffled in silence by stern looking white suited guards into the mausoleum itself. To see Ho Chi Minh lying in state is a little unbelievable but there he is. To me it was a fascinating piece of history, there lies this man I knew little about yet the name Ho Chi Minh is so familiar from my childhood. You can't take photos and respect is key, it it's a very interesting insight into the communist state and cult of personality that exists here.

Interesting historic visit. Be sure to get in line early to avoid what can become very long waits. It is quite interesting to see Ho in his mausoleum. After your visit, be sure to tour the surrounding grounds to see the home in which he lived and worked.

Get there early. The lines moved quickly, but go early to figure out entrance. We had been to the area the days before and thought we could easily walk to the entrance. The area in front of the mausoleum was closed off and we had to walk around the entire area before getting to the entrance. Decent experience

The honor which is bestowed upon him. The mausoleum demonstrates the honor which is bestowed upon Ho Chi Minh by his people in the elegant grounds decorated with espalier, the building which houses his remains and the respect paid him by the guards and visitors.

Solemn but Serene. My knowledge on the history of Vietnam as a whole is pretty embarrassing. I started my north Vietnam trip with zero anticipation nor expectation as I was kind of ushered to join in. So when I heard we were visiting Uncle Ho to pay homage, I was like "yeah, whatever". You can imagine my utter surprise as we lined up to wait our turn into the mausoleum. We had to line up outside the mausoleum, 2 single lines, caps/hats off, bags scanned and searched as we made our way into the depths of the mausoleum under the watchful eyes of white uniformed guards/soldiers at every point.Once in the main chamber where Uncle Ho serenely lies in state it was surreal. I think everyone that walked through that particular area felt the instant calmness and quiet glory that envelop you all at once. Uncle Ho looked angelic in his eternal sleep and I felt somewhat moved to have been there.

Is it him or not?. Having never been to a mausoleum before I wasnt too sure how to rate this. Free to enter, join the queue and move with the flow. If you are not appropriately dressed or sombre enough the guards will point it out. There is a belief that it isnt actually him. Its down to belief. Some believe its him others dont. Either way its a bit different. Ho Chi Minh wanted his ashes split into three and the portions to be buried in the North, South and Centre of the Country. Personally I think that would have been a better option. Still, it provides the people with a focal point.

Dont mess around here. Brilliant no talking hands by your side and dont look back at Ho Chi min.he looked like one of those statues of knights in cathederals in the the uk lying down but no cameras allowed here well worth the expereince to see this guy.

Creepy but memorable. Dead 43 years and still looks great! Interesting experience going through mausoleum. White uniformed guards tap your hands if you have them in pockets; or motion to remove your cap. Then you enter main chamber where Uncle Ho is on bier, with a guard at attention at each of four corners. I thought he would be under glass but he's in open air, with light shining on him from wooden canopy a few feet above his body. You walk past about 10 feet from his body. Creepy. Wonder how often they dust him off?
Strange. Questionable as to whether it was really him we were told this by the guide. Once again hurried past the exhibit and no photos were allowed

Very educational, interesting, and motivating.. This is full of history. It is a beautiful facility with much to see, read, enjoy, and be motivated by. I also like the raising of the flag in the early morning, and the lowering of the flag in the evening.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. similar to the Mao Tse Tung Mausoleum in Beijing but not as grand. Security is present but not very strict. Every one queue and walk pass the glass coffin and pay the respect to "Uncle Ho"

Walk in a line. Well this is called follow the leader. You line up and wait, move some more, line up and wait, etc. (no talking!!) Finally, you get to Mausoleum and walk around a glass casket which contains what may in fact be a wax figure. You're not allowed to stop, so the actual visit is less than 20seconds. But afterwards you can go to the presidential palace which is great.

a must do experience. a must see and quite an experience to undergo to see Uncle Ho, and go through tight Viet security. If you lucky, youll experience the guard change (very Buckingham palace like, except you get to see the well preserved body of Ho Chi Minh).

A place must go. When you visit Hanoi, don't forget to go to visit Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, one of the best place in Hanoi, this complex is included mausoleum, fish pond, house on stilt, presidential palace, and beside that is one pillar pagoda.

Long queues. Although there were long queues at this site, it was worth it and people moved constantly around the mausoleum site. I did not realise that Ho Chi Minh's body has been preserved in this way.
Surprisingly well organized. Efficient entry procedure, much better than Moscow or Beijing. Not exactly memorable but such things are more interesting as symbols than as actual experiences.

Respectful visit. I have pay respect to President Ho Chi Minh twice. His body was very well maintained and when I saw him, he was peacefully sleeping.
Amazing, the queue was very long during any holiday in Vietnam's . you see flocks of people from all over Vietnam came here to this great man.

Something to do. To say that Vietnamese people hold Uncle Ho in high regards would be an understatement. And as such, I thought it would definitely be interesting to go see his mausoleum. The whole complex is a pleasant 20minute walk from the Old Quarter along Dien Bien Phu Street. Once there, you go through security and are required to turn in all cameras and turn off your phones, etc. (Not sure if everyone does turn their phones off, though)You lineup in single formation and walk through the well maintained gardens and into the mausoleum. Honestly, for those of us who aren't that in awe of Mr. Minh, the whole experience was a bit anti-climatic. You walk through this small dimly lit room, see the embalmed body of Uncle Ho, and you walk out. Done!The rest of the grounds of the complex are more interesting, but this is something to do to mark it off your list.

Interesting. A bit of history the complex, built by the French.in their colonial period, is massive worth taking the time to visit Uncle Ho is revered by the people. But still seems a bit bizarre to have him on display, particularly when he wished for his ashes to be spread in North, cCentral& Southern Vietnam however after his death others apparently thought differently.

Ho hum Ho chi. Neat orderly lines move slowly for what seemed like blocks. Take off you hat, hands out of pockets, dress respectively, no photos, no videos, ... To see the mummy of Ho Chi Minh. One big plus lots of government employees keeping the line on good behavior. Not worth the time.

No body, no fun.. I didn't get the opportunity to see Ho Chi Minh's body, as I was apparently late. Make sure you visit this place early in the morning or you will have to make do with admiring the mausoleum from the outside. Also, be sure to take pictures of the parliament building nearby.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. There was a long queue for visiting the mausoleum and being early was ahead in the queue. At exactly 0800 hrs the entry to the mausoleum began and photography was strictly prohibited. I was reprimanded by a guard for photographing the mausoleum externally.At the entry to the Mausoleum were two guards at attention with bayonets akin to Statue.Every Vietnamese visitor paying homage was well dressed, in their best attire akin to a religious gathering, myself being the rare foreigner tourist in the crowd.On entering the Mausoleum had to walk up to the first floor in the queue and pass along the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh lying in the coffin with his hands placed in front, very life-like as shown in photo's and portraits.There were four guards guarding the coffin and the crowd of people just pass along the coffin in a single queue, very systematic and orderly.After the Mausoleum visited "Ho Chi Minh" house on stilts and his estate, a enormous museum complex.This mausoleum is said to be modeled on Lenin's tomb in Moscow.

Old socialistic approach. I've never seen more boring museum. I was born in socialistic times and I remember how such museums looked like, however I believed last 30 years even Vietnam could learn something about publicity, culture and art. The visitors in the museum are mainly children from various schools, actually it is full of them, so my advice is to avoid the visit to museum and to spare the time for better activity.

My visit to see Uncle Ho. This was a very surreal experience. The lines were long but move very quickly. The tours are only in the morning and close down at 11. It was a little bit like seeing Lenin's tomb. If you go to Hanoi you must see this

My visit to see Uncle Ho. This was a very surreal experience. The lines were long but move very quickly. The tours are only in the morning and close down at 11. It was a little bit like seeing Lenin's tomb. If you go to Hanoi you must see this
I didnt go inside. I only saw this from outside as didnt want to join the tour bus queues, but was happy to be able to say that I had walked past. The museum was excellent

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. regimented, we were asked to walk in pairs, once we reached the front we were asked to unfold our arms, stop talking, we walked through, not allowed to take photos inside the tomb, Viet people come to pay their respect, As tourist, we forget the importance and the great respect that Ho Chi Minh has as father figure for the Viet people. Its like a religous place for the Viet people.

Landmark of Hanoi. We had the misfortune to arrive at Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum during the closure of the memorial. For close to two months every year, somewhere between September to November, the mausoleum has to close down and the body of Ho Chi Minh sent to Russia for maintenance (yes, the embalmment needs maintenance). So it definitely would be wise to check ahead with your tour agency or hostel clerk regarding the mausoleum's closure if you are visiting during those months. Interestingly for us though, both the tour guides and hostel receptionists knew that the mausoleum was closed for maintenance but not when it would reopen. Fortunately for us though, the mausoleum reopened on the last day of our trip.There will always be locals (as well as some foreigners) cutting the queue past the shuffling throng, indifferent and oblivious to the indignant glare of foreigners, so be patient with these people. Long the queue may be, but at least it was moving albeit at a snail's pace.The interior of the mausoleum was not vast, surprising considering the size of the mausoleum from the outside. However the corridors were wide enough to accommodate two abreast with much room to spare. We noticed that the interior was rather dimly lit and cold, lending an even grimmer and dour sense of the place. Honor guards stood at intervals along the path, silently staring at passersby with an air of indifference.We entered a rather small area where everyone's attention was fixed on the dais in the middle of the room. Encased within a glass sarcophagus was the body of Ho Chi Minh, the nation's leader. He looked rather serene, lying within the sarcophagus with hands clasped and sandals on as if asleep, with only the waxy face betraying a hint of his embalmment.It took us more than 30 minutes to reach the heart of Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum but less than 5 to walk past the body of the deceased leader. Most guides will recommend in a short sentence one other event to witness while visiting Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum - the changing of guards. I however recommended strongly to be there at the right time to witness it.Is there mausoleum worth visiting? I would say it depends on your purpose. One may not hold much interest in the bygone communist days of Vietnam of for the deceased leader of this nation, but the monument itself is such a landmark of Hanoi that one could barely claim that one has visited the city without snapping a photo in front of the edifice. Following the queue may not be necessary for most, if you are only there to take a picture of the gray facade.
Very committed. Learned enough to want to read more about Ho and his accomplishments. His determination for an independent Vietnam was sorely under estimated by the French and US.
Don't waste your time. Unless you are a hardcore historian, this is not worth you time. You can walk around the round, but you can't even get in front of the palace, everything is fairly buttoned up.

Nice. It's only open Tuesday to Thursday hours 8am-11.30amThis place is like going to the airport, security plus.You go through the scanner you put your bags on a scanning machine.YOU CANNOT TAKE FOOD OR WATER in to this place! A young girl tried to take fruit and it was taken off her.My iPad was also taken put in a bag your given a tag with a number on it iPad returned when you leave.There is security all over the mausoleum so if you thinking of doing something wrong here don't bother!I accidentally went to walk on the grass and a whistle was blown at me.With all the do nots it's a nice relaxing place There was on the day I went 3-4 classes of lower level primary school kids. It was amazing how when we went to walk in the room where their great leader lays you could of heard a pin drop! Not a sound was made! But once outside the kids were all "hello" I think near 11.30 there might be a changing of the guard or similar,
Architecture superb. Wasn't open when we went but loved the buildings, the mausoleum and the gardens. A great must do activity.
Do Not Miss!. A well organized tribute to Ho Chi Minh where you can pay your respects in an orderly, manner.The history of this leader and his impact on his country are so well experienced here.

Um...how does one comment on a guy on display?. The experience was strange. You get in line to get in a line to walk in a line to the front of the tomb entrance. Then, single file you walk in, no photos inside or near the inside, also no sunglasses, no arms crossed. You go up stairs, walk around the orange hued display guarded by four men, some people are bowing, then you exit and you're done. Walk down stairs and that's it.Ho Chi Minh's stilt house and museum are right next door.(I did not see an elevator access for this building.)

place must come to see. It is the #1 must-do thing in Hanoi. Everything was very well organised, and i didn't have to wait at all. I had been seen the man that people Vietnam respect as a god. The father of Vietnamese .

paying tribute to a great man of history.. pres Ho chi min led his people to freedom. vietnam will never be the same without this great and brave man. it is but fitting to honor him by preserving his remains and putting in in a glass box. this way, not only them vietnamese will pay tribute to him but the world as well as he is a man that contributed the the world's historic landscape. the way by which his body was preserved is awesome. it was so nicely done that you would think it is a wax figure. but the presence of the guards in the corners of the glass box will convince you that it is indeed his body there. this is a place that should not be missed in Hanoi. the very brief parade of the guards is an interesting site too. after viewing pres. Ho chi Min's remains, have a short walk to the grand park. take a few clicks of the mosuleum as it will be your only souvenir pictures. no cameras allowed inside the mosuleum that's why.

quite a moving experience. I'm the exact opposite of a communist but this was a moving experience viewing a historically important figure. The place is immaculate and the soldiers like clockwork. Every visitor is kept in line, sun glasses off and hands out of pockets. Body looks tiny, smooth faced and well preserved. Also go and see HCM small house nearby where he lived and worked after refusing to move into a grand palace.

Different Tour. Mausoleum looks very Russian in build and it's a very strict formal entry into it. You have to keep in straight line and cannot cross your arms over your body. You walk through no stopping and there is Ho Chi Minh lying there for you to see. Very pale and waxy looking but a tour you have to do. Walk around his home was very interesting.

A well visited shrine. If you get there early in the day, then you are pretty assured of not having to wait in a lengthy queue. Photographs are not allowed to be taken inside and the time spent inside the mausoleum viewing Uncle Ho would be about 30 seconds. This is a wonderful final resting place of the man that is often called "Uncle Ho"

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Come to visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum The mood is all visitors to see more close Uncle, will feel better in the morning, he was the proud Vietnam, believed to have chosen the path that Uncle.ausoleum - The pride of Vietnam. Is a fascinating place to visit with local and foreign tourists.They close every year for a month while they send the body to Russia to preserve and embalm the body and bring it back to Ha Noi.This is a very intriguing place and I would suggest that a visit to Ha Noi would not be really complete without seeing this place.

RIP?. Get up early and join the faithful to see Uncle Ho, but make sure you dress correctly & only walk on the correct paths. Ho, similar to Lenin looks a little like a waxwork, the changing of the guard is impressive. A must do especially as it is free.

Pretty neat but a lot of people and kinda dull. Seeing Ho's body preserved was definitly the highlight of the Mausoleum, even though there is a museum and two other houses. This place is laden with guards who are quick to call you out for anything but not overly pushy, just no talking, hands out of pockets, & no pictures...that sort of thing. Other than that the whole complex is kinda weak. You can only go through the Mausoleum, Ho's house, the other houses he worked and lived in, or the museum ONCE...basically once you are herded through with the other countless groups you eventually walk out the back exit and that is it. I can understand how this would be a great trip for local Vietnamese but we were basically going just to see his preserved body (which is remarkably preserved having died in 1969). Other than that it was kind of dull. The museum is hard to follow as most of the displays are not translated.

A walk by, at least, a must.. I can understand people not wanting to go into the Mausoleum to view the body of the former great leader of Vietnam but a walk by visit is certainly a must.We did the walk by visit and were luck enough to be there when the guards were being changed. Interesting to watch. This is a very intriguing place and I would suggest that a visit to Hionai would not be really complete without seeing this place.
Amazing mausoleum with fantastic surroundings. Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is well worth a visit. It is a great building with impeccable grounds and a fair bit of history, making a great photo opportunity.

Glad I Did IT.
