A good venture for a few hours,I found it a very revering & sombre experience to see uncle ho who was a national figure during my growing up years.There was also a display for General Giap who had just recently passed away.The whole venue genuinely means a lot to the Vietnamese people,their adoration & loyalty I find impressive & this place will explain why.

preserved like he is alive. They close every year for a month while they send the body to Russia to preserve and embalm the body and bring it back to hanoi. They had just opened it in November so the line was long and moves fast. Can not photograph the body and guards are everywhere. Worth the visit.
A solemn look at Ho Chi Minh. Ho Chi Minh lies in a glass coffin, with a guard of honour, while a continuous queue of people walk respectfully by.

Odd experience. The Mausoleum is a grand, impressive and very straightforward piece of architecture that dominates Ba Dihn Square, surrounded by very well-maintained grounds. The actual act of observing a dead body is kind of weird, but the overall experience of lining up, passing through the building, and sticking to their strict regiments makes the Mausoleum an experience worth checking out.
Very restricted. While the mausoleum itself is impressive, the ritual and constant reminders to keep your hands out of your pockets and keep your hats off detracted from the spectacle.

A piece of history. We visted here early one morning and in all honesty did not have to queue very long. Whilst in the queue though we noticed a young girl sweeping up leaves and if one was to fall this was quickly dealt with - the grounds were emaculate and lovely to look at whilst waiting. Obviously this monument is very well guarded and you have to be so careful as you have to 'cover up' arms and not wear shorts above the knee. Went entering you are not allowed to speak and must keep moving which is watched over by the guards - all very smart in their white uniforms. Once inside you file past the body of 'Uncle Ho' but you are not allowed to stop for a second as you are ushered on. I found the experience to be very moving although regimented. Afterwards we walked around the grounds and then made our way to the one pillar pagoda. Well worth a visit as it's history that we remember.

Impresive. It is a huge place in a huge square. If you want to visit it you must come in the early morning. I met a man who offered me the posibility to go with him in his motorbike to show me and explain me about the history of Hanoi especially related with the US war, for 6 dolar I had a greatexperience for 2 hours

Grand and Ghoulish. Come, comrades, and see the remains of our Dear Uncle Ho, laid to rest atop the grand mausoleum for triumphantly imposing his vision of Communist rule on one and all. Never mind he caused the deaths of millions of his countrymen in the process. This is typical of the hero-worship displays of totalitarian regimes throughout the world. Hey, he’s dead, and if you’re going to see him – stuffed and displayed like a trophy fish – you’re not. That’s about the best that can be said for this Halloween House of Horrors.
Part of any visit to Hanoi. You got to see Uncle Ho, but expect to walk around a lot and get directed on prescribed routes, plus no pictures. The museum on site is not worth a visit.

To know more about Uncle Ho. We are lucky to visit this place with a private tour guide. When we went there, we are sort of clueless but as our tour guide explains everything, then we understand more about Ho Chi Minh. Here you can find his cars (from his friends all over the world), you can also see his old house at the back of the Big Mansion that was built by French when they occupied Vietnam and HCM's final resting place.
Closed on Mon. Part of a city trip, interesting to walk around the premises to learn a bit more of Vietnam's history.

Impressive architecture. We didn't know what to expect, however i felt let down! There were a lot of people visiting, the staff on duty are very officious, and they go over the top with their levels of respect, covering your arms and long trousers!However Ho Chi Minh new wooden house was interesting and the grounds are pleasant. We were lucky we saw the changing of the guard which helped as we queued in twos before entering the tomb. Certainly not near the top of our list of Indochina experiences!

I agree, a surreal experience. Tickets and entry are easy to get into, at least they were in January. You are ushered through, with serious looking soldiers stationed throughout. The Vietnamese people are almost awed as they pass through to see Uncle Ho. The walk by is quick and easy. The body, in my opinion, doesn't look much like the pictures of Ho Chi MInh. After you exit the building you follow a path that takes you through different places Ho Chi MInh lived and worked. I think the body of Chairman Mai is a little better preserved in Beijing, if it is him at all. One more to go in Moscow.
Worth a driveby. Pretty predicable if you have seen photos. We were lucky to see the changing of the guard which made the stop somewhat interesting. It is what you see - a huge monument to one man.

Surreal experience. Our visit started in the morning, we tried to access the park by foot and it was not clear which way we had to go to. After a while wondering around, we found our way, gave our backpacks to the security checkpoint and patiently waited in the long cue. The inside of the building is simple and everyone that is visiting has only a few seconds to see uncle Ho.

Definitely something needed to be seen. This did not take a long time and was not something incredibly amazing but is definitely something I would go to see if I had not been to Hanoi before - especially as Ho Chi Minh had such a big impact on how Vietnam is today. It is a cultural experience entering the mausoleum and staff are extremely strict with behaviour and dress code.

An experience not to be missed. What is most interesting about this visit is just not walking into the Mausoleum to see Ho Chi Mihn's actual preserved body, but the entire experience. Being from the US, I would never expect to have to go through the amount of security, checking in backpacks and cameras, and the proceeding to walk around the entire complex in an organized line before entering the building to see a former President's Tomb. Not to mention the line is REALLY long. It keeps moving so the entire visit takes like ~30mins, but still, what an neat experience. It gives you some insight into the Vietnamese culture and how they revere their leaders. Something you don't experience in the US.

Organization was incrediable!. They wasted no time lining people up and channeling them through. Very interesting to get to walk around him and see him laying there like he has been asleep for 60+ years.

Huge crowds but no Ho. The Mausoleum is an impressive building and with it's white uniformed guards makes for some good photos. But the crowds were immense on the day I visited, especially queued up to inspect the other associated buildings. And the Mausoleum itself was closed due to the body of Ho Chi Minh having been sent to Russia for annual maintenance.
Hard to Rate !. This was included in our tour, we probably wouldn't have gone otherwise. However it gave us a cultural insight into the country at the begining of our holiday.

A stop by Uncle Ho's resting place. The huge mausoleum is tough to miss from the road. It really is quite the sight. It's a huge memorial for Vietnam's most famous leader. The only reason why I won't give it a higher rating is because of the limited entrance/viewing time.
Home of the father of the nation. Beautiful setting, very well kept. Visiting the house gives you an idea of some of Ho Chi Minh´s traits and personality.
Ho Chi Minh. A great big quiet square where H.C.M is resting. Unfortunetly I did not pay my respects to Him because they close at noon. But I saw the changing of the guards at 03.p.m

HO CHI MINH MAUSOLEUM. Visiting the Mausoleum is free of charge but involves a set of strictly enforced regulations. No short skirts or tank tops are allowed and there is high level of security check upon arrival. Day packs can be put in a safe deposit before you enter but make sure you do not carry many valuable items with you.Taking photos, talking or finger-pointing are strictly prohibited inside the mausoleums.

Impressive Building. Since we were there early in November during the period when it is closed so he can be "refurbished", we were only able to walk around the outside of the building which is quite an impressive structure. I was sorry that we couldn't view him (I think)!

Be respectful. My husband unfortunately had his hands in his pockets and was told off by a soldier, so no talking, no shorts or short sleeves, be respectful or you'll be told off.Long lines with local people on a Sunday paying their respects be prepared to wait but the lines did move quickly. Lots of other things to see nearby as well.

People from all corners. It was amazing to the see the line snaking all the way down the street when we reached at 9 am to visit the mausoleum. Ho Chi Minh mausoleum our guide told us was a place where people from all corners of Vietnam come to pay their respect. Truly so, because more than the tourists there were lots of local people who had come to pay homage. It is simple building that is surrounded by a huge courtyard called the Ba Dinh Square and the atmosphere is very somber. There are lots of guards who are around and our tour guide told us to be respectful whilst visiting the place. The crowd is handled very efficiently and everything proceeds in a very organized manner.

Worth a visit. As someone else said below a bit odd but glad I went. I was in Hanoi last week and went to see the mausoleum on the recommendation of someone we met in a restaurant although it was not on my list of things to do. There was a huge snakelike queue which put me off and I almost changed my mind. However it was moving very quickly so we joined it. I have to say the queue moved very quickly and it really didn't take long. For me it was the experience rather than just seeing the old chap lying there. The communist state really came out. I kept getting told to stand right next to my wife while walking in the queue and if we moved away slightly were told to stand together. If we moved slightly out of line or dropped back very slightly they were quickly on it telling us to move along. I found myself doing it deliberately just to annoy them. They did take my camera off me before we entered but they did let me take quite a big bag in after they checked there was nothing in it. I did have an iphone in my pocket but think it would have been a big mistake to take it out while I was in there. Photos weren't a problem outside. Worth a visit if you are in the area and tickets to get in cost next to nothing.

great to view at night. Unfortunately this is shut in November so couldn't go through the day, but worth a trip to at night for the excellent photos you can get. I was surprised that the local use this area for exercise, late into the night people are there dancing, jogging, thai chi. So make the effort even if you are there during the months that it is closed as there will always be something interesting going on.

Worth a visit in Hanoi. Expect long line to see the enbalmed body of HCM, who was the most important character in this country history. The visit to his nearby residential places (museums) are also enjoyable to at least get a glimpse of the past and where modern vietnam history was shaped. Do not miss this visit when you come to Hanoi as everything else outside culinary experiences are still limited.

The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is worth a visit.. We were very lucky to have a great tour guide with a University degree and very good English speaking skills. We had an intensive history lesson but unfortunately Ho Chi Minh's body was in Russia being re embalmed so we missed out on a viewing. If only history was taught this way at school, we would have been A grade students.

Popular place!. Even though the Mausoleum was closed for the annual "refurb" of the man himself there were many people visiting. We were fortunate to be in the company of a friend who knew quite a lot about the history and about Ho Chi Minh as there was almost no information around the site. The site is large and well laid out but the volume of people means a little patience is needed to see some of the exhibits.

Not open To the public on Fridays. Hanoi is a place rich in culture and has numerous museums. My travel partner had the Mausoleum on his to see list and even though it's not open on Fridays there were literally hundreds of people from all cultures taking photos from the square. Like most of the attractions in Hanoi I have read that the entrance fee is about $1,25au per person.Although we were not able to enter we soaked up the atmosphere. The grounds are beautifully maintained and guards dressed in white uniforms. I was not on a guided tour so just walked around at my own pace taking lots of photos. I'm glad we went there. Lots of security around the area and a few small tourist shops selling things at inflated prices.

it depends if your into mausoleum thing. What should you do going there?1. Be there early - the line entrance to that place is so long.2. Dont bring huge bags - guards wont allow you to enter the place, only small bags like as small as belt bags, or clutch bags.3. Cellular phones and cameras - they are not allowed inside the mausoleum to avoid taking pictures of things they dont want you to see in pictures (for your eyes only).4. Dont bring any passport - put in the safetybox of your hotel, theres no locker in that place and your tour guide cant hold on to your things at the same time. Again bags not allowed inside that place.(just to avoid lots of things to carry on while your walking, yes you wil have a bit of a long walk).If you are travelling with tour guides he can carry your mobilephones and cameras for they are allowed to carry it for you to avoid tempting of taking pictures.they will give it back to you after you go out of the mausoleum. Because outside its ok to take pictures.What to see inside the mausoleum?1. Body of ho chi minh with guards2. Ho chi minhs used cars (you can take pictures of it)3. Stuffs related to ho chi minh...everything is about him.What to see outside the mausoleum?Foods and drinksGardens and thats it.If you prefer for just sightseeing, the place is ok...but if you dont want to have a long walk and if its ok with you not take pictures as your remembrace to everything you see, the place is fine too. But not that memorable in my own opinion. But we have to respect their customs and their society for what they think is the right thing to do with regards of their property.But i think i wont recomend that place for my friends. Theres not much things to see after such securities and long walk.I wont go there again if incase given a chance, even if its for free.But as i have said different people, different opinion. If your into museum thing... visit the place.

Very impressive looking--go to see changing of the guards. Very impressive site to preserve the memory of the founder of modern Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh, who was an absolutely amazing man transforming Vietnam from an oppressed state by China, France and Japan into what it is today--a vibrant communist/capitalistic country with wonderful people.

Go early!. Interesting place, I'm glad I went, but it's a bit odd. The buildings are stunning, particularly the palace ($1.20 entrance to the grounds).I recommend going early. We slept through our alarm and got there as 15 busses turned up, which made seeing everything a bit slow. While you're up that way though, it's not far to the B52 lake, which is quite interesting and takes you on a little tour through some cool alleyways.

I am sure it is great, but so poorly organised. Wow, a review posted this a few months back and I couldn't have said it better:"Lots of check controls on the street. They don't let you walk though the mausoleum, they tried to obligate us to go around nowhere" Agree 100%"The police do a strict enforcement. And they don't look friendly. They look paranoiac". Agreed they are downright rude and a blight on Hanoi.There are really huge lines. It's completely insane. Agreed - lines that seem to go nowhere."We just wanted to check it from outside and that it was almost impossible. Even take a pic of the building is a challenge". 100% couldn't agree more. So disorganised that it is laughable. .

Cult of personality. This mausoleum is quite unique and certainly worth a visit for this reason. The ceremonial is very solemn.I am quite sure that a vast majority of the non-Vietnamese visitors know very little about Ho Chi Minh. It's probably more the intriguing aspects of his cult and the propaganda around him that's most interesting.When we went there, there was no queue at all. Other reviewers mentioned long waiting times - would I have waited hours for this? Probably not.
A must. If you go to Vietnam it is pertinent to get an impression of old Uncle Ho, and this is the place to go.

Fascinating experience albeit brief. After entering the long but efficiently moving line, you enter the grand structure and ascend the stairs. The central room is quiet and square, and you enter along one side of the display, walk around the front (foot) of his body, then out the other side. Ho Chi Minh looks very peaceful and is amazingly preserved. As others have said, it can be tricky to time when the display is open, but I think Mondays are bad and other days you just need to confirm times available. As for dress code, I had longer cargo shorts and a t-shirt which were fine, but one friend with above knee shorts was turned away.

Impressive but what is the story with Ho's body being there?. The Mausoleum and the buildings around are impressive to see and are well worth a stop. However to see the body it is a bit more tricky. I could not work out when the body was there and when not. I've asked different guides and they all had different answers, so I still don't know when it is possible. But still even when the body is not there I would say go over and have a look.

There's a body laying there. So went here with the family, no cameras allowed so they check them for you. The line is long but it goes by pretty quick. Also it's really cold inside and that's because Ho Chi Minh, is actually laying there. Wish someone told me that before i went in, lol!

Grandiose Mausoleum. The mausoleum was closed when we were there. The embalmed remains of Ho Chi Min is normally displayed in the mausoleum, but, was sent to Russia for a few days for the yearly maintenance and touching-up. The building is guarded by soldiers and the surrounding area is quite impressive. There were thousands of tourists. It must be even much more busy when it is open.

Closed. Beware. This Mausoleum closes approx. Sept. for a few month while Ho goes to Russia for a face lift. It was impossible to find out the dates of closure before we booked our holiday and of course, it was closed when we were there. You can see it from the outside!

Closed during our visit. We could only see from the outside but it is still a very impressive building.It was closed during our stay in Vietnam and Ho Chi Mihn was undergoing some upkeep. Still interesting watching the guards etc though.
Interesting. We found it quite surprising that Ho Chi Minh's body was on display in the mausoleum...TIP: Women should wear a long skirt, or be prepared to buy one at the entrance for US$4.
Homage to "Uncle Ho". A necessary stop on a first visit to Hanoi. Near Ho Chi Minh's home, it is a fitting edifice. The changing of the guard was an added plus.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum closed on Fridays. Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum was closed on Fridays which was our only free day in Hanoi and was not included on our tour. We still went there to explore the outside and take photos. Well worth a look and an interesting building. We also visited the Ho Chi Minh Museum which was behind the Mausoleum.

Kinda Weird. We were there on a Sunday and the line was rather long. You get in there and ol' Ho Chi Minh is lying in state in this big glass case. You file past and head out the exit. That's it. I think this is a bigger deal for the Vietnamese (obviously.) I felt a little weird partaking in this, felt like maybe being an American it was in some weird way disrespectful (for lack of a better word) to be seeing this. I got nothing from it. He looks like a wax figure. An odd experience indeed.

Creepy, and eery . After queueing up for ages with no water allowed we watched the changing of the guard. Precision marching in formation. Entering the tomb no hats, sunglasses, talking or cameras allowed. The guards are very strict my friend was even made to remove her transition lenses. Ho is lying in a glass case very wax like, it's creepy, I felt like I was trespassing on someone's grave. To make it worse we found out Ho's last wish was to be cremated making it feel like a violation of his last wish.
eerriee. Saw mr Ho's body. Looked like he was sleeping. Guards were very strict with us seeing him. no cameras allowed inside and no talking and no hands in pockets. high security for a sleeping man?
Homage. Long line. But moved fast. A stark contrast to the simple life Uncle Ho lived. Very communist era Soviet-esque.

Quiet respect. Aim to visit and queuing, many restrictions and rules made me a bit of frustrated. No proper signage or rule written for tourist. Apart from rule set, visit the great leader and see how he lead Vietnamese people.

Ho Chi Minh mausoleum . In March, 2013 , i went to Ha Noi myself to visit my sister. My sister and I went to Ho Chi Minh mausoleum.
But, the people was too much, i couldn't get inside.
After that day, we had got inside and meet Uncle Ho.
(My english is not good. I hope everyone understand)

Limited interest.... HCM was in Moscow for a recondition, so there was no defiling. The whole place is quite sad if you know that HCMs wish was to be cremated and not exhibited in a glass cofffin...
Very heavy stalinist architecture

Fascinating experience. Went there on a weekend, so it was really crowded and I queued for a couple of hours, mainly with other locals. It's a bit of a waste of your day since you really only get to spend a few minutes inside the mausoleum itself, but the solemn atmosphere and respectful quietness of the line inside made the (very) short visit a memorable fascinating experience.

No Chi Minh mausoleum. Was worth going here for the vast open space similar to a mini Tianamen square surrounding this imposing edifice. Watched the guards doing their high stepping stiff armed marching as they changed shifts. Be aware of the no camera signs dotted all over the place as I got a severe whistling at by a guard whilst unknowingly snapping the private residence through barred gates. I suppose being cynical, the size and presence of the mausoleum and the opulence of the surrounding gardens and buildings reinforces the power of state over individual
Processional. Uncle Ho was not present (annual preservesTigon work), so the mausoleum was not open, nor the official residence. A slow moving procession past the garage and his houses.
Do not miss. What a piece of history to see Never saw anything like this before and our guide Phong got us right in line. We are so happy we made the time for this experience.

landmark building. While not a particularly pretty building, I recommend seeing it based on the standing that Ho chi Minh has in the eyes of the Vietnamese. The building was closed during my visit as the embalmers were at work.
Huge complex. Mausoleum was under maintenance so we could not go inside and view the body but the history is rich and the grounds are very well preserved. It's quite impressive.
A Note with. The mausoleum open everyday excepts Mon and Fri. We have been there on Monday. It wasted our time. Please check this before going.
Ugly building. The mausoleum was shut during our stay in Vietnam, but I wouldn't want to visit anyway. The actual building was quite ugly and uninviting.

Hardly could take photos!. I found the guards in green quite abrupt and annoying while we were going through the mausoleum and the residence . At the mausoleum, while walking briskly , the guards would rush us along, even nudging us with their hands to make us hurry.

Macbre and somber. Very similar to the Lenin Mausoleum in Moscow. Long Lines to be expected. Entry is not allowed during the months of Sept. and October. The site is still beautiful and the nearby attraction are worth the visit, especially the house in which Ho lived in. It is very simple and humble. The parks and grounds around his residence is very beautiful, a very calm and peaceful setting.

Don't go on a weekend. The line to get into the mausoleum was unbelievable. We assumed it's because we were there on a weekend... but maybe not. We did not get in line.... next trip. But the surrounding grounds and exhibits were interesting, particularly Ho Chi Minh's house - amazingly modest for such a big-shot.

Not opened in September and October. You cannot enter inside in September and October. But, spacious outside of the mausoleum is nice. You can see the bamboo gardens both sides of the mausoleum which is the symbol of Vietnam war. This is a must visit place in Hanoi due to its historical background. Apart from the mausoleum there are couple of more attractions about Ho which are also must visit places.

A very quick glimpse of one of Vietnam's most famous men. First things first, make sure your shoulders are covered. I made the mistake of wearing a vest top on a very hot day and got turned away. Once I returned with a long sleeve top we got directed into a long queue. You need to hand your bags into security and you're not allowed to take cameras in.They assemble you into large groups and lead you to the Mausoleum itself. There are a number of rules to adhere to, no chewing, no photos, no hands in pockets, no talking and even no smiling. You are very much rushed through and are in and out in a matter of minutes.However they are a very cool few minutes. To see the body of such a hugely important figure in Vietnamese history was amazing.It's a very interesting place and worth a visit.

History crash course without the dullness. At first, I thought I wouldn't enjoy a mausoleum stay, but turns out, they have really good and interesting pieces like vintage cars and such. The building is quite simple from the outside and the architecture may not be appealing to young audiences, but it was worth the try. Coming into the building was a marvel, and if there is one thing that I really liked about the place, it was how they presented the artifacts to make it less sanitary (like most museums that look like hospitals with hanging pictures.) This was a bit different, especially with the different shapes and pieces that they exhibit. It was a great way to present Hanoi's history.

A must visit. You can't go to Hanoi without visiting the Mausoleum. It is a huge parcel of Hanoi/Vietnam's history. The building housing Ho Chi Minh's Body is not open in Sept & Oct but there is so much history to make a visit to the Mausoleum a must but don't walk over the white lines as the guards will blow their whistles and instruct you not to proceed. We witnessed a lady trying to take a photo and didn't realise she's overstepped the line until the whistles started.

Iconic image of Hanoi, A must visit!. The Mausoleum is of significant importance to the Vietnamese. It holds the preserved body of former leader Ho Chi Minh. No photos are allowed inside and you basically walk in a square around the body. Whether the body is real or not is debatable for for me it's not about that. It's about showing respect for the man who did such great things for Vietnam. I recommend looking at Ho Chi Minh's wikipedia page beforehand. It makes a great photo from the outside, especially at night.

Don't be put off by the queues. At first the size of the lines outside the entrance to the mausolem was a little daunting - but don't worry, they move quite fast. You will be required to hand in your phones and cameras but the process of collection and their return is very efficient. When you get into the mausolem do not slow down - or else. I did, for a better look, and a young man holding a very business-like rifle with a particularly sharp bayonet on top grabbed my arm and gave me a strong push to keep going - so I did! The outside of the monument is impressive and if you time it right you will be able to witness the changing of the guard. After the mausolem, make sure you visit Ho's house that's nearby.

Interesting place to visit. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is in Ba Dinh Square, Hanoi. Cameras were taken from us on arrival and given back at the end of the visit to the body. We were lined up two by two and marched in past the body of Ho Chi Minh. Soldiers with guns were guarding all round the embalmed body. Ho Chi Minh was Prime Minister from 1945-1955 and President of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (North Vietnam). He died in 1969. Very interesting visit.
WATER PUPPET PERFECTION. This is the original, the best, and never to be missed when in Hanoi. Wish they had better selection of puppets to purchase after show but I am sure that is coming!
Big Square Tomb. This is a serious big tomb with a fore court and avenue big enough to use as a run way for a 747. Some serious guards who do not like to be photographed.

Lovely view of the Mausoleum. You need to know that it is closed on Mondays and Fridays, but that the body of Ho Chi Minh is removed in September for three months and the Mausoleum is not open for viewing, so you just get to see the outside.

Famous Place. It is a world famous place you you need to stop and get a picture here. If you come in the morning or night you can see a flag putting up or taking down ceremony. Not supposed to get on the grass. Not a whole lot to do, but famous place to put on your I saw that list.

Shhh....don't wake him up. Evidently HCM wanted to be cremated but after death was overruled...so that people could pretend he was just sleeping and not really dead. So much for honoring last wishes....or accepting his human nature. It is a large and imposing building and there is a lot of symbolism, along with the changing of the guard (not as grand as at Westminster to be sure) but the interesting thing I noticed is that while the square is immense and the 'road' is expansive in front of it, there are no benches or other seating sites to be found. Maybe if you sat and contemplated it all you would realize he really is dead....not sleeping

Uncle Ho. Great to see Uncle Ho balmed in a glass coffin. Just to say you have seen him you should go there. But the only thing is there is a long cue and only open in the morning 6-11 am and you can only be inside for like 10 seconds
Taking A Glimpse at Viet History. The grounds are well-maintained & clean.Tourist Lines/queues are long but organized.Restrooms are clean but you have to pay

Stay off the grass. A brutalist grey structure behind a massive expanse of heavily guarded lawn. Unfortunately Uncle Ho was at his annual spa in Moscow getting "rejuvenated" so the interior was closed. Impressive symbolism and worth seeing.

Nice part of Hanoi!. If you want a vast empty space in Hanoi, this is your spot! You can actually walk freely - no bikes, no one selling you things, no one bumping into you! There are nice gardens and the Mausoleum is impressive so if you have the time, pay it a visit:-)

Places to see in Hanoi.. It was closed for renovation and the body of Ho Hi Ming is in Russia being re-preserved. Would have liked to have seen that but oh we'll. still a pretty impressive place to see.

3rd time to Hanoi and he is always away getting "fixed". Ho Chi Minh has not been in the mausoleum on the 3 separate trips I have been to Hanoi. The website didnt say anything and my hotel didn't know - but when I got there the guards told me he has been in Russia getting fixed for over 3 months. Dont bother going to see the site as your time is better spent elsewhere.

Closed. What else can you say, I suppose it has to be done, but didn't know till we got there. A bonus was seeing the 1000's of people lining up for the funeral of the recently departed General, fascinating, I can't imagine any Australian person I would line up to pay my respects too!
An important monument. Uncle HO still exists but only just/. He was far bigger than in real life I think. For history buffs like me it was just another piece in the jigsaw that was the Vietnam war.
Nothing special, you may skip this ........ Nothing special of this Mausoleum :-( The queueing makes you only tired. You may skip this place unless you have nothing to do .......
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. This is very well organised. the queues are long but they move quite quickly and it is free. it is well worth a visit.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Place is huge. The "body" you see inside is not Ho Chi Minh - its a replica. And the queue is pretty long. You need to budget about 1 to 1.5 hours at least. Be warned.
Very interesting for a look. Very interesting for a look . You do have to line up go early but the line does go quite fast as you are not allowed to stop they keep you moving

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Although there was a long queue, it moves really quickly. You can see that Ho Chi Minh is still revered by the locals, and you can feel the atmosphere. And he is still really very well preserved. The gardens at the back are well worth a visit. Dont forget to wear appropriate clothes!!!

Ho Chi Mihns mausoleum.. Although the crowd's are huge and the queue seems endless it is very well organized and you do move quickly through the building, try and go on an organized tour with a guide you will get preference over the normal visitors and jump most of the queues.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. An unusual and slightly spooky experience. Saw Uncle Ho' lying in State and the man is obviously revered by the locals. Queues not too bad but very strict re photography and dress code. The grounds are beautiful and it's interesting to see his two, very basic homes on site.

You have to go.... This is one of the most interesting things I ever saw in all my travels...Initially didnt know what to expect, just went with an open mind. What I observed in addition to Ho Chi Minh was the deep devotion the Vietnamese held for him even to this day. The only thing that spoiled the moment was tourist talking while walking around the coffin...please show some respect when you go. And ladies wear a long skirt it it is considered culturally inappropriate to go in pants you may be refused entry.

Unique. It's quite incredible actually. Make sure you're in the queue at opening time as it is not open all day. The line can be quite long but it moves along at a good pace. At various points, you have to submit backpacks and bags etc . Remember to keep your receipt for each point and there are no problems collecting your stuff. You cannot take camera's or mobile phones into the Mausoleum. There are plenty of soldiers ensuring people do the right thing.You do get to see inside the casket on 3 sides from a reasonable proximity. It's a unique experience.Remember to note the opening times in advance.
A non event. We're not able to go inside as the mausoleum was closed, so in fact the trip there was a waste of time, besides that it was rai I g which made the trip miserable
Closed. The Mausoleum is closed for a couple of months each year. The building is impressive and the gardens nice. The boulevarde in front is impressive but of course the point is to see Ho Chi Minh!

Imposing. We did not go inside as "Uncle Ho" goes off to Russia for 3 months a year for touch up's but we walked around the outside - it is similar to Lenin's mausoleum ( Russian engineers helped build it) and very imposing

A moving tribute. Its amazing what some rain and travelling here in September does for crowds. Last time we were here we queued for nearly 2 hrs.We recently travelled back with friends and went along again with them. We walked straight in. And because there wasnt the pressure to get the crowds through quickly, we could walk through the Mausoleum more slowly and really take it in.I wonder what Ho Chi Min would say! This was something he specifically didnt want after he passed away, and yet here he is for the world to see for all eternity.

Closed in Summer. The place is monumental in a Greek classical sense. Visitors just milled around outside, as the place is closed for a month or so every year to tidy up any embalming issues. Nice in a massive sort of way.

?. We were really excited to visit. We got there.. and were not permitted inside due to renovations. So I guess check to see if they have finished before you plan your day around it. We ended up bummed and had to come up with a new plan.
Forced homage. I couldn't find any way to see the residence except by going through here. It is personality cult used to protect the current regime leaders. Avoid if you can.

Interesting - Worth Stopping By if you have time. The mausoleum was an interesting stop - seeing Ho Chi Minh's body was a unique experience. If you go, make sure that you have something that covers your shoulders and knees. Also, they will take your camera from you (this totally freaked me out so I wish I had known it was coming). When you go through security, they will give you a bag to put your camera in and you will need to hand it in to them before you go into the mausoleum - they will give you a number that matches the number on the bag that you put your camera in. After you go through the mausoleum, there is another little office outside and you give them your number and they return your camera to you. After that, you can swing by the house where Ho Chi Minh spent some the end of his time - it's worth stopping by as well.

go for the Ho Chi Minh houses. to me the best part was not the mausoleum per day, it is the "three house" where Ho Chi Minh end up his days.looking at that you will be able to understand why the Viet people adores his old leader.by the way, there is fees for every attraction, but they are around 1 to 2 USD so it is like free... it is just a matter to organize your time to take full advantage on what Vietnam can offer you

Mausoleum & Residence - go early and dress appropriately :). The dress code is strict - shoulders and back covered, clothes to at least knees etc. You must also check in backpacks, large bags, and water to the free luggage check in. The complex is only open from 830 to around 11am so timing is important. I get there around 930am and join the long queue. All up, it's probably 1km or so of queuing under shaded awning. Luckily today it was busy but we moved forward at a slow walking pace rather than being stopped. It ends up being a scenic and leisurely stroll through the park grounds so it's not too bad.I watch the changing of the guards in their crisp white uniforms, bayonets, and sharply defined steps. Entering the Mausoleum we are gestured by guards to remove hats and be silent. We file through the marblesque tomb past Ho Chi Minh embalmed and under spotlight. He looks rather like a wax figure from Madam Tussaud's. I don't know why people say it's creepy; I thought it was very reverent.I loved the moment when the guards around Uncle Ho changed and two of the young men smiled at each other as they swapped. The young guy struggled for a few moments to swap the smile for a Buckingham Palace guard type look and had to keep his face ducked down; I'm not sure if anyone else noticed.From there, we file outside and follow the path through the grounds. The Presidential Palace is viewed from the outside as is the Stilt House - though the windows are open so that we can view the interior. It looks homey and I can see why it would be more comfortable living there by the lake then in the palace.

Impressive!. We visited the Ho Chi Minh Square on our first morning in Vietnam. The mausoleum was closed, but we did have an opportunity to walk the grounds, which were exquisitely maintained. We chanced upon a new group of recruits in their dress whites. The Vietnamese are very proud of this site, but I'm not sure Ho Chi Minh himself would have appreciated the extravagant surroundings.
Miss the mausoleum. Not something that has to be seen, cold concrete,officious and grim guards, unlike the joyous mausoleum of Gandhi in Delhi. However his palace and gardens are very pleasant.

It is a copy of Lenin's Tomb in Moscow.. I went to the mausoleum with a student. The line was long and they opened over an hour late. It was the "first day" of this 9-month exhibit. You need to understand that, every year for three months" the body is sent to Moscow for restoration. So, one can think that this is closed from October through December. If you have valuables, you will have to check EVERYTHING before entering. I felt uneasy leaving my expensive camera and accessories as well as cell phone with security and then getting a numbered chip in order to reclaim them. It is efficient, fast and painless. I have NEVER heard of a theft of any item during this check in.Inside the entrance and through the meandering stairs, they are picky about how you comport yourself: no hands behind your back, always showing, silence or the lowest whisper ever, and you can not stop! Seeing the body in the glass enclosure, fresh, clear and clean, was an "unreal" experience with the body of Ho Chi Minh seemingly floating just above the bottom of the 8-foot tall enclosure, the body is at the lowest level and, right after that, one climbs up and out and into an open area where items are claimed and the experience completed.Imagine if George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, John F Kennedy or Martin Luther King, Jr. Were entombed and you were able to see them floating in clear embalming fluid. It is a deep experience and, for the Vietnamese, Ho Chi Minh is equivalent to how we revere those I mentioned earlier.Worth going and there is no fee that I can remember.

huge construction. it gives the idea of breathing again after being in the old quarter where all is very narrow. this is a big open space. I could not enter into the mausoleum cause it was closed for 2 months.
It's big. If you like big slabs of concrete & red flags etc you'll like this but the only 'impressive' (sad) thing about it, is it's size. What a waste of space & resources!

Attractions. Alas the Mausoleum itself was closed as Ho Chi Minh was not in residence as he had been transported back to Russia for treatment. The museum was very interesting and the gardens were lovely.

Pay your respects to Ho Chi Minh. It was raining but we joined the queues to file in and past Ho Chi Minh who is protected by armed guard. Single file, eyes forward, no bags, steady pace. Well worth it. The line kept moving and it didn't take long but I wouldn't have missed it
Too long wait. Went here early in morning as advised but queuing was so long that we came away. We're told later that others had queued for over 1 hour.
Cold. This is the most imposing cold looking building I have ever seen, check opening hours before going to see as if its closed you will be disappointed.

Lots to see and do here at this attraction. There is a small fee for this attraction but very well worth the money. It is an amazing place and the security it very strict. The visit through the Mausoleum is very solemn which is to be expected. You need to allow enough time to all of the displays in the grounds here. Ho's house, palace, grounds which are stunning, museum and lots to learn.

Ho Chi Minh. We were there during one of their public holidays so the place was opened to the public for free. But there was a huge crowd, so we had to stand in line for a long time just to enter. Then we were ushered out in less than 2 minutes. Therefore, try not to visit during public holidays. The garden and the square around it were impressive.

Seeing Ho Chi Minh. Went to see Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and found it a fantastic experience! It was good to see the preserved/embalmed Ho Chi Minh but was also impressed to see so many Vietnamese people visiting the Mausoleum and how much they respect Ho Chi Minh. The whole complex including the museum and his house was very impressive and well done. Very glad I went to see it.
Excellent. How interesting! If you are interested in the history of Vietnam this is a must. Procedure to enter the mausoleum is formal and respectful and well worth waiting for. Interesting!

Cold Austere Architecture. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a large memorial of Ho Chi Minh. It was open in 1975 and it is built in the spirit of the Lenin's Mausoleum in Moscow. We were able only to see it from the outside. Our guide stated the Ho Chi Minh was away for maintanance which is periodically scheduled. We watched the change of guard in front of the Mausoleum.

A must see in Hanoi. You can't understand Vietnam without understanding something of Ho Chi Minh. The Mausoleum is an absolute highlight of Hanoi. Be prepared for a long queue, or your guide may be able to get you in quicker. It is well worth it. The experience is both eeirie and respectful at the same time and the whole building and area in front is very impressive. Don't miss this!!
Don't know what to think. Very strange thing to do, impossible to rate really, hence the average score. Not really sure what i thought about it.

Uncle Ho. Visting Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was ok, u dont get much time but actually also dont need any longer to walk around his body. Long Queing before need to be calculated, it does take a lot of time. it was closed when we tried to go there at friday. u should go in the morning.

Interesting. Make sure to drop off in entrance gate. Our cab dropped us off at the back of mausoleum, since we didn't know about the entrance we were walking aimlessly since to enter mausoleum you need to put your bag in counter. And they don't allow you to take picture inside the mausoleum. I found out people who queuing are hesitate taking picture before the entrance ,afraid if the camera will be taken. Since we were walking backward, we freely took picture outside the mausoleum :p
Mausoleum HCMC. The queue was very long but guards moved people along efficiently and quickly. Was a bit rushed inside but still worth visiting.

Hard to find the entrance and rubbish signposts. When we finally found the mausoleum we were most unimpressed. On the map, it looks like you can just walk straight up to the front. When we got there, guards told us we couldn't walk across the grass to the mausoleum and had to walk all the way around to the entrance. And when I say told I mean grunted and waved at. If you have a tour guide, it might be better/easier. I'd heard that you can actually go see the body, but when we got there it looked closed and there wasn't a line anywhere, so I'm not sure what happened. Probably check the opening hours. Ho Chi Minh museum is just next door. Don't waste your money visiting it.
Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. The snaking line is very long but efficiently monitored so it moves fast. A must see. The exit leads you to the presidential palace and then to Ho Chi Minh's residence.

Haunting. We were almost put off by the queue, it was the first day opening after Uncle Ho's annual restoration of is body.I was impressed by the solemn speed of which the queue was handled and the reverance of the people, tourists and Vietnamese alike.Not to be missed.
Not so interesting. Luckily for us it was pouring, so the queues were very short for what is basically a walk around a dead body!
Interesting resting place. The concept still boggles my mind that this is an attraction. Morbid and it lasts only about 30seconds then it's done. Grounds are beautiful

It should be done but don't expect to be blown away.... It's definitely worth seeing if you have some time to kill one morning (definitely try and avoid the crowds in the midday sun!) but it is a slightly strange experience and it's over in less than a couple of minutes. The gardens however are not worth the price.

Heads up. We didn't know you needed to be wearing long pants in order to enter the mausoleum so it was a fairly brief visit. Make sure you have pants and I think they don't want you to be in sandals either.

Look Mom, no motorcycles on the street!. The grounds outside may be worth seeing during the cooler part of the day but beware that some weeks (or months) there is just nothing happening here other than a wide street without motorcycles (an even worth seeing) and a big building where you're not even allowed to get near.

Essential Visit. Any visitor to Hanoi must come here to view Ho Chi Minh's glass encased body, if only to observe the reverance and importance placed upon it by the Vietnamese.Be prepared to cover shoulders and knees, hand in cameras and take off sunglasses prior to the lengthy but orderly queue to get in.Then spend the 60 seconds or so shuffling around the 'tomb' and back out into Hanoi.
Visit to the grounds. We visited this attraction on a Friday, unfortunately the mausoleum was closed but the grounds are beautiful

strange but phenomenal experience. We were not sure what to expect when going to Uncle Ho's mausoleum but there is nothing macabre about this. We visited on a Saturday and joined the queue with thousands of Vietnamese people who were making their pilgrimage, everyone is willing to tell you how great a man Ho Chi Minh was and what he did for the people of Vietnam. The police\guards on duty keep the queue moving and ensure that everyone remains respectful by removing sunglasses, being quite etc. We did this as part of a private tour so our guide was able to give us any and all information on the life of Ho Chi Minh and what he means to the people of Vietnam.A truly humbling experience.
A must. Convenient waiting lines for walk through the mausoleum. Did not need to wait more than 15 minutes until get inside. Interesting to see the Vietnamees people honoring their old president

A must, organisation is far better than Lenin in Moscow or Mao in Beijing. If you only have half a day in Hanoi, this is a must visit site, there are only a handful of individuals revered by all of their own people and Uncle Ho is one of them.Very interesting collection of buildings, interiors, cars etc - all linked to his life.The complex is far more thoughtful than that of other embalmed communist leaders; and only when you visit Vietnam do you realise how high his status continues to be.

An historic monument, but that's it. This is a national monument as here lies Ho Chi Minh's body.In the end the monument itself is nothing special.Some people like joining a tour to see Ho Chi Minh's body, but this is not always possible.We did not care to go inside, so I would not know about that.This place is ok if you want to just get a pic of the building and after a few minutes you are done with it.I would rather spend more time wandering in the old town.

Fascinating. It s a mausoleum. The concept in itself is interesting. Yes it is very authoritarian and the line was long but hey it moved far quicker than most lines at disney or anywhere in the uk ! Have visited Mao in China so knew what to expect re security, bag check in etc so no surprise there. It is definitely worth a visit even if you are herded or rushed through. Make sure you are dressed conservatively - long trousers / knee covered at least and covered shoulders and arrive early ( we were there at 8.30 am and the line was huge! ) Not an issue for young children but take a cardigan or something in case . Uncle Ho is revered in Vietnam, this much is obvious. Well worth a visit. Even young children find it interesting.

Surreal experience. Rated on Rough Guides as one of the most creepy places in the world, I had to try this out. I wouldn't necessarily agree with them and say it's the creepiest place in the world. I'd change the adjective to "Surreal". Guided around like sheep, climbing the building steadily, until finally entering the main room - Uncle Ho lies there, in rest, lit gently by amber coloured lights, guarded by four armed guards, while other uniform clad generals of the parade line the red carpet and ensure you don't take photos or walk with your hands behind your back. Very regimented, but worth the visit. Only open from 8-10 in the mornings (Closed on Fri and Mon).

WORTH A VISIT. It is very heavily gaurded which was such a shock to us. Armed gaurds and if they did not like the look of you, they just pulled you out of line. We were not told that women had to have shoulders and legs covered out of respect. So my niece had to quickly purchase some scarves from a local shop to cover up. History of the place is interesting.

Don't miss this one. It sounds like an odd place for tourists to go, but it is a very interesting place. Be sure to explore the gardens around Ho's little house, and the house itself. If you really want to see something diffrerent, go back at night for the flag lowering ceremony. Watch the locals around you, and witness first-hand how much they still love Ho.

Interesting experience. Visiting the Mausoleum was an interesting experience and well worth doing when in Hanoi but that's about it. I guess it means a lot more to Vietnamese people than to us Europeans.

breath taking. being a left thinking person, Ho was always my hero.Last time we visited Hanoi,(3 years ago), the mausoleum was closed on the day we had available. This time, we visited. I was spell bound to be in his presence, and by the magnificent presentation. A highlight.

Very good. Was here around seven years agoGreat building and amazing to see the preserved bodyDon't miss it Forget what it costNot much anywayVietnam is a great place to goVery safe and friendly peopleGreat oil paintings to buy tooHighly recommended

HCM Mausoleum. Packed full of Vietnamese "pilgrims" and tourists usually the waiting time is pretty long. The visit itself lasts about 2 minutes. Ho Chi Minh is laying in an open coffin while visitors pass him in an eternal slow flow without stopping. It's worth a visit but lasts only short time. Many locals say that he was replaced by a wax figure a long time ago. The mausoleum is closed in November, opening hours are 8 to 11 daily except friday.
The man. So well organised to get in, didn't take long, nice gardens surrounding the building . Needed more information or perhaps and area with information about him - photos of his life

Alright for free entry. We went to the Mausoleum as it was rated on here as a worthy place to visit. It's a good place to walk around for less than an hour, but I wouldn't call it incredible. We saw ex-president Ho Chi Minh, and the one pillar pagoda. Expect very strict entry conditions including baggage removal, and camera/phone removal further in. A tip for women - ensure your knees and shoulders are covered or you won't be permitted entry.

Impressive. Before you go in make sure you know all the rules before going to the Mausoleum. Women need to have their shoulders covered and big bags are not allowed in as well as cameras. There are lockers to store all of your things. But as long as you put your camera in your bag you are fine. They have guards watching you at all times. The line to the Mausoleum is LONG but moves quite fast. There really is no signs of the rules so when you get to security check point you get told things. I must say the staff at the Mausoleum are very unfriendly and rude. I asked a question and they just pushed me on or completely ignored me, this happened twice to me. They yelled at people for doing something they didn't know they weren't suppose to do. This is the first thing you do when you get to the whole Ho Chi Minh Complex and it really leaves a bad taste in your mouth. I must say they are efficient when you go in the Mausoleum and the Mausoleum is impressive. It is kind of peaceful walking through but it is very fast and then you are ushered out again. It is free and interesting to visit just beware of the guards and don't let the line scare you it really isn't that long of a wait.
A must see in Hanoi. We enjoyed finding out more about Ho Chi Minh from our guide and found the visit to see him both interesting and reflective.

Definitely worth a visit -. This was the first of several historic sites we visited while on a 3 day visit to Hanoi as part of a long Vietnam tour. Got there early which was useful as the crowds were already queuing! However it is managed with military efficiency so it moves along quite nicely.. Very hot when in the open air queue so wear a hat, loose clothing but must be respectful and wear skirt or shorts that hit or go below your knee and shoulders must also be covered. This definitely had all the associations we expect of a communist regime and it leaves you in no doubt as to the historic significance and reverence the country has for Ho Chi Minh. Really interesting experience.

Over the top. It didn't take long for me to get a bit tired of Ho Cho Minh in Vietnam, where he is basically their Savior. Pictures everywhere, sayings, etc. It's so strange for an American. The Mausoleum is huge and very "Soviet" in style. We waited in line over an hour before being whisked through the doors into the freezing air/con to march silently around the huge sarcophagus. Uncle Ho is looking pretty good for a dead guy! If you're in Hanoi, you gotta go. I mean, it's Ho Chi Minh.

The mausoleum is another must see in Hanoi. Although the architecture is a bit dour the mausoleum is another must see in Hanoi. The changing of the guard is well worth seeing and hopefully you will be lucky enough to be there when the local children are visiting. They are absolutely charming.

A must do in Hanoi.. A must see attraction, we went early in the morning and the queue was only about 15 minutes but we were told it is much busier later and it closes in the middle of the day. It is very well organised and very strict regulations adhered by the soldiers so respect the area you are in. A guide to and after the visit we found a great asset to learn more about Ho Chi Minh, the area around the centre is extremely well kept and other buildings and gardens are included in the visit.
Impressive. Impressive, especially seeing the reactions of Vietnamese people coming from all over the country to visit.
okay. Not much to look at. The guards are not is the same league as their English counterparts. The march is all wrong!!

Long queue but it was worth it. I came around 8 and was pretty shocked with the queuing. There were many Vietnam people who also visit this place. They really have high appreciation to their leader.Eventhough the queuing was long (maybe almost 1 km long), it didn't take much time to finally enter Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. I was stunned by what I see inside the building. This place is worth a visit.

A strange experience. You may have to queue for a while (avoided if you get there for about 8am), but this is definitely a worthwhile experience. After walking all the way from the tourist entrance to the main building itself, you're led 2-by-2 into the room which holds Ho Chi Minh himself. It really makes you realise to what extent Ho Chi Minh is revered amongst the Vietnamese people.One minute after you get into the main room, it's all over, as the queue is constantly moving forward at a slow pace.

Morbid but essential. Really can't be in Hanoi and not do this. Obviously "obsessively" revered with massively regimented process and queues. The men white uniforms are only security guards but in typical Viet fashion they look like highly decorated generals. They are the decorum police so DON'T put hands in pockets or wear a hat or slouch or walk slow. Our guide would not say anything controversial in there because thought police active there. He was critical back in the bus. The presidential palace (still functioning) good picture for French architecture and Ho Chi Minh house and gardens are very nice. Another must see

Different. Mmmm ok, if you like going to look at embalmed old men kept in a beautiful freezer then this is for you! Seriously though, you cannot visit Hanoi and not go and see Uncle Ho. It is almost identical to Lenin in Moscow complete with honour guard. You will have to leave you bag at the baggage counter along with your camera at another counter further along the line (dont ask!). The queue moves quite fast so dont worry if it seems long. Also note that this (at the moment) is only open from 8am to 11am although there is a sign stating that they are considering opening until 5pm in the near future. We will see..

Take 20 minutes to see HCM but time it right. We went to see HCM first thing in the morning. We had to surrender my water and check my camera but we only waited in line maybe 10 min. We were led through a very dimly lit and well air conditioned processional past his body that could have been in a wax museum. It was interesting how well guarded his body was! At the exit I picked up my camera. I don't think I'd wait more than 30 min in the heat to see this, especially with kids. But I thought it was interesting and we also went to his residence and one pillar pagoda. Be sure you are dressed appropriately. Women must cover their shoulders and knees--no shorts or tank tops!

Well what can you say. Difficult to rave about a mausoleum really when you are herded single file into a small room containing a glass box with Uncle Ho embalmed within. Its def worth a visit though just to say you have seen Ho in the "ahem" flesh as it were.Limited open hours (8am to 11am) so get there early - we got there about 9am and there was still a huge queue covering a number of blocks. We managed to gate crash a line and have no idea how we did it, a security guard beckoned us over and told us to join a line and we went straight into the building. There seemed to be a number of different queues and some where having their bags checked, others (like us) when through with our bags and no one blinked.Single file you are ushered into the main room and there he is, lying in state, surrounded by guards who usher you along - you can't stop moving nor can you take pictures (that would be rather morbid though).No entrance fee so if you are up and about early, you have to go and see him.

You can't leave Vietnam without visiting this place. Very interesting and impressive site. The queue was long when we visited but it went rather smoothly. Go as early as possible to prevent waiting to long. There were mainly Vietnamese people in line from all over the country. Don't forget to visit the wooden house where he lived in. It shows the modesty of Ho Chi Minh.

Too much regimented walking in the heat!. I guess every visitor, as well as every Vietnamese, has to 'pay their respects' to Uncle Ho. It was all too controlled and regimented for me with much walking in procession around the block.We were inside for barely a minute as the line processed around the glass case in which his (supposedly) embalmed body lay in state - not dead our guide said, just sleeping! I couldn't even take a photo!By the time we got to Uncle Ho's stilt house and the Museum, I had had enough and couldn't raise the enthusiasm to go inside. I was pouring with sweat because of the 'long trek' and the humidity.This visit was part of the Hanoi City Tour but I would suggest that their are much more interesting places to see in Hanoi.

unbelievable. I cannot give advise on this except... We went to the mausoleum and so did 3 kilometers of people. That was the length of the queue waiting to get in. So if you are prepared to stand in a line for around 3 hours so you can go in for 20 seconds do so but take lots of water and an umberella for shade. The crowds where well behaved and patient, lots of army personal and a huge police presence, all very regimented.

amazing. Just to see how many people who line up for ages to see his body is what is amazing he is so important to the north Vietnamese as he is the one they think gave their freedom from the oppressors France and USA

This goes to the heart of what made modern VIetnam. Really worth going to and seeing the whole complex. There are long queues. We got there near to 10.00am and the line wasn't so bad and we saw the changing of the guard. It took about 15 minutes in the line.

Don't go on a weekend - it's too busy. We first went on a weekend and the line was about 5 k's long and over an hour wait. We went back on a Tuesday and there was no line and we were in in about 5 minutes.

Very serious place. From the time we got off the bus,one could tell this was a place where everything was a very important place to be. The first thing that struck me besides the heat( it was a very open place with little shade) was how tourist orientated it was. everyone had to queue in an orderly manner. The queue was fairly long as alot of people here. There were soldiers everywhere on duty. The condition of entry into the Mausoleum proper were no cameras,sunglasses off as also hats.I saw first hand the "no camera" policy. One gent with us was taken aside and his camera confiscated until the guards were satisfied he had taken no photos of "Uncle Ho". Otherwise it was worth the effort of going. Everything was spotlessly clean,inside and outside. However,once back outside of the Mausoleum proper, you could take photos to your hearts content. Be prepared to feel the heat though,as I previously said,it is a very open expanse of concrete.

Queues. Went here on a Sunday which in itself was probably a mistake, but it made Disney queues look pitiful. There were several entrances for pre-booked appointments, VIPs etc, but the main queue was in excess of a mile long and that's what we could see. Very little shade and zigzagged across several roads. Met people who had bothered to queue and said they found it worth it with people very moved by the experience. May be go during the week.

Loooong lines for locals. I felt sad that our tour group was allowed to cut the line rather than wait hours as the locals do. It was eerie seeing this very well preserved deceased body. There are lots of rules, no cameras, no big bags, no talking, no hands in pockets.

Nothing more, nothing less. It's really just one room. Security guards at the entrance will ask you to wear pants and closed shoes, but you can just ignore that and go inside. Same with the "security check", where they ask you to leave water bottles behind. You can just grab them and walk in anyway.
Impressive from the outside. This place was not open when we visited. Impressive from the outside and nice gardens around the back. Lots of guards keeping you off the grass and getting too close

Interesting.... It was interesting. Not everyday you see a deceased person so well preserved. Our group skipped the looooooooong line and once inside, our tour took all of 30-seconds. At least it was cool inside.
Long Que, yet worthwhile!. Despite the title I didn't manage to enter, but definitely coming back again! You literally get to see uncle Ho there and guards guarding the place like he is alive!

Communism is massive. If you like this sort of thing, it is awesome. See a dead god of communism. It is an eery and fittingly militaristic tribute. Don't talk too loud or the handsome guards will tell you off (ie respect) and make sure you wear shorts that go below your whole knees. I ended up having to buy and wear a skirt just to get to see it, which is disrespectful on my part. Long line, but then again, it is worth it. IF you like this sort of thing, which I thoroughly did.

Interesting attraction. Interesting. We got there around 8 or 8:30am and were one of the first groups of people let in. It is quite a long walk from the entry to the mausoleum but the walkways are all covered and apart from being very steamy weather it was quite a pleasant walk. The number of guards surrounding the grounds, body and mausoleum was a bit unnerving but overall it was worth seeing especially if you have limited time.

Must see in Hanoi.. This is a must see for any visitor to Hanoi. I actually went twice because you are not actually permitted to stop walking once inside the mausoleum. Don't be daunted by the long queue - it moves quickly. It's a great experience to see such an important historical figure. Make sure you wear appropriate clothing. Females must have their shoulders covered. Visit the Ho Chi Minh museum afterwards to learn more about him. Admission is only 20,000 dong, and children are free.
Cool place..no cameras. Go early, long lines, don't take bags. Don't take photos or get ready to be pulled out of line. Very touristy stalls next to the exit.

Overwhelming, HOT and take plenty of water ....and a fan!. Queuing the line to view Ho Chin Minh was an experience in itself. There were literally thousands of people young and old wanting to pay there respects. But if you don't like queues DONOT go on a Sunday ok haha or during school holidays for that matter! And ps the guards are ruthless in demanding respect for ho chin Minh, so people don't wear your hat or take photos whilst in or entering the mausoleum .... Don't go unless you have read the lonely planet guide at sacred ground in Vietnam !

Visit Uncle Ho. This is an important place to visit to have an understanding of Ho Chi Minh's place in the hearts of the Vietnamese people. There are strict rules about dress and behavior at the mausoleum.

Very Solemn Visit. I just came back from the Ho Chi Minh Maouseleum and I was really impressed by it, although I may not adore and celebrate Ho Chi Minh like the Vietnamese people it still is a great site and offers you a once in a lifetime glimpse of an important historical figure. The lines are crazy long and two times we had to wait and watch the veterans and schoolchildren behind us get in first but as long as its not raining it can be okay and it's awesome seeing the guards march around and stand guard. Ho Chi Minh's body was perfectly preserved nothing gruesome but it might be kind of intimidating for a child. I was reading a lot of reviews on here with people complaining about unfriendly guards but do keep in mind they are not guides or information kiosks they are decorated officials who are not there to help confused tourists. To enter the attraction you must cover your knees and shoulders which is pretty much a given but we saw way too many people dressed like they were going to the beach and they were turned away, so keep in mind to cover up! Overall this is a great trip and offers a glimpse of history you will never forget......seriously!

Great history and a must visit. It was a very hot day, so make sure you take lots of water, wear sunscreen and a hat! We went on a Sunday which was clearly the busiest day for locals visiting! But it didn't put us off. We queued for just over 2 hours, but it was worth the wait. You have to hand your cameras in, so make sure you label it! There's a beer Hoi close by which made for a welcome lunch break afterwards.

A must see. You haven't been to Vietnam if you haven't visited the mausoleum of Ho Chi Mihn. It is very touching to feel the piousness of the vietnamese people standing in the line in their best clothes. The mausoleum is only open af few hours in the morning, and you have to expect a long queue which is part of the experience though.
A must Do? I guess if you have the time.. Worth it if you have the time, but don't worry if you don't. Classic communist style mausoleum styled after Lenin's.
Free and very cool. It was a very cool experience getting in line with tons of people, tourists and vietnamese alike and walking past HCM's preserved body.

You still kinda have to go see Ho Chi Minh. Okay...its a dead guy preserved since 1969 and you get to queue for a mile or two and go see him. But it Vietnam and hes such a big part of the history of the last century in the country. So take the time and visit.

Crowd control takes precedence over experience of a great historical figure. We found the structured conveyor belt style of access a bit stifling. Being required to line up two aside and progress through the venue wile being overseen by armed soldiers a bit unwelcoming. We really wanted wanted to understand the man and his esteem among the populace, but we felt like we would be shot on sight if we looked like we might be enjoying it. Fair enough, we accept the NO Camera stuff, but we were also directed by an armed soldier to remove our sunglasses as we approached the building. Why? Loosen up guys, some of us actually appreciate what Uncle Ho did for this country, but we don't need to feel like you would detain us if you felt the luminescence of his embalmed majesty was somehow diminished by our Maui Jims.

Cold War remnant?. We went with a very good and passionate guide, who gave us the low-down on what was going on (I'd recommend a guide). In order to avoid the queue which was >2km long (seriously), we just did a lap of the big black box (the outer stone thing that presumably covers Ho Chi Minh's plasticized perspex encased remains) and the surrounding buildings. It was seriously like what one see's on TV in North Korea or from the Soviet / Mao era - it was a sad anachronism given that HCM stated that he wanted his ashes scatter about Vietnam. Well worth a 1h lap of the box and surrounds.

One has to visit. One has to visit if one is in Hanoi and has not visited before but there isn't really much to see. If you are not with a knowledgeable guide make sure you do so reading before the visit.

A must visit.. We went twice. Once at 5.30am to see the Vietnamese flag being raised. It is amazing to see all the locals in the square exercising before going to work. The second time we queued to go into the tomb. Do both if you can get up early enough!

Interesting place. We went on a Saturday as did many Vietnamese locals, the line was incredibly long and as usual it was a hot and humid day. You can not take any electronics (cameras/phones) with you into the Mausoleum, there is a holding place outside but luckily our guide took care of our items as someone got given the wrong camera after leaving.Once you get through the long line, the pushing children and those that think it is fine to just cut in front of you (there are lots of these sort of people in Vietnam) and you get inside it is a quick walk past the resting place of Ho Chi Minh, it is very interesting to see and even with what I have said it is worth it, his part in the history of Vietnam is undeniable. You spend way more time in line, walking into and out of the mausoleum than actually seeing Ho Chi Minh but I am only saying that so you are prepared, it is still worth it.
Great place to see. Loved it, especially when we went back at night and got to see all the locals exercising in the gardens. Definatley a must see

It is worth standing in line to visit. This is a huge part of the Vietnamese culture, and it should be visited and respected. There are other things like the automobile collection and the pagoda that are worth visiting
A must see. Great to see but be prepared to wait in long queues but moving slowly you are asked to move on no stopping .
Worth standing in the long queue!. Amazing to see the love of citizens towards the father of the nation! Had never seen the kind of queues and enthusiasm before.

School trip. The visit to the Mausoleum capped off a series of poignant and interesting backgrounders, from tour guides) to Ho Chi Minh and the important role he played in establishing Vietnam as an independent nation. Our students were impressed that it was free, surprised by the level of respect and security, but really pleased that they went. For most it was the first time they had seen an embalmed body.

Worth a visit. Well worth a visit, if only to see the passion and respect accorded to him from the Vietnamese people.Security is very tightly controlled and seemed rather "over the top" however it's their country and no worse than visiting the statue of liberty or anywhere similar these days.

Must see this. Ho Chi Minh is reverred as the leader who unified Vietnam. He wanted a quiet memorial but he got a huge Mausoleum where he lies preserved for all to see. This is commonly a field trip for young Vietnamese students and open to visitors for free. It is an interesting look at Vietnamese culture and crowd control. There are rules--no talking, no cameras, no hands in pockets, no hats, etc. And a fairly quick paced visit for viewing. Be sure to visit the park area by the mausoleum for a better look at how "Uncle Ho" spent his later days.

If you like seing corpses, this is for you.. You ate basically paraded round the dead body of uncle ho. Nothing more, other than seeing his garden (the old cars were decent) its nothing special, unless your into that type of thing.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Visited on a very hot day but was able to move slowly under a covered walkway. Countless groups of kindergarten school children were given priority to walk down the road and go ahead of the queue. Their colorful dress was lovely to see and they seemed very happy as they passed along on their way to see the body of their esteemed and respected liberator. We eventually got inside and walked around the glass case containing Uncle Ho. Interesting to find that his body had travelled to Russia where it had been re-embalmed for display. Also interesting to see the humble way in which he lived and was an example to his people. If in Ho Chi Min then a visit to this location does provide a better understanding of the country and its peoples.

Worth the wait. We almost bailed out when we saw the length of the queue - it took us 20 mins to walk from the drop off point to find the end of the queue! I expected to wait for hours! But it kept moving remarkably well and we were through in just over an hour and a quarter. Not something I would do a second time but definitely worth doing once.
Ho chi min mausoleum. Although you saw Ho for a very small time I thought the visit is well worth. Visiting his gardens with a guide is also a must

If you're in Hanoi as a foreigner then you need to thank the good Uncle for that.. Initially I thought "this is a bit over the top, queuing for about a kilometre to see the tomb of a past head of state". By the time we had passed through the inner chamber where Ho Chi Minh lies 'sleeping' we started to grasp the significance that this man had on unifying a country. All this visit will cost you is time so don't go thinking this is a 30min stop off. Be patient as you'll be rewarded with an understanding how far this country has come in the last 60 years.Remember to cover both shoulders & knees or you'll be pulled out of the queue. No shorts, no singlets.The gardens surrounding the main temple are well worth a wander.

The Mausoleum. I was amazed at how the crowd out front getting tickets turned into a quite moving line that approached the tomb with a smooth pace in and and a few minutes later out , remained peaceful quite after we left .

Truly memorable. We got to the complex around 10am on Sunday morning. The queues seemed long, but they moved steadily. We went to the back of the queue only to be beckoned by one of the attendants to come and join the queue closer to the front as we were European and they were clearly proud and pleased that we bothered to come and see the great man.
