I have never seen an embalmed person before and considering he died in 1969 he looked like he was asleep. Our children 18 and 15 were most impressed too.

The poor cousin of the Lenin Mausoleum. Don' t bother to visit, unless you are curious to see Ho Chi Minh for 30 seconds in his very own frozen state, while moving reverently down a long line of people and past soldiers standing at attention. They should have honored his wishes to be cremated.

Another must see and do.. Worth the time to pay ones respect to the founder of modern day Vietnam. Get there early, as the the queues can often be long. It is also worth a visit in the evening at around 9pm when the Soldiers perform a ceremonial event which is also nice to see on a warm summers night.

Interesting. Be prepared to wait a VERY long time (up to 2 hours) outside, before your 90 seconds inside. Be sure to arrive early in order to avoid the heat and the longest waits. However long (or short) the wait, it is indeed fascinating to see the body of the famous leader preserved. Those visiting include tourists and locals alike. Knees and shoulders must be covered, so dress appropriately. Photographing is not allowed inside.

Longest que I've ever been in but worth the expeance. The longest que I have ever been in but well worth the time. Took us an 90 mins but in that time was able to talk to many Vietnamese people and understand more about the way of life.

Weird experience, but should do if in Hanoi. Basically it's a massive line of people waiting to see Ho Chi Minh. The guards and atmosphere seemed quite strict, which is understandable given how important this man was to Vietnam. Once you are actually in the room with his body, you are not allowed to stop so make sure you get a good look. It was weird seeing a preserved body of a man who wished to be cremated and not be in the state that he is in now. By the way, no photos once you are inside the building

get in line. Ho Chi Minh is the great hero of the Vietnam people, it is free to come and see his body and there will be huge queues. I have travelled quite a lot, but never experiences a queue of this lenght before. Very strange seeing his very well preserved body even 44 yrs after his death. The time we got to spend in the mausoleum was probably about 1-2mins after about 1,5-2 hours queue, but definately worth it
The cult. Prepare to wait more than you stay inside (you cannot even stop). Feel the cult around Ho Chi Minh. Go if you find time.

Short visit to mausoleum. Was a short visit but depicted how famous and revered Ho Chi Minh was when he was still alive to his death. This man did a great deal for the Vietnamese. You can't take pictures of the mausoleum from the inside.

The experience is quite regimented. These displays of embalmed former leaders are always a bit strange, but Vietnamese visitors seemed to genuinely revere Ho Chi Minh. The experience is quite regimented but well-managed (no shorts, bare shoulders or other revealing clothing).

HCM is very charismatic even he is passed away. i like to get the special moment when i see the body of the HCM. he looks very charismatic and great.i'm sure he is the special one from the vietnam country.
Short but interesting.. We arrived early in the morning, and the line moved rapidly, efficient situation. Very strange looking at him.

It was closed on Monday afternoon. Didn't get to go inside the museum as it was closed on Monday afternoon. But it looks great from outside. Also noticed that as I was walking along the Mausoleum, there was a rope around so that visitors do not get too close. It is a scared place to revere Uncle Ho for Vietnamese.

Impressive display of patriotism. This attraction is possibly the most revered site in the whole of Vietnam. If you have the time you can walk here from the Old Quarter, taking in the interesting district nearby which houses all the foreign embassies styled according to their national traditions. Just head for Dien Bien Phu Road, checking out the statue of Lenin on your left and then zig zag up some of the side streets as you walk towards the Mausoleum. Take care to be early though as the Mausoleum admits it's last visitors at 10.15am and many tour buses dump dozens of sight seers. If you take a taxi, don't be alarmed when they drive past the Mausoleum, because the entry is around the back, where you will have to check in your backpack and other items. Take care to find out the latest time you can collect your belongings or you may have to come back another time. Cameras are allowed, but no photographs are permitted within the Mausoleum itself. After purchasing your ticket you can walk along a covered footpath but will then have to line up in the open for many metres to wait for admission in very small groups. If it is raining and you have no protection, you WILL be soaked. Wear modest clothing and behave respectfully otherwise you will be ejected.The building itself is an imposing Soviet style concrete edifice with plenty of attendants ensuring security and decorum. You will need to shuffle silently through the dimly lit chamber housing the vestige of the man himself and he is surrounded by no less than eight stiff guards all immaculately dressed in white, and seriously armed. No stopping is allowed. Having passed away in the late 70's, Uncle Ho is looking a bit pasty these days, even though his body is apparently sent annually to Russia for an embalming touch up. No disrespect intended. Afterwards wander through some nicely kept gardens and perhaps check out the nearby Ho Chi Minh Museum and One Pillar Pagoda.

Interesting visit. Check to ensure Uncle Ho is there before visiting.. We went on a Sunday and there were very long queues. Many local Vietnamese were also out to pay their respects to Ho Chi Minh. It was an interesting visit and well worth queuing for. After that we also visited the Presidential areas and HCM's house on stilts. The most interesting thing for me as observing the admiration to locals have for their departed leader.

A Different Experience.. This is certainly an unusual way to spend an hour or so - but it's not something you'll do too often. Don't be put off by the queues - it all moves along pretty swiftly. Obey the requests of the guards, make sure you're properly dressed and also check the time for reclaiming your bag, as you might have to return after lunch if you're not sharp and spend too much time at the other places on the site.

Go as early as you can - massive queues. Arrived at 9 and queued for about 1 hr in a long procession of Vietnamese tourists. Definitely worth it. Stoic soldiers in sparkling white uniforms, with heavy backdrop of propaganda music and awe-inspiring geometric architecture. A must for any political enthusiast.

Bizarre, but interesting. This is a strange place, surreal in the sense that it is very strict on dress code etc., but not quite as austere as the similar mausoleum of Mao Tse-Tung in Beijing. A worthwhile experience while visiting Hanoi, although westerners will probably find the unquestioning reverence of Uncle Ho a little odd. My best tip would be to get there early, as the place closes at 10ish. With all the building works around the area and the confusing directions to the entrance, we arrived too late and had to go back the next day.

Very Good!. Make sure your shoulders and knees are covered as we nearly got sent away, but luckily my shorts rolled down! Long queue but went quickly - you have to keep moving so all over and done with quickly - but very surreal and really worth it! No bags or cameras.

A serious place!. Yes this is the most serious place in Vietnam for tourist. You must wear appropriately while visiting. It was surrounded by guards and open only in the morning. Be earlier to visit this place. Although it is only a short period, you can look at Ho Chi Minh's mummified body. To know him more, proceed to the small wooden house and another grand residence he used to live. The museum nearby is not bad as well.

slightly surreal, very memorable. Make sure to get there early as the queues build up quickly and they stop letting people line up jut after 10am. A worthy experience, even though it's odd to gaze upon a dead man in a box, it's worth it to witness how many Vietnamese people make a pilgrimage to see HCM's remains and how they react. It will give you a better understanding on his role in the national consciousness.

Interesting. The waiting line was very long when we went, it was about 1.30 hours, we tossed up to leave many times, however it was worth the wait in the end, just for the experience. We did not expect to see Ho Chi Min straight off in his enclosed glassed viewing room. I think that was what shocked us. The guards at the corners were armed with bayonets and at attention. What dedication. His body was perfect, perhaps a little too perfect. Walking around the garden and other things after the mausoleum was worth it. Just go if your in the area. After my trip to Vietnam I have come to understand what Ho Chi Min did for Vietnam and I understand why the Vietnamese hold on to his memory so much.

Ridiculous. Lots of check controls on the street. They don't let you walk though the mausoleum, they tried to obligate us to go around nowhere. The police do a strict efforcement. And they don't look friendly. They look paranoic.There are really huge lines. It's completely insane. We just wanted to check it from outside and that it was almost impossible. Even take a pic of the building is a challenge. I wouldn't stay in a line to see it.

Long Wait for a quick glimpse. We visited this one a sunday when it is only open from 8am - 11am. We had to wait 1 - 1.5hrs in the queue in 30+ degree heat. Beware the locals like to jump ahead in the queue!You must have shoulders & knees covered, although you can buy sarongs if you don't have appropriate clothing.There is also shade for almost all the time in the queue.Well worth a look even if only for a very brief time as there is no stopping once inside.Be aware this is closed Monday's & Friday's.

Tour by picture. After being herded through a long line in a barrier, you will pass HCM in the mausoleum - as a westerner without an affinity, I am not sure the line up is worthwhile for the 20 second viewing . The museum itself is fill of pictures and objects however there are very few translations and without this, it appears to be put together quite randomly. The HCM museum in HCMC is more worthwhile...

Very nice from the outside. We were disappointed when we got there to find it was closed and we could not find out off anyone why it was so. The soldiers guarding it looked very impressive and they did marching drills up and down the concrete outside the mausoleum. I hope you have better luck than we did and get inside but it was still good.

worth the effort. The Vietnamese are very serious about dress code and cameras and the like when going in to see Ho Chi Minh. But it was worth the several check points and the ever moving lines to see him.

Camera Deposit = Camera in Pocket :). The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum boasts crowds that would rival most 300 Spartan fight scenes. Long crowds who's vision of personal space rivals most competitive tango dance lessons. After several minutes of being barked at via megaphone (think german shepherd - volume level 9) and herded through a line to "deposit" our bag. Several security check's which were conducted frequently that featured gawking at my partner, who mind you was almost totally covered. They allowed some cameras to be taken through but not my shiny SLR. We were removed from the line and requested surrender my camera, only after to find staff going through the contents of its bag. Upon stating I didn't feel this treatment was fair (expecting to see my camera on eBay) we were spoken to as if we had violently sneezed in the face of security. We followed all the guides on being respectful to the Tomb but were subjected to constant disrespect and ultimately were escorted out of the premise. It took almost an hour to retrieve our gear. The tour is free however sneaky tickets are needed once you compete the tomb visit.

A really weird/fun way to spend a morning. All you really do is wake up really early, line up for kilometres (the line moves quickly), get shepherded through the tomb by guards, then spend ten minutes trying to figure out how to leave the grounds without going through the artifact museum. Nevertheless, we had a great time lining up with the thousands of Vietnamese people coming to check Ho Chi Minh out, and I would recommend going to anybody visiting Hanoi.DEFINITELY go as early as you can. We got there at 7:30 and the line was already absurdly long. Also, make sure to cover your knees and shoulders, and try to avoid bringing a bag.

Trishaw ride through Hanoi - a must do!. We ordered trishaws to pick us up from our hotel Hanoi Moment 2 to take us around the Salt Lake, through the French Quarter and past the Opera Hous. Our drivers were exceptionally experienced and even in the busy Hanoi traffic we all really enjoyed the experience. If you're interested in doing this call Tken on 091 7901025.
Good. It was a good experience and fascinating to see Ho Chi Minh. There was almost no queue and it was quit fast

Not more than a memorial building. First of all, the building entombing the comunist leader was neither magnificient (not like Tien An Men at China) nor attractive. It is just a small structure, with a big square in front of it. Umbrella or hat is important as shrubs around the mausoleum were not enough to provide shelter from stinging sun. Learned from other reviewers, the queue into the mausoleum can be stunningly long. So, drinking water might be necessary while we battle through the queue.The mausoleum was closed on Friday as well as on Monday. My family and I didn't go into the mousoleum as our visit was on Friday. However, taking photo outside was allowed. The trip to mausoleum should be done together with other places nearby such as Hanoi Botanical Garden, One Pillar Pagoda, and Hanoi Royal Citadel.Hanoi Botanical Garden next to the mausoleum is really worth a visit, as it houses the stilt house of Ho Chi Minh. The story about how uncle Ho refused presidential palace and lived in the stilt house was touching- that's what the real leader should be. The trip to Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is not complete without visiting Ho Chi Minh stilt house. More of my experience is available at bettyandlingshing.blogspot.com/2013/05/ho-chi-minh-mausoleum-and-places-nearby.html.

Impressive. After 4 weeks travelling throughout Vietnam and getting to know more and more about the country and its past, we decided to go to he Mausoleum.The queue was long; 2 hours, but it was an impressive morning and a adequate way to pay respect to the country and its past.

Closed on Monday afternoon. Didn't get to go inside the museum as it was closed on Monday afternoon. But it looks great from outside. Also noticed that as I was walking along the Mausoleum, there was a rope around so that visitors do not get too close. It is a scared place to revere Uncle Ho for Vietnamese.

Instructive. Uncle Ho sure is revered and loved. I liked the humility and special way he lived his life. The military way the Mausoleum has been somewhat relaxed now from 5 years ago. Its worth a look!

Be prepared for a long queue. When visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum in Hanoi, Vietnam, be prepared for 2 hour queues ....unless of course you are visiting in a wheelchair, and then be prepared for a full on military escort all the way through! If you are travelling in a wheelchair let them know at the security checkpoint. You will then be asked to wait about 5 minutes, before someone comes to escort you past the mile long queue. You will then be met by 6 guards at the base of the Mausoleum, to be carried up the front stairs into the building. Be prepared for stares, as they are dressed in white, (mourning) full on military uniform, and cannot be ignored! You will then have this escort through the whole building. I was actually too busy trying to stifle giggles at this, (along with the guards), that I probably missed the significance of seeing the embalmed body.No photography is allowed, and no stopping is allowed. You will go in one side, and walk straight out of the other, in a long line of people. Do not try to visit on Fridays or Mondays as it is closed, which also means that it is twice as busy the day after. This is a must when visiting this city, but do be prepared. The only other time I've seen such queues is at the Vatican City.
Amazing experience. This is a must do - nothing like it anywhere else that I know of. Can be long queues and you have to go at the prescribed pace & no speaking!
It's a must. Even tho its hot you have to be fully dressed and go early in the morning so u don't have to line up because its way to hot so go early but its a must

must see and don't mind the queue. This is probably the single most important site to visit while in Vietnam. It is not just for its historical significance but it is a remarkable and unique experience so do not be put off by the macabre concept of viewing an embalmed body. This sums up everything about Vietnam, the thing that makes them different to the rest of Asia and reflects their special tragic history.DO NOT be put off by the giant queue to view the body. The line is a fascinating journey in itself and worth doing and as early as you can in your visit.A

Camera is not allowed.. The rules around here is very strict and one has to always maintain a respectful attitude while waiting in line and might be reprimanded by the officials guarding the place. Camera is not allowed.
Unique. Great to see - huge queue but it did move very quickly and you are provided with shade for most of it. A must see if you are in Hanoi.

impressive place, unfriendly personnel. The entire grounds of the mausoleum including the gardens is an impressive looking place and very expansive considering space is such a premium in Vietnam. Ho was lit with an eerie looking shade of red. My water bottle was confiscated at security screening, flow of pedestrian traffic to see Ho is one way only, but I needed to retrieve my water bottle so had to go the long way around. My advice is to leave your belongings with the numerous checkpoints that allow you to do so. On our way to get my water bottle we were shouted very aggressively 'BUY TICKET!' by some guy in a miliary-looking outfit, the tickets were for a tour guide at 25,000VND pp and I didn't see why I needed a guide. Looking around, nobody else was buying them, so I'm not sure if only foreigners were required to buy them as all the locals seemingly could leave without one, or if it was just some random dude dressed up trying to scam us, needless to say, we found another way out without having to buy a ticket. The employees in military garb do not speak any English, if you need to express something, speak to the ladies at the belonging checkpoints as they can translate and pass on the message for you as I had done. When I finally reached security screening and got my water bottle back, what I found unnecessary was that the man there had to escort me by arm out of there...I know which way I came from thank you very much. Also we saw many people wearing shorts and t-shirt, females also. Just look polished and you should be fine, we didn't take anything else besides water so that we didn't have to check in our things at belongings, so we wore long pants on a 35 degrees celsius day without something to change into (where are there any change rooms anyway) and within a few minutes we were wishing we had.

Mausoleum. HI this place is one of the most important place to the local people , please show respect when you visit here as it deeply hurts the local if respect is not shown , make sure you cover up no shoulders showing or shorts to be worn if you do you will have to buy over priceed clothes there to go in

Strangely captivating. I was surprised by how much I appreciated the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Ho Chi Minh is all but worshipped by the Vietnamese, and did indeed live a very accomplished life - through his humble early years to his political activities, imprisonment and several wars (against the Japanese, French and the US). The mausoleum contains just his preserved body, which I found oddly moving to view. There was a decent-sized line to enter the mausoleum (which was free to enter) but it moved at walking pace and took just a couple of minutes to get in. There are plenty of rules to follow: - No tank tops - my wife brought a silk scarf to cover her shoulders - No photography inside - and we actually got told off for taking photos of guards outside so be careful there- You'll need to check your bags if they're bigger than a purse; same goes for DSLR cameras (we removed our memory card and took it with us to be safe, but had no problems) - you can reclaim them immediately upon exiting the mausoleum- Lonely Planet said no sandals or shorts but we wore sandals and saw lots of people in shorts The whole thing is over in a couple of minutes - there's just the one room with the closely guarded body - but I found it worthwhile.
Looooonnngggg Queue. It's just a long queue and nothing else. You get 3 seconds inside to see the frozen former leader. And ten the crowd and noise outside, that's all there is.
A short glimpse. You have to stand in a line for a long time just to be able to see Ho Chi Minh for a moment, although it should be worth it if you come early, he really looks creepy..

Very interesting. Very well organised, shade covered walkways very welcome in the heat, had a great time chatting to school children ahead of us wanting to practise their English . The shrine and the man on show very interesting .

Not open. Unfortunately not open when we visited but we could walk through the grounds although watched by soldiers with rifles.
Felt a bit threatened by the military presence.
Worth seeing for political history purpose. Not a friendly place.
Watch out for thieves.

Long lines - but they move quickly. We joined a line that looked like it would take forever, but it wound and meandered through the complex for about an hour and a half before the quick 30 second tour through the Mausoleum. Probably worth the time, but not if it is extremely hot.

Interesting from affar.... Only saw this rather large structure dedicated to "Uncle Ho" from a distance as the area was under repair and we could not get really close to it. From what we saw it is very impressive monument to the leader of North Vietnam and later Vietnam.

Long queues. Get to the mausoleum early. Queues are long and when not under shade it's hot! The mausoleum has A/C and the entire experience a bit creepy but an important part of recent history and perspective

a little bit a strange atmosphere. We were there, early in the morning, but still there were so many tourists we had to queue and the "police" guarded as very well. We passed the mausoleum and saw the body of Ho Chi Minh and it was a little bit a strange atmosphere.

Impressive monument worth seeing!. Despite the heat and the queues I think it is essential to visit this impressive monument to the man the people love.I found it very interesting expecially learning that it was not his wish to be immortalised like this. It is also well worth the tour through the gardens and through his houses etc. Make sure you have someone with you who can explain about everything and the history. We went with Hanoikids Zom and Hoa who gave us so much interesting information, it made this tour very worthwhile.I think if you are in Vietnam this is something we should all see.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Hanoi, Vietnam. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is not far from the Hanoi city center. It's closed on Mondays and the queue was longer when I was there on a Tuesday. Along the covered walkway, there are TV monitors showing the war footage. No photography is allowed inside the Mausoleum. Once out of the Mausoleum, you will see a large open ground with a very tall flagpole. You can also visit Ho Chi Minh's Residence nextdoor, in the garden of the former French Governor's Residence. When Uncle Ho became President in 1954, he stayed in the garden's quarter, whed his wooden house on stilt was under construction. Take a look at my video on YouTube at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qpstUARPPiw.

A simple man. Well worth the walk along the assigned lines. Make sure you arrive early to avoid a long queue. The line moves steadily until you find inside the crypt with Ho Chi Minh laying in state. Make sure you also visit the stilt house etc in the magnificent gardens.

Mix feeling about current Vietnam and his legacy.. The place was full of people and long line. Although as other people said you don't wait too long as the line keep walking to see Mr. Ho Chi Minh's body in short time. However I'm not so sure that his legacy can continue that way. As many website explained that in his will, the founder of the modern Vietnamese state specified that his body be cremated, with his ashes scattered over the north, center, and south of his country. (All about) To me, it is a moment of thinking his personal wishes and what was his legacy to the country and people of Vietnam.You can look at him very quickly...not just look it is like a walking pass. This is only open for public between 7:00am till 11am. Friday and Monday seems closed.
A little creepy. Very long queues and very short time to actually view Ho Chi Minh's body. However it was good to take part in a ritual that is valued very highly by the locals.

NOT ESPECIALLY INTERESTING. This is I suppose a venue that just about every tourist is taken to, but, as a foreigner, I found little of real interest. The day of our visit was actually the anniversary of Ho's birth so the crowds were absolutely enormous, to the extent that we did not actually file past the embalmed body because of the length of the queue and the temperatures/humidity, not that anyone in our group appeared to object to this.The remainder of the grounds and buildings were much like similar venues around the world and thus of only passing interest. Given the importance of the site to the host nation, it is probably an unavoidable venue for foreign tourists if they are on a group tour but I would suggest, ahead of the tour, that not too much should be expected.

Dress conservatively. This was something we had been looking forward to for some time, without disappointment! Although I had a lapse in common sense and wore a singlet top, which meant that I had to go to and buy one of those motorcycle jackets just to get in! The lines moved really quickly - we barely stopped moving on the way to the mausoleum.Strict camera and bag regulations. Something I hadn't read anywhere was that you can't take water in! The military presence is heavy, but that is part of the excitement.

nice visit. When we got there the queue was so long, but dont be turned off by that, the queue moves really quickly, we only had to wait 15 mins to get into the mausoleum. Be prepared to leave big bags at the entrance of the queue, for free. Here u can see the preserved body of ho chi minh. After the mausoleum follow the crowd into the palace grounds where u can see some of the buildings in there and his garage. Definitly worth a visit. It closes at 10.30 ish so get there early.

A little strange but cool. Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum is by the Presidential palace, his museum and residence. You can see all 3 in one morning. Please note that tours of the mausoleum close at 11AM. It is located in the old part of the city and that's where you want to stay anyway. People from all over the country were there. The lines can be long but they move fast and it is well worth it.

Interesting, but be prepared to wait. We visited the Mausoleum on a Saturday morning around 9am. The place was packed out and there was a queue about a mile long. Luckily the organisation of the staff meant that we got through the queue reasonably quickly (>20 mins) and visited. Be aware you only get about 5 mins inside the actual mausoleum, but there is plenty to do afterwards in the same complex.My advice, go around 7.30am to avoid queues and hot weather

Honour to view. Extreme long line up but well worth your wait. You have to move along quickly...there are guards everywhere, you have to hand over your camera and pick it up afterwards (be prepared for this). Make sure to check the times, it's not always opened for viewing.

Sobering yet interesting.. We took one look at the line and nearly didn't do this but I am so glad we did! Literally thousands of people queue up to see Ho Chi Minh's preserved body and pay their respects (we went on a Sunday, so it may have been busier than other days). Line does move quickly, but it took us about an hour to do the whole thing. We were even lucky enought to see the changing of the guards at the door of the mausoleum! Amazing to see how in time they march. A little creepy once you are in there, but fascinating. Try to get there early as I think it closes at 11am.

Worth a visit. Don't get put off by the longs queues to get in - they actually move very quickly. Once you pass through the mausoleum and see Ho Chi Minh then you can take your time and look around the area. It was raining when we went so we rushed through a bit but the grounds were well maintained. It was good to have a guide to explain what each thing was as there is not much information around regarding what things are.Well worth a visit

the hero we admired so much!!. heard and read the story about uncle Ho and the Vietnameses for their thousands years defending the country until today,that's so brilliant and unbelievable.Learn more about the hero who lead the way for million Vietnameses,admire his knowledge,love the way he moved,a great point for people follow :)

Like a stroll backwards in history. This is a national treasure for the Vietnamese people and you are expected to behave and dress appropriately. If you chew gum or wear your hat just a fraction too long a guard will be glad to correct your bad behavior. You certainly learn to queue well at this sacred place. Mr. Ho Chi Minh himself is present in the Mausoleum and you have an opportunity to view his mortal remains. Kind of reminiscent of Lenin - who is no longer available for viewing. Expect long lines and behave yourself.
Pay your respects. Its a glimpse into Vietnamese society line up and go through. you have to cover your shoulders and knees. Uncle Ho looks very peaceful
crowded but worth it. Went there by taxi , i think a must see in hanoi , lots of people visiting but not a problem , go early morning better

the wait was the most interesting thing. go early, and dress conservatively, like the guidebooks say. the lines move and you're in the actual mausoleum for no more than 3 minutes. there's more reverence in mao's mausoleum, frankly.but watching people on the line was fascinating. there are films and much music and it struck me that lots of folks were happy to sing along with lovely tunes whose only words i could make out was 'ho chi minh'
A long wait. It is worth a visit if you have time to spare, but a long wait. The arrangements are a bit chaotic. No photos - just filing past the body
Dont visit Hanoi on mondays. Mondays are holiday and nothing opens. It happened to us and couldnt enter the mausoleum. Many tourists dont know this and it is important to know it

long queue. we went to ho chi minh mausoleum september 2012, we have to wear a formal dress, and the queue was very long..and the weather is hot, so we didnt go inside, we just took some photo outside the mausoleum.

Nothing spectacular. Quite a disappointed as the exterior looks grand. But the artifacts and records are mostly replicated stuff and the mix of showcase do not really bland and make sense. I love visiting museums when I travel but this one, sad to say, one of those that I would not spend more than 30 minutes.

This is patriotism. I loved watching the Vietnamese people essentially worship this man. I haven't see patriotism like this anywhere in the world except at Chairman Mao's former residence. The entire experience is great. First, you have to form a line just to enter the area where you form a line. This made no sense but set the tone perfectly for a trip to see a great Communist leader. We went through metal detectors, but I just kept my camera in my pocket. The detector alarmed but they weren't checking anyone. If you play by the rules, you are supposed to check in any camera or recording device and they will give it back to you afterwards. Seemed risky to me, so I kept mine in my pocket. Go early to beat the heat. Line moves quickly.

Was not expecting this!. We knew that a must do was to see the mausoleum... I wasn't expecting to actually see Ho Chi Minh, himself! I thought he would be in an elaborate coffin in which we could not see him... Very interesting. You can't take pictures and his body is heavily guarded.
They really do love this man.... You cant help but be in awe of how this man is loved by the vietnamese. Good spot for photos, lots to do in the area.

Well Worth A Visit.. Excellent outing, well set out in beautiful well kept grounds.
The Mausoleum was fantastic & would recommend to anyone who is interested in Vietnams history.

Long queue but fascinating experience. It was so hot when we visited but the fans really helped when queuing. The queues are long but they go down fast and it is quite a fascinating experience. The body is guarded by men and there are plenty of guards about to kepe things in line. Definitely wear respectable clothing but flip flops are fine.
Ho's tomb. A regimented tour of the mausoleum to see Ho Chi Minh in his glass coffin. It was a serene, peaceful place where even the children were quiet and respectful to their past leader

A revered leader. Wasn't sure I wanted to go here, but Uncle Ho is one of the most revered people in Vietnam, and felt I couldn't miss the experience. Make sure you do exactly as you are advised because the place is very regimented and you don't want to step out of line. The queue was very long, but it moves quickly. I am glad I did visit.
Impressive. I thought the visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was very interesting. Don't forget to cover your knees and shoulders!

Very interesting. I guess this is not for everyone to want to see.To some a hero to others a different opinion.But I felt it would be a regret if I came all his way and did not visit this man. Where respectful clothes, do not wear your sunglasses inside the building. Make sure you go early.Be aware that on the day of his birthday the crowds are big and it will possibly take a couple hours. No cameras are allowed inside the building. Don't freak out if your guide insists you give him your camera just before you go in.
Too late to visit. You must visit this place early as it is only open from 7.30am til 10am. We were very disapponted as we got there too late.
incredible. we must queue for half hour to saw Ho chi minh's preserved corpse, but it's give u new experience, u must visit this place if u come to hanoi

Uncle ho. The queue looked enormous but didn't take too long. You have to follow the instructions to the letter and it is a strange feeling to be marshalled in such a regimented way. It was worth the time. We had a guide to take us around the rest of the site and this was great. He explained everything in a very positive manner and was full of information. A great couple of hours.

I've never seen an embalmed body before .... and after lining up for a very long time I finally did. A very eery experince but worth a visit. I believe the day we went was busier than usual as Unle Ho was about to be shipped to the Soviet for maintenance. A must do, Uncle Ho is very much revered and loved by his people, its great to see how many local people come to pay there respects, the proof of the love for this man are in the long queues to gain entry.Make sure you have your knees and shoulders covered, they are very strict on this.

Long Queue. The queue to the mausoleum was quite long but because they were moving people along constantly, it didn't take us long to get inside. There were more local people there than tourists, which was interesting.
fabulous. now going to see the mausoleum there is always a queue make sure you have your shoulders covered or you have to buy a scarf but other than that it is apart of history you should not miss

See once & move on. Out of all days of the year we went during Reunification Day....so it was packed! Plus side is my tour got to fast track through the line. Lined up & moved through quite quickly considering how long the line was. Guards are emotionless & pushy so make sure you stay in line. You move past Ho Chi Mihn’s fast which I didn’t mind because it’s quite sad seeing his little body in the glass coffin. Only need to see this once, wouldn’t go a second time.
Very Interesting. amazing ...walked around this guy lying in glass box...in one door and out the other...thank goodness we didn't have to pay...very interesting though

Worthwhile experience. These displays of embalmed former leaders are always a bit strange, but Vietnamese visitors seemed to genuinely revere Ho Chi Minh. The experience is quite regimented but well-managed (no shorts, bare shoulders or other revealing clothing).
imposing. I was there on Ho Chi Minh's birthday; the square was deserted so that the mausoleum had an imposing dignity without the bustle of crowds and tourists distracting from it
Very long line up:(. To early during the weekday, but remember closed on Friday and Monday. Avoid the weekends. Crazy line ups and go super early in the morning. Opens at 715am.
AMAIZING. good place to visit in hanoi capital of vietnam.ho chi minh was a great man.you must go early in the morning to visit de museum.
The Great Man. To see the people lined up to see this great man and know what he did for his country was special e even for us visitors. We also saw the changing of the Guards .

Something you should see when in Hanoi. One of the biggest communist icons - is resting here - so if you have ventured to this communist bastion you should go to see him. I have heard he was embalmed against his will - but that does not change anything - it is still worth seeing.We were there a thursday morning. The taxi ride from not the old quarter was 50.000 dong - but unfortunately the taxi drivers drop you close to the mausoleum. Unfortunately the entrance is quite along way south west of there. Have your hostel point it out on the map and insist the driver drops you there.After our long walk to the entrance we got in line and went to the mausoleum with the other guests. I would go on a weekday as it gets crowded in the weekends. When going into the mausoleum stick to the left - and/or behind someone who is not too tall - so you get a clear view of Mr. Minh. YOu will only have about a minute to take it all in.Be respectful when visiting - you are a guest in Vietnam - so don't fool around and insult the armed guards. Follow the rules.Don't bring too much stuff as you have to hand it in at the gates -something I am always reluctant to do. No photography is allowed in the mausoleum itself.Remember the place has very limited opening hours (morning usually)After the mausoleum you can go to some buildings - if you are in a big group you may get in without paying the 25.000 Dong. Unfortunately we were the only Caucasians in an asian group - so we got singled out.

Worth a look, a quick one.. Much like the mausoleums of Mao and Lenin the queues will be there. This Vietnamese icon is no different. This a curiosity piece and something to tick off on your visit to Hanoi but little to see beyond the morbid fascination of seeing the man in his glass sarcophagus.Mercifully, the queuing area has a canopy to protect you from the sun and the queues move reasonably quickly. Well, they don't stop. once in the building you are ushered through and past the waxy remnants of the former leader at a steady pace. No photographs are allowed and you should remove your hat in reverence.It is chilly inside as they have to regulate the temperature. Also, the soldiers may take umbrage if you are wearing shorts and sandals. I had even heard of people not being let in with short sleeves but there was no evidence of this when I went. Vests were a definite no-no. Best to bring something long sleeved and light trousers just in case.A point worth noting is that you should leave your camera and water at the security check. They don't allow water or liquids to be taken in so unless you want to lose it, it is best to leave it behind for the time you are in there. In Hanoi, you don't want to be without water in summer particularly.

Get there early!. We arrived 15mins late to get to go inside the mausoleum - you need to be there very early (7:30 -8:00ish - double check this) to line up with the hoards of locals and wait in line for about an hour before you are shuffled past his body and out the other side. We spoke to others who said it was ok - but not worth the hassle. That said - the surrounds of the Mausoleum and lovely and worth seeing, the building itself is average though.

Visit early morning to beat the crowds - and not on Sundays. The locals all visit on Sunday morning, so avoid this time, unless you are prepared to queue up to half an hour. No photos allowed inside the Mausoleum.

worth a visit. if it is just for curiosity then take a look - you are not allowed to browse and have to walk past in an orderly fashion - alsomake sure you are dressed accordingly. Have also been to see Lenin in Moscow - very simular and truth be known not muc o see. Rest of complex is also quite interesting

Frankly nothing great to see than to see great leader of vietnam. Just ok, long queues, hot weather, nothing very great to see actually. Just nice to see the love that people in North Vietnam have for HCM

So very odd. Stuffed and pumped full of formaldehyde, Uncle Ho’s conveniently on display at the dismally gray Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. He entertains visitors from 8 to 11 a.m., Tues.-Thurs. and Sat.-Sun. – that is unless he’s vacationing in Russia for “servicing.” Uncle Ho died in 1969 and despite his desire to have his remains cremated, his countrymen entombed him like Snow White — in a cooled, glass coffin.If you choose to pay Uncle Ho a visit, dress conservatively and arrive early because the lines to gawk at his stick-thin, embalmed form can be long. Still cameras, videocameras and cell phones are not allowed inside, so either leave them at your hotel or hide them lest they be confiscated. Also, hands in pockets and crossed arms are a no-no.TIP: The entrance to the mausoleum complex is well behind the actual mausoleum because there's a series of checkpoints you must go through. You may have to walk quite a ways behind the mausoleum to get in the line that leads into the building.

Queued 1hr+ to see body of Mr Ho Chi Minh. Make sure u are queuing to enter the mausoleum so that u get to see the leader's preserved body. There is another queue for people to just tour the exterior of the mausoleum. Oh! and wear clothes that cover your arms & below knee cap. Bottled water not allowed to be brought in too. It is opened until 12 noon but people can only join the queue before 10.30am or 11am latest. So as to ensure that the last visitor finish by 12 noon i guess.

Different, worth the wait. We got there early and the queue moved quite quickly. The whole experience is interesting and worthwhile. Going into the building is really quick but as you approach, the guards are very intent on making sure that everyone is lined up very neatly and that you are silent. Not something you experience every day.

Well worth a look. Long queues but still worth the experience. Everything is set up for long queues with shades etc. Whist you a ushered through the actual mausoleum at reasonable pace its is still something that everyone should do when in Hanoi. It is worth doing this with a guide to get an understanding the history of Ho Chi Minh and the impact he has had on the country.

Take time to enjoy all of the Mausoleum.. For me the biggest need was water as I went there on a day of 40 degrees and high humidity. There is a lot of open space so be sure to wear a hat. It takes us through a history of life in Viet Nam. Don't miss the out buildings of life centuries ago. Take time to read the postings for a clearer understanding.

Interesting. We waited to go here after Ho Chi Minh's birthday celebration. There were still a TON of people but at least the line moved pretty quickly as people don't really stop and stare at his body inside the mausoleum. I'm not going to lie though- his body looked like a wax sculpture to me....is it real? is it fake? I don't know-just telling you my observation. The room was also very dark. An interesting place.....
Interesting to see if you are in Hanoi. This was interesting to see and a good area to wander around. There are stalls for souvenirs and drinks.

Worth a look. Visited the Mausoleum as part of a gudied tour and found it to be very interesting. I don't think it would be worth looking at without a tour guide as they give you a good insite into the history here.
Queues queues and more queues. Went here early in morning as advised but queuing was so long that we came away. We're told later that others had queued for over 2 hours.

Very special. This was the longest queue I have ever stood in, but it was so worth it to see such a unique and very significant place. the Vietnamese people have such respect and admiration for this Man and it really shows.

Very interesting. We went on a Saturday morning with thousands of other people. There are a lot of military staff controlling the lines and telling you when to stop or go. Your handbags are searched and all cameras have to be handed in and collected at the exit. You actually get about 2 minutes to look at the body as the line keeps moving and nobody is allowed to slow down. Many locals were very emotional and apparently try and see this once in their lifetime. I enjoyed the entire experience and loved talking to all the school kids in the line who wanted to practice their English.

Wheelchair visit. We had not expected all the walking so wheelchair was not booked. We arranged one with guard house and when reaching the Mausolem four white uniformed guards proceeded to carry my chair up all the steps, around and down again. Looks like he is just asleep. Hard to believe preservation is so good.. i flelt regal during this carrying venture.

Celebrating an Icon. An absolute must do in the city...where else to you get to see a stuffed historic icon outside Egypt? But just be forewarned...they are strict...no laughing and giggling. But seriously, you must visit it...in and out, takes an hour!

Do it!. Dress properly: rule one. Not sure why people turn up in tiny dresses but you will be asked to dress properly which means buying and not hiring clothes. Keep a tight rank (block off the left) as everyone will try to push in. It ended up a game with us - the minute you turn the corner old ladies and kids will try to push in so we just made sure we blocked it up. The line is really long and it's hot so come with water (or buy from the people along the isle), sunblock, hat etc. We had a camera but I kept it over my shoulder with my handbag covering it so no one made me check it in (don't even think of pulling the camera out or they will make you check it in). It's really eerie being in the mausoleum. Keep quiet and in rank or the soldiers will gently push you and shush you lol. Seeing the body is for you to experience so won't comment on this. You can take photos once you get out. Also you will be told to pay when you walk back the way you come but this is to go to the museum. We got confused and thought there was a fee for foreigners to see the body but it was the other area so turn right when you see everyone walking straight (it is free for locals)

Well worth it. After the considerate chaos which is Hanoi traffic - car, moped & foot - it is amazing to walk into this organised, orderly shrine. We arrived early - the Mausoleum is only open from 8 am for a few hours Tuesday to Saturday - and, after walking a considerable way, ended in a line next to a group of beautifully dressed pre-schoolers, who we followed in to the sound of a primary school band playing. Overall it was a rather surreal experience but one which gives a different insight into the people of Vietnam and their reverence for Ho Chi Minh.
Very Formal and Huge Crowd. The line was long and the sun was beating down on us. I think this is better for history students than casual tourists.

Uncle Ho in repose. It is an odd attraction of course but to see the reaction of the Vietnamese, who are the vast majority of the visitors, is fascinating. The reverence is quite genuine. And it's interesting to see the state of the art communist leader under glass technique. The long outdoor line moves swiftly and it's sheltered from the elements under a canopy. It really is a must.

Worth queuing up for. This was a good introduction to the more recent history - both social & political, of Vietnam. Be respectful and use the opportunity to discover about the founder of modern Vietnam.

More signifcance for locals than for tourists. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is open in the mornings. Our tour guide noted that approximately 10,000 people per day visit this site. Please be mindful of the dress code for this attaction. Women are best to wear long skirts/pants as well as a modest top as there were many tourists being made to purchase scarves to cover themselves before entering (inlcuding women in knee lenth skirts).Security checks are also required and big cameras and water bottles were confiscated for pick up at the other end. There are soldiers throughout this attraction to enforce the rules. The Masoleum itself was a long queue to walk in silence past the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. As much as I can appreciate the significance of this attraction for locals (they truly adored this man), for someone not impacted by his work or life it was hard to feel the significance. Our tour guide spoke about the modest life that this great man of Vietnam lived and the request that his ashes be spread under three mountains in different parts of Vietnam. Seeing his body in a grand Mausoleum seemed somewhat incongruent with the stories I heard about him alive.

Must do. Surreal experience. Get there early and expect a very long line. They will keep your camera and have it available at another location outside the mausoleum when you get out (no worries, good system). Sometimes they close it early. By the way, I heard his body is taken to Moscow for 2 months every year for preservation processes.

Intimidating, eerie and unsettling. A beautiful architectural example of Vietnamese creativity meets communist bombast. The intimidating grey structure feels incongruent to the perfectly manicured grass that lies before it and the kind yellow buildings around it. And this is just the beginning.From the outset you're intimidated (as you rightly should be). Line up with other tourists to have you cameras confiscated until you re-emerge from visiting Uncle Ho's preserved body. Be sure to dress appropriately - visible shoulders and knees are disrespectful. Don't be one of *those* tourists.Once you've been ushered through in the single file queue, the actual walk through the room to see Uncle Ho is actually very short, seconds in fact. It is also extremely unsettling. Ho Chi Minh specifically requested that his remains be burnt, to be scattered across different regions of the country. That the government has gone against this express wish in the exact opposite, most garish way, affects many a visitor. You've been warned.Once out of the mausoleum, from there it's a short walk in to the neighbouring gardens of the President's Palace and HCM's old living quarters. Beautiful and worth the visit in summer especially.Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum is a very valuable experience as a tourist to really get a sense of Vietnamese culture in the north, and underlying political sensitivities, still very present today.

Gain more knowledge. History about President Ho Chi Minh only have to queue under the hot sun to enter thje mausoleum. we get to see the rooms & cars used by President Ho and his preffered simple life style. a reaaly understanding & considerate great leader.

Mixed feeling. Part of the daily tour that we took. Need to go early as it closes at 10.30 am. Long walk under the shade, well kept gardens and alleys. A large memorial with high security and guards, very austere. Need to be properly dressed. No bagpacks, cameras allowed inside. although a lot of people, it goes pretty fast when in the chamber. Very well organised and controlled.

Interesting to see. I enjoyed seeing how the groups of children of all ages from about 18 months old plus locals and all of us tourists, being lined up in long lines of two. The children are taken there twice a year to pay their respects. The grounds were lovely.

Reverence. The organisation and slightly unnerving presence of white uniformed guards was impressive along with the obvious admiration and respect for this great man. Long long queues under cover walkways lead you slowly to the austere, cool and silent chamber where he lies. Hint...they take all backpacks etc off you before the 1/2 mile walk in baking temps even your water. Women seemed to get away with carrying a handbag so may be worth trying to keep a small bottle in a small handbag.

Mauusoleum of Ho Chi Minh. This is a unique experience. I have never seen anything quite like it before. The Vietnamese people certainly revere their late leader. The only comparable experience I could imagine would be Lenin's mausoleum in Moscow,
Long Queue. Very well organised, grounds are beautifully maintained. The queue moved very quickly, especially when you reached inside and went around the coffin

Mark of respect. We were advised by our hotel to get there early as it takes a while to get in and it closes at 1030. We queued for about half an hour and luckily were under the shade so it wasn't too bad. There were lots of school groups who went straight through, we were ok with that, but we found that people behind us just walked past us when we slowed down a pace or two. That was rather annoying but I think its just part of the culture - as can be seen by how they drive, you just need to get used to it!After queuing for half an hour we were inside the mausoleum for less than two minutes. It was a bit spooky seeing an embalmed body but judging by the number of local visitors, many who were very young, you can imagine how well respected Ho Chi Minh still is.Entry is free, but you have to leave your backpack and camera at the entrance and the only way to get it back it to go through the park which cost 25k Dong for foreigners.
Beautiful architecture. The architecture is beautiful. But we could only have a look at the outside of the building at a distance.
must go. this place is a must but remember to wear long trousers that cover the knees and go early as it opens at 8.o clock and closes at 11.o clock
You must see!. Hi everyone! Ho chi minh museum it could be the best museum I ever seen in HAN,OI. It's very nice space and quiet. You need 1 hour for seeing that.

Worth the visit... You need to be early to visit this place because it closes at 11am. Lots of tourist and locals lining up to enter the mausoleum where Vietnam's beloved former President Ho Chi Minh is embalmed and covered with a glass box. Security is tight and it is everywhere. Everyone is to walk in a 2 x 2 line starting from the entrance until you exit the mausoleum. No one is allowed to linger after seeing the former President as guards will usher you out. Also remember to wear decent and non-revealing clothes.

an experience you will not forget.. the line up and the guards making sure everyone was in the right place, no drinking no water bottles. and security checking - by the time we had snaked our way around the outside lines (under cover) and into the entrance (more special guards) up the steps and around the corner and whoa ! not sure what i was expecting to see but Ho Chi Minh looked as if he was asleep! In a glass box granted, but restful. We were filed in at a fast past 2 by 2 and out the door and that was it. long time to get there and a short time there. all of our group commented we would have liked more time. our tour gide said every vietnam person attempts to make this trip once in their life time. you have to pay and i noted our guide stayed outside. There were old men dressed in army uniforms, groups of older ladies in traditional dress, groups of school children in their uniforms, parents with little children, and - making this pilgrimage. And lots of tourists too. you are checked in security - bit like the airlines security. cannot take photos inside.

Worth a visit. It is worth a visit. Ho Chi Minh is very respected in Vietnam and there will be a lot of Vietnamese people who come and pay their respect. Important to note that the places closes at 11 am therefore it is important to go there early and you have to be dressed decently, not shorts or strappy tops are allowed. There will be quite a queue of people, mostly Vietnamese people, but the queue moves fast and therefore you will not lose a lot of time.
Too Late. It closes at 11am so make sure to get there early otherwise youll only get to see it from the outside, like me!

Worth the visit. This is a must do if you are in Ha Noi, we were there on the public holiday celebrating the end of the Vietnam war, so there were easily several thousands of locals there to line up to take the walk through to see him.. However it was worth the wait to have the experience to see Ho Chi Mink in the Mausoleum.

Wow very interesting. We went here on a local holiday celebrating the liberation of Vietnam. A long line snaked around building and roads. The crowd was generally well controlled by the people in charge. The line it self took us about 45 minutes to reach the Mausoleum and we couldn't take our cameras or phones however to witness the Vietmanese pay their respect and to see the guards all dressed up was very interesting.

Surprisingly worth visiting. We were on a tour of Vietnam starting in Hanoi, the mausoleum was the first place on our itineraray. If I had been travelling independently I don't think that I would have visited but I am glad that I did. We arrived about 9.15 and the queues were long however we moved along quite quickly. At time it is like being on a school visit you are required to walk 2 by 2. When in the mausoleum you walk around the embalmed body which is guarded by 4 soldiers.It was moving to see the reactions of the Viethamese people some were clearly emotional. Overall if you are in Hanoi I would recomend that you visit

Must do. The mausoleum essentially just contains the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh which you can see in a glass case surrounded by guards. He is such a towering figure in Vietnamese history that i think this is really worth doing anf intersting to see what he looked like. This is part of the museum and residence complex, so it makes sense to do them all together and it tells you a lot about the history of Vietnam and his role in it.Security is strict here. You can't take in food and have to leave cameras.camcorders and other electronic equipment at a booth (to pick up after).

Worth a visit. They are very strict on how you approach the mausoleum. No camera, no hats, no hands in pockets. You are frog marched along outside up to the mausoleum. Once inside you mustn't stop, but there is planets of time to see Ho Chi Minh embalmed in his coffin. He's been there for 40 years and is flown to Russia yearly for maintenance. A bit of a weird experience but why not?

OMG. By the time we got there (10am) there was a queue of about two thousand people - no exaggeration! We didn't realise we were staying just 2 kms from the mausoleum but the taxi metre went so fast it almost spun off the dashboard! VN 1,630,,000 (USD 55) later and a grand tour of a few blocks twice over, we arrived to find the huge queue. We didn't bother in the end and walked back to our hotel for FREE!

If planned well, worth the visit. We showed up at 8AM, waited approximately 15 minutes in line, saw the mausoleum, and finished the visit 15 minutes later. If you arrive later, I suspect the line will be long. Worth the visit just to see the national role Ho Chin Minh played in Vietnam. There is no cost associated with our visit.

When in Hanoi.... This is one of those things that you just have to see - the building itself is not that amazing but it is interesting to see how highly he is still regarded by the locals. Also quite eerie to see the Soviet hammer and sickle flags flying en mass in the square

Interesting and a must see. IIt was good for the most part and the vietnamese respect their beloved leader greatly since they have built this museum in his honour much against his wishes. The grounds are nicely kept..unlike the rest of Hanoi. Cost is minimal and only for foreigners.

Not happy. Went on a day tour and Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was 2nd to see, arrived only to be told we couldn't go in as was closing in an hour or so and too many people lined up. Tour guide tried for us but they still refused. We did manage to enter the grounds to take photos from outside but they weren't going to let us do that either at first. We were all glad to get out of there, not very friendly people.

Well presented. You get to see what you expect but in a very respectful way. HCM is lying in his coffin, very well preserved, and well displayed. Guards are motionless. Everyone is filed through with plenty of time to take it in but the line is kept moving. No cameras allowed but there are secure places to leave them. A really slick operation that keeps a large number of people passing through without ever feeling that you were waiting anywhere too long.
Creepy much... Liked that there was no charge, was creepy to see Ho Chi dead but looking like he could wake any moment.Interesting to see the preservation of him..he's been gone for so long.

How do you rate a mausoleum ?. The queue was more than a kilometre long but moved quickly. Luckily we had a tour guide with us who could look after our camera or the guards would have taken it from us as these are not allowed. We were shuffled along very quickly and were told not to stop as we walked past Ho Chi Minh's body in 2 by 2 rows. The guards were quite aggressive keeping people in Line and before you knew it you were passing his body. It's difficult to rate this type of attraction (attraction??.?) it is a persons body after all.

A respected leader. We queued and paid our respects to the great Vietnamese leader. It was a moving experience, knowing how revered Uncle Ho is by the Vietnamese people. The mausoleum is open for only a short period of time in the morning. It is closed before 11 am. You can visit the complex, the temple of literature and the lenin park on the same day. They will make you leave your camera, water/food and big bags. When we went there, they were not too strict with the dress code. But still, dress appropriately.

Too crowded with local people.... Went there during weekend and it was surprisingly super crowded with Vietnamese, guess there were few kilometres queue to get into the mausoleum. If you are not a Ho Chi Minh super admirer, this attraction is not so recommended in Hanoi. the security control is very tight to enter it. However, it is very inconvenient and instruction is not tourist friendly at all.
Must Do. A very interesting experience that I wasn't initially planning, but having gone felt I had a much better appreciation for Vietnam and this time in history

Unreal experience. This is one of those experiences you will likely only have once in your life. The line is VERY long and comprised of mostly Vietnamese people, but it is very orderly and moves quickly. The reverence that they feel towards that monument is palpable and so intense. It is a lot of waiting around for about one minute of staring at his embalmed body, but the uniqueness of it somehow makes it worthwhile.The hours are very odd though, so be sure to double check before you head over.

Be prepared. The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is very interesting and should not be missed. Remember to study up on the rules and regulations. It took me three trips to actually get inside. The first time I showed up it was later in the day- you need to arrive at 8 in the morning. The second time I was turned away because I was wearing shorts- a big no-no with them.

Impressive site!. The Vietnamese people are extremely proud of this attraction and rightly so. It is immaculately kept and is still a very large attraction. We visited in the late afternoon and it was still teeming with tourists.

Interesting. From the entrance the queuing begins, its moves fairly quickly and most of the route is under a covered walkway, there's no cameras allowed inside the Mausoleum, your guide should advise you and hold them, you can place with the security staff if need be.Once you start to climb the steps into the building the temperature drops, white uniformed guards usher you along to keep the queue moving, you then pass around three sides of a dimly lit resting place where Ho Chi Min lies, then suddenly you're outside again - it was worth seeing.

Weird and long queue. It's one of the most famous places in Hanoi, so you'll probably end up going there. I found it very weird, going to see the mausoleum of a dead person, stay two hours in a queue, obey a lot of rules (like leave your bottle of water or food first, then leave you camera) and stay less than 20 seconds inside, in my opinion, wasn't a great experience. Also, no one speaks english there and because we weren't allowed to come back in a way we did, we didn't see the pagoda. we went to the museum, it's interesting to se how Ho Chi Mihn is a hero for Vietnam, but it's very badly organized. i only recommend if you have time.

A strange, odd, but worthwhile experience.. OK, so I am going to give this top marks, because I think it should be visited. BUT, be aware, you will probably have to queue for a long time, when we got there the queue just went on and on and on and on, but persevere. You go through security, and yet it still goes on and on and on and on, and when you eventually get there, you have about 10 seconds to walk past the embalmed body. BUT, he is such an important and key part to Vietnamese history, no matter what your thoughts are on communism, I found it a fascinating experience, not just for the man himself, but all the Vietnamese people and children who go to see his body.

Worth a visit (Only in the mornings, last entry 10.30am.Close Mondays and Fridays,). If you have heard or read about Uncle Ho, then I would recommend that you visit this place. It is FREE to visit the Mausoleum, however it cost 25,000VND if you wish to explore the complex (the Presidential Palace area, garage of HCM’s used cars, the house where HCM lived and worked, HCM’s stilt house and the One pillar Pagoda). Appropriate dress code is required (no short, mini skirt or singlet). No photos but they allowed me to take in my handbag and camera. It did seem that foreigners are more restricted to places they can walk around in the complex than the locals. Got there at 8.30am, which was just nice – no long queues.

It was closed. I went on Sunday and the mausoleum was closed. We did see a changing of the guards around 2 o'clock ish dressed in a white uniform with guns which was interesting though (and reminiscent of Buckingham Palace).

Nothing Outstanding. One must go see this site I suppose if one is in Hanoi, but there is nothing exceptional about it unless you are a devout fan of Ho Chi Minh and want to pay respects. Of great disappointment was that our guide talked to us about the wonders of Ho Chi Minh for hours on a tour which should have taken 1/2 hour.
Give your full respect. Show respect to this person means showing respect to all Vietnamese people. The security might be tough, just follow it.

long queue. Ho Chi Minh is very important to the Vietnamese people and they have created an impressive mausoleum. The queue to enter is hideously long. Get onto a tour and they can sometimes get you in the VIP entrance and save over an hour of waiting.Poor old Uncle Ho is not a riveting conversationalist these days, and viewing a corpse is not my thing, but it may be yours.

Interesting experience. Many many Vietnamese visit the mausoleum. Notice how respectful they are of their revered Uncle Ho. Interesting experience to shuffle in orderly under the watchful stares of the guards and in respectful silence. Do not come too late as it is only open in the morning.
Nothing like it. Closes by 11am so get there early. File pass a most unique tomb for country's dead leader. Worth the visit.

Ho Chi Minh a rest. The day was overcast but our spirits were calm as we waited in line to visit the Mausoleum that is a tribute to a fighter for his country. The fortress like building rises several stories high in beautifully attended to gardens. Guards stand at attention both inside and outside the resting place of "Uncle Ho". It is a quick walk through to view the preserved figure of this local hero and legend in Vietnamese history. A must stop on your Vietnam adventure!
Average. It's an average site to see but I think my travel to Hanoi won't be complete had I not visited this.

Very interesting. It was just interesting to be there and to understand what HCM was all about - unfortunately we could not get inside - but stood out on the parade ground in front. Interesting nevertheless.

Well organised. Make sure you don't plan to visit on Monday or Friday as it is closed. The arrangements for visitors are excellent. One of our group was in a wheel chair and from a point 4 guards carried the chair with her right right up for her to view the body and back. Unfortunatly we could not take a photo as we were not allowed to take the camera.The queues were very long but everyone got a good view without a problem.

It was awe inspiring. The afternoon we went there, the weather was pleasantly cool, a bit chilly winds I would say. The Bading Square seemed magnanimous to me; we saw the change of guards as well; the story we heard about HoChiMin was awe inspiring, specially his death wish to spread the burnt ashes of his dead body across Vietnam was so touching, instead his country people out of love preserved his dead body mummied in a coffin in the Mausoleum and how they moved to & fro with the dead body for safety concern throughout war period before they could settle it in the Mausoleum! The flower garden at the backyard was also serene, specially the series of Bonsai. The low-key patriotic songs in the PA system praising HoChiMin added to the serenity of the place!

Where's the entrance?. Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum is worth seeing, no doubt. An intense and unique experience. However, be sure to know how to get in before going. I realize it sounds silly, but they make it difficult. Cab dropped us off in front of it, but you cannot walk across the lawn, as they have extremely vigilant police on that case. You cannot walked to the other side of the Mausoleum, as you'll get a police whistle to the face there too. You must walk about 10-12 mins the long way around and two blocks behind the place to get in line. No signage. Basically, we just kept trying to get in until we could. Also, go earlier in the weekday morning for more reasonable lines.

Only for Believers. I respect the fact that for VietNamese people Ho Chi Minh was (and remains) a great figure, but if you are a Western tourist I would advise you to give this place a miss. It is about hagiography and the worship of saints - the curious form of Communist sainthood that placed Lenin and Stalin in similar catafalques of embalmed display for mile-long queues of the faithful.I find it more interesting to read about 'Uncle Ho' and to talk about him with living VietNamese people than to worship his corpse.

Amazing Experience. I really didn't want to do this but am glad I did. Getting in line with mostly Vietnamese to see uncle ho is a true cultural experience. Little children, school classes, families, old people....all put on their best clothes and file through the mausoleum in a respectful, orderly manner. Even though Ho wanted to be cremated, this is an interesting monument to his importance to the Vietnamese people.

Uncle Ho in good form!. So there is really only one major drawcard here - and it is worth the wait in line to file past and see Ho Chi Minh lying in state. Quite moving to also see the many veterans and school kids making their pilgrimage. A must do in Hanoi.

Very Respectful of Ho Chi Minh. We visited in the morning with our guide and quickly moved through the mausoleum.
Get the full story from your guide of why Ho Chi Minh was such an important man and make this visit even more worthwhile.
He sounded like a truly visionary and genuine gentle and and is no wonder the Vietnamese respect him so much.

An inecitable experience. This is more-or-less a must-see in Hanoi, although it is more than a little macabre. Lines are long, but move swiftly. I wasn't surprised when a guard motioned for me to take off my hat--would have done so anyway--but we were both surprised when he indicated that my wife had to take off her sunglasses! You spend only a few moments filing through the mausoleum chamber, which was fine with us. One Vietnamese we had a conversation with observed that nobody really knows whether that is, in fact, Ho Chi Minh's body, or a very good wax figure!

Early weekday mornings are best. I was ambivalent about going here, but I am glad I did. We got there early and were moved through quickly and efficiently. We were told that on weekends, the lines are very long but this was not our weekday experience. It was an interesting experience and the best part for me was seeing the many very young and adorable school kids on their field trips, and the goosestepping guards on parade. The mausoleum is in a nice park area and worth a visit for it's historical significance and importance to the people of Vietnam
Weekend. Don't go on the weekend particularly Sunday. Huge waiting lines to get in -- very popular with Vietnamese and lots bused in for the day

Way to busy. Would have been good but , being a weekend , and the fact that every Vietnamese school child will visit the mausoleum, the waiting time of 1 1/2 hours was just too much so, as a group, we chose to skip it. Straight lined queues of people for 4 or 5 people deep for perhaps 1 kilometer!!

Very surreal experience. We went on Easter Saturday so the crowds were huge- but the Vietnamese are great at orderly queues (you would be hard pressed to get Australians to line up over 1km long). The queue moved at a steady pace and weaved in and out of the larger grounds. There are signs which say to drop your bag off at the locker point but we found out later that you don't have to drop it off at all. You need to hand over your camera and mobile phones at the second check-point. If you have a money belt, best to keep your phone on you turned off. Walking up to the Mausoleum, the crowd hushed and we entered the shrine in a very solemn atmosphere. It was a truly bizarre experience and I believe even the Vietnamese people in the crowd were also filled with awe and shock at the slightly macabre nature of the open 'coffin' itself. Definitely worth visiting as the feeling of seeing Ho Chi Minh's body over 30years deceased is indescribable.

Interesting place. Go early to avoid the crowds. Check the days it is closed. Grounds are well kept and interesting history on site. Very much worth seeing. Be aware they will not allow cameras on tour to visit Ho Chi Minh body and you must drop off at a small kiosk
A Movign Experience. Exploring what the leader means and the man he was is part of the Vietnam experience. Make this simple gesture of respect part of your visit

I see dead people.... The line was quite intimidating (it looked like it was miles long.....it may have been actually?), but it moves quickly. We were in line for about an hour, but it's pleasant enough to snake though the grounds. Who knows how much is really left of Uncle Ho, but it's interesting to see the place. No tanktops or shorts though...and they're serious.

Vietnam's Past, Present, and Future. I was able to catch the last entrance to the Mausoleum this morning (around 9:30am to 10:30am) and it's true that there is an awful long line. However, it was moving which is why the wait didn't feel as long to me.I was prepared to leave my backpack on the 1st checkpoint but was informed that I can take it with me provided that I surrender any water or food with the security. I had a bottle of water so I left it with them. They give you a stub and when I came back for it, it was returned to me.The 2nd checkpoint is where there is a machine similar to that used in airports where they scan your bag. I had two cellphones and camera inside but because it was kept and with no intention to use, again, I was cleared to bring my backpack.While walking in line, guards may have to remind you to take off your hat or shush you when you're closer to the entrance. I suggest keeping a solemn behavior and your hands to your sides. The viewing is a thousand times shorter than the walk and to get a better view, I would recommend that at the very gate, stay on your left side when the guards/ staff ask you to form two lines. When inside, don't take your eyes off the casket (enclosed in glass) but of course be mindful of your step so as not to bump into the one in front or in back of you.I'm glad I had the chance to visit this place. I don't need to see the other Museums anymore. This makes every bit of Hanoi worth it. :)P.S. There is no entrance fee.
Respect and reverance. Only visit if you are able to show respect - this is not 'just' a tourist destination. the queue is long but moves very quickly and efficiently.

Get there early!. As THE icon of Vietnam it is a must see. We went on a saturday, and despite the torrential rain it was still absolute chaos. Queues went for more than two hours, for what amounts to less than a minute to see Ho Chi Minh. He is well restored though and beaitufully lit, giving a very tranquil look as you file past. The guards that line the mausoleum every 5 feet give the place and eery military feel. For me it was just incredible to see how many people queued just to see this great Vietnamese icon. A tick on the cultural side, but it is simply to see a glance, there is nothing beyond this (as the museum is next door)

An interesting experience. The first thing to work out when visiting the Mausoleum is how you get in to join the very long snake of people winding there way in. We thought the best way would be across the grass directly in front of the mausoleum. A nice soldier with a very loud whistle made it most clear that though one could clearly see the mausoleum and it looked the quickest way in we were wrong and a good 10 minute walk around the perimeter was the only choice.
