Once you find the entrance - no mean feat - you can then join the queue. My tip would be to avoid this on a very hot day. All bags have to be checked in prior to joining the queue. Small cameras have to be placed in pockets. No photography is allowed. I think food and drink were were not allowed. So a long wait in the sun in the queue may not be an attractive option. We were lucky as the day we went there were not too many people there. Our guide said that queues ot two hours are not unusual. This being somewhat excessive for what amounts to a few minutes in the mausoleum.As you get closer to the mausoleum the queue quietens down and the atmosphere becomes more reverential. There are many soldiers on duty ensuring that all the rules are obeyed. Once inside the mausoleum the first thing you experience is the pleasant effect of airconditioning. Then it is slowly up some stairs and you are there - still in the queue - but slowly walking around the body of Ho Chi Minh laying is state with two soldoiers gurding him. Then its down some stairs and out.. And that is it....Not a unique experience as there is also Lenin and Mao - but a fairly unique experience and perhaps of all the sights you amy see in Vietnam perhaps the most powerful one. So if the weather is cool and the queue is short it is recommended.

Fast but a must do when in Hanoi. A visit to the father of everyone in Vietnam is a must! We got there at 8.20am just before hundreds of school kids so we timed it well.You have to leave all food and drink at the start and then you pick it up at the end. You then walk under a covered walkway where there is some bathrooms before the 2nd check point which is a security check point. Here they put bags through a scanner and you walk through one as in an airport. Then cameras are taken at the next stop and put into a bag - you get a card and the camera is returned safely on the other side - there is no problem with this and is safe so don't be concerned. You the line up and walk into the mausoleum - you must be silent and you walk around the casket with ho chi Minh inside. You spend less than a minute walking around the outside of the glass casket with 4 guards around it. It is a very humbling experience. It is rushed and you can not stop but 1 minute was enough. You the exit and have the choice of leaving by turning right or paying 20,000VND and visiting the area where he lived and the stilt house. We didn't enjoy this as much as it was busy. Could easily skip this part and head straight for Hoa Lo Prison (Hanoi Hilton) which we loved - see our review.

Surreal. The organisation of this place had us baffled from the moment we arrived. First, you leave your food and water at the 'luggage' station. You do not need to leave your bags, those you can take inside. Then we joined the orderly queue for a few hundred meters. There was a blue canopy up to mark the route, which would have been greatly appreciated on a hot and sunny day. For me, on a not so sunny day, it simply highlighted the fact that everyone was being ushered along one path when actually there were many routes we could have taken to arrive at the entrance to the Mausoleum. Along the way, one of our party was told she had to leave her camera behind at the counter. None of the rest of us did though, we were told. We never did understand why. When we arrived at the entrance to the Mausoleum the queue moved quite quickly. It soon became apparent why. People in the line were 'shushed' when talking quietly and one of our group was even 'told off' by a soldier as he had his hand in his pocket! The queue moved through the hallway in a steady fashion, no one stopping or even slowing down on the way through. Then out the other side. This was a surreal experience and not one I particularly enjoyed, although I am no history buff so perhaps that is not too surprising. On the basis of the organisation of the whole place, we decided to give the Museum next door a miss.
was ok. a lot of people, mausoleum wasn't very special...the grounds around it with very limited access, not much really to see...

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Arrive early Monday to Thursday (it's closed on Friday), it is FREE which is always a good thing. You'll be ushered through fairly quickly despite what look like long ques (it moves fast).Once through you have the option of paying a small amount for a ticket to enter Ho Chi Minhs house which is actually really beautiful and well worth it.

A moment of history before your eyes. There are only 3 communist figures who have been embalmed and are on display: Lenin, Mao and Uncle Ho.  Ho is less impressive than Lenin, in my opinion. Still, it is important to see this political figure whose portrait is everywhere in South Vietnam and observe the people who wait on line along with you in a reverent silence.Get there very early, at 8:00 am , sine the mausoleum is only open until 10:30. The lines get long quite rapidly. It is closed Monday and Friday and when Ho's body is being treated in Moscow.Also, after viewing Ho walk around the complex to see where he lived and worked. You can even view the cars he used. Very interesting and not crowded at all since only some Vietnamese venture into the complex after viewing Ho's body.

Very interesting. As people have said, the lines are huge, but within 30mins you are into the Mausoleum. Once you are into the Mausoleum it takes about 40 seconds to walk around Ho Chi Minh and then you are back out again.A few tips* Women must wear clothes that cover shoulders and skirts below the knees, there is a shop you can buy shirts and sarongs from.* Guards make people put their arms down by their sides once in the Mausoleum, but seem to be harder on the Vietnamese than the tourists

It is closed on Mondays.. We came on Monday. It was closed. Couldn't see much except for a bunch of soldiers marching upfront. It is supposed to be near the temple of Literature but... we got lost and scammed while trying to find the temple of literature. :(

Humbling Experience.. We first visited the Mausoleum on a Friday - it is closed on Fridays so we could only walk around the outside and then go on to visit other attractions nearby.However while we there we were lucky to see a guard training procession - which was interesting and a great photo opportunity! We returned to Hanoi for the last couple of days of out trip and needless to say we went back.Don't let the long lines of people put you off - the queues go down really quickly. It was definitely worth the revisit.

Cultural Experience. It is not every day you have the chance to visit a mausoleum so we felt compiled to go, after all this is the man who united Vietnam defying the might of France and then America. So it was more out respect that we made our visit. We did not have to wait, and slowely walked through in single file. Silence has to be maintained as you would expect for Uncle Ho is like a saint in Vietnam. Glad we went.

Don't let the long lines put you off. Good old fashioned Vietnamese organisation works a treat at this significant Vietnamese attraction (not sure if this describes it). It's almost like a religious site for some but the line moves quickly. You cannot take photos and you have to check your iPads etc in at a desk (don't worry they give you a tag and they're in the other side afterwards). Uncle Ho is laid out in all his splendour and you get less than a minute to walk by. I felt like I'd been on a ride that I wanted to back on - worth a look!
Lots of Queueing. I didn't kjnow what to expect, but if your strapped for time. I'd suggest you could skip this one, lots of queuing and walking round to get a 30 second file past.
Very long queue for a quick visit. less than 2 minutes inside the complex and 45min queue: not worth it!Pick something else to do while in Hanoi or shorten your stay in the city.

Maybe if it wasn't so hot...... Maybe if it was not so hot we would have stood in line for hours but actually, I probably wouldn't. guards were nasty and authoritarian. we did enjoy seeing all of the adorable school kids who only wanted to practice speaking english to us.I'd say don't bother.

Strange experience. You queue for quite a while in rows of two you have to look straight ahead and hands by your side,no photos,all to look at a corpse,but when in rome ect grounds lovely and worth the visit

A definite Hanoi must do. We weren't able to view Uncle Ho, closed for this on Fridays but were able to walk the grounds and learn about how he spent his life and were given an insight into his philosophies and able to see some of his modest possessions. This is really interesting

What is the point. You cannot get near it, it is so heavily guarded. Even though it is just a tomb for a body, you are not allowed to photo it even from a distance.You wonder what they are trying to hide. Odd

Fascinating. We saw the palace that Ho Chi Minh was supposed to live in, but he chose to live in a small wooden house on the property with one bedroom, a small office and perhaps two more rooms. Soldiers stand guard but you can peek in all the windows. It was set around a quiet lake with lovely grounds.

Must see in Hanoi. No trip to Hanoi would be complete without seeing Uncle Ho or Ho Chi Minh's body. We arrived early before the line ups began. You can not allowed to bring in a camera or a backpack. The guards are very strict about the entry. You must dress appropriately and no sunglasses or hats allowed. You are also not allowed to talk. You walk around the open casket in 2 lines. I found the whole experience to be very respectful.

Long line went fast!. Open ony in mornings and I think it's closed Mondays like most Hanoi museums. Don't be dismayed if the entry line goes around the corner for waht seems half a mile. It goes quickly, is organized, and most of the way you are under a covered walkway out or rain or sun. Beautiful grounds.

He looks in good shape!. We filed thru this mausoleum to see the great leader. Apparently his remains are taken back to Russia for refurbishing every so often.Their are huge line ups but we had a preferred pass that put us at the front. Nice gardens nearby.

Fascinating. to witness the awe and respect towards "Uncle". Everywhere silent and crowds very well disciplined - do not try to walk with hands behind your back unless you want a poke! Amazing to see the various groups - schoolchildren, families, veterans. The area behind is well worth a vist too - seems a million miles from the noise
A very long queue. We walked pass the Mausoleum without entering due to the 2 hours long queue. Security check was strict. We visited Ho Chi Minh's former residence instead.

Coooooooooooooooooooool. Never actually saw the old boy as the attraction opens at 7am and closes at midday with the last entrance at about 10.30 am. To early to get out of bed and cue to see a corpse...not my thing. However, the mausoleum and the square and government buildings were great. Obviously they were the old French Colonial centre of things and they have been restored to a fantastic standard. You cannot go the Vietnam and not at least make a passing visit here. Recommend.

You have to visit Uncle Ho. Rules regarding dress and behavior are strictly enforced by staff and guards. Visitors must be silent, and walk in two lines. Video cameras, cameras are not allowed in the mausoleum. I was giggling softly while entering the mausoleum and the guards just shut me off, so remember not to even giggle!The queue going into the mausoleum will take some time but be patient, it's worth the visit.

must see. If you're in Hanoi, you can't neglect to see uncle ho. That's just weird. It's not the coolest exhibit ever, but a huge part of history. You need to check your camera, phones, and other bigger electronics. Tell them your kindle is an iPad if you have one. They looked at mine like a bomb. No talking is permitted. Security is kinda tight and the line moves pretty fast, so don't freak out. You also have to walk all the way around the building for access, no access on address listed. Follow the crowd.

Many visitors. We visited on a Wednesday and the site was full. Many students in their uniform. Its good that we visited with Hanoi kids and they somehow made up for the long lines. However, the site is very historical

Worth doing once.. We didn't go in to see Ho Chi Minh as we arrived a bit later in the morning, but it was quite an impressive looking building from the outside. Don't get too close otherwise the guards will blow their whistles at you (stay beind the yellow line)! If visiting to see 'Uncle Ho' in his glass case - don't forget about the dress code (no shorts, sleeveless tops, etc) they will not let any one in who is not dressed appropriately! Worth doing once - especially if you're into the history side of things.

A concrete cube with rude people. When we were there the mausoleum was closed, so we couldn't see ho's corpse... Though people say it's quite a creepy show...But we wanted to visit all the other places of the complex, like ho chi min's house.The place is so badly organized that we spent 3 hours walking around, asking for the police and "guides" where to go, and all of them said different things, often in a very bad mood. You feel like you are really bothering them in that place. There are no signs at all! The place is completely dirty.So we ended leaving the place very angry, and we could only see the one pillar pagoda (nothing really special) and the mausoleum from the outside, that is just a concrete box...

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum: Echos of the past.. The building is obviously Russian designed. Guards in full dress uniform patrol the perimeter of the mausoleum, which was not open on the day we visited the site. Still the plaza and the mausoleum were an impressive site.
A people's hero. This visit is a must for all history buffs. Even though the lines were endless and the sun relentless, it is very well organized and the crowds are orderly and respectful.

the queue is part of the experience. Arrived at 8.am on a Sunday to find queues already very long but only waited about an hour or so - very worthwhile experience, intresting to see the reverence shown to Ho Chi Minh. Walked in the gardens afterwards which was very pleasant.

Long long wait!!!!!. Dragged the kids along as this was something mainly my husband wanted to see. Felt a little intimidated by the sudden atmosphere created by guards, soldiers and police etc compared to the chaos just outside the gates!! Waited FOREVER in the long snaking line, asking a lot of the children to stay quite and well behaved. Most of us lacked a true understanding of the history so making this experience a bit of a time waster really. Kids weren't particularly phased by the body, which looks like a dummy.....and just wanted to see 'something' after all that waiting!!! Families beware, there must be a better time of day to go.

Thought-provoking. We went early in the morning and although there was a queue this moved very swiftly. You can't take in big bags or your own water - bags have to go through a scanner. You can't wear hats in the mausoleum itself. It was very moving seeing how respectfully 'Uncle Ho' is revered by young and old Vietnamese.
go very early to ensure you don't queue for hours round the block !!. We didn't get to see the dead president Ho Chi Minh due to time the queue was round the block at all of 9.30am !!! GO EARLY !!

Real??. Having queued for nearly 90 minutes to get into the mausoleum I was unsure whether or not the body is actually Ho Chi Minh, he looks waxy and a bit fake to be honest. Having got back a did a bit of reseach and in 2009 they had to shut and get experts in to examine as he wasnt preserving as well as thought. So not sure now if theyve made a statue or overcome degradation of the body. Either or its worth a look. I would suggest getting there early as it opens at 8am and shuts at 10.30am and there are a lot of people

Long wait. we stood around an hour and a half to see his bodyit seems like a must when visiting Hanoi.Be aware- big backpacks ( even ones you can enter to an airplane- can be consider big ones) are not allowed in- you need to leave them in a storage room that is closed by 11:30- so you have to be early in line to see the mausoleum....Camera are not allowed in too, and are being left in another storage place ( although if you have a small back pack that you can keep- your camera can be stored inside)

Into the Heart of Today's Vietnam. Our first tourist stop in Hanoi was to visit the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. I won't make comments about other related, nearby, sites that have their own Tripadvisor review pages, but will note here that the area has a number of sites, within easy walking distance of each other, that involve the legendary leader's life and legacy (such as where he lived, and his cars). I think this area and the mausoleum, in particular, represent the ideological and political heart of today's Vietnam and its reverential position clearly show in the beautiful grounds and state of upkeep. (I can't say spiritual heart as the nation is officially atheistic, as I understand it). So a visit to these sites should be recognized as significant, in terms of the history of the nation. It is worth spending some time reading a bit of its history to gain some background.The "street" in front of the mausoleum deserves notice. No traffic is seen, on what I estimated to be its width, equivalent to perhaps fifteen or more lanes. I do not know what its planners envisioned in its design, nor do I know how it is used. But on the day we were there, it appeared to me as a somewhat stark, silent, concrete reminder of human labor - and I should note that all the roads we were on during our stay, every few hundred feet or so, displayed red and yellow national flags often alternating with red and yellow hammer-and-sickle flags. The Soviet Union is gone, but its symbols, and the Soviet-designed mausoleum building conttaining Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body, present a sense of the country's Communist ideology. I don;t know if there is any place else in Vietnam that provides this experience.We were informed that the Soviets provided the technical assistance needed to preserve and maintain Ho Chi Minh's body, with their experience from embalming and maintaining Lenin's body, in Moscow.There were long lines but they moved efficiently, into the mausoleum, around corners, and finally into the darkened chamber the held the body on a raised platform,k lit by lights from above. No picture-taking was allowed. From the outside, we walked on red carpet into, through and out of the building, as I recollect.

Worth a visit. The queue is slightly offputting but the mausoleum is worth a visit and it is free. Our entire visit took 40 mins from start to finish and we then paid 25000 each to enter the grounds of Ho Chi Minh's presidential residence.

Ahh poor old Uncle Ho. Firstly you have to appreciate that this is against all of Ho Chi Mins last wishes as he had asked to be cremated to avoid this kind of spectacle. But he was a national hero so they kept him!It is busy, queues are very long due to most visiting Vietnamese wanting to visit, but they move at a good pace due to some over enthusiastic guards near on kicking peoples ankles to keep them moving and you are soon filed past the Embalmed body of Uncle Ho, he is looking quite good to say he's been dead 45 yrs!Apparently he is sent back to Russia for 3 months every year for a spruce up.Remember this is a mausoleum so dress with respect, you may be turned away if you are in shorts etc.Visit the museums after, there is a charge for this but you may as well check it out as you are nearby.

Huge monument-worth a look; even from outside. Didn't get to go in due to very very long queues on our Tuesday visit.-3rd week of MarchFrom tourist info it seems it is closed on Friday and Monday. The queue was enormous. All way along the front and around the corner past initial entrance check point.Despite this the view is very impressive from outside over near the grass fieldsWe were told:- approx 700 guards involved in duties at the mausoleum.- those in a white uniform at the steps of mausoleum are police and they change on the hour.- Green uniforms are apparently soldiers- And the grassed area opposite was cut by hand to remind of basic work life.Hints:Be respectful of the very high regard for Ho Chi Minh.Watch the guards changing--see their very high slow stepping action when coming down the steps.Listen for the whistles blown by soldiers (green uniform), and obey their signals/nods/pointingTo avoid a whistle:Don't wander aimlessly along the paved area adjacent to/opposite the mausoleum entrance.Don't sit down on any part of the huge open area pavement or on the side curb

Apiece of history. Although the mausoleum was closed (on Friday) we still chose to go to visit. You become awstruck while in front of the building. Guards are present and make sure the crowds remain at a distance and are respectful.
Interesting. Interesting to see the huge area outside the mausoleum and could imagine the impressive sight when military parades are there. Very smart soldiers on sentry!

Fascinating. We had to take a cab here, and when we saw the line to get in, which went for blocks, we were intimidated. I'm glad we stuck it out. The line moves fast and it's so amazing to see Ho Chi Minh.

See Chairman Ho Chi Minh. This is an absolute must. Get there early, around 8:00am, as the line gets longer and longer as the day goes on. It does move quickly though. Walking past Chairman Ho's body, even if you don't agree with his politics, is a rewarding experience.

Get there early. You can't get in to see the inside unless you are early...be quiet and respectful , then spend time in the gardens and temple, put yourself back to the early times when this was a real seat of power

A good place to visit. This was a fascinating place, we filed past the embalmed body of this revered leader, the armed guards made sure everyone was very respectful. There were other places to visit on the site and it was a good day out. It was an easy journey by local bus.

Shhhhhh!!!!. It was a long queue but moving. Begs & big cameras limitation during visiting were so confusing. Actually i'm not so sure what to expect, never read it properly. So i end up get the up get a fierce shhhhh! by the guard. Still blur why he shush me by when i pass by the "body" then only i understand. Weird but worth a visit. It's really amazing how Vietnamese really worship him. Just wondering with so many visitor daily like that, can he really rest in peace?

A must-see in Hanoi. We were surprised at how long the queue was and equally surprised as how quickly it went down, you were constantly movingInside the mausoleum was atmospheric and austere, with all the armed guards checking that you remain silent and respectful when walking around his body, which was very well preserved and left me feeling eerie. It was a surreal experience but one I wouldn't have wanted to miss.

Grave Experience. Very interesting experience to file past Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body lying in an illuminated glass case. The gravity of the occasion is evident from the demeanour of the mainly Vietnamese who musn't speak, laugh, have hands in pockets, take photos and dress modestly. You may be lucky to see the changing of the guards. All for free.

Yes, a must see event.. This was one of the weirdest experiences of my life. Fortuneately we didn't have to que as the line was only 50 metres long, but the attention to detail and the respect and honour for the former leader is infectious. Soldiers indicating hands out of pockets, uncrossed arms, no talking, no hats and keep shoulders and legs covered. Then to enter the chamber and see him there with nine armed guards in full military regalia. You cannot help but be impressed. It is quite eerie along with the sounds of sobbing women (and some men) it was an experience that left a very strong impression on my trip.

classy memorial. Well done memorial to Ho Chi Minh. The line moves steadily. The whole thing is more tastefully done than most such mausoleums. As I understand it, Ho Chi Minh wanted to be cremated, but that didn't happen.

Slightly odd but worth it. Didn't really know what to expect when I read this in the guide book but thought "when in Rome...!"The queue was massive when we arrived even though it was early but it moves quite fast as you cannot stop inside the mausoleum so it's always moving forwards.Personally I did find it very strange but glad I went.A few tips:We didn't take any bags or water or anything with us as you have to give everything up but it's up to you if you want your valuables in storage. Plus you have to find your way back to the different storage points when you come back out, a mission in itself.Check opening times and days so you don't trek all the way up there if you are staying like us in the Old Quarter to then find it closed!Read the do's and dont's of visiting and respect them for the sake of an important man and the Vietnamese people.Oh yeh you don't have to pay so don't know why some people have said they did, strange?

Must see if in Hanoi. Great to see place, but too many tourists, school kids, etc. Just so busy that it was a pain to get into the inside of with long, long lines and tour buses causing traffic jams out in front. Again, take a tour or take a guide.
Beautiful landscapes. Well worth a visit, beautifully landscaped grounds with the most amazing bonzai trees. Explore the site and enjoy the buildings and history.

Ho Chi Min looks like he is just sleeping. Had the chance to see again Ho Chi Min Mausoleum where the attraction is the preserved body of Vietnam's great leader. This time, my 78 year lod mother was with me. The queue was long but the place give special treatment to seniors. They provided a wheelchair for my mom. There was a lady who escorted us with an umbrella straight to the mausoleum, they did not ask us to queue. And at the foot of the mausoleum, there were 4 uniformed men ( very handsome) who carried the wheelchair where my mother sits & carried it inside until Ho Chi Min's body. It was a very memorable experience for my mother. I will be forever grateful to the Vietnamese for making my mother's visit very safe & respectable. Ho Chi Min's body was well preserved, he looked like he was just sleeping.

Good to see. We were there, early in the morning, but still there were so many tourists we had to queue and the "police" guarded as very well. We passed the mausoleum and saw the body of Ho Chi Mingh and it was a litte bit a strange atmosphere

Closed Mondays & Fridays. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was one of many attractions we visited during our Hanoi visit. Unfortunately, we were not able to see Ho Chi Minh's encased body as it was closed to visitors during our visit. We were told by our guide, that its closed Mondays and Fridays, so if you are planning to visit, check the schedule. Luckily, we did get to walk by the Ho Chi Minh's Residential, Presidential Palace and the One Pillar Pagoda, as it was close by and worth the trip.

Another must see. Although the architecture is a bit dour the mausoleum is another must see in Hanoi. The changing of the guard is well worth seeing and hopefully you will be lucky enough to be there when the local children are visiting. They are absolutely charming.

Fascinating, but Disarming. Going here was something I would have done on my own, but I went on a tour. You are rushed through by guards who are "socially challenged." You line up, walk into the Mausoleum single file, and get about 17 seconds to pass by the body encased in a glass box. But the entire "park" is beautiful, and as an American, the whole experience is interesting.
Respect even to date....... The place is guarded as if Uncle Ho was alive in there. The respect extended to his mortal remains is to be seen and experienced.
Not Worth the Bother.... Very disappointing and raining with it. Grim uninteresting structure with a red line so you don't get too close (!), His mummified body is in China anyway...

A hanoi must!. It really is an interesting and bizzare experience and a must for a visit to hanoi... (The first time I came here i didn't and really regretted it)The experience of actually seeing Unkle Ho in person is humbling and quite something - it is hard to believe it is man himself and it is evident how much the experience effects the Vietnamese visitors who are there paying their respects.

Place where Ho Chi Mi is mortal remains are kept. Place where Ho Chi Mi is mortal remains are kept , lots of jingoist communist graffiti this can make you bit uncomfortable if you come from culture that's anti communist

Great experience. The most important place in Vietnam and one that every single Vietnamese person attempts to visit at least in their life. It's only when you see the emotion of the local people that visit the mausoleum that you realise just how important this is to the nation.Yes, the rows of people are regimented and organised, and you have to go at the pace of the queue as dictated by the guards. But if that didn't happen you would probably wait all day to see Uncle. End of he day his is NOT a tourist attraction, it's a shine where the people pay their respects.No cameras allowed, no large bags and you must at least wear long knee length shorts and a have your shoulders covered.Well worth a visit. Also worth visiting shortly after daybreak for the flag raising ceremony. Grab a cyclo and have a quick trip around as the city wakes up.
Vietnam Oddessy. This visit throws a whole new perspective light on the American (Vietnam) war. An interesting tour and the surrounding area, well worth a visit.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Was quite surprised how good this was.We jumped the long que with our guide but i think this was really where we were supposed to go in he was just chasing a big tip.The rest of the city tour was a waste of time unless your into temples and average museum.

Glad I saw it - worth a look.. Yes there were queues but the line proceeded quite quickly. I would describe the building as austere and having an eerie feel to it. It is an important site to the Vietnamese who according to our guide are encouraged to visit every year. Not sure if there was an entry fee or not (we went as part of a day tour that encompassed other sites). The guards do usher people through quickly and cameras are not permitted. The viewing room is quite dark but the famous leader can be clearly seen and appears to be well preserved having passed away in 1969! If you are in Hanoi you should visit this.

A must-do in Hanoi. Besides the slightly odd spectacle of seeing Ho Chi Minh's preserved body a visit to the mausoleum and surrounding presidential offices and gardens is a really good way to get a feel for how important he and his ideas still are to the Vietnamese people. It's worth paying the small fee to go and see Uncle Ho's house and offices but I wouldn't bother with the museum (the giant concrete building you'll go past as you enter the complex), it was just one floor with nothing really worth looking at.

Outstanding architecture and displays. Dedicated to the life of Ho Chi Minh, slanted toward party propaganda but an excellent museum nontheless. A true hero to the Vietnamese people, and deservedly so, although I think he would have been upset with the direction that the present policies have taken.

Fascinating. Be sure to approach the mausoleum form the Ngoc Ha side otherwise you have a lengthy walk to the visitor entrance. A must see if only to witness the respect the Vietnamese pay to "Uncle Ho" as they file past him.

Ho Chi Minh's memorial - unbelievable. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is unlike anything I've seen before. His body is hauntingly life like. The viewing is very organized, everyone in a line and moves very quickly with more than enough time to view Ho Chi Minh.*Make sure your shoulders and legs are covered to your knees or you cannot enter.
magnificent!. i did not expect to see what i saw! you must see it for yourself.if you're traveling on weekend, don't go too early or expect an extreme crowd. go just before 11AM or after lunch time.

Historically interesting. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was the 1st place we visited in Hanoi. It was an impressive site, what helped me to appreciate the site was our tour guide. I found the history of Ho Chi Minh rule interesting and worth hearing.  It does not take much time to see the Mausoleum but it is worth visiting. If you are visiting on your own without a guide to better appreciated the mausoleum take a few minutes to read the history of Ho Chi Minh.

EErie. It was an experience. Quite noticeable that there remains a total love and respect for Ho Chi Minh. One could not talk while observing Ho Chi enclosed in glass and fully looking alive. It was a bit creepy at first and the room was very dim lit so one was not seeing him in daylight. Still I thought it was pretty cool!

Suprised or what. If I told you too much here you might not go to see it because its all over in a few minutes. You only get to see this sort of thing a couple of other places in the world. GO see it.

Saw more than I expected. We took a cheap taxi trip from the old quarter and were relieved to escape those crowded little streets and see a nicer side of Hanoi. We went early at about 8am and although there was a line up it wasn't too long. Be warned, you must wear trousers to cover your knees and a shirt with sleeves otherwise you will not get in also do not cross your arms while going into the mausoleum, disrespectful I assume. Did not realise you did not have to pay to enter which was another surprise. Cameras and water bottles are taken at the entrance and returned to you on the other side of the mausoleum. It was an experience I was very glad that I did. On opposite side of mausoleum you pay a small fee to see the Ho Chi Minhs house on stilts and other attractions which were well worth visiting. I am so glad I visited this attraction.

Befitting a great statesman. This spacious and well-organised layout is really grand to commemorate such a great statesman who had contributed so much to the country and so loved by the people. The museum nearby illustrates so much of the country's modern history.

See the most loved man in Vietnam.. The entry is free and you are guided along the footpaths all the way to the mausoleum. Inside is very atmospheric with immaculately dressed armed guards, red carpets and an eerie cold silence. You can view Uncle Ho quite clearly and he is well looked after. My heart was beating with excitement and appreciation for being able to see the man. Incredible experience. Best to get there shortly after opening, and if you are interested it is just a short 10 minute walk to the Lenin statue.

A must visit and this bit is free. This part of the attraction is free and well visited.We arrived at 8.30 and only had a 20 minute queue. We did have to walk in line and no cameras allowed and you file past Ho Chi Minh and his 4 guards. Quite humbling experience and well arranged. A real must see site

Interesting. Long but fast moving line. Was surprised by the large number of school children in attendance; also surprised by the poor behaviour of the teachers. Saw one teacher run after a larger westerner to take a photo and laugh at then. Interesting experience but I think "uncle ho's" body is now more wax than flesh and looked as such. A must do in hanoi and works in well with the propaganda trifecta of the prison and revolution museum.

An extremely serious place. A visit to Uncle Ho gives an excellent insight int Vietnamese people, Government and society. Visits are strictly controlled, with young soldiers, resplendent in pressed white uniforms and huge epaulets, stationed every few metres, on constant lookout for the smallest deviation from correct route and appropriate demeanor. The building itself is impressive and Ho Chi Minh looks peaceful but of most interest is watching Vietnamese people, some with tears streaming down their faces, file solemnly past their revered former leader. Fascinating.

A trip highlight!. Seeing Ho Chi Mihn's body was a highlight of my vacation in Vietnam, because he's a hero to the people.It's well worth the experience. Chances are, you'll be on the same tour that affords the opportuning of walking along the lake where U.S. Senator John McCain was shot down in the 1960s.

The guards should not follow and rush the tourists. I found the guards in green quite abrupt and annoying while we were going through the mausoleum and the residence . At the mausoleum, while walking briskly , the guards would rush us along, even nudging us with their hands to make us hurry. I thought we were already going at a brisk clip. While walking (again at a good pace), through the house and gardens, they would blow the whistle at people, and making motions with their hands to hurry us. We hardly could take photos!
well maintained. It was quick and our tour guide gave a quick history into it. Seems like HCM uncle is well preserved. I would have thought he would be in HCMC instead of Hanoi though.

Regimentation. Huge queues but don't be put off. It doesn't take too long to reach your destination. I was amazed at the condition of Ho Chi Minh. Much better than that of Lennon in Moscow when I saw him many years ago. You need to arrive fairly early in the morning as I think the Mausoleum closes at 11.30 am

Visit to see uncle Ho. We found it a long way walking as we had to walk around the whole area and come in the back way.The time is restricted to mornings but the long queue closes at 10 30 am and we only just made it.However it was worth seeing as it's something you may never see again and so the experience was a learning curve. The main thing that spoiled was all the tatt for sale at the end of the tour and the aggressive vendors.
A bit eery and sad. Did not expect to see uncle hos body lying there on full view....think its sad that his wish was to be cremated and he is being displayed in this way

how bazar. to look at him in a glass box, on show what a contradiction but you have to see it. Go early to miss the long queues and to see all the other things to look at as well, remember its not open Mondays

Quick Look. The site is strictly monitored. The line moves quickly with guards at every turn making sure no one loiters. No cameras are allowed, so the only picture is fixed in one's mind. We got there very early and did not have to wait - we walked directly to the tomb, went in and were out in less than 15 minutes.

Sad place. The security at this site was very tight protecting their old, (dead) leader, I found it all very over pretentious, the soldiers wearing white uniforms, and chosen because they are handsome and severe background checks are done before they can take up their position. The body of the leader looks very fake, the yellowish lite shining n his hands and face, make the body logo as though t was not real.

Ho Chi Minh wish not met. President Ho Ci Minh wanted his body to be cremated, but the generals and the communist party of that time decided not to keep the wishes of this man, and instead follow previous communist party leaders in maintaining the body for all to see, whether you are a local or a visitor .On my visit to the mausoleum, I waited only a short time, as the queue was moving at a great pace, in the entry a very impressive building not only for now, but when the Vietnamese built it.The background told to me by my guide was that in order to maintain the body and the complex it is equivalent to 100 adult wages for 20 years at the current rate of pay,
Don't waste your money!. This was such a waste of time and money. You can see everything in that place and still be out in 10 minutes. Don't bother!

Solemn moment, well organised. Ignore the queue if there is one, as its organised to the point of precision, so you won't have to wait long. Guards ensure everyone keeps moving. The whole experience makes you understand that Uncle Ho was/is accorded the highest respect.

Interesting. We stopped by on a tour of Hanoi as it seems an important place to see in Vietnam's history. We saw the changing of the guards, but you aren't able to get inside or even relatively close to building. Its interesting to think about how important Ho still is to the country of Vietnam.
An amazing experience. This was so regimented and organised! Its hard to appreciate how a leader/politician can be so revered coming from the west!

The most important place in Hanoi. Majestic monument towering over small tourists, who cannot cross the line and get too close.Surrounded by wide walking area, too far when it rains. But there are always flowers to colour up the area.

Great Experience. Very tight security! You can bring in big bag. They scan your bag like in airport. No camera. No mobile phone. No talking. Have to walk in long line to enter the mausoleum. In side the mausoleum you can see elevated Uncle Ho's preserved body. He is wearing traditinal viet costume completed with beard exactly like in photo. Just google it. Nearby you could learn on how humble Uncle Ho living his life.
Check opening times. Although we arrived on a day when access was limited it was still fascinating to walk around the buildings and appreciate the floral displays.

Glad I went. First visit to a mausoleum. I am glad I went. I liked the whole experience of queuing and the military telling you where to put your arms etc. I have done loads of travel and like to take in all the sights and this was not exception. Something different to back home.
Meh. Somewhat anti-climatic experience and not at all worth the time but still something you can say you have done

Interesting start to our Vietnam visit. To understand the importance of Ho Chi Minh in Vietnam's history helped us set the stage for our Vietnam visit. You will pass through a couple security checkpionts before entering the mausoleum. Appropriate dress and quiet is demanded; guards are everywhere, and they do not hesitate to tell you to be quiet and respectful. Fortunately we had a private driver who directed us where to enter, or I'm not sure we would have found the entrance.

Get there early!. Well worth the effort to see Uncle Ho, as long as you get there early and beat the crowds. Very cheap; maybe only a couple of bucks (Vietnamese get in for free). The adjoining museum is a little odd though - if you're strapped for time give it a miss.

Excellent mausoleum. If you like to see the remains of dead people this place is excellent for that. I would have liked to have spent more time but they only allow you about a minute to pay your respects.

Stand where Ho Chi Minh is honoured. Sombre place, very large numbers of school kids, Vietmanese and western visitors. Quick visit was worth it just to experience the huge respect shown by almost everyone who comes to worship the greatest Vietmanese leader in recent times.
Immaculate. Very well maintained mausoleum. ordelryl lines which move very fast. huge open square in front. old house next door. The whole city is clean.

Was not able to enter. The area around the Mausoleum is vast, and good for running and people watching. The Mausoleum isn't open all the time, so make sure you check times. Also, get a tour of the place for the history and information.

Interesting. Not something I would normally choose, to view a corpse on holiday but it was pre-bokked by our tour guide and it was a strangely interesting / conflicting not to say moving experience. I have been told that in the summer the queues can sometimes take 3 hours or more but fortunately we more or less walked right in.

A must see in Hanoi. I agree with other reviews - you must see this if you are in Hanoi - it is such a part of the city. It was shut when we were there in October but was impressive enough from the outside (even with the rain!).

Worth a visit. HCM Mausoleum is one of the attractions that's worth visiting when you're in Hanoi. When you're there, you will really feel how Vietnamese value everything that Uncle Ho did for Vietnam. His mausoleum is located near the museum and there is also a garden at the back and a pagoda. I suggest you go there when you can get in the mausoleum itself for a full experience!
HCM Mausoleum. Very impressive site and great to see the gaurds in the beautiful uniforms. Make sure you check its hours of opening because they are limited.

Very impressive. Crowds of people go every day to visit Ho Chi Minch Mausoleum. If you don't have an appointment you should stay on the line for some time (we didn't wait long as we were affraid), but it is a good opportunity to study people from different countries. When you go inside you follow a corridor that leads to the transparant coffin with His body inside. The atmosphere was moving, many people (Asian mainly) were crying because the loved him and admired him because he was a wise and decent politician. I madmired him too!

Don't ever miss the visit. It's a worthy and memorable visit to this Mausoleum, the area is quite huge but well organized by all the staff. Your stay in Hanoi won't be completed without visiting this wonderful Mausoleum.

A must for history buffs. A highlight of our trip, this is a must see for all who are interested in the history of Vietnam. Before going, make yourself aware of the rules for visiting such as no cameras, silence in the mausoleum and conducting yourself with respect.
Huge. Although the museum was closed (closed on Mondays I guess) the Mausoleum was open - it was huge - so much bigger than I ever expected.

A must see. Nothing compares to the experience of joining the entire procession that leads you to the mausoleum. It's stunning. Watch out for the opening hours (8 to 11 am only), and 2 months a year the mausoleum is not open to public. The line went very fast so dont get intimidated by the crowds it's all very well managed. Very, very unique experience.
Watch where you step. An impressive monument. Watch where you are walking! There is a line you may not cross over in front of the building.

Have to go. Opens only until 10:15 am, worth the visit. A very interest experience.. there is always a big line but go for it, the line moves fast! The tip is not to bring a bag, they will make you put in a storage that many people say doesn't look safe... no photos inside so leave your bag at the hotel.

Worth doing. Go early to avoid the crowds. Check the days it is closed. You are not able to take cameras into the mausoleum nor large bags. There are lockers for storage. Often the body of Ho Chi Minh is away for cleaning.we were lucky the embalmed body was in residence.

A lot of rules. If the lines are long I would skip, I am not sure Ho would have wanted The pomp and ceremony. Guards are excessive in rules, no cameras allowed in site, no talking, hands must be at your sides . So ok but missable

Good history. The people are very fond of "Uncle Ho" We enjoyed paying our respect to an important person in Vietnamese society. Grounds are well kept and interesting history on site. Very much worth seeing. Be aware they will not allow cameras on tour to visit Ho Chi mins body and you must drop off at a small kiosk. You can pick up camera afterwards and take pictures out side of mausoleum.

one of top attractions in Hanoi. Interesting to see but lots of control and rules with plenty of guards. Have to be quiet and respectful to enter and walk by well preserved body in a glass box. There is controversy as to if this is really his body or a reproduction. It looked too good to be real.

A must... Visiting the Mausoleum seems to me as a must. Seeing all the worshiping Vietnamese people, seeing the way this leader lived in the most modest way is highly impressive, even to one who hate glorification gestures like me..
Impressive Mausoleum. Very impressed with this site ! Surroundings are very beautiful and the Mausoleum itself if really impressive !

Get there early. Our guide took there first thing in the morning (around 9) as he knew that later in the morning there would be very long queues of people waiting to enter the mausoleum.Cameras and telephones are forbidden inside the building so you will have to leave them with your guide (hoping he doesn't leg it!). It only takes about 1 minute to see Ho Chi Minh's body.

Interesting to see. I wasn't sure what to expect before visiting here, but had heard quite a lot about Ho Chi Minh when visiting Saigon and thought I should really visit where he had lived.The grounds around Ho Chi Minhs home and the buildings themselves are very well maintained.Its quite incredible to see such a powerful man now at rest in a Mausoleum as though he is asleep.

100% must see. Who knows if it is really him.... We are told it was but we were very surprised that they have him on show like that. You have to walk in single file past him, with your hands by your side and no smiling. No photos allowed and get there early as the queues are massive.

A calm respectful experience. There are lots of rumors and legends about whether that's really Uncle Ho in that display case; people talk about his yearly visits to Russia to be refurbished, about the fact that it's a wax dummy and he's really kept in some town outside of Hano; the legend about identiying him by one abnormally long digit. Whatever the reality, it's nice to walk solemnly with Vietnamese and pay one's respects to a great man. There are also other exhibits on the grounds, including the overly honestly titled "Ho's Used Cars", three vehicles Ho used during his life, and a replica of the stilt house Ho lived in during the beginning of the struggle agaisnt the French. Worth visiting.

A reminder of how some things used to be,while ultimately an humble homage to Ho Chi Minh. I am sure if you ever visited Soviet era Russia;more recently China or yet more presently North Korea,you will find ,as I did many reminders of what is for a lot of the world a bygone era.Nevertheless,ultimately I was glad I took the time to visit the Mausoleum.Fast-forwarding and as mentioned elsewhere the queue (line) moves along briskly and what appears as a futilr hope of admission can fairly soon seem an unjustified fear.The ultimate raison d'etre is somewhat stark while retaining humility and reverence.Some reminders for visitors;The Mausoleum observes some practices,as is entirely their right and for the most part are no more than common sense - no shorts or indecorous clothing.You are not permitted to directly approach the area ;as pictured directly. This involves a circumnavigation of the site.Vigilant soldiers will shout and whistle if you transgress,You will not be required to deposit small rucksacks or cameras before entry but cannot take water through the security check area,where your bag will be scanned as in an airport.Having said this,and bearing in mind my opening caveat which entertains the possibility that any given day or hour may be different,I do commend a visit.

So many rules, for a walk pass. I understand this is the resting place of a great man to Vietnam, so some rules needs to be made to show proper respect.However, i did find it rather restricting. No photos in many areas, bags bigger then certain size not allowed, and so on...All that for a quick walk pass as you are hurried along but the stern faced guards..I don't think you are missing out much if you did not go for this.

Impressive edifice for a humble man of the people. This is an odd memorial to a man who was promoted as being a humble man of the people, "Uncle Ho". Apparently Ho Chi Minh requested that he be cremated after death but that wish wasn't granted and this huge edifice was built to commemorate the father of modern Vietnam. The grounds are just as imposing as the building itself, with wide streets (probably useful for passing military parades). That said, however, it was good to be able to see him in the flesh, so to speak, even if you can't get closer than a few metres to have a good look. There was a big line when we were there but it moved quickly. You don't get time to loiter when walking around the body. While no photos are allowed inside, you can take plenty of the outside on your way out. It is free entry but not open every day so check before you head off. Don't miss Ho Chi Minh's presidential residence while you are in the area.

Ho Chi Minh. They take this VERY serious. No cameras or iPads. Proper dress required (long sleeves for men, shoulders covered for women, no shorts). You must be quiet. Follow their strict instructions (stand in proper lines, no hands in pockets etc.). White dressed soldiers everywhere. A quick walk around Ho Chi Minh in his glass case and VERY cold mausoleum.

Eyes straight ahead.... If you're happy to be straitjacketed by innumerable rules, it's an unforgettable experience.You'll have your camera taken from you, and pretty much anything can be taken as contravention of some rule or another; you can't read a book, look down, walk above or below a certain pace, make eye contact with anyone else, make any noise, or really do anything apart from slowly walk forward with your eyes straight ahead.If you can handle all of that, then it's a beautiful building, and a privilege to get up close and personal with a figure like Uncle Ho. A Hanoi highlight.
Memorable. This is probably one of the experiences I shall always remember. The whole process from queueing up to seeing the body is truly memorable. It is a very impressive site.

Surreal Experience. This was a surreal experience. The buildings are fashioned in the Soviet-era style with wide, almost boulevard like walkways. Very stark looking building. A brief journey to another time and place.

Experience it. Went with a small group and was awed by the expanse of the mausoleum. It was a cold rainy day and there was no waiting, so we moved quickly to view the body. Very solemn experience. Glad I did it.
grey day, grey building. Mausoleum was closed so we just did an outside visit. I guess it's on the MUST DO list but a driveby would have sufficed.
dead boring. Want on a rainy day.. frogmarched along designated pathway to the Concrete bunker... shame Uncle Ho wanted to be cremated but now waxed up in his coffin. At least lenin is near St Basils

A typical Mausoleum, bombastic and cold.. I quite enjoyed watching the guards goose-stepping to and fro. The gloomy rectangular, pillared building is supposed to remind you of a lotus flower. It doesn't. It is not what Ho Chi Minh wanted, at all!

Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh: 43 years dead and still lying in state.. This was the quintessential communist experience: get in line, single file, no cameras, no phones, no talking, no hands in pockets, look straight ahead, and walk by the waxen corpse of a revered leader. The irony of all this is that Ho Chi Minh wanted to be cremated but the Politburo thought better of it. They decided that Uncle Ho could be better put to use as the well-preserved perpetual symbol of unification of the North and the South.This visit included a walk by the beautiful French state house that HoChi Minh rejected and a peak at the 3-room traditional Vietnamese house on stilts that he preferred.
A must see !. Slightly macabre - but probably a "must" for visitors to Hanoi. Enjoyed the trip around the grounds and our guides explanations more.

Creepy attraction. I would pass on this site it is a little weird and propaganda inspired. Visiting the site, however, with all the military presence and flag flying brings home the presence of communism in this country which was interesting for us as visitors.

Must visit in Hanoi. This is The monument of Hanoi. Architecture is strongly inspired by Lenin's mausoleum in Moscow, and the whole area is very grandiose and triumphal. You must leave your bags at entrance if you have anything potentially "dangerous" with you (like knifes, scissors or liquids). We just drank our water bottles and were allowed to take our bags with us.You don't pay anyhing at the entrance, but after you leave the mausoleum itself you're forced to pay 25 000 dong per person if you're not Vietnamese. Then there's a park where some Ho's premises and presents from other leaders of countries in that era are presented.Overall, recommended visit, but expect armed soldiers making you to go in a straight pair formation into and out of the mausoleum.

Very Strict! Too Strict in fact. It felt weird to be treated like schoolkids in the area. We are to fall in line like in grade school. Cant speak, cant laugh, cant even cross your arms. No camera, no bottled water... STRICT!But it puts the message across that their respect, reverence and gratitude to Mr Ho is very very high.I love the complex aside from the visit to the Mausoleum.

Get there early. The mausoleum has restricted hours and can get very busy. We arrived at 7:30 for the 8:00am opening and walked right in. Be sure to go to the Ho Chi Minh museum nearby for more of the story.
Very interesting. This place is amazing. The history of this great man and what he did for his country, puts him up there with all the other great leaders. A must visit when in Hanoi.

Excellent part of history. We found this place really interesting although I can understand why it's not everyone's cup of tea. We didn't go until about 11am on a Saturday (it shuts at 11:30am) and found it was very quiet and no lines. The body itself is free to view, but you pay to go into the palace later on. It was a strange experience but very well worth it. There are a lot of rules that I suggest you follow because the guards are quite strict. I'd say it's a must do in Hanoi.

Show respect for 'Uncle Ho'.. A visit to the Mausoleum, if nothing esle, will remind you you're in a Communist country. The guards organising the queues and guarding the building are stern and have total authority. You will be told to be quiet when approaching the room with Ho Chi Minh's casket, uncover your heads, and treat the whole experience with reverence. It might appear curious to us, but he really is still considered the saviour of Vietnam.
Another must when your in Hanoi. A strange experience but none the less a must whilst you are in Hanoi, I'm glad I visited. Be warned though, no cameras, no speaking and be respectful at all times!
Very well done exhibition. This museum is very well set out. There is an English explanation of all the exhibits. Didn't dislike anything about it
Strange experience. We were told to go in single file and warned not to talk. I found it almost creepy to look on someone who has been dead for over 40 years.

Bizarre ...... It is quite an expirence. It sort of felt like paying respect at an open coffin. You will be told on how to keep your hands. You are not permitted to wear sun glasses. There is a security check at the entrance area and your camera equipment will be kept in storage (except the small ones). This seems not to be a matter of logic.On a sunny hot day you might want to bring a sun hat or umbrellar, there is no shade while standing in line to get into the mausoleum and you never know how long or short the wait is.

Go see a wax copy of Uncle Ho. They insist this is a very well preserved body of Uncle Ho but I would bet with 90% certainty it is a wax figure. They are quite strict about walking in lines, not talking and not using your camera. Some guy pulled out his camera to take a photo of the wax Ho Chi Minh and was prompty whisked away into an interrogation room. Never saw him come out. It is a unique experience. Be aware it is open very limited hours. A great thing to combine with the museum and the palace grounds.
Surreal. This is a truly bizzare experience as you have so many rules to follow. They even broadcast the air quality on the way through the line. But a trip to Hanoi must include this experience.

I just met Ho Chi Minh. Just nice for the whole experience with the guards! Fast to visit but a must see. Ho Chi Minh is well conserved. Got to make sure you can see him because in some months the Mausoleum is close.
Paying Respect. If you love the sceneries and your stay in Hanoi, its but proper to pay respect to the person behind modern Vietnam.Be there early, and behave accordingly.

Bad timing. Sadly we arrived on a Monday to find the mausoleum and the museum both closed.We return on the Tuesday to find they had closed for lunch. we were unable to return before we left. Check the times to museums before leaving Hotels so as not to be disapointed like us.

An intriguing but essential experience. On the face of it, visiting a rather worryingly well-preserved body in a display case, doesn't seem the most obvious way to enjoy a holiday. However Ho Chi Minh's contribution to modern Vietnam is so integral to the political and cultural structure of the country that one simply has to visit the Mausoleum. Of course, Ho Chi Minh himself never wanted to be displayed (rather he wanted his cremated body to be scattered across the three main regions of the country) but his successors and admirers were determined to pay homage to him, and so it is. At times the queues are likely to be enormous and the mausoleum is only open for five days and only until 10.30 in the morning - so be prepared to get up early and get there before the tourist buses and endless school parties. And, above all, one has to be respectful (the many military guards make sure of that !!) - so no talking, no hands in pockets, no dawdling, and definitely no photography. It will be a short visit - the guards again make sure the queue moves quickly - but it is most definitely memorable and together with all the other institutions named after "Uncle Ho", you do get to understand how important a figure he really was and how proud the Vietnamese are of their achievements thanks to him and his colleagues.

Rarely open. These days Ho Chi Minh isn't as hospitable. If you step across a yellow painted line apporx. 30 metres from the edge of the mausoleum, you get a whistle blown your way by a stern guard.The actual opening times of the mausoleum itself was difficult to discover; an impressive and imposing building nevertheless.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum in Vietnam – Homage to the Loved Son of the Soil. Any visit to Hanoi and so also Vietnam would be incomplete without paying homage to its favored son Ho Chi Minh by visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum located a the center of Ba Dinh Square and the place where Minh declared independence in 1945. The 21.6 meters high and 41.2 meters wide structure have a couple of platforms on either side of the mausoleum used to view parade. Front side of the mausoleum is divided into 240 green squares with pathways separating one from the other. Highlight of the mausoleum is the surrounding garden that houses over 250 divergent species of plants and flowers. Embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh has been preserved in the central hall with a military honor guard protecting it. The place remains open to public from 9.00 AM to 12.00 Noon. Strict dress and behavior codes are enforced in the mausoleum and visitors need to be prepared for no smoking, no drinking, no eating, and no photography, observing silence, and dress covering legs.

Surprisingly moving.. Definitely get here early so you don't need to stand in line too long. We got there at 7:30am. Really well organized (read regimented), huge line of visitors and very moving actually seeing the very famous Uncle Ho.

Moausoleum and Presidential Palace. The importance and respect of the Vietnamese people for Ho Chi Minh is obvious by the long line-up awaiting to view his body, not just tourists but the locals as well. An important part of history and a must see.

Should not miss this. It is a well organized attraction but only open until 11am in the summer as it gets too hot to stand in line. Be sure to cover your arms ladies and no shorts or short skirts. The line moves quite fast and you go right into the mausoleum where Ho Ch Min lies in state in an open coffin and looks jut as he died in 1969. No cameras allowed and 4 guards stand y the cakes at all times. The grounds are well kept and the museum is also worth visiting too.

Mausoleum of a hero. This is another place I missed in my last visit to Hanoi. Worth a visit. Clean,tidy and well maintained. It is an interesting experience. There was a Q but moving fast. One cannot call it a tourist attraction but the body,the massive building and the museum attached to it are some thing to see. The botanical garden is also not very far from the mausoleum. The visitors can cover both in one visit. Not very far from the Old Quarters.
Make sure you come early. This is kind of an one-time experience. A must if you go to Hanoi but then it is enough just going once.

It's a massive construction. We visited during the afternoon and unfortunately the Mausoleum was closed however we were able to walk around the immaculate gardens and see the 'changing of the guard' .It was very nice to find this very large area in the city that was quiet, motorbike free and relatively polution free.It is worth a visit just to see how one man was so revered by the masses, the extent of the construction and the size of the place is amazing.

Politics. Was so cold on my first day in Hanoi that the visit to this was coloured by my lack of suitable clothing. Again it would have been better if I had done some more research on Vietnam's history before I went.

strange experience. This is apparently the real Ho Chi Minh on display, although it looks remarkably like a waxwork. Quite a long queue to get in and military personal everywhere with instructions not to smile, not to cross your arms etc. It really was a mist bizare experience!
A Place to see. the place was not crowded and we moved along easily to see the mausoleum and body - I did not find it creepy or overdone, as I expected.

A good cultural experience. An interesting experience in many ways. We were shepherded in two lines leading up to and through the mausoleum. It is strictly controlled by uniformed guards and visitors are expected to be respectful (no talking, bare heads, etc). We weren't allowed much time as the line was moving along slowly but it did help to explain the importance of this man to the Vietnamese.

Emotional atmosphere. After all the bustle of the city, a trip here reminds you that Vietnam is in fact a communist country. We hadn't intended going as we knew that 'Uncle Ho' was out for repair but we found ourselves in the area with time to spare. Despite it being closed there were still plenty of people milling around and I have to say that I was unnervingly moved by the whole thing. I'm not sure I would have queued up to see the actual body but I am glad i saw the mausoleum and its surrounds. It helps you understand the reverence and love the Vietnamese people have for him
Interesting , long wait. As mentioned walk on left , cover arms and wear long pants . Arms by side , leave camera in bays and remember where you leave it . Interest plus
Must See. The complex, including the Ho Chi Minh museum and residence, is excellent. The museum, in particular, is exceptionally well designed and informative.

Amazing!. The Vietnamese love their 'Uncle Ho Chi Minh'. They have his body displayed in the mausoleum, where it seems his body hasnt aged a day since he died. Although strict instructions when dealing with the body e.g. hands by your side, only look forward, quiet voices etc.

Worth a visit both for the architecture and historical significance. This is a most impressive building both inside and out. Lovely lawns when you approach the building ( in long lines of people ) and most impressive bonsai on the other side.Viewing the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh didn't do a lot for me personally but I realise he is still a hero to many Vietnamese. The Botanic Gardens behind the mausoleum are also well worth a looksee.No big cameras allowed into the mausoleum and no photography with any cameras.

Reminds you where you are!. Vietnam is so geared to capitalism that It's easy to forget sometimes that this is a communist country. The military pomp of the mausoleum reminds you. The grounds are nice and this makes for a great half-day sightseeing stop. Keep walking down the street on which the entrance is located to find some wonderful local food -- just small restaurants on the street, but really delicious. (Pick one with lots of locals sitting outside.)

Wow. The whole process of this visit was amazing. They make you form two lines and move you through very efficiently. They make sure your hands are not in your pockets, you have no hat on, you are quiet and generally respectful. A quick viewing of a remarkably preserved Ho (although my kids were convinced they saw him move).

Worth a visit whilst in Hanoi. The first day we arrived the queue was a mile long with heaps of school kids in the queue. We decided to leave and come back the next day and get in the queue early. The doors opened at 8am and we got there at 730am and the queue had already started, although not that bad. This was a good move, as by the time you walk to the building its all over in about 3 minutes if that.The first day we arrived the taxi driver dropped us right around the back on the far side of the grass overlooking the parade ground, we walked and walked and asked guards as we went how to get to the front, they just point. The second day another taxi driver tried to drop us to the side near that back, we told him no and to keep going, not sure what it is but the taxi driver didn't want to go near the front, probably traffic!Alot of donts.... don't walk on the grass near the parade ground, no hands in pockets, no hats and no speaking... we watched people being told to shush and hand signals to get hands out of pockets. Fair enough alot of this should be common sense anyhow!If your there at the right time you might see the army in action and their version of changing of the guards. It's an impressive sight.There are a few steps inside the building and it's free of charge.

Historically interesting. I am not for hero worshipping and sanctification of people and therefore do not consider this to be a highlight. I appreciate the significance of this to the Vietnamese people, especially the people of Northern Vietnam - I did not get the same level of appreciation from the South Vietnamese, for probably obvious reasons. It is interesting to go and see the old man from a curiosity perspective. The building is quite impressive and the number and age of bonsai around the mausoleum is amazing. From a historical perspective a definate to go and see. If you are not that interested in the history of Vietnam and vietnamese people, there are other more exiting things to go and see.

amazing building surrounded by beautiful gardens. Just satnding before this anazing ediuface was the tiem we invested, the gardens aroud it are quite nice, but most impressive is the scale of this place, right in the midlde of a vey congested city--amazing!
Inspirational. A very impressive place to visit. Well organised and easy to get to I could get there walking from my hotel also very close to Literature temple.

Before you head for the mausoleum, know where the entrance is located. Hanoi could improve on signage for tourists.On my quest for the mausoleum I ran into several other tourists who weren't aware of the entrance location either so as several roads were blocked (Ministry of Defence) we walked an extra few kilometres. So prepare and avoid the extra hike.You'll get instructions from the staff although the instructions are not always clear (leave bag behind, don't leave bag; leave camera behind, don't leave valuabes...). Read the Lonely planet for some clear instructions on how to dress (properly) and what to bring).Lines were short and moved fast. You're inside the actual mausoleum for just a few minutes and walk around HCM takes less than one minute. Yet it's impressive.After your (free) visit the route takes you to the (paid) presidential palace. It's quite a struggle to exit the place without visiting the palace yet it is possible.

Go see "Uncle Ho". Get there first thing 8am. We were able to avoid most of the crowds. It was a fascinating, odd, regimented process but really worthwhile. The preserved body of Ho Chi Minh is highly revered. Just, whatever you do, follow the signs, don't put your hands in your pockets and don't make eye contact with the body. Tee Hee.

Strange but interesting. We wanted to understand the Ho Chi Minh story, and the experience was quite weird. Standing in line being strictly controlled by guards and then filing slowly through past the body - wouldn'yt have missed it.

Very different. This is certainly a different experience to anything I have been to before. At security I had to argue my small backback handbag was my handbag and I didn't want to check it in. I still checked in my water. You queue up. It's cold like a fridge. It all goes silent. The guards tell you to take your hands out of your pockets. The westerners get put onto the outside and literally pulled along by the guards. Do it !

Organized with military precision. You cannot go to Hanoi without visiting the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. However, the visit is that you cannot meander past. No hats on, no hands in pockets, no cameras and no talking, single file and you're in and out in a matter of minutes. I left wondering wether it really was Ho Chi Minh or a very clever wax model.

A must see. This is really a must-see when you are in Hanoi. You line up, no giggling, camera or disrespectful behavior. We got caught in the loop again, and had to see it twice, because we were afraid that someone would get offended if we left the queue. Well worth it. Very memorable and you should continue to learn more about him. A very interesting person that was misunderstood by most non-vietnamese leaders.

Must see. The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is a must see, if only just for the experience of it as it seems kind of bizarre to Westerners. You are ushered through a maze of walkways in single/double file as per whichever guard is on duty, and then quickly and silently ushered into the room where Ho Chi Minh lies. Then upon exiting, guards keep you away from in front of the monument. A really fascinating experience.Do this in one trip with Ho Chi Minh's house which is next door, then visit Van Mieu (literature temple) and one pillar pagoda followed by lunch at Koto which is a lovely restaurant right near the temple. All this can be done in about 1.5 hours plus lunch.
Different from the ocidental way. Completely different from the way heroes have a place were people pay respect to them in the Occidental part of the world. It is impressive, huge. A must see.

Behave yourself!. Very strict guards - you have to part from your camera before going inside, stay in line and take your hands out of your pockets, otherwise you're in trouble!75% of visitors are Vietnamese, including school children paraded through. If the queue is not too long, still worth a look at the great man. Closed between September-November, when the body is sent to Moscow for preservation.

Grounds are spectacular. Check the hours for the Mauseleum prior to planning your day. I'm sure that it will be we'll worth the visit. Missed seeing the Mauseleum, but the grounds, lake and buildings related to Ho Chi Mahn were really spectacular. A step back in time. Well worth the visit!
Specious.. Special to see the precident laying in his coffin inside the mausoleum. Never see anything like that. special atmosphere inside the Maousoleum.

Go early. Make sure you check the opening times of the mausoleum. It is shut on Mondays and only open in the mornings on other days. We went at about 8am and there was already a queue, albeit not too long. I can imagine that at peak times, it would be miserable standing in the rain or in the heat.No photos are allowed and the guards are very strict so make sure your kids, if you have any with you, and indeed yourselves, behave respectfully and immaculately otherwise you may get a tap on the shoulder.

Worth a visit, impressive grounds as well. The ambience and detail to HCM propaganda is worth a visit. Even though the actual view of HCM's preserved body is about 30 seconds-- you are herded through the mausoleum and pics are strictly forbidden-- the atmosphere is fascinating.I would skip the museum on the ground unless you have a keen interest in other Vietnamese revolutionaries beside HCM. Also most info inside is in Vietnamese.Tip: there is a booth outside the mausoleum that appears to demand your bag/ camera. I had no problems holding on to my stuff.

Interesting insight into Vietnamese mindset. We had to line up to get in and no cameras, bags or water. It was interesting to watch the changing of the guards on the way in. A little strange to see a well preserved ho chi minh, looking like he was sleeping. It was also interesting to see the places where he used to live. He is highly revered and touring this area reminds you that you are in a communist country. Worth seeing if you have time, but not a tragedy if you miss it.

Unpleasant experience. The barking guards were a bit too much for me after the warmth of the city's people. Was also not keen on leaving my iPad at the door. A grim reminder of what an authoritarian state feels like.

a unique experience. Ho Chi Minh is still a very revered figure in Vietnam and the experience of filing past his preserved body is quite surreal. The guards told off visitors who were talking and it is obviously a very sombre occasion, which you need to respect. Most of the visitors were vietnamese people which illustrates how important it is to visit to understand vietnamese culture.

Quick and interesting. The visiting hours are very restricted. At the moment only 8am to 10:30am (closed Monday and Friday), but the times change at different times of the year so check before you go to avoid disappointment. I've seen Mao in Beijing and Kim Il Song in Pyongyang, so it was good to check another embalmed Communist dictator off my list. The queue moves quickly and the whole visit takes about 20 minutes only, with less than a minute of actual viewing time. Remember this is set up for people to pay their respects, not to entertain tourists, so don't expect them to go out of their way for you. But the whole process is very simple and efficient.
Nothing much to see. Just for taking pictures, nothing much... Good thing is, it is just a few minutes walk from the pagoda and museum

Strict.. Everyone there is uniform and there are strict rules everywhere. Almost as if they are "tolerating" visitors instead of "welcoming" them. Nice crash course in military regime perhaps? When you visit be observant and don't break any rules. Was glad we went, and was even more glad when we left.
Watch out. Some guide books provide inaccurate info about visitng hours. We missed our opportunity to see HCM's body.

30 seconds to see him but worth it. I revisited this place last month after visiting in 2009. Well worth the trip. Get there early to avoid disappointment. You pretty much just queue up for 15 mins, walk around his body then walk out but it is an experience that you should have if in Hanoi. Free entry too.
Closed much of the time.... Apparently, Ho Chi Minh himself spends three months of the year in Russia being refreshed, so we weren't able to go in at all. Still, it's a good photo from the outside...
