Austere!. Worth a look just to go through the austere process of seeing Vietnam's most reverred. However he does look a bit fake. Therefore worth doing if the queue is short but not if you have to wait more than 10 mins

This is an experience!. Roll out the Communist propaganda - this is an experience not to be missed! As a Westerner you probably won't come across this type of experience often, or safely. From Uncle Ho himself embalmed and entombed in imposing architecture to pristine 1950s vehicles and Communist documents on display, you'll really get a great feel for the Communist machine. Follow the directions of the guards at all times and expect to have to hand over large knapsacks and cameras if you go into ghe mausoleum itself.
A Must visit place. Well organized and feel somber. I wish they would allow more time to see other intersting items related to Ho Chi Ming and history of Vietnam

A bit freaky but very cool!. This is an interesting attraction. You get to see Ho Chi Minh himself, in his current state (which is impressive as he passed in '69)You only get to see him for a portion of the year as they spend alot of time (about 4 months of the year) to prolong his body in its current state.The tip for this one is they wont let you take your camera in with you. It's not an issue but it's a funny but strange situation to be in if you don't speak Vietnamese.There is a bit of walking around so it takes about an hour and should be coupled with his residence.

Sombre. The mausoleum is very stark and devoid of anything except his body (which is well preserved). Some flowers could make it a bit cheerful. The guards are a bit rough and push you into a two-row formation (probably justified to manage the crowds).

A visit you should make. Quite formal and you have to queue for a while, but given the importance of Ho Chi Minh to the history of Vietnam, this is one of the places you should visit whilst in Hanoi. You will be there with a lot of Vietnamese, including school children and due reverence is expected, but don't let this put you off.

The story of Vietnam. Unfortunatelly the day we went there the Mausoleum of closed. But outside the Mausoleum there are some soldiers white dressed. The day was cloudy and was impressive. You must go.

Worth a visit but only in the morning. It worth a visit to see the preserved body of Uncle Ho Chi Mihn and the surrounding gardens including his residence and all the antique cars. Very strict and tight security and strictly no cameras allowed.

I guess you have to go and see it. There were not too many people when we went, its something you have to see if you visit hanoi i suppose. The body of ho chi minh is embalmed and lying in state inside. Impressive soviet style architecture.
3rd time lucky. We finally managed to visit the mausoleum. Other times it was closed. Take note of the opening times and get there early to beat the crowd.

Ho Chi Minh..Still Very Much Alive. The Mausolem is a must see for all Vietnamese...That is, They MUST see it. For a tourist, it is obviously optional, but it is a really unusual, and therefore highly interesting attraction.First, you have to be serious about this. Ho Chi Minh was Vietnams' George Washington, Winston Churchill and Franklin Roosevelt all in one. This place is all about reverence with no pictures allowed. You cant even put your hands in your pocketsIts more than filing into a marble mausoleum and briefly viewing a dead guy. There is nothing like this in the world. What I found more interesting is the park outside, which showed how this simple man lived....basically in a few rooms with a basic office and a few pretty modest carsThat was his real legacy to the Vietnamese and to a larger extent the world

Interesting Place. We went on our final day with the kids (ages 5 and 3). They got a kick out of seeing all the soldiers and Ho Chi Minh's body. The grounds are nice and we also saw his house and cars. A nice place to visit for an hour or two. Not sure what it is like at other times of the year. We did not have to wait in lines, but I think that is not always the case.

Worth a visit. We joined the que at 7:45am and there were already thousands of people ahead of us so we thought we would be there for ages. However, the que moved very quickly and we were out by 8:45. It was interesting to see, I would definetly recommend it.

Moving experience. One of the few national figures to remain in a mausoleum Ho Chi Minh is held with absolute reverence in Vietnam, don't be put off by the queues because they move quickly, don't forget to buy the ticket before you join the queue some people make this mistake, no cameras allowed inside but the building is most impressive.
Opening times. Went there today, arrived about 11.30am to find that the mausoleum was open from 8.00 am to 11.30am. Not open Fridays or Mondays and not open in the afternoons. Will go back tomorrow.
Interesting, sometimes very busy. The mausoleum is sometimes very busy, especially during the weekend when lots of Vietnamese visitors from outside Hanoi come to watch and honour Ho Chi Minh.

Enjoyed watching the guards police the yellow line. I had no interest in queuing to see a body no matter whose it is. However, i did see the changing of the guard and them repeatedly whistling, telling people to stay behind the yellow line. Why the yellow line and not just the pavement I have no idea, funny.

Mausoleum. I really had trouble understanding why this is here. I understand the importance of teh person to the country but all he asked for was to be cremated and here he lies. Our guide could not understand how anyone could come to Hanoi and not pay respects to Ho Chi Minh

OK if you have the time. The Great Leader Embalmed in a glass sarcophagus while reverential crowds file by is one of the iconic images of the 20th Century Communist Experience: Lenin (Stalin), Mao. If you haven't been to Moscow or Beijing, then a visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is an interesting experience of that sort. Impeccable guards, choreographed changing of the guards. By aware of the likelihood of very long lines, and VERY strictly enforced rules by silent glowering guards.The Ho Chi Minh residences are also on the grounds, and a bit more interesting to get a feel of the lifestyle of one of the Significant Men of the 20th Century.

Unusual but worth a look. The queue was long, but don't be put off by that, it flowed pretty well. The mausoleum is quite impressive, not having anything of this nature in Australia, I was fascinated. It's a little weird seeing uncle Ho lying there. The Vietnamese people must still revere him as the ladies in front of us in the queue shushed us (and we were only speaking in low voices). The guards are a little grumpy, telling my husband to take his sunglasses off and yes, lots of finger pointing if anyone steeped out of line when winding up to the mausoleum. But it's all part of the experience and a must do when in Hanoi.
Closed on a Monday. We got to see the changing of the guard and the whistle man telling people to stay behind the yellow line. Pity we missed going inside

Better inside than out. The Mausoleum itself is an interesting piece of architecture in its own right and stands adjacent to an imposingly large and obviously Soviet style Ho Chi Minh museum next door. The actual Mausoleum opening hours are only on specific days and close at 11AM, so make sure to ask your hotel. Most taxi drivers, hotel staff and tour operators all seemed to be well familiar with the days and times. Inside, you walk around his embalmed body which is in a glass display case up at eye level. You aren't allowed to stop or to take photos, but it was enough time to visually take in the site. His body looks as though he died only yesterday. It was eerily interesting and thought provoking. Outside, in front of the Mausoleum is a large park space but is also an excellent place to take photographs. There is a strict no-cross yellow line in front but it's close enough that you can still take a good shot. None of the guards we spoke to would allow us to take their photos or have our photos taken with them. I'm not sure if that was personal preference or policy, but it would have been fun had they allowed it. Still, it's worth making the trip even if only just to catch a photo of the exterior.

It's worth it. You get to see whatever you want to see.. You get to see whatever you want to see.If you are interested in watching a corpse, chances are that the long queue will discourage your morbid instincts. If you want to see one of the characters that modified the history of the XX century and attest how his people pays him respect almost 50 years later, this is your kind of place. I would really recommend it. Somehow, it's like being in the history book for a while.

A line like I have never seen. Tried to get here on a Saturday morning. Finally found an entrance but the line was like something I have never seen before. Didn't have hours to queue so walked around the gardens, took some pics and moved on. Guards out the front are very serious - lots of whistles and pointing which kept us amused for a while.

Not something you experience too often in your lifetime. You are ushered into the Mausoleum following patiently in line, The guards are impeccably dressed. You feel an understanding of the high regard felt for Ho Chi Minh by the citizens of Vietnam. Not to be missed if you are in Hanoi.

Somber and eery, but moving. Well worth a visit if nothing else to experience how a single minded ideology (which I would argue does not exist any more in the west) is respected and continues to be held in high regard. Ho Chi Minh sounds like an amazing wise gentleman, a real father of the nation. It is quite a learning experience to see this huge complex dedicated to him and surprisingly free for all.

Somewhat Rushed. We did not have to wait or queue up at all to see Ho Chi Minh, we just walked straight on to the end of a line of people visiting the mausoleum, most of whom were Western visitors. Ho himself is the same colour as the marble pillow he lies on but there is no opportunity to stop and look as everyone is shuffled in and out as quickly as possible.

anomaly. i experienced very mixed feelngs; thinking about Ho Chi Minh's lifestyle and beliefs and tryng to reconcile these with what I was seeing....it seemed far more an elaborate mix of influences for the tourist and less of an accurate interpretation or representation of Ho Chi Minh....i left a bit disturbed
Simply unique. The queue was long but visitor movements were managed efficiently. Facilities were good and clean too.

A Respectable Place. I think anyone visiting Hanoi should make a point to come to this respectable place, regardless if you decide to see the embalmed body of Mr Ho. We did not as we've read that it was against his wishes. The surrounding are nice and it's a short walk to one pillar pagoda.We were fortunate to witness the guard changing.

Visit Uncle Ho. The Mausoleum of President Ho Chi Minh is a must place to visit in Hanoi. The late uncle Ho is buried in this mausoleum and the whole area is broken down into a few parts in which you will need almost 1 - 2 hours to complete. Uncle Ho is inside and he is always deep in Vietnamese heart.
Sombre walk. This quick walk round the mausoleum summarises for the visitor the respect and regard that the Vietnamese people have for their leader

not something you see every day. i think it's something that all visitors to hanoi should see. seeing the great lengths the vietnamese have undertaken to preserve their leader is amazing. where i wish it had been better is providing more history/information. be prepared to pass of your camera to a checkpoint to retrieve it after visiting the body. you are allowed to take it to all other areas, including his residence.

All Vietnamese want to see Uncle Ho!. After a walk through the Citadel along Government buildings and guards (No photo!) we arrived at the Mausoleum. Impressive setting from outside. The queue was just too long for us so we decided not to see Uncle Ho...

Inadequate information and writeups. After security check, we were hurried through the mausoleum, as it was nearing 11am, the lunch break. We did not know that to complete the 'museum circuit' entails buying ticket to the HCH house. By doing so, we would retrieve our checked in belongings at the back of security. since we did not do so, we had to loop around the compound along the main road to retrieve our bags at security, just seconds before the guards close on us.Give it a miss if you cannot make it at least 2 hours before it closes. The rush and time wasted was simply not worth it.

A New Perspective. Learning how important Ho Chi Minh is to the Vietnamese people was worthwhile. The care with which his body has been preserved and the reverence for him shown by the Vietnamese was amazing.

Don't let the name put you off--this is an interesting place to see.. The Mausoleum, and museum are fascinating. The museum presents a perspective on Ho Chi Minh that is so foreign to those that many westerners have, yet it is not an excuse for propaganda, but it a well displayed and thoughtful exhibit.
Well maintained facility. I went there on June, and its a good place. In fromt of the Mauseleum have a park, and i think its a good place to have jogging there or just take a walk around this place

Must see!. From the hustle and bustle of Hanoi, you feel almost transported to a different place here. The security is tight, you have to keep your things in a locker before you make your "procession" to the mausoleum. The mood is sombre, the closer you get to the mausoleum, the guards make you walk two by two, remove your hats and you can feel how important this man means to the nation. He looked very peaceful, the room was very cold and silent. There were guards posted on the 4 corners of the body as well as along the path for the visitors. You can't spend much time looking at him as the guards usher you to continue walking. But overall, nothing I have ever seen or experienced before, so it is a must visit for me.

Unforgettable. The sheer size of the building and the guarded ceremony surrounding the Mausoleum creates an aura of awe. Seeing the much revered Uncle Ho is an interesting insight into the culture of communism.

I enjoyed visiting. Uncle Ho was and remains a national hero. A remarkable person who is widely venerated.The changing of the guard is an interesting side show and the place is just around the corner from the one pillar pagoda and the museumNote the opening times for the museum and there are a lot of people wanting to sell you things around here I was lucky the last time I was here to see a tour group of VN army vets. Great guys...

definatly worth a visit. a very sombre experience walking silent and single file past their beloved past president. he looked very well preserved considering he passed away in 1969. well worth the line up in the rain, and the guards telling you to keep in a single file line and not to stray from that pattern.
great building. I was surprised at the size inside of this building , wonderfull outside buildings and gardens, as long as you like walking this is a must, dont miss

Don't waste your time. I know all Vietnamese revere Uncle Ho but, this is not an appealing site to visit. The Vietnamese should be celebrating his life. Instead, the entire atmosphere is solemn and the guards are downright rude.

A must!. Very interesting place to visit, a revered man truly. Dont try and walk across the grass they wont let you even though the signs say dont walk on the grass it also means dont walk on the path between the grass

Boring and not worth the time. Queue is long but moves quite fast. The mausoleum is well maintained and clean but the significance of seeing a dead body of a vietnamese president is not that high so in my opinion, there is no need to spend time queuing to get in. Taking pictures outside the mausoleum should suffice.

Ho Chi Minh in Glass. One of the few places in the world you have the opportunity to see a preserved dignitary. Take the time to visit and be sure and on't linger too long. I slowed down for a better view and was whacked by a guard.

The symbol of Hanoi. Besides Temple of Literature, Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum can be seen as an iconic landmark of Hanoi. The grand Ba Dinh square marks the independence of the country after colonization. It is also good for a walk after a busy day in the chaotic Old Quarter.

Scary guards but exhilarating experience. Very stringent getting in process because you get checked and you leave your cameras with the guards and that's expected because Ho Chi Minh is a revered icon in Vietnam. Not much to do except look at Ho Chi Minh's preserved body; good for an experience but can be skipped.

beware of opening times. Only open for certain periods through the day. Check this before planning a trip.
Big crowds there too.

Makes you wonder.... After seeing 'him', you get to see the residence where he spent his final years. Somehow I find it hard to imagine that a man who led such a simple life in the end, would want to be stuck in an air-conditioned vault that's guarded 24/7. Please let this hero rest in peace. Oh... And don't go on weekends, school holidays or local holidays unless you fancy a bit of shoving and pushing.

Glad we did this. We weren't sure we wanted to take the time to wait in line to view Ho Chi Minh's body, but we're very glad we did, just for the experience. It's quite sobering to see the reverence the Vietnamese people have for their departed leader.

Very imposing building. I've always had a thing for really large and interesting buildings and since this one was close to were we were staying, we decided to pay it a visit. Good thing I made my research first as they have a lot of rules for visitors, including a garment interdiction i.e you're not allowed to wear tank tops or miniskirts. You're not allowed to take photos either, so thumbs down for that. Its their right, I won't comment on that, but it would've been nice to be able to take some photos to capture the architectural marvel of this attraction. There's no fee required as well, and the outskirts of this temple are also beautiful. Do visit if you're truly interested in Vietnam's history and culture!

Better from outside. Except if you are particularly interested on corpses or Ho Chi Minh himself, avoid the queues and bureaucracy: take your photos from outside and move on. The one pillar pagoda is next door and much more interesting, for instance. And the lakes are just 7 minutes walking away.
why bother. huge lines to see an national hero but for westerners, very little to justify the visit. The building is lavish but uninspired
Weird. Thank goodness Americans do not feel the need to display the dead bodies of their dead leaders. Building a monument of some sort or another is preferable to being herded by a dead body.

Very surreal. While qeueing (for some time if you dont get there early enough) you get the drill on how to behave - no talking, laughing etc. But nothing really prepares you as you enter the cool, dimly lit chamber holding the embalmed body. Is it all real? Yep, very surreal.
interesting site. Something seldom seen other places. vast property with few houses of Ho Chi Min, with his belongings and his mausoleum, thousands of people visiting. Nice for people watching

Ho Chi Minh was there. This was my third visit to Hanoi and my first opportunity to see Ho Chi Minh's body within the Mausoleum. Viewing the body isn't possible every day, or year round - so if you can manage to be there when it's open, go in and see. You will be struck by his beauty and serenity.

Worth the long queues.... Fascinating to see the immense respect still paid to the humble and modest "Uncle Ho" who still lies in state in his mausoleum guarded by local armed forces who insist on silence and no photography. The adjacent museum and gardens are well worth a visit - make sure you have an excellent local guide - lots to see and learn about this impressive Uncle.

Much repect shown for this great man.. Ho Chi Minh is one of recent history's great men and well worth visiting. Our visit went very smoothly, once we figured out the correct route to entry. The site could do with more signage father afield as we had to walk such a long way to get to the entrance. The visitation to Uncle Ho's embalmed body was quite fast and orderly. Obey all soldiers! Free before 11am.
Eye opening. This experience was slightly overwhelming, but very educational. It was interesting to learn about this man's life and the grounds are gorgeous.

HE'S STILL DEAD. Second time there but with family this time. Interesting mostly because of the pomp and seriousness of the workers. Not a top attraction (including Ho's residence) but one most people take in.

Interesting but lacks a clear story. Glad I went to visit but the museum is not laid out to give the best story of the history. A lot of random exhibits which were not clearly linked to the overall message or story

Propaganda is alive and well!. I found this museum rather disappointing, though it's a virtually compulsory visit for Vietnamese schoolchildren. Most of the artifacts are in French which would make it difficult for anyone who does not have at least a smattering of the language. I suspect Uncle Ho would be less than impressed with the interpretation of some of his life. As the guidebooks say, don't expect to come away having learnt much more about the man

Impressive Mausoleum. We went to the museum and strolled by the mausoleum. It's worth a look as it's very impressive - I have never seen such a big mausoleum. If you are not interested in the museum you can get good photos of the mausoleum from the road.

Very Large and Impressive Mausoleum. The site is quite dramatic - rather cold and bland except for the size and scope. The best thing is to be there for the lowering of the flag ceremony in the evening.

OK. The Mausoleum has odd opening hours and many people arrive and don't get in. Early in the day is best. Once you find your way to the correct entrance you have to deposit bags and then queue up. You go into the mausoleum and walk around the guarded body and out again. The building itself is rather unimpressive and seing the embalmed body won't be everyone's cup of tea.
Impressive monument. Had great time taking photos with the water spray bursting from the grounds one evening.....it was a cool scenery...

Worth a look if you have time on your hands. Couldn't go inside on the day we visited but looked around outside. Very imposing in size and proportion from the outside, set on a long wide boulevard. Spent a bit of time amusing ourselves at the guards screeching at tourists who inadvertently made a minor infraction of the rules - crossing a yellow line etc.One Pillar Pagoda is around the corner, as is Phan Dinh Phung Street that has many beautiful old french buildings on it and some great photo opportunities. In fact I'd give the mausoleum a miss and focus on the walk around this area, it's lovely.

STRICT!. This was high on my list to see and experience. No phones, cameras or bags allowed in the line but the people in front and behind us all had their phones out taking photos when signs say not to. The gurads stared and ignored that they were on their phones. However these people looked like locals. I personally got told to take my hands out of my pockets so go figure. The surrounding areas of residence are beautiful.

Can not miss this ....long lines but worth the wait.. Ho Chi Minh is reveered and this is a very quiet and strict experience, I have visited twice and the guards keep you moving the entire LONG LONG line, no photos and no english speakers ...just keep moving..ha.
closed on day we went. unfortunately this is closed on a couple of days of the week but cant remember which so check before you go. Still quite impressive from the outside though and worth seeing.

Long Queue and overbearing security. The scurity protocols seem overbearing, we followed a group of school children who were clearly petrified of the austere soldiers leading into the mausoleum and stared silently at the body of Ho Chi Minh who looks very wax like. Its a long queue process but the grounds are pleasant and if in a group you are able to chat before entering the main mausoleum and watching other groups particularly children is fantastic

Speak about communism!. It was like we were in a bootcamp or something. We had to line up and walk in pairs just to enter.. You cannot take photos in the middle of the square. Uncle Ho is definitely a respectable man to the extent of that.

A long queue but an expeience. We had to wait in line for a while to get in but for me that was all part of the experience. Seeing the video of Children singing about Ho Chi Minh while we were waiting, the guards matching outside and those guarding the body gave one more of a sense of political Vietnam. Get there early when its cooler and maybe less tourists.
Must see when in Hanoi. How can you visit Hanoi and not go here? Everything you expect from this place. Definitely recommended
Didn't see it.. Stood in the baking sun for 30 mins and the queue moved two feet. Was going to take another two hours to get into the mausoleum so we gave up. Obviously a very popular attraction.

Very grand!. We spent half of the day in the complex, museum, mausoleum, etc. It seem important to visit to better understand how much Ho Chi Minh means for the Vietnamese people. Worth a visit for sure!
Only saw it from the outside. We didn't fancy the long queues and need to comply with strict rules so just looked from the outside. Interesting to see the place but a short visit is sufficient!
Must see if your are a communist. Nice place with whistling policeman. Easy to get but very hot to walk. Do not come close to the gate :)
Unmissable. Just one of those things that you should do while you are in Hanoi. He was an amazing figure of the 20th century

You need to see this to believe. It is a highly "managed" experience as you file thru the property and see the wide screen TV's showing people singing songs of praise, soldiers every few yards, no talking allowed, hands to hang at sides, not crossed in front or back...don't worry, the guards will quickly correct any posture or behavior issues. It is amazing when you see the body of someone who has been dead so long. Truly worth the experience

A long queue, but you have to do it!. We went the first day of re-opening after the annual restorations. So not sure if the queue was longer than usual. It took about 40 minutes or so to see Uncle Ho. It was a hot day and I forgot to wear clothes that cover my shoulders, but the souvenir shop sells inexpensive light shawls, so all good! You do have to hand over bags and collect them later. We were allowed to keep our camera, but no photos inside the Mausoleum (okay for his residences though). Seeing the embalmed body was an unusual experience. Given the higher proportion of visitors seemed to be Vietnamese, it's clear he is still revered.

Not sure he would have approved!. While filing past an embalmed body is not really my thing it would be hard to deny that it does pack an emotional punch. We were behind a group of old Vietnamese soldiers, a number of whom had to be helped up and down the numerous steps by the attendants (this is not a disabled friendly building!) but they clearly wanted to pay their respects to Uncle Ho. I think HCM would have hated the heavy, ostentatious building in which his body is housed. But as roughly 2/3 - 3/4 of the line was Vietnamese it is hard not to argue that he is still a huge, iconic figure in Vietnam.

OPEN!!. We visited today- 18 nov, and it is open. Not closed as stated elsewhere. No queues, straight thru once handed over camera. Closes at 1130-2pm, so does museum and house so try to time it all before the siesta. Look out rip off taxis outside- cost 70,000 dong ( £2 ish) to get there from old quarter, but on return the meter 'malfunctioned' and went crazy- driver demanded 440,000! Stood our ground and paid 70,000. Also men with bicycle rickshaws- offered to drive us round for 200,000 to see the prison, b52 bomber and temple. When we returned he demanded 200,000 per stop. We paid and learnt our lesson. Make sure you know exactly what you are agreeing to first! Overall mausoleum worth a visit but be careful in tourist areas!
Always closed??. We went twice and twice were told it was closed for various reasons...under renovation, state event...not too sure if it is ever open.

Brief but beautiful.. The queue (which snakes for a few streets) looks off putting but it moves quite quickly. You're only in the mausoleum for less than a minute before you're waved ahead but the glass case and the embalming of the body make it a beautiful, if brief, experience.
That s Vietnam history. It reminds Chinese Mao Mausoleum. Not to be missed. Comunist style. It s a piece of history. Big square in front, silence and respect.

An interesting experience. As a Vietnam War veteran the visit to Ho Chi Minhs mausoleum and nearby museum was and interesting experience. He was a demi-god in the eyes of the North Vietmanese. Lots of references to the "American War". Excellent guard marching display. Recommend a visit to all.
Huge resting place. Guarded 24 hours a day 7 days a week. Ho Chi Min was away on his yearly ''holiday to Russia whilst we were there'. Mixed comments from visitors about this once leader.

Confused..... We went on an unguided tour and had quite a hard time finding the main entrance. The guards were pretty unhelpful in pointing us to the right way. Finally found the entrance and had to go through stricter-than-immigration-custom checks. Had my bottled water and M&Ms (?!) confiscated. Direction signages were in Vietnam and French language, can't read. Paid Vnd25,000 for the entrance fees to the museum - not worth, very noisy (the guides were speaking through their microphones in that little museum), can skip. And then finally found the queue to the Mausoleum, which was way before the entrance to the Mausoleum. You will have to queue and walk in groups to Mausoleum, and it seems if you detach from the group, you will be gunned down (lol! very rigid!). Nothing much interesting, but since you are in Hanoi, paying respect to Uncle Ho seems like the right thing to do.
Mausoleum. The native Vietnamese still revere this man and his legacy of the people. Try to look at things from their perspective and you may gain some insight

Ho Chi Minh lying in state. While the line to get into the mauseoleum may be long it moves fairly quickly. On approach to the mausoleum the guards ensure that you have taken off sunglasses and hats prior to entering and there is to be no talking. They also ensure that the line keeps moving past the body of Ho Chi Minh, which lies in a glass-like coffin. Worth a visit.

Surprisingly serene. Nestled in the heart of a very leaf area in the city, great for just strolling. The Mausoleum was closed during our visit but it was an interesting enough experience. dont miss the one pillar pagoda right next door.

impressed. excellent storyline, u can find many historic tools and tales in there..the decoration is excellent.is normally open daily from 09:00 to 12:00 to the public..no shorts and miniskirts allowed

Reverently Spooky. This was one of the most original and different 'tourist attractions' I've ever visited. You walk through in quite an orderly queue ushered on by armed guards, who really don't like it if you stop to peer for a closer look. Having said that they aren't at all intimidating, just serious and keeping order. Uncle Ho's body is remarkably well preserved - apparently it gets regular maintenance by being sent to Russia. I felt quite sad that the man himself wanted no such worship or veneration and had requested to be buried after death - I suppose he's the victim of his own success by beating the French and then the Americans. Remember it's only open in the mornings and check the day too. It's also worth driving past at night as the building is transformed by lighting into quite an imposing presence, and there are always Vietnamese exercising and doing other things at the front of it, which makes good people watching.

Grand memories. Tis is a typical mausoleum to a father if a nation. It is brutal architecture allegedly resembling a lotus flower (!) set in a massive square for the populous to stand in and revere him. The doors are guarded by magnificently uniformed soldiers including one who is there to keep you on the right side of the yellow line. Ho Chi Minh was not available to be viewed as he was being 'maintained' in a similar way to Lenin .

He was away... Ho was just starting his vacation for three months in France -- or was taken away for dusting, so you could only see outside when we were there. Grandness and wide open spaces reminds me of Tienamen Square in Beijing. Good to drive near. Unless you need exercise, I wouldn't bother walking around.

Wasn't open for public. What a shame, the corpse of Ho Chi Min was out of the country for 'treatment' in Russia. We had to watch the mausoleum from the outside on a foggy day.... Not the ideal circumstances. But then again no visit to Hanoi is complete without a visit to the mausoleum

Amazing. The fact that Ho Chi Minh was such a private and reclusive man in his later years to see his mausoleum to be so public. It was interesting to see the military defense force in there special uniforms and there dedication reminded me of the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

Great Man of the People. It was a Monday in Oct when I visited HCM Mausoleum. HCM's body was sent to Russia during Oct and Nov every year for "upkeeping" purposes. Walking around HCM complex and hearing from the guide, our respect goes to HCM for his selfless character. Kudos to him

A must see.. Like him or not this has got to be on your to do list whilst in Hanoi. The mausoleum is impressive and gives you some idea at to the high reverence the Vietnamese people have for their former leader.
Interesting. The whole history of Ho Chi Minh is very interesting and the spartan lifestyle he led. A highly revered man the mausoleum is probably a fitting tribute to him.

A must see. Very strange to have enjoyed it but enjoy it we did, was great to feel the atmosphere and reverence of how special he was to the people of Vietnam, felt honoured to share a small peice of fascinating history

cleanest part of Hanoi. After a long walk you leave most of the hustle and bustle and enter a shrine of well preserved gardens, Extremely well looked after Mausoleum, guards hovering so you don't get to close or the whistle will blow and send you on you way. Was disappointed we couldn't go in though. A group of us must of walked around this place for ages.

Closed at the time we were there. It was unfortunate for us the Mausoleum was closed when we were there. We therefore missed the ambience of the mausoleum and just viewed the outside which is not all that exciting.

An Atrocity. In his last will and testament Ho Chi Minh asked that when he died he be cremated. His ashes should be scattered on a peaceful hillside out in the Vietnamese countryside. A small rest-house could be constructed for those who wished to visit the site. Visitors would be encouraged to plant a tree in his memory.The Vietnamese government surpressed Ho's wishes for many years and built this granite monstrosity to house and display his embalmed corpse.A far better memorial to Ho is the small wooden house he had built for him on the grounds of the Presidential Palace. He'd use the palace for ceremonial purposes and large meetings, but he actually lived in this beautiful and humble little house.

Serious and solemn. There are many regulations are quite strict: strictly confidential and costumes... We lined up patiently waiting to see the great man of the people of Vietnam as well as the world. Feelings are hard to describe. But I respect his mind. Atmosphere in the mausoleum is very serious and solemn. Then we are visiting in a large garden with a few mementos of Uncle Ho. A beautiful garden and nearby there is an unique temple. Temple named one pillar pagoda. Trip has brought many new feelings for me. Greatest value may be witnessing a great people of Vietnam and the world.
Good to see but not must to see. Queuing up to enter the mausoleum and to see Ho Chi Minh, is okay when you see plenty of time. Otherwise we can do or see other things

Peaceful Area. Unfortunately it was closed when we went there (October) but it was still one of my favourite places in Hanoi. We went there late afternoon and loads of families were just chilling out in the traffic free area in front of the Mausoleum and doing their daily exercises. Wish it had been open but still well worth a visit to sit and chill. We were lucky enough to see the changing of the guard too which was cool :)
See it if you can. Hard place to get into, well worth the look if it is open. If you get the chance go and visit the mausoleum and the museum interesting to see their outlook.

Pay a visit to this place please. `it looks solemn and quite but it welcome a great number of people go there everyday. A piece of advise is try to be as early as you can so you can be one of the first to visit

A Nationalist at Heart. Wonderful to learn about Ho Chi Minh a simple man with an ideal. We did not enter the Mausoleum as it was closed for maintenance but it is an impressive building. Ho Chi Minh house is worth a visit to see the simplicity of his life and enjoy the stroll around the lake
Nice!. The gardens and buildings are very beautiful. We didn't have the chance to go inside because the mausoleum is closed on that Friday.

Uncle Ho is getting a makeover in Moscow. Awesome outside the mausoleum, but no Uncle Ho as he apparently needs a charge up of some sort for two months every year and that included our visit. So nice pix of the team outside, but felt a bit let down that he should be revered was missing in action.

A Unique Experience. To observe the respect bestowed union this man and to see the massive mausoleum is an experience not to be missed. Security is tight with restrictions on cameras and phones, but it is worth the small inconvenience for the experience. We saw the mausoleum as part of a day tour with Sinhcafe, (the original one - there are frauds around!). We did not have to wait long and the queue moved quickly. It was worth the short wait. We would highly recommend Sinhcafe tours for price and quality of tours. We booked when we reached Hue at their tour office.

watch out for Oct and Nov each year. Unfortunately during our visit 'Uncle Ho' was in Russia having his annual makeover. Worth noting that this occurs every october/november and hence the Mausoleum is closed during those times. However we have been to Hanoi at other times and certainly a visit to the Mausoleum is most worth while, if only to observe the deep reverence still paid by the people (both young and old) to this extraordinary man

Was closed, but still worth going to!. We came in October, so we couldn't go into the mausoleum, since Ho Chi Minh was away. However, it is definitely worth coming to see this impressive building, the guards, and to visit the Ho Chi Minh museum nearby.

Is it or isn't it?. Is it really him? In low light and with all cameras and mobile phones banned it's hard to say. The day I went I queued for an hour in a line that snaked around half of Ha Noi and I jostled jovially with Vietnamese as I left my phone with the cloak room (don't even think of taking anything electronic in there). The whole day was a cultural experience in itself. Look out for the angry guards in white if you a linger a little too long in front of Bac Ho (Uncle Ho).

Morbidly awesome. We really enjoyed our visit here, but due to time constraints, we didn't get to the museum. We lined up for at least an hour to get into the mausoleum, but it was well worth it. We also enjoyed the beautifully landscaped grounds and the residences. Very interesting and well worth the visit. We will come back here on our next trip to Vietnam. Be sure you adhere to the opening times as we saw many people turned away if they arrived too close to closing time. Also, you need to ensure shoulders are covered and clothing is not too revealing.
Leafy park behind. The mausoleum was closed for a few months. But you can go into the park behind where they have HCM's house and the lake beside it. One of those things you do when in Hanoi.

ho chi minh mausoleum. The atmosphere and location of the hotel is quite okay which I think I could see a lot of local cultures there. It's a walking distance to Dong Xuan Market.ho chi minh mausoleum, I can say the hotel owner (the family) is nice to me.

nice. Nice and quiet area of Hanoi, make sure you are there before 12 or after 2pm as they close for lunch time. The Mausoleum is closed 2 months a year so if you want to get in to see Ho Chi Minh Tumb, check it first

A bizarre place to visit. A very unusual place to see, that's for sure, but I would highly recommend no one come to Hanoi and miss it, It's absolutely something worth visiting, the landscaping and buildings themselves are very nice, but the experience of walking in on the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh is a very interesting thing to experience. There were also some guard drills going on outside with a lot of people taking photos, and plenty of touring schoolchildren and so on who were eager to practice their English. The only downside is that towards the end there is a row of souvenir type stalls where you are likely to get heckled (much like the rest of South East Asia) which is fine if you are looking for touristy souvenirs but does become tiring.

Pretty Cool!. I wasn't too sure about this before going, but it was pretty interesting. Ho Chi Minh is still embalmed and on display for anyone who would like to visit. Make sure you dress conservatively and act appropriately as he and the mausoleum are very important to the Vietnamese. You should have this on your to-do list in Hanoi.
Boring. Im sure the great man himself did wonders for what is a diverse and interesting nation but this place is plain dull.
Interesting building but closed in September&October!. We only saw the outside as the building is closed every year in September & October for refurbishment

A little weird. Packed with visitors and tourists, the place was very popular so gets very busy. Saying that, even though the queues are long they move quickly. There are lots of guards ensuring you behave respectfully, especially when you approach the tomb itself. It was a little weird seeing Ho Chi Minh laying there in a guarded glass case but felt it was important. Definitely worth a visit - interesting but bizarre.

Closed unfortunately. While the Mausoleum was closed, the surrounding grounds and other attractions are well worth a visit. The mausoleum is a great example of Stalinist architecture and contrasts nicely to the ex-colonal governor's residence and Ho's house on stilts. We were lucky to be there for the signing of an agreeemnt between the Vietnamese and Cambodian military, so lots of photos of the kids marching with the officers!

What an insight into the Vietnamese people.. We were lucky enough to be visiting Hanoi on Ho Chi Minh’s birthday and the Mausoleum was on the list of stops organised by Indochina Pioneer, I recommend having this stop on the itinerary of an organised tour, the lines were huge and the rules are fairly strict, it was good to be able to join the queue towards the front with the other tour guides and to have someone to leave our valuables with.There is no better way to gain an understanding of the respect and appreciation that the Vietnamese people have for this leader then to file silently past the entombed body of Ho Chi Minh, please do not miss this experienceThe surrounding grounds are a real oasis in a bustling city.
History monument. Got to respect Ho Chi Minh and what he has done for the country. Wasn't able to pay my respect as the mausoleum is under maintenance for the period of Sept and Oct.

Long Walk Tried but Failed. Its quite a big complex with a lot to see but you have to be there at the right time to see the body of HoChiMin, the actual museum is a must but very drawn out and quite intense. Believe this must be judged by each person.

They Close this for servicing in Sept/Oct. If the mausoleum is open, then you will have to leave your backpacks etc on the bus, if it is closed, then you are able to wander around with it. The mauseoleum was closed when we were there so we did not see inside, but the gardens etc were lovely

Impressive building and grounds.. Large park with many other sites to see (Presidential Palace, Botanical Gardens, One Pillar Pagoda, Hoh Chi Minh museum). It is a nice place to take a walk around in on a sunny day.
Cultural museum. This is a good place to start in learning the modern history of Vietnam. You will also get to see Mr. Ho Chi Minh lying in wake in a open coffin.
Not sure how to give a title. It was ok but they are very strict about going in the Mausoleum. I had to leave my purse with guards and it was crowded, dark and slow moving. All in all it was ok.

You have to say you did it. A real cultural experience to stand in "line" with throngs of Vietnamese to pay homage to Bac Ho. The line is hot and long, but it's quite amazing (1) the incredible state of preservation of the body and (2) the genuine reverence of the Vietnamese visitors. Plus, I got a sweet commemorative fan for 5000 dong.
Well worth it. This is obviously an icon for Vietnamese people and I can understand why. Full of history, Ho Chi Min's house an eye opener, delightful gardens, a pleasure to visit

tribute to a great man. the mausoleum is just like the normal architecture.but the truth behind it is that of a visionary person with a simple living standard.
uncle Ho chi minh was a leader par excellence,but lived a spartan and simple life.the grandness of this monument is far less tribute to him.

HCM Mausoleum. would have liked to have entered but the great man is "away" in September so the mausoleum is closed. The grounds & surrounding buildings are well worth a visit & the guides have so much information to give

Must do..... Give your respect. Don't worry about the long waiting lines. they go very quick and organised. You have to leave you belongings with the administraters (so its easier not to take to much). Inside take only a short time, but is a must see. Continue afterwards with the gardens and house of Ho Chi Minh

Viewing Ho Chi Minh's corpse. The grounds around the buildings are beautiful. We had to stand in a long line of locals to go through the mausolium part...not a big deal tho....A lot of very serious looking soldiers around. You are not aloud to bring you camera inside when you view the body, but it is secure in the bag check booth. An interesting place! Also within walking distance to the Old Quarter.

The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was very helpful inmy visit to the Mausoleum except it was closed to the publicin Sept as I was told they closed once a year, but there wereother things we could see, like Ho Chi Minh's house and how helived, and the cars he rode.

A Must See in Hanoi!!. As a history buff, I am always interested in seeing memorials. This one is great. I have also seen the Mausoleum of Mao in Beijing, who actually died after Ho. The Vietnamese did a much nicer job of preserving their leader. As a former US soldier in the South....it was very sobering.

Stay on the outside - much more fun!. You have to visit it. I mean, he's the father of the country. So you have to take the shots of this huge and imposing mausoleum so you can tick all the tourist boxes. But they don't make it easy to get inside. From what we could ascertain, they're open for 20 minutes or so, early in the morning, on the second Thursday of the month... hence, the queues to get in are gargantuan, and largely composed of Vietnamese schoolkids on compulsory day trips. Our friends toughed it out, spent hours in line, trundling step by step ever closer to the great man's final bunker. Their verdict? "Six hours of our life we'll never get back". Much more fun on the outside where you can watch the whistle-wielding guards throwing hysterical hissy fits at any tourists who dare to step foot across the arbitrary white lines painted on the giant car park in front of the place. Turn up, take the shot and then head right for the swan pedallos on the lakes around the corner OR head left for Hun Tiep Lake and the downed B52 bomber... even more random fun!
Half day on Sundays.. I only saw the building outside, so imposing but regret not to see its contents. It's a few hundred meters walk from the One-Pillar Pagoda and the HCM Museum.
Ho Chi Minh. Fantastic Mausoleum, A lttle macabre, Guards a bit officious. The Russians have spent a lot of money providing a fine building and looking after the body

Nice large space but could not go in.. Could not go in as the old boy was having work done. Just took a photo outside and watched the troops practicing in the grounds for some parade they must be preparing for in the coming weeks.

Is it real?. This is a surreal experience, but given that if you spend any time in Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh will be at the forefront of your experience of the country. queues can get quite long, but once you are in you must ensure your hands are by your sides and not behind your back, as I found out when a guard poked me quite hard for the position of my hands. The body is in amazing condition and it is a strange experience. Just be aware that the ship the body off to Russia every 2 years for a "touch up"... The area around the mausoleum is well kept and presented and it is also worth seeing Ho Chi Minhs house, a display of some of his cars and other buildings which he used. I was torn between seeing him as a tyrant and a hugely respected leader of the Vietnamese people. Come to Vietnam, do some reading immerse yourself in the culture of this great country and you decide for yourself!!!

Long Ques. You would have to que up very early in the morning (8am) to be allowed into the mausoleum. They are very organized, where they provide lockers for you to keep your bags and cameras, etc. And on your way out, you can collect them again. It's a nice experience to be queing with hundereds of people so early in the morning to get into the mausoleum.

Gives you a glimpse of the high regard that Vietnamese have for Uncle Ho!. Just to have a sense of perspective as to the reverence and respect the Vietnamese have for who they affectionately call Uncle Ho, this place is probably one of THE sites in Hanoi to visit. The queue may be long but it moves really fast. In fact, it feels that there is no queue at all. Out of respect, you have to walk in single file when you are about to enter, be silent, and of course no photography is allowed anywhere near or inside the mausoleum. Be sure to take a walk around his residence (nearby). You will probably see soldiers standing guard at various spots, and this is probably the only place you can take pictures of soliders without getting caught.Out of convenience, I would recommend that you go on a group tour anyway. Unless you are very confident of taking cabs in Hanoi without getting an unpleasant cab driver. It just gives you a peace of mind!

Great experience. Surreal. Go stand in line with all the Vietnamese (the line moves pretty quickly) and experience the sheer adulation for the man who liberated the country. Don't miss his Russians cars and the house were he worked.

Disappointed.. We were prevented from getting near to the mausoleum as there was some visiting dignitaries from Germany, also unable to enter as Uncle Ho is currently "on holiday" in Russia, it is a very popular destination impossible to takke pictures without others in them.

Worth a look. While there was a huge queue it was very well organised and moved quite quickly. Security was very tight and it was a bit disappointing that you are rushed very fast through and not able to stop and look.

Nice irony to checkout while in Hanoi. I spent 5 days in Hanoi, primarily in the Old Quarters and flipped through my Lonely Planet book numerous times until I decided to check this landmark out. I didn't bring any pants on this trip, only shorts so I was rather bummed by the idea of having to buy pants to get into the mausoleum. However, I don't think you actually need long pants (although they say to cover your knees). I saw a few folks wearing shorts with a button up shirt. My guess is that you just need to look respectable and leave the Bart Simpson look at home. The mausoleum itself is ridiculous. It's quite a spectacle to watch as the heavily guarded mausoleum is teaming with security guards and military personnel. This by itself was more amusing than Ho Chi Minhs' corpse. You only get to spend literally 1-2 minutes in his mausoleum. He looked alright, a bit skinny and his nails were starting to get a brackish color. The amount of manpower they use to upkeep the grounds and guard his dead body is just ridiculous. There was even a full platoon of sorts with assault rifles hanging out in one of the many gardens. The country outside is struggling to develop and pull itself out of poverty, but inside this mausoleum no expense seems to be spared. Seriously, it's worth the visit because of it's sheer ridiculousness.Quick pointers, you will get yelled or turned away if you don't follow these tips:- Check-in your bag if it's large, a typical day backpack is not allowed. Purses and man-purse (murses) are ok. Free check-in.- Don't put your hands in your pocket when you're in the mausoleum, it's considered disrespectful.- Don't chat while in the mausoleum or on the way in.- No food, including water, otherwise you'll need to check it in.- No electronics inside the mausoleum, but you can take pictures on the grounds outside.- Dress respectfully, pants below the knees and covered shoulders. Bring a scarf or something if you want to test waters.

Very busy. We went here for virtually a whole morning we didn't go into see Ho Chi Minh as the queues were massive the one pillar pagoda is in the grounds and there is a museum which is very large. Everywhere here is very busy so be prepared to queue to get into or near everything

Make sure you are able to see HIM... When we went to the mausoleum, we were unlucky bec we cld not enter into d mausoleum itself...apparently it is closed on certain days...do check out before going..

Ridiculous entry process. We walked around the monstrous facility twice before figuring out the right way to enter (and got yelled at by guards when we went the wrong way), but once we figured it out it was interesting to see the body of a highly revered Vietnamese historical figure. He looks just like he does in pictures!

An integral part of history.. We chose not to enter the tomb but enjoyed entry to the gardens which were so well cared for. It was interesting to see the personal home of Ho Chi Minh. The museum chronologically documenting his life was an interesting perspective.

interesting!!!. We had to queue to go in, best to go in the morning. There was a bit boring. There are some nasty principles but nonetheless must respect them. It's worth a visit - Uncle Ho, as the Vietnamese people refer to Ho Chi Minh who was admired and loved by millions of Vietnamese people is there in the mausoleum. It's interesting.

Very impressive. This is one of the most important places to visit in Hanoi if you ask me. It seems absurd that so many people will stand in a kilometer long queue just to get a 30 sec glimse of the old leader. I have a hard time understanding why you would embalm Ho Chi Minh, but this is also the reason for it being so interesting.

Impressive building, but didn't go inside.. While we did not bother to line up for 2 hours in the scortching sun, wear long jeans, go through airport-style security, get stripped off all of our electronic devices, to see the dead leader for 15 seconds inside, we can certainly appreciate the structure itself.Many folks claim this is "a must" while in Hanoi. Well, it is certainly not. You can appreciate the mausoleum from the outside without having to go through the Via Dolorosa to get in.
Very interesting.. Very interesting experience. I would recommend it as part of a trip to Vietnam. This country is fascinating.
Walk like a robot. We are supposed to walk and act like robot to see the dead communist leader. The reverence to Ho Chi Minh is impressive but the security measures are over the top - total frenzy.
Fabulous buildings. The history of this man was amazing to say the least! And at the end of the day he was a humble man.

Fascinating to see him 43 years after he died!. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was very interesting although a little brief. You must arrive there early as it is only open for a couple of hours each day and you must have your shoulders and knees covered up or they wont let you in. The line can be rather long but since they shuffle you through like a cattle line it doesn't take long to get inside. The building is airconditioned to the extreme! You are ordered to walk 2 abreast and you cannot talk or wave your arms or gesture or slow down or you get told to move on. You walk in and round the body and out, that's it. However it is fascinating to see him 43 years after he died in such a good condition due to Russian Embalming technology!

A must-do if you're travelling through Hanoi. If I remember well it's only open till 11 so you might wanna get up early because you'll have to get in line for a LONG time. I'm talking about a 600m waiting line :)

Huge and Imposing but ultimately a bit empty. The grounds of the mausoleum are imposing and beautiful in a stark way. The square in front is huge and empty but well worth a walk down it just for the sheer size if it and imagining what it must be like with huge army parades. The Mausoleum is well worth visiting, to see Ho Chi M inh obviously, but for little else really. We found the museum a little boring, especially after a fairly long queue. But the devotion the people have for Ho Chi Minh is worth seeing in itself, quite moving actually.
Must see. You must go and see this it is historic you can feel the history come to life hereThe exhibit is very moving I enjoyed it imensley

Macabre, unique communist tradition that should be part of your visit. Having visited Chairman Mao in Beijing and Kim Il-Sung in North Korea, I thought why not Ho Chi Minh while in Vietnam.This Mausoleum is really close to other sites, such as the Military History Museum, Ho Chi Minh Museum, and Ho Chi Minh's Residence. So it makes for a convenient site visit. I don't know if it was because of the rain, but we were able to get into the Mausoleum right away. In China and North Korea, the Mausoleum line-ups were daunting.  Make sure you check the hours before you go. While we were there, it was only open for a couple of hours in the morning, on certain days of the week. And as I understand, it is closed entirely for a couple of months each year. Note that you have to check in your camera before entering the Mausoleum, which you retrieve on the way out.And the experience is free of charge.
Really interesting. this was a great attraction to visit. lots to see and the walk through to view Ho Chi Minh was very solemn and respectful. the house on stilts was cool!

Memorable and a very significant building.. Important place to visit for the history of Uncle Ho and his lasting effect on the Vietnamese. Take a Tour Guide. Make sure the main man is in town and not in Russia getting restored. Sorry we missed him.

Don't miss Uncle Ho.. We were not quite sure what to expect but were pleased we did not miss Uncle Ho. Yes, he almost looks like a wax dummy but the level of reverence and respect the vietnamese have for him is catching. It is important to dress respectfully, not scruffy and treat the visit seriously.

MUST DO IN HANOI-STRANGEST CULTURAL EXPERIENCE EVER. Marching passed Ho chi Minhs body lying in state, Long queues, along covered walkways with TVs showing sections of the war and Ho chi Minhs life, standing in pairs, armed guards telling you to remove your sun glasses and stand in a straight line. Make sure you wear trousers or below the knee dress....Then onto his house and cars all in the shadow of the Pepsi sponsored cafes and gift shop with 3 d portraits. Loved it.

It's worth a look. All in all, it is a rather boring site, but that does not mean you should skip it! It's not a far walk from some other attractions, like the Ho Lao prison, so it is worth a look. The only thing to really do is take some pictures, but it's still pretty cool.
Impressive. Did not go inside, but the building itself is very impressive.We got drenched in a real storm as soon as we arrived, nowhere to shelter so maybe have an umbrella ready.

This should be on your itinerary for Hanoi. Quite impressive, especially the way they expect you to behave for example. Every Vietnamese must visit at least once a lifetime, but they like to do it every 2 years. Always crowded, go early and be aware that the mausoleum is closed for 3 months every year.
a great day out. I wasn't sure what to i was going to see but i was suprised by the scale of the place and by Ho Chi MInh's body himself, definitely worth seeing in Hanoi

Impressive. The whole mausoleum visit felt a bit regimented. For sample, you are led through in silence in single file. One of my friends was told off by the guards for not having her hands by her sides, which I a bit strange. Worth a visit nonetheless, very interesting.

It's interesting to see - but follow the rules. Everyone will tell you the line is long but it is a continuously moving line so it's really not that long - maybe 10-15 minutes in the line but you will be walking towards the entrance the entire time. It's worth a visit - Uncle Ho, as the Vietnamese people refer to Ho Chi Minh - is there in the mausoleum. It's interesting.

Quite an experience. You will get to see Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body here. The rules around here is very strict and one has to always maintain a respectful attitude while waiting in line and might be reprimanded by the officials guarding the place. Camera is not allowed and you have to leave it at the counter before entering and could collect it at the other end where you exit.

interesting. Its worth a visit but definitely go early we got there at 7.40am and joined a queue. whilst leaving the queue was soooooo very long heaved a sigh of relief whilst driving by in an air conditioned taxi.

A piece of history really worth experiencing. It was quite an experience between the guards with faces like stone, bayonets and Ho Chi Minh looking like he could wake up any moment. You get a sense of the North Vietnamese.

A must see if you go to Hanoi. A well organised tourist attraction, which is very interesting.
The museum is also worth going in, and the grounds and gardens are lovely

Unmissable. An unforgettable experience, you just can't miss it! Such a sacred place to the Vietnamese so remember to treat it with respect and dress appropriately. Try to go early to avoid the queues.

Mixed Feelings. We had to queue to go in, best to go in the morning. Its practically just queing/walking through and passing by the pickled man. I would give it a miss and if you cant you wont miss anything much.

Get there early to avoid the crowds and queues.. The image of Ho Chi Minh (Bringer of Light) is everywhere in Vietnam and where he lays is one of the holiest places. He was the significant player in obtaining independance for Vietnam. Our tour group were there before 9am and there was a small queue. By 10am this was quite extensive. The Mausoleum is an imposing building which is strictly guarded by military soldiers in striking white uniforms. Dress for the occasion - i.e. no shorts, or skimpy tops. No cameras, no talking! You file past the body of Ho Chi Minh and it is all over in matter of a minute! In the grounds around the Mausoleum you can visit where Ho Chi Minh lived in his later years in a simple house on stilts, as well as the One Pillar Pagoda.

Disciplined Viewing. The strict conduct of the viewing of Ho Chi Minh's remains reflected the reverence of the Vietnamese people for their iconic leader. One would however be reminded somewhat of the communist history of the country as lines were strictly enforced and access points were limited. Cameras were absolutely prohibited inside the mausoleum even as food and drinks were required to be left before entry. All in all it was a unique cultural experience and a privilege of sorts to stand in the same room as a historically recognized charismatic leader.
History Knowledge. Get to know the history of Ho Chi Minh, and his life in Vietnam. Understand more about the history of Vietnam

Must - Go. Another Must-Go in Hanoi. No doubt about it. Just remember the usual stuffs:Note the restricted opening: Tues to Thurs till 11am and Sat - Sun till 8am. In another word, it is closed on Mon and Fri and on all afternoon. For attire: Ensure that you wear sleeved top and bottom must be below the knee level. For shoes, officially must be covered shoes but I do see people wearing slippers in. Officially, they do not avoid bags, waters, camera into the place. To avoid trouble, bring a small bag wtih all the essential stuffs and avoid the banned item.

A No Go in the Autumn.... In OCT 2011 we saw the outside and grounds but not "Uncle Ho". My understanding he is flown to Russia every Fall for a touch up by embalmers so the mausoleum is closed. Was there in AUG-2001 and saw "UncleHo" then. Young guards with bayonets fixed on AK-47's in the tomb especially eyeballing old Viet Nam veterans. 1ID/67-68.

Don't let the queue scare you!. It's only open till 11:00 every morning and the queue is massive around two blocks, but it moves rapidly, so you will definitely make it in. Not much to see but the man himself. I would always do it again though!For the girls: cover knees and shoulders or you can invest in nice scarves right there!

One of my top 3 tours. As a Vietnam vet, there were 2 must see places. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and Hoa Lo (Hanoi Hilton) prison. The mausoleum is a very tightly run, strict, with guards all over making sure the line moves and people observe the proper dress, etc. Recommendation is wear long pants, don't bring a backpack or large bag as you will have to check it at the entrance which is a distance from the actual mausoleum. No cameras or cell phones (turned off in pocket) allowed since photography inside is forbidden. I gave our tour guide my camera and he took pics of us waiting in line but that was the extent of it until we got out of the mausoleum. I had read that the lines can get quite long but since August is the rainy, slow tourist season, and schools had started, not much of a wait. The line moves constantly as there is no stopping allowed. The guards got slightly annoyed with my wife who uses a cane when she slowed the line down behind us as she was climbing the stairs. The actual time in the mausoleum is no more than 1-2 mins max. You can take pictures of the outside of the mausoleum and the grounds are very well kept and spacious.

Must see.. A blast form the past. We had to see this place. Mausoleums are few and far between. Coming from where we do, we think its weird to idolize some dead guy.'Anyway, the mausoleum is there, and it as well as Uncle Ho is a big deal in Vietnam, so we felt it natural to visit. It is a part of the history lesson this whole trip was meant to be for our kids. The day of our visit, an official North Korean delegation visited the mausoleum, so the side entrance normally open to foreigners (according to our guide) was closed, and we had to get in line. I had read it can take a long time to get in, but despite foreign dignitaries, I took us no more than 45 minutes to get in. It rained, but most of the pathway where we lined up was covered, so we passed time by looking at the overhead monitors, showing non-stop videos of various celebrations of the great leader. Sort of "get you in the Uncle Ho mood" while standing in line.The mausoleum is heavily guarded(?) by soldiers dressed in white parade uniforms. We were told they are trained for at least three years before they can serve at the mausoleum grounds. That is because they are not allowed to move as much as an eyebrow should they be unfortunate enough to have a bee land on their face.......Once inside the mausoleum, you are filed at slow pace in a big U around the glass coffin. There are ushers to ensure no one stops, and the coffin itself is surrounded by an honor guard.The dresscode was said to be very strict. I had brought extra pants for the occasion, as it says that men must be covered over the knees. That was not true. I wore shorts and no one said a word.After the mausoleum, we visited the grounds. They contain many interesting buildings. The most beautiful in my opinion is the Presidential Palace of Vietnam. Built from 1900 to house the French Governor-General of Indochina, it is a beautiful example of an Italian Renaissance building. Unfortunately it is closed to the public. There is also a garage with Ho Chi Minhs three cars on display; a Peugeot 404, a Pobeda and a Soviet made (Packard copy) 1954 ZIS.Further on is the simple apartment Ho Chi Minh lived in, and a stilt house he also lived in. The One Pillar Pagoda, or rather the reconstruction of the One Pillar Pagoda that was originally erected on 1049 sits on the grounds. The whole complex is absolutely well worth a visit, even if you skip the mausoleum.

Worth the queue. We went on a Sunday (very silly as it's everyone's day off) and the line was very, very long. But closer to closing time (10.30am I think) the line moved quickly and we were able to see Uncle Ho up close, well...about 2 metres away, behind thick glass and moving along at a pace set by the security. Very interesting, particularly seeing the reverence the locals show.

Not what I expected. Bigger than Red Square, more relaxed atmosphere, guards are very friendly. A bit of a must see for those of us over 55 and who remember the 60's. If in town a must visit, but in reality not much to commend it.

Must go. This is a "must go" place within Hanoi, try to avoid to go there during the weekend due to the long queues to get in. The atmosphere is good but you need to pay attention and respect the rule, is a sacred place. Also the surrounds is a must to visit the places where Ho Chi Minh stayed.

A Chilling Must-See: Don't Be Frightened by The Line!. The dauntingly astronomical queue to get in actually flies by, a true testament to the efficiency of the place, so don't be discouraged at first. Once you're in you get courted by armed guards at attention to the final resting place of the greatly revered Uncle Ho. The architecture itself is grandiose and awesome and once inside the chilled mausoleum it's hard not to be remind of some real life haunted house. Very chilling, very cool. As an add on to this free must do in Hanoi, the surrounding complexes are equally stunning and well worth checking out.

Worth the long queue. Though queue was long but very fast moving as everyone was only given a short glimpse walking around the embalmed body of Uncle Ho. Well organised and certainly one of the must visit places when visiting Hanoi

Interesting but they are so strict it detracts. You can't take camera of any kind which must be left with security. You must also wear long sleeves and trousers below the knew for men. Guards are very up tight! Maybe that's understandable but I couldn't wait to leave.
Boring. ok so, this is pretty much a snore, so i would say see you later to this site because its just boring, if you like watching some old turd in a marble house then it could well be your thing

closes at 11. make sure you wear long pants and long sleeve to go otherwiese they don't let you in. Most of the tourists are Vietnamese, and it's interesting to see their reaction as they pass in front of the body.

Very moving experience!. Do not let the cue scare you, it actually runs along quite quickly. Yes there will be people jumping the line, but it will not slow you down I promise! Remember this is Uncle Ho you are going to see, a man who dedicated his life to simplicity and now he is displayed in a huge Mausoleum and let's not forget the people love him and respect him. It was very moving to see him along side people from all over Vietnam.
Walk past only. No longer allowed to enter so a walk past photo to say you were there!?? Guards in their white uniforms quite photogenic

A rare chance to see a little history. The que was enormous but the wait was well worth it. It's important to cover up shoulders and knees otherwise you won't get in and the security is tight. No phones, no camera's, no drinks and keep walking. The mausoleum is spectacular and the experience is brief as you must keep moving. Well worth it as are the gardens and grounds.

Unusual but.... We were not too sure about going to see Uncle Ho, but we are glad that we did, the line looked huge and it almost put us off, however it moved really really fast so we didnt need to wait long at all. He looked so well that you would almost think he could get up and say hello !!

Double check on opening!. The changing of the guard ceremony is simple but effective. Check that the actual mausoleum is open if you intend to go inside. There are times of the year when Uncle Ho is getting a refurb.

Interesting for the historically interested. The mausoleum itself is a solemn place. If you're - as I am - interested in history, you will not want to miss the chance to see Ho Chi Minh face to face. Come early or be prepared to queue. Also, don't forget 'decent' clothes. If you don't really need to see Ho Chi Minh himself, but rather want to get acquainted with the spirit of this man, go to the presidential palace area next door, where you can visit the very humble wooden house he built there for himself.
Hanoi august 2012. Long but fast line on saturday morning. Efficient staff. Touching experience.Easy reachable with taxi from the old quarter.

Highly organised. Worth the experience despite my initial concerns at seeing the queue, which was organised with military precision... by the military. The queue moved at walking pace - no pausing (or talking once in the mausoleum) - past the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. Given the annual 3 month repair / reconstruction of the body one can only wonder at how much of what is left is actually Ho Chi Minh. At least you can say you have been there and done it!

Surprising. It was amazing to see the Mausoleum and the real body of Ho Chi Minh exposed there... I didnt really read a lot about this place before going, so it was very surprising to me... Remember to wear clothes that cover most of your legs, otherwise you cannot go inside the mausoleum...
You must not miss it. Half the fun (sorry for wording) is watching senior Vietnamese citizens paying respect to their leader.

Really interesting to experience. I think this is a must. Ho Chi Minh is such an important part of Vietnam- and to be able to see him and his actual preserved body is something else and incomparable to other Mausoleums because of this. The lines can be massive, but it moved really quickly. It is a tourist attraction but it was cool to see many local people going to pay their respect- more reason to go and more evidence of the important role Ho Chi Minh has taken in Vietnamese lives. Once inside, you probably get to see him for about 1 minute, but it's so cool. We were lucky enough to see a change of the National Guard as well at the same time. It's worthwhile and it was very easy to get to. It was very intriguing to experience.

Mausoleum. Remember to get here early if you want to make it on time. They close an hour before noon. The lines were rather fast and efficient and we were in and out of the Mausoleum quite quickly. In total, the average visitor only has about 20 to 30 seconds to look at the body, but that is enough time anyway because obviously cameras not allowed in such a place. If you have a camera you will need to turn it in before going in but you get back once you exit. It is pretty easy to see where to drop off and pick up your camera. There are other attractions nearby including the Temple of Literature. I recommend you start the day here and then walk out and explore the surrounding area.

Hanoi's landmark. You can't be in Hanoi and not see this mausoleum, but plan ahead if you'd like to go in. It closes early (around 10:00AM) and do check the schedule ahead of time because it closes often (Friday, public holidays and in other occasions).The line is usually long but moves quickly. Plan ahead as you must dress properly (no sleeveless shirts, shorts or sandals are allowed) and you can't take backpacks, cameras or cell phones inside. Lockers are available.

Interesting but sad. I felt sad visiting the Mausoleum because he had expressly said it wasn't what he wanted. It was an interesting experience however, plenty of people for an otherwise quiet weekday morning and amazing to see the reverance and respect shown for Ho Chi Minh.

Interesting To See. We were lucky enough to go inside the mausoleum which was a very eerie experience and worthwhile. Defiantly worth a stop while in Hanoi, and while you are there ensure to see the surrounding residence and pagodas which are very interesting.

Breathtaking!. Standing in line for 2 hours was totally worth it!!!The 2 minutes it took us to pass by Uncle Ho, left us with a lot of different emotions. Looking at the Vietnamese people in the room with us was a study of pride and honor. He was very beautiful and peaceful to look at.... brought a lot of thoughts about life.

Like taking part in a moment of historical importance. Liked - You get to see Ho Chi Minh himself. Very well-preserved.Disliked - Nothing else to see and you just walk by where he lies in state. You are not allowed to linger.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. A very impressive mausoleum!It shows the respect and love Vietnam has for Ho Chi Minh.FYI, sgoulders have to be covered (they sell shauls at the entrance) and you can not take cameras in with you but there is somewhere to leave them and pick it back up once youve been inside.You can also see Ho Chi Minhs palace, office and home within the grounds.

Amazing experience. This was one of the most bizarre and interesting things I did whilst in Vietnam. When I arrived there was a very long queue but it moves rather quickly . The whole experience is very surreal as you walk around ho's embalmed body. There is complete silence and you must continue to walk without stopping with the guards watching your every move. What moved me the most was the Vietnamese people and their devotion to this man. It's free and worth the experience.

Interesting and Odd - go early. Top Tip, go early. We were here in July (which is apparently when all the Vietnamese are on holiday) and only got there at 10am. The queue was massive, down the road and into a parking lot and round the corner. Saying that, it did move reasonably quickly. You do literally file in and out of the Mausoleum quickly and look at a dead body, but it was an interesting expeirence.
