Make sure your shoulders and knees are covered, otherwise they make you buy cheap scarfs at the 'reception' area, but they weren't expensive, and no water allowed or cameras. The gardens where he lived where probably more interesting - you can go straight there from the exit of the Mausoleoum and foreigns pay 20m Dong to enter.
Queue to see a dead guy. There is pros and cons. The guards are so rude in the actual mausoleum. They pushed us. Not allowed to dawdle. Was worth it but was definitely weird

Impressive structure. What impresses the most was how quickly you do this tour. I say that because the queue is a mile long but it moves like a foot race. This place is not open in the afternoons and is the one place where you will find dress regulations that they inforce

The ugliest lotus flower. I rated this site highly purely because since it is free, it is worth experiencing the bazaar event for yourself. Before you go, make sure you have read even just a small paragraph about Ho Chi Minh. Hell I will tell you the little I know. Uncle Ho wanted to be cremated and have his ashes spread across Vietnam (kind of as a giant gesture of Vietnamese unity). After he died, they decided instead to embalm him and place him in possibly the coldest ugliest building you will ever come across. It is rumored the (wannabe Lincoln mimic) building is representative of a lotus flower. We had fun trying to imagine how! Why I recommend the trip is because once you have been marched into the mausoleum, silently walked around the body and marched right back out you will feel genuinely disturbed. More than ever you will appreciate your free will and rights! Go do it!

Ho Chi Minh. Impressive that after 40 years Ho Chi Minh can still be visited. You have to wait in line as the mausoleum is very popular, especially by the Vietnamese people. The visit of the bar itself will take you around 1.5 min as you are not allowed to stand still. Also speaking up with a soft or loud voice is not allowed. I believe whe you have a chance go and experience it.

Long Lines. Expect long lines with securities. They will take your DSLR. Small cameras will not be taken. But no photo taking is allowed. Must cover your shoulders and no sunglasses are allowed. It only took less than 1 min to see Uncle Ho's remain.

Depends what you're in to.... The bottom line is that you follow a slow moving queue to enter the mausoleum, walk slowly around Ho Chi Minh's preserved body and then walk out. Didn't do much for me to be honest, but the whole setting is quite impressive I suppose.
Long queues. Very long queue, and standing in heat .Vietnamese push and shove, unlike us Brits and even when you get in,you are pushed past very quickly.

Excellent Experience. The mausoleum is beautiful. The embalmed body of Ho chi minh is in it. You cannot take pictures inside but after you come out you could click the mausolem from the outside. For the ladies, please wear cover clothes. ( no sleveless and short dresses allowed).

Join the crowds. This was one of the true Vietnamese experiences Im glad we went be prepared to queue and get hot but when you see the guards standing in the heat we had shade not too bad. You will have to hand in your camera very organised its waiting for you when you leave , you get to see what this man meant to this country, if you have time go

Too pushy. We went to the Mausoleum as part of pre-arranged tour. Sort of glad we went to make a valued judgement but very disappointed at the same time. The 'soldiers' (read 'kids in dress-ups') were arrogant and pushy. You are marched through the building and before you know it you are marching through a room with Uncle Ho taking centre stage. Then you are out again. It's only open till midday so go early, if you go at all. It's one of those places where you say I am glad I have been, but could never recommend it.
Relic of Ho Chi Minh President. This is very good place for our children to visit in Hanoi. Our relatives from US are very excited to visit it. I also have a great day with city tour of Hanoi.
like this much. the perfect view and the soroundings is great to take picture and the opportunity to view the remain of Ho Chi Minh.
Go have a look but nothing sensational. If you are in the vicinity go stroll around the mausoleum. It is massive so in that respect it can be impressive but overall it is not mind-blowing.

Must see and worth the wait. we stood in line for about an hour, In fron and behind us were 8 to 10 yo school children so excited for the FIRST trip to see Uncle Ho.. You well see how loved he was by the people that will be around you. No cameras, No cell phones.. Guards with guns everywhere, I think they would shoot you if you did something wrong, honestly.. You will feel shocked to see him there inside the glass...

Ho Chi Minh Resting place. I like the fact that the lines were moving very quickly despite the large number of people trying to get into the mausoleum. We were not harassed by the guards or anything-one of them politely asked me to remove my hat. It was a very educational tour although the guide will give you a spin about how great Ho Chi Minh is in giving freedom to the Vietnamese people. I don't like to be spinned, so I asked him if people in Vietnam are free to criticize their government without fear of being arrested or worse. He kept quiet about Vietnam's "freedom" after that.
Well worth the queues. How often do you get to see an embalmed icon from history? Its well worth the queues and the whole process is fascinating. He was a great man.

Interesting experience. This was a very moving experience for me. I've never been to anything like that before. If you go make sure that you have your shoulders and knees covered (men and women) and you have to give over your cameras before you go in.

Interesting experience. I think its a must if your in Hanoi. A really interesting experience, being that close to the preserved body of someone that meant so much to the Vietnamese people. Its one of the few 'attractions' for want a better word where the westerners are well and truly outnumbered by the Vietnamese who must flock in their thousands to see their great leader. Don't expect to get much time to look at him, literally had about 15 seconds and was soon told to move on when I briefly paused by the guards. A surreal experience. Make sure you get there early as its pretty popular and closes for a couple of hours at lunch.

Uncle Ho looks peaceful. The queue seems endless and the quick glance at UncleHo's body is momentary = get on the left line for better viewing! the gardens surrounding his old house and house on stilts are manicured. Try to see a ghanging of the guard at the house on stilts.

Cool quick and free attraction. We google mapped directions there from the Old Quarter. Be mindful, the military citadel is off limits and you can only enter the line to go to the mausoleum in two places. So do not trust google maps because the streets they tell you to walk down are restricted. The mausoleum is only open from 8am-11am, I'd recommend going on the earlier side to avoid the heat and long lines.You enter from only 2 entrance points. There are signs with arrows all around the area telling you where to go. All backpacks are scanned and you walk through a metal detector. You are not allowed to bring water with you. After security, you follow the line of people to the entrance. Military guards with bright white uniforms are around directing people, impossible to get lost. The line to the entrance is covered blocking you from the sun, very nice!Walking the steps to the mausoleum, passing the guards in white you are greeted with very cold air conditioning. It's much appreciated in hot Hanoi! Following the line, you walk on a red carpet, through 3 short undecorated halls to meet Vietnam's most famous celebrity. The room with Ho Chi Minh is quite small with 8 guards, photos are obviously prohibited. WALK SLOW! It's not a big room and you can't stop, so walk as slow as the guards will let you to get a good glimpse. You only spend about 30 seconds in the room with Uncle Ho. From there you follow the line to the hot outside and you can go where you like. We went back to the front to take pictures in front of the mausoleum, pictures are allowed of the outside.This is a great attraction because it's free and short. From standing in the security line to leaving after taking pictures in front of the mausoleum, it's about a 15 minute attraction. Plus have you ever seen anyone embalmed before? It's a very interesting experience.
interesting. The long line of people to get in was a suprise and the security was tight (no water bottles, back packs etc) worth a vist if only so say been there done that

Impressive!. I was feeling a bit unsure about visiting a body, but decided to go anyway and I am very happy I did.
The vision of Ho Chi Minh's body was very impressive. It seems in very good condition and it felt like been in his funeral
Loved the grounds.... To get into the mausoleum you'll need to be dressed in long pants and collared shirts. Not something many tourists to the tropic hot and humid country pack with them

Pleased we went. A group of four of us went early in the morning to visit the Mausoleum. It was on our 'must-see' list, and we were all pleased we went. Was a bit of a bizarre situation but makes it all the more worth it.SO many people, even just after 7am when we got there, but were even more people in the queue as well as buses of tour groups when we were leaving.We had just got off the overnight train from Sapa, so after a shower and breakfast walked straight to the Mausoleum and were in the line just after 7am. It opens at 7.30, so only had to wait around 10-15minutes before the line started moving. Can't take anything in with your (ie water, cameras etc) but they have free storage. Free to enter the Mausoleum.We stopped at a small cafe (Lix Coffee Takeaway - we recommend this place too!) just around the corner once we were finished to refresh.
Must see. It was truly a must see the white suited guards were a little intense. Most of the site seers were vietnamese. So it was quite interesting to see their dedication.

Visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. A must i guess when you are in Hanoi. A very long line to go in, but it was moving all the time so it did not take long. When I was in there I couldn't help wundering if it was really him.

Insight into cold war style communism. This place was not what one would describe as the friendliest place on Earth. My teenage son cut a corner and nearly got a rifle in his back. If one delays for more than a split second when walking past Uncle Ho, you guessed it, cold steel in the back.Oh, and make sure that you cover up. My daughter had to by an overpriced scarf at the entrance to cover up as her skirt was above the knee.All in all though, something that you should see if in Hanoi.
Mausoleum. Classic communist mausoleum. Great photo opportunity
State pump. Very busy so go early... Lines go quick as you cannot stop...

A DEFINATE MUST VISIT PLACE.. This is very much well worth a visit, the Mausoleum is beautifull and kept in the best of order, the guards are extremely smart and the Vietnamese who visit in their hundreds show deep respect for the man who they still honour today. He is deeply adored and respected.

In a word... Weird.. Visited here in July 2012 as part of a guided tour.The experience is... in a word, weird.  Our tour guide had arranged access via a shorter VIP line, so we only waited maybe 15 minutes before entering the building.  However the lineup without this VIP access was massive, thousands of people.  The mausoleum itself is cool, armed guards are everywhere and respectful etiquette is expected.  It is after all a grave of one of Vietnam's most important leaders.  Some western tourists were disrespectful.  We may not share the feelings or even understand the dedication to Ho Chi Minh but I was disappointed by how disrespectful some of the tourists were.  The guards did set them straight by asking them to remove hats or be quiet.  Ladies be aware that you must cover your shoulders and knees.  If you didn't bring anything they will sell you a wrap for around 4 USD.  You are shuffled along at a slow but steady pace, it is ice cold in the building.  You enter the tomb and then spend maybe 30 seconds to a minute in the room, always shuffling forward at the same pace.  Afterwards you exit and it is all over.  To be honest you're not seeing much, but its kind of cool to see such an influential person from history.  Unless you're a big history buff, the lineup isn't worth it.  If you have VIP access its only a few minutes, otherwise you spend an entire morning queued up.  The grounds around the mausoleum are nice places to take pictures.  It's very hot and crowded in the lineup.  It's cool, but in my opinion not worth standing in line for hours for.

Interesting. With how much HCM meant and still means around Vietnam we felt we had to go in to the mausoluem, despite not really having 'see a dead body' on the top of my honeymoon list of things to do! I'm glad we did as despite the ridiculously officious guards, it was a real eye opener. The clear Russian stamp on it was a bit unnerving but something that was good to see to make sense of some of the past thoughts around the country. Also to see the villagers who've travelled from more remote parts of the country show how important the mausoleum is to them.

Large land area presented in the middle of Town. While understanding that it is a place of honour for the father of the unification of the country and a place that you must see for its significance, I find "bare soul" in places like this.Nevertheless, I always make the time to visit them.
Visit Uncle Ho. Brillant. I did expect to see the real Ho Chi Minh. This you must see. Very busy lots of people go there. Get there real early

A particular slant on history. A good way to see how the ruling party presents the nation's turbulent modern history to its people. The great diversity of Ho Chi Minh's life and his unstoppable determination are shown in detail.

Go see Uncle Ho.. Great insight into the man still so revered by the Vietnamese - young and old alike. We went here with the Hanoi Kids who were able to offer lots of information. Interesting place to see and would recommend you make the trip. Its closed on Monday's!

Impressive site to understand more about Vietnam. Similar to Mao's mausoleum in Beijing, this is a very important site in Hanoi. You have to join the queue (separate and shorter one for foreigner in a country of equals...) for about 20 minutes to get into the Mausoleum where the body of Ho Chi Min is displayed. Take a quick look as the very serious guards will move you on very rapidly.

Totally unnecessarily unpleasant experience. Ripped off by the taxi driver to start with, no time to protest as an official with a big stick threatened us if we didn't get moving. Checked our cameras and joined the shuffling to pay our respects. No reciprocity there, an armed guard manhandled me round the corner in the inner chamber and shoved me on to get me out as quick as possible and then hissed at my wife. We were perfectly respectable in our dress and demeanour but felt intimdated and were happy to leave. It reminds you that as a tourist destination, the people seem split between those who welcome us getting to understand their culture and those who'd rather see the back of us. Then again, I'm grateful for a taste of a real place and people. Even so, I could have done without it. When you get your camera back at the other end, there's some good photo opportunities in the park of the outside of the mausoleum.
Zzzzzz. Basically a regional version/copy of Lenin's Mauseleum in Red Square. Very long lines but they do move quickly.

Worth seeing. HCM Mausoleum was worth seeing. I felt the soldiers were over the top. Felts like your in the army - no hands in pockets, stand straight, hands down on your side, no camera, no hat, no sunglasses, walk in straight line. But it was interesting to see HCM's body.

Unique place. If you are in Hanoi you should definitely see the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It is an experience like no other and very strange. I would recommend getting there early though because it closes early and there are always long lines (they move quickly though)
HCMC Mausoleum. The mausoleum and HCMC museum are very informative, giving rather detailed background about HCM himself and the Communist Party.
Good Luck on The Weather. This is a massive of space dedicated to HCM. Try to wear light clothings and bring shades. We didn't last long as the weather was scorching!

Amazing Amount of People Visiting. We didn't get to go into see HCM as it was school holidays, and the line went for so long we would have taken 2 or 3 hours in the line. Don't go in Vietnam school holidays, line tooo long. We went back later and no one was there, so only went through his residence.

The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is a must when you visit Hanoi. It's fascinating how the Vietnamese honour Ho Chi Minh and preserve his body so well and make him available to the public and the world. The number of visitors to the mausoleum tells you how much revenue is generated through tourism in this country.

Ho Chi Minh's Body!. Felt like little soldiers - marching in a row, not able to talk, no photos - unable to take cameras or phones into the Mausoleum. No hats and sunglasses off! Stay between the lines and do not stop - just keep moving through. The french have done an amazing job with the embalming - he looks fabulous - it's a shame they did not respect his wishes as he actually wanted to be cremated!
A different view. Avery different view of life in North Vietnam strange but interesting place to visit
Make sure it's open,. We went twice but both times it was closed for unsheduled maintenance. Still an impressive structure from the outside.

must visit. very impressive landmark. We didn't go inside but I personally think it is the most impressive location of our trip. It's quite far from the heart of the city but definitely worth a visit.

Worth a visit. As per previous reviews the line was very long, however moved quickly. It is really important that you take note of the rules when entering the mausoleum, my daughter was given a hurry up by one of the guards because she left to much space between herself and the next person.

A few tips that I wish we had... I am not the best person to comment on this attraction because when we arrived to the Mausoleum only the museum was open and we could not gain access to Ho Chi Minh. We were unaware that this part of the attraction closed circa 11:00am. In this regard, I would advise people to go early if they are making the trip out to the Mausoleum. Also, as a mark of respect, be sure to wear trousers below the knee and a modest t-shirt...as hot as Hanoi is, you will not gain access to the Mausoleum dressed any other way.

You HAVE to see this!. Yes, there are ridiculously long lines, but they're constantly moving, you're never standing still. I went on a wet, humid day and found the experience (the lining up part too) unlike anything else. If you have any interest in war-time history, or Vietnam at all for that matter: you HAVE to see the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh. Remember, dress appropriately, it's unbelievable what westerners think they can get around in foreign countries in?!Amazing. A must see!

Leave it to the locals. The queues were astonishing, at least a mile long; and we arrived at 8.30am! We got in through a side entrance so only queued for 20 minutes or so. It's probably best left to people who actually want to pay their respects to HCM rather than tourists.

Really interesting. Similar to any other Ho Chi Minh related thing in Vietnam, respect is a must. 'Uncle Ho' is still widely respected so its best to keep yourself out of politics if you not positive about it.I've tried to go to this place about 5 times in 6 years, and only once it has been open. You can go around the outside, but getting in is always a bit of a battle. Remember, even though you may be booked on a tour to go there, it may not really be open, so don't get angry at your tour operator, as they really don't know if it is or isn't open.

Well preserved!!. As a "Westerner" with a tour guide - you get placed toward the front of the line - and not on the end - which can be up to a kilometre long. But the line moves fast - and it's really cool inside the mausoleum - which is good in the heat and humidity of Hanoi.

Well worth the visit. We joined a mile long queue but thanks to the efficiency of the VN army guards it took us just 20 minutes to get to view the remains. It is impressive to see reverence of the people of Vietnam, and especially the young people, for Ho Chi Minh and his achievements for the nation.

Peaceful vicinity within a Very Busy City. The area is safe and pedestrianised, giving the opportunity to take in the Architectural and colonial past of this part of the City. Pity more fresh paint is not applied to the beautiful buildings some of which are beginning to fall into serious disrepair.

Not your usual tombstone. This was a surreal experience for us and would not mine lining up to see Uncle Ho. It was really amazing how much they revere their old leader and liberator. Such devotion and love.
You should see it. Don't forget that it is holly place for vietnamese people. You should have no shorts, no naked arms, no short skirt (woman in check-room sell me sarong for 3 Dollars)

A beautiful place. Opens at 8am but try to be there at about 730am queue gets super long after 8am, remember not to bring your food or water as retrieving it can be difficult, mine got lost no camera is allowed leave it outside, a number tag will be given to collect later

Highly respected place in Hanoi. We visited at 9 AM and there was a long queue which was around 1 KM. but it quickly moved and we completed within 30 minutes. The place is highly organized and disciplined. Very serene. Nice to see the respect for their 1st president.

Amazing preservation. What a way to preserve history, by preserving one of, if not the key figures of recent Vietnamese history, Uncle Ho. Resting in peace amidst beautifully caretaked grounds, laughing Koi, and venerated by thousands every year ...
If nothing else, visit witha. Knowledgeable guide to get a taste of the politico-social context of the country.

A very nice place to visit.. The Masoleum is one of the places where you will be captivated with the energy and silence maintained where HO CHINH MINH's body has been kept. The body of such a great leader lies calm making us remember about a great time period where he stood up for his country. We loved visiting
you see him. Security is tight, respect with no cameras, no talking etc, but the man its there and the line moves really quick

Soviet style!. Very imposing building this one. Great setting. You get filed past the remains of "Uncle" - hard to believe its really him. He gets taken back to Russia for 2 months a year Apparently for "maintenance"!
Timing is everything. It closes before lunch; if you want to take a peak at him, you need to get there early. I hear the lines are rediculous daily! The afternoon is peaceful for a nice stroll

30 seconds of Uncle Ho - definitely worth it. Be there at 8 in the morning and you dont have to wait for hours in the sun.
Even if you cant take a picture of this experience and you are only allowed to take a 30 sec. look, its definitely worth it!
DO IT

Very popular with locals long queues. Was looking forward to the visit, but the queue was more than 3 blocks long and despite having carefully read opening times and dress requirements, we were told we were inappropriately dressed and not permitted to enter. We were wearing long trousers and long top, but had no sleeves in them. Believe this was the problem, though we did notice some others being allowed to pass the checkpoint dressed more scantily than we were. It was 37 degrees too. So, be prepared to wait in the sun in summer and make sure you have a shawl with you and no short shorts or sleeveless tops
Clean and . . . closed!. We went there on Monday and the place was closed. Could not tell what was inside, however, the outside area was very clean -- lots of guards.

you must go...... If you are in Hanoi you must go to this - Make sure the taxi driver takes you to the correct entrance for viewing the tomb, otherwise it's a long walk. Firstly you will experience a typically odd Vietnamese secirity process, which includes having your camera taken off you, shipped over to another booth near the tomb & given back. As others have said go early, when the Vietnamese say they are closing at 11 am -they mean it.....I missed part of the Ho museum (which I was very disapointed about as it looked like something which should have been designed for showing the work of Salvador Dali).The experience of seeing Ho was very unique, I have been lucky to also see Lenin. To understand The cult of personality around Uncle Ho is a fascinating part of the Vietnam experience. As is watching the disciplinarian gards in action around the tomb, and visiting Uncle Ho's hous and garden.

Definitely worthwhile. When I arrived to see a queue around 1km long at 0715 in the morning I wondered at the wisdom of this. However the queue moves very quickly and we soon got to see President Ho. We saw no other tourists in the queue so it gave a real indication for the feeling the Vietnamese people have for President Ho. While you were continually moved past the body there was a real respectful feel about the whole process.I was concerned with the security of having to leave my camera outside but it was very well organised and no problems.
necessary tourist stop. Reminded me of seeing Lenin's body except the Russian soldiers were rougher moving people through. Sad to see the preserved corpse of a man who had requested to be cremated.

Visit to Uncle Ho. We went to the Mausoleum on Sunday at 10am expecting vast long queues. However the long line of people moved quickly and took about an hour altogether. It is free to see and you can drop bags off at the beginning for free too. It's a bit strange seeing the embalmed body (or perhaps an excellent example of Madame Tussauds) and interesting to watch the reactions by Vietnamese.
Architecture. Very well designed building. Good maintenance and friendly staff.

Worth the Long Lines!. Do what the locals do in Hanoi--go see Uncle Ho in his final resting place!We went first thing in the morning (8am) and only waited about 30 minutes in line. There were almost no foreigners...so it was a truly authentic Vietnamese experience. The mood is somber and serious. You have to wear long pants and a long sleeved shirt. The hotel staff will tell you if you're dressed appropriately before you go. Leave your camera in a bag or purse, as it's not allowed inside the mausoleum.It's a very cool experience--well worth the lines :)

Surreal. I actually enjoyed this & would recommend it to anyone that visits Hanoi. Yes the lines were unbelievably long, but it did move efficiently enough. When you finally get in, you get ushered through the tomb in about a minute. Having said that I found the experience surreal & worthwhile.

Go early and expect a queue. There was a queue to get in but it moved along very quickly. You don't get long to look at Uncle Ho - you are ushered past him very quickly but I would say it was worth the wait! (about 30 mins on a Saturday morning at 8am).
Better than Mao's in Beijing. Pleasant park setting, unlike the starkness of Mao's tomb in Beijing

A little bizarre. Interesting if a little strange. There is a long inefficient and over-bureaucratic process of going through security and leaving valuables before being marched into the mausoleum. Once in the mausoleum it takes around 30 seconds to walk round his body and the guards, of which they are many, won't let you pause even for a second.

good for those interested. my friend and i visited the mausoleum but didnt spend too long because we werent too interested. i would recommend it to those who are interested in vietnam's history or would just like to visit a "must-see" in vietnam. can be done in an hour if the queue isnt too long and slow moving. no cameras allowed so dont bother bringing it otherwise you need to drop it off and then pick it up at a later station. it gets crowded even in the morning, so be there as early as you can!

A life preserved and deserved.. There was a long queue but it moved quickly. Westerners need to get there early be prepared for some strict controls and a bit of good old fashioned discipline from the security. You walk through and past the rposing preserved body of Ho Chi Minh. How good is that ? A memorable experience. It's about a half hour walk from the end of the old quater, easy to spot in the distance. Get a taxi if you can't take the heat. The local come in big numbers to this most days, like a pligrimage I guess.

Miss Mausuleum and see Museum!. An extensive and informative museum - clearly had lots of investment in the memory of Uncle Ho. Seems the mausoleum is for Vietnamese who deeply respect Ho - westerners head for the museum to be informed of the Vietnamese view on him.

a long row for a dead body. A very long row, it took me an hour to get in, a lot of regulations. The one pool temple besides the mausoleum was terrible. The wooden pool was replaces by a massive concrete pillar.

Go for the whole experience, but go early. One of the few places on the tourist map where Vietnamese overwhelmingly out number foreigners, and for us this made the visit much more interesting. The park areas and the opprotunity to look at where Uncle Ho lived are as interesting as the actual mausoluem. Seeing literally hundreds of school and pre-school children on excursions was also fun. It is a beautiful area. Go early though. By the time we came out mid morning the queues were very long.
Superb. This is a place that you must visit if you are in Vietnam
Go early if you don't like queuing. Another must see attraction in Hanoi. It's quite eye opening to gain an understanding of how much HCM is revered in Vietnam.

Sobering. The queue was crazy on a Sunday at 09:30, we couldn't figure out where to join it and eventually gave up. After wandering off to see the nearby B52 we accidentally stumbled back into a much shorter queue and were shepharded through. It still took about 45 minutes to go through even with the much shorter queue.I can't explain the quietness or mood inside the mausoleum but it was definately an experience - all be it not one I would have wanted to queue 2 hours for.Try to go early if you can and avoid weekends if possible.
just go and see. short but one of those things you just do...this could easily be skipped
Got to visit the big guy!!. Huge queue with lots of confusing signs and pushing in - but worth it for the experience and to see the living quarters of HMC.

????. Wait, walk a little, wait, walk a little more it took nearly 11/2 hours to get into the tomb, was it worth it? well it was a novelty as for the residences and gardens well OK. If it hadn't been included in the tour I'd say a waste of time and money. But each to their own, not for me.

Get their early!!. Finally on our third attempt we made it through! Our first day we arrived to late, our mistake. The second time we arrived at 9 as it closed at 11. Lined up for an hour and a half & still didn't get in. On our last day, a Sunday morning we arrived at 8 and we still lined up for nearly three hours. Worth it - it's just an amazing experience to see someone who was so powerful and such an important figure in Vietnamese history.

How to get a hassle free experience. The guide books explains what you should wear and how to behave at the mausoleum but even when you think you have done everything in preparation it can still be a hassle. So I hope this review will help eliminate some of that hassle. First don't go on the weekend. There are thousands of local Vietnamese turning up to pay their respects and the queues are enormous. Stick to a week day and go early. Do not have bare shoulders but you can wear shorts as long as they cover the knee. You will not be allowed to carry any food or drink into the mausoleum and will have to leave your rucksack/bag at the entrance building. Carry a smaller bag for glasses, wallets etc which you can transfer these belongings into. About half way along the queue you will have to deposit your cameras. These go into a security bag and you pick them up as you leave the mausoleum. They are very efficient and the system does work so don't worry. The actual experience inside the mausoleum is interesting because of the great reverence Vietnamese people still pay to "The Father of Vietnam". The experience inside lasts a matter of minutes as you are ushered around and quickly moved on by security guards if you pause. Once outside you can buy a ticket to visit the other buildings associated with Ho Chi Minh. The museum is definitely worth visiting. But remember the complex closes for lunch so collect your bag before they close otherwise you are stuck until they reopen in the afternoon or following morning.

Proud History. Its best to go here with a guide or friend that knows the story, please dress appropriately/respectfully or you wont be able to enter, great photo opportunities and a chance to learn a lot about Vietnam's proud history
worth a visit. Wasnt able to get very close to mausoleum, due to security, but quite impressive

KEEPING THE LOVE ALIVE!!. All countries have their different ways of acknowledging their greatest Leaders etc, but this is the ultimate in my opinion. Regardless of your age you will definitely appreciate visiting this site

Stately but watch out for the strict military rules!. Do not bring camera, big handbags, water or food into the mausoleum as they are not allowed. Don't think you can get away with taking photos with your handphone, either! The mausoleum was great - HCM's body was very well preserved you could say there was a glow to his skin, even. There are guards all over the place who will keep you in line - do not walk out of the red carpet and do not stall as there are many people who visit and everyone needs to be in single file to quicken the process. It is good to know that a great leader remained humble throughout his life, and that he had brought so much change to the country. The house and the surroundings sit on very serene grounds.

Very Impressive and Somber. Our first adventure in Hanoi was visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. I wasn't prepared and quickly realized how reverently he is treated by the Vietnamese. No talking, no photos, hats off and single file as we walked around inside.

Cover your arms and legs. Was not sure about going here but it was in the city tour. It was a long long wait in boiling hot sun and I dont think it was worth it. You file pass an embalmed Ho Chi Minh and if you work out how long he has been dead you start to wonder.

Still not sure how I feel about it. The building is certainly impressive. You can see it is very important to the Vietnamese.The guards are very regal and formal standing at the entrance and inside.Is only open till 11.30am. Closed Friday and Mondays. You have to wear clothes that cover your shoulders and knees. If you dont you can buy a wrap there to cover yourself.Wasnt intending to go inside the mausoleum as had mixed feeling about this. Really wanted to go to the grounds where HCM lived and worked. But in order to get to the grounds we had to go via the mausoleum.You queue up in what is a long long queue. But it moves fairly quickly. You enter the mausoleum. Walk past HCM. Show your respect for this man and what he did for his people and country.Behind the mausoleum is where you find the Palace and gardens.

Got to be done when in Hanoi. A big, imposing, ominous structure one that shouted out Soviet. After having this thought I read that it was based on Lenin’s tomb so that figures. It was a shame that we couldn’t go in as we were under the impression that you could but perhaps things have changed now or maybe it’s because it is the low season. Either way a significant building in Vietnamese history and one that should be visited.
Make the Time for It. Place you should see to just experience the quiet and solitude. Pretty stark construction but does not take away from the importance of the site and hsitory that goes with it

A great experience!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. We visited the Mausoleum one morning and were amazed to see the wonderful structure, the pristine surrounding area and the efficiency of the staff working there. Every bag was thoroughly checked at the entrance, water and any electronic item that could capture pictures were placed at the security post near the exit of the mausoleum. People were filed in a single row and requested to show adequate respect for their departed President. As you walk through the high ceiling room one after the other without stopping you can understand the affection of the people of Vietnam for the gentleman lying in state. As you exit the mausoleum, you can collect your cameras/phones and proceed to the other attractions within the complex such as Uncle Ho's house, one pillar pagoda etc. Must visit when in Hanoi
When in Hanoi...you should. Something to experience for sure. The Vietnamese take this VERY seriously so showing respect is important. Also the area around is nice also.

Better than expected. A visit to the Mausoleum was on out programme but after visiting Stalin's tomb in Moscow a couple of years ago which was very aggressively policed we were a bit unsure. In the event this was an interesting (if short- you had to keep moving) visit that presented well the kindliness of the great leader.

A bizzare experience. You'll need to go early as the tomb closes around 11. You're not allowed to take anything with you (including small children) and you will fell like you're in Year 2 again as you march towards the mausoleum in two straight lines. Given the reverence that is bestowed upon Ho Chi Minh it is surprising really that foreigners are allowed in to see him at all. For that reason then, I advise you to maintain a certain solemnity, unlike some French people who were just in front of my daughter and I in the line. It's not that hard really to move silently as requested and to observe a couple of minutes respect for another person I think. There is no time for loitering to have a look at Ho Chi Minh but the first thing you notice is his definite orange glow! The second thing is the dumb-struck awe on the faces of the Vietnamese - this really means something to them. Once outside, the Presidential Palace grounds are adjacent to the mausoluem. You ca also stand at the front of the mausoleum and take photos - but don't step on the grass!

A must in Hanoi. People considers this place the most important for its history, what it represents. It is a beatifull place, with a lotus-like pagoda near the Mausoleum. Recommended, it takes just an hour maximum.
Not easily accessible. The mausoleum building itself is a fine piece of architecture but the opening times are tourist unfriendly. Only open a couple of mornings a week 8.30 till 11.30.
A Must do. A surreal but very moving experience. You can feel the reverence and esteem as thousands shuffle past.

Make this a priority. This is a truly amazing moment...it speaks volumes of the nature of ancestor-worship, hero-worship and the place of history. Even getting into this site is an incredible and moving experience. Be prepared to share the tourist experience with the local national experience. It is a place that makes you think...

Impressive. Maybe you have to queue up for a while but what you see is part of History, whether you agree with what it represents or not. It is impressive to see how Vietnamese people still venerate Ho Chi Minh's memory, more than 40 years after his death.
Interesting. Interesting to see how proud of this the locals are. Visit before 11:00am when it closes.
Worth a visit. Fascinating to see the Vietnamese perspective on the war and on Ho Chi MInh. Ho Chi MInh's body is interred in the mausoleum and he appeared very well preserved.

A respectful memorial. The mausoleum is one of the attractions in Ba Dinh Square. Others include the one-pillar pagoda, the presidential palace, the stilt house and the Ho Chi Minh museum. Long line ups to enter mausoleum but the lines move quickly as museum guards are on hand to ensure no photos are being taken, there is no talking, hands are out of pockets and hats are removed. Ho's preserved remains lie in a refrigerated transparent viewing casket. I understand that his body is sent to Russia on a regular basis to ensure the embalming process remains high quality. Given that he died in 1969, it would appear the process is effective. Despite stories to the contrary, "Uncle Ho" is considered to be the founding father of modern Vietnam and we were told this was considered, by Vietnamese, to be one of the holiest sites in the country.
A Must See. This is the main attraction to see in Hanoi and should be manditory for all to see passing through Hanoi. Make sure to get there early and avoid the long lines though.

Go with a guide, or be prepared for a long wait.. When we arrived at the Mausoleum at 9 in the morning we were met by 2 long lines of people waiting for entry. As we were with our guide ,Mr Cahn Ahn -a legend - he was able to get us through very quickly. It helped knowing about clothing and cameras, and Ahn was able to fill us in on the history as we waited. The mausoleum experience itself is a little eerie. Two lines of silent people viewing Uncle Ho as he lies in state, protected by 4 guards. You really should make the effort to go to visit this mausoleum if you are in Hanoi. It is so historically and culturally important.
Not for foreigners. They have weird opening hours and heavily guarded by guards/police. Unless you are local or indebted to Mr Ho, otherwise really no point visiting.
nice historical place to learn new culture. you can learn about life of vietnamese from the past to present

Forgive the pun but "Ho-hum". If one enjoys seeing an embalmed body, this was ok. Not sure it is worth the time it takes to wait for admittance; seeing Ho's residence was mildly interesting. Not a priority compared to other things one might do in Hanoi.

Strange place. Yes it does provide some good detailed information about Uncle Ho, but the exhibitions were strange and non cohesive with random pieces that made no sense, not even the guide with us could explain it.

Must see. I suppose it's mandatory when in Hanoi to visit Ho Chi Minh. All the locals seem to pay great homage as the queues were incredible the day I was there. Still it's worth the wait to see how revered this man still is.
get there early enough. Seeing a embalmed body is quite an experience, don't forget to get there early in the morning or you may have to stand for an hour.

Go early. We arrived early AM, no line up, and moved straight through. A bit sad to see such a revered communists wishes not being followed. He wanted to be cremated, but they continue to have his mumified body on display. Very sombre, I would not miss it.

Uncle Ho. With Lenin in Moscow and Mao in Beijing, Uncle Ho is the third political 'star' to be kept on ice as it were. Unlike the other two fellows, the visit to Uncle Ho is relatively easy. Just join th elong long line, make sure you don't cross your hands or put them in your pockets (the large number of watchful soldiers are quick to point out anything they don't like you doing) and of course holster the camera - it ain't going to happen here. Interesting soviet-era styled mausoleum - beautiful in it's stark ugliness and Uncle Ho himself... well he's not travelling so well. Pity they didn't listen to his specific request not to put him under glass. Worth visiting and then moving on.

Very Communist. Very somber, rigid, cold. Hands below the waist, head bowed, no talking, no pictures as you file thru this large block of stone to see "Uncle Ho" resting in a glass case guarded by soldiers in white uniform. Earie, but probably something you won't see anywhere else in the world.
Amazing. Like going back in time - once in a life time opportunity to see the man that has meant so much to so many, and still inspires a country on the move.

Amazing Cultural Experience. Ho Chi Minh lies in state, preserved through modern mummification techniques, inside a massive concrete mausoleum. Never mind that he wished to be cremated, or that preservation of somebody like this is more of an imitation of what the Russians (who paid for Ho Chi Minh’s preservation) did with Lenin, he lies in the mausoleum for all to see. We waited in line for 30-60 minutes, a relatively short time compared to normal waits here. We are carefully herded two-by-two through a series of right angle turns until we are in front of the mausoleum. In the course of waiting, we have had to shed all cameras, and been checked to ensure we meet the dress code-no short shorts, bare shoulders, sunglasses, or hats. This place deserves all the respect and more of the most sacred temples in this country.  Outside and inside the mausoleum are guards wearing white uniforms trimmed in the gold and red of the Vietnamese flag (gold and red historically symbolize prosperity and happiness in Buddhist tradition, but the red today also symbolizes the blood that spilled by many generations for Vietnamese independence; the five-pointed gold star in the middle of the flag symbolizes five classes (military, professional, administrative, farming, and working) working together for the prosperity of the country). I am assuming this assignment is quite like that of Arlington Cemetery for U.S. Marines, but I was also taken here by how unkempt the uniforms looked and undisciplined the guards outside seemed. None of the look-straight-ahead-stand-straight-as-a-board-never-twitch discipline that I associate with our Marines at Arlington. Inside the mausoleum, I counted 18 guards, including four who stand at attention with rifles at each of the four corners of the glass enclosed tomb where Ho Chi Minh’s body lies. Guards along the line seemed to be devoted primarily to grabbing slow movers, like me more than once, by the elbow to move us along. After an hour wait, one views Ho Chi Minh for less than a minute, and then moves on to the the French-built building where he lived from 1954-58 (not the “palace” the French had built, but the former servant’s quarters), and then to the Vietnamese house built on stilts in the style of the homes of the mountain people where he lived the remainder of his life. It is a simple, pretty, heavily guarded place on pond where tourists clap to attract the carp to the surface where they feed them until they are shooed along by the guards in white. The preserved corpse is a little creepy. The homes are simple, but provide real insight into the man. The real reason to go her, though, is to see the thousands and thousands of people who flock here from all parts of the country to honor Ho Chi Minh. This complex attracts thousands upon thousands, young and old, families and couples, Vietnamese and foreigners--much like Washington DC, when school is out.

A great experience. Check the opening times as it has quie restricted hours, but it is worth the effort to get there.The organisation to move the visitors through the mausoleum is fantastic. A lot of tourist attractions in other parts of the world could learn from it.The start of the queue was about a mile from the mausoleum but it moves very swiftly and you are inside the mausoleum in no time.It may be a bit morbid to walk past the embalmed leader but many vietnames visitors are visibly moved. It is cold inside so bring a jacket!

Day is ok, but visit at night. Its on the list of must do's in Hanoi really, take your time, stand in the lines, it will take a while and the actual time you spend seeing Ho Chi Minh is brief but you can tick it off the list. I enjoyed all the school kids and the securities attention to detail the most. They are clearly very proud of the Mausoleum and go to great lengths to protect it. Don't bother with water, they will take it from you at the security check point. But for a real buzz, visit here from 8pm to 9pm at night. All the locals are exercising, I was the only westerner, and the lights are magic. At 9pm they kick you off the concrete and have a huge procession to drop the flag, I had a local family help me understand which was great fun. Do this, you won't regret it.

Find out the route. Lovely setting in park area. Beware that you will be directed "around the houses" to gain entry..our taxi dropped us off in front of the mausoleum but didn't tell us where t go..every way we tried to go directly we were stopped and turned around..must have walked a kilometre when we started out in front of the place!

Get there early.. It was 39 degrees the day we were there. Hot and sticky! Fortunately we missed the queues since we got there at 8 am ahead of the crowds. Plenty of security checks till you get inside - no water, fruit or cameras allowed. Quite eerie but a fascinating experience.

A value place to pay a visit. This is one of the visiting site you shouldnot miss. It is closed on Monday and Friday and afternoons. Vietnamese are proud of him and here you can see this famous hero where he lived and worked as well as his tomb & body still keep

A well oiled machine. There are a lot of security checkpoints. Bags must be deposited at the first booth. Cameras must be deposited at the second. Relax and follow the signs. Everything is very well marked and efficient. If you're in Hanoi you cannot miss this. It's too surreal.

Bizzar. Its free.
The procedure to walk in mausoleum its very bizzar and you have few minutes to see the dead HCM.
Its a experince you cant miss.

Worth queueing for. We visited the Mausoleum during the recent liberation day celebrations - one of the busiest times! We waited for 2.5 hours in the heat - well worth it though. It's just one of those things you have to do when in Hanoi.

very majestic. we didn't get to go inside of the ho chi mausoleum as it was independance day and the line up to get inside was massive. we thought we would leave it to the faithfull. outside the mausoleum was in full beauty. flags flying large wreaths out the front of the entrance. it looked spectacular. maybe when we get back we will get inside.
A must see!. For visitors to Hanoi I believe this will be a stop well worth seeing.

Short but worth it. I visited around 9o'clock during a week days. Although I had to wait for 40 minutes, I didn't find the place that busy. Groups of tourists (caucasians, vietnamese kids 4-18years, veterans... all groups) had a privilegium to go first, then they let individuals in. If you have a big bag, you have to deposit it, the same goes for every camera (cameras will be given back right when you walk out from the mausoleum, for bags you have to walk back to the starting point).Guards were changing flowers, everything seemed very professional.Once you are inside, you can't stop, eventually you get maybe 15 seconds with Ho Chi Minh in his nice suit and pale skin.. good job russians..

An essential stop on your Hanoi itinerary. Not only is the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum one of the most popular tourist attractions for locals, not only foreign tourists, but its in the heart of one of the most interesting areas in Hanoi. Lots of laid back properties, interesting architecture, housing government offices, and officials. Its definitely worth a visit and walk through.Its considered quite a privilege to work in this area of Hanoi.
Brilliant. This was a highlight of my trip to Hanoi. Was just so interesting and so much culture and rules was fab.

Must see in Hanoi. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, as well as the adjoining houses and complex where Ho lived are well worth a visit. I did not go inside the Mausoleum, though, as it was packed with visitors, but it is a stunning architectural design, not unlike Mao's in Beijing
Beautiful. A great place where families gather during the early evening and impressive lighting at night.

A worthwhile experience. I went here due to pure fascination after reading about it in various guides. Unfortunately I didn't really get a good view of Ho Chi Minh as they line you in in twos, and I happened to be on the outer edge of the two. This position meant I couldn't simply, respectfully, take a look. I had to be a fool and try to look around other peoples heads. This is especially awkward as you are expected to keep moving and, well, who wants to put themselves out there like that when the Vietnamese are so incredibly dignified? It's a disservice.In any case, I am glad I went. It was a side of the Vietnamese I had not encountered in my month stay and it's something that I really valued.

Interesting but short. You get very limited time and aren't able to stop, the guards usher / politely shove you past but it is obviously worthwhile nonetheless. The visit to the mausoleum is free, and you're made to leave your bags at the entrance for collection later, but if you don't then pay to go on to the part that follows the mausoleum it is incredibly hard to get your bag back - be warned! We were told to leave the compound then walked around the block several times trying to get information on how to get back in / collect our things with very little help from any guards.

Military precision. Over crowded - not for me, the thing i enjoyed the most was watching the well behaved very young school children lining up for the viewing, would have been totally lost without a guide to run us through the protocol

A surprise visit. This was not on our original itinerary, but due to the weather(rain) it was added on. Worth the visit as the queue was not long. Wouldn't bother in hot weather or long queue. You're only inside for 5mins.
is he wax?. Nice an d cool inside, but come prepared to cover shoulders and legs since skimpy clothes are not allowed. Uncle Ho looks like he's made of wax.
well you have to go. It is worth going just to observe the crowds and the ensuing silence when entering the mausoleum
Mausoleum Vist a Must. A Step back in history. Do not worry about the long lines. I only takes a short time to vist the Mausoleum
Something worth seeing. This whole building is dedicated to one man. It's a worth a trip just to think about it.
A fascinating experience. In true military precision the guards kept visitors moving at a respectable pace. The visit was a fascinating experience.

Interesting but...... Great to understand how Uncle Ho fits into the entire Vietnam society/culture...but smacked of indoctrination and worship rather than just respect for an amazing leader of change. Highlight : Young school children all queued up hanging onto each other.....gorgeous. Veterans and their wives.... so lovely and welcoming....made us all seem like giants ! Tiny frames and stature but million dollar smiles !
Ho Chi Min's body lies in state.. The changing of the guards and actually seeing Ho Chi Mins's body perfectly preserved was quite interesting. The heat was a bit much.
Uncle Ho. Ho Chi Minh was very well preserved. He looked like a very dignified old Vietnamese man in his sleep.

Worth doing once. For the mausoleum we suggest an early start (arriving around 6am) to see the flag raising at the front of the tomb and then an opportunity to be near the front of the line to visit the mausoleum when it opens. If you decide to visit the mausoleum later in the day we have been advised that the waiting times can be up to 2 hours. The tomb itself is essentially a marble building holding a number of guards, a glass box and in that box - Ho Chi Minh.
Place you got to see.. Being in Hanoi!. Being in Hanoi this is one of the basic site you gotta visit. Though I can't say that we come all the way to Hanoi to see this. Hah! Overall a nice experience!

Worth seeing. I was nervous when I saw numerous school groups as we had a tight timeline but it went very quickly.  They do a good job of ushering everyone through.  Here are a few tips:Cover up,  we didn't read about it anywhere but they made my husband sag his shorts so that went lower Don't bring a day bag.  They make you check any sort of backpack and finding where to pick it up isn't easy.  My day bag was an over the shoulder bag so I got to carry it in but we sawing sweaty tourists looking for bag pick up.  They make you check our camera as well but it waiting for you as soon as you get out.

Historically interesting. I guess everyone visiting Hanoi should experience a visit here, but be prepared for an extremely restricted, regimented experience. We had to queue up with masses of other tourists and there is very strict security (understandable I suppose) and everyone is moved through the actual mausoleum very quickly by several stern faced guards. All a bit over the top we thought. The building itself is also rather severe, in contrast to many other beautiful buildings in this fascinating city.
Very odd but interesting. We stood in line for about an hour to see Ho Chi Minh's body for about 2 minutes! It is rather peculiar but can understand why the Vietnamese revere him.

Something you have to do!. The line-up went on forever and we could only wonder what it was like in busier, and hotter, times. We were quite impressed by the number of people who patiently and very respectfully waited for a very quick glimpse of "Uncle Ho". Once in the chamber where his body is, guards move you through very quickly, taking your arm to propel you along - even when the person in front of you is just inches away. I was so focused on moving, that I barely looked over at the body - which all seems somewhat creepy anyway.

Super. The queues moved quickly and almost reverently into the mausoleum. The white uniformed guards provided the backdrop to the actual tomb of Uncle Ho. Walking around the three sides at a steady pace gave time to look upon this key figure in modern history and to reflect!

Strange. The mausoleum is impressive but it come across as strange that someone that stated in his last will to be cremated and thrown over north, middle and south Vietnam is put on display. Therefore his will was not honored.

An attraction with a difference. I am intrigued by this kind of thing and found the visit very interesting. It was amazing to see a person who died fifty years ago lying so peacefully and intact. You have to be very somber when walking past with arms by you side. I had my arms crossed in front of me and a guard nudged me and asked me to put my arms down. The guards here seem kind of tough, unsmiling. There were little kids who were brought in droves - preschoolers all lining up one behind the other, each hanging onto the shirt or skirt of the one in front. So cute. Although they were snickering and giggling outside once inside they too were amazingly quiet. You do have to be properly clothed - shorts for men are OK as long as it comes below the knee. Get there early to beat the crowds. The site is open only till 11 a.m.

Be a part of recent history. There is a great reverence from the locals for their uncle Ho. It is worth a visit if you have time to spare, but a long wait. The arrangements are a bit chaotic. No photos - just filing past the body

Jury's out on this one. Not sure what to make of this, queing up in regimental fashion with the poliburo police to see the body of Ho Chi Minh laying in state in a monolithic slab, I guess you need to be Vietnamese to really feel anything for this.

Ho chi minh in the morning. Only open in the morning. Very well organised by the officials. Suitably solemn, not macabre though. Great surroundings. Close enough to Temples of Literature, Koto and West Lake pagoda
A must see when you are in Hanoi. we did Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum when we took the Hanoi City tour with our Travel Agent and it was a wonderful place to see.Just one hour but good to see.

Be prepared to wait. We waited in line for about an hour. It is reasonably well organised and very clean. They expect visitors to show appropriate respect but it was worth the wait. Not sure if it is really Uncle Ho or a wax dummy!

Life time moment. It is well worth the line up for this. The line moves fast and is very orderly. While you are not in there for long....I would not have missed this....my friend cried when we got out...she was very moved.

An now for something a little different. Do not let the line-ups deter you from this solem moment, they move quickly. The value of the experience comes mostly from watching how people behave in these line-ups, from the sincerely devout to the school tours who would rather be elsewhere. In spite of all the warning signs, there are still those who attemp to bring in cameras and food past the vigilant guards all along the procession. It all very well managed. Oh yes, it is kind of eerie, seeing Ho Chi Minh lying there. The remainder of the grounds are well worth paying the extra dong to visit.
Worth the wait. Try not to visit when it is busy but this is one of the major tourist attractions in Hanoi, that should not be missed1

Historic must-see attraction. We came to the mausoleum first thing in the morning and only had to wait about 15 minutes to enter the complex. Cameras are not permitted inside the venue and there is quite a thorough security checkpoint.While seeing Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body was impressive, the experience was quite rushed as you are placed into single file and marched around the tomb. You can't stop and appreciate what you are truly experiencing in the 30 seconds you are allowed.Once leaving the mausoleum several other tourist attactions are very close including the presidential complex and the one pillar pagoda which had no queues. We suggest at least a brief understanding of Vietnamese history to fully appreciate the experience
couldnt find the entrance. we couldn't get inside to see anything which you can apparently go. it needs to be better signed. the building from the outside is very impressive and beautiful.

A definite must. We waited in line about 20 minutes to go in to see Ho Chi Minh. No entrance fee but make sure you wear appropriate clothing, no tank tops for women and long trousers are recommended for men. You walk around 3 sides of the room as you are able to look at his body in a glass case in the middle. He looks fairly ghostlike, very pale and waxy. The rest of the site wasn't very interesting but it seemed like in order to exit, foreigners had to pay 25,000 dong to go through it all to exit. It was a short visit but a definite must while in Hanoi.

serious checks before entering the inner mausoleum. Enjoy the hussle and buzzle around body and bag checks before visiting the mausoleum. Uncle Ho lies in a quiet peaceful surrounding with a dozen seriously looking soldiers around his corpse
Excellent. Most likely the highlight of the Hanoi visit...........very crowded but worth the wait to get in. Really appreciated the passion & believe of the Vietnamese people.

Don't go on Sunday. We took advise and arrived shortly after 8am.....still had to queue for an hour! It's free and the thing to do on a Sunday it seems. Lots of children, families, couples, young communist groups wearing red scarves on their day trip. Handbags are ok but anything larger has to be left at the entrance. Camera are deposited in a red bag at another check point and you collect them at the exit, very smooth really. We were allowed to keep our phones.The queue constantly shuffles along slowly but it is a long wait. The guards are very serious about you walking with hands by your side, no sunglasses, no talking. It's all a rather sterile experience. The grounds are rather lovely and the walk around the lake is pleasant afterwards. Breathe in the propaganda.
Standing outside a giant building. taking my photos and wishing I had done more research on this one. It wasn't open and I have to admit I still don't know if it ever is

Queued for a long time for a 30 second glimpse. The Queue was quite long. They divide you into groups and you are shuffled around in queues where they peridically take stuff off you. (Your bag first, all electronis sencond). Then you get hustled through the actual Mausoleum for about 30 seconds.

Two minute visit at most,. The guards are every where, seeing dead people isn't my cup of tea, but I went as part of a group, so the majority wanted to go here, the mausoleum is heavily guarded and watching the guards interested me more than the dead leader.
How could you miss this on a trip to Hanoi???. Kitchy but great local attraction. Get here early to get through quickly and avoid all of the kindergartners that are here to see Uncle Ho.

Uncle Ho's resting place. What an experience to see Ho Chi Minh kept in preservation and the reverence shown to the man by the Vietnamese People for his service to Vietnam.Be prepared to join a very long queue of hundreds of people for a walk by of Ho Chi Minh preserved in a glass case surrounded by very tight security, but it is worth it!!
wax or real. had to wait 40 minutes to get in so I could walk past his preserved body you have to be interested in this or it is a waste of time
moving. very stately. ho chi minh was truly a great leader and it was good to see him recognized as such. we wonder though how this very austere man would have felt about this whole complex for him.

Get there early!. Make sure you get dropped off behind the mausoleum on Ngọc Hà street and not in front of the mausoleum (where all the grass is) on Hùng Vương street. Check to see if the mausoleum is open before going and arrive at the Ngọc Hà entrace before 10am, no matter what your guide book or anyone tells you. We found out the hard way and went back a few times.

Paying homage to Uncle Ho. Unmissable - even the long queues and authoritarian regimentation are part of the experience. Mainly Vietnamese queue and you can see the veneration in which they hold Uncle Ho.
Must go. Open only till 11am. Worth a go. Tight security, so leave your stuff as you wont be able to bring them in. Very cold, dim... but you get to see Ho Chi Minh laying under the glow.

Go, pay your respects. Whatever, you do, don't laugh, don't smile and don't fold your arms. Bow your head, hold your hands solemnly and act respectful, failing which the white uniformed armed guards will jump on you, as my 14 yr old daughter discovered. However, that aside, it's worth the visit, you don't often get the chance to see an embalmed, long dead, great leader.

Must do in Hanoi. Went there as part of our guided city tour of Hanoi. They take all of your cameras and phones off you and you handbag if it is a large one. also backpacks etc. You then have to walk in two lines into the mausoleum. No talking, laughing etc. a very sombre place. You then walk up some steps(in 2 lines) then walk briskly past Uncle Ho, who is looking remarkably good for one who has bee dead for so long. Apparently he goes to Russia between September and November for a touch up each year. When walking past the guards also ensure you walk with your hands by your side. a word of advise- very cold in there so make sure you have a light jumper or cardigan. also, you must ensure you have shoulders and knees covered to be allowed in. so no tank tops and shorts but T. shirt is O.K and longer skirt, shorts or jeans. After filing past the coffin, you get to see where he spent the last few years of his life and view the outside of the presidential palace.

Interesting architecture. Very typical grand soviet style building, didn't go inside as wasn't that keen on seeing a man's remains. Be prepared to queue for ages and have bags handed in for security. Go covered up, shorts and t-shirts aren't considered respectful enough!

Interesting experience. The lines are long but they move quickly. Can't take in backpacks or cameras and have to leave them at two separate check points. Camera can be picked up at the exit but you have to walk all the way around to get your backpack again.

Mausoleum. If you are really interested in the life of Ho Chi Minh then go. Otherwise, it's just another militaristic examplar of extravagant funerary monuments. Could have missed this particular stop without regrets.
Viewed with respect. Showed how much the people of Hanoi revered their leader. The whole environment was pleasant and serene (probably because there weren't many crowds at the time when I visited).
Concrete grave. This building is just a concrete building that we never managed to get in to and we're not sure it's open to look in. Why he's got one I'll never know as he wanted to be cremated!
A must see. If in Hanoi please go to see this. It is amazing and well worth the effort

Weird but worthwhile. Only time I got a real sense of the seriousness of the "state". Strong and serious military presence. Remember to cover your shoulders and not wear short shorts or you won't get in. Uncle Ho looked pretty good for being dead for so long. Worth the experience.

Something Everyone Should Do. I was astounded by the crowds of people waiting patiently in line to pay their respects to this Vietnamese leader. We waited an hour and a half outside this gigantic mausoleum but it was something we felt we should do while in Hanoi. It gave us a sense of the adoration the people have, both in the past and ongoing, for this great man, Uncle Ho.
amazing to see, remember to wear respectable clothes. great to see, it gets very busy best to go at 8am when its alittle quietier. and remember its only open til 1030am

Overhyped but worth cultural experience. A deference to one exceptional man. This place is high security, no pictures inside and very strict. Worth the experience. Go on weekend to avoid a very crowded experience

Nice park and buildings. We did not visit the Mausoleum, but the nice and well-kept surrounding park and buildings. The place gives a very nice, calm and pleasant contrast to the general stress and noise of Hanoi.

Very weird experience but worthwhile. I had no idea what to expect when we visited, the 2 long lines of people being scolded by the guards and shushed was interesting, then before i knew it we were being ushered past the corpse. Does anyone else wonder if it is really him? the face is remarkable well preserved after so many years and batched in an ethereal light (I know he is sent off for 'maintenance' yearly but even so...)No cameras or bags allowed, luckily our tour guide was allowed to keep my camera in his bag, this seemed to satisfy the guards so I didn't have to go queue to deposit it and then to collect it. We went early and there was already a big crowd but the line moves very fast. By about 9:30 there were also big groups of local schoolchildren - I wish I had seen the guards try and keep them quiet :)

Uncle Ho resting. Long lines, followed by 30 second view of Uncle Ho. An interesting look into others culture. They respect this man, several vietnamese in line cried when they saw him. He is heavily gurarded, and yhou have to follow strict rules. You must wear pants and no hands in pockets

If you blink you'll miss it. The line moves quickly, don't forget to check in your camera, dress respectably and each to their own when it comes to time spent here. The viewing of Ho Chi Minh's body was quick and you really need to take it all in with such short time.Then you can take your time viewing where he lived etc. It's pretty and interesting. Go early so it's not too crazy with tourists.

An interesting experience - definitely worth the long wait!. I would say this is one of the highlights of my experiences in Hanoi and something not to be missed! My husband and I got there about 10:00am. I would advise getting there much earlier. There were a lot of people being dropped off in coaches. We queued for about 45mins. You must dress sensibly to enter - no low tops or short skirts. (We witnessed two woman being turned away because of the way they were dressed!). Large bags and backpacks were not allowed inside the mausoleum and cost us about 10,000VND to check in at the office. No water or cameras were allowed. We first had to go through airport type security - bags had to be put through a scanner and each person had to walk through a metal detector. As we got closer to the building itself it was all quite formal, like a military operation! We had to walk single file, in silence and all hands out of pockets. There were many guards with rifles by the entrance and inside. They were checking everyone in the queue and making sure we kept quiet. We had to walk through the building at a slow pace without stopping. It was very cold inside and you get a very odd feeling seeing Ho Chi Minh's actual body laying there in a glass coffin. There were 4 men in each corner of the coffin guarding his body. Complete silence! You were only in the room with the body for about 20 seconds but overall it was definitely worth the long wait and I would recommend it to everyone visiting Hanoi. The whole thing was an interesting experience!

Amazing architectural structure. The waiting in line is a bit annoying and going inside the mausoleum to see the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh is a bit of a non event for me but getting close to see this incredible monument makes it all worthwhile. Big, powerful building that impresses as soon as you see it.

Take in the whole experience. I would say queuing to see HCM's body is definitely part of the experience, and actually it does not take that long to get inside the mausoleum. Take time to stroll around the gardens while you are there, and to take a look in the museum.

Hanoi experience. A good visit just to know you've experiened it. I found it more fun and interesting exploring how he lived, the cars he drove supplied by the Russians, and the simplicity of it all than I did of the rushed visit the pushy guards at the Mausoleum.
A Word of Advise. When the Guards are marching, you may take pictures but do not stand close to anyone of them as they may scold you.

long queue, fast done. If you like it a bit morbid, this is the right place to go. Don't worry about the queue, everything is well organized and one moves fast. Be prepared to leave phones and cameras at certain check points as you cannot take pictures inside the mausoleum.

Intense. We had a great student guide who showed us around the complex in return for a bit of help with her english. The mausoleum itself was a little too intense for me with all of the military around.
Nice from the outside. No recommended to make the huge queue to see (in 20 seconds) the Ho Chi Minh's body. Really nice from the outside but nothing more.

Long Lines, Brief Glimpse. I got there late (10:15) and waited in line for over 30 minutes. No water nor cameras are allowed here, and you will have to check them in. Everyone walks through in two lines, everyone is silent, and you must keep moving. The tomb itself is nothing special, but marching through the mausoleum is an odd experience.

Waste of time. You are only allowed inside for 30 seconds not near ho chi minh, the grounds are nice but not the actual viewing. Go to the museum and walk around the grounds don't bother to queue for two hours to see.

Worth the visit. Visiting the HCM Mausoleum and noting the reverence for HCM was a perfect ending to our trip. I know want to learn more about HCM and this country's history. Westerners in shorts and skimpy clothes were dispicable, so glad the rules forced them to cover up. The Mausoleum closes at 11:30 so go early. There is no charge.
Looong wait. Get here early in the day to avoid a long wait. Everything is held up by people not reading signs of what they can and can't take with them.
Interesting. Wish we could have seen more. Was a bit intimidating and there were no signs to say if we could go anywhere like around back.

Be informed. The security is very tight and you will not be allowed to carry cameras or a backpack bag or even a water bottle. Be within the timings allowed so that you could store them.... However cameras and bags are not an issue out side the mousolem..

Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. The process of getting into the mausoleum can be lengthy. We waited ~2 hours before entering the mausoleum and before that went through 2 security screenings and surrendered our camera. All of that for maybe 10 seconds to see the embalmed Ho Chi Minh. Still, an interesting thing to say you did.

Ambience plus. We lined up with tourists, locals and Vietnam's visitors for more than 30 mins before we entered the Mausoleum and even though Ho Chi Minh hasn't been a significant part of our lives here in Australia, we did indeed feel very much in awe when we viewed this much loved man in Vietnam. The complex is vast and very interesting. Worth the visit, especially at the beginning of our Vietnam holiday. Go early though.
Educational. View the imposing mausoleum (ensure your shoulders and knees are covered) and visit his stilt house and the One Pillar Pagoda. All part of learning about Vietnam's culture.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The lines getting into this place was astounding, but it was worth the wait. The queues moved fairly quickly considering there are thousands people lining up for a five minute view. The changing of the guard is good if you time it right. Overall well worth a visit.
Well air-conditioned!. Well - I finally saw Uncle Ho.... looks OK..as he did on the stamps I collected 50 years ago! The security is paramount and the experience is well worth the trip to see him.

Odd but really interesting. You will need to walk for a mile to get into the mausoleum, but once you get there it is really interesting. Simply because you see Ho Chi Minh lying like he is only taking a nap. It was a really odd experience, but a definitely a "must do" in Hanoi.

Long Lines. The line was long but I enjoyed (enjoyed?) the experience of standing in line very politely and waiting my turn as the line snaked (eventually) past Uncle Ho's body. Guards will ensure you obey the rules. No talking. No hands in your pockets. Keep up to the person in front of you. No doddling. What I would call an ... experience.
Impressive Mausoleum. If you're in Hanoi for a few days and have run out of ideas its worth checking this place out. Not spectacular but very interesting and very well kept.

A must see if your are in Vietnam. A vietnamese could not imagine being in Hanoi without paying a visit to the HCM mausoleum. The mausoleum itself is impressive, and also the seriousness of the guards who ask you to take hands out of your pockets. It is nice combined with a visit to the adjacent museum, which explains this important part of Vietnam history

Just plain weird. I know that I shold be more respectful, but to stand in a long line to filter through multiple security guards getting pissy if you bring your hands up (they must stay at ones side) to walk quickly past what appears to be a sleeping wax figure lined by guards who make certian you do not even pause for a moment to look at the dead guy, I guess it is on the bucket list but the lines to see this guy are amazing, that is the more interesting part- there must have been thousands if vietnamse children in school uniform filing past! The park is austere and the monument is supposed to be a lotus flower (I cannot even think how?) Go because it is on the bucket list but do not expect much
