Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Long lines, but moved swiftyly.When you do finally arrive at his body lying in state you are quickly rushed through (but that was fine with me).

communist adoration at its best. wait in line for an hour for a two minute loop around the preserved, yet well-lit, body of ho chi minh. keep your hands out of your pockets and your mouth shut. extremely weird.
Pretty cool to walk by Ho Chi Minh's taxidermied body!. They collect all your goods and cameras and you have to retrieve later. Still cool to see this leader's stuffed body!
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It takes a long time to get wait in the queue before entering the mausoleum. It can be confronting and sad, but I think it is worth a visit.
Unusual but interesting. Went here with know knowledge of what we was going in for amd after found out more history. Strange but good experience, worth seeing!!

nothing to watch if you have been to Lenin's mausoleum. I have been living in Moscow my whole life and at least monthly pass across Lenin's mausoleum (though never been inside), so I was surprised only by the size of HCM's - but nothing beautiful in it.. Looks as our countries had a competition which one will be bigger (and no doubt - HCM's is bigger :))

Is it Real?. An awful lot of security around this. No talking you told by the guards to be quiet. They stand around his body which to be honest looks like a statue. We were told by the guide that they do not know for sure if it his body or not.

Surreal. Though there was a lengthy queue to see the 'sleeping' Uncle Ho, it was well worth it simply because it was an utterly unique experience. The mausoleum has the aura of the sacred - no photographs allowed, arms must be held at your sides (not in front of the body), and there is no stopping on entering the mausoleum, just a very quick walk around the 'display' before being ushered out.Despite queuing for 20 minutes for a 10 second view of Ho Chi Minh, the experience overall is what this is really about - a terrific glimpse of how revered this figure is in North Vietnam.

What an experience!. Just teh grandeur and seriousness of the Mausoleum is worth the trip, but then to actaully see Uncle Ho is almost sureal. If you grew up during the 70s this is an amazing experience. We learned so much more about Ho Chi Minh that I also have a new respect for him.

Grand. The mausoleum is very impressive and well kept. The area calls for respect. In all my trips to Vietnam I have never had the opportunity to go inside the mausoleum to see the body of Ho Chi Minh, I believe you have to be there on certain days and at very specific hours.

This was planned for us not really my scene. I didn't not like it very morbid. When you see the grounds and residences and look at the poverty on the streets it made me very sad to see this, but that is the nature of the country and the way and what people have to believe in. So I really cannot say anymore

Be respectful!. The process of queuing etc. was not too bad but they tend to target westerners and some other eastern nationalities, with confiscations of cameras, mainly due to concerns about on-adherence to on-photo rules.. Just take out your memory card and the process of getting your camera back is very efficient. The process of having the Guard supervising the huge number of viewers is not really intimidating when you consider that it is an open coffin of a Natonal Hero.

An Experience. Just for experience to see Uncle Ho at rest was amazing. He is so revered by all in Vietnam it was great to pay our respects. Some may have a different views but it is worth the wait in line.

Keep off the grass..... Uncle Ho as he is lovingly called, isn't looking so good anymore. It is that pasty, glistening embalmed look that comes with decades of touch-ups. However, Lenin in Moscow has a few more years on Uncle Ho. When visiting: wear clothes as ordered, follow the lines, do not stray onto the grass, keep your hands at your side, take off your hat, take off your sunglasses, check your camera, pick up your camera hopefully where you left it, no laughing, no talking, keep up with those ahead of you, 10 seconds of looking, get going.

Very unique. Good experience other than seeing a dead body Ho Chi Minh, we can see how Vietnamese respect and proud of Ho Chi Minh.It was a long long queue and we needed to spend an hour for seeing less than 5 minutes.

Long queues, officious guards and a short view. OK it is obvious that 'Uncle Ho' is the perpetual figurehead of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam but I'm not sure if this is what he wanted. The queue, even early in the day, was long and tedious. The guards are extremely officious and controlling re what they regard as disrespectful behaviors and when you get inside the mausoleum the viewing of Ho Chi Minh is relatively short and also a bit difficult due to the lighting being just a little low. Yes this is a significant place for Vietnamese but can't help thinking it is a bit overdone. Worth going through to see the gardens and buildings of the Presidential palace.

Not so interesting for the mausoleum itself but for the cult around. I think all guided tours in Hanoi have this mausoleum as a stopping place, so what will you get. The mausoleum itself is a stone block no big architectural moment here, a mixture of soviet realism and greek temple in style. Inside there is Ho Chi Minh lying in a sacophag and you can see him pretty good. Unless you are a fan of him, nothing very impressive, in the end it is just a dead man. What is fascinating is the cult around it. Not only tourists are driven there by the busload, also huge amounts of vietnamese people come her, a lot organized and the minorities in their local custom. (they get priority access) The queue does moove pretty fast, you have to check all your belongings (cameras, bags and so on). Outside and inside soldiers will guard the place and they make sure you have even your hands in the correct way. All in all a good way to feel the dedication and admiration directed toward Ho Chi Minh.

Hanoi must see.. Vietnam is ,of course, a communist country, but the only time I felt this was when visiting the Ho Chi Mausoleum. Think big parade ground, with huge red flag over it, Military presence in pristine white uniforms, overseeing standards of respect and decorum in the lengthy queues, and flanking the embalmed remains. If you don't see this you may just miss a fundamental part of the country that is not too evident elsewhere, but pervades things in a way we maybe don't get to see. Note the coachloads of orderly children from all over the country in disciplined crocodiles, but also perhaps notice the teenagers nearby with their smart phones and skinny jeans etc and wonder where it will all be in 10 years time.

Unique but Long Queue. Very very long queue to have a brief 10seconds look but a unique experience to see who they call Uncle Ho. Be aware you need to wear something they deem respectful. Something below the knees and covering your arms despite the weather. Worth the visit but go earlier as they cut off the line at a certain time. Don't step out of line or you will know about it!
Eerie. Somehow we went there on a Saturday, and walked right up and thru the mausoleum. Guards walk you up and thru. We had almost a private tour. Seeing body was eerie.
Worthwhile. There was a line up to enter the mausoleum but the ushers were efficient in moving the crowd. Pay attention to boundry markings.

Visited each time I arrived in Viet Nam. Each time I have visited, several people ask me where I am from......(The US). Then the smiles come. I have never felt any hostility. The lines may be long but they move quickly. Cameras are prohibited. Each time, I have "checked it" my camera with no issues. You will see deep reverence by Vietnamese.

Interesting experience. We visited the Mausoleum one morning and were amazed to see the wonderful structure, the pristine surrounding area and the efficiency of the staff working there. Every bag was thoroughly checked at the entrance, water and any electronic item that could capture pictures were placed at the security post near the exit of the mausoleum. People were filed in a single row and requested to show adequate respect for their departed President. As you walk through the high ceiling room one after the other without stopping you can understand the affection of the people of Vietnam for the gentleman lying in state. As you exit the mausoleum, you can collect your cameras/phones and proceed to the other attractions within the complex such as Uncle Ho's house, one pillar pagoda etc. Must visit when in Hanoi

Glad I went to see this!. Ho Chi Minh had such an impact on Vietnam and on world history, so I don't think a stop in Hanoi would not be complete without visiting the mausoleum and palace area. Try to get there at 8am to avoid the tour groups and to get in line to surrender your camera. Some of the waiting area before you enter to see his body is air-conditioned, so that's a relief if you've been waiting outside in line.

Not easy to get in to. The llines move quickly but can be intimidating. The Mausoleum is only open for a few hours each day. Ho Chi Minh is lying in state (and has been for 30 yeara) and it is interesting to see him, however all you are doing is filing pass him with the rest of the crowd. I would not include this if my time was limited. You can walk around the outside and visit the gardens and his residence next door.

Should include on your list to see in Hanoi. The building and grounds are very well maintained, secured, very nice. It's very organized, so even if there's a long line of crowd it went very quickly. You cannot bring your camera inside the Mausoleum.

Interesting to see the man. You are marshalled into a line and go through security. Then you merge with other lines. The school children chatter and wave but quieten down as they get closer to the mausoleum. Decorum and dignity must be observed throughout and the soldiers will ensure that you do exactly as they wish. Once you are inside, tere is no stopping and you are back out of the mausoleum in no time. Whatever your politics or previous experiences, it can be interesting to set eyes on this man from recent history.

Vietnam's George Washington. Whatever your political views, it's important to understand Ho Chi Minh from the perspective of the (North) Vietnamese people. To them, he's George Washington and Abraham Lincoln rolled into one. His mausoleum is a national shrine, containing his embalmed body on display, flanked by guards.Proper respect is the rule, and a degree of solemnity is expected. Well worth the 30-45 min. wait in line.

Hurry up and wait. Maybe I chose a bad day but there was a lot of queuing involved to wait for the moment we were shoved (I mean ushered) past the tomb of the great Ho Chi Minh. It's a (free) must do thing for a visit to Hanoi and can be followed up with a visit to the presidential complex and the museum for a bit more of a background on this interesting, if overly revered, leader (both 25000VND each).

Another must do in Hanoi.... A must do, how could you come all is way and not line up with the other thousand people to file through the building and see the dead guy himself? The guards will usher you in single file, prod you if you step out of line and usher you out the otherwise in a matter of seconds, but, worth doing it. Be prepared to leave you camera with the guards, but you will get it back on the otherside of the mausoleum, system works quite well. The area around is nice to check out too. Don't step foot on the grass whatever you do!!

Not What I Expected. I've never been very interested in seeing the bodies of past "Dear Leaders," (despite having spent a lot of time in Beijing, I've never been to see Mao's body), but this kind of blew me away. The atmosphere is so reverent, and you walk so close to the body, that it's really an amazing experience.
Mausoleum. Was a really excellent experience. Much better than expected and worthwhile visiting.
Also a much recomended place to visit. The waiting and queing are a bit long considering the mere minutes you are allow to view uncle Ho
a remarkable story. Be prepared to line up and be prepared to leave cameras and mobile phones, as no photos of Uncle Ho are allowed.The guide was excellent.

Is it really him?. If in Hanoi this is a must do. Along with thousands of local children we joined the very long queue at around 7.45am to visit the Mausoleum. Although the queue was long it did not take long to meander our way to the viewing which took a minute or two to do. Everyone is marshalled at a pace to ensure every one is moved on in the few hours this venue is open. During the winter months it closes at 11am.Although the embalmed Uncle Ho looks more like a Madame Tussauds waxwork he is guarded by many servicemen in pristine white uniforms. It is hard to believe he has been dead since 1969 but with so little time to view it was impossible to absorb the importance of this man and to decide if it really is him.

the queue. We joined the queue to get into the grounds of the mausoleum and then joined to queue to file past Uncle Ho's body. The experience was good in that while we were queueing we watched the army marches and routines, and watched as other tourists were told to take their ands out of their pockets and be more respectful as they filed past the body. The man behind us (a local Vietnamese tourist) burst into tears as if he couldn't come to terms with Ho Chi Minh's death - he is obviously still very loved. I was glad we went, it was an experience I won't forget, and, even in death, he looks a very kind man.
Fine. You are ushered through and watched the entire time. The grounds are nice.

A serious business. After visiting many Ho Chi Minh Museums, it was an interesting experience to queue to see the man himself. Even the many groups of young school children behaved with decorum, not that the teahers gave them much choice.

A must for Vietnamese Students, but for Tourists?. Every morning a long queue forms purchasing tickets, to then being marched through the mausoleum, getting a glimpse of Ho Chi Minh in his glass sarcophagus. Annoying is that all bags have to be deposited at a security check point prior to the march, and retrieved thereafter, before being able to visit other attractions in this complex.

Great place if you are into keeping persons mumified against their last wishes. guess if you are sightseeing in Hanoi, this is the place you have to go. Being from Estonia maybe I am bit biased with respect to such memorials, if you see one mausoleum of communist leader, you have seen them all... The area where the centre is located is very different from normal Hanoi city scene, grand french built well kept buildings that now house different embassy's.
Huge and imposing. Built against the wishes of the modest, undisputed national hero, but should be seen when in Hanoi.

Gives an insight into the Communist Mindset of the Vietnamese. While in Vietnam (and especially in Saigon/Hoi An) you often forget that you are in a Communist country. Hanoi reminds you of that. In fact when we landed at the airport, we thought we had landed in Pyongyang (North Korea) instead of North Vietnam. The mausoleum is part of that experience and helps you understand the psyche of the people. The military discipline and the bureaucracy are to be seen.
Not to be missed. A historic and dramatic experience but check times as you need to go AM and it is not open every day

fantastic museum. A visit to this museum is well worthwhile. It often has really good temporary exhibits and the style and layout are different to other museums. I have been a number of times and always enjoy it. Even if I go for a new exhibit, I still enjoy looking at the permanent displays.

On the plus side entry is free. Very strict,very poorly sign posted and a long walk out of the city,very touristy I.e Chinese etc and very unwelcoming and rude to westerners,if you are a westerner and female be sure to cover up as much as possible but obviously not to look foolish,quite a lot of pointing and staring by tourists of Chinese appearance and also by Vietnamese police making the whole experience very uncomfortable but I can say Iv seen it now at least and as the title says "on the plus side "it's free!

Ushered n guarded. The area is extremely guarded and the many security gates one goes through makes me wonder why.
Anyhow,it was a different experience.
It worth the trip I suppose

This is history. Whatever you think, the Vietnamese revere this person, and you can see his body (maybe). Surely a piece of history. See the lowering of the flag at 9:00 each night. Complete with military music and marching. A treat!

Interesting visit !. I found this strange as visits go ! I have never been to a mausoleum and witnessed a body laying in state.The cue always looks long, but dont be put off by this, it moves at a good pace.Also make sure you go very early as to avoid the majority of people, but to also note that it also closes at 10.30 am ! so no time to hang around !

A surprise to see Ho Chi Minh in the flesh. Strangely, we were dumped by our guide here to queue up and leave all our bags, phones, cameras and water (yes, even bottled water!). We didn't know what to expect so we just lined up. Along the way, there were uniformed guards who shushed us. No talking, no putting your hands into your pockets. Then we came to a room where the aircon was significantly colder, and there he was…Ho Chi Minh in the flesh and he looked like he was sleeping in a glass and wooden, carved coffin. Four uniformed guards were around his coffin and these guards change shift every 2 hours. He is under 24 hour guard duty! He was very well preserved and you could see that his cheeks were plump and not sunken at all. You could see his fine hair. Imagine, he has been lying in this state since 1975! Apparently, the Vietnamese learned the technique of preservation from the Russians, as they had also preserved Lenin.A must see, even if the whole thing just takes 10 minutes. You're not allowed to stop and ogle!

Ok been there bought the t shirt......now back in the real world.. A brief glimpse of the strict controls imposed upon the Vietnamese by the ruling communist regime, prior to filing past the body and exiting mightily relieved that the next days trip will be to the airport and back to freedom of speech.

A Truly Surreal Experience. It's worth a visit just to go through the rather bewildering experience leading up to the viewing of his body. After being investigated thoroughly and leaving all electronics behind, I felt like I should have been boarding a plane, but no, it's a dead body this is for. The experience increases in oddness when I'm told to 'shhh' very abruptly by a man, in a uniform, with a gun: I feel like I'm on a school trip and my (scary) teacher is telling me off (but for coughing rather than laughing). 'Don't tell me to "shhh"', I thought, 'I'm an adult!' But the respect Uncle Ho is remembered with in Vietnam is unimaginable. It's a bit like the way Americans remember JFK. The body itself was cool to see, but you are not alowed to stop to look so it's more of a fleeting glance than a good investigation of the beard. Look out for his garage of cars afterwards, that also struck me as a bit odd, but at the same time, wonderful!

Its different. We got there early in the morning before the queues formed and there was a solemn respectful air from all people. Lots of security which helps give a feel of importance to the country of Vietnam. The rest of the area is a welcome oasis of peace and quiet from the noise and bustle of the rest of the city.

Fascinating. The process of getting into the building is as much part of the experience as seeing the maintained body. You really get to see how strict the government is and how much they love their former president. Worth the visit, but make sure to be there before 10:30a.m.

Big old stone building. I guess you should see it but it's a huge building with a parade gound in front and gardens behind. It is guarded by a special group of young military guards. Worth a glance on the way to Ho Chi's residence so not really off the beaten path.
He is still there. Big groupe of people waiting to see his body. It is like seeing Lenin's tome. The same people did the preserving of the body.
A historic must. Very interesting insight into this period of the history of vietnam

WEIRD. We didn't know what to expect. You follow single file past loads of guards and you are told to keep your hands by your side of your body. No talking. Then you pass through a room and there he is lying in state embalmed!
worth the hype. must see if you go to Hanoi, just the prodcution to get into the place is worth the time

Hard to See Ho Chi. I was really looking forward to seeing the Mausoleum but unfortunately the visiting hours are limited and I didn't get to go inside. It is an impressive looking building, and still worth seeing from the outside. Make sure you check the opening hours!

Confused..... Went to the Mausoleum and was very confused with the layout and how to actually get in. Was ripped off by a local taxi to get there and on arrival had to hand in my backpack. The staff at this bag checking area were extremely rude to my wife who is from South Vietnam. After that unpleasant moment, we went through the laughable security screening point...... from there, i had to drop off my camera into a funny read back (it did not fit) and leave it to be collected after the visit. Then walked into the mausoleum itself. It was interesting to see 'uncle ho'. After all of that i had to collect my camera and run back to pick up my backpack as the bag storage place was closing for lunch..... overall, pretty average and as the title says..... confusing

A must see. We arrived at around 8.45am on a Saturday morning and there were huge lines of people waiting, we thought we would be hanging around for hours but the line moved really quickly and it was no more than a 15 minute wait. Really is worth going to see. Be warned that the opening hours are very limited.

A feel of cold war. I guess it is a must see in Hanoi, although there is not so much to see actually. It is more the atmosphere, high security regulations, walking in a line past soldiers and then the monumental architecture of the Mausoleum.It can be reached by taxi within 20min from Old quarter.

Stately and solemn--very moving. This is a major attraction in Hanoi and should not be missed. There are long lines, which move well, that go past the embalmed Ho Chi Minh on a regular basis. It is a very moving experience to view this, Note--you have to check your camera and things like water before entering, but they are returned to you promptly after the visit to the mausoleum.

Prefer monuments to mausoleums. I have been to Lenin's mausoleum and now Uncle lHo's. Both suffer the same issues - there is a body lying in state and because I have no connection to the revolution, I was respectful but bored.
Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Very regimented, lots of guards. We all wondered why so many guards as the poor guy is dead and who would want to blow the mausoleum up!!! Its still great to see.
what an experience. very strict rules to be observed .much loved man by the people ,nice grounds lots to see such as hih house and cars and where he lived his last days

Fascinating cultural experience. The Mausoleum is located in a lovely area of Hanoi. It was a fascinating experience to line up for 40 minutes with tourists and locals alike to pay homage to" Uncle Ho". It gave ample opportunity to pause and reflect on the man and his contributuions and impact on Vietnam and the world.

Controlled visit. It was interesting to see the body of a famous person who died so long ago, but the visit was not particularly enjoyable as you were treated as inferior people who had to be made to follow the rules, keep quiet, walk in single file, keep moving, remove your hat, show respect to their great leader etc. We were happy to get out of there.

A Must Do. Despite the fact that you are basically staring at a dead body and despite the fact that embalming was strictly against Ho's wishes (he hated the personality cult so would probably be turning in his grave if theyd' buried him instead of embalming him!) the need to say you have visited the mausoleum is overwhelming. But remember to get there between 8am and 11 am because it closes after that. The queues can be long but they move quickly. You won't be allowed in unless you are dressed respectfully (no shorts, no exposed shoulders) and you have to leave cameras and mobile phones in a secure area. I am told that every autumn he is flown to Russia for maintenance so you may need to check that he is actually there when you visit. Finally, it is ironic that as you exit the mausoleum and make your way to the rest of the complex you are confronted by stall after stall selling Pepsi Cola - if only the Americans had waited 30 years they could have avoided a lot of trouble!

Incredible!. Oh my goodness! This place is incredible... Unfortunately we didn't get to go inside but even to walk past is phenomenal! In all honesty, I think we spent about 30 minutes just looking at it!! We were fortunate enough to run into a couple who had been and they said that it was just as amazing inside!

Eerie and too quick .... I loved seeingthe surrounding palace and gardens, but seeing the mausoleum was frustrating .. after a 3 hour queue, you are marched past Ho Chi Minh for a 10 sec view, which for me was not even enough time to pay respect ... remember to leave your camera behind as no photos allowed ...

Definitely "Should do". Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum is one of those places that isn't particularly mind blowing, but definitely should do if you are in Hanoi. The line looks long, but doesn't move too fast and you have to check pretty much all of your luggage and valuables. We didn't have a problem with the checking (I ended up having to check my bag with computer and expensive camera lens). Best is to get there early.
History Lesson. An interesting approach to one of Vietnam's defining moments in history; it was informative

Excellent but creepy. You get a 30 min cue to go to mausoleum and see the Ho Chi Minh body. Before hand they will remove your camera and will return it back at the end of the trip.You can't wear skirts or shorts showing off the legs. When getting near the body, avoid talking or steering to the guards near by, they will pull you off the cue. Also, you can't cross your arms or have hands in pockets.Its worth a visit
Make sure to know the open time. I couldn't go inside, because I forgot to check the time it stay open...

A unique experience. We had never before been somewhere to see a preserved body, and during the wait to get into the mausoleum you have a few minutes to really think about death and reverence. The walk through the mausoleum itself is silent and very controlled and you see Ho Chi Minh in a glass enclosure as you walk around a large room. It is interesting to see the formality of the guards in their white uniforms and to witness how much this site means to some of the visiting Vietnamese people.The palace and garden walk was worthwhile but we did not much enjoy the museum that seemed filled with random ephemera and strange installations.

A trip to the past. An atmospheric trip to the past. It takes about an hour to go around. Most tours starts at 8, so keep that in mind. Women should be dressed respectively (no skirts or shots are allowed). You should avoid talking and having your hands crossed as you walk by. The queue is huge, but it's worth waiting. After all moves quickly! You have to tell the taxi driver to let you at the right side of the mausoleum, otherwise you have to walk to the main entrance. What is more important after all is that you get the chance to see how the communist works (you can see MANY people doing all kind of simple works).

How many times did you get to see a dead hero?. If you have time you should do this - it is truly one of a kind. It closes at 11am - get there early as the line gets long. But the line moves very quickly - it was about 3 blocks long but it took approx 40 minutes. The people in line range from 6 yr old kids on school trips that love to yell 'hello' to old timers and of course tourists. The actual amount of time you actually see Uncle Ho is 30 seconds and once you are inside it is very serious. Cameras are checked in at security point (very easy to retrieve)' no hands in pockets, and I would not wear tank tops etc out of respect for their hero. I am glad I went but if I ever return I would not go back for second viewing.

Do not arrive on a Friday. The Mausoleum was closed to the public on Fridays so we only had a look outside. It was cold and raining the day we were there and there were plenty of people outside and locals milling around just as we were. We were told there are normally huge crowds so we were not so worried as we visited Ho's house.

Stern but worth it. Recommend this experience. It was so austere and respectful. Furthermore combined with the iconic reverence of Ho Chi Minh displayed everywhere I felt honored to be able to pay homage to such a national figure.

He is not well. Real step back into the communist era. With cues of vietmanese and a few foriegners wait to parade past the little chap. It is atmospheric and there were still a few locals in tears at the sight of him.

Surprisingly Moving. As it was on my tour list, I went to see Ho. I am glad I did. I found it an interesting experience to be in the presence of such a great man. He is very much loved and revered and after doing this visit, I can understand why.

Beautiful grounds. It is really interesting to see the man they respect and love so much. The grounds on the complex are stunning. Tips: Women dress conservatively they do not allow shorts and small strap tank tops.

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. We arrived at 8.40am!! the Queue was huge!! Our taxi driver dropped us out on the front side of the Mausoleum - where there is a massive expanse of grass and paths, however you are not allowed to walk over this, and we found ourselves walking approx 1km to get to the side entrance where people queued. Make sure your taxi drops you around the side!!! Although there were lots of people the line moved relatively quickly - we were through within 1 hour. Definite must see!! Make sure you get there early!!
it is one of the most interesting things in hanoi.. Just the whole idea of the mausoleum and all the people involved in the security etc makes a visit there worthwhile
Very Interesting and Insightful. Lovely artwork and well presented museum. A great eye-opener into Vietnamese culture and history especially during the war.

Worth a visit. The Mausoleum, Ho Chi Minh's private residence and the one pillar pagoda, all are situated in the same complex. It takes around a hour and a half to go around. The bugging aspect is the security check at the entrance. The procedure requires to be streamlined so that long queues are avoided.

Good, but have a Guide/Tour to Explain. Most tours start at 8am or 8:30am, and most will start at the Mausoleum. So even if you go early, you're going to wait in line with all the tour groups. All the tour groups have special connections with the people that allow entrance - what a surprise. Even tour groups will wait. If it's raining, be prepared to wait with your poncho. An hour or more - all to see about 45 seconds of Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body. This could mean a lot or little to someone without more history from a guide - such as that Ho Chi Minh never wanted to be embalmed or have a Mausoleum in his name but wanted to be cremated. I suppose it's still one of those tourist things you should do if you are in Hanoi.
A must see while in Hanoi.. Impressive soviet architecture in a city that is a mixed of french and Chino-Vietnamese architecture. Interesting for anybody who appreciates architecture.
Be prepared to wait. We waited for around an hour to get into the Mausoleum, well worth the wait though!

Dramatic and possibly a little macabre. It was a damp day slightly cold and I had my hand in my pocket was told off before entering - quite right - but it is an indication how glum and stern the guards are - which adds to the gravitas of the visit to view the mummified body.
Terrific. Great experience to join in and feel the love this nation has for this man. Big queues and long wait but amazing experience. Highlight of our day tour of Hanoi
expect long queues. well worth a look, but expect long queue'sgo early to avoid the worst queue length
majestic. we watched the change of the guards,typical comunist monument and majestic in his style.

MUST SEE. This was on my 'must see' list & I'm glad I went. The opening times are a bit of a pain (well a big pain actually!). The complex (which includes the museum & other buildings) closes at 11 am - not helpful. I got there just after 9 am so I had to rush round the museum at breakneck speed. It spoilt my visit. I didn't have another day to spare so I had no other choice.The Mausoleum was quite a spooky place with guards all over the place. It was definitely worth visiting but get there early!!

Statue-esque. The line-up doesnt take that long and its close to the HCM museum and also the warm museum, little pagoda, etc. so its worth a look, just to experience the system. Otherwise not much to it.

Worth Doing. The queue was almost non-existent and, apart from a coachload of loud Germans, the place was largey deserted. We filed through and had about 30secs to digest the scene. Rather spooky staring at the almost glowingly white complexion of "The Great Man" who may be a little peeved that his will requested cremation. I guess the numbers of visitors since his death may perhaps have proven that The Greater Good was served.If oyu are not into temples then this is the best Freebie in Hanoi. Don't bother with the museum though

Bizarre but Interesting. ..A visit to this site is quite a shock for a westerner. One realises the phenomenal degree of reverance that the Vietnamese hold for their former outstanding leader who played such an important part creating the country that Vietnam now is. Before you visit you will be advised as to appropriate etiquette and behaviour (respectful clothing, no noise, keeping your hands down etc when you enter the tomb). On arrival you will be taken aback by the level of security provided by dedicated guards in elaborate white uniforms with much gold braid who largely stand statue-like on each side of the single-file route you must follow. They will however challenge anyone wearing sunglasses or otherwise acting irreverently. You will then follow the slow moving queue past Ho Chi Minh's enbalmed body which even after 43 years shows no sign of deterioration. One thing a visit does is wet your appetite to find out more about the man himself. To see the wooden stilt house he lived his final years in, right next to the Mausoleum in the ornamental gardens, gives a revealing glimpse into the frugal life he lead. This has got to be worth your while to visit as it will surely be unlike anywhere else you've been.
Long lines - get there early. Be prepared to wait in line and make sure you are appropriately dressed.

only go if..... you need to be up early and fight with the masses. if you have done Lenin then don't bother. The VN revere Ho so it is interesting to see how they respond. the area is quite pleasant - one pillar pagoda nearby - botanic gardens at the back are also pleasant and very few foreigners go there.

Educational. It was educational to see how the Vietnamese regard Ho Chi Minh, the father of their country, somewhat as a cross between Ghandi and George Washington. Moving, with unusual emotions, viewing my countries one time adversary during the "American" war.

wow....totally weird. Very impressive building, quite freaky going in to see a dead body with very stern guards telling people off for laughing, having sunnies on head etc. Quite surreal and i wouldn't do it again!

Worth checking out. Quite spooky, but well worth the visit. His body has been preserved immaculately. Just make sure you stay very quiet when your in the room otherwise you may find one of the guards bayonets in your face!!!
Wax doll. Like for Lenine or Mao, you have to pass by the relic. Many people say that the mummie is in fact a wax doll, easier to maintain.

Spooky but interesting experience. I loved the mausoleum and the weird experience of watching the communist leader, who strangely enough had made it clear that he did not want to be glorified and embalmed.I now need to add Mao and Lenin to my 'collection'.

Nice place. It's nice to go there and feel the 1960ies Soviet influence of Vietnam. Don't waste your time peeking at the wax doll! Try it early in the morning at 5:00 am to see 2000 people running and doing their exercice.

Very educational. The whole experience was very good with everything presented
in A1 condition both buildings & grounds. A lot of history.
nice. nice but I am not into history, but I like to watch guards change.

disappointing. After going through a failry rigorous security process--no cameras and no backpacks allowed---i was quite disappointed by the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Although it was stunning to see the man, so revered by the Vietnamese people as a ''hero'', the 10 second walk around Minh's resting place was a waste of time, especially on a busy itinerary. After being quickly ushered in with many other tourists, and hushed by the anxious security guards, this 'visit' to the Minh Mausoleum wasnt as incredible an experience as i thought it would have been. However, walking the rest of the grounds was a bit more interesting, where one can see the House where Ho Chi Minh resided for a few years, as well as his unique car collection.
Historic. This was free to the mausoleum, small queue moved quickly, all quite dignified and respectful. Small entrance fee to the museum which was moderately interesting.
Dead guy, time consuming. Mondays closed!Open until 11 am be there at least an hour before to be sure to get in.

Worthwhile visit. Understanding that seeing a preserved body is perhaps not for everyone and arguably a bit creepy, the Mausoleum is an important site for the Vietnamese. Even more valuable than actually viewing the body is the whole experience of making your way through the park while guards march and maintain the silent reverence with which people are supposed to view Uncle Ho.

Surreal Experience. Definitely worth a visit. It's very surreal, and fleeting. You aren't allowed to linger by Uncle Ho's body as one of his many guards ushers you along, but it's an experience not to be missed. You aren't allowed to take large bags or cameras in with you, but there are areas you can leave them for free. You have to dress respectfully (knees and shoulders covered).

Very picturesque.. About a 30 minute walk from the old quarter (definitely walk), the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is quite grand. Situated in a park, this large monument definitely gives you an experience. You are actually even able to enter the mausoleum from early in the morning till 11am. The Mausoleum is also close to the Ho Chi Minh Museum and the 1 piller pagoda. So like I said, it is a nice walk over there and you have plenty to see in one spot.
a must see. get here early to avoid huge lines, a great experience to visit ho chi minhs body and see how sacred he was and still is to the vietnamese people.

Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum well worth visiting. Ho Chi Minh's resting place, an impressive mausoleum in Hanoi, is well worth a visit, but be warned - get there early as thousands of Vietnamese families begin lining up from about 7am. You'll be required to leave your camera for safe keeping as you join the queue (no photography is allowed in the mausoleum) but it will be waiting for you several hundred metres away when you leave the mausoleum. It's a very efficient service .Depending what time you arrive, it can be a long, slow walk in the queue to reach the mausoleum. Make sure you time your visit with the changing of guard which is a spectacle in itself. Make sure you watch the older members of the families explaining to the children what they're seeing. Their reverence is amazing and it's common to see people crying as they walk around the glass tomb.Nearby is a museum on Vietnam's history and Uncle Ho's house, which features outstanding use of timber. The gardens near the mausoleum are a great respite from the heat. On the way back to Hanoi stop and look at the infamous Hanoi Hilton in the old gaol and get more information on the country's history.

HCM Mausoleum. We have been in Vietnam for a little over 2 week and visiting this place was the first and only time we have felt like we were in a Communist country. It was so regimented and very little freedom of movement was allowed. No stepping out of line, walking single, then double file, every movement was controlled. Lots of soldiers everywhere all looking resplendent in sparkling white uniforms; but put a foot wrong and who knows how they'll react. Even outside on the street, everyone could only take pictures from way back and far away.HCM was a very tiny man!
Interesting Experience. It is a restricted area - there is a lot of controls and guards - where to walk, what to take into the museum, and need to remain silence while in the building itself.
Long queue but not a long wait. Just be careful not to walk on the little concerete pathways in front of the Mausoleum. This results in shrill whistle blasts and angry shouts from policemen!!

Not really worth it. This may sound bad as I'm talking about seeing a persons body, however - militant staff are not friendly and you are forever being told off for walking on the grass, walking on the pavement, being told to empty your pockets - don't put your hands in your pockets etc etc etc. When you get in eventually, you are ushered along and in all honesty, its all a bit freaky. Ho Chi Minh didn't even want to be embalmed!

Strange experience but it is what it is. Went to the mausoleum while in Hanoi and it was a very strange, experience. Queued up to enter but it went very quickly - you need to put any bags in the left luggage area but my small rucksack was just tied up with an elastic band and the water taken out - we had to throw that away. Then about a 5 minute walk to the mausoleum itself (no talking and single file). Visiting the interior actually took about 1 minute - four guards around the sarcophagus and a constant stream of people going through. Then when you get out you can go to see Ho Chi Minh's house (quite interesting - 10,000 dong) and the Museum. We took a taxi to the mausoleum and it cost about 25,000 dong from the centre.

Amazing and surreal experience. What an incredible experience to see this character from history at peace in his Mausoleum. Very humbling witnessing the VIetnamese people who obviously have much love and affection for 'Uncle Ho'. Well worth the 30 minute queue.

uncle ho's resting place. the whole experience was disagreeable; from the guards at the outset who forced you to go through their security, then the fact that you were brusequely forced to hand in your camera at a checkpoint furthest away from where you're lining up to go in, and you are then rushed to go through the whole visit. an unpleasant experience altogether.
Well one dead body is very similar to another. It is probably part of the things to do but one could give it a miss.

Worth a visit to see the on going Communist tradition on display of the guards. This is so like Red Square and other traditional communist displays for their revered leaders. I loved the flags , hammer and sickles and guards with their whistles being blown vigorously at those silly enough to walk in the wrong direction, like me.
Respect for Uncle Ho. The reverence and love that they give to Ho Chi Minh is remarkable.

pretty interesting view of Vietnamese culture. It is worth going, as you will hear so much about Ho Chi Minh during your trip in Vietnam. Make sure you don't bring your camera, otherwise you will have to leave it behind during the visit! Oh and you may feel like at the airport when you arrive, bottles of water are thrown away and you have to go through a metal detector!

Pleasantly surprised. They did a pretty good job in "presenting" this mausoleum. I was expecting it to be morbid just like the mummies in Egypt but I was presently surprised. Ho Chi Minh's body appears to be simply sleeping. If you are lucky enough, you can also witness the changing of the guards.
Away. Have only been in Hanoi when the ' Great Leader' is away - need I say more. Will keep trying

Worth a look. Slightly creepy but worth going. Make sure you arrive early and line up in the right place. Tour groups have a tendancy to arrive at the last minute and waltz in infront of everyone. You have to walk quickly when you are there or you will be shouted at! Great experience.
Brief walk in and out. You walk in, see the gentleman's dead body and walk back out, this is pretty much it. If you're not particularily interested in Ho Chi Minh's life you won't really care.
Pretty impressive. Great morning walk, make sure you head there early to beat the massive crowds and the place closes around mid day so they can most likely sterilize and deep freeze Ho Chi Minh

Solemn place. It was the first mausoleum I´d been to and was amazed by all the security measures you have to go through in order to get in. Although you get to see Ho Chi Minh´s body for just a few seconds it is worth it.
By itself a little quick. But worth visiting the rest of the museum - you are shuffled past Ho Chi Minh so quickly that it's almost difficult to register. However - well organised and v respectful.
Ho Chi Ming sleeping here. You can see Ho Chi Ming's embammed body here, a nice monument and a once in a life time opportunity to see this historic personality, seen as alive

First thing to see while in Hanoi but check your dates.... The Communist presence is palpable in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh is a legend there. As a result, this "attraction" is a great way to start off your trip. He is only available to view on certain days of the week and he's away for about two months each year for "maintenance." Be sure to get there early as there will be a line...I think we waited about an hour...and the experience once you are in the building is just a few minutes. It's a bit strange seeing a "Uncle Ho's" embalmed body (especially knowing he wished to be cremated), but it is totally worth the effort - if nothing else, to be a part of this outing with the locals and to understand first hand their deep respect and reverence for him. Be sure to respect the rules when you are there: no cameras, no talking, no hands in pockets (keep them at your side)...just take it in and use it to kick off the rest of your stay in this interesting place.

This spectacle is not what Ho Chi Minh wanted. If you like seeing made up dead communist leaders, this site is not to be missed. Otherwise, this one looks much like the tombs and bodies of Mao and Lenin, and isn't worth the time to visit. The tomb is stark and there is nothing to see other than the body in a glass case. The nearby stilt house of Ho Chi Minh is slightly more interesting.

Solemn. The Communist presence was extremely evident, we were scrutinised by the Guards, not allowed to speak or even whisper, had to walk slowly with hands down by our sides - quite intimidating but interestin experience.

Interesting place. I went to see 'pickled Lenin' many years ago and I'm sure that Uncle Ho is a better experience. Queues are smaller and I'm sure you get closer to the 'main attraction'. Despite the signs, you can take small bags with you and if you have a camera you leave it at a special counter and collect it later. Changing of the guard happens on the hour so try and coincide your visit for that. And get there early as it closes at 11!
very decent and impressive. likedc the decent atmosfere and the cxlear dsplay of a great man,s life and contribution to Vietnam
Worthwhile visit. We walked from the centre (20mins) and well worth it, though arrived after 11 so didnt go in (didnt really appeal anyway!)

A must visit for anyone visiting Hanoi. Never experienced anything like it. No talking and hands to your side. If you don't the guards (every 5 meters) will tell you. Very communist architecture - stark and imposing. You really feel the respect and reverence that the Vietnamese people have for "Uncle Ho".

very interesting. Ho Chi Minh's body is exposed, you need to keep your arms along your body and stay quiet, show respect....anyway there are a lot of guards to remind the rules to you. No cameras, no phone. Ho chi Minh didn't want this Mausoleum, as he wanted his ashes to be spread in north, center and southern vietnam to symbolize reunification. Interesting.
Worth a look. I'm glad I made the effort to go. I was caught out the first day with the early closing of 11am.
A bit creepy but a worthwhile wait. arrive at 7.30am so that you are early in the queue
Centrally located. Just viewed from the outside as it was shut on New Year's day

Follow the trail.... So much fun for people watchers. This is, not unreasonably, a special place for the Vietnamese whether they are really venerating HCM or just enjoying a day out in all of their finery. As a result, queuing to get into the Mausoleum is three quarters of the fun. Take kids (assuming they're your own), prepare to be snapped on one million and one phones and do lots of snapping back!Leave the frivolity to one side once your in the building. You'll be ushered through pretty quickly but should still get a decent chance to gawk at the Big Man. Our kids wanted to check whether he was sleeping or dead. After the queuing experience outside it was hard to be sure.

Worth seeing. The line is long, but moves pretty quick. Stay alert since the guards will regularly ask you to stick to the rules. The actual visit to see Ho Chi Minh is pretty short once you get inside the mausoleum.

Watch out. An unusual experience - guards everywhere, a solomn place. Get there at 8am to avoid long queues. Can't take photos of certain things and can't walk in certain places. Be on your best behaviour.
A must in Hanoi. A must while in Hanoi. Some waiting should be expected, but it is worth it. Go see the surroundings (the house he lived in, etc) while you are there.

uncle ho!. uncle ho is the most interresting person in the history of new vietnams history! never visit a mausoleum arround the world! there a only a few choices to do that! and when you do this,you can feel a lot of love from the vietnamese people for this man! also interessting is the whole arrea arround the mausoleum with ho`s house and museum!

beware of security baggage check. keep your lose money in your pocket!security is pretty tight here and you will have to go through several bag checks before walking to the mausoleum. i had money taken from the first bag check. i was asked if i had a knife and then later if i had any food in my bag (AS she was going through it, so clearly she could see i had neither). this all seemed to take longer for me than for my friend. i went through the tour and later found all my money missing.
Careful with your belongings. Uncle Ho looks like wax. The most frustrating part for us was that security took away our drinks and when we returned to get them, they had misplaced them or drank them.

Must see to understand. Clearly portrays the rise and rise of Uncle Ho and if you are at all serious about understanding modern Vietnam you must go here and invest some serious time looking at and through the exhibits.

Weird but interesting. Ho Chi Minh rests inside a glass case in a purpose-built magnificent grey building in well-kept grounds. He seems very well preserved. Take an umbrella if it looks like rain as it's a long walk from where the bus stops.
Regimental. Free to see but a lot of security. Camera's not allowed in and only open from 9 to 11am. Thought I was in Madam Tussauds...

An interesting experience. We visited Uncle Ho (as known to the locals) mausoleum and enjoyed the experience. The mausoleum is only open in the morning from around 8:30-10:30am. Admission is free. We lined up for about 10 minutes before we went through a security check. Camera are not allowed in the mausoleum. There is a secure collection point for cameras and when you finish visiting the mausoleum you are able to collect it. Also only bring a small bag as you will also have to check your bag in as well.Once you reach the entrance to the mausoleum a number of guards are present reminding you of correct behavior - no sunglasses, hats, arms folded or talking. In a single line you walk up a number of flights of stairs to Uncle Ho's resting place. You are only in the room for a couple of minutes as the guards keep the line moving.We really enjoyed (I know that sounds strange) seeing the preservation of his body. Note that certain months of the year it is closed as the body is sent to Russia for embalming/preservation. Sorry I can't remember the months.Interesting for history lovers.
Amazing. Amazing! Looked like he was asleep!Good photo opportunities in the gardens

Some history about Ho Chi Minh the man. We visited to mausoleum to gain some insight into the life of the revered Ho Chi Minh. Unfortunately we could not view his body, as visits to that part of the mausoleum was closed on Mondays and Fridays (we went on a Friday).The Ho Chi Minh museum is housed in an impressive building, but mostly contained some history about the war struggles of the Vietnamese.

Interesting experience. May have to wait one and a half hours to see Ho Chi Minh - walk through is one minute in respectful silence. Our guide managed to get us to the front of the line, which made all the difference. An interesting experience.

Didnt think it would be my thing but glad I did it.. I didnt think that seeing the embalmed body of the legendary leader would be my thing but it has gone onto my list of things you must do in Hanoi.All very strict and you cannot take camers in.You must also as a female be covered on the shoulders or legs and if not they sell you a shawl to cover the exposed area for a mere $2US.It is well worth the effort to see and enjoy the reverence that they bestow on Ho Chi Min
Surreal. It was interesting to find out how you get treated by communists - forced into line and silence by armed guards

Dont step out of line!. Fascinating and atmospheric room where Ho Chi Minh's body lies. The guards make sure you are suitably dressed and behaved; no talking or hands in pockets, stay in line and keep moving.
Just a big mausoleum.... Nothing much else to see but if you are walking around Ha Noi, go and visit!

Interesting. Spent a couple of hours here as part of a day tour of Hanoi.Make sure that you get there as early as possible as the crowds really do start to gather after around 10am.The surrounding gardens are great and don't miss having a peak at HCM's collection of old cars including the Russian Zil.

Take the picture and make your way elsewhere. Make sure that you get there at the right time of day or you will miss the viewing. Also get yourself a disposable rain jacket because it is cold and wet in early January.
Historically important but quite ugly. Unless you intend to visit his house too, and look at the palace next door, would not be worth the detour.
Very well done. Was ery interesting to see how Ho Chi Minh lived when he could have lived in an elaborate home. he seemed to be a man of the people.

Not a must visit. It was not closed as mentioned in many guidebooks. Security is very tight and quite a hassle as you are not allowed to bring in anything and have to deposit your belongings at a counter.

Very Solemn. We only manage to look at the outside of the building, but lucky enough to walk through the lovely gardens(apparently rarely opens to the public). If you are a fanatic of bonsai, there are a number of excellent specimens here.

A sad tale.. Uncle Ho was displayed as if he was a sleeping wax figure. Amazing, what technology is capable of. It is sad that he wished to be cremated but his wishes were ignored and he is now on display at the Mausoleum.

Must see. This is a must see in Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh is the revered founder of modern Vietnam and not trip would be complete without visiting the mausoleum and the two nearby houses he actually lived in, which are nicer and more interesting.

Not convinced. This part of town is quite militant. It was a bit intimidating having to stand in a single file to go through airport-like security and then have guards stationed every 5 or so yards. Then I got randomly stopped, and one of the guards inspected my purse manually (after it was scanned through the machine). Once you enter the mausoleum, you cannot talk, you have to have your arms hanging to the sides (don't put them in your pockets, or a guard will walk up to you to correct you). At last you arrive in the main chamber and have about 30 seconds to look at the body. I looked, and looked again, then looked some more. Perhaps it's my inexperience with embalmed bodies, but I swear it looked like one of Madame Tussaud’s wax figurines. The other people on my tour agreed. It just looked so fake and waxy with a yellowish tint. The hair on the sides of his head looked like it was etched into his scalp rather than protrude like normal hair does. I came away unsatisfied.

Interesting. Ho Chi Minh was freshly back from his annual makeover in Russia, and looking great. This was a fascinating experience - a lot of standing in line, and a lot of very stern looking guards, but a fascinating glimpse of a revered leader and his people's ongoing devotion to him.
Very interesting. Well worth a visit. Good to learn a bit about this man. He was very humble. I now want to read a bit more about him. The whole museum is well kept and well presented

In and out in a flash... But worth it. Well worth the wait... its only open a few hours a day so go at the right time... the que's are really long but go down really fast, also was nicve to interact with the locals whilst waiting too, Well worth seeing him...
unbelievable but true. This is a must visit, although don't expect to have any picture memories of Ho Chi Minh. The site is very strict and the soldiers bustle you through the Mausoleum.

Worth the visit. We saw Ho Chi Minh! that thrilled us, it was worth the lines. They are not long, because the passing scenery and the military processes involved are unlike what we are use to. take the kids, its great, would go again.

Don't put your hands in your pockets!. The soldiers guarding Ho Chi Minh take their job very seriously - no talking, no hands in your pockets, and no hands behind your back. I find preserved bodies a little creepy, but enjoyed the historical buildings in the surrounding park.

The view at night is prettier. The lights at the mausoleum are turned on at night and is in red color. Good photo opportunity. Lots of people taking a walk in the square in front of the mausoleum.
If you go during the day, need to arrive early in the morning as the line can get long, even at 7:30am.

Visit the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum and the One Pillar Pagoda. A must stop to visit this area for the sake of history and to enjoy the wide open space and breeziness of the area. Photo opportunities and an interesting One Pillar Pagoda at the South end of the area.

Good, but.... This place is literally around the place from my house, so I know a lot about it. It is really like someone dropped you into Soviet Era Russia. There are armed guards with AK-47's, they have on their fancy uniforms and they promenade around Ba Dinh square. It is a great photo opportunity. BUT, here are some things to know before you go:1) Cameras are NOT allowed in the Mausoleum. You also must leave all bags at the entrance.2) You cannot stop while passing Uncle Ho, or else a guard will get angry with you.3) The Mausoleum, and the museum, is closed on Mondays and Fridays, so plan accordingly.4) Uncle Ho goes to Russia for his yearly touch-ups in late November or early December, so he may not be there.

Moving. It was very overwhelming, we actually went through behind a small group of decorated Soldiers, a lot of them were sobbing and wailing with their grief still. It was a bit confusing for us westerners and although we do respect all Asian traditions we did make some small mistakes and were reprimanded vociferously

Essential visit.. The building has a very serious and cold look to it, and the area is wonderfully maintained and impeccable. There are many soldiers nearby, which stand and guard the place. Inside, no pictures are allwed. I can walk past but cannot stand there. And so, the visit is like a very slow conveyor belt, which allows me to see the body.
Impressive site. I was prepared for how big the site is and how emotionally involved Vietnamese people still are with Ho Chi Minh. So glad we went there.

Large site dedicated to Ho Chi Minh. Obviously not as grandiose as Mao's mausoleum in China, but nevertheless worth visiting. Is the largest site dedicated to Ho Chi Minh in Vietnam. Sadly we did not get to see inside, but exterior is impressive.

arms by your side!. you have to go if you're in hanoi - calm, organised - and you must show respect! i was reprimanded by a guard for not being upright with arms by my side - covered arms of course! nice area to wander

Quite impressive. We never felt we were in a communist Vietnam until we saw the Mausoleum. Quite impressive with everyone expected to show the right amount of respect. We also saw the residence on the premises.

A must see experience but you will be underwhelmed. Would I go again? No but I'm glad I went the once because you get close to the cultural mindset of the North Vietnamese by visiting the resting place of the father of this lovely country. Don't expect to be allowed to linger as the stern faced guards will move you on with a less than friendly shove in the back and do respect their wish that you should be dressed appropriately.
Must See. The whole experience ,from the guards to the glass coffin was an incredible experience
Respectful. Well organised queue of people able to pay their respects

lit de parade for years. It was with mixed feelings I visited the great uncle Ho.He didn't mean anything to me in person but on the other hand it felt wrong not to go.Now i'm happy to have been there.The lines was short and it was more or less "easy" to figure out what to to next.After a hazel with bags and cameras, passing by soldiers we where lined up two and two to walk through the mausoleum. If you can, walk on the left side since it is easier to see from there.
Very neat and quite. Make sure you wear clothes that cover your knees.A very reverend resting place for uncle Ho, supported by commercial tourist shops? Is nothing sacred?
Ho Chi Minh mausoleum.. Very grand. The people of this country hold this man in very high regard. Go early as it gets very busy.

Interesting, but a little weird. Seeing ole Ho there like an ashen corpse. Apparently, the Vietnamese are experts at embalming and were called in to embalm Mao as well. Still its a little strange to see Ho there from 40 years ago. But obviously I was curious, since I saw Mao as well!

A must do in Hanoi. I think that the importance of Ho Chi Minh to modern Vietnam makes this a must see attraction. Although the queue looked pretty long, it only took about 15 or 20 minutes to get to see him. Once inside everything is very regimented - just go with the flow. After visiting here, you can go to his house which is just next door.

An interesting experience. We visited the mausoleum grounds and paid a visit to Ho Chi Minh himself while we were in Hanoi. It's an interesting experience on a couple of levels, but probably not one of the more memorable experiences from Vietnam. If you go inside the mausoleum you'll spend all of 20 seconds walking through the room where Ho Chi Minh rests, and he looks most similar to a sculpture from Madame Tussaud's. Ho Chi Minh is an important figure to the Vietnamese people, particularly in the northern part of the country, and visiting the mausoleum will get you as close to Vietnamese soldiers as you are likely to get during your visit. But overall I think the visit is much more meaningful for the locals than for the tourists.

Beautiful building but closed when we visited on 30/11/2011. LOGISTICSThe Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum Complex hold the glass sarcophagua containing the late Ho Chi Minh. I would recommend you do it as part of a larger walking tour of the city featuring Old quarter sites (Ngoc Son, Memorial house, Bach Ma, St Josephs cathedral) > History museum > Hao lo prison museum > Temple of literature > Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum Complex.REVIEWWhen we went there the mausoleum was closed (30/11/2011 or 1/12/2011 can't recall). Newer reviews suggest that it is now in fact, open. Regardless the grounds were beautiful and the building was quite decent for some photo's. The numerous soldiers around the grounds were well presented but DON'T step over that white line or they will yell at you! (fair enough too). Would recommend visiting this place to get a view of the great man himself. If he isn't there it is still worth a look for the building alone and the nearby HCM museum.CONCLUSIONWould recommend coming to this place for a view of the famous mausoleum complex building alone. Viewing HCM and seeing the numerous locals paying their respects would be a bonus.

Long wait, To see someone sleeping. Long pants and cover your shoulders other wise no entering, be prepaired to stand along time waiting, Not missing much if you gave this place a miss. I can see why Vietnam and it's people love Ho Chi Minh, He did so much for his country, This place just shows how much respect he is still given even after all these years.
Interesting history. Good to go to this area as the palace is here to, lots of government buildings preserved & beautifully gardens. I think a must if you are into the history of Vietnam.

A Must See. Uncle Ho is visible everywhere in Vietnam and is treated as a god. So, whilst looking at a decades old dead body might not be too appealing, it's a must do to see the reverence with which he is treated by the locals. We went mid-morning - after the huge queues which are there when it first opens have already dispersed. Consequently, walked straight in without waiting. When you enter the mausoleum, just make sure you don't walk with your hands behind your back - and no slouching!

listen. I only rated excellent because you get an awkward feeling on the way, and inside the mausoleum. It's like being guided by guards to your doom. Watching Ho chi minh only lasts a minute though... but i think it was pretty worth it
Not as exciting as Museum of History. The museum of military history covers way more that just Uncle Ho's museum...

Hard to rate. Seeing a deceased person in situ isn't something we seek out but observing the number of local people paying their respects and the reverence they have for this man and what he achieved for Vietnam is very special and a "must do".

VVIP in Vietnam. Thanks to my tour guide-- David again. He told us so many things about Ho Chi Minh and History of Vietnam. At first, I thought that listening to such story is just like having a history class which is boring and meaningless. However, I changed my mind after listening to David. From what David told me, I really gain a lot of knowledge. I knew that Uncle Ho was a very important person in all Vietnamese heart. David said -- Uncle Ho is never die in their heart. This made me feel so touched.

Imposing. Just about every guided tour of Hanoi will include a visit to Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. Indeed it seems almost mandatory that tourists will pay a visit. It doesn't take too long to work out just how highly the Vietnamese (well those in Hanoi at least) regard "Uncle Ho". The Mausoleum itself is a massive building of Russian design ocupying center stage in a large open traffic free space. The contrast between the cramped, crowded incredibly noisy Hanoi surrounds and this location couldn't be greater. Guards dressed in white uniforms, complete with white gloves, stand sentry at the entrance. We were sweating in shorts and thin tops; we wondered how they survived standing in the full sun in Hanoi's humidity for any length of time.Usually there are long queues of Vietnamese and tourists waiting to pay their respects to Ho Chi minh, but for our visit the Mausoleum was closed to visitors for renovations; apparently to the body of Ho Chi Minh, not the building.We did wonder what such a seemingly humble man would think of this memorial built in his honour and to house his body. It was Ho's wish that he be interred in three separate areas of north, central, and southern Vietnam upon his death. Instead the beauracracy chose to erect this monument.
A must do. Something you have to do, you cant come here and not view the most pivotal figure in the last century of south east asian history.

Its good to see the man who was the leading force of Vietnam. Vietnamese idolize him. My guide/friend told me: "To be able to see his body resting peacefully in the Mausoleum is the dream of everyone kids, teenagers and folks in Vietnam." Place is full of rules, hands not allowed to be tucked in pocket. Follow in line, Chattering not allowed. And the guards will be quick to correct that. Just follow the line and you'd be fine.

CREEPY. Considering how long he's been dead. Surprisingly fast moving line to see his impeccably embalmed head and hands. Did I mention creepy?Wonder how long they will "Uncle Ho" this way... Indefinitely??

Interesting.... Its not the most exciting thing to see but if you find yourself in Hanoi it probably ought to be on your list of things to do. We went completely by chance, it wasn't on our guide book and we were actually looking around for the Ho Chi Minh museum. Only open during limited times so make sure to check the hours.

Must See. Despite Uncle Ho's wishes he was embalmed and laid to rest for all the world to file past. While the mausoleum is impressive I found the grounds itself to be well worth the visit. There is so much more to see here including the French designed palace, lake filled with carp and Ho Chi Minhs residence in which nothing has changed since he passed away.

Not to be missed. Seeing the man who changed (and directed) the history of this part of the world was astonishing - he looks so small and frail. Don't be put off by the queues - they move fast. We were in the middle of hoards of school children eager to practise the contents of chapter one of their text book, and what seemed like half of the women in the People's Army, in town for a conference and eager to see Uncle Ho, and to have a few words with us as well. Not inside the Mausoleum, I hasten to add - there it is very solemn, rightly so. The grounds of the Presidential Palace, the House on Stilts etc were evry crowded, but worthwhile absolutely.
closed. Be aware that this tourist attraction clses on Monday Afternoons, and guess what day we went.......never mind, something for the next visit.
not much to see. Not really that impressive and really not much to see. I was bored inside of 5 minutes....

Well worth a visit. The Vietnamese are very proud of their history and Ho Chi Minh is held in the highest regard. The mausoleum is something of a surprise if you haven't read up first and come face to face with Ho Chi Minh himself 40 years after his death.

Amazing. Seeing Ho Chi Minh in the flesh is an amazing experience. Highly recommend going to a few museums about Vietnamese history first, as seeing the man after understanding what he means to the people of Vietnam is all the more moving. Get there early. The mausoleum closes at 11am, and the surrounding museums and palace close at 11:30am. Be aware also the the mausoleum is closed during October and November.

Vietnam's No.1 Idol. It is a little confusing to find the public entrance (you can see the Mausoleum but just can't quite seem to reach it!) and the queue can seem quite daunting once you arrive, but don't be put off as the queue moves very quickly. You can't take cameras in but you submit them to the security office and they magically appear at the other end.The Mausoleum is a big attraction for Vietnamese people and it is taken very seriously - no talking, no hats and reverential shuffling round the body once you're inside. But it is interesting to see the man whose name is everywhere in Vietnam, even if he does look a bit (dare I say it) like a waxwork...

A free glimpse of Vietname people's hero. Well, Uncle Ho is dead but more popular than ever. So if you have time to go there: DO IT! The long queues are nothing to worry about. Socialist organisation talent and steadily moving means less time to wait: it took me from the entrance of the complex to Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum 45min only! Consider the followong things.1. Uncle Ho is annually away for maintainance work (2 months, mostly NOV/DEC) --> but just re-check with some locals as this year he was back earlier2. At the entrance your bagse will be checked (maybe you have to leave them there!)3. Bring your camera (before you go into the mausoleum you have to hand in the camera as taking photos inside the mausoleum is forbidden) --> behind the mausoleum you will get your camera back as you might need it for the complex and the other buildings (I didnt know that and couldnt take any pics...my bad!)3. Dont wear sunglasses, hats, ultra short shorts or sleeveless shirts --> they might ask you to cover your "exposed body parts" :-)4. Its free...so go there and enjoy (as much as you can enjoy looking at dead people...)

Rules aplenty at this attraction. Don't speak too loudly, don't bring big bags, cover your arms and make sure you follow every direction! It was like being on a kindergarten trip, being sheparded through this site. And Uncle Ho himself looked like a wax dummy. However, it's one place you should go even if just to say you've been!

Not quite sure what to say about this. It is something you can do in almost every communist countries i think. Nothing much more interesting than reading and learning about Ho Chi Minh and his political campaign, ideology itself.

Certainly one to pop in and see. It is sort of the done thing to see Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum when you are in Hanoi. I come from the school of thought that sees it all as a bit ghoulish, but fortunately I was there in December when the body was away from re-embalming, so I got away with only viewing the waxwork replica.The Vietnamese are very formal about it, as you would expect for the last resting place of a dead national hero. Photography is strictly forbidden, although I did see a few people taking discrete shots with camera phones (although not inside the mausoleum itself - that would take a brave or stupid person). Goose stepping guards lend an air of surreal formality to the procession. And every so often they snap at someone who has not shown the proper respect (for example, by not removing a hat). I wouldn't want to overstate it, but it did provide something of a window into the way that the ruling party sees itself and its country.Overall, I think it is worth stopping in, not least because the setting is very picturesque and you can enjoy the calm and quiet. You can then go on to see the One Pillar Pagoda by the exit, and (if you like) pay to enter the Ho Chi Minh museum.
Lots to see. Was very interesting to see how humble Ho Chi Minh was and learn about the culture surrounding him.

Bit weird but worth seeing. My review would be average but my boyfriend thought this was brilliant so I have given a very good ranking to take account of the two views. Uncle Ho's body is not available for viewings on Fridays - if you do want to see him, get there early and be prepared to queue. Cover your shoulders, don't take cameras or luggage, be respectful. Okay, it is the long dead body of a communist leader - so a bit strange to see. He is surprisingly well preserved.The rest of the grounds include his old houses and the one pillar pagoda - all worth a visit.
Uncle Ho is most of the time out of town and somewhere in the USSR. Ho needs a lot of maintenance and so Ho's home is most of the year closed. Therefore it is an unattentable mauso

Interesting but Creepy. You don't get to stay and look for long... they move you along in a line (slience, hands at sides, etc. very strict) pretty quickly. If you've never seen a famous body embalmed like this, I'd say it's a must just because it is so interesting. But looking at a dead guy you've never met is rather creepy...

The respect still shown is amazing. Early morning queues are quite long because of organised tour groups and they seem to thin out later in the day if you have the flexibility in your itinerary. Young children may have difficulty in meeting expected behavioural standards and in viewing the embalmed body.The uniqueness of the viewing, sombre nature of the site, the close monitoring of visitor behaviour and the protocols of the honour guard made this a memorable experience - not enjoyable but a must do to understand the reverance that Uncle Ho still evokes.If you have time view the changing of the guard (about every 2 hours I think) and drive by at night to appreciate the lighting.
Boring for Europe people. If You arent interested history it'll be boring for you. Inside many future shows, we was enjoy about ti

Go Early in the Morning. My understanding is that the mausoleum is only open for a few hours each morning and closed on Mondays. I visited on a Saturday morning to find a long line of visitors. However, the line moved very quickly and soon I was inside looking at Ho, pale as a ghost. You must remove your hat and sunglasses before entering and walk up one flight of stairs. Very somber inside and respectfully done. DO NOT try to take a picture of any of the guards nearby.
A must see in Hanoi. Great place for a stroll, excellent picture opportunity.

Spectacular Edifice. Although the Vietnames are more likely to visit here - they go there in their throngs - it is worth a visit. i would suggest you go early before the locals arrive and if you want to see Ho Chi Minh resting do not go in the winter. He is sent to Russia every December, I think, for reembalming and doesn't return until the end of January. The grounds around the Mausoleum, including the One Pillar Pagoda, Nha Bac Ho, and the museum are all worth a visit. Don't miss the changing of the guard!

Historic site. The Mausoleum was not open for visit in the month of October, this we did not know before we went there. Still impressive to see the huge Mausoleum from the outside. The Guardians are also worth to see. The beautiful music in the outside very touching.

somewhat surreal...but worthwhile. A must if you are collecting sightings of dead bodies of communist leaders. Everybody is very respectful a as they file past. make sure you are decently covered up. Pay attention to the signs about photographs
iconic landmark. Despite not being open to visit at the time of year we visited it was still worth going. The one pillar pagoda is nearby.
not necessary. long queue and then the walk through was 30 seconds, very somber/dark and not much to see really
