A Soviet fantasy. We spent much longer here than we expected, we had a tour guide who explained more of what we were seeing, without that I suspect that the visit would not have been at all interesting.

Closed for two months of the highseason every year, really!!!?. I really wanted to go, but apparently,they close it all, including the grounds and gardens down, from late oct till early january, every year, for repairs and maintanence....
Historical and reverential. Saw Ho Chi Minh embalmed - not gruesome at all - the iconic symbol of of Vietnam's freedom and independence
surprisingly good. Worth a trip, amd also interesting to see the explanation of the "American war" from the vietnamese side - and also the role of the australian journalist Wilfred Burchett.
Okay place. We were not so impressed. If you have time, you may want to just briefly visit. It won't take time.

Most important man in Vietnam. You will see "Uncle Ho" on every piece of paper (well, plastic) money, most homes..............everywhere!
Ho Chi Minh is unbelievably well preserved and reverently displayed in the mausoleum.
learn more about Vietnam. very good to learn more about Vietnam and how Ho Chi Minh lead country!

a must do and see in Hanoi. Great visit, very interesting and impressive. You must come early as the queue can be very long however it moves quickly and it is worth it. Whilst there you must visit the musuem too.

Worthwhile experience. Best to be a part of an organized tour. Our tour guide took us to the front of the line so we got in quickly. He took our cameras and phones and met us after the tour. The viewing gives you a better sense of the man and his country.

Interesting Museum.. Lots of information about Ho Chi Minh and the various struggles of the vietnamese people. Need to go early in the morning or early in the afternoon as closes for lunch and early afternoon. Ho Chi Minh wasn't there he was on vacation in Russia!

Worth a visit!. We were lucky as the Mausoleum was opened when we arrived. Read from TA that some tourists didn't able to visit this place as it was closed for Uncle Ho's yearly maintenance. Anyway, this place was huge! There were so many people - tourists & locals waiting to pay their respect to Uncle Ho. We lined up for security checks -- no cameras, you need to deposit them before entering and getting them back afterwards. When you approach the Mausoleum, no talking, hands next to body, no glasses, no hats. Very strict dress code - make sure you cover yourself until knee length (the longer the better).Uncle Ho was resting in peace in the glass coffin. The Vietnamese grandma next to me was crying while paying her respect. We were very amazed to see him in person. He has contributed a lot to the country.This place worth a visit for paying respect to Uncle Ho.
must see. was well worth visting give you the veiw of the local people

OK for a walk by - Was Closed. Was closed; annual maintenance in November & December, we could just see the guards standing there, the guide said inside is interesting. The landscaping outside was very good for photos, our guide almost gave the biography of Ho Chi Minh in about 20 minutes; we understood the pain he had taken to pull the country from where it was in the dumps. OK for a 30 minute walk by and some clicks when it is closed.

Early morning splendour. Ho Chi Minhs' mausoleum was definately worth the visit. We were told to be prepared for a long wait in line to see "The Man". Luckily we arrived quite late at about 10.30am and just got in. Drop off your handbags and cameras (no, you can't take anything into the mausoleum) and after a quick screening you will be directed to the mausoleum. Even waiting in line is an experience as there are military soldiers dressed to the nines in their fabulous white suits all along the pathsways. The square in front of the mausoleum is huge and must be packed on special days. The entry is as grand as the building and full of reverence and awe. As you shuffle quickly up some stairs and into the main area where Ho Chi Minh lies instate, you can't help but be touched by the way he looks.....just asleep, but what a fine looking man. It is cool, dark and surreal and must be your first stop in Hanoi to understand the country and the reverence which Ho Chi Minh commands even in death. After you are shuffled out, race back to get your cameras and bags etc and take a couple of hours to wander at will, around the beautiful gardens and grounds and take in the cars, stilt house, ponds, drink stands and all the little shops to buy some goodies to take home at reasonable prices.
Understand why Vietnam loves Ho Chi Minh. Great to get an understanding of who Ho Chi Minh was and why he is loved by his country.

Impressive Building. Absolutely worth the visit even if it's just to get a photo. A very impressive communist style building. During my visit it was closed for maintenence of the body and building. But still worth the visit.

Must do. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is really a must go as he is regarded very much as a father of Vietnam. It is appropriate to go and pay your respects to Ho Chi Minh ( the body is maintained visible in the cool environment) and learn about history of Vietnam's struggle for freedom and independence. Beautifully maintained grounds and preserved "home" of Ho Chi Minh .
Hardly worth the effort. No-one is allowed in the Mausoleum so you can only stand in front of the building.Disappointing place.

Hard to see Ho Chi Minh. We had to stand in line for an hour to go into the main hall where the body laid. The room was dark and it was around 16 ft. from the visitors to the body so it was very hard to see his face. Waited for half an hour for a 2 minutes walking in and out, not very worthy then.

Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. The setting that Ho Chi Minhhas been laid to rest in is certainly a fitting tribute to a man that was instrumental in the freeing of his people. . the guards the grounds all very official and formal affair.
Important Stop. This is an important stop in Hanoi. It's worthwhile. Go early in the morning so you don't have to stand in a long line.
We when it was shut. because we wanted to see the building and not Uncle Ho. Worth a visit to see the guards in action

Museum gives propaganda a contemporary twist. What do you get when you combine contemporary art with propaganda? Come to the museum and see for yourself. The mausoleum itself was closed during my visit.

Impressive to see this monument to a real hero.. A good understanding of the 'American' war (known to most as the Viet Nam war) helps to put the significance of this monument in perspective. Worth a visit if only to share the citizens' respect for Uncle Ho
Huge communist building. Looks a bit similar to the Mausoleum in Moscow on the Red Square. The visits were not authorized when I visited so I had to stay on the lane in front of it.
it's not worth. hey, it's not worth, i have stayed about 2 hours in a line, to see almost nothing...don't go there, go meandering in Old Quarter!

Impressive and stately. This is where Vietnam's much respected leader is buried. Much like Lenin's tomb in Red Square, Moscow, this is a must see whilst in Hanoi. Don't cross over the white dotted line or the soldiers will blow their whistle!
gone to be refreshed. The entire site is well worth a taxi ride to explore. Ho Chi Minh was closed but the buildings, museum, parade grounds etc was spectacular.
Closed when we visited. Not a lot to see - but something you can mention when you get back home. Near the presidential palace, so you might as well walk past that as well.

Very quiet and respect. This is worth place to visit when traveling in Hanoi. Ho Chi Minh is the first president of Vietnam. Before you go to visit, remember to wear the long shirt and trouser. Turn off telephone, sunglasses also hat before move inside and you will be collected the camera before enter. Do not talk loudly while you are inside, very quiet and respect.

Crazy Lines, Crazy Experience. Lets just say I went into culture shock in Hanoi.. I had a hard time with the masses of people and scooters. So I can honestly say I didn't enjoy this city much. This museum was RAMMED with people. The people that worked there had a big job on their hands to organize us all and move us around. I followed the rest of the people while being yelled at and felt kinda dazed. Seeing Ho Chi Min preserved for all time was kinda neat. He kinda looks like a wax doll. He had a big role in the history of Vietnam. I had to opt out for several things because I felt too claustrophobic. There were people pushing on all sides of me. I never did see Ho Chi Min's House.. I couldn't make myself go thru all the people. Even waiting to buy a Popsicle I was pushed aside by people. which I found out is very common here if you leave space for someone to push past you in line then you are going to have people walk past you.

Formidable. We were unable to enter because of maintenance issues but the Mausoleum complex is formidable, especially with the guards. What a tribute to the found of modern Vietnam! We drove by at night and it is beautifully lit. Our guide said Ho Chi Minh's last will and testatment asked that he be cremated and taken to three different parts of Vietnam. But the government ignored this and has preserved his body for the people of Vietnam to venerate him.
try it. closed the day we went but very impressive building.

Watch Out for the Line Jumpers!. Our taxi dropped us off on the complete opposite side of where the line ended, so we had quite a hike in the scorching July sun. I've seen seen a line quite like it. I've lived in Taiwan for 8 years and am used to people ignoring queues, but the Vietnamese have made an art out of it. After about an hour in line, we were finally ushered into the sombre and eerie mausoleum. Visitors are quickly ushered around Uncle Ho's glass sarcophagus, and the entire experience is a bit surreal. Even more surreal was the bombardment of Western influence that you don't really see anywhere else in Vietnam, upon exiting the tomb when you visit the rest of the grounds...Micky Mouse hats, Tropicana drinks, and tacky merchandise. It was a little shocking given Ho Chi Minh's disdain for America.

A vital part of Vietnamese history. You may have to queue for some time, but be patient and it's a good oportunity for people watching. There are very strict rules about how you stand - hands by your side, no talking, etc but this all adds to the feeling of reverence. Uncle Ho lies peacefully and in very good condition. If you want to experience Vietnam, this visit is a MUST.You then have the opportunity to see where he lived - very modestly - unlike Vietnam's present rulers, I suspect.

You see Ho Chi Minh!. Which is pretty spooky. He's remarkably well preserved but he was pretty old so it's not a great site. Just really funny shuffling through the mausoleum with reverent locals and stern guards (don't do anything silly inside or in the square outside).

Ho - Hum. This attraction has historical value but the actual monument was uninteresting.There are vendors that supply food and water around the grounds. Taxis are readily available too.If there is no line you will be done in less than 10 minutes.

Seeing the body lying permanently in state is a curiosity. I saw a long queue of mainly Japanese travelers waiting to go inside the granite mausoleum in Ba Dinh Square to see the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh.Yes, there he lies on a four-poster bed with a guard at each post. His body down in a cut-out section of floor so that visitors can walk around and look down on his uniformed body. His mausoleum is fashioned after Lenin's in Moscow. Once a year, he is shipped off to Russia for renovation... and new makeup, I would presume. Then he is back in place for visitors. He was there in all his regalia while I visited so, naturally I had to see this site for myself.After seeing the body, I then had to see where Ho lived in a modest home and then the lovely place built for him. Always on a pond stocked with fish since he loved fishing. Seeing his revered body only intrigued me to learn more about this man so I researched more when I got home. Fascinating figure. This was really different that seeing mummies or relics of popes in other countries. Definitely one side of Hanoi that is worth a visit. Standing in that long queue is something I would not have done without the help of our guide, Han, who got the six of us past the line and inside easily. If you have that priviledge, go in the mausoleum. Traveling time is so precious, standing in long lines does take up too much time when I could be seeing other sites of interest. I was lucky.If there was a fee, I didn't know, as I was part of a very tiny group and it was included. I can't answer the question below about this attraction.

Not many mausoleums in the world- a must visit. Do not miss this! The long queue is an excellent cross examination of the Vietnamise society. Enterteinment provided. Do not worry about handing over your camera, the system is reliable.

Amazing. Amazing and surreal experience. Not only the viewing of Ho Chi Minh but also seeing how the people of Vietnam's react to viewing him. as well as the experience of getting in line and following the rules- 2 by 2, no talking, hands on your side and walk quickly. Definitely a top choice to see in Hanoi

Incredibly disorganised and confusing!. I travelled with my sister on a whirlwind trip of Vietnam for 2 weeks. During our stay in Hanoi we decided to visit the Mausoleum, a place where Vietnamese travel to pay homage to Ho CHi Minh himself. My suggestion is that if they don't want tourists then don't open it up to them!It was complete disarray! After taking half an hour to find the entrance, we couldn't find any signs where to pay to enter etc. We circled a few times only to got back to the start where we found a security booth which had been unmanned previously. We walked in to ask what to do and were told to get our bags scanned. We were then told we were idiots for not putting our water bottles in the bin...sorry didnt see the sign on this??!! We were then shoved out the door and pointed left. We wandered along until we found a covered walkway and followed along until a place where we deposited our camera. Sure I was never seeing that again I actually did get it back. We then sauntered along (Vietnamese dont do anything fast lol!) until we filed through the mausoleum for 20 seconds of looking at HCM and then bam ya out, collect camera and then pay to go look at his house etc. I have a great appreciation of other country's history and culture but this was not worth the hassle!

A must if you are in Hanoi.. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is really a must go as he is regarded very much as a father of Vietnam. It is appropriate to go and pay your respects to Ho Chi Minh ( the body is maintained visible in the cool environment) and learn about history of Vietnam's struggle for freedom and independence. Beutifully mainteined grounds and preserved "home" of Ho Chi MInh. Thanks, Pentti

Wasn't expecting much but was blown away. All I can really say about the mausoleum is that if you are in Hanoi take the time to visit and spend a few dollars for a tour guide. We paid $US25 for a tour guide for a whole day who spoke fairly fluent English and glad we did as we got a lot more information for all the attractions at the Ho Chi Minh Complex. I was expecting the Mausoleum to be fairly ordinary, something to tick off the list but I was blown away by how much respect the people have for this man, and rightly so I guess - he was certainly a modest leader for the people. To see Ho Chi Minh embalmed, perfectly preserved was, I can't describe it, the place just had this unusual vibe to it. The strict guards, the silence, the line shuffling through - I'm glad I experienced it and would actually go back again if I ever return to Hanoi.

Have to see it!. 40 minutes from first joint line to leaving the mausoleum. Men must wear a shirt and long pants. Women must cover their shoulders and wear clothing that covers their knees. No cameras, no bags, no hats, no sun glasses, no clothing draped over shoulder, no hands in pockets, no crossed arms, no water bottles, no talking, no slow walking. You view the body for about a minute as you file past. The left of the 2 x 2 line is the best side for viewing. It is an experience, especially the local folk overtaking in the line to get 1 place in front.

Important to the locals and worth a visit. We went on a really hot day in July and were impressed at the fairly efficient system they run here! Cameras and bags are surrended on entrance (free storage) and we got it all back at the end safely although the camera collection point was a bit of a scramble. Bit eerie inside the mausoleum but worth seeing for all the pomp that surrounds it (armed guards in smart white uniform). Recommended as you'll probably be in he area at some point and its free and quick despite what can look like long queues (they shuffle you through quickly).

Interesting. We went her with the tour and I have to admit it was freezing, and wet in early Feb. So I would take at least one winter coat for Hanoi. We arrived very early and the coaches and cars were already filling the car parks. You join in the line, no bags or camera's are allowed so give them to your guide, plenty of security around. The resting place of Chairman Mao is as the description depicts a Mausoleum. You are ushered in and walk around the embalmed body of Mao and out again. You can then venture around, lots of other things to see the gardens and where he lived.

One of things that you must do while you are in Hanoi. Visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum can be a little bit hard when in the hot weather (specially in July), the queues to visit this place that holds the embalmed remains of Ho Chi Minh can get quite long and sometimes looks like be interminable but still worth seeing. Be aware of the time if opens only in the morning from 8 to 11am and from tuesday to thursday. As consider the holiest sites in Vietnam they have a dress code: it is not allowed to wear shorts and sleeveless shirts (as the weather in this time of the year is too hot a scarf is a good option to cover your body). Cameras is not allowed they collect all cameras before you enter the mausoleum (so if you have a massive one just live it in your hotel or in the luggage storage place). While you are inside, don't talk loudly and take off your sunglasses and cap. Admission into the Mausoleum is free.

Somewhat surreal; but interesting. If you are pushed for time, then don't bother. If you have time on your hands, then why not.Opening times: only in the mornings until 11am, and not open on Mon and Fri.The queue is very long, but moves quite swiftly; I went at peak time (saturday 10h30), and the queue was at least a kilometre long, but it only took 30-40 minutes to get inside.You'll only get about a minute in there to file past the man himself who appears very content, but looks like he' made of chalk.

Unusual attraction. We waited in an extremely long queue and my husband kept questioning why we were there? Well after waiting in line for 45 minutes we got to an official guide who than pulled me aside rudely and told me my dress was too short and I could not go in. Anyway after pulling me aside she basically ignored me and told my husband he had to leave his bottle of water at the collection area. He did get a numbered tag so he could get it again after seeing Ho Chi Minh. Meanwhile I asked the guide what I had to do to be able to get in so she told me to buy a shawl from the shop and wrap it around my waist. This cost about $6. My husband returned and asked me where I had gotten the shawl from I told him I had bought it. He started to laugh and told me that they had them for free up in the collection area and you just returned them on leaving. Ripped Off! Seeing Ho Chi Minh was an experience I guess but would I recommend it? Probably not especially if you are restricted by time. There are better things to see and do in Hanoi.

Mostly for Vietnamese. This is a notable place, but mainly for Vietnamese people. If you're nearby you can check it, but try early in the morning (the Mausoleum opens at 7.30 am). In the building itself you can only see Ho Chi Minh, nothing other. Be prepared for a strict "system": at first, you have to hand down your luggages, then you have to stand in two lines, you have to move exactly on the path marked, then finally, you have to hand down your camera as well (no photos allowed in the building).All Vietnamese people are touched by the sight of the great man, so dress appropriately and behave very modest.The only thing that is definitely worth is to see local peopel touched by the event that they can see Uncle Ho. You can see on the faces that most of them is very grateful.

Visit This Site For the Experience. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was built on the spot where Ho Chi Minh (not his real name but one of his many aliases), declared Vietnamese independence. The Vietnamese people love Ho Chi Minh but not enough to honour his wishes that he be cremated and his ashes scattered over the countryside of Vietnam. Viewing Ho Chi Minh is a rigidly controlled experience. Guards line people up two by two and people are not allowed to stop walking when viewing Ho Chi Minh. One man walked in clasping his hands in front of him and he was immediately told to put his hands by his side. People musn't touch each other while walking through the mausoleum. No talking of course, not even whispering. Nothing can be carried into the mausoleum. The line of people walk into the mausoleum, along one wall and then across the front of the Mausoleum. Turning their head to the left they can then see the emblamed Ho. There is a light that illuminates Ho. Behind Ho, the wall looks to be dark brown marble. On one half of the wall is a big yellow star and on the other half of the wall is a hammer and sickle, all done in marble. It looks very dignified. Be careful of opening hours - sometimes they are restricted. Also be aware that Vietnam sends Ho Chi Minh to Russia somewhere around September - November each year for re-embalming. So he isn't there during those months. It is worth visiting the mausoleum just to experience the rigid conditions of entry as the viewing of Ho is extremely short.

The body of main leader of Vietnam. I visited the place on Sunday. There was extremely long queue. I was not really sure what to see inside, but I epxected it must a very good experience if so many people are willing to queue. It took about 40 min to get inside. Note that the only thing you can see inside is the body of Ho Chi Minh. You can not stop while watching him, as the queue is long, so you walk in the line, you can spend about 1 min inside, walking around him. If you are a Vietnam enthusiast, then you must see it. I had mixed feelings after the visit. Also note that is it not allowed to take your camera inside. It must be left outside, and I only got a keychain with a number, to get back my camera at the exit. I have a DSLR, I was a little afraid of it. Finally there was no any problem.

Solemn. Actually pretty quiet tour in contrast to the busy, honking traffic on the streets of Hanoi.It was pretty solemn, strict atmosphere going through the mausoleum. I have more understanding and respect for Ho Chi Minh now that I've gone through this attraction.

WOW............you get to see the real Uncle Ho.. Its free and thousands of people want to see Uncle Ho's dead body. Lots of security and they will confiscate all food and water bottles. You can buy water/food after you exit. Also they will make you check your camera in at the security desk, but you get it back at the end of the tour. I was really worried that I wouldnt get my camera with all my pics from the last two weeks on it back. But I was happy to see my camera waiting for me at the security desk after exiting Uncle Ho's tomb. Absolutly no talking or horse play while viewing his body. Overall we were glad to visit Uncle Ho. You can take as many pics of you want after you exit, just dont walk on the grass...hahahaha.
Hallowed place for a big hero. We were informed a lots about Ho Chi Minh – the hero and ex- president of Vietnam. The environment in here was so hallowed and quite.

The first time in my life. We had time to visit Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum on sunday tour,the guide told me many things about president Ho Chi Minh.He was the great people in our soul and Vietnammese people too.Very beautiful place in the center of Hanoi,we met many people from other countries.

An amazing and moving experience. This was really an experience. Make sure your knees and shoulders are covered or you will need to buy a shawl from one of the many vendors! It was something I did not get to do last time as his body was in Russia for maintenance, I think this happens every year.Highly recommended.

go, it doesn't take long. I was put off by the long queues but they do move quickly. It looks like there are different entrances for Vietnamese and foreigners, foreigners getting the advantage!It was welcomingly cool and very heavily guarded. It’s rather strange to see a dead body. You are only in there for a minute but it stays with you.Changing of the guard was an added bonus.The lawn in front of the mausoleum says don’t walk on the grass but it actually means don’t walk anywhere near it. Walk around or the guards will whistle at you.Dress respectfully, cover knees and shoulders. Keep quiet. Large bags will needed to be handed in. I was okay with a purse and a guide book but I had to get rid of my water bottleOpen between 8-10:30am

I like it!. When I came here I can see how the Vietnamese worship Hochiminh! In the early morning they were waiting for seeing Uncle Ho! It is so interesting to see that among busy Hanoi, there was a most peaceful place!

An absolute must!. This is a must-see when in Hanoi. Don't be put off by the kilometre long queue of people waiting to go in. It moves very quickly. You will need to hand in any large bags and cameras etc. before entering, but you get them back after coming out of the mausoleum. Words cannot really describe this part of the city - just go see it for yourself!

Please be aware that from 1/04 the.... Please be aware that from 1/04 the opening times change from 8-11am to 7.30-10.30am. Please don't get caught out with the change in summer opening times - like we were yesterday!

Kind of creepy but worth it. Before you get into the compound, we had to go through an airport-like screening (why I couldn't bring water in, I don't know). All cameras and other recording devices had to be checked in to a kiosk where they would hold it until you came out of the mausoleum (no pictures there, duh). We were told to form a line and then ushered in. You had to walk in a slow but steady pace to the building, up some stairs, then around Ho Chi Minh's body, then down stairs and out of the building. During this whole trip, you are watched by guards every five feet or so. Also in the complex are the Presidential home of Ho Chi Minh as well as his garage and the home he lived in after his time in office.
Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. 30 seconds only for seeing the God-father of Vietnamese people.Visitors must be respectful : dress neatly, walk solemnly and do not talk. No cameras here.

Must visiting place. Come here to know more about UNCLE HO and see how the Vietnamese people love him. The Ho Chi Minh Complex included Ho Chi Minh Museum, Ho Chi Minh Mausolem and one pillar pagoda. The entrance fees around 2 USD for all.

An Interesting Experience!. We went to visit Uncle Ho on 30/12/2009. The guidebooks say it shuts at 11am so we got there by taxi at 9:30am. Admission is free (at the moment). There were not big queues although we were told to follow the passageway and "pause" several times (for what I'm not sure). The patriotic singer was a hoot and the pomp and ceremony were remarkable. He's certainly a God to the nation and he's still treated like one (even though it goes against the communist principles). No talking, no laughing, no cameras (these were taken off us and returned afterwards - no problem) arms by the sides, long trousers, two-by-two! We saw him for thirty seconds but the organisation was not to be missed.Outside we took a few photos of the place and then, for 15,000D, toured around the Presidential Palace (outside only), Uncle Ho's house and garage (three cars?? in a communist state??) and the bamboo house. Don't forget the one-column pagoda too.The whole thing took about 90 minutes.

The place must come to see. I have heard manythings about uncle Ho. Now I can see uncle Ho by my eye . One man that people Vietnam respect as a god. The father of Vietnamese . If you come here it open from Monday to Friday . And I think it's a place people should come.

Interesting Experience. Mausoleum, the place where the body of President Ho Chi Minh.Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is open five days a week, on Tuesday morning, Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday.At present gate money be free of charge and guest visat must comply with requirements such as trim, do not bring the camera and keep order in the royal tomb. But u need to queue very long.

Interesting and definitely worth seeing!. We visited in November and found it a really interesting experience. Everything was very well organised, and we didn't have to wait at all. There are guards all over the complex who direct you around - we were quite amused by being made to march two by two across the complex. Guards also surround Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body as you walk slowly round in silence. We enjoyed walking round the whole site, which is very well maintained. A very interesting (if slightly strange!) way to spend a few hours - would definitely recommend it.

very cool, must see in Hanoi. Its so far the only mausoleum i've visited in my life and it was a very interesting experience. I had to buy a long dress to wear because of the strict dress code of covered knees and shoulders (but its a good excuse to buy clothes! hehe) Our cameras and phones were taken while we were visiting and later returned to us as we left. Theres no talking allowed in the room where he lies and his body is guarded by guards with big guns. All in all it was a good eductional experience and a definite must see while you're there! *I only wish I didn't have to wake up so early as its only open from 8am to 11am
Interesting stuff. Fascinating to see how Ho Chi Minh has been preserved. This was packed out as well and you must keep quiet and not fold your arms.

Interesting. The walk around the mausoleum etc was very interesting. We may have been lucky, but there wasn't a long wait at all, and despite the heat of the day, it was quite pleasant walking around the area. We had been told by several Vietnamese people in Hanoi that we would have to ensure we were wearing long sleeves and trousers, but there were many people there in shorts and no-one stopped them from entering (although everyone was wearing long sleeved tops), so am not sure if the dress code has been adjusted to deal with the heat!! All in all, a very interesting experience.

Long wait, momentary wonder. Although it was interesting to see Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body on display in a glass coffin, we weren't particularly moved by the experience. We waited in a "line" for about 45 minutes for just about a minute's worth of time walking around the coffin in the mausoleum. While we didn't observe any particularly interesting reactions from visiting Vietnamese (they made up the majority of visitors), it was interesting to experience to the very strict way in which the site is run. Aside from the strict dress and behavior codes, the guards are constantly whistling at people to correct their infringements (e.g., walking in prohibited territory). The signage is terrible, so try to observe others to learn the appropriate rules for navigating the property.You must check-in all personal belongings, but beware -- we were sold unnecessary brochures by an employee who behaved as though they were mandatory. The mausoleum is free, so no money needs to be exchanged unless you want to visit the museum or other attractions on the property. It was only 10,000 dong for two, but the principle remains -- in Hanoi, a scam lingers around every corner, so always be on your toes.

Don't miss seeing this place in Hanoi. We visited this place our first day in Hanoi. The officials running the place are very efficient and the line moved rapidly. Some people were corrected for talking while others were asked to remove their hats or take their hands out of their pockets. I couldn't help but think how frail the man looked but then I thought that he looked that way when he was alive. You really have to give him credit for engineering the independence of his country. He was instrumental in the defeat of not only the Americans and French but the Japanese. This small country also fought the Chinese and Cambodians. Whether you like Uncle Ho or not, one really has to respect his accomplishments.

Feel the Communism in the air. Visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum was not an attraction that my husband and I had planned to see. Our guide took there anyway...what an eye opening experience. We felt the Communism in the air from the moment we were in line. They take your bags, phones, cameras (our guide took ours so we didn't have to give them to the guards). You walk in silence in this long line of people. Inside it is dark and so cold and silent... no talking allowed, and the guards take that serious! There seem to be guards everywhere. It is kind of creepy to go in and see Uncle Ho laying there, but is very interesting to see the guards, the VIetnamese people, and their reverence for this man. I would highly recommend going to there just because I have never seen or felt anything like that before in my life! Afterwards, our guide met up with us again and talked to us about Uncle Ho and the history. Very interesting to get a Vietnamese point of view!

Check the opening hours before you go. It is advisable that you do a quick check (with reliable sources) on the opening hours! None of the reviews i read so far (either on this or other sites) mentioned the opening hours so i thought it would be good to point this out.I was told by the hotel this place opens only on Friday - Sundays, from 7.30am to 10.30am. However, my tour guide told me it closes at 12 noon. Because of the last-min. notification of its short opening hours, I had to give the Mausoleum a skip as I could not reschedule it in my plans. Just a point to note if you are planning to visit. It was a 'so-near-yet-so-far' situation for me! :(

Must-see sight in Hanoi. It is the #1 must-do thing in Hanoi. It is free. The other reviews/guides give you the gist -- you line up in 2 lines, usually with about 2000 schoolkids and other curious tourists. You walk steady from the back of the line through the room where they have Ho. No pictures or they might shoot you. You get about 10 seconds in the room with Ho. Quite an experience. Really is neat to see the reactions of the native Vietnamese, especially all of the young kids (I believe that class trips are very common).

Uncle Ho. Uncle Ho is a revered figure in Vietnam and his mausoleum is over the top. They line you up two at a time and in total silence you are allowed to walk by and view him lying in state. While it may seem goolish, it is a fascinating experience and take a moment to look at the faces of the Vietnamese that are in line with you.
